I know that she does not have much longer in this world and I want to make her final days as comfortable as possible and possibly extend her time with us.I received the Joint and Hip supplements from Primal in return for testing, evaluation and review.  Based on my experience so far, it has been very positive.  My dog likes them, which is a huge plus.  I would not use them if I had to shove them down her throat.  The ingredients are all natural and from my research, are also effective.  I am enthusiastic and optimistic about this new course of treatment.  After all, nothing is too good for our Princess!

The Organic Retinol Body Lotion from True is a nice thick cream that is non greasy and fully absorbs into the skin.  Retinol is an anti-aging ingredient which helps to preserve your skin cells.  I have only been using this for a few weeks and havent noticed younger looking skin, but it is a good moisturizer.  I use it on my hands, arms, elbows and also on my legs when I get out of the shower.  Because of the rich thick texture, a little seems to go a long way.  The bottle is small for body lotion.  If I were to use it generously all over my body, it would be gone in no time and at this price, I use it primarily on my problem areas and in small amounts.  It has a clean fresh light scent.  I also like having the cream in a pump dispenser so you do not contaminate the supply as compared to a jar into which you are dipping your fingers.  Also on the plus side is the fact that it is organic, cruelty free and made in the USA at an FDA certified facility.I received the body lotion from True for testing, evaluation and review.  Based on my experience with the product and my observations,  I would have to use this lotion for long term to notice any younger looking skin.  The bottle that I received for testing was not large enough to make that determination.  However, I did find it to be a quality moisturizer which kept my skin hydrated, therefore when used daily can definitely make a difference. So based on that, I would recommend this product.

The womens crew neck sweater from Knit & Love is very cute and comfortable.  I ordered a medium and it fits snugly.  I personally prefer a loose fitting sweater but this sweater looks good either buttoned or unbuttoned.  I have long arms and this sweater does not fall short.  It comes all the way down, covering my wrist.  What makes this sweater unique is the detail in the buttons.  These are toggle buttons which are a golden metallic and really a nice accent.  It is like having built in jewelry.  The fabric, 65%viscose 35%nylon seems to pick up fuzz and animal fur very easily which is common for most black knitted garments.  Although it says that you can machine wash, I would probably wash it by hand and lay flat to dry to keep its shape and size.I got the sweater from Knit & Love for testing and evaluation.  Based on my personal experience I would recommend it because it is very cute with the unique buttons and styling.  It is comfortable and with the classic color and styling, goes with almost any outfit for any occasion.  My recommendation is to purchase a size larger than you normally would wear.  I ordered a medium and have a 34 bust.  It did fit but felt snug.  It is described in the listing accurately and priced fairly.

The Sporty Shatterproof Sunglasses from Ponosoon are a hot item in our household.  Everyone that sees them wants them.  They are contoured to block out peripheral light.  The colorful lenses look like an aroura of changing hues and provide 100% UVA and UVB protection.  The Flexible Polycarbonate Frame is composite white and green, giving them a sporty look.  They provide excellent protection from sun glare, dirt, dust and bugs when cycling, driving or jogging.The quality of the Ponosoon Sports Sunglasses can be seen in the detail and workmanship.  The shape of the glasses and lenses are so universal that they look great on any shape face, male or female.  Included with the shades is a durable hard case, foam lined, a heavy duty zipper closure, and belt clip.  Also, as an added bonus, a cloth drawstring carrying bag and microfiber cleaning cloth.I received the Ponosoon Sports Sunglasses for testing, evaluation and review.  Based on my personal experience with them, I would definitely recommend them.  They are moderately priced for a pair of sunglasses of this caliper, look great and are very functional.

You dont have to be an acne prone teenager to benefit from Insta-Naturals Skin clearing toner.  I use toner every time I wash my face.  Toner penetrates the pores and lifts out any residue left behind, whether it is makeup and oil or soap residue.  These are the things that clog pores and cause inflammation and blemishes.  I have found this toner to be a good consistency, it smells nice and not medicinal and leaves my skin feeling refreshed.  The vitamin C, Hyaluronic acid, retinol and other moisturizers are an added bonus.The Insta-Natural toner along with the skin clearing serum work together to preserve the youthful appearance of skin.  Scientifically, I think that this is a great combination of skin enhancing natural ingredients.  Personally, I just like the way they smell and make my skin feel clean and soft.I received the Insta-Natural products for testing, evaluation and review.  Base on my personal experience with the toner, I would recommend it and purchase it again.  The toner itself is gentle, I have not experienced any irritation from using it and have seen a marked improvement in skin texture.  It tends to minimize my pore size.  The 4 oz bottle is average size for this type of product and should last about 8 weeks with daily use.

The paper lantern is a very cute Halloween decoration.  It is made of paper and plastic so it is not weather durable but is great for a starry night or for indoors.  There is a small light-bulb at the bottom which lights up the lantern.  It takes 2AA batteries which are not included and comes with a handy hook for hanging.  The bottom is flat so it can also be used as a table decoration.  Included is a form that when inserted in the pumpkin helps it to keep its shape.I received this add on for testing and evaluation.  Based on my experience with the product, it is very cute.  Not intended to last a long time but serves the purpose.

The joint support from Zenwise has all the natural minerals and ingredients to support your joint health.  As we get older, the cartilage in our joint break down and eventually disappears.  I know because it has happened to me.  I had started taking Glucosamine and Chondroitin for several years ago, on and off.  It does help when taken regularly.Not all supplements are created equal.  These particular tablets also have MSM and hyaluronic acid.  They also have the one of the highest potencies on the market.  The pills are quite large as are other brands, so this is normal for this type of supplement.  Suggested serving size is 3 tablets which I like to spread it out taking one at each meal.  I find that when taking them all at once, it tends to irritate my stomach which makes gives me heartburn and a bloated feeling, but that happens to me with any brand of Glucosamine supplements.  There are 180 tablets in the bottle, so taking three per day, they should last about 60 days.  Zenwise Joint Care is made in the USA under FDA regulations and has earned the GMP seal so you can be sure that it is a safe, quality product.I received the Joint Care supplements to test, evaluate and review.  My opinion, based on my experience is that it is a good product.  It helps to maintain the cartilage in your joint, lubricates them and protects them from degeneration.  I recommend that if you are an athlete who is hard on your joints or over 40 that you start to take a joint care supplement.

I hadnt heard of this supplement before I was approached to try it out so I wanted to know what it was and what it did, so researched the supplement.  One website said it supported cardiac health, another the immune system.  I have also read that ashwagandha helps to improve sleep, reduce brain fog and fatigue, aid in weight loss, and decrease symptoms of menopause. These are big claims for this root derivative which is related to the tomato and potato plant.The capsules are made of a gelatin and filled with ashwagandha root powder.  I have taken one every morning with my breakfast, for a few weeks.  They are easy to swallow.  I have not noticed any significant difference, however in all fairness I dont think I have been taking the ashwagandha supplements long enough to be able to give an accurate assessment.  I have type II diabetes so I was hoping that the anti-inflammatory effects of the supplement would help and maybe it will, however it is too soon to tell.  There have been no side effects or repeating aftertaste.I was given the supplements from Zenwise Labs for testing, evaluation and unbiased review.  Based on my experience, I have not seen any significant changes in my health, neither good nor bad.  Several weeks is not long enough to notice.  I will continue to take them until the 120 capsules are finished.  If there is anything to report, I will post an update.  As it stands, I am giving 4 stars because the product is made in the USA in is quality assured under the GMP seal, is all natural, packaged with a tamper resistant seal, reasonably priced for the quantity of capsules and I have experienced no side effects from the supplement;  and maybe, just maybe a little more focus.

Oh my gosh; popping eyes!  I had these when I was a kid and they were so much fun.  With Halloween just around the corner, I had to have a pair.  I can't wait to see the kids faces when I open the door with my bowl of candy and my eyes pop out.  These are always a lot of fun at Halloween parties and as take home favors.  They are inexpensive fun!  A little small for the adult face but doable.I got these popping eyes add onfrom Sixkiss, for testing, evaluation and unbiased review.  In my opinion, they are good junk.  Not made to last long but creates fun in the moment and sometimes that is priceless.

The Dead Sea Magnesium Oil is different than my current brand of liquid magnesium.  The one I currently use is water based and the Dead Sea Magnesium is of course oil.  I find that I prefer the Dead Sea Oil Magnesium.  It is odorless, colorless and can be massaged into the skin.  The Dead Sea oil also softens and conditions the skin as well as delivering the Magnesium.  The instructions tell you to leave it on for about 10-20 minutes and then rinse it off, however I found that I can leave it since I did not display any sensitivity issues.  It is fully absorbed by my skin and does not leave a greasy residue, just softness.There are several reasons why I take this mineral.  A friend had recommended taking magnesium supplements when I told them about leg cramps and ringing in my ears.  At that time, I took tablets which take longer to absorb.  After some time, I did notice that it helped to minimize the frequency of those two annoyances.  I have since learned that it is also good for stress and to promote relaxation and sleep.  That explains why I fall asleep soon after my head hits the pillow.  My husband always remarks about it and quite frankly I think he is envious.I received the Dead Sea Magnesium Oil from Magnum Solace for testing, evaluation an unbiased review.  In my opinion, this is a high quality, potent product that is beneficial to your well-being and safe to use.  It is manufactured here in the USA under strict government standards, so you can be sure you are getting what is on the label.  I definitely would recommend it and will be purchasing it again for myself.

The craft tags from Marrywindix are made well and cut precisely.  I got two neat stacks of 50 in each bundle for a total of 100 tags, along with jute twine for fastening.  The tags themselves feel to be about 80lb cardstock material with a natural unbleached brown color.  The shape and color is reminiscent of old fashioned country labeling.  The punch out holes are large enough to easily thread the twine through without difficulty and can be cut to the desired length.  These will be great for Mason jar gifts of mix kits, candy or jams.  I always make a few of these for teachers, neighbors, and friends.  You can label the contents on one side and write instructions on the other.I am also using them to attach to spare keys.  We have keys galore and sometimes I look at them and dont remember what they unlock.  This is a great way to label the spares so that when you need one, you dont have to go crazy trying each one until you find the right one!  The tags are quite useful in so many ways, I am glad to have them.I was given the tags to test, evaluate and review.  In my opinion, the tags are a good craft quality, a nice size, easy to assemble, handy to have and priced right.

These Pink Flamingo floating coasters are so darn cute!  When I saw these, I had to have them for my next pool party.  Unfortunately, here in the Northeast, summer is over and fall is here so the pool party will have to wait and so will I.  This is a six pack of mini inflatables.  When deflated, they dont take up much space, flat as a pancake.  When inflated, they come alive.  They have blue enchanting eyes and are sure to charm you as much as they charmed me.They are constructed of PVC Vinyl and have a valve on the side.  Plug it quick because the air can escape.  Once plugged the plug stays tight.  The coaster is the perfect size for a can of soda or beer, or even a cocktail glass.  These graceful creatures add color and conversation to your poolside.I received these cuties for testing, evaluation and unbiased review.  In my opinion, you cant go wrong with these decorative floating coasters.

The running belt from Metrics products, isnt just for runners.  This is a great little hands free pouch that is very handy to have on outings as well as sports.  Many times you are sightseeing, at an amusement park, a fair and you dont want to lug around a heavy pocketbook but you need a few essentials like money, credit card, tickets and your cell phone of course!.  The running belt from Metrics is the perfect size for those essentials.  It locks into place around your waist and is easily accessible.  This is great for bicycle riding and horseback riding as well.The material is a soft and comfortable synthetic.  It is hand washable and the pockets are waterproof which protects your belongings from the elements.  The belt itself is adjustable and has a lot of stretch to the bands so it will fit virtually any size waist.  The unisex design can be worn by men or women.  There is a lot of nice detail on this running belt.  There are two zippers in contrasting color, very neatly sewn into quilted pouch.  There is even a button cutout hole on the back to anchor it in place if you wish.  It is constructed and designed quite well.  Stitching is neat with no loose threads.I received the running belt from Metrics for testing, evaluation and unbiased review.  It is my opinion that this appears to be a high quality, comfortable, practical and attractive running belt. It lays flat and can even be worn under clothing.  Since I got it, I have been using it several times a week and find it very useful.  It is reasonably price and I would definitely recommend it.

The Pearl necklace from Bamoer is a stunning statement piece.  The large pearl in the center of the setting is the focal point.  The teardrop design has a double row of cubic zirconia which catch the light and add sparkle to the piece.  It is 18K white gold plated which makes it a little better then costume jewelry.  It feels smooth with no rough edges and is very attractive.  The clasp is lobster claw style, making it easy to put on yourself.  I am not sure what the link type of the chain would be called but I can tell you that the links are very different than most chains and seems to be strong.  There is an extender so that the pendant can be adjusted at various lengths to accommodate your outfit, whether it be a collared shirt, turtleneck or plunging neckline.  Pearls are very classic and go with just about anything and for any occasion.I received the product for evaluation and review.  My conclusion is that the actual necklace is very nice.  I like it a lot and will probably wear it often.  It goes with casual or dressy.  It is easy to put on and take off.  The only suggestion I have for improvement is to present it in a nice box.  If this piece were in a black velvet box, it would be an exquisite gift.

I have tried my greatest to find a diecast B-47 around the world, a metal toy about 1/125th scale, and failed. The B-47, which is more the star of this film than Jimmy Stewart, was America's first true jet bomber in the Cold War and the most beautiful jet ever made. It was a short-lived stopgap between the postwar B-36 and the still in service B-52, the most enduring weapon of the Cold War or just about any other period in history.In the film, Jimmy Stewart gets recalled from pro baseball with the St. Louis Cardinals to air duty and has some angst with his wife over it. She wants him home, not out fighting communisits. He did enough of that during the war, she says. By contrast, the Air Force loves him and thinks he's great, especially his boss, Frank Lovejoy. They say he's a fine pilot with magnificent leadership qualities. Stewart has some internal dissension over this and determines which way he'll go with it -- to his wife's chagrin. Later action in the film makes that decision for him, however.There, I talked about the movie. Now back to the B-47. It's smoky and steamy takeoffs are a thing of real beauty and are exploited to the maximum in Strategic Air Command. Those takeoffs always reminds me of life in the 1950s living next to the railroad tracks when the steam engines would roar through our little town 100 MPH carrying 60 boxcars. They'd spew so much steam and soot in the air the clothes hanging on my mom's outdoor clothesline would have to washed again!For those on you that have never seen this movie or the B-47, it was a lovely, silver, swept-wing combat bomber that used outriggers under the engines to steady it -- since it only had two large sets of wheels under the front and back. This added much to the beauty and line of the aircraft.Back to the movie -- this is hardly Jimmy Stewart's greatest film; it probably isn't among his 25 greatest films. I thought the action and plot somewhat stilted and deliberate, actually. Not much ever happens until the final scene when there's action on a plane and Stewart does his best to make you act as worried as he seems to be. But it's faux danger, we all know that. Otherwise, there is nothing to distinguish this from any other mediocre peacetime Cold War-era film made that decade.It is, however, the best way ever to see lots of B-47s and see them in action. To me, that is the enduring feature of Strategic Air Command. Now if only someone somewhere would make a diecast toy of a B-47!

This review is of the Berg concerto, which I downloaded. I neither purchased nor listened to the Beethoven.As it regards Alban Berg's violin concerto written "to the memory of an angel" -- the 18-year-old Manon Gropius, daughter of Alma Mahler (the composer's widow) and Walter Gropius -- German violinist Antje Weithaas may set a new performance standard for the piece. Far from the raging desolation most violinists project when recording the concerto, Weithaas, abetted similarly by the Stavanger (Norway) Symphony Orchestra conducted by music director Steven Sloane, creates a threnody that expresses profound sadness.Compared to the commissioned version with Louis Krasner on the fiddle and Anton Webern conducting, this rendition is quieter and more contemplative than theirs or just about any other. Weithaas takes a bit more than 25 minutes to complete the concerto compared to 29 minutes for Krasner. Most versions recorded now are in the 25-27 minute range.Special mention should be given to Weithaas' bowing and the phrasing of the orchestra under its leader. The woodwind and brass figures that support the orchestral strings follow more incisively and logically here than in other recordings I know, including those from Ivry Gitlis, Anne-Sophie Mutter and Pinchas Zukerman. Under the Weithaas-Sloane collaboration, these don't sound like 12 tone rows; they sound like traditional melodies from the romantic Berg.There is nearly a complete absence of the random noise that results from many performances when volume equals passion. There is plenty of ardor here, but gently stated -- even during the raucous opening of the second movement. Where most performances project an angry sorrow, this is clearly calculated to result in an utterance of deep sadness that fulfills Berg's mourning.In this vein, the performance is much more like Mahler's songs on the death of children, Kindertotenlieder, and his expression of a child's  version of heaven in his Symphony No 4. Like those predecessors, there is a lack of volume, bow pressure and other musical affects usually associated with Berg's concerto. The pacing adds to this affect, especially in the ultra-quiet closing section where Weithaas's line is almost threadbare.Not buying the CD I have no notes, biographical information or documentation on the recording date(s) or place(s). The CAVI-MUSIC website said it was released Nov. 15, 2013 and Weithaas's bio on the Karsten Witt Music Management webpage suggests she has recorded and played a number of other "modern" concertos including those by Jrg Widmann (born 1973,) Shostakovich, Prokofiev, Ligeti, Gubaidulina, Korngold, Hartmann and Schoeck.The downloaded sound is 5 X 5 X 5 with everything fairly close and a natural placement of the violin in the orchestra. Like most modern recordings, you can hear a lot more than you probably would hear in the concert hall, especially in the orchestra, which sounds like a chamber ensemble.

Napoleon is famously credited with saying history is lies agreed upon, a truism proved every new century through historians' mirrors over the last 100 years' history. This book, like other re-histories that have cropped up in the last 20 years, proves again that Napoleon, while probably not correct is his assessment, was on the right track.In The Untold History of the United States, their mate to the Showtime television series, filmmaker Oliver Stone and collaborator Peter Kuzniak have re-told American history since World War II to show America a far less generous and wonderful country than you may have learned in your grade school, high school or college history courses. The authors use actual historical events to show an America at odds with much of the world, supporting tyrannies, and using its military might to exploit lesser nations' wealth and promote American self-interest. This isn't the only such history that exists these days.Being born 1950, going through school in the 1950s and 1960s and college in the 1970s, I was taught a very different history about the United States than the one you'd learn if you took a class in community college today. Probably the greatest reinterpretation is the America of the 19th century. In my day, we were taught America was a self-evident leader whose manifest destiny was to lead the world through promoting democracy and goodwill post World War II, and that its 19th century growth in the West set the pace for this leadership. American exceptionalism, it came to be known.Today, you'd learn 19th century America did indeed thrive, but not through goodwill or democracy -- that its growth was constucted on a foundation of genocide. The European-Americans that settled the country put in place laws and pogroms that decimated native Americans (we used to call them Indians) while kidnapping, enslaving and carrying out holocaust against African-Americans brought to America in chains. The Civil War of 1961-65 was supposed to level the ground but historians now teach it took another century to even begin to right these immoralities.There are parallels in 20th century and one American history taught today skewers ideas once set in stone. In my youth -- after World War II and during the Cold War -- we learned the Second World War ended because the United States dropped two atomic bombs on Japan, who then immediately surrendered. While not demonstrated as directly in this book as in Five Myths About Nuclear Weapons, there is today a counter history promoted in some circles.That history is Japan surrendered in World War II not because of the A-bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, but because the Soviet Union had entered the war, was storming through Manchuria, and threatening to invade and occupy Japan. Historians have produced letters from Japanese political and military leaders demonstrating such fear of this that the country gave up and acceded to Allied demands for unconditional surrender. They didn't care about the A-bombs, this theory carries, because all their cities had been destroyed. So what is two more bombs were dropped and Truman promised more?History isn't just rewritten in America, either. The Austrian composer Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, one of the greatest creative minds in classical music history, died 1791 from what for years was thought to be scarlett fever. Today, withouth the benefit of gene discovery or an autopsy, his death is attributed to everything from smallpox, rheumatic fever, medical malpractice, strep throat and  hypochondria.The point is history is fluid, not static, and it is re-realized, reinterpreted and rewritten at least every 100 years based on new evidence and ideas. Stone's and Kuzniak's book is a reinterpretation of postwar history that arrives at a viewpoint not considered earlier in American times. Is everything they write correct? Possibly not. But it's clear all the historical events they describe actually happened even though the context they discuss the events in is probably different than you may have heard before.As to the more damning notions that the authors contend America was on the "wrong" side of World War II and the Cold War,  these are polemic arguments. What cannot be contested is that America did not always support democracy and goodwill, especially during the Cold War, and that much of the motivation for its foreign policy after World War II through the fall of the Berlin Wall was based in self-interest and fantasy.Its clear at least some of America's Cold War foreign policy was directed to save the American way of life. That is the only possible reason America through the CIA supported the fascist coup of an elected communist government in Chile circa 1973 and supported the Shah of Iran, whose policies were anything but democratic. There was no democracy in Vietnam for America to support during its long war there. And carrying out foreign policy against the idea that multinational communism was a threat to the United States and its way of life was never proven correct in Korea, Vietnam or any other conflict we entered from 1946-89.With respect to Ronald Reagan, Margaret Thatcher and everyone else that got some credit for ending the Cold War, communism in Europe failed on its own because it wasn't economically viable. With someone like Gorbachev coming to power, communism would eventually have failed had we never sent any troops to Vietnam, Korea or Germany. The proof of this is communism still exists in the world today in a few small nations but our monolithic enemy is today thought to be Muslim-based terrorism, the reason we have entered the new Crusades.And while I believe we were on the "right" side of World War II, it's clear we carried out war crimes in doing so. In the film of his life The Fog Of War, World War II political strategist and Vietnam-era Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara admitted American leadership would have been tried for war crimes had the Allies lost the war.McNamara said Tokyo was one of 67 Japanese cities, mostly made of wood buildings, that American forces fire-bombed with incendiaries late in the war for the purpose of inciting terror and forcing the Japanese to surrender in order to save the estimated million lives that would have been lost by invading Japan. The Americans and British also carried out terror bombings on hundreds of thousands of noncombatants in Germany during the war, most famously in Dresden, a city with no war production or military purpose.But war is hell, we all know that, and lots of innocents pay the price for war. I think this is one of the fundamental messages of this book: that lots of innocents paid the price for American imperialism after the war, and not always to support democracy, God and/or goodwill. A lot of times it was to support U.S. Steel, AT&T and our other multinational corporations around the world. The authors clearly believe in heroes and failures in American history and it isn't hard to figure out whom they are. Perhaps their greatest hero is former Commerce Secretary and vice-president Henry Wallace, whom most historians believe a "Red" in the White House. These guys think Wallace, had he been the 1948 candidate fro president instead of Truman, would have led the world in a very different direction than the Cold War ethos practiced by the U.S.A. from 1946-89.The book has other curiosities you'll find along the way that conflict with other histories you may know of postwar America. One things this book has that most other do not is exceptional readability. In its best pages, the authors move through a morass of tales swiftly and easily, rarely bogging down the reader even thought they mix metaphors and commingle historical stories readily and often. The book reads fast, to put it briefly, and it is usually very entertaining even if you are infuriated by some of what it says.So this book is one history among many, perhaps more modern than some, as valid as most and far more entertaining that just about any other. When approached in this light, I think this book is valuable, especially as a foil to the highly entertaining series of programs carried in its name on Showtime last autumn even though the book has flaws a-plenty. There's probably something in it you haven't read before, as well, making it worth your time and money.

Coming in show in the choral symphony sweepstakes behind Beethoven's 9th and Mahler's Resurrection, Mendelssohn's Lobgesang is oddity cantata wrapped inside a symphony. Unlike its predecessor and descendent, the hymn of praise exhibits Mendelssohn's enduring faith in God while Beethoven's is a secular exclamation and Mahler's expresses his hope there is a heavenly landing place.There have been a goodly number of Lobgesangs over the years that, while many were highly thought of in some circles, were sunk by a characteristic or two. Most often, a weak tenor sinks the ship -- as it did in a couple of Naxos versions. Other times, quicksilver turns the proceedings to syrup. Elsewhere, there doesn't seem to be much understanding of what the music is about by famous conductors or those of less imagination. More often, a certain blandness carries the day.Only a handful have been consistently successful from start to finish, in my view. Foremost among them is Dohnanyi whose fine 1970s concoction is  exquisitely sung by a wonderful team of soloists with unsentimental. dramatic leadership that gets to the heart of Mendelssohn's counterpoint. Another exceptional version with many of the same qualities is from the young Claus Peter Flor, one of the best Mendelssohn interpreters extant.What I like about this one is Christoph Spering's mercurial leadership mated to the beautiful singing of sopranos Soile Isokoski and Mechthild Bach and tenor Frieder Lang, all of whom translate the messages of Christian love, faith and redemption gloriously. Eschewing any idea of Victorian excess, Spering gets through the whole thing in about 65 minutes, enough time to say everything effecitvely while allowing the singers plenty of leash in their solos. This is a minute or two faster than Dohnanyi and quite a bit more rapid than the more centrist Abbado.The dispirited downside to Spering's version is it seems no longer available. Old liners disusted by period performance probably enjoy that but to others it is an inconsolable loss in a field for years dominated by bland, unfocused musicianship in one of Mendelssohn's least-recorded major choral works.

Made four decades back via bastardizing a Japanese novel, this film treatment is more Henry Miller and Oedipus than Eastern culture.While the novel focused on the sailor's vision of his future at sea and the way it was compromised by his affiar with the widow, this capitalized on 1970s sexuality zeitgiest in film exploiting the relationship between the sailor and widow against the Oedipal foil of the son who, abetted by a Lord Of the Flies-type club of upper class school boys, exacts revenge on the sailor in the end.The film is full of sexual symbols, none greater than the boys' meeting place. It won't shock anyone in 2014 except those that have read the book and fall asleep waiting for something to happen in the first hour of the movie. If you make it to the second hour, the sexuality and boys' perversions is far greater than what the book had to offer.

Clearly inspired by Charles Whitman's 1966 shooting rampage at the University of Texas, "Targets" is an ultra-realistic view of mental instability, murder and human interaction that resulted in a bunch of people being killed and other lives ruined. It's also a first and last of sorts, being Peter Bogdanovich's first feature film, one of later-director Samuel Fuller's first screenplays, and actor Boris Karloff's last film.The plot of "Targets" revolves around the protagonist's mild-mannered demeaner and home life, which suddenly turns sour when he first shoots his mother, then his wife -- repeating the exact sequence of Whitman's real-world killings in Texas. The plot then varies from what really happened as the shootings move to other places than a university tower building. The main subplot is actor Karloff's career winding down and an upcoming personal appearance at a drive-in movie that happens to coincide with the exciting final scene of the film, where shooter, targets and Karloff all interact.This is a fine and disturbing film to watch, made all the more so by its mimic of real-life events from just a year earlier -- and produced on a cheapie budget. Bogdanovich casts the whole thing in ultra-realism; there is no Hollywood gloss, no stilted script, no fakes in the actors or prima donnas outside of Karloff playing himself. The locations in the low-budget thriller are also real-world.The black and white print is a little gritty but it hardly detracts from your involvement. This is an outstanding, hard to watch drama and a notch in the bedpost for everyone involved, first, last or othewise.

I agree completely with this review:While this is a nice, thoroughly enjoyable performance of the symphony, there are many currently available recordings that are as good or better. Gandolfi's reading is direct and tautly rhythmic in the two last movements, but the orchestra lacks the sheen and finesse that makes the first movement so magical in recordings like those of Beecham, Wand, and others. Still, I don't think anyone would find this reading disappointing.The performance of the Mass is, however, a winner. Here, the small forces, the unpretentious sound of the chorus, and the fresh-voiced soloists (unnamed on the recording) suggest the choir loft more than the recording studio. The simplicity of approach works beautifully in this music, especially in the Benedictus where the three solo voices combined with the small orchestra produce an intimacy more often found in chamber music than in settings of the Mass. The sound of the recording is very good and the notes are informative.Richard Burke for Fanfare magazine 1995

Organist and conductor Martin Haselbrock has turned himself into a Franz Liszt specialist, recording the composer's symphonic poems and Dante symphony and, here, a half-dozen of his Hungarian Rhapsodies. Liszt wrote the rhapsodies for solo piano and/or piano duet in the middle 1800s, then returned to the form again later in the century. He also orchestrated them though some of these were orchestrated by Franz Doppler. Liszt wrote the rhapsodies based on native Hungarian music and dances played by gypsy bands.Haselbrock, whose recordings of the tone poems lack fire and imagination, does a better job here though these are hardly incendiary. His is a concert music approach that focuses on structure, melody and counterpoint in opposition to the highest spirits, similar to those who take ballet music and make it into concert (instead of dance) music. You hear this uniformly through the six rhapsodies in the collection including the famous Nos. 1 in F minor and 2 in D minor.When I listen to these I am more aware of the composer's symphonic poems than dance music. The opening notes of rhapsody No. 1 remind me more of the opening phrase of Hunnenschlact -- albeit with a lot less emotion -- than any dance music I know. At the other end of the recording, rhapsody No. 6 opens as more a stroll in the park than unrefined gypsy dance -- and never really becomes the latter even in the final rollicking moments. In comparison to the likes of Georg Solti, I'd say that's true for the entire collection.While the musicmaking isn't as good as elsewhere, what makes this album worthy and collectible is Haselbrock's connection to his period band, the Vienna Academy Orchestra. This is the same group with which he recorded the symphonic poems only this time they show more life. Many have commented on the sound of the orchestra with its small bore brass, gut strings and period woodwinds. I heard some of this the first time I played the record but on repreated listening find the period instruments neither a distraction nor an improvement over recordings using modern instruments.One thing for sure: Haselbrock has kept the vulgarity level way down in his band compared to Hungarians like Solti and/or the young Zubin Mehta who played it to the hilt in recordings of Liszt's orchestral music.This, then, is a civilized, even elegant, version of Liszt's dances (rhapsodies, sorry) that is more like an afternoon pops concert than a visit to a gypsy camp. If is subtly yet effectively delivered, highly musical and well-played. Some people would call this an "English" enunciation of Hungarian music where the failure to be gentlemanly is always avoided. If that's what you're after you'll enjoy this recording. Be advised, however, this is hardly a gypsy reading that lacks fire and doesn't linger in the memory like some others.CPO provides 24 pages of multilingual essays on the music and players, notes and documentation on the 2012 recordings including a complete list of the orchestral players, photos and bios of the band and conductor. This is part of the "Sound of Weimar" series of Liszt works from Haselbrock and his group that started on the Naxos and NCA (New Classical Adventures) labels. Now is has moved to full-priced CPO in what is probably the best of these adventures, which to this point have in my opinion been well-executed but unexciting and largely forgettable.Haselbrock the organist has also released a collection of Liszt's organ music that may or may not still be available new.

Though once recommended by the dearly departed Penguin Guide, in this age, when magnificent performances of Mendelssohn's Elijah are everywhere, this recording with nondescript Willard White in the lead role and Richard Hickox conducting without passion or direction is, at best, a mediocrity.How this recording ever got any plaudits is a wonder to me. For whatever reason, they should have died when Bryn Terfel's characterization of Elijah came along in Paul Daniel's 1990-something recording, for everyone knew then what the biblcial prophet was supposed to sound like. White, whose singing is consistently characterized by notes starting lower than their value, has a strong bass voice but is hardly the essence of Elijah.While Terfel stole the show as Elijah, Daniel's often unimaginative leadership and his cast of less than stellar singers left the door open for the old standby with some of the greatest singers in history -- the Fruhbeck De Burgos recording on EMI with Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau in the title role backed up by the likes of Janet Baker, Nicolai Gedda and Gwyneth Jones, a recording with singers for the ages.Even with the ascent of the new Elijah under Paul McCreesh with Simon Keenlyside as Elijah -- in a recording that tries to recreate the English oratorio tradition of having singers in the hundreds perform -- Fruebeck De Burgos still has the best sung version whether or not you like Fish Dish in the leading role. For period performance mavens, the choice probably falls to Terfel and Daniel. In this forest of new and old recorded Elijahs, this one is definitely in the shade.

The classical music industry, which some say is in death throes, sometimes confuses me. While it sets out to record the umpteenth version of Beethoven and Mahler symphonies, it doesn't seem interested in bringing back tried and true classics like Eugene Ormandy's LP of Sibelius tone poems, never quite equaled elsewhere in the industry.Eugene Ormandy, the long-time director of the Philadelphia Orchestra who maintainted the "Philadelphia sound" started in the 1930s by Leopold Stokowski, made these recordings in 1953 amd 1955. The contents are Jean Sibelius's En Saga, Op.9, Pohjola's Daughter, Op.49, Oceanides, Op.73 and Tapiola, Op.112, some of the composer's most well-known and best-loved Scandinavian tone poems.Ormandy's work in those days was characterized by passion and tempo relationships that were just right, far more so than his later recordings of Sibelius that became more measured, less passionate and much slower. These readings have an urgency and appeal people that only know the conductor from his stereo days won't understand.Columbia, now Sony, never released this LP on CD though both American Haydn House and France-based Pristine Classical will burn a CD for you on demand. Both recreate the music from analog sources, not from original tapes. Either is acceptable if you can't find the LP which has exemplary sound and depth. Sibelius lovers that don't know this music should remedy that immeidately here or elsewhere.

I have to side with the people that love this machine for it's the best washing machine we've owned in our 35-year-old household. It does a great job on clothes, especially whites using the white cycle; they've never looked better. The accompanying dryer is just as good.We've owned our machine 3 years, bought it new, and have never had service on it. It does 4-5 loads of laundry a week, usually on two different days, and has never failed. Since we converted from the old mechanically-driven washer whose tub was full of water to this electronic model that uses only a few gallons of water, there was a learning curve. We found you cannot overload this washer; indeed it works best with small loads. You have to follow the instructions in the accompanying booklet and do what it tells you to do. You have to leave the "eye" open at the bottom of the tank if you want the laundry to come out well.While I can understand some of the people here than complain about breakdowns -- we also bought a Whirlpool refrigerator the same time we bought this washer and dryer and had to have it repaired once -- I cannot understand the people who say this is a piece of junk and/or doesn't work well. Our experience is exactly the opposite. This machine not only works well, it works 10 times better than any we've ever owned -- providing you use the correct detergent, fabric softerner and bleach and use the appropriate amounts and providing you adhere to the instructions Whirlpool gives in the manual.One other thing: we did a major home improvement three years ago and switched all our major appliances to water- and electricity-saving models at the time. Primarily because of this washer, our water bill went down about 25 percent in a period where our municipality raised our rates. Our electrical bill also declined every year since we redid our appliances. We did not add a new furnace at the time (we live in Michigan where a furnace is a necessity) and in fact own a 50-year-old furnace that is about as inefficient as possible.So here's a BIG vote of confidence for this machine that works wonderfully in our household. If you are having trouble getting laundry clean with yours, I'd recommend you read your owner's manual and follow the instructions, then try again. And DON'T OVERLOAD the thing since that could force water into the electronics inside the cylinder. This machine works best with small loads, so cut your loads in half if you are washing a lot of clothers all the time.

Anton Bruckner's Mass No. 2 is the lead item here, a piece he penned in 1866 and revised later. The German contributer to the abruckner.com website said the revision was done 1882 while the notes to the original LP of this performance pegged the revision in 1885. In either case, the revision tightened the drama and changed the number of measures in some movements, remaking the opening Kyrie more unifrom with other sections. In this recording, the Kyrie runs 7:05 while the following movements are between 5 minutes and 9:05.Hans Gillesberger's 1964 conception is both dramatic and reverant. His opening Kyrie ranks with any I know for clarity of voicing and austere, religious conviction. It gets better after that, too. The whole thing glows from beginning to end and is sung magnificently by the then-named Vienna Kammerchor (chamber choir) assisted by the woodwinds and brass of the so-named Vienna State Opera Orchestra. There's always been a contention these were pickup bands used to make recordings in Vienna. Others say the orchestra is a shortened version of Viennese players including many who play in the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra.In any case, the woodwind & brass band (there are no strings in this mass) isn't the issue; the singing is the issue and, on that mark, this is an outstanding recording of a Bruckner masterpiece with reverence in the beginnig, elation closing the central Benedictus section. The recording is ideally clear, allowing you to clearly hear all four parts of the chorus (there are no soloists) recorded seemingly somewhat ahead of the band. The notes talk about Bruckner's life and a little about the mass, telling you some of what I've said here. The recording includes three shorter motets -- Ave Maria, Locus iste and Os justi, all written in similar voicing and style to the mass.As a latent Brucknerite and choral singer, I love for this music, would go to heaven to perform it, and have collected many versions of it over the years. This one, for me, ranks with the best I know including Frieder Bernius' similar program and the exceptionally reverential version from Eugen Jochum that was once available individually on a DG long-playing record but today can be had via download or in Jochum's collection of all three Bruckner masses.

I am 5-11, 195 pounds and generally wear a size large or extra large top for biking or triathlons. I have bought a lot of these things online at Amazon and other places and often been disappointed by the fit, which is ridiculously small. One of my last failed efforts was with Blue Seventy Men's TX2000 Tri Singlet from 2012 that was one sale cheap because it was a year old. The fit on this was so small it was almost humorous. I'm unsure if a child could wear a "men's" large!By contrast, the Sugoi Men's Sonic Tri Tank fits me -- almost. While I normally wear a size large, I had to buy the XXL size to do it but at least I can get it on my body. The coverage is good thouhg there's some rise at the midriff when I am exercising; however, the fabric is almost unbelievably soft and comfortable, it stretches wonderfully in every direction, and the thing is airy, light and just a great product for doing anything rigorous outdoors in warm (or hot or not so warm) weather. This is one of the more pleasing products of its type I've purchased in the past year.But take care to ensure you get one at least one size, and maybe two sizes, larger than you typically wear. I note the one I've bought that were apparently tailored for shurnken people are usually made in China. This one was made in Canada, perhaps among the reasons it fits a North American body.

"Damsels In Distress" appears to be a contemporary film about modern college life on the surface but underneath lurks a throwback screwball comedy to an era when films like this starred Cary Grant and were directed by Howard Hawks. The plot of this thinly-disguised reverb revolves around four college women running a suicide prevention center and using dancing as therapy for those so lovelorn or torn by conflict they may want to end it all. To satisfay modern sensibilities, it spends some time in their socialization with men. However, the dancing subplot (wait until you see the end!) should give anyone under age 50 a clue this film isn't about modern times but a refelction of the not-so-near past.If that's not enough, the film eschews all the trappings of modern college films. There are no sex scenes, no topless women, no bimbos, few idiotic young men living out of a beer bottle, almost no predictable scenes, and just about none of the cliches that usually surround college age film in the new century (or the latter part of last century.) This film is instead a sober, almost understated, comedy about being young and growing up, turns in life, mild conflicts, subtle humor, sensitivity and making lemonade when handed lemons.It was very pleasing to see such a fine film among the trash that usually passes for filmmaking today. Not a single time did I have to witness a cheerleader, jock, BMOC or other cliches in a college film. In contrast, there was often intelligent humor and conversation substituted for profanity and other R-rated tactics meant to draw in the younger audience seeking titilation. Without the apparent trappings, it's a curiosity to whom the film is intended. My guess is it is people seeking highly creative entertainment with elements of both fantasy and real-life. If that's you, go for it.

My 7-year-old Calico, a highly intelligent and playful hunter that lived the first year of her life in the wild, goes nuts over this toy. Our local merchants quit selling them some years ago and I feared the end was at hand. I found an old, chewed up one in her toy area last week; she still goes nuts over it.If you have a highly playful and intelligent cat that responds to catnip toys, I urge you to buy this while you still can. Outside of Da Bird, my cat has consistently responded to this toy better than any other I know.

My mother died earlier this year with a trust and I was the designated trustee. She was not wealthy so there was not a large estate. My sister, brother and I were the beneficiaries and we divided what little property and assets she left without discord in accordance with her will and written wishes.This was a very easy process to manage, from my perspective. Even transferring ownership of her home from her to the trust to another relative only took two visits to the trust attorney and two visits to the county Register of Deeds where the property was located to file two different quit claim deeds (the latter could have been done by phone, web or mail also.) The whole thing cost a few hundred dollars in filing fees and lawyer fees (a lawyer wrote the quit claim deeds.) I don't know what mom paid the lawyer to write the trust in the first place.This book, Make Your Own Living Trust, asserts it will provide you will all the tools to do all this yourself without hiring an attorney. The book has 238 pages of text and another 75 or so pages of forms you need to file, such as the quit claim deeds I filed to transfer ownership of my mom's house. This book is also connected to a website where you can download forms.Having gone through the process of being a trustee, I thought this book might help me file my own trust. However, I found an error in it as early as page 6 where it says: "No court proceedings or papers are required to terminte the trust. Once the job of getting the property to theb eneficiareis is accomplished, the trust just evaporates, by its own terms."This is not true. When I became trustee, I had to file with the IRS for an employer ID number. This is a formality and does not indicate I was an employer, though some trustees apparently do have employees. Like the precept of this book, the IRS posted on its website how easy it was to acquire and employer ID number following their online process. Only it didn't work for me and I had to call them.It wasn't hard to get the number -- just a brief chat with an IRS agent and answering a couple questions, then submitting a form and you have the number. However, the IRS agent told me I had to file a report by the end of 2014 to terminate the trust. I can't do that until I file my mother's 2013 taxes next year. So much for this book's idea taht nothing is necessary to terminate a trust!I haven't otherwise read the whole book so I can't comment on everything else inside. Most people around here seem to like it and my overview indicates it has a lot of information inside. However, it's hard not to be skeptical of something that includes an error on the sixth page. I would also add that our trust attorney provided us with recommendations on how to deal with creditors after mom's death. I didn't see anything in this book about that.

Here's the C minor requiem that so impressed Beethoven he had it played at his own funeral. Luigi Cherubini (1760-1842) was among the earliest romantic composers and used emotion in his opera and choral music in ways that would suit Napoleon and later influence the romantic Beethoven, the classically-inclined Brahms, and the new romantic voice of Richard Wagner.His requiem is heard here in an outstanding period performance by the New Orchestra and Christoph Spering, mated with Cherubini's wonderfully soulful and beautiful funeral device, "In Paradisum", a short piece about life in paradise that is sometimes played to conclude the requiem.Cherubini's masterwork is in 8 movements -- Itroitus, Graduale, Dies irae, Offertorium, Sanctus, Pie Jesu and Agnus Dei. The days of wrath section builds monumentally from a slow beginning to a titanic pronouncement while the concluding Agnus Dei does much the same before closing the matter...or leading into the gently spiritual view of paradise. There are no soloes in the requiem; the chorus has full reign the entire time.The otherwordly In Paradisum says this:"Into paradise may the angels lead youand may the holy martyrswelcome you and lead youin the holy city of Jerusalem.May the choirs of the angels welcome you,and, with Lazarus, once poor,may you find eternal rest."Lazarus of Bethany, according to the biblical Gospel of John, died and was restored to life four days later by a miracle of Christ. Wikipedia says it all about this: "In the context of the Gospel of John, the narrative of the Raising of Lazarus forms the climactic sign... Each of Jesus' seven signs illustrates some particular aspect of his divine authority, but this one exemplifies his power over the last and most irresistible enemy of humanity--death."The assembled forces turn in an outstanding job in this great sounding DDD disk. Many crtiics seem to like Ricardo Muti's way more with this music. Muti is a bit more emotional but the sound is miles below this and the execution by both players and singers is not as well enunciated as in Spering's performance that's a fair example of period practice circa 1994 -- a bit ascetic for some tastes but fine for others.There are other recordings of the requiem with a profile but none I know that link it to In Paradisum. I owned this, then sold it and bought Muti's when I came under the influence of critics. That was a mistake. This is the superior recording of this music, in my opinion, even without Muti's Italianate fire.

David Hall's The Record Book International Edition is a follow-up on his original tome (advertised here) that came out when most collectors were still listening to 78s and LPs were in their infancy. Hall's book was perhaps the first effort in America to tell collectors what was available and to provide grades for the best recordings they could buy. This followed The Record Guide by English authors Edward Sackville-West and Desmond Shawe-Taylor that did same overseas. Their books led to development of Penguin Stereo Record Guide from Edward Greenfield et al that eventually became the now-defunct The Penguin Guide to Recorded Classical Music.Hall's book laments the relatively few recordings available of many now well-recorded composers like Gustav Mahler and Anton Bruckner, whose mammoth symphonies are now routinely all recorded. Hall also spends the first 200 pages of the book (Part 1, he called it) explaining the recording industry, helping his readers better buy recordings, and giving the reader an inside look at musical history, especially the pre-Bach era.Hall is an everpresent guide through recordings and musical history in the pages of this fascinating book. His comments on the Mahler 9th symphony, which was not a popular composition after World War II when this book was in circulation, are telling. "In the Ninth Symphony," Hall says, "we come face-to-face with a different Mahler from the exhuberant nature poet of the First and Fourth (symphonies) or the musical dramatist of the Second and Fifth. The Mahler of the Ninth Symphony, as of the Lied von der Erde song-cycle, is a poet, sick and idsillusioned and read to bid farewell to mankind...looking to death as a welcome release from earthly trial."In the light of history and knowledge we've learnd about Mahler in the succeeding 65 years (my book was signed by its owner on August 6, 1948) these words may be slightly innocous or naive but still pretty much hit Mahler's work on its head: the composer vastly influenced by nature, God-worship and his own affectations of death related to deaths of his childhood siblings, daughter and his own heart condition. I doubt many musicologists were writing this about Gustav Mahler -- now our most popularly-recorded symphonist -- in 1948.In the same section, Hall praises the recordings of Mahler's 4th Symphony under Bruno Walter, with Desi Halban doing the solo singing, and Walter's collaboration wiht Charles Kullman and Kerstin Thorborg in Song of the Earth, recordings reinvented by Antante in their celebrated series of 78 reissues.Like Herbert Russcol's fabulous Guide to Low-Priced Classical Records and David Ewen's Musical Masterworks, as well as Sackville-West and Greenfield in Europe, Hall leads today's reader and record collector through the history of recordings, including many he recommends that returned in some form in the digital era. The lesson here should be clear to anyone that cares about music: today's new releases, while they may sound better and come in modern wrapping, really have nothing on yesterday's classics.

From a foggy recording to average woodwind execution, here is yet another in the endless list of overrated recordings from Sabine Meyer and friends, this time doing a couple of Richard Strauss's wind arrangements and the Dvorak serenade for winds op. 44.I first became acquainted with Meyer and her cohorts in their Krommer Octet-Partitas where all the same faults became obvious: playing that lacks zest and life accompanied by a foggy recording that merges all the instruments into one big mass, as if the 1970s rage of homogenization was back in vogue.There are far better recordings of all these works, not least of which for the Strauss is the exciting and much better recorded by Ensemble Villa Musica for MD&G where, in Vol. 1, you can hear the chamber arrangement of Til Eulenspiegel with the Sonatina in E flat major known as the "Happy Workshop."The irony of the latter piece has always felled me since it was written while Allied bombers were pounding Struass's hometown of Dresden to rubble during the closing days of World War II, yet it carries the signature happy.In any event, look for Ensemble Villa Musica in these Strauss scores and the Nash Ensembler for the Dvork and relegate this recording where it belongs: somewhere else.

The Chinese manufacturer of this very expensive product must have no concept of the size of American people. I ordered this in the size I normally do, mens large. I am 5-11 and 195 pounds with a 16 inch sleeve and 42 inch chest. I typically wear a large though sometimes I have to buy extra large. The sizing info on this product says I would wear a large.When I received this product, it was so small I could not put it on my body. It was at least 3-4 inches too short for my torso and it wasn't wide enought to fit over my shoulders! I thought surely it must be a child's size. The label, however, said L for large. I called the vendor about a return. The representative said many people have to "size up quite a bit" to get one that fits. I'm quite sure I could not buy one of these large enough to fit me.This looks like a nice product and the material seems fine. I bought it because it is very difficult to find this kind of product in navy blue. This isn't the first time I've tried to buy something that wouldn't even fit my size 6 adult daughter so I don't blame the vendor. However, I wonder how successful any company can be selling products no one can fit into.

Jill and Karen Sprecher, who co-wrote a dozen episodes of HBO's silly, laughable parody of Mormons, Big Love, here create their own paean to the Coen brothers' Fargo, doing just about everything possible to ensure viewers who've seen it know this is Fargo 2. Among the plot devices and directorial contrivances the Sprechers borrowed from the Coens for this film include:-- Location. While Fargo took place in North Dakota and Minnesota, Thin Ice takes place in Wisconsin.-- Weather. Both films had actors complaining about cold, snowy winter weather.-- Plot contrivances. Fargo had the killer doing away with someone in long-term parking, claiming he was taking a trip to Florida. In Thin Ice, one of the cast members takes a trip.-- Lack of integrity. In Fargo, the leading man was a car salesman in debt. In Thin Ice, the leading man is an insurance salesman in debt. Both try to skirt the law as a way to get out of debt.There are many more obvious similarities from the tone of the production to the slow intial build-up to the series of misadventures that turns an insurance salesman's dilemma about thievery into a free-for-all wacky mystery-black comedy.Had the Coen brothers never created Fargo, Thin Ice would probably have succeeded. It has a strong cast with Greg Kinnear in the lead role and Alan Arkin playing the object of his illegal ardor. Billy Crudup is pretty good as a nincompoop home security salesman playing essentially the same part Peter Stormare played in Fargo.The movie is interesting from the opening scene, also, and builds well for about 75 minutes to quite a climax. However, the final five minutes of Thin Ice is a failure as the writers and director simply try to jam too much plot twist into too small a time frame, giving viewers no ability to absorb all the changes in such a brief time frame. This lack of subtlety and planning is the downfall of many a good film -- the failure to know how to close out a good thing.If you're in the mood for a mystery of the Fargo ilk, Thin Ice will probably fit the bill. It's an interesting, sometimes involving, dark comedy of errors that pile up and become something quite different at the end. Had the denouement been handled better, this could have been a much better film. As it is, it joins the throng of copies of great films destined to be forgotten on the scrap pile of Hollywood history.

I agree with the other reviewer's three star rating of this recording but not the content of his review. I don't find the sound per se at fault; I find the playing and the sound of the instruments to be the deciding factors.The sound is OK; it is fair super audio. The reason the strings sound weak is twofold: first, these concertos are played one-to-a-part in the orchestral sections, meaning the "orchestra" could be as few as a half-dozen or less isntruments. More important, these are period strings making the typical yawning or wheezing sound. To me, this distracted my enjoyment of the musicmaking, which I would call average for the most part.The playing by soloist Rachel Podger and members of the band is OK; it eschews the sometimes Speedy Gonzales tempos some period practitioners use. However, this recording provided exponentially less enjoyment for me every time I played it because of the wheezing sound of the instruments, the one-to-a-part orchestra that lacked body, weight and volume, and a generally bland, affect-less presentation most of the time...or a presentation that lacked expression or personality. It could have been a computer playing this music.I bought this after reading critics in England that wet their pants over this recording. I can get on board with updating something (this is Podger's second recorded go-round at some of these concertos) and the newness of something. However, I do not understand critics who think this recording is any way superior to older period recordings like this one unless they believe the characteristics I cited above are somehow superior or better-sounding.The best part of this recording, by far, is the triple violin concerto that closes it. A remake of J.S. Bach's concerto for three harpsichords, the soloists and members of the band have more sprightly rhythms and generally invest this music with more energy and emotion than the earlier, more famous, pieces, especially the double and triple concertos which I have heard better played on this old LP and Antonio Janigro's recording with I Solisti de Zagreb and soloists Josip Klima, Ivan Pinkava, Andre Lardrot and Werner Tripp with Anton Heiller on the continuo.So, all told, an OK purchase but not an essential one for anyone's music library since the most popular concertos have been done better elsewhere.

Any audiophile that questions the validity (and value) of spending $40 or more for a Japanese-made SH-M compact disk only need sample Valery Gergiev's 1999 recording of Stravinsky's La Sacre du Printemps to judge for himself or herself. In my opinion, the value is great.SH-M CDs are made in Japan on a limited basis. They are constructed using plastic that does a better job of drawing out the sound than the typical redbook or even super audio CD. The sound on this CD is magnificent, more realistic and lifelike than any I've ever heard with depth that mimics the best sound you've ever heard in your home or car. There is simply nothing like a SH-M CD for magnificence in recorded sound.This wouldn't matter much if the performance wasn't top quality but it is. To paraphrase what a critic in an American journal recently said, Gergiev's forces managed to be raucous, unsophisticated and beautiful at the same time, quite a trick in this music.Le Sacre celebrated its 100th anniversary in 2013 having been premiered during a riot in Paris in 1913. Because of that, Decca released a Le Sacre du printemps 100th Anniversary Collector's Edition, a package of 20 disks and 38 different performances of the ballet.This package was revieved in the May-June issue of Fanfare magazine by two critics including the one I paraphrased above. Both critics said this recording, by Gergeiv, was the pick of the litter among those 38 renderings. One went so far as to say Gergiev's recording set a new performance standard for the music.High praise, indeed, but worthy, especially when you hear it on this SH-M CD. These expensive recordings aren't made for everyone, of course, just those willing to spend the money to acquire the best possible recording. There also aren't many recordings released on SH-M CD. The best one I'd known before this was Pollini's classic recording of Beethoven's five final piano sonatas which made the older DG sound come alive in ways I'd never previously known.Because of their expense it's best to sample SH-M CDs on classic recordings that are going to stand the test of time against competition to come in the future. This recording is one of those.

Any fan of 18th century church or sacred music simply must have this enduring and magnificent collection of English language hymns from Franz Josef Haydn and his English friends, among them Charles Burney, Johan Arnold Bahmen and John Foster. Right from the first piece -- "Dr. Harrington's Complaint" AKA "What art expresses" -- this collection engages the mind and heart with counterpoint for three to five singers and/or choir in Haydn's typically melodiously, humanistic and engaged style.Every piece here is seemingly a simple little thing for a single or two or three or five soloists and/orchorus -- until you try to master it. I chose one of these hymns -- "Maker of all! Be thou my guard" -- for a Sunday church service. Set for two sopranos and bass, I (a tenor in church choir) chose the second soprano part with our best soprano and our best bass musician for the other parts. We are all accomplished singers that have participated in paraprofessional concertizing, quartets and are experienced church choir and choral society singers and this was a difficult trick taking on Haydn's deceptively simple hymn detailing God's help, glory and love.And so it is with the remainder; these tunes fall easy on the ear and the lyrics, always understandable without resorting to the texts included in the booklet, are always enunciated with excellence from the soloists and members of Psalmody, an English period choir. They are equally well-supported by the Parley of Instruments, five English soloists on violin, viola, cello and organ or fortepiano.Among my favorites are the first tune, "What are expresses," the one I chose to perform in church, and John Stafford Smith's "Horrible is the end of th' unrighteous generation," an 11-minute-plus tune that starts dour and goes all over the place after that -- a mini-cantata for five male singers (one a male alto), choir, string quartet and organ where each singer has recitative and is followed by another. What a masterpiece!All the rest are at a similar level of exhultation, as well. Hyperiod captured this concert in first rate sound that exposes everyone's voice to best effect and lets you hear everything that's going on. The CD version is accompanied by a 20-page booklet that tells you something about every tune and has all the texts.One final note: if you are like me and become so entranced by one of these tunes, good luck finding the sheet music! None is available on the Petrucci online library and it took me over a year to find the music for "Maker of all!" I finally found it in a new English book of choral music. Even the slight "What are expresses," with only two lines of text (!), doesn't appear available anywhere.Sad this is for this album will definitely inspire you to participate!

Hans Schmidt-Isserstedt's Hamburg version of Brahms' Symphony No. 4 is, unlike his BBC concert version, steeped in the values of late Brahms with an autumnal glow over the whole thing that best characterizes the composer's late years. Brahms, a native of Hamburg, is exceptionally well-represented here, in my opinion. This is my favorite version of any recording of the Brahms Fourth Symphony and is the intellectual opposite of the much-praised and, in my opinion, highly overrated  Carlos Kleiber recording that makes Brahms late edifice into the ravings of a madman of sorts. Knowing so much about the composer's late life, his longings and his diffidence, I simply cannot accept this interpretation of late Brahms.Unfortunately this recording -- or its counterpart from the integral set of Brahms symphonies from Schmidt-Isserstedt -- is not available as a single recording anywhere but in Vox's deleted LP. For those of you that still spin LPs, this is a find in wonderful sound. The orchestra may be a tab homogenized in the recording and the sections of the orchestra don't stand out as they would in a London Phase 4 wreck. However, if you want to hear Brahms' resignation at the end of his life, here is one of the best ways to do so. Only Barbirolli's Vienna Philharmonic recording, sadly also out of print in USA, compares.

For those new to classical music, the late Canadian pianist Glenn Gould reconstituted J.S. Bach's art in the middle 20th century and turned its world upside down when he released the 1955 Goldberg variations. He did so by playing the music staccato without using any pedal then carried it forward in all Bach's keyboard works. While everyone in the period performance era now plays this way, it was new in 1955 and had never before been heard. The technique works better some places than others and works well in Bach because of the composer's mathematical perfrection in thes preludes and fugues where left-hand and right-hand voicing is so absolutely critical. Listen to the most approachable Prelude and Fugue in E flat No. 7 in the first book, tracks 13 and 14, to hear everything you need to know about this and about Gould -- including his famous humalong technique that has sent fans and critics on both sides of the Atlantic and a few other oceans atwitter for more than half a century now.Gould was one of the most interesting characters of the middle 20th century and was exploited by the recording industry more than just about any other virtuoso in the 1960s before he stopped recording and playing in public. He played a piano at his cottage on a lake near Toronto that sounded like a harpsichord and was the first major figure in classical music to try to make a modern piano sound like a harpsichord with no reverberant characteristics. This aided the clarity of his sound but also made it into a hybrid of modern pianism without beauty. To suggest Bach wanted his music played t this way is questionable although Bach never considered the 48 suitable to be played the way they are now -- with whole sets performed in concert and often recorded. Bach wrote them to promote his idea of equal temperament (the use of key structure we now follow unquestionably) and then his students and others played them for practice and to memorize equal temperament.Gould, being the ultiimate cult figure in his time and ours, is enough for Sony to continue rereleasing these works to new audiences. The sound hasn't been improved here so don't bother if you have one of the older sets. Gould wil always be unique for his approach. As to ideas one reviewere wrote that his "digital technique in its relationship to the keyboard was of astonishing," this is now commonplace among recent graduates of musical conservatories. Gould is no longer unique in this respect with the thousands of new pianists copying him every day with even more perfect forms of prestidigitization at the keyboard. But, as anyone that always hated Gould's apprach inately knows, there is more than one way to play the piano; just ask (or listen to) Andras Schiff's well-tempered klavier -- or any other pianist that believes in using the sostenuto pedal with some romantic character.

...and I'm the fool as I was for buying this collection of bland Mendelssohn symphonies. My first exposure to Emmanuel Krivine and his period band was in their Beethoven: symphony box that got some buzz in classical music circles for somehow being different from the norm. Influenced by the buzz, I bit and found nothing out of the ordinary in their Beethoven, yet I went back for a second drink with this recording.I'm a sucker for the Mendelssohn "Reformation" symphony, his final exposition in that genre, and have owned and/or heard just about every recording of it ever made. I was pleased when my local orchestra performed it in concert a few years back. Had this recording been of my local orchestra's performance, I would likely have been more satisfied.I heard the end of this Reformation on my PBS radio channel in the car one day and was impressed by the clarity of the instrumentation and depth of the playback less than the way Krivine built the dramatic finale. What a disappointment it was to hear the whole thing! First, it includes a none-too-individual-nor-spectacular recording of Mendelssohn's warhorse Italian symphony. To me, that's the kind of music that gives Mendelssohn a reputation as a lightweight in classical music. While full of memorable tunes, it is like that river in Nebraska that's a mile wide and an inch deep. I enjoyed it the first 10 times I heard it as a new classical music collector in 1972 and have been bored with it since.So shame on me for buying it again. Sadly, that's the only way I could acquire the CD (no thanks to the download) of the Reformation. That was a disappointment too. While the period band's instruments do stand out and, with that, bring the lines of counterpoint into the open, there was nothing about Krivine's leadership in any way impressive. It was a read-through performance with little or no nuance that one might hear in practice. What I heard on the radio was pumped up by the filters my local FM station uses, making their sound larger than it really is. When played at my house, the thin sound of Krivine's period orchestra was exposed. I should have known that after my experience with their Beethoven but, as they say, memory is among the first things to go as one ages. Shame on me again.Fortunately, there are many better alternatives for anyone seekng a reading of the Reformation symphony with more guts and insight than this one. My favorite among all the recordings I've heard is from Mendelssohn expert Claus Peter Flor whose recording of Mendelssohn's Symphonies 1 & 5 is out of print but still available used for little expense from Amazon vendors. Flor understands Mendelssohn better than any conductor I know that has recorded much of the composer's work. He is a master of pacing, never overplays the music, yet consistently finds the dramatic threads hidden within Mendelssohn's gloss but never puts it in your face like some other conductors I know (see below.)The one notable downside to this recording is RCA's tubby and congested recording that disallows the Bamberg Symphony from being all it could be sonically. The recording is slightly improved on the later release of Mendelssohn's symphonies, concertos and overtures under Flor, which is definitely the best buy for anyone seeking an inclusive box of all Mendelssohn's symphonies.Another great Reformation symphony comes from the legendary conductor Arturo Toscanini. Conducted slower than the norm these days, this was one of the maestro's best transfers in the Toscanini Collection even though the mono sound, while quite good, is yesterday's sound. For those seeking a stand alone recording of the Reformation symphony with more detailed and open sound, I would recommend the interpretation from the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra under Max Rudolf that was once available on a Decca LP but was never to my knowledge introduced by Decca on CD or download. You can, however, buy it in both CD and download format from two aftermarket companies -- Hadyn House and Klassic Haus Restorations -- that make recordings from pristine originals.
