Both have remade Rudolf's Reformation symphony from reel-to-reel tape originals.Both companies link it with Franz Berwald's Symphony in C "Singuliere" that was its original Decca LP mate. While I don't find Berwald an ideal mate for Mendelssohn, it is to me a better match than hearing the Italian symphony again and it's a better work than Mendelssohn's first symphony on Flor's recording. For the unititiated, the Romantic era but more modern-sounding Berwald is far more than makeweight and is equally well done by Rudolf and Cincinnati whose projection and power suit the music perfectly.Of the two recordings I like the Klassic Haus version best for a couple reasons. First, it sounds better. I think Klassic Haus uses a better filtering and recording system than Haydn House, whose recordings made from LPs often sound more distant and with compressed dynamic ranges compared to the originals. Klassic Haus retained the original gimmicky Decca source with violins in the left channel and lower strings in the right. Klassic Haus makes it available in a 320kbps download for $5 or CD with the original LP cover for $12 while Haydn House only offers a $12 CD with its own paraprofessional artwork.Because of my inclinations toward the Italian symphony I don't have a range of recommendations but will note one. Aside from his recordings of Beethoven, Wagner and Richard Strauss, I am almost always disillusioned when I hear Herbert von Karajan and the Berlin Philharmonic. I waited years to buy their box of Mendelssohn symphonies and, after hearing it, was glad I didn't spend much money on it.However, Maestro Karajan's version of the Italian symphony astonished me. After hearing him butcher the other symphonies with ceaseless pounding timpani and other inapproriate Germanic characterisitics, his lightness of touch and spontaneity in the Italian symphony made it an unexpected delight. Perhaps this because it was the rose between four thorns but, for whatever reason, I can recommend Karajan's Italian to anyone seeking a recording of it.

I bicycyle, swim, hike and otherwise spend lots of time outdoors all year, especially in the fair weather seasons, and look for long-lasting sunscreen that will deter skin cancer in my prolonged exposure. I tried Banana Boat's Sport performance coolzone formula SPF 30 as part of Amazon's Vine program; while some say there is nothing stronger than SPF 30, I'd have tried SPF 50 if I was buying the stuff -- which I may do after this trial.Banana Boat says this formula works for swim, splash and sport, is non-greasy and fast absorbing. My experience with this after a couple weeks' use mostly as a sun deterrent while riding my road bike contradicts at least one of these claims: I consistently felt greasy after using it though I never incurred a burn or rash.Typically I use Coppertone Sport Lotion SPF 50 Sunscreen & Antioxidants-8 oz for my daily regimen. Compared to it, the Banana Boat sunscreen goes on about the same, I use about the same amount for coverage on my head, shoulders, arms, hands, chest, legs and feet, and it leaves me feeling more encumbered after my outdoor day is over. Generally speaking, Coppertone Sport stays light on my skin long after my day in the sun is over. This was not my experience with a single application of this product. On a couple occasions I put it on twice and there was little difference then.Part of the reason for this, I imagine, is detailed on the Banana Boat bottle which says "Non-Greasy Fast Absorbing Water Resistance (80 Minutes)." The directions say to put it on 15 minutes before sun exposure and to reapply 80 minutes after swimming or sweating. Translation: it gets washed off when you sweat. For me, 80 minutes is about the typical duration of one of my outdoor bike rides so extra layers are not usually necessary. Depending on your habits, this may be an issue.A more telling element may be the composition of the product. For comparative purposes, Coppertone Sports has more ingredients than Banana Boat to wit:Coppertone SportAvobenzone 3%Homosalate 13%Octisalate 5%Octocrylene 5%Oxybenzone 6%...SunscreenBanana Boat SportAvobenzone 2.5%Homlsalate 5%Octocrylene 4%...SunscreenMy unscientific reading of this says there is more active ingredients in Coppertone and more sunscreen too. One final note: I have found this sunscreen better after summer is over during the autumn. It isn't as heavy but still does the job for the milder sun in late September and October, when I'm still active biking daily.

"Sinister" is a little horror film that made the rounds of small theaters coincidental with its video release. I saw it yesterday in a mall theater in Grand Rapids, Mich. It's the story of an author (Ethan Hawke) who writes about grizzly murders for a living, moving himself and his family (wife plus two kids) to the whereabouts of the killings for his book research. In this film, his family has moved to the home where the murdered family lived and where the deeds occurred. And, this time, the intrepid journalist gets a lot more than he bargained for, receiving clues about the murders no one else knows from who knows where.The production involves many typical horror film tricks -- loud noises and things that go bump in the night, ghostly visions of what may or may not be people, townspeople at odds with the principal characters because they are revisiting the murders that rocked their neighborhood, machines that turn themselves on after everyone goes to bed, the usual malcontented children, one of whom can't sleep through the night without going into something like night shock. And on and on. All the odd noises and strange goings-on happen in the dark, of course.But a few clever plot contrivances, a marginally serpentine story that will keep you vested, and some originality save this little film from being just another exercise in horror film ho-hum. I can't tell you the best part because it would spoil the end and disclose the denouement. However, I can tell you that neither my wife nor I -- who are 65 and 62 years old, respectively, and veterans of hundreds of horror films in the theater and at home -- could guess how the film would be resolved and what would happen at the end. If neither of us can guess how a movie is going to end -- and you get a few clues in the last half-hour of "Sinister" -- then it is in my book an effective movie.Be forewarned, the opening scene of "Sinister" is fairly grizzly in itself. Having seen the opening, I was fearful the movie would venture into X-rated territory but it did not. It is R-rated for intensity, adult content, scenes of murder, language and blood but the movie does not particularly manifest anything the average horror film maven would consider bad taste in 2012. See this in the small theater, like we did, or on your 55-inch TV and prepare yourself for a good horror story.

Since ganster films took over for cowboys and Indians as American mens' chiefs fantasy genre, there frankly haven't been a lot of good mob movies. For every Goodfellas there are a dozen Knockaround Guys, movies that try to get mens blood boiling but instead fall into the pile of forgettable, milquetoast movies. Here's one that transcends the arc and is high-paced, powerful, memorable and well-acted with an anti-hero lead you can root for."Kill The Irishman" is a fact-based story about Cleveland roughneck, union leader and mobster Danny Greene, played well by real-life lookalike Ray Stevenson, and the turf war he ignited with the Cleveland and New York Italian mafia over a loan gone bad. This movie has just about everything any man wants in a male fantasy: lots of tough talk, explosions, mayhem, killing, overflowing glands and even a sex scene with a beautiful dame. I found this movie an oasis in the ocean of bad mobster movies I am daily presented with on my 250-channel dish offering.The flick include newsreels from the 1970s, the era when the greatest action took place, that verify what really happened and even splices a piece of film showing the real Danny Green so you can tell Stevenson really was his look-alike. It features graduates of movie and TV mobsterdom including actors from Sopranos, The Seven-Ups, The French Connection and the aforementioned Goodfellas. If you like mob movies, there's a lot to like in this actioner based on real-world bad guys.

Starting with The Penguin Guide to Recorded Classical Music 2010 critics have piled on this 1751 version of Handel's Messiah saying Rene Jacobs' conducting is mannered, the solo singing is nondescript, and the conductor's penchant to add a lute continuo and some other affectations takes much away from the music, instead focusing on performance style. While I agree there is a certain individulity about this performance, this is the twentieth version of Handel's Messiah I have owned and nothing Jacobs does here strikes me as particularly mannered, certainly not in comparison to what Beecham did in his famous 1959 recording that added kettledrums, brass and lots of other noise. And it has far more fire, religious affect and personality than more straightforward accounts such as Marriner and Colin Davis.Since there are several editions of Messiah available, this one may not be to everyone's liking. It's my preferred version mostly because of the addition of the chorus "Let all the angels of God worship him" early in part 2. I generally prefer to hear the tenor section prevalent in the final moments -- that's not the case here -- but this is a good enough rendering from Jacobs and his group. Otherwise, I find this version more satisfactory than some other period versions I know including those from Pinnock, whose first and second parts are not equally fine, Higginbottom with trebles in the female roles and some stodgy rhythms, Hogwood's variably excellent and vanilla version, Williams Christie's recording very similar to this one, and McCreesh whose theatricality sometimes seems out of place in the music.

This is among Herbert von Karajan's final recordings and it comes back here in a single disk edition for people that still buy compact disks. The recording itself is a little more immediate than earlier versions.Musically, this is in league with a couple other two disk versions of the Nowak and Haas scores from the same period -- Carlo Maria Giulini's recording from Vienna and Gunther Wand's Lubeck cathedral recording. All three have solid reverential and Brucknerian qualities and, while Wand's has the edge being recorded in concert in the cathedral with its smashing reverberant sonics, there's not a lot else that differentiates the three unless you count against Giulini his tendency to focus on minutiae.I generally consider Karajan overrated as a Bruckner interpreter and think his integral set of the symphonies, while sometimes mighty and Germanic, often unimaginative and regularly showing the bar line. This version of the monolithic Symphony 8 has stood out for years and, now that it's finally available on a single disk, it's a better buy. His fans are happy to have it back; perhaps others can be too.

I put one of these on my 2011 Chevy Cruze with its 1 1/4 inch hitch after my old trunk bike rack scratched paint on the lid. The trunk rack never fit property, probably because the Cruze has such a short deck. This rack eschews that problem becuase it fits into the trailer hitch. Be advised this rack only fits 1 1/4 inch hitches and won't work on a 2 inch hitch. And, if you don't already have a hitch on your car, you have to get one of those first. The one I bought cost $220 installed. You could conceivably do that yourself on a Cruze since the place I went to didn't weld it and was finished in 15 minutes.But we're talking about the bike rack here whose manufacturing is outstanding with excellent fit and finish. The thing is super heavy duty, weighing in at around 45 pounds, but it's easy to fit it into the rack. The bikes sit in fitted cradles with no metallic finish to scratch them. They are held on the rack by heavy velcro straps; I suppose these could wear out over time though they work great for me now.The steel is substantial and putting the rack together out of the box is easy; there are only three parts, six nuts and bolts, and a bolt to deal with. It fits fine in the hitch and has a little sway but nothing to worry about unless you are carrying a gorilla back there. I see no way it could ever make contact with the vehicle short of driving in a hurricane or tornado.One feature that drew me to this model, aside from the substance of construction, ease of use, the fact it fit my Cruze's hitch, and that great reflector on the back, was the offset shank that allows the bottom of the rack to ride a few inches higher than the point at which it contacts the hitch. The Chevy Cruze rides exceedingly low anyway so the hitch is low. This was a major consideration in my decision to buy this product, as was Amazon's free shipping.

I'm not diabetic and don't have the foggiest notion what these socks do for diabetics. I've bought diabetic socks before and none were as good as these. These all-cotton (about 1 percent nylon for the stretch) socks fit my need which was, regrettably, vanity based. My wife always complained when I rode my bike riding crew socks because the things are constructed so tightly they stay up. I guess she thought I looked nerdy with socks touching my calves.I looked in stores and around the Web for all-cotton socks that would naturally droop a bit to a lot and guess what? They apparently don't exist. These are the closest I could find to the 100 percent cotton crew-style socks I wore in high school during the 1960s that would never stay up and crumpled into a pile on my ankles. These don't do that although they will -- comfortably -- if you want them to. They stay up fairly well and even retain some rise after an hour pumping my 21-speed through country roads 18-20 MPH.The other part of these great socks, and what I did not expect, is they are very warm and exceedingly comfortable. In fact, these are probably the most comfortable socks I've ever known. The slight but significant comfort bottom helps my feet feel better than in famous label socks that cost $25 a pair. At $15 a pair these are a bit pricey for crew socks but, in my opinion, they are worth it.I've bought four pairs of these and put two through several wash and dry cycles. The quality control has been consistent in sizing, fabric quality and fit and they haven't shrunk, yellowed, faded or debased in any way. These socks are a winner for anyone wanting to eschew all the manmade products in typical crew socks. They probably do well for diabetics, too.

Made from concert recordings in England during 2011 and 2012, this is Paul McCreesh's realization of Mendelssohn's original performance of Felix Mendelssohn's (1809-47) oratorio Elijah from 1846. McCreesh, a period music practitioner who used an extra-dramatic approach in his recordings of Haydn's Creation and Mozart's Great Mass in C minor to somewhat split effect, seems willing to take a more reverential, perhaps religious, approach to Mendelssohn's drama about the prophet Elijah with speeds generally slower than the norm for our era and singers using a lot more vibrato than the norm today.He is supported by Englishman Simon Keenlyside in the principal role and mezzo-soprano Sarah Connelly who joined him in the Mozart. Other soloists are soprano Rosemary Joshua, tenor Robert Murray and treble Jonty Ward whose contributions are greatest in the closing pages of the first half before the Lord laveth the thirsty land. Several choirs joined the Wroclaw (Poland) Philharmonic Choir and McCreesh's Gabrieli Consort & Players to make this ginormous recording.In recent years, coming under influence of the period performance practice movement, most new recordings of Elijah have used choruses of 40 or less including the performance led by Paul Daniel that starred Bryn Terfel in the leading role. This and similar recordings allowed the choir to enunciate all the words in the text so the audience could understand most of what they were saying without resorting to printed guides.That didn't happen here with about 350 singers in the choir. Some of the choruses start out sounding legible but most are a mass of sometimes undecipherable sound. McCreesh has never struck me as the kind of guy to keep the British choral tradition of massive sound going strong but that's what happened here. As to individual singers, I found tenor Murray to be the pick of the litter in this group. He is always eloquent, impassioned and reigns in rubato and vibrato for the most part. Aside from going flat in the opening ("As God the Lord of Isreal liveth..."), I've heard Keenlyside overplay his hand before and he does so here, misplacing English gusto for Biblical blasting. Connelly is typically lovely but the womens parts are small and they use too much vibrato as if they were singing opera.While the British press wet its pants over this recording, even some of them had to admit its warts. One reported, "The orchestral playing, though full of fiery drama, occasionally left quite a lot to be desired: horribly spliced brass entries were a particularly (period performance) highlight and there were all the usual tuning difficulties, especially in the woodwinds." Another debit: "In a performance so consciously in line with a big, grand tradition of English choral singing it was no surprise to hear Elgar in there too," meaning the enterprise sounded Elgarian as well as, or perhaps instead of, Mendelssohnian -- romantically heavy and pompous instead of classically lithe and dramatic.I think anyone that listens critically to this against other renderings will find this a good recording if you want a massive sound and chorus or if you want to pretend you were part of the occasion of the recording, which must certainly have been splendid. But, for listening repeatedly at home, this one doesn't topple my list of favorites that include Daniel, Burgos' classic version and Spering's German language period version that rivals this one with a smaller chorus and more focused and condensed choral sound. To me, this is neither as dramatic as McCreesh's other recordings and similarly lacks religious conviction to his recording of Bach's Magnificat and Easter Oratorio.A note for the packaging. The CDs come inside a 41-page book with the vocal score reproduced in English and Polish, lots of bios on all the performers, essays and other material about the music, its history and this performance. One downside is the CD slides into rather tight folders on the front and back cover and will probably be scratched over time. Also, the thickness of the thing makes it more suitable for a bookshelf than a CD stand or your car's tiny holder.

Ricreazioni is Italian for entertainment and that's about what you get in this concept album devoted to music of Italian composers from the Baroque, Classic and Romantic periods reinvented by 20th century Italians. The contents are:-- Gian Franceso Malipiero's (1882-1973) Vivaldiana, a three-movement (about 16 minues) parody/simile on any ubiquitous concerto from Antonio Vivaldi with 20th century ideas and orchestration woven throughout. Malipiero is generally credited with popularizing Vivaldi's music -- which sat unplayed after his death like J.S. Bach's before Mendelssohn unearthed it -- during the 20th century.-- Luigi Dallapiiccola's (1904-75) Tartiniana, a divertimento for violin and orchestra in five sections (about 15 and one-half minutes) built around themes from Giuseppe Tartini, who wrote hundreds of violin concertos and sonatas in the 1700s. Dallapiiccola was a serial composer greatly influenced by Wagner, Debussy and the Second Viennese School. He wrote Tartiniana mid-career in 1951.-- Alfredo Casella's (1883-1947) Paganiniana, a divertimento for orchestra on themes of Niccol Paganini in four movements (about 19 minutes), fairly transcends music from the named composer. Casella, best known for a number of Mahleresque symphonies, composed this suite that includes a loud allegro agitato first movement, a polka in allegro, a romance and a tarantella that offer moods greater than most will know from Paganini.-- Ottorino Resphigi's (1879-1936) four part suite (about 25:30 here) on themes of Gioachino Rossini known as Rossiniana, a favorite of conductor Ernest Ansermet with some of the appeal of the Respighi-Rossini collaboration La Boutique Fantasque (the fantastic toyshop.) This is the most famous and oft-recorded item on the concert with about four dozen recordings in Amazon's archive for either orchestra or guitar.I bought this for Rossiniana mated to something different than normal and like the collection, especially Casella's romance in Paganiniana and Respighi's tarantella from Rossiniana that's much better than the tarantella in Paganiniana. Italian conductor Aldo Ceccato leads the Malaga (Spain) Philharmonic Orchestra with lively, attentive musicmaking that isn't always Italianate. Josef Horvath is listed on the credits; he must have been the producer for he has no profile as a classical musician that I can locate.Ricreazioni befits its description as entertainment but comprises fairly innocuous and unimportant music that occasionally lacks the bounce of Vivaldi, the zest of Paganini, or the color of Respighi and is only available via download with no information about the reasoning behind this collection, its recording date(s), the label, conductor, orchestra or Joseph Horvath. It's probably best suited to those that enjoy any of the mimicked composers without demanding one of their masterpieces be on the menu.

I purchased the two-CD version of this performance (not the MP3 download) that's available through Amazon Sept. 25. I can't tell if the sound is better on the CD since I didn't listen to the download.Otherwise, this is Paul McCreesh's realization of Mendelssohn's original performance of Elijah from 1846 taken from a series of concerts given during August and September 2011 in London's Proms concerts in cavernous Royal Albert Hall. The latter fact makes this somewhat eccentric sounding since the hemispherical hall is notoriously difficult to record in, especially when you have hundreds of singers hanging around like this one does.McCreesh, a period music practitioner who used an extra-dramatic approach in his recordings of  Haydn's Creation and Mozart's "Great" Mass in C minor to somewhat split effect, seems willing to take a more reverential, perhaps religious, approach to Mendelssohn's drama about the prophet Elijah. He is supported by Englishman Simon Keenlyside in the principal role and mezzo-soprano Sarah Connelly who joined him in the Mozart. Other soloists are soprano Rosemary Joshua, tenor Robert Murray and treble Jonty Ward whose contributions are greatest in the closing pages of the drama before Elijah broke forth like a fire and the morning light breaking through ends the story. Several choirs joined the Wroclaw (Poland) Philharmonic Choir and McCreesh's Gabrieli Consort & Players to make this ginormous recording.In recent years, coming under influence of the period performance practice movement, most new recordings of Elijah have used choruses of 40 or less including the performance led by Paul Daniel that starred Bryn Terfel in the leading role. This and similar recordings allowed the choir to enunciate all the words in the text so the audience could understand most of what they were saying without resorting to printed guides.That didn't happen here with about 350 singers in the choir. Some of the choruses start out sounding legible but most are simply a mass of sound. McCreesh has never struck me as the kind of guy to keep the British choral tradition of massive sound going strong but that's what happened here. As to individual singers, I found tenor Murray to be the pick of the litter in this group. He is always eloquent, impassioned and reigns in rubato and vibrato, for the most part. Keenlyside tends  to overplay his hand in many roles and does so here, misplacing English gusto for Biblical blasting. Connelly is typically lovely but the womens parts are small.While the British press wet its pants over this recording, even some of them had to admit its warts. One reported, "The orchestral playing, though full of fiery drama, occasionally left quite a lot to be desired: horribly spliced brass entries were a particularly (period performance) highlight and there were all the usual tuning difficulties, especially in the woodwinds." Another debit: "In a performance so consciously in line with a big, grand tradition of English choral singing it was no surprise to hear Elgar in there too," meaning the enterprise sounded Elgarian as well as Mendelssohnian.I think anyone that listens critically to this against other renderings will find this a good recording if you want a massive sound and chorus or if you want to pretend you were part of the occasion of the recording, which must certainly have been a splendid venue. But, for listening repeatedly at home, this one doesn't topple my list of favorites that include Daniel, Burgos' classic version and Spering's period version that rivals this one with a smaller chorus and more focused and condensed choral sound. To me, this is neither as dramatic as McCreesh's other recordings and similarly lacks religious conviction to his recording of Bach's Magnificat and Easter Oratorio.One notable advantage of this CD version is the packaging. The CDs come inside a 41-page book with the vocal score reproduced in English and Polish, lots of bios on all the performers, essays and other material about the music, its history and this performance. The one downside is the CD slides into rather tight folders on the front and back cover and will probably be scratched over time.

When I listen to Arpad Joo and the Budapest Symphony Orchestra play the symphonic poems of Franz Liszt (1811-86), I think their renditions are the best. Yet, when I listen to the same music from Kurt Masur and his better orchestra, the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra, I think theirs the best. The only way I resolve this conundrum is to keep and listen to both sets repeatedly.Thankfully, Bernard Haitink's set with the even better London Philharmonic Orchestra is a non-starter in this argument, given that the conductor is so temperamentally at odds with Liszt's excesses and all-out requirements. Had the youthful Zubin Mehta recorded all Liszt's symphonic poems when he was in Los Angeles -- as he did with three of them on this exquisite recording -- he'd have probably been the winner of this sweepstakes. But, alas, he did not and Lisztophiles have Joo and Masur to save the day.If you've not exposed yourself to Liszt's symphonic poem canon beyond barnburners like Les Preludes, Mazeppa and the few others higher profile conductors dabble with, his poems may take some time getting to know. They are divided into two camps: those of philosphic origin such as The Ideal, What One Hears On the Mountain and From the Cradle to the Grave, where the composer sets out to discuss ideas about life, death and everything in between; and those of national origin such as Hungaria and Battle of the Huns, the latter probably be the best and most exciting of all Liszt's symphonic poems even though it suffers from his tendency to repeat themes and involve banal effects.Music lovers whose nature is reflected in the intricacies, subtlety and delicacy of Mozart or Chopin probably think the adjective banal best describes Liszt's symphonic music. I disagree though I admit it exists in his longer, less compact pieces. There are bountiful glories for the intrepid lsitener as Liszt perfected the symphonic poem and cast the matrix for nationalist and international composers that followed -- Smetana, Dvorak, Richard Strauss and Tchaikovsky. Whether any of those giants would have gone on to compose magnificent orchestral tone poems without Liszt's leadership is a question for the ages.In comparison to Masur's collection with the Leipzig orchestra that focuses on faster speeds, more excitement and razor-sharp orchestral execution, Joo's complement of Liszt exploits the composer's orchestration, his poetry, the 360 degree span of his disposition, and the relative orchestral balance inside the music, an area Liszt is rarely considered expert. Yet Joo picks up on this and translates it in every poem, never more tellingly than in the quiet second subject of What One Hears On the Mountain. He makes Festlange -- which can be banal trash under lesser hands -- into a monolith of texture after the opening exposition and before the recapitualation.Even discussing concepts like exposition and recap in Liszt's symphonic poems is dangerous. The composer sought to extend those ideas far beyond anything that had been known up to his day. Instead of the taut translation of ideas in strict sonata form one hears in Brahms' Academic Festival Overture, Liszt allows his music free reign to run all over the place in secondary, tertiary and primary ideas, often foisted from the point of recap or even the literary equivalent of denouement. As Wikipedia wrote about this part of Liszt's genre:"As purely musical structures, the symphonic poems do not follow a strict presentation and development of musical themes as they would under sonata form. Instead, they follow a loose episodic pattern, in which motifs--recurring melodies associated with a subject--are thematically transformed in a manner similar to that later made famous by Richard Wagner."Recapitulations, where themes are normally restated after they are combined and contrasted in development, are foreshortened  while codas, where pieces of music generally wind to a close, are greatly enlarged to a size and scope that can affect the listener's concept of the themes. Themes shuffle into new and unexpected patterns of order, and three- or four-movement structures roll into one in a continual process of creative experimentation."In this way, Liszt not only foretold the coming works of others in the genre, he influenced the likes of his son-in-law Richard Wagner and his acolyte Anton Bruckner -- with the constantly repeating thematic material -- and even the 20th century modernist Gyrgy Ligeti, whose Lux Aeterna begins on rising themes found in Bruckner's E minor mass and, earlier, in some of Liszt's sacred choral music.Joo and the Budapest Orchestra are with him every step of the way in all 13 poems and selected other works from his pen. While the big moments shine as brightly here as anywhere, those with greater repose and/or poetry seem to speak even more loudly in terms of their message in the greater context of the poem. This box comes with a description of every piece that will give the uninitiated a good starting point if they are new to these works. In good modern digital sound, this is a collection to begin and end your search for understanding of Franz Liszt's visionary tone poems.
Absolutely wonderful performances by an unknown orchestra of two favorite pieces.  First class acoustics and recordings.

GREAT pillow, IF you want a solid latex rubber foam pillow and understand how it differs from all other pillows.  BUT, I returned it to Amazon.com because the same pillow is $23.91 CHEAPER on Walmart.com!  That is a HUGE difference!  Other reviewers explained about this type of pillow very well, but I would like to add my comments.  Most pillows are either fiber fill of some sort, intended to simulate the down pillows of old that are now extremely expensive.  You "fluff" them, put you head on them and your head sinks in with the pillow flattening.  Newer pillows use "memory foam," which - in MY opinion - is very uncomfortable in ANY bedding use (e.g. mattresses).  Memory foam is sort of supportive, BUT - at the same time, it is mushy.  Memory foam conforms to the shape of the weight on it; like your head.  Memory foam, by its nature, resists movement of what is on it; i.e. movement of your head.  IF you are like me and move around at night, memory foam is not comfortable in addition to being overly warm regardless of infusion with "gel" technology.  Solid natural rubber latex foam, and - to a large extent - shredded foam pillows, support your head but allow for movement.  Many years ago, solid natural rubber latex pillows came in a variety of densities or "firmnesses."  I do not see that variety today.  THIS pillow is nearly identical to my old Beautyrest solid natural rubber latex foam pillow but is slightly smaller and considerably less dense.  Some reviewers complained that the pillow felt to them like "sleeping on a brick."  While likely a gross exaggeration, these pillows are vastly different in feel than anything else.  The current model is quite soft and pliable.READERS NOTE: these pillows are made from natural rubber latex.  I did NOT see any health warning in the ad or on the packaging, but there probably should be.  People who are allergic to natural rubber latex should probably avoid these pillows!

I rated this lens as 3 stars, "It's OK" only because it is probably suitable for people wanting "record shots" that will never be enlarged or examined critically.  This lens is NOT suitable for anyone who truly pursues photography as more than simple record keeping.  I was seeking a lightweight and moderately priced single lens alternative to the Canon 18-55 and 55-250mm kit lenses.  I was assured by the vendor from whom I bought this lens that it is "much better optically" than the Canon kit lenses.  Upon receipt, I took this lens out with my 55-250mm kit lens and shot identical photos, under identical conditions, seconds to minutes apart with both lenses.  There is a VERY significant difference in sharpness between the two lens, notably at the 200mm focal length.  Please see the two test images attached to this review.The lens handles well, focuses fairly quickly and accurately and appears to be solidly constructed, but all that is meaningless if your images are not sharp!

I have no idea how the image was taken for the advertisement!  The screen on the phone that I received was NO WHERE as sharp and clear.  It was difficult to impossible to see in normal room light, in the middle of a sunny day.  Admittedly, my den is not extremely bright, but it is ridiculous to need to turn on a room light or use a flash light to see the screen on the phone.  IN SHORT - the photo in the ad is VERY misleading.  When I tried increasing the contrast on the screen, all that happened was that the "hidden" "unused" numerals and characters became visible, INSTEAD of increasing the visibility of what I wanted and needed to see.  Please see attached photos.  I must admit to NOT having read reviews before buying this phone.  Before I find a replacement, I will do research.  The need for batteries/absence of an AC adapter is surprising and disappointing although not a fatal flaw by itself.  Whatever I do buy to replace this phone will have a well lit screen and an AC adapter.On the positive side - this phone offers perhaps the best call log facility I have ever seen in a telephone.  Unlike other phones that I have, the call log was very easy to access and provided very clear and concise information.  Apparently, the phone is well engineered for the hearing impaired (as I am).  The few calls I had on this phone were clear and easy to understand.  However, I did notice that the phone amplified the room air conditioner I have in my den.  NOTE: I did NOT try the "audio assist" feature.  In retrospect, I am wondering if it was turned ON and that is why the air conditioner was amplified?

I was somewhat familiar with this group before I listened to this entire album on an American Airlines transatlantic flight.  It BLEW ME AWAY!  Musically, the harmonies and instrumental arrangements were nothing short of wonderful.  While I loved, and purchased the CD through Amazon.com upon returning home, one track, in particular really does something for me and to me.  The song "Hallelujah, written by Leonard Cohen, is one of those enigmatic songs that is far beyond my comprehension.  BUT, there is something to the Gestalt of the piece, the rhythm, timing, something indefinable that reaches deep into my soul.  Perhaps because the first time I ever heard it was on an episode of the Scrubs TV series.  The song was played upon the passage of a beloved nurse character.  While there are several performances of the song available, to my ears and soul, THIS ONE is the BEST ... PERIOD!  While the entire CD is magnificent, it is worth the price for this one track!

I far prefer the new, all inclusive, edition. This edition is aimed at my parents' generation (I am 68).  I believe that ALL humans are equal, male and female, all colors, all ethnicities, all "orientations."

A High Holiday prayer book for MODERN people.  All inclusive.  Probably heretical to the ultra-Orthodox.  Want a prayer book to which YOU can relate?  This is it!  Excellent quotations and meditations from various authors.
Disappointing movie.  To me, not as good as the first recent Star Trek.
Good design and very usable.  Bluerigger cables appear to be somewhat stronger.  BUT, these usually do not get much movement or stress.
Well designed, well made.  Excellent signal transmission.
PERFECT for the purpose.  Solidly designed and manufactured.  Excellent signal quality.
Disappointing.  TEARS meat instead of cutting it.  I am sorry I bought these.
In my opinion, one of the best books describing the process, debates, reasoning, logic and needs of the 13 colonies when forming our country.  Well written.  Easy to read.

I have been searching for a lighter camera for travel purposes to replace my beloved Canon T3i + Sigma 18-250mm lens (combined weight of around 39 ounces).  Before purchasing this SONY model through the awesome Amazon.com, I tried and rejected a Panasonic G5 (rejected for poor image quality), an Olympus OM-D E-M10 (rejected for poor ergonomic design - it actually made the fleshy part of my thumb sore) and a SONY a6000 (poor ergonomic design - simply not comfortable in my right hand.  EATS batteries!).  Since I was unable to find an a3000 locally to hold, I took a big chance ordering it blindly from Amazon.  HOWEVER, since Amazon is very responsible and responsive to customer needs - especially with respect to returns, I bought without worry about being stuck with something I did not like.What I love about this camera -The ergonomics - The body shape and hand grip are both well designed and perfect for my right hand.  While not the lightest possible lens/body combination available (the Olympus appears to be), it is about 12 ounces lighter than what I now have AND offers a longer zoom range than the Olympus.The images - I have tried both the 18-55 and optional 55-210 lenses.  Because of my shooting style and interests, I am likely to rarely use the shorter lens.  However, both performed very well on this body; especially for inexpensive "kit" lenses.  Neither focused very quickly, but fast enough to catch wild life photos.  I found almost no "shutter lag," a critical issue for me when buying a camera.  Most of my early test shots were done in fully idiot-proof mode.  I believe the ISO was automatically set to 100 (I have since over-ridden this and changed the setting to ISO 400, at the moment, for smaller apertures and faster shutter speeds, with no apparent image degradation).Features - At least THIS SONY model offers "manual focus assist," which I find to be a WONDERFUL tool.  Holding the shutter button halfway down, you let the camera autofocus.  THEN, you can fine tune the plane of sharpest focus to your liking with the manual focus ring.  When you do so, if you have this feature turned on in the menu*, the camera will magnify a small area of your whole image.  I find this to be an enormous help IF I have the time to manually adjust the focus.  Obviously, not very suitable for birds and critters that won't sit still for long!  I do have a small complaint about this feature, but it may be my lack of understanding about how it works.  I do not understand how the camera chooses which section of the whole image to magnify.  It is NOT. necessarily, the center of the screen!The camera has a built in panorama facility.  Turn the one setting dial (ONE dial, not 2, 3 or more like some modern cameras) to Panorama mode.  Aim the camera facing the left most portion of the scene you want included.  Press the shutter button and keep it depressed while panning across the desired image area.  Voila!  A perfect panoramic image produced IN the camera.  No need to use Photoshop to "stitch" together sections of a panoramic image!Very intuitive settings.  While I have glanced through the THREE manuals available in .pdf format on the SONY website, the last thing I want to do is sit and read them.  I was easily able to choose various menu settings to configure the camera to my liking without lengthy research.*Menu system - There are two menus; one for camera settings and one for photographic preferences.  BOTH are easily accessed with the push of a single button on the back of the body.  You can either view them in the eye level finder or on the larger view screen.  As you go from one item to the next and each choice within an item, a brief explanation appears.  NOTE: the explanation is in excellent English and makes sense!  Once you are familiar with the settings, you can turn off the explanations if you wish.What I hate about this camera -I bought this camera having read MANY reviews and also after having bought and returned an a6000.  I was well aware of battery life issues and bought anyway.  I have used the camera 3 times, so far, to make sure I want to keep it.  Each time was for about 1 hour and each use was for roughly 25 still photos without flash, 3 videos scattered over the 3 days, and 2 panoramic shots.  After this one hour use, the battery was down by 20-30%.  This is beyond pathetic!  It is SHAMEFUL for a company like SONY.I never had battery life issues with my early SONY a100 or with my Canon T3i.  I was able to shoot with both of those cameras ALL day and never once had to change batteries mid-day.BTW, SONY saved $5 or so per camera by NOT including an external battery charger. As noted by other reviewers, until and unless you buy an external charger you must charge the battery IN the camera.  The camera is NOT usable while charging the battery.  Charging can take up to "290 minutes" = 5 HOURS!!!!I am hoping that SONY cares enough about their customers to redesign/re-engineer their batteries to remedy this problem despite the fact that people, like me, are BUYING their cameras even knowing about the horrible battery life.  NOTE: 47th Street Photo, and likely others, sell compatible batteries with power capacity approximately DOUBLE that of the OEM battery!As of today, 7/8/2015, I know that SONY has at least one employee named Mitch assigned to reading and responding to customer reviews.  I am hoping that Mitch, or someone else from SONY, can respond with word of a better battery for this and other cameras using the NP-FW50 battery.Finally, other reviewers have commented on the low resolution eye level finder.  Their complaints are valid.  Resolution is inadequate to tell if you are capturing a sharp image.  However, it is adequate for purposes of composition.  You can always review the image on the large view screen after capture.  Plus, with one button push, the image is magnified and magnification can be increased with a turn of the rear wheel.  I find an eye level finder to be mandatory.  I am not used to holding a camera up and inches away from my eyes to compose and shoot using a large view screen.  MANY newer cameras are lacking an eye level finder of any kind.  The SONY a6000 has an eye level finder, but it is not well situated (at least for my taste).  It is located in the upper left of the rear body and flat against the rear.  Using it places your nose against the large view screen thus smearing the screen with normal nose skin oil!  The eye level finder on the a3000 is centrally located at the top of the body and it protrudes rearwards a bit.  My nose still touches the large view screen, but in the upper right - MUCH LESS problematic.Today, 7/27/2015, I returned the a3000 and 55-250 lens to Amazon.  This was a VERY difficult decision in view of the excellent image quality.  The problem, and reason I returned the SONY, was the horrendous resolution of both the eye level finder and the rear view screen.  It was like the olden days of film when you had to process the film to see what kind of results you had.  I could NOT tell almost anything about my SONY images, other than composition, until I got home and opened them with Photoshop.To quote another recent reviewer: The thing with the screen is that more often then not, I'll get home, load up my pictures on my PC and think Dang, those look so much better than I thought they were!"I also did not like the delay upon awakening with the SONY.  That does not exist with my Canon T3i.  Unlike one reviewer who explained that he preserves battery life by switching his SONY ON and OFF between photos, I like to leave my camera ON so I do not miss a photo opportunity.  To conserve battery, the camera times out and goes into sleep mode.  It takes some bit of time to awaken.  In that fraction of time, you have missed the photo opportunity.Until mirrorless cameras improve their ergonomics and viewfinders (see my comments on the Olympus OM D-10), I will have to stick with a mirror and pentaprism, regardless of the added weight.
SUPERB performances by a rather unknown orchestra!

The original Waterpik shower massage.  I never could figure out why some have 7 or so settings.  I am happy as long as a shower head had shower and massage settings.  Better still, somehow, Amazon is selling these brand new, factory sealed, units as "open box" at a reduced price.  Amazon ROCKS!
NOT the theme from Rizzoli & Isles which is what I wanted!  OK piece of music, but disappointing.

I bought this camera as one of my failed attempts to replace my beloved Canon T3i + Sigma 18-250 with something a LOT lighter for traveling.  I simply cannot walk around with 2.5 pounds hanging from my body anymore.  I get a terrible backache.The camera and kit lens took excellent photos (see attached samples - the "bouquet was shot from a distance and cropped, the hibiscus was also shot from several feet away - not a macro shot).  BUT ...1 - While others have commented on poor battery life, there HAD to be something wrong with the one I had!  In ONE hour's time, the camera ate through 20% of the battery capacity.  That is while walking around shooting perhaps 25 still images.  NO VIDEO.  NO rapid imaging.  It is possible that part of the problem was the camera constantly switching between eye level finder and rear display (until I figured out how to turn the rear display off).  I did see that one commenter, an engineer, discovered that the constant wifi is a battery drain with this camera.  MAYBE that is the remedy.  BUT, probably not with the unit I had.  It was likely defective.2 - Also, likely indicative of a defective unit, the area of the camera grip around the battery compartment got quite warm.  True, it was over 90 degrees that day, BUT ...!3 - One of the reasons I bought a SONY was the possibility of using my old SONY/Minolta AF lenses.  In a call with SONY, I learned that the brand name adapter is $200.  BUT, it is 100% mechanical and offers NO electronic connections between camera and lens.  YES, you can use your SONY/Minolta mount lenses with the adapter (BTW, there are many generics available for around $20-30), but all operations will be manual.  I dare say that most casual photographers today have zero idea what an f stop is and how it affects your image.

Wonderful, well designed, well thought out, children's book.  VERY educational PLUS offers the opportunity for quality time between parent or grandparent and child!  I recommend this one over "Maisy's Castle," also by Lucy Cousins.  I felt that the Castle book would be destroyed too easily and that the subject matter is not as educational as a book about weather.The fun and learning starts with the cover of the book.  In the ad image, do you see the SUN near the tip of Maisy's nose?  There is a wheel on the right edge of the cover.  Move the wheel and the sun is replaced, in turn, by virtually every common weather phenomenon: rain, snow, etc.Each page spread offers some pop-up or other interactive movement and the opportunity to explore weather with your child or grandchild.

As I am aging, I find that I get a terrible backache carrying 2.5 pounds of camera + lens around my neck or on my shoulders.  I bought a Nikon Coolpix L840 in the hope of getting a fairly lightweight camera suitable for traveling.  I was hoping that this model did not have much "shutter lag."  NOTE: A few years ago, I had bought and returned a Nikon D5100 because of obvious quality control problems.  NOTABLY, the D5100 would NOT focus.  BUT, Nikon still has "the reputation," so I gave the manufacturer another chance.  BIG MISTAKE!Problems:1 - The camera apparently has the same of similar design/manufacturing problems as the D5100.  It had trouble focusing.  I don't mean focus quickly.  I mean focus at all.2 - Whether a lens, sensor or software problem is unknown to me, but virtually EVERY image taken with this camera required post camera CONTRAST correction.Before any of the Nikon lovers again attack me; I do NOT work for Canon.  I am an experienced amateur photographer and know what I am doing.It IS possible that this one unit was defective, just as it was possible that the D5100 I had was a single defective unit.  The reviews of others tend to belie this defense.My conclusion is simple: Nikon has gotten lazy or is too focused on profits and is cutting corners.  Until and unless they examine their engineering and quality control, I cannot recommend any Nikon product and certainly NOT the Coolpix L840.

As with so many other soundtracks, this one is somewhat disappointing outside the context of the movie, itself.  BUT, it is good.  What is notable about this CD are the extra tracks that run during the credits (I think).  If you enjoyed the music during the movie, you will enjoy this CD.  Whether or not you will enjoy it enough to warrant buying it is a different question; maybe not.

I confess to enjoying "easy listening" music, lovingly known as "elevator music."  If you are a young person today, you are not likely to enjoy this CD.  IF you are from the 1960s and like easy listening, you will love this CD.  The CD that I have was originally marketed by the Tandy Corporation - likely in their Radioshack stores.  The performers on the CD are members of the Studio London Orchestra and chorus.  The arrangements and performances are excellent except that I found their version of "Midnight Blue" disappointing.  The track choices are wonderful.  Note that the title of the CD identifies it as "instrumental" music.  This is not completely correct.  Several tracks have some vocal accompanied portions.

I bought this tv on sale at Costco for $189.99,  I am a big fan of Samsung equipment but this tv was a huge disappointment.  As noted in several other reviews, the picture has a washed out look.  I twiddled with the picture controls including the advanced controls and managed to improve the picture somewhat, but not enough.  The contrast and color balance was not right even after extensive modifications of the settings.  I returned it the next day.Re: sound - I found the sound to be adequate for a bedroom tv.  I did not experience the problems that some others have had.  That said, unless you are spending thousands on a theater tv, do not expect great sound from ANY model/any brand and especially not in small tvs.  There is simply not enough space in the cabinetry for decent speaker systems.  Of course, manufacturers COULD easily and fairly inexpensively do a lot better than 5 watts per channel, that would help enormously.  BUT, that cuts into profits!

I have an older Samsung TV that is internet "capable," but requires some sort of intermediary to get to the web.  I bought this device SPECIFICALLY so I could stream through my Amazon Prime account.  There is NO "app" for that purpose, nor does Amazon plan on having one created.  Therefore, the device cannot be used to stream from Amazon Prime!It is useless unless you subscribe to other services. Frankly, I do NOT understand why Amazon has not/is not able to provide the APP to allow this use except that the devices for which this link stick is intended are now older and likely Amazon simply does not want to spend the money for the programming.

This is an awesome collection of bluegrass music featuring The Nitty Gritty Dirt Band and well kmown guests.  This album provides what I believe to be the BEST performance of "Will the Circle Be Unbroken" begun by the wonderful voice of Johnny Cash and spotlighting the NGDB's other guest artists.  The sound quality is excellent especially considering the age of the recordings.  Young'uns, put away the rock and hip hop for 50 minutes or so and listen to this CD!

Looking for an INEXPENSIVE keyboard?  I bought this keyboard based on reviews by other buyers.  For the price, I did NOT expect a professional keyboard.  On the other hand, with modern electronics, I did expect something a bit better than this.  It did play when first turned on, but the sound was only coming from the LEFT speaker.  I thought it defective.  Then I unscrewed and opened the case to discover that it ONLY has ONE speaker!  Folks, that is CHEAP.  The sounds are also not sampled.  Or, at least, not sampled from any musical instruments I have ever heard.  Plus, the keys have a strange feel.  It is polyphonic for TWO simultaneous notes.  Not enough for a chord.  All that negative said, if it is as durable as other reviewers have written (I have not yet given it to my granddaughter), then it is worth the price for a very young child who is not a prodigy like Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart!

I reviewed another one of these from a different vender.  In THAT review, I gave the device 1 star because it did not feed.  This one works properly, although it took me several tries to program it.  In retrospect, I wonder if the first one was working properly just that I did not follow the ENTIRE programming protocol.  The instructions are obviously translated from some language OTHER than English; likely Chinese.  While they are clear, sort of, they are somewhat of a challenge to follow all the way through.  Without the final step, the feeder is not programmed and will NOT feed at the time you THOUGHT you set.Been working about a week.  As noted in my other review, I grind up my food, a combination of flakes, shrimp pellets and pleco algae tablets, with a mortar and pestle and place the fairly fine mixture in my feeder.

I find this stuff to be the PERFECT gluten free oat based cereal.  It is slightly sweet.  NOT OVERLY sweet.  It is definitely chocolatey without being cloying.  I modify it only by the addition of toasted, slivered, almonds.  I highly recommend this brand and this particular product, although their other "flavors" are also good.

I found Adobe Photoshop Elements to be much better suited to my needs AND easier to use based on my experience and amateur familiarity with older versions of Photoshop.  I needed a newer version of Photoshop to be able to handle the "raw" images from my then new Canon EOS T3i.  I read many, many reviews of both Lightroom and Elements written by amateurs and professionals.  To be honest, it was difficult for me to understand the difference between the two software packages.  My son-in-law is comfortable with Lightroom and uses it well, so I tried it.  I found it to be vastly different from previous generations of the full Photoshop software.  Even after trying it, I am not certain I understand the differences.  The major difference MAY BE that Lightroom allows across the board corrections and modifications over many images at once, whereas Elements allows image by image manipulation.  Without extensive reading, study and tutorials, I had difficulty figuring out how to work on a single image at a time with Lightroom.  I did use Lightroom successfully to create a slide show fairly easily.  But this can be done with several software packages.In the end, I uninstalled and sold Lightroom and replaced it with Elements 11.

In my opinion, one of Dean Koontz's BEST, most disturbing, books is the basis for this almost unknown movie.  John McGinley, aka "Dr. Cox" on the "Scrubs" sit-com, is PERFECT in the role of the psycho lead.  My only complaint is that the end of the movie differed somewhat from the end of the book.  The latter had much more impact.  IF you enjoy a truly disturbing movie, this one is GREAT.

Perfect and at a fraction the price of that charged by dealers.  It is what it claims to be, a protective liner for the cargo compartment of your Honda CR-V.  It is fairly stiff, yet somewhat flexible allowing you access to the spare tire compartment.  It fits the cargo compartment very well.

Somewhat "long" book that explains with detailed and well-researched referencing the roots of the current mess in the Middle-East.  While many countries have contributed to the mess, I am convinced that the origins stem from Britain and France privately attempting to carve up the area as spoils of World War I with almost zero consideration of the needs, desires, interests and aspirations of the various groups who lived in the regions affected.  Well written and easy to read, BUT lengthy and very detailed.  If you want the "blow by blow" this is the book for you.  If you are seeking a synopsis, this ain't it!
Absolutely wonderful movie based on the TRUE story of a British effort to provide disinformation to the NAZIs that helped make the D-Day invasion a success.
Wellaby's Parmesan gluten free snacks are much better.  These are somewhat greasy and not very cheesy.
I love these gluten free snacks, but as with all "novelty foods" they are outrageously expensive.  They are cheesy, light, crunchy and very satisfying.

Until recently I'd been using a Penn-Plax "Daily Double" automatic feeder.  It lasted me more than a decade but the plastic of the food bin dried out and, ultimately, the retaining tabs broke off.  I was never very happy with it for two reasons: 1) I do NOT feed my fish twice a day.  Once a day, and probably once every other day, is sufficient.  As the name implies, the "daily double" feeds twice a day and is not adjustable.  I looked at the half dozen or so models of automatic feeder available through Amazon (isn't Amazon awesome!  And, no, I did NOT get paid to write that) that are under $30.  I read user reviews.  I looked and looked at the photos.  I settled on this one for a number of reasons, notably the alleged protection of the food from moisture from the tank.  Looking at the photos, it appeared that the food reservoir of this model sits far above the water and is likely to stay dry.  In actual use, the food reservoir DOES sit 1.5 inches above the top of the tank edge and probably 2 inches or so above the water surface when the tank is "full".  I also did not want a unit with a Velcro mounting system.  I prefer a clamping device.  Finally, I wanted a unit with a reasonable mechanism for adjusting the amount of food delivered at a feeding and one that allows for once daily feedings.  This unit appears to allow a fairly accurate method for adjusting the amount of food delivered AND from one to four daily feedings.NOTE: For automatic feeding, I use a blend of flakes, algae discs (although I am convinced that my Pleco ignores them) and shrimp pellets.  HOWEVER, I grind all of them up with a mortar and pestle to a fairly fine granular consistency.  I do this because of experience with the Penn-Plax Daily Double feeder.  Other reviewers have observed that flake food does not flow well through many feeders.  I have seen flakes that are quite large and I could understand them getting stuck in some feeders.A few notes to help the next buyer:1 - In order to get the cover of the battery case open, you MUST at least partially "slide" the feeder off the rails of the tank clamp mount.  The instructions do not mention this (well, maybe they do in Chinese on the back, but NOT in English).  I found that the fit between the feeder and the mounting rails was SO SNUG that I needed a small hammer and some careful tapping to budge it.  Once I had moved the feeder far enough, the battery compartment was easily opened.2 - Programming was actually not very difficult.  The instructions, although obviously translated from another language into English, are not hard to follow.  Others had trouble with programming.  I did NOT.3 - Removing the food reservoir is NOT difficult if you look at the photo in the instructions.  The reservoir literally slides off as a unit (the black base will still be attached to the transparent cover).  DO NOT TWIST IT.  The axle has a "key" ridge.  Pull gently from the bottom of the feeder.  BTW, if you have already installed the batteries, watch where you hold the device when you pull.  If you touch the "on demand" feeder button, the reservoir will rotate.  The black base, that must be removed to add food to the reservoir, is bayonet mounted onto the reservoir.  NOW, a slight twist is required,  BUT only slight.  Maybe 1/8 to 1/4 inch.After a few days of "running" on which I was watching at the set feeding time and saw NO drum rotation, I returned the defective feeder bought another identical one.  After struggling over a few days to get the programming right, I finally did and it appears to be working properly.  Programming requires very close attention to the instructions and completion of ALL steps.  It is not difficult once you figure it out.
Disappointing, especially after hearing and buying the soundtrack from Foyle's War by the same composer!  Missing some of the best music from the show!

Maimonides, possibly the originator of the "golden rule," (do unto others as you would have done to you, although Maimonides wrote it as in a negative form, do not do to others what you do not like done to you), was a GREAT man in so many respects.  I have long sought a compilation of his sayings but had trouble finding one until I came across this book.  I was not interested in reading Maimonides complete works or even his "Guide for the Perplexed."  The reason I only gave this book 3 stars is due to the extremely dense writing style of the author.  I TRIED to wade through the 30+ page introduction and had extreme difficulty.  THANKFULLY, the quotes from Maimonides are MUCH better written (or translated) and MUCH easier to comprehend.  I had the distinct feeling that Twersky is an academic trying to impress other academics.  While I spent 12 years in universities, I am NOT an academic.  I appreciate plain and understandable language.

I am not a music critic nor a professional musician, so I am not qualified to give that kind of a critique.  I know what I enjoy!  This three CD set is AWESOME and would be so at three times the price.  As with other CDs from the Canadian Madacy Music Group, Inc., the recordings are of excellent technical sound quality.  The arrangements and performances, predominantly by the Vienna Opera Orchestra, are delightful.  Even the novice to Viennese waltz music will recognize some of the pieces.  Others were completely unknown to me.  ALL were wonderful.  If you are looking for background or dinner music, you cannot go wrong with this inexpensive collection!

I found this CD new for $1 at a local "dollar" store.  For $1 I frequently try new, unknown and/or different music.  I am very pleased that I tried this CD.I am not a music expert, so I cannot comment on the musical talents of the performers other than to say they sound SUPERB to my ears.  The selections are wonder. A little gentle guitar, a little gentle piano, etc.I highly recommend this CD for soft background reading music.  For days when you come home frazzled from work.  For gentle music during a nice dinner with a loved one.

I like using this essential oil to help me relax and de-stress. I have used lavender essential oil on its own and that has helped me relax, but this works so much better because of all the other essential oils that are included. I do smell the lavender the most though. I like using this essential oil as a spray for my pillow or in my diffuser. The scent is fairly strong, so I don't have to use that many drops. I received this essential oil at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

This is an awesome way for me to open up my sinuses. I get congested and have sinus pain when the seasons change and I don't like to start taking medications right away, so I look for natural remedies. I twisted off the top and took a big inhale and I could feel my sinuses opening right away. I love that it's made with all natural and organic ingredients. I can really smell the peppermint and eucalyptus. I am glad that I can just inhale this essential oil straight from the bottle, but I also like to use it in my diffuser. The scent isn't as strong, but I find that it still helps with my congestion. I received this essential oil in exchange for my honest review.

I have used Sublime Beauty serums on my face and I have loved the way they work on my skin, so I was very excited to see them include all of the wonderful ingredients in this one serum. I love that all of the ingredients are natural and organic also. Hyaluronic acid has always made my face look very hydrated and I make sure that it is an ingredient in all of my serums, so I was happy to see it included in this Zen Power Serum. I also like the way Matrixyl and Collagen work on my skin, especially as I get older. My face appears more youthful and my wrinkles and fine lines are much less noticeable. I have only had to use one pump of this serum to cover my face. It goes on very smoothly and absorbs quickly. It has a subtle herbal scent. I like to use Sublime Beauty's Day Moisturizer on top of this serum. I have sensitive skin and I have had no problems using this serum. I received this serum at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

I have really enjoyed all of the essential oils that I have received from Majestic Pure. I feel that all of their essential oils are made with high quality ingredients. This essential oil contains 100% pure and natural Bergamot oil with no other additives. All of their oils come in a large 4oz bottle that will last for quite a while. They also include a long glass dropper to make using their oils easy. I like using this Bergamot essential oil in my diffuser. It makes my whole room smell fresh and clean. It has a fairly strong citrus scent, so I only need to use a couple drops each time. I received this essential oil at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

This speaker has a great sound quality for its small size. It works very well for the price. It is very small, so it's easy to carry and store. I had to charge the speaker before I could use it. This only took about 2 1/2 hours. The band of light on the speaker will glow red when it needs to be charged and it will be blue when it is ready to use. There is an on and off button near the bottom of the speaker. It is a toggle switch. Next to the on/off button are 3 buttons to control the volume, change songs, and pause. There is an operation manual included that explains all of the buttons and how it use the speaker. It is very simple to use. There is a voice prompt for things like pairing. I had no problems pairing it with my IPhone 4s. I like that it also comes with an audio cable, so I can connect it to my IPod that doesn't have Bluetooth. It comes with a charging cable too. I really like the way this speaker was packaged. It came in a sturdy plastic case. I received this speaker in exchange for my honest review.

I like that this exfoliates, but doesn't have a lot of micro beads that scratch my skin. I have used exfoliators that are very gritty, which I guess is how they exfoliate. This one doesn't have that at all and it still takes off all of my dead skin cells. It is a clear gel that goes on smoothly when applied. I made sure to rub my skin in a circular motion for 60 seconds before rinsing it off. It has a cooling sensation when on my skin and has a nice fresh scent. My skin felt very, very soft when I rinsed off this gel. It also made the skin on my hands look renewed. I was considering giving it 4 stars because of the price, but it is the most gentle exfoliator that I have ever used and it does work very well. I received this product in exchange for my honest review.

This pet stain and odor remover is amazing. I foster kittens and I have a kitten room that I put them all in. I have had 7 kittens in there at a time. I don't like to have to leave them in a kennel, so I let them loose in the room. The problem with that, is that they will make a mess. Most are pretty good with using a litter box, but there are times when I will find messes on a blanket that I left laying on the floor. They have also gone on the tile floor. The tile is much easier to clean up, but I worry about the odor remaining and them starting to use that area over and over again. This stain and odor remover works wonders. It took the stain and odor out of the blanket. I kept an eye on the kittens and they didn't even give the blanket an extra sniff, so I knew that the odor was totally gone. It also took away any odor that was left on the tile floor. I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

I am very happy with my portable toothbrush sanitizer. I am definitely a person that thinks about germs, so this sanitizer gives me a great peace of mind. I think that it's amazing that the UV light will kill 99.9% of bacteria, viruses, and germs. It does all that in just 6 minutes. I like to use it when I travel because I use a manual toothbrush, but I can also use it on my electric toothbrush head. Both toothbrush heads fit securely in front of the UV light and are held in place by a rubber clip. After closing the lid, the UV light comes on automatically and lasts for 6 minutes. After the 6 minutes, the light will turn off and I can leave my toothbrush in the case when I am traveling. At home, I just take out the electric toothbrush head and place it back on my toothbrush. This sanitizer does take 2 AAA batteries that aren't included. I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

I have been doing yoga for quite awhile and I really enjoy it. There are some poses that I still need to use a block for and probably always will. These blocks allow me to get deeper into a stretch or position than I could just on my own. I have my own yoga mat, so I can do yoga at home with a video, but I always used the blocks at the gym, so I didn't have any of my own. I got the bright orange blocks because I love a pop of color. These blocks are very lightweight and feel sturdy and durable. They are the standard size of most yoga blocks. I received these yoga blocks in exchange for my honest review.

This charcoal deodorizer bag works very well on pet odors. I have 2 cats and foster kittens, so I have a few litter boxes that I have to worry about smelling up the room that they are in. I have used plug-ins and sprays, but they just mask the smell. It might smell good for a short time, but there is still that litter box odor in the air. I keep looking for new things to try, so when I was offered to receive this at a discount in exchange for my review, I was excited. For some reason, I thought that the bag would be bigger, so I wasn't sure how well it would work when I saw how small it was. I was pleasantly surprised at how well it eliminated the odor though. The room that I used it in is a bedroom and I made sure that I placed it near the litter boxes, so I think that really helped. I am very glad that this is non-toxic and pet friendly, so I don't have to worry it being around my cats and kittens. I have only been using it for a week now, so I am not sure how it will do in the long run. I am curious to see if it lasts by putting it in the sun once a month. I received this at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

These leaf claws are amazing. I love having trees in my yard, but it is such a chore to clean up all of the leaves when they start falling. There is still no way around the raking, but these leaf claws make picking up the piles so much easier. I used to use the rake and one hand to pick up the piles, but that still didn't allow me to pick up as much as these claws do. I am a woman with small hands and I found that my hands fit nicely into the areas of the handle, so I was able to maintain a secure grip while using the claws. There's really no need to wear gloves while using these claws because your hands stay away from everything since they are on the outside of the claws. The claws are pretty big and can pick up quite a few leaves at a time, so the pile disappears in no time. They are shaped so that one fits inside the other (stacked) for easy storage. There are holes in the tops of the claws, so they can be hung on a hook or nail in the garage. I received these leaf claws at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

I think that this flask with a built in shot glass is such a cool idea. It maintains the classic flask shape while having a collapsible shot glass built right in. The flask feels like it is well made, solid, and very durable. I like the look of the leather, including the leather circle in the middle of the bottom of the shot glass. It adds a classy look. I love that the top is attached to the flask, so there is no worry about losing it. The top screws on tightly, allowing nothing to spill out. The collapsible shot glass is very easy to pull out of the flask. The shot glass is very sturdy and when it is fully extended, it stays that way and doesn't collapse on its own. I like that there is a small funnel included in this set, because it makes it easier to fill the flask. It is small though, so it would also be easy to misplace. This would definitely make an interesting and unique gift. I received this flask set in exchange for my honest review.

I love this carrier oil stick. I have just gotten into using essential oils and I usually use them in my diffuser. I read that I had to use a carrier oil, if I wanted to use them topically. I have some Jojoba essential oil, so I used that as my carrier oil and it was okay, but to me, it was a little messy with so much oil. This is a perfect solution for me. I didn't even know that there was such a thing as a carrier oil solid stick that I could use. I think that people definitely need to start using this and spread the word, so others know about it. It really makes using essential oils easy and convenient. I rolled this stick over the area where I wanted to put my essential oils and then added a couple drops of the essential oils on top of it, then massaged it in. Of course, the area was slightly oily, but nowhere near as oily as it was when I used a liquid carrier oil. I like the fact that this solid carrier oil helps my skin absorb 80% more of the essential oils to make using the essential oil more beneficial to me. I think that this is a must have for anyone that wants to use essential oils topically. I received this carrier oil stick at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

It's amazing how much this kinesiology tape helps my knee. I experience pain in my outer knee area whenever I run or do squats and lunges. I enjoy doing these exercises and I don't want to have to stop because of the pain, so this tape is perfect for me. I found a Youtube video specifically related to taping my outer knee, so I watched it a few times before applying the tape. I like that this tape is not precut because I need different lengths of tape for my knee. I have to stretch and bend the tape in certain areas when I tape my knee, so my first time taping was kind of tricky and it didn't come out that well. It didn't take me long to get the hang of it though and it became very easy to do. My knee feels much more stable when I have it taped and I also don't experience the pain that I used to. I love that I can wear this tape for at least 3 days even with taking showers everyday. The ends do start peeling up, but all I have to do is trim them and I can get the 3 days out of it. I received this kinesiology tape at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

I used this in my car, so I could listen to the songs on my old IPod Nano. That is where I keep all of my music to listen to when I am at the gym, so it has all of my songs on it. It doesn't have Bluetooth, so I need to use a transmitter that I can plug it into. This transmitter works well, but it took me awhile to get the right frequency. The transmitter came up with a frequency and when I went to adjust my radio to match it, it sounded a little fuzzy. I had to play around with it to get it to sound clear. It might be the radio I have or where I live that made it more difficult. Once I got it set up though, I was able to listen to my music with no interference. The sound quality was pretty good for the price of this transmitter. The cord is long enough for me to set my IPod on the dash or on the passenger seat. I received this transmitter at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

I have just gotten into essential oils and use most of them in a diffuser, so I was very excited to try this immune boast essential oil blend that I could use topically. I love using natural remedies and I have noticed some great results with the essential oils I have used so far. It seems like since entering perimenopause, my immune system doesn't work as well as it used to, so I find myself not feeling all that great quite often. I like that this blend contains the carrier oils, Jojoba Oil and Sunflower Oil, so I can use it directly on my skin. I did not realize the importance of carrier oils when I first started. Most of the essential oils contained in this blend have antiviral, antibacterial, antifungal, antiparasitic, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory properties, making it great to help boost the immune system. I have used some of the essential oils on their own, but never in a blend like this. I absolutely love the smell of this oil blend. It's hard for me to describe because it contains so many different fragrant oils and none of them overpower any of the others. They just combine to make an amazing scent. I have used this oil on the bottoms of my feet at night and I have also inhaled it. The only thing that bothers me about using it on my feet, is that the oil gets on my sheets. I don't like wearing socks to bed, so I am not sure how I am going to get around this. I would rather use it on my feet during the day. I have felt a difference since using this though. I have been feeling much better and stronger, so I look forward to seeing how I feel a month from now. I received this oil blend at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

These infusers are such a fun way to make tea. It is very easy to fill and use. The little guy's pants hold the tea leaves and can hold quite a bit. In fact, I didn't fill the infuser all the way up and my tea still tasted nice and strong. The pants are shaped so that they are easy to hold and fill with tea leaves.
