One that had been bothering me (and I had been avoiding) for years, in fact. And it wasnt exactly a backyard fence. The house shutters were painted professionally at the manufacturers facility many years ago to match my interior trim. Unfortunately, some sections of one shutters frame have begun to clearly show the woods grain pattern through the paint (shown, 1). Otherwise the paint coverage was adequate. I needed some way to spray my interior trims latex paint, and I decided this was it.I rationalized that my job was a good test case for a review since two functional capabilities would be critical:  o  The volume of paint in the spray would need to be controlled adequately to avoid runs in a small area.  o  A light volume application needs to be uniform enough in pattern, with decent atomization, allowing a minimum number of passes to, again, avoid runs.If the above criteria could be met, the wood grain that was gradually exposing itself could be hidden again.  o  AND, I wanted ease of set-up & clean-up - because, I hate painting, remember?Initially, the unit appears almost toy-like. But a closer look and some hands-on time reveal its design to be simple and robust rather than elegant. Its air supply motor seems to be a hand-held vacuum unit, utilizing its exhaust rather than intake end. One odd concern: several thickish strands of white plastic flash were sitting in one of the paint jars, and one decent-sized flat piece of blue plastic came rattling out of the air hose (both pieces shown, 2 & 3). Check your unit carefully for errant plastic bits before use.I became familiar with the various components, changed out the installed paint jet for the smaller size for my light volume requirement, adjusted the trigger/needle valve retraction for a minimum opening, popped open my original latex white trim paint can, thinned it way down, and shot some test sprays on cardboard, adjusted paint volume, thinned it more, tested some more and was set. This gun shoots a very big pattern, even with the smaller jet installed. But it *was* uniform, even when metering the paint way back. This looked promising.Since these surfaces were painted previously, I sanded them lightly for decent new paint adhesion. I had left the two bothersome horizontal frame pieces exposed and covered the large remaining area of shutter and tabletop with my newspaper drop-cloth (shown, 4) to catch all the overspray. It still wasnt enough.But the paint job worked! A handful of passes (read the instruction book to remind yourself how to move a sprayer correctly) and it looked great. The top section needed an additional two passes and was a bit thick, but very uniform and just took longer to dry. Even for my jobs small area, the paint density on the spray was light and uniform enough to succeed. The semi-gloss result is a bit lighter in shade than the faded surroundings, but the grain is gone and the ease with which this job was done, is making me considering doing the entire shutter assembly. (Final results shown, 5 - note that the phone-camera's flash exaggerates shade variance, which the eye can barley discern.)If this simple unit can be adjusted adequately to handle a fine/small scale job, its paint volume control and uniformity qualify as great in my opinion. Disassembly and clean up was a snap. It appears built to last.I love how this spray unit performed for my job. Time will tell if I ever come to love painting itself.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for writing an honest unbiased review.First of all, it is impossible at this time to rate this flea control product which has only been on my dog for a short period of time.  Usually products like this take several months to properly evaluate.I gave it 5 stars based on ease of application and price and the fact that he had no reaction after I applied it.  It is very easy to apply, easier than Frontline.My dog does not have fleas and in 10 years I have only found one on him.  But... evidently they land on him and probably bite him and as he is highly allergic to flea saliva and he breaks out after being bitten.  Apparently Frontline, which we have used for years, is successful in killing them before they can lay eggs, but the saliva damage has already been done.  He can go for months having no breakouts or heavy scratching.Since I received three months supply of it,  I will use that time to judge it's performance. If the results are the same, I will definitely be purchasing it.

I received this item free of charge in exchange for an honest, unbiased review.Main Pros: comfortable handle, safe tipMain Con: no pointy tipThe barrel/handle is very comfortable, and made me realize just how uncomfortable most standard utility, razor, and X-acto-type knives are.The blade tip, however, is rounded, which may occasionally prevent a small wound, but it also means you cant pierce anything to actually start a cut. Blister packs - no. Cutting a small gasket - no. It turns out, at the micro scale, piercing with a sharp tip is important. Making a knife safer is great. Taking away some its elemental functionality is not.When the blade is retracted, the nose piece rotates about 15 degrees, locking the blade in place, which is handy for transit. At least, I assume thats an intended feature, but its not mentioned anywhere in the product descriptions.The replaceable blade claim is practical, but there are no instructions on how-to do that - at least on the packing material. I wondered if further rotation of the nose piece would unlock something. I tried that, but felt I was at the breaking-point, force-wise, so I backed off. The manufacturers web site doesnt seem to have that info, either. Perhaps I am missing something obvious, but it wouldnt hurt to mention the procedure somewhere, perhaps at the product info blurb for the knife or the replacement blades (which at $19.99 for 4, you wouldnt want to waste). Plus, experimenting with physical force while holding a sharp tool, is rarely advisable.Returning to attempts at precise cuts.. a small metal blade flexes slightly, which can be a good thing when cutting a tight radius, and for corners, where precision counts. Ceramics, of course, are known more for shattering than flexing.Im sticking to X-actos for precision work, and cheap utility knives for cardboard boxes and crude garage work. Ceramics should be reserved for the kitchen - and high-performance brake rotors.I'll go 2 stars for overall comfort and the round tip for frequent Emergency Room visitors. I think this design is actually more harmful that beneficial.

I received this product for free in exchange for an honest unbiased review.In a nutshell, the SoundTouch connected and performed exactly as I had hoped it would.Boses attention to sound reproduction accuracy, aesthetic detail and ease of setup makes this an excellent product for those with deep-ish pockets. My Apple equipment all paired with it flawlessly, and as advertised.  iTunes and Spotify played right along. I did not attempt to access a NAS device as a source. Connection flexibility is the units forte: direct to source via headphone/output cable, wireless to bluetooth enabled computer/device, wi-fid to your network. The only things missing are RCA and optical input jacks, but those require cables from another time and protocol-proposal entirely. The USB ports are for setup/configuration only, but also demonstrate a willingness to be reasonably inclusive.A combination of rich sound and borderline portability (my lab report says 19.6 lbs.) compel you to consider relocating the SoundTouch whenever you switch rooms - which I suppose bodes well for Boses grouping functionality, which is on offer with multiple units. Other than stereo separation, which is obviously limited due to the fixed width, this product is hard to fault. Ive always subscribed to the old stereophile adage: buy the heaviest speaker/amp you can afford. That seems to apply here.Music is clear and loud for the size of the drivers, though additional control of frequency ranges - beyond just bass - from the configuration application, would be a nice-to-have. I realize many players have equalizers, but an additional few adjustments at the music delivery point, to compensate for the acoustically variable environments the unit will find itself in, could add tailored convenience.Regarding the 6 channels/stations and the display: more presets would seem like an easy addition, since there is no actual downloading of a music library and therefore its memory requirements remain minimal. And for what may qualify as the most obscure problem in any review: the text presented on the units display should gently fade in and out when cycling. Each time a new description (track, artist, album, whatever) abruptly pops up on the bright, harsh, bluish-white on black display, it demands my eyes attention, if only for an instant. An admittedly minor, but irritating, distraction. Include a dimming option, perhaps?4.5 stars would probably be my preferred ranking. But I think I do love it. So, 5.

I received this item free of charge in return for an honest, unbiased review.Anyone who wants a mechanical view wristwatch should probably find something - anything - else. Just not this. I wont elaborate on subjective topics such as the design, or quality of the engraving (stamping, actually) since this is clearly not a thousand+ dollar watch, despite any future MSRP claims. This formerly prestigious brands name was purchased, after it declared bankruptcy, by Hollywood-based Swiss Watch International.Cons:- Massive, thick, heavy- Very difficult to read: hands are thin, dark blue, and get lost in the busy face and metallic perimeter- "Marquis de Sade meets Origami" wristband mechanism is bizarre; difficult (and sometimes painful) to use- Rose-gold finish looks odd - though maybe that's just mePros:- Mechanism is somewhat interestingIf the manufacturer is interested in improving this product:  - make the hands larger/discernible amid all the details  - make the perimeter dark so that the Roman numerals can be seen - maybe make the numerals a bit larger, too  - use a wristband mechanism that doesnt require an hour to deconstruct its usageIt seems to keep fairly accurate time. And the self-wind works as advertised, as does the manual option.

I received this item free of charge in return for an honest, unbiased review.All printing was done from iOS, using two different MacBook Airs (one on a 4.2Ghz wireless channel and another on a 5), an iPad and an iPhone. Everything worked properly, with seemingly no compromises. Copying from the front control panel also worked smoothly.Pros:- ease of setup; accurate, comprehensive instructions.- reliable wireless operation - via network or connected as a client to the printer.- printer/queue properly deleted a print job imm. before being printed - wow.- ink system superior to cartridges, with a smaller plastic/petroleum footprint.- copying allows enlarge/reduceCons:- color reproduction quality on photo paper- light construction, raises longevity as a question mark.Overall, configuring and using this printer, wirelessly, was almost too easy. It all worked exactly as advertised with not one hiccup from any device.It also held a particularly nice surprise. While testing, I realized I was about to print the wrong image.. and I was able to cancel the print job at the very last second. That has never worked for me. Ever. So far I havent wasted a single sheet of paper, which is unheard of when starting off with any printer Ive ever had.The ink wells are impressively sized, and should produce a serious volume of pages. For a small business, this printer type is a good alternative, provided the ink refilling procedure doesn't intimidate you. While the cartridge type printers are pretty much foolproof, this design, if only by virtue of avoiding a lifetimes worth of little plastic/petroleum cartridges, seems to be a better way to go. When filling the ink-wells, do use rubber gloves, and several layers of newspaper as a drop cloth - it saved my bacon.Utilizing the copying functionality from the front control panel (which would benefit from being a bit larger) was challenging at first. The minuscule display, and layout of the menu options requires some familiarization. But an enlarge/reduce function (yay!) more than makes up for an initial learning curve.Printout quality overall was good, but as a test, I compared the Epsons output to a veteran HP PhotoSmart 380 series, 4x6 printer, which is a small but specialized unit. I inserted a few sheets of HP 4 x 6 everyday photo paper, and selected the proper size on the laptops driver/printer configuration. The Epson paused at the print request, with the front panel alerting, and requesting selection of another paper size and type. All good so far. But the quality of the photo was not great. A section of the image with uniform color showed irregularities, making the original, smooth surface appear like snakeskin. Its as if the dyes fought one another and were unable to properly blend. Regular paper was better, but obviously lacked the pop of the photo-type.One other matter is the fact that it weighs very little and seems a bit thin in construction. So far, its worked fine, with the control panel and selection buttons proving solid enough - but I would be careful not to bang it around too much. In the past, Epson products in my world have had excellent reliability. If this one proves otherwise, I'll be back here.So while it doesnt do everything perfectly, the flexibility of the wireless printing access makes this a delightful printing treat for home. For the short-on-quality photo printing and small screen/interface, I remove one star.
Good price, nice large bowl.  Great for baking or large salads.

We had been looking for a new inside back stair light fixture but could't find that we liked or wanted to pay that much for.  Then we saw this on Amazon... and we are very happy with the looks, light, and price.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest unbiased review.I had no idea that was such a thing as clear cinch bags.  I really like the idea for storing things, winter clothing, Christmas items, my large yarn stash, and numerous other things that I have yet to discover.I have already used several in my kitchen trash container.  I am more than pleased with their size, thickness and strength.  The first day that I put it into my trash can every time I looked at it from a distance, I forgot that the bag was clear and kept saying to myself, 'how could I have forgotten to put a bag in the can'.....not the thinking of an Einstein, but of a very busy housewife who doesn't think about her garbage that often :-)

I received this product free-of-charge in return for an honest, unbiased review.Pros:- excellent build and sound quality- sleek design/appearance- reliable bluetooth connectivity- headband spring tension - and rubber keeper band - holds onto your head- good battery life + std. mini-usb charging- lightweightCons:- tactile identification (and even operation) of the very small buttons is difficult- headband spring tension could numb your earlobes- poor microphone for phone calls.- flashing night light only covers rearThese are solid headphones that carefully prioritize features geared toward active listening.It does, irritatingly, misfire on some functionality which other phones manage to nail - namely allowing your fingers to easily and reliably feel their way onto the correct button and then operate said button easily. Although the volume/bass drop is reliably accessible, the other feature buttons virtually require your taking the phones off, which is not good.Also, if you choose the white model, it's very hard to leave it behind.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest unbiased review.I have been using Reynolds Heavy Duty Foil for many years.  Occasionally I USED to buy cheaper brands to save money, but I learned from experience that I really wasn't saving anything as I had to use twice as much as it was thinner and tore easily.Yes, it is more expensive than some other brands, but since I use less and am more than satisfied with the end result, it is well worth the extra cost.  If I am just baking, or reheating something small, sometimes I don't bother to use a small pan, I put the food directly on the foil and it is heavy enough to hold it when I lift it out of the oven.It's great for lining casserole dishes, broiler pans, wrapping things to freeze and so many other things.This 130 feet box is a good value too at the Amazon price of $8.72.Like other reviewers mentioned, my box arrived a little bit beat up on both ends.  I taped the ends and the box is fine now.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest non-biased review.A build quality failure occurred within the first few minutes of use.  When I attempted to release my iPad screen from the locked viewing position, a magnet detached itself from the holding frame.  Belkin's glue wasn't as strong as the magnet's pull.  You can avoid this by sliding the iPad in and out of position and not lifting it straight up.  But that is still a poor design.Although the case is nice looking and appears to be well made, personally, I find it to be rather heavy and with my iPad inserted, it is too heavy to carry in my purse or in a tote.A deal breaker as far as I am concerned, is that it does not go into sleep mode when the cover is closed.  Since most of us are used to this automatic function, it is easy to neglect shutting it off before closing the cover, and wasting the battery on the iPad itself.The attachment mechanism is OK, and does hold the tablet securely in place.The keyboard is easy to use and the keys have a nice spring to them. I found no fault with the keyboard itself and enjoyed using it.  If the battery itself does in fact stayed charged for six months, that alone would be worth ten stars.Some features are definitely worth 5 stars and others 1-3 stars, so I averaged out my review to 3 stars.Would I buy it .... definitely no as it lacks the automatic sleep system when the cover is closed.  I have already inadvertently closed it several times without manually shutting the iPad off, which cost me a portion of my battery's charge.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for writing an honest unbiased review.I have been using my FoodSaver and FoodSaver bags for many years and I have always been pleased with the results.  This is the first time that I  have used GameSaver bags.I held a FoodSaver bag and a GameSaver bag side by side and truthfully I couldn't see any difference.  Since I  have always had excellent results, freezer-wise, with the regular bags, I am expecting to see the same results with these GameSaver bags.Since only time will tell, I can't honestly say that they are any better.My five star rating is based on my expectations, based on my many years of using FoodSaver bags.  I'm sorry that I can't be more conclusive.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest unbiased review.I have been using FoodSaver and FoodSaver bags for many years and have always been satisfied with the results.  This is my first time using the larger GameSaver bags.They seem to be a bit thicker than the regular bags that I have been using.  Yesterday I cooked several large batches of several soups and stew like dishes and they went into my bags last night and then into the freezer.I like that they are 11" wide and can accommodate servings for 3 people at one time.At this point in time I cannot comment on the freezer life of the bags and contents, but since they are FoodSaver bags, I feel that they will protect my food as well, if not better than their bags that I have been using.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest, unbiased review.I hate to admit this, especially to strangers, but my hair is thinning on top and without something to keep it in place, I look like Einstein on a bad hair day ---- according to my lovely wife.It holds my hair in place fairly well.  It's easy to gauge the amount by spraying it onto onto my palm first, rather than into directly into my hair, and then working it into into my damp hair. If I need a bit more, it's easy to repeat it with with a few more sprays, with the bottle resting on the countertop.I can definitely feel it on my hair, holding it in place, but it is not a stiff feel, if that makes any sense.  I do know it is there, by the way it holds my hair in place.The first time that I used it, I noticed a chemical smell. The next and subsequent times, I did not notice the smell at all.  Unlike most gel products, it is very easy to rinse off of my hands.I gave it four stars instead of five, because I have to use a lot of this product, numerous pumps.  to achieve the hold that I desire, and I have no idea how long this container will last.I have never used a non gel sculpting gel before and I am very satisfied with this product.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest, unbiased review.It appears to be extremely well made.  It has two zippered compartments on the front side  and the back is one large zippered compartment.  One of the front compartments is heavy mesh, the black part in the picture, and is see through.  This is an excellent feature. I only gave it 4 stars, as I wish that the see through compartment was larger or that there were two of them, making it easier to see the contents.I already have it filled with pencils, pens, erasers, a few paper clips,some scotch tape etc.. a walking office.  The binder holes are heavy duty grommets.  I expect this to last for a long long time ... but again, I wish it had a larger or more mesh compartments.

I've had a set of these canisters for many years.  A few weeks ago I dropped and shattered my sugar canister.The only thing that is different is the top.  My old one, and the others in my set have a flat wooden top with a gasket that makes it air proof.This new  does not have the flat wooden top, but has a small knob.  It does keep it airtight (I think) but truthfully the small knob is a pain.  You have to handle it very carefully when putting on or removing the top.  I am so afraid that it will slip out of my hand and break.  Also when I put it back on, I have to push it in to make sure that it seals.I am keeping it because apparently this is the only one that Harry Watson makes that is terra cotta and basically matches my other canisters.If I could find my old stye, with the flat wooden top, I would gladly return this one, but I guess they are no longer making them.Aside from the top, it looks nice and apparently seals my sugar tightly.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an unbiased, honest review.I originally got this product for my husband who has thinning, fly-away hair in front.  He didn't like the smell and only used it once.  I decided to try it myself and I liked it very much.First of all, I did not find the smell off putting.  I have been using it for a week or so and my sometimes frizzy hair has behaved beautifully.  It lays smoothly and without a heavy gel feeling that I have found it so many other products.  It is not plastered down, yet stays in place.After washing, I put on conditioner and then while my hair is still wet, I put on some of this gel and then blow dry it.I got my husband to try it again (no mean feat) and he said that the smell no longer bothers him.  His front hairs stay in place and look nice all day.  I told him that when he is at work and in the bathroom, to wet lightly wet his hand and push it over the top of his hair.  He has been doing that and when he comes home, his hair is still is in place and looks nice... he no longer looks like Einstein.

I needed some inexpensive small scissors to wear around my neck to cut yarn on the zillions of granny squares that I am making for an afghan.  I didn't want to use my expensive needlepoint/embroidery scissors and 'thought' that these would be a good alternative.  I relied on the DMC brand name, thinking that they probably weren't the best for that price,  but would at least be of a descent quality.  Since they were sealed in plastic, I couldn't try them before I bought them.Boy was I wrong.  They are cheaply made and are VERY stiff and they bind occasionally.  In other words, they do not operate smoothly.  My husband put a bit of oil by the screw, but it didn't do much good.  They cut the yarn easily enough, but since they are new, I don't know how long the blades will stay sharp.I'll use them until they are dull and then toss them.  Lesson learned ... you get what you pay for and you can't blindly trust a brand name.

I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest unbiased review.I have been using these bags for sometime now, and I am very impressed with the ease that they zip and unzip.  I use them for leftovers and occasionally to freeze food for short periods of time.  If they are in the freezer for  any length of time, they tend to get frost on the outside and occasionally on the food inside.I also carry snacks and my dog's cookies when I am the go.I find them to be invaluable when I travel.  I use them for cosmetics, medications, lotions, and other small objects.  They contain any leaks from gels or other liquid items. They keeps things organized and readily available in my luggage, especially in my carryon wheelies and my tote.  Of course I put my liquids in them for security checks.I also use them for my various craft supplies, especially for my crochet doodads.While I was writing this review, I suddenly realized how often I rely on them and use them for so many aspects of my life.  :-)
I make cookies for my dogs and have for many years.  I grind the cubes into powder and add to my cookie dough.  All of my dogs have loved it and a few even stood by the oven as they were baking.

It may work, but I suffered a lot of hair loss after the first shampooing.  I tried it several more times, and the hair loss continued, so I stopped using it.  The seller was more than fair when I complained and they said that the shampoo was too strong for my hair and returned my purchase price.So, in all fairness, I can only speak for my own results.  Others said that it helped them, but I will never know.... hair loss vs psoriasis... not a fair challenge. :-(

My little fur baby was developing dry flakey spots.  A friend recommended this product and I have been very pleased with the fast results.  The flakiness disappeared within a few weeks and my little guy gulps down his dry food as soon as he smells the oil.  I give it to him for his morning meal.The only down side, which is minimal, is that his beard smells after he eats and I have to clean his face, but that is a small sacrifice for what it does to his coat.Based on  our success with it, I would definitely recommend it to others.

I was received this bath rug for free in exchange for an honest, unbiased review.It is a quality made, attractive and very absorbent bath rug.  The lattice design is so much more attractive than my other solid color mats.  When I step out of the tub onto this rug, my feet sink in and it feels very plush.I have not had to wash it yet, but when I do, I will follow the manufacture's instructions and wash it in cold water, but I will line dry it as I know that will extend the life of the rubber bottom.  I do this will all of my bath rugs, with excellent results.I am going to order it in other colors also, but I am unable to find a matching toilet rug to go with it.Obviously I am totally satisfied with this rug and I hope it will last a long time with proper care.

It fits my oven perfectly and works beautifully for keeping pizza delivery warm in the over and for reheating bread, rolls etc.  I had a hard time finding one that would fit my oven, but this fits the bill.

I had a difficult time using the off/on switch on the handle.  It was almost impossible for me to move.  Amazon sent me a replacement and it was even worse.  I did like the unit itself and maybe over time the switch would loosened up, but in the meantime it was almost impossible for me to use, so I returned it.Other than the switch, I was satisfied with the unit.
I use these regularly for my kitchen garbage, with excellent results.  I have never had a bag leak or break.
We use this tape regularly and have for quite a while.  It seals our packages well and we know they are secure when sent via UPS or USPS.

I really have to wonder why the souls who toil away in back offices at publishing houses are so relentlessly prone to exaggeration. The descriptive paragraph meant to lure one to read this novel contains every single possible bit of hyperbole: "wickedly funny", "totally engaging", "richly observed", "wildly colorful", "flamboyant" and more. For heaven's sake, enough! It's as if the description was written by a used-car salesman trying to unload a beater.I opted to read/review this novel in spite of the excess of stock comments. And I'm happy that I made the choice. This is one of the rare books from which I hated to be separated. I carried it with me everywhere, and resented all the driving I have to do as a matter of course, because it was time I'd have preferred to be spending with Annie McDee, her alcoholic mother, and the unexpectedly resourceful Jesse.I loved following Annie's thoughts as she creates meals that include not only food but the appropriate settings in which it has to be served. For me, this was high art, just as much as the paintings described throughout the book. I also loved the delightful whimsy of the titular painting having a "voice" of its own.There is so much to enjoy in this novel. It's one of the rare times when I truly wished I knew the author, so I could ring her up and tell her which parts I found particularly affecting, and congratulate her on a splendid piece of writing.This book deserves to top the lists! Highly recommended.

To me, Brit for Women has a strong similarity to Thierry Mugler's Alien Aqua Chic. But, happily, Brit lacks the rather harsh edge of Alien. It is an altogether softer fragrance, subtle and exotic. I have fallen in love with it. It's about to become my preferred fragrance, after decades of devotion to KL. Since I only wear fragrance in the autumn and winter, a 3.3 ounce bottle will last a good long time. I adore the now-and-then whiffs of Brit that drift past me. Lovely stuff!
Excellent. Bought a 14" iron skillet and needed a cover. This is first-rate!
I got two of these for my grandchildren. They're poor quality, and started coming apart almost immediately upon being removed from the packaging. NOT RECOMMENDED.

For the most part, I like Lynch's films, and I had hoped this book would offer some particular insights into the man. But this slim volume is such a dry, rather pedantic treatise, that I found it difficult to stick with it. It takes more than a way with words to create a biography that offers a genuinely revealing view of the subject. It takes heart and a level of caring commitment that is lacking here. Rather than a stirring interior look at the man behind the movies, the book feels more like the printed record of a lecture given to a roomful of barely awake students. Uhm, no.

This is a book that wants to be a lot of things but merely winds up being superficial on all fronts.There is an extraordinary hand-noted piece of music found in Rome that goes home with Julia, the violinist heroine, to Boston. From the moment she first plays the found waltz in the presence of her 3-year-old daughter, things go terribly wrong--in every conceivable way in this flabby narrative.Every aspect of this book feels timeworn, like parts of several novels written before, and more convincingly, by other authors. There's nothing at all fresh; the characters are wooden and predictable, and there is a lack of true emotion to situations that demand a depth of feeling in order to be meaningful to the reader.Taking on the effects of the holocaust on the Italian characters in the shared story line borders on the offensive to anyone with some genuine knowledge of this horrific segment of world history. The author rides along on auto-pilot, never digging down far enough--again-- to bring a true depth of feeling to the situations and characters she describes. This is a painful, even irritating, example of biting off way more than one can chew.There is so much wrong with this book that when I got to the aha! moment of the plot, I actually almost laughed. Sadly, this is the kitchen-sink style of writing: throw everything into the pot and hope it turns into a tasty stew. It doesn't. It's a slapdash effort that might have been a good tale if the author had dived far more deeply into the stories (there are two narrative lines) and felt the pain of her characters, rather than simply talking about it.This is a fail.

First of all, this system is HEAVY. The UPS driver had to bring it inside for me. I couldn't pick it up. Then, once inside, a lot of effort was required to unbox it. I imagined I would be receiving a smaller, more compact unit. But okay. It's Bose. It has to be great. Right???But this is not as simple as the tech-savvy reviewers would have you believe. I've only dealt previously with small, compact speakers. This required some downloading--first the app for my iMac and then the one for my iPhone. The set-up might have been easier if I'd started with the iPhone but since I wouldn't often be sending music from the phone to the Bose, it made sense to set up the computer first.So okay. First the download from the product page, followed by the installation of the app. Then some steps to get it up and running. Once comprehension kicked in, it wasn't all that hard to make the Bluetooth connection, then "mate" with iTunes and play my music. However, today when I wanted to play music (part of my review process) I found that the machine was connected to my iPhone but not the computer. In order to play from the iMac, it was necessary to select the AUX button, then open the SoundTouch app and iTunes and set everything up again.I had similar difficulties with playback from the iPhone. The remote does work but what surprised me was that once powered on, what came on was one of the NPR stations I had preset. I had to select my choice of playback manually.So ... if you're reasonably good at hooking things up (I am, but this one was/is a doozy!) it's likely you're going to have some of the same problems I've had. I'm about to call Bose for tech support. Even though I followed all the instructions I still have a lot of issues.On the plus side, the sound is great, nicely balanced with rich tones. I just wish it were a little less complicated.

Here is a recounting, in amazingly touching pictures and brief prose fragments, of the monstrous pain created by the loss of a child. It is most parents' worst nightmare: you put your toddler to bed in her crib and come the morning she is gone. Blue.With his deeply felt black-and-white images Tom Hart conveys the best memories of little Rosalie: her daily expanding discovery of the world: magical acorns, watercolors and paper to paint on, mac and cheese, a book about a boy named Louis. Rosalie comes entirely to life in author Hart's images. It's an incredible creation. He makes Rosalie so real, so alive, that we know her and mourn her loss along with her parents, Tom and Leela.This is a brave and beautiful book, a travelogue of the first steps of pain and grieving; a stunning momento mori to a lost little girl.

This is a lovely doll, not too soft but soft enough. It is sufficiently sturdy to withstand being dragged around, being chewed on and slept with, sat on and bashed. I suspect the binky (pacifier) will quickly get lost and heaven only knows what may wind up magnetized to baby Stella's sewn-on smile. This particular Stella is going to a newborn, coincidentally named Stella. A relationship that, clearly, was meant to be.I wouldn't hesitate to buy this doll (or any of her cute relatives). I can't imagine a little one who wouldn't love this baby.

This is a delightful novel, with research so seamlessly enmeshed in the prose that the reader is easily taken back in time and place. I didn't find it " ... romping and hilarious" as author Elizabeth Gilbert did, according to her cover quote. Romping? Hilarious? Come on. This is a rather gently told reimagining of a true story about the many and varied "collisions" between the louche factory owner Henry Kaufman and his thuggish cohorts and the redoubtable Constance Kopp and her sisters.My only problem with the book is the depiction of the youngest sister, Fleurette. Her behavior is more appropriate to someone much younger than 17. And while I can understand that the girl has been shaped by isolation, it's still a bit annoying in contemporary terms. But this is a small quibble, really, and doesn't negatively affect this enormously readable and charming tale.

The major minus: This stroller is h-e-a-v-y. As a grandmother (of somewhat advanced years) I can't imagine how I could possibly fold this up and get it into the trunk of my car. I suppose I was spoiled by the Maclaren strollers both my daughter and I used; various models over time weighing in at under 12 pounds.That said, what attracted me most to this stroller was the ability to have the primary seat facing backwards (instead of forwards) so that the baby could see who was pushing the stroller. Strollers used to be made that way as a matter of course, but in recent times they all seem to have forward-facing seats. I think little ones like the reassurance of being able to see who's up front, at the controls (so to speak.)I like the multi-positional reclining aspect of the seat and the large UPF-50 sun (or rain) canopy. I also very much like the idea of the second seat being included. It wipes out the need to purchase a new stroller when another baby comes along.Altogether, this is a solid, sturdy item and I definitely recommend it.

What I didn't expect when I opted to review this book was the good-natured, big-hearted narrative by author and former Alice Cooper band member Dunaway. In spite of the classic trials and tribulations common to so many rock bands - regardless of their uniqueness - Dunaway's telling of the trajectory of the band is never mean-spirited or bitter.There's a great aspect of fun and discovery to how the band came to be a great success, with its outrageous costumes, long long hair, and theatrical performances that accompanied the music. Where the misery creeps in has to do with the terrible effects of alcoholism combined with ego. Trying to hold a band together when two of its members are getting lost in an increasingly drunken fog is like trying to juggle mercury. Impossible. It falls apart, goes rolling off in every direction. Beautiful and sad.Thanks to Dunaway's unfailing grace, the book doesn't descend into ugly recriminations or horrifying revelations. It's a well-told tale that covers the delicious pleasure of working diligently toward a success that comes and then, too quickly, goes.Well worth reading.

After recently reading a number of books that have me deeply concerned about the current state of publishing, along comes The Border and restores my faith. McCammon is a writer who understands that good writing doesn't require gimmicks. This an engaging, heartfelt effort, with entirely believable characters. And the images of devastation, and the morphing, flesh-eating aliens battling overhead in bursts of red and blue lights are very vivid.Everyone comes fully to life and we are taken along on interior and exterior journeys through the ruined landscape and the damaged hearts and minds of the small group of survivors, following young Ethan as he searches for answers.What I particuarly liked -- and this may simply be a case of my personal extrapolation -- is McCammon's depiction of the warring aliens as unspeakably grotesque and emotionless killing machines. This is a viable metaphor that could apply to all aggressors: there is nothing attractive about entities who destroy everything in their paths. Much of today's world is struggling to live with creatures like this. It's a cautionary note to which we need to pay attention.I wondered how this tale would be resolved, and greatly admire the clever yet profoundly simple solution McCammon provides. This is an enormously entertaining and thought-provoking novel.Highly recommended.

I quite like period pieces--as long as they're well done and faithful to the era. This time out it just doesn't happen.Aside from being so predictable that it felt as if I'd read this book several times before, there are so many words, phrases, expressions that are contemporary that there's very little sense of events that happened 60 years ago. It's not only the author's fault, it's also the fault of the editor and the proof-reader (if they even exist anymore.) I'm willing to forgive one or two anachronisms, but when I start taking notes of the ones I find, what we have here is a book in trouble.Here are just a few:Referring to military men as "doughboys." Well, no. By WWII, they were called GIs.Supercop??? Get outta here. No way.Psycho killer? Not, at the very least, until after 1960 when Hitchcock made his creepy masterpiece.Peanut gallery. Yeah, okay. A vaudevillian term referring to people who sat in the cheap seats but popularized by the Howdy Doody Show which didn't go on the air until 1947 -- two years after the war ended.On and on and on.I disliked the characters. Again, it seemed I'd read about these same people in half a dozen other books. Stock characters, behaving in stock fashion.So, no. Give this one a pass. There are so many other, better books waiting to be read. Go for one of those.

This is a nice little machine, with a good long cord. It works well on wood floors, isn't great for carpets but did a decent job on my carpeted stairs. I don't have a ceiling fan and actually use an extendable duster to reach the higher areas/corners of my home. But for a quick go-round, it's a decent, not-too-heavy cleaner. I like the bagless aspect (our previous Dirt Devil took bags and when the machine died - fairly early on in its short life - we were left with a lot of bags.] Overall, it's okay. But if I were out shopping for a stick vacuum, I very much doubt that I would choose this one. My long-time old stick vacuum (by Eureka) actually was better, despite its minimal attachments and shorter cord. It worked equally well on carpets and floors. This one does not.

According to my daughter (who, along with my granddaughter, was one of the test subjects) this is a quality product. But its narrow width makes working on her long (below the shoulders) very thick hair, time-consuming. It worked more efficiently on my granddaughter's long, moderately thick hair. But it took a while for both of them. The vibration was a plus - "That tells me it's working" - as was the fact that it doesn't catch (or pull) the hair. So she'll be keeping it and using it in future when she isn't rushing to get out the door in the morning.

This is a book that wants to be so many things that it winds up being nothing much at all. It's got a cast of headless chickens all running madly about, brimming with emotions and overspilling tears. (Impossible to care about these chickens!) We've got marital infidelity; bullying (a deeply serious topic ineptly done); autism (which comes across as serious mental impairment, not remotely like autism - or even on the spectrum). We've got married police officers whose relationship reads like a dismal romance novel. Dead young men: suicides hanging here and there. It's a mess. How on earth did this get published? Give this one a miss.

The first surprise was opening the package to discover this item folded flat. Not what I expected, given the product page photograph. The second surprise was the very nice feel of the bin. And the third surprise was how incredibly well made it was. I'm a lifelong knitter and have a great appreciation for quality stitchwork. This piece is flawless. It's also washable - another bonus. And, finally, it was made in Vietnam, NOT in China. It's beyond difficult to find anything not made in China these days. So when an attractive, quality item shows up, I'm simply delighted.This bin will hold the small containers that are used for my grandchildren's school lunches. It's perfect for that, or for anything else that requires a bit more care in storage.Wonderful product. Recommended!

This pendant looks lovely in the product listing photograph. However, in reality, the chain seems too flimsy for the pendant. The "opal" is too obviously fake and the "diamonds" have no light to them at all. The packaging is very nice, although the outer black box containing the inner box holding the pendant arrived in pieces. Altogether, I can't conceive of wearing something so blatantly fake. My 8-year-old granddaughter, on the other hand, thinks it's very nice and she's going to play with it.Overall, the actual jewelry box gets high marks. It's a quality design, sturdy and attractive.The pendant ... yech.

Here's a book that takes off like a rocket. Taut, lean writing. Lots going on. Interesting premise, although it kept making me think of Person of Interest (the TV series.) There are quite a few similarities to that show, and the book ultimately just wasn't strong enough to keep my attention from repeatedly going back to it.There was a bit of a stock feeling to this book and its characters. And that's okay because it's a genre that calls for prototypical types. What elevates a thriller is what the author does with those types. This time out, everything holds together for a good half of the book. And then ... it rushes toward an ending that feels as if dinner was waiting, or a dental appointment. Gotta get this done and get outta here.Too bad, because the premise was intriguing. But unlike Lee Child, whose Reacher sometimes suffers injuries, Lee's Dryden is a superman - knocking off the bad guys in quantum numbers without sustaining even a scratch. Nah! It doesn't work.Three stars for the first half of the book. One and a half for the remainder, which left me thinking, Whaaat? Wait! Did I miss something?

The author has done a commendable job in creating an authentic-feeling diary, with meticulous research that doesn't in the least feel like research (which is exceedingly difficult to do). Rosette climbs off the page and stubbornly keeps hold of the reader's attention throughout a novel that brings to life the Civil War and a young bride's determination not to be left behind when her husband leaves her only days after their wedding to go off to war. Rosetta and Jeremiah are of a time and place when young people were engaged in actually living life, going to war for the stipend that would allow them to fulfill their dream of a farm out west. I suspect these characters would be horrified by the current reality of people their age welded to expensive cell phones, addicted to their invariably trivial text messages. Author McCabe succeeds in taking the reader back into a very different world, a time when the things that mattered (war notwithstanding) had considerably more heft than the current urgency of unanswered text messages. Highly recommended.
This film has NEVER been released on DVD for North American play--probably as a result of copyright issues. If you buy this DVD you are buying a bootleg copy, not a genuine factory-issued film.

Having read all the Tales of the City books, I was looking forward to the finale. Sadly, The Days of Anna Madrigal just doesn't deliver. Anna is 92 and the book reads as if it's ancient, too. It's a tired effort, lacking energy and lacking, too, the heft of a major effort to go beyond a kind of superficial, automatic writing. There's nothing particularly profound or touching, just a creaky narrative recitation that wants to be meaningful but lacks that above-mentioned effort and energy to take it to a deeper place. Too bad. It's a disappointing end to an enjoyable series.

I saw this film a number of times in my childhood and loved it. It was a favorite back then, primarily because of the two little boys who were so very different from the children I usually saw in movies. [The only child actor who made a similar impact on me back then was Brandon deWilde in Shane and Good-bye, My Lady.] I recently watched this film again and was delighted at how well it has stood the test of time. The children really are delightful and the film is an unfussy, straightforward narrative that holds one's attention. I wouldn't hesitate to show it to my grandchildren. Highly recommended.

This book is embarassingly bad. S-l-o-w and puerile. It's hard to believe that such an accomplished writer could go so far astray. The lead character Indiana is a Barbie-doll with a Valley-girl manner of speaking. The hero, a Navy SEAL is cartoonishly unbelievable. Indiana's daughter ... No. I'll stop. There's just no point to going on. These are plastic people I couldn't care about in the least. Ripper is a failed effort and not worth the time it takes to slog through the 400+ pages. Give this one a miss. Spare yourself the tedium.

I've been reading Martin Cruz Smith since the Romano Grey "Gypsy" series back in the early 70s. He has always been a writer to enjoy and admire. While Tatiana is a more slowly paced book than some previous ones, I found its pacing appropriate to the advancing age of Arkady Renko. The investigator has been around for a while now; he's taken a bunch of beatings but he is still a relentless, unstoppable pursuer of truth. Tatiana offers entertainment in its truest sense: it provides puzzles, crazy villains, and an always scary view of the Russian political and criminal climate.Ignore the complainers who posted negative reviews because they're disappointed that the author isn't writing the same book over and over again. This is quality prose with gentle touches of humor and wisdom. Even the most minor characters are fully fleshed and believable. And Arkady rolls with the punches, still standing at the end.

My daughter introduced me to these wipes when my twin grandchildren were born. I had no idea back then that the majority of baby products contain a boatload of chemicals, and that most wipes are processed with chlorine-containing chemicals and dyes, fragrances and alcohol. Yikes! Seventh Generation wipes contain none of those things and I keep packages in my home and my car--in case of spills or a need to wipe sticky hands and/or faces. I personally use them on occasion and so do my now almost seven-year-old grandchildren. We are loyal fans of all the Seventh Generation products. But the wipes were the first of their products I came to know and love.

This book has a formulaic feel to it, with a ton of cutesy gal-pal stuff, and a should-I-shouldn't-I-marry romance aspect. It's just not especially interesting or entertaining. The characters really aren't very believable, and it feels as if the author has run out of steam with this series. Perhaps it's time for her to consider moving down a less-traveled road.

This is by no means a typical thriller. The sections go back and forth in time and place and it requires concentration on the part of the reader in order to keep track of both the actions and the characters. However, it evolves into a very rewarding story with what, in old British parlance, was referred to as "a sting in the tail." The ending has an extra kick to it that works as a satisfying conclusion to a narrative that seems a bit scattered but ultimately draws everything together and makes complete sense. Well worth reading!

This book took me over so completely that I was fairly bereft when it ended. I haven't stopped thinking about it since I finished it. In particular I was deeply impressed by the author's delicacy and skill in handling multiple characters--strands of yearning and violence woven into a cohesive fabric without undue graphics that would have detracted from the narrative. There are moments of sudden warmth and moments of matter-of-fact betrayal: people simply being themselves without thinking too deeply about why they're doing the things they do. And there is an ending that is immensely gratifying; absolutely perfect in its rightness for the characters the author has brought to life. Rarely have I read anything to equal The Purchase. Most highly recommended.

When it comes to testing speakers, I like to begin by saying I am not an audiophile.  What I like is a good sounding speaker that is easy to use.I opened the Nyne TT Bluetooth speaker and saw that it came with a medium quality carrying case and a power supply with a handful of connectors that I could see are for use in various countries.  I found the connector for the United States and attached it to the power supply and charged the unit.Like most guys probably do, I did not read the directions.  It took me a few tries to figure out that to turn the unit on and off, I just had to quickly hit the power button.  I was trying to hold the button in like I have to do on another brand of Bluetooth speaker and the unit would not turn on.One thing I really like about this brand is that there are volume controls right on the speaker itself.  I really like this as I usually play music through my iPad.  I do not carry my iPad with me, I usually only carry the speaker and leave the iPad in one place as I move from room to room.  My favorite speaker does not have volume controls on the speaker itself, which forces me to find my iPad every time the phone rings or someone walks up to speak with me.  The volume button on the speaker makes it much easier to turn down the music without searching for my iPad.I would rate the sound out of this speaker to be very good.  The speaker does all ranges very well with the exception of very low bass.  I use the song Ruby Tuesday by The Rolling Stones to test a speakers capability to handle bass due to the low, double bass they use in the song.  The speaker did excellent with the exception of the lowest of the bass in the song.The only drawback with the sound of the speaker is that it does have a hiss in the background, that very much reminds me of an old TV when you flipped to a non-existent channel where the white and black things are dancing across the screen.  The sound is there when you play music if you listen closely.  My solution is to just turn the music up louder until I cannot hear it anymore.The loudest volume of the speaker is not the loudest I have had out of a Bluetooth speaker, but it is pretty loud.Overall, I am quite pleased with this speaker.  It is not my favorite Bluetooth speaker I own, but it is a very close second (and I mean very close).

0:45 Mins Let me begin by saying I am not an audiophile.  I like something that is easy to use and gives good sound quality without a ton of effort.  I reviewed the speaker with this in mind.The Nyne Aqua is the 4th Bluetooth speaker I have owned.  This is one of those few times where I think the product is good and mediocre at the same time.I like to play music through my iPad via Bluetooth speakers.  Without even opening the directions, I was able to quickly and easily pair the speaker with my iPad.  One thing I really liked about this speaker was that it has volume controls on the speaker itself.  Sometimes, I will set my iPad in one place and only bring the speaker with me.  I like my music loud.  My favorite speaker (SOL REPUBLIC Deck Ultra) has no volume controls on the speaker itself and if my kids or someone tries to talk to me, I have to either power off the speaker or find my iPad and turn the volume down there.  I really like the volume controls being right on the speaker so I can turn it down when I need to in a hurry.The loudest output of the speaker is good, but it is not enough to completely "blow me away".  It is loud, but for me, it was not loud enough to really impress me.When the speaker is used in a dry environment, the sound is good to great.  The high end of the speaker sounds great in my opinion.  There is a constant, low volume hiss in the speaker when you put your ear up close when nothing is playing, but nothing that really distracts from the music.Where I am dissatisfied in most portable speakers is with the bass.  When it came to the bass, I would say this speaker is better than average, but was not great.  When I played "Another One Bites The Dust" by Queen, the bass guitar solo really comes through nicely.  However, when I played Ruby Tuesday by The Rolling Stones, this is where the speaker fell short.  The speaker cut out the low end of the double bass in the song.  I could still hear the double bass distinctly though, which is a huge improvement over most of my other speakers and sound output devices I have used.Where I really think the speaker fell flat was the sound when the speaker was being used in a wet environment.  The speaker floats as advertized.  I was able to submerge the speaker and spray it for several minutes with the shower head and the speaker continued working.  However, with even the smallest splash of water over the speaker, the sound gets terribly distorted and muffled.  If the speaker portion is kept dry, then the sound remains decent and clear.Personally, I would give the speaker of 4 stars when dry and 2 stars when wet.  This is my first waterproof speaker I have tried in a wet environment.  Perhaps this is the best "wet" use speaker on the market, but I was just not impressed with the sound of the speaker when it got wet like I might expect it would be in a pool with kids or a hot tub full of drunks.  Averaging the ratings, I will give the speaker 3 stars.

After having had a toy accidently thrown through the screen of my Samsung Plasma TV, I had gone out and bought an LG 50LB5900 LED TV.  While I really liked the video aspects of the TV, the factory speakers were terrible.  Despite the TV being only across the room, I would constantly have to have the TV volume turned up to the 70s to 90s out of 100 to be able to hear the TV.  I then opted to purchase the LG NB4543 sound bar.  I chose this product simply because it was the same brand as the TV and it was on sale at the time I needed it.Installation of the sound bar was quite easy.  The sound bar has HDMI, USB, optical, and a portable device interface (looks similar to a headphone jack, not sure of the size though).  Personally, I connected the bar to the TV via the optical port.  Upon powering up the subwoofer, the wireless subwoofer immediately synced with the sound bar.  I then set up the TV up to work with the sound bar and the sound bar and TV worked flawlessly together.Personally, I found the sound quality from the sound bar to be good to great, but not quite excellent.  The bass put out by wireless subwoofer is great to excellent.  I have the base turned up high and I honestly love the rumbling sound the subwoofer puts out during something like an artillery attack in a movie.I also think the high end on the sound bar is great.  The sounds on the high end come through clearly with great tone and volume.Where I think this speaker is lacking is in the midrange.  The bass is good and the treble is good, but there seems to be nothing in between.  While the system does not sound bad, the output at times feels like it lacks depth and is thin.Despite my perception that the midrange output is lacking with this sound bar, I am still happy with my purchase.  The output of the sound bar is 10 times better than the factory TV speakers.  I personally think this is a solid product and I am happy with my purchase.

This book caught my eye as I toyed with the idea of being in the medical profession once upon a time.  Rather than applying to med schools, I opted to take my Engineering degree and start my professional career.  As with many decisions in life, I kind of wondered what I missed by going the Engineering route instead of the medical field.  This book appealed to me as it documented a doctors first year internship at a hospital and I thought it might give me a taste of what might have been.The book is the memoir of Matt McCarthy a Harvard Medical student. The book documents Mr. McCarthys first year as a medical intern, first a brief stint as a surgeon in a Manhattan Hospital and then a bulk of the time spent rotating in Columbia University Medical Center.I did find the book a bit choppy to read as the author jumped from one rotation to the next.  The author told the stories of patients he interacted with and told them very well.  He did an excellent job detailing the personal highs and lows of the first year in his noble profession.  In a way, the book reads like a great soap opera, all the elements are there:  suspense, tragedy, self doubt, triumphs, love and caring for others, and personal growth.  While I did find the flow to be a bit off in my opinion, the stories told are great.  The book kept my attention and I was always anxious to turn the page to see how the current sub-plot would end.All in all, I really enjoyed this book.  As I mentioned, I had an interest in medicine and this really gave me a glimpse of what could have been for me.  I will say becoming a skilled doctor certainly appears to be a long, hard road filled with self-sacrifice.  If this is a subject of interest, I would highly recommend the book!

Personally, Gatorade has always been my go to product for rehydration after lengthy, strenuous exercise.  It is relatively cheap, it tastes good, it seems to get the job done, and I can drink it fast without upsetting my stomach.  I had never tried an EAS Hydrate product yet and thought I would give it a try to see how it was.I tried the product several times and I honestly did not care for the flavor.  The smell of the product once mixed is a pleasant orange smell which reminds me of Tang, though not as strong smelling.  When I take a drink, the first taste that hits me is the taste of salts.  That is quickly followed by a chemically orange flavor that I did not find pleasing.  Again, quickly following the orange was a subtle sweetness.  The finish of the flavor is this kind of pleasant sweet and saltiness on the tongue.I did not find the overall flavor of this product pleasing.  Kind of like a flat beer, it just seems that something is missing when you taste it.I checked the nutrition profile of the EAS Hydrate Workout Supplement and see that 8 ounces has 25 calories with 270mg of sodium and 180mg of potassium.  The Lemon-Lime Gatorade has about 53 calories with about 107mg of sodium and about 30mg of potassium.EAS Hydrate has almost 3 times the sodium and 6 times the potassium of Gatorade with half the calories.  Is this a good thing?  I am not sure, but my thought process is this.  If I am exercising to the point where I am worrying about my sodium and potassium levels that much, then I probably want to try to do whatever I can to be getting calories for fuel in my system as well.  I think I would be willing to sacrifice some electrolytes to gain some extra calories.I am really hoping to earn the trifecta in the Spartan Race series this year.  I found that I had problems drinking this product rapidly like if I were to drink at a water/fueling station.  There was just something about the flavor and/or composition of this particular product that just did not work for me and did not feel right in my stomach. I would not discourage anyone from trying this product to see if it works for them.  However, I personally plan on sticking with Gatorade.I also wanted to mention that I did drink several glasses of this prior to going to bed after drinking a lot of beer at a beer festival a few weeks back.  As I got older, I seem to be much more prone to hangovers.  However, I did wake up feeling great the next morning.  I will be trying this product again as a hangover preventative.

I ordered this wiper to put on the windshield of a 2002 Ford Explorer.  I usually use Anco 30-22 Winter Wiper Blades on my vehicles.  I put the Bosch 4922 on one side and left the 12 month old Anco 30-22 Winter Wiper on the other.Installation of the Bosch 4922 was a little different, but easy enough to figure out.  I had the hook type wiper arm and this requires flipping a piece molded into the wiper.  It required a little manipulation to get it out, but I was able to flip the part out and easily connect the wiper to the wiper arm.I used the Bosch 4922 wiper for about a month.  After a month, the Bosch wiper seems to clean the windshield quite well.  However, comparing the Bosch wiper side by side with a year old Anco Winter wiper, I really did not see a ton of difference.  The current price for the Bosch 4922 is about $19 per wiper and the current price for the Anco 30-22 winter wiper is about $9.50 per wiper.  Based on what I have seen thus far, I am not sure the Bosch 4922 is worth the extra money.  However, the Bosch 4922 wiper does work well and other than the significantly higher current price, I would have no issues recommending it.

This is my first time using the Turbo Tax line of tax preparation software in over a decade.  I have been a loyal H&R Block software user for many years.  I thought I would give Turbo Tax a try after being away from it for a number of years.There is nothing really extra ordinary in the taxes I prepare.  My taxes mainly consist of work income, interest, dividend, and investment sales.  I have a mortgage and pay property taxes on several parcels of land.  I have a relative that lives in Alaska that I help with their taxes, so I do deal with the Alaska Permanent Fund Dividend payout and retirement income there.Loading the software onto a PC was quite easy, though it did seem to take a bit of time to load.  I imported my H&R Block tax return into Turbo Tax without any issues at all.Updating last years information and entering new information into Turbo Tax was easy and for the most part uneventful. The only thing I really did not like with the Turbo Tax software was that it was not obvious where to enter the Alaskan Permanent Fund Dividend information for federal taxes where in the H&R Block software it was much more obvious.Comparing my experiences between H&R Block and Turbo Tax, I found both programs to be very similar and both to be very easy to use.  Personally, if I have to choose between the two, it would 100% come down to price.  For the 2014 software, I would need Turbo Tax Premium to deal with investment income or H&R Block Deluxe.  At the time of this review, H&R Block Deluxe is about half the price of Turbo Tax Premium.  While the Turbo Tax software does the job just fine, it really seems to be a poor value for the money.  H&R Block Deluxe is a very similar product, does just as good of a job, and the cost is half as much.Unless you have a strong attachment to Turbo Tax for some reason, I would recommend passing on this product and picking up H&R Block software.

I am always misplacing my kitchen thermometers.  As such, I am always in the market for a new one.  Seeing this item interfaced with a smart device, I thought it would be neat to try.I unboxed the unit and it basically consists of the thermometer unit and a metal probe.  The thermometer unit is about the size of a doctors stethoscope.  The probe plugs into the thermometer unit and the cable measured in at 4 feet.I opened the provided quick start guide and I personally found the quick start guide very lacking in directions.  Once I knew how to operate the thermometer, the quick start guide made sense.  However, I personally needed to go to the companys website and download the full user manual, which can be found at  http://idevicesinc.com/kitchen-thermometer/downloads/KTmini-user-manual.pdfThe full user manual lists the following devices as compatible with the thermometer (the quick start guide makes no mention of the supported hardware platforms that I see):-iPhone (4S and later)- iPad (3rd generation and later)- iPad mini (all generations)- iPod touch (5th generation and later)-many Android devices equipped with Bluetooth 4.0 and running Android software version 4.3 or laterAfter a failed attempt to use an iPad 2nd generation (as the quick start guide did not specify what I could use with this product), I loaded the app onto an iPad mini.  I found the app to actually be quite user friendly and very intuitive to use.  Referencing the full user manual mentioned above, I was able to connect the thermometer to my iPad via Bluetooth and was able to start measuring temperature.After using this thermometer, I will say what I would not recommend it for.  If you are looking for something to use as an instant read thermometer, I would look elsewhere.  While this will work just fine to check the temperature of that hamburger patty in the frying pan, it takes too much time to set up and there are much more convenient alternatives out there.What this unit does excel at is measuring the temperature of anything that take some time to cook.  If you are heating water to a certain temperature to make homemade beer, smoking meat, or making a turkey in the oven, I think this is an excellent unit.  The app plots the temperature at the probe over time, so you can tell how fast the food item is heating up and tell if it is maintain temperature and make heating adjustments accordingly.Once I got past learning how to connect the thermometer to my iPad mini, I really liked the device.  Again, I would not use this to quickly check the temperature of something, but is awesome for monitoring longer cooking items.

I had one of the old style versions of the Foreman Grill in the late 1990s.  While I was not watching my fat intake at that point of my life, I did like the small, compact design and how it cooked from both sides.  I recall using it quite a bit for cooking preformed, frozen hamburger patties.  These patties always seemed to consist of high fat meat and the Foreman Grill was awesome for cooking these easily and quickly when I worked nights.  While I do not recall what happened to my first grill, I do recall that I did not like cleaning the grill as the plates were not removable and I recall that there were no controls whatsoever.  I was quite interested to see how 10+ years has changed the concept of the Foreman Grill.This version of the Foreman Grill is much bigger, measuring roughly 15x12x6 inches.  The cooking surface will very easily fit 2 large meat patties or two slices of bread/sandwiches.  The grill is designed so that it can be used as a flat cooking surface or tilted so that the fats and juices run off into a collection reservoir.There are three huge improvements over the original model.  The first is removable plates.  Rather than having to try and clean the surface of the grill with the cooking surfaces attached, the plates can easily be removed and cleaned in the sink.  The second is digital controls.  The grill controls have temperature adjustments and has a built in timer.  The third is the sear option.  I think the short, high heat initial cooking option adds excellent flavors to meatsI played around with the grill and cooked several items.  From powering the grill on to the 300F mark is a 5 minute wait time.  From 300F to the 500F sear heat is an additional 5 minutes (or about 9.5 minutes from cold to 500F).  The grill comes with an instruction book that gives you an idea of times to cook various items as well as having cooking guidelines on the front surface of the upper portion of the grill.  I really love the sear option.  I have been using this a lot with fresh hamburgers.  The sear option perfectly seals and slightly caramelizes the meat resulting in an excellent burger.  I also played around with making grilled cheese sandwiches with the grill.  This took a little practice.  There was a very small window between getting a perfect grilled cheese and two slices of toasted bread with all the cheese squished out.Another thing worth mentioning is that the cooking plates are now ceramic coated instead of Teflon type.  However, the waffle plates appear to be the traditional Teflon type cooking surface.  The ceramic plates do clean up quite easily.Overall, I am quite happy with this Foreman Grill.  If this type of appliance is something if interest, I would highly recommend it!

I have always wanted to find a reliable, small, remote control flier of some sort.  I have tried a few RC helicopters, but managed to break then in record time.  I thought I would give the Parrot MiniDrone Rolling Spider a try.Unboxing the unit, I was initially impressed.  The unit is fairly small, about 3/4th the size of my hand and about two fingers high.  The flier is a basic quadricopter design and has no guards around the propellers.  The propellers are a thin plastic material while the chassis is what appears to be a thicker, much stronger plastic construction.I downloaded the Free Flight 3 app onto an Apple iPad Mini and attempted to fly.  While the quick start guide will get you up and running, it is virtually of no help after that.  I had never used this app before and could not figure out how to fly the thing to save my life.  Thankfully, after reading a few reviews here on Amazon, I found someone pointed to the user guide at the URL:  http://parrotcontact.emencia.net/website/user-guides/download-user-guides.php?pdf=rolling-spider/Rolling-spider_User-guide_UK.pdfAfter downloading the User Guide, I was able to get an idea of how to fly the thing, use the acrobatic tricks, and take some photographs.Personally, I have not used the wheels.  Using the wheels obviously adds weight and cuts down on the already short flight time.  In a place without winds such as in a building, the Rolling Spider is incredibly stable and easy to fly.  Flight is accomplished by tilting your iPad or smart device in the direction of desired travel.  The app is loosely a joystick and button design.  The left joystick controls altitude and rotates the drone on the XY plane (left or right).  The right button is used to activate motion in the drone as well as trigger a few acrobatic tricks.  The acrobatic tricks are mainly 360 rolls in the forward, backward, left, and right directions.Flying the unit outside is a bit more challenging with the winds involved.  While the Rolling Spider does remain stable, the winds will push it around and requires the user to compensate with the controller if attempting to keep the drone in a certain area.The Rolling Parrot is equipped with a camera.  I found the images it takes tend to have a washed out color and appear grainy.  When you take a picture, the image is not sent back to the controlling device.  Rather, you have to connect the drone to a PC and download them, much like you would with a SD card from a digital camera.The battery does not have a very long life.  On a charge, you will get about 8 minutes of flight without the wheels.  I have been charging the unit via the USB port on my PC and it required approximately 60 to 90 minutes to get a full charge.In my month of usage, I have crashed the Rolling Parrot numerous times.  For the most part, the unit has come away unscathed.  It seems that occasionally a crash might push on a propeller and tightens the propeller down and I am guessing causes that particular propeller to turn slower.  This resulted in the unit moving in one direction very rapidly and crashing.  Usually the 2nd crash fixes the propeller issue.  At another point, my unit did quit charging and would not turn on.  I fixed this easily by reseating the battery.  Nothing has broken on the unit this far.  I have had a propeller fall off, but they are easily pushed back on.Overall, the unit is fun and easy to fly once you learn the basics.  However, I found the included documentation to be poor at best.  There is nothing on the app that teaches you how to use the various options on the app.  Also, the flight versus charge time is approximately 1 minute of flight to every 7 minutes of charging.  Personally, I think the company could have done a little better than this.

For the longest time, I felt a flashlight was a flashlight.  Honestly, whenever I needed one, I would just buy the cheapest one available.  The only exception to this was a 3 D cell Maglight I used to carry with me when I worked overseas and that had more to do with being able to use the flashlight as a weapon in a bind more than the light quality.  I have to say I was curious what might make the Goal Zero 250 worth the current asking price of $80.The Goal Zero Portable Torch 250 weighs in at 15 ounces and measures about 10 inches x 3.125 inches x 1.5 inches at the widest points.  The cross section of the flashlight is trapezoidal rather than the traditional round shape.The flashlight does not have replaceable batteries like one might expect on a flashlight.  The unit is charged via solar, hand crank dynamo, or via a USB cable.  The solar seems to be painfully slow and the handcrank seems to only provide minimal power for use in an emergency and the batteries are drained.  One of the great things about this flashlight is that the USB cable to charge the unit is permanently fixed to the flashlight housing so there is no cable to look for when it needs to be charged.The flashlight itself has 3 lighting options, a white spotlight, a red spotlight, and a white flood light.  Both white lights have a high and a low setting and the red LEDs have steady and flashing settings.  I do have to say the lighting aspects of the flashlight are outstanding.  The spotlight is bright and nicely focused.  At about 200 feet, I would estimate the illuminated area is only about 15 feet across.The floodlight is very good for illuminating a much larger area and I also think it does an excellent job.  I was recently using the flood light to evaluate a landscaping project in the dark and was able assess the work I needed to do in the morning.I personally have not used the red LEDs a great deal.  They seem to illuminate enough to see where you are going in the dark or read something close up in the dark.The flashlight also has a USB port to use to charge an external device.  I tested this and I was able to charge several devices off of the USB port.Honestly, I have to say that this has become my favorite flashlight.  I like the ability to charge via solar and the fact it has a hand crank dynamo in the event of an emergency or a sustained power outage.  I also like the fact that the unit can be used to charge electronics if I am not near a power source or if there is no power.  The flashlight puts out quality light and overall, I am quite happy with this product.

The Black and Decker 8-Slice Extra Wide Toaster Oven is quite impressive in some aspects.  As advertised, this toaster oven will easily fit a 13x9 inch baking pan and have room to spare on all sides.  The unit is also capable of broiling items which I find very handy.  Simply move the rack up to the top, throw cheese on top of my nachos in the pan provided and viola, in 60 to 90 seconds I have perfectly browned, melted cheese!On the flip side, there were a few things I did not care for.  To make toast in this oven on the medium setting takes roughly 4 minutes (and personally, I like my toast a little darker than what the medium setting gave me, so for me, it takes even longer).  I am not sure if this oven actually holds 8 slices, but I am sure it does for a reason.
