The Bissell 1548 is a heavy vacuum cleaner.  It is not intended for the elderly and infirm.  The greatest difficulty I experienced was in maneuvering it up and down the carpeted steps between my condo's floors.  The cord was plenty long.  While I pushed the vacuum, used water was transferred to the Dirty Water Tank.  The Dirty Water Tank surprised me.  The water was very cloudy.  I didn't realize my carpet was that filthy.  Even though it looked clean, it wasn't.  Also, the tanks are small.  I had to empty them several times before the entire condo had been wet vacuumed.  In Deep Clean Mode, our carpet took a long time to dry.  It wasn't until the next morning that we could really walk on it without our socks becoming soggy.  From now on, we'll use the Express Clean Mode.  The attachments did a great job of removing cat hair from couches and chairs in the den.  The cats love to snuggle on this furniture when we are not around.  Upon coming home from work, Tammy or I will catch them sleeping on the furniture.  They will awake, jump off the furniture and dash up the stairs.  When the carpet was wet, they were afraid to leave the third floor bathroom and venture downstairs.  As I stated earlier, the Bissell 1548 Wet Vacuum Cleaner did a great job of refreshing my carpet.  However, there were some stains in Sue and Bill's bedroom that could not be removed.  These were near the area where the dresser had been sitting and in the walk-in closet.  No matter how many times I ran my vacuum over them, the stains would not go away.  Fortunately, I am a realistic person and don't expect miracles.  Overall, the vacuum cleaner did a great job.  I would have had to pay nearly two hundred dollars for professional cleaners.  (That is why I never had my carpets steam cleaned--too expensive.)  For home use, I highly recommend the Bissell 1548.  It will pay for itself after the first few times of using it.

My favorite styling gel is Biolage Gelee Firm Hold Gel from Matrix [BIOLAGE by Matrix GELEE FIRM HOLD GEL 16.9 OZ ( Package Of 4 )].  For Christmas, Mom always gives me a large 16.9 ounce bottle; she buys it from the hair salon located inside a department store at Foothills Mall in Maryville, Tennessee.  She must wait until it is on sale because Matrix products are expensive.  Recently, the Amazon Vine Program offered me Suave Professionals Sculpting Gel, Firm Control, 7 ounces.  The Suave gel works just as well as the Biolage gel but is less expensive.  Normally, my light-brown hair is very straight, thin, fine, and unmanageable.  Thankfully, the Suave gel leaves my hair feeling soft and fluffy and it holds my simple style.  A little dab goes a long way.  Also, the gel is clear in color and virtually odorless.  I simply use my fingertips to spread it throughout my wet, freshly washed hair.  Then I comb and blow dry it.  In the past, I have used many Suave products.  They range from bottles of 2-in-1 shampoo + conditioner to body lotions.  Suave products generally work as well as their more expensive counterparts.  I plan to introduce Mom to the Suave Professionals Sculpting Gel, Firm Control.  It works as well as the Biolage Gelee Firm Hold Gel from Matrix.  I want Mom to save her money for more important items such as life-saving medications.

I played with Legos and Lincoln Logs when I was a child.  I probably played with them for too many years.  I enjoyed creating large buses, buildings and boats and then destroying them as though they were props in a disaster film such as Earthquake, The Towering Inferno and The Poseidon Adventure (1972).  Receiving the Green Toys Block Set brought back a lot of good memories from my childhood.  Before allowing my neighbor child, Ryan, to play with the blocks, my girlfriend, Tammy, and I played with them.  We created a game where we took turns buiding something tall and spectacular within one minute.  We had to use all eighteen pieces.  We would take photos of our structures with our iPhones and judge who had the best creation.  I won because I have the greatest (or most warped) imagination.  The Green Toys Block Set came with all eighteen blocks.  However, the colors were different from the ones on Amazons website.  I suppose the multi in the product title means that the blocks arrive in a multitude of bright, carnival-like colors.  For example, our two triangular blocks were green whereas the ones on the website are yellow.  Our four largest blocks were yellow, whereas the ones on the website are blue.  It is true that the blocks dont fit tightly together.  This is to prevent small toddlers from straining and pulling to get them free.  You dont want children hurting themselves.  The blocks will fit together, but not tightly.  The blocks themselves are so huge that they would be impossible for a baby to swallow.  I feel comfortable leaving them in the presence of a baby.  We plan on allowing Tammys infant grandniece, Claire, to play with them when shes older.  Our neighbor child, Ryan, who is approximately three, played eagerly with them.  I think, however, he would have liked to have had more blocks.  Eighteen wasnt enough.  When he gets older, hell definitely want more.  I highly recommend the Green Toys Block Set.  The blocks are made of 100% recycled plastic and will safely introduce children to the world of creative blocks.  Let this be your childs Lego starter kit.

I've loved all of the Axe Products, especially the ones from the Shampoo + Conditioner line.  I only use bottles of Shampoo + Conditioner.  In the mornings, I am in a perpetual rush to get to work.  (If I don't arrive by 6:30, I don't get a parking space and must park outside the shipyard where I work.)  I don't have time to mentally debate with myself over whether or not I used conditioner the previous day.  I use conditioner every day; my hair will become very greasy if I don't.  With the Apollo, as with most all of the Axe Products, a little bit goes a long way.  I try not to squeeze too much of the blue liquid from the bottle.  It is very easy to do if I am in a hurry.  It lathers very well.  This is a major complaint from men who use a Shampoo + Conditioner product--it doesn't lather well.  However, Apollo does.  It also has a light, masculine scent that is very subtle.  I never smell it in my hair.  It quickly dissipates during the rinsing.  The Apollo cleans my hair, leaving it light and fluffy.  How do I know when my hair is clean?  When I don't feel it.  It is as though I'm bald.  I have to shake my head to feel it against my neck.  When I rub my hand through it, my light-brown hair feels silky soft.  Also, my hair is easy to style with gel.  It remains clean throughout the day and into the night.  I highly recommend Axe Apollo for all men.  In fact, I recommend all the Axe Shampoo + Conditioner products.

I was sent a generous supply of Charmin Basic Double Roll Toilet Paper; it consisted of four packs of twelve rolls.  It is named Basic because it is solid white and doesnt have a scent.  This is great for those who suffer from allergies.  Also, basic white is very easy to coordinate with any bathroom dcor.  I always purchase solid white, unscented toilet paper.  This Charmin Basic toilet paper is double roll.  Each roll has lasted me twice as long as the brand that I normally purchase.  I use toilet paper for various reasons, one of which is for blowing my nose; I suffer from chronic sinusitis.  The toilet paper is very soft; it doesnt feel rough like some brands of recycled toilet paper.  Furthermore, Ive been using Charmin Basic for two weeks and it hasnt clogged up my toilet.  Normally, I dont put too much toilet paper into my commode at one time; I flush several times to prevent clogs.  Since moving into my condo over three years ago, I havent had to call a plumber.  I highly recommend the Charmin Basic.

Honestly, I would have never chosen the Wrangler Mens Authentic Short Sleeve Performance Polo if I had known it was 100% polyester.  I stopped buying polyester over twenty-five years ago.  It makes me itch.  It doesnt breathe.  Yes, there are some advantages.  Polyester doesnt shrink when accidentally washed in warm water and doesnt need ironing.  I soon learned that this polo from Wrangler is different.  Besides being attractive and fitting well on me, it feels very comfortable.  It has moisture wicking technology that keeps you cool and dry.  It acts like cotton in that it breathes and absorbs sweat.  The next day after it arrived, I wore it with dark blue denim jeans to church, where we dress casually.  That night, I turned the polo inside out and washed it in cold water on hand wash cycle.  Then I laid it flat to dry.  It dried quickly.  I didnt need to iron it; the garment didnt have any unsightly wrinkles.  I wore it to work two days later.  Each day I wore it, I received compliments.  Furthermore, the polo always felt comfortable, never itchy.  It is not made of ordinary polyester.  I have fallen in love with this basic black polo from Wrangler.  It coordinates well with everything.  Furthermore, size Large is perfect.  I prefer my T-shirts and polo shirts to hang loose on me.  I dont want them skin tight and revealing all my unsightly bulges.  I am in my early fifties.  The younger generation, I realize, likes to wear clothing that is tight fitting.

It is 1796 and Will Rees, a traveling weaver, is in Salem, Massachusetts; he is buying cloth for his pregnant wife, Lydia.  Rees has a chance encounter with a fellow war veteran, Stephen "Twig" Eaton, who is a mortician.  At Twig's request, Will attends the wake for the wife of a wealthy maritime merchant, Jacob Boothe.  The next morning, while traveling home in his buggy, Rees is halted by a frantic Twig who informs him that Jacob has been murdered.  The tragedy has been compounded by the arrest of Twig's fiance, Xenobia, a slave of Jamaican descent. While searching for the true killer, Rees discovers that the Boothe family has many dark secrets--secrets that will cause more deaths in Salem.  An extremely dysfunctional family is the center of Eleanor Kuhn's latest Will Rees novel, "Death in Salem" [following "Cradle to Grave" (Cradle to Grave (Will Rees Mysteries)) and "Death of a Dyer" (Death of a Dyer (Will Rees Mysteries))].  Before her death, Anstiss Booth, the matriarch of the Boothe family, was kept in seclusion, her body wracked with pain; her husband, Jacob, denied her the opium she needed.  The children are spoiled.  Peggy, the youngest daughter, wishes she were a man so she could run the family business.  Her brother, William, is power hungry.  The other son, Michael, a playboy, wants to be an actor.  The oldest daughter, Betsy, wishes only to marry a wealthy gentleman, but too many family scandals may prevent this.  Also, it is rumored that Jacob Boothe was having an affair.  Salem is a strange city rich with history.  Superstition and suspicion still reign more than one-hundred years after the infamous witch trials.  Taverns have names such as Moon and Stars and Witch's Cauldron.  There is a bordello named The Black Cat.  A myriad of dark tunnels lie beneath the city.  These tunnels connect homes with warehouses, taverns and bordellos; they aid with smuggling and other illicit activities, including adulterous trysts.  Rees's life is jeopardized when he pursues a murder suspect into the tunnels.  There is a lot of tension whenever Rees travels beneath the city.  Rees's life, it appears, is in constant danger as long as he searches for an elusive killer.  To make matters worse, his pregnant wife, Lydia, comes to Salem to aid him with his investigation.  She serves as his sounding board.  I constantly feared for the safety of her and her baby.  In the last novel, "Cradle to Grave," Rees and Lydia adopted five orphans.  Rees has a fourteen-year-old son, David, from a previous marriage; David resents his father adopting more children.  Father and son don't speak.  It appears that Rees is in Salem partially to get a break from a family that has become overwhelming.  Furthermore, his sister, Caroline, is still causing grief for him.  Indeed, Rees encounters family problems and more family problems.  Rees can't escape them, whether they are his own or those of another.  He even meets a little girl, Annie, who wishes to leave her mom, One-Eye Mary, who is the madam at The Black Cat.  Annie wants to live in the Shaker community where Lydia once lived before marrying Rees.  Also, Rees gives advice to a young lad, Billy Baldwin, the same age as David, who dreams of working on a merchant ship.  Rees has a kind, generous heart.  He makes an admirable detective.  The mystery in "Death in Salem" is a complex one.  I didn't know the identity of Jacob Boothe's killer until nearly the very end.  Neither did Rees.  I almost felt as though he was adlibbing when he had gathered all the many suspects together, a la Lieutenant Columbo, and announced the killer at the end of a lengthy dialogue.  A complex mystery, coupled with a large assortment of strange characters (one of which is the extremely effeminate, foppish Deputy Sheriff Swett), a creepy setting, gruesome murders, and a lot of emotional drama, makes this novel a must read for fans of historical whodunits.  I love stepping back in time with best-selling author Eleanor Kuhns.  I can't wait to read the next novel and hope Rees spends more time with his brood of adorable children.

Two young Christian graduates of Georgia's Pentecost University, Samantha Boggs and Missy Montgomery, have disappeared while hiking the Appalachian Trail (AT) in the Hundred Mile Wilderness.  The Place Last Seen (PLS) was established at a Chairback Mountain lean-to shelter near Monson, Maine.  Game Warden Mike Bowditch and his girlfriend, Stacy Stephens, a biologist, have joined the massive search party.  There are numerous ways to die in the forest.  Are Samantha and Missy the victims of a hate crime committed by local rednecks?  Did they fall prey to a serial killer who stalks hapless hikers on the AT?  Could they have been savagely torn apart by rogue coyotes?  Or are they merely the victims of an accident that occurred when they stepped too close to the precipice of a cliff?  Mike and Stacey put their lives in danger on numerous occasions as they search for the truth.  "The Precipice" is the most disturbing, most nerve-wracking of all of Paul Doiron's Mike Bowditch novels.  It has been three days since I've read it and I still get nervous thinking about the plot.  Having grown up in Blount County, Tennessee, at the foot of the Smoky Mountains National Park, I have gone hiking on numerous occasions with the Boy Scouts and Sunday school classes.  Becoming lost in the woods has always been a genuine fear of mine.  I never stray off the designated hiking trails.  One could stumble across wild bears, boars, or wolves or someone's marijuana patch.  (I've also seen a lot of horror movies about cannibalistic hillbilly mutants.)  According to "The Precipice," every year 500 people are reported missing in Maine. Within 48 hours, most are found.  After that, the odds of them ever being found alive grow slimmer as time passes.  In the Hundred Mile Wilderness, if the mosquitoes don't eat you alive, something else will.  As I strongly suspected, "The Precipice" was a fast-paced novel with numerous shocks and grisly discoveries.  The body count was high enough to keep gore hounds, like myself, satisfied.  The disappearance of Samantha and Missy is just one of several intertwining plots that are extremely fascinating.  Whoever, or whatever, is responsible for their disappearance remains a well-guarded mystery until nearly the very end.  Unusual characters abound.  You encounter all kinds of hikers on the AT that range from very nice to very weird. All of them have pseudonyms such as Incredible Hunk, McDonut and El Chupacabra. The reader receives a crash course on hiking the AT.  For example, I didn't realize there were so many lodges, lean-tos, and shelters that hikers could sleep in.  Paul Doiron describes an exciting and beautiful, but dangerous, world that makes me want to grab my boots and commence hiking.  "The Precipice" couldn't have been published at a more opportune time.  Thanks to President Barack Obama, the Confederate flags are coming down and the rainbow flags are going up.  This novel deals with the sensitive issue of homosexuality. Readers already know that Mike Bowditch's girlfriend, Stacey Stephens, is bisexual.  There are characters who believe that homosexuality is a sin.  One of them is the gaudy, obnoxious Reverend Mott who represents the parents of the missing hikers.  Paul Doiron is one of those extremely gifted writers who can blend timely, real-life news stories with a unique setting and interesting, realistic characters.  The Maine wilderness to a city boy like me is a foreign country.  Furthermore, Mike Bowditch is an incredibly likeable protagonist whom I truly admire.  He has his flaws, but don't we all?  He's an agnostic and I'm a devout Christian.  However, I can understand when he says, "My prayers rarely come true."  In a world full of tragedy, it can be difficult to keep one's faith.  I have faith that Paul Doiron's next Mike Bowditch novel will be another bestseller.

A rescued dog, Cheyenne, has been stolen from the Tara Foundation.  Thanks to a GPS chip implanted in her collar, defense lawyer Andy Carpenter traces Cheyenne to a house where her abductor, Gerald Downey, is found with his head nearly severed from his body.  Tommy Infante is arrested for the murder.  Someone planted the bloody murder weapon in his backyard.  During his investigation to free Infante, Carpenter learns that the victim is just one of several men who have been viciously executed because of a conspiracy involving stolen diamonds.  Soon Carpenter and his whacky staff will become the next targets of a ruthless assassin.  In his latest novel, "Who Let the Dog Out?", David Rosenfelt has once again created an over-the-top thriller involving a dog and the threat to thousands of American lives.  A heinous murder grabs the reader.  Additional murders, committed by a ruthless assassin, Aleksandre, ensure a fast-paced plot.  Most of the novel, however, involves a trial in which Carpenter attempts to perform the impossible:  Have Tommy Infante declared innocent even though the evidence against him is overwhelming.  Carpenter, with his glib, witty, smart-alecky humor, always seems to outsmart the prosecuting attorney.  This time around, it is one of his oldest nemeses, Dylan Campbell--a crooked lawyer who has his sights set on a future career in politics.  At the beginning of "Who Let the Dog Out?", Carpenter has already married his long-term girlfriend, Laurie Collins, who is an ex-police officer.  He has also adopted Ricky Diaz; this adorable, nine-year-old boy was orphaned in the previous novel, "Hounded."  Ricky's basset hound, Sebastian, has become a playful companion to Carpenter's golden retriever, Tara.  Carpenter is much happier now that he has a family.  Despite being a wiseass, he is a very likeable protagonist.  In all fairness, he belittles himself as much as other people.  One example of Carpenter's humor is when he is introduced to two FBI employees, Agent Hernandez and Agent Gardiner:  "Both of your first names are Agent?  Wow, what are the odds against that?"  Even though he is a wiz in the courtroom, Carpenter would be floundering if not for his excellent staff.  Sam Willis is an expert computer hacker who is able to find hidden records on the internet.  Hike Lynch is a great assistant lawyer, but his manic depressant persona could permanently erase the huge smile on Pastor Joel Osteen's face.  Marcus is Carpenter's hired muscle; he is a large Neanderthal who listens to classical music, only grunts when spoken to, and moves faster than lightning.  He has saved Carpenter's life on more than one occasion.  After nearly thirty years working in the Federal Government, I have learned that a supervisor is only as good as their employees.  I was disappointed that more of the novel wasn't set in Maine.  Readers soon learn there is a group of terrorists concealing themselves in a remote area of Maine, primarily an island, Ashby, which is connected to the mainland by only one bridge.  A fan of Paul Doiron's Mike Bowditch mysteries, I have learned to love the Maine wilderness with its beauty and danger.  However, most of David Rosenfelt's latest novel takes place in a courtroom in Paterson, New Jersey.  The trial's outcome, however, has far more outreaching consequences other than whether or not an innocent man goes to prison.  With its zany, but lovable, characters; gruesome deaths; and intriguing plot involving stolen diamonds, "Who Let the Dog Out?" is a great installment in the Alex Carpenter series.

Goodbye summer; hello fall.  I love everything pumpkin, especially pumpkin bread, Pumpkin Pop Tarts, and pumpkin spice coffee.  Normally, I buy the type of Pumpkin Spice Coffee-mate Coffee Creamer that needs refrigeration.  I prefer the refrigerated variety over the non-dairy powder or the liquid creamer singles, both of which don't need refrigeration.  I was thrilled to receive for review the Pumpkin Spice Coffee-mate Coffee Creamer Table-Top Pump Bottle.  The table-top pump bottle arrived well packaged.  The bottle and the pump were separate from each other.  I had to rip open a transparent blue bag and take out the red pump; it was easy to install.  Simply remove the cap and seal from the bottle and screw on the red pump.  The pump will have to be pressed a few times before it begins dispensing the creamer in measured amounts.  I learned from trial and error that I only need two pumps.  Three pumps are too much and one isn't enough to sweeten my coffee.  Each pump is equivalent to one liquid creamer single.  Normally, I use two liquid creamer singles in my coffee.  If I use the creamer, I don't need to add sugar.  Some people do.  I purchased several boxes of Green Mountain Pumpkin Spice K-Cups.  I have a basic model of Keurig.  I brewed the Pumpkin Spice Coffee and added two servings of the Pumpkin Spice liquid creamer from the pump.  The resulting coffee was absolutely delicious.  It was like gourmet pumpkin spice coffee from a coffee shop.  I took the table-top pump bottle to work and shared it with my coworker, Eric.  He also enjoyed the pumpkin spice creamer.  We're both big coffee drinkers.  We both own a Keurig, though his is more sophisticated than mine.  The Pumpkin Spice Coffee Creamer Table-Top Pump from Coffee-mate is highly recommended for lovers of holiday coffee.  As I stated, fall is right around the corner and you will want to stock up on this creamer before it vanishes forever.

I took the Elmer's Freestyle Repositionable Adhesive Lighted Mirror, Hollywood Pink, E6337, to my office space at work.  I decided to attach it to a top shelf of a metal storage cabinet in my research room, which is adjacent to my work station.  I carefully followed the easy-to-read instructions on the back of the package.  First, I used a wet paper towel and a dry one to thoroughly clean the area where I wanted to hang the mirror.  The filing cabinet, like the rest of my office, is less than a year old.  It was not filthy dirty.  If it had been, I would have cleaned it with isopropyl alcohol; it is a safe cleaning solvent that many use to wipe their walls before mounting various wall hangings with adhesive backings.  I was disappointed that the package back wasn't perforated like the one for the Elmer's Freestyle Repositionable Micro Suction Technology Catch All Cup (Elmer's Freestyle Repositionable Micro Suction Technology Catch All Cup, Clear, E6349).  I wanted to save the packaging for storing the adhesive disc.  I used a pair of scissors and carefully cut across the packaging approximately one-inch above the plastic bubble in which the lighted mirror is stored.  After making the incision, I carefully pried the cardboard away from the plastic and removed the lighted mirror and the release liner/adhesive disc.  I carefully peeled the adhesive disc from the release liner.  I stored the release liner inside the packaging, sealing it shut with about four paperclips.  I firmly pressed the adhesive disc onto the top shelf of the metal filing cabinet, making sure the arrow was pointed upward.  I tried to remove as many air bubbles as possible.  According to the instructions, it is best to allow the adhesive disc to remain affixed to the surface at least one hour before applying the mirror.  I let the disc remain attached to the shelf overnight.  Meanwhile, I opened the mirror and inserted the three AAA batteries which were not included.  Fortunately, I already had a fresh pack of eight which I brought to work with me.  The compartment housing the batteries is slightly flimsy.  I had to be careful when opening and closing it not to break the door or the tabs.  It takes some patience and gentleness.  I didn't experience any trouble attaching the mirror.  I turned out the lights in my tiny research room and turned on the mirror.  It shone beautifully in the room, reminding me of a seventies disco.  "This is my party room," I told some of my coworkers.  They laughed.  A week later, I had no difficulty transferring the mirror from one cabinet to another.  I simply removed the mirror, gently peeled off the adhesive disc, attached the adhesive disc to its release liner, cleaned the new area, reattached the adhesive disc, waited overnight, and then reattached the mirror.  The mirror hasn't fallen and everyone seems to like it.  The lights are bright and I can see all the blemishes on my face.  I highly recommend the Elmer's Freestyle Repositionable Adhesive Lighted Mirror, Hollywood Pink, E6337, to anyone who has a locker, office cubicle, or private home/work office.

I took the Elmer's Freestyle Repositionable Micro Suction Technology Catch All Cup to my work office.  I chose to hang it on a storage shelf located directly above my desk top computer.  The shelf has a simulated wood cover that I always keep down.  The simulated wood is a smooth, flat surface.  After deciding to place it near the left-hand side, I thoroughly wiped the surface clean with a wet paper towel and then dried it with another paper towel.  My work station, I must admit, is only about a year old.  Therefore, it isn't filthy dirty.  If it was, I would've wiped the shelf clean with isopropyl alcohol; it is a safe cleaning solvent that many use to wipe their walls before mounting various wall hangings with adhesive backings.  The back of the package has a perforation that makes it easy to open, reach inside and remove the release liner/adhesive square.  This prevents damaging the package, which I can save for storing the release liner.  I gently peeled the adhesive square from the release liner and firmly stuck it to the wall, smoothing out as many air bubbles as possible.  The instructions say to allow it to adhere to the wall at least one hour before attaching the catch all cup.  I actually waited until the next morning before attaching it.  The cup held firmly to the wall.  The cup is smaller than I had imagined.  It only holds about seven or eight pens.  I review/edit administrative instructions and use a lot of red ink.  I put a bunch of red pens in this cup.  Their sole purpose is to edit my work.  A few days after initially hanging the cup on my shelf, I decided to move it to its right side.  This was easy.  I detached the cup and gently peeled the adhesive square off the fake wood.  There was no sticky residue of any kind that remained stuck to the fake wood.  It came off neatly.  I placed the adhesive square back onto its protective release liner that I had kept inside the package.  Then I followed the procedure above in order to hang the catch-all cup on the right side of my shelf.  I didn't have any problems in re-hanging the cup.  That was a week ago and it hasn't fallen down onto my worktable.  I recommend the Elmer's Freestyle Repositionable Micro Suction Technology Catch All Cup for any office work station, dorm room, or locker.  It would make a wonderful stocking stuffer for the student or office employee.

Recently, I received the Omron 7 Series Wireless Wrist Blood Pressure Monitor (Model BP654).  It makes monitoring and sharing my blood pressure convenient and fun.  First of all, it is very compact.  I can take it with me anywhere I go such as work, church, vacation, etc.  Recently, I carried it to work and monitored my coworkers' blood pressures.  Most of my coworkers are female and are approximately my age.  The ones who were already on blood pressure medication had normal readings.  Those who weren't had borderline high readings that read somewhere around 135/91.  Now, my parents are worried about me.  I made the mistake of e-mailing my results to them via the Omron Wellness App that I downloaded to my Apple iPhone 5S.  I don't consider myself a tech savvy person, even though some of my friends and coworkers believe I am.  I simply read instructions.  The Omron instruction manual is easy to read and follow; it has a multitude of helpful instructions.  The manual is a fold-out pamphlet that one must re-fold like a map.  I wish it had been more like an actual multi-page booklet with staples.  The fold-out pamphlet won't endure many years of usage.  The Omron BP654 was easy to use.  At first, I received a few E5 errors, which meant that the cuff was not applied correctly.  However, these E5 errors soon vanished.  The orange position indicator still flashes sometimes, requesting me to lower or raise my outstretched hand.  I have not disabled this function.  The Omron BP654 requires 2 AA batteries, which came with the device.  They were relatively simple to install; no miniscule screwdriver is required.  The cuff wraps easily around my wrist.  I apply it comfortably about one-half inch below my upturned palm and just below my joint bone knob which sticks out quite a bit for me.  (In order to correctly monitor one's readings, it is imperative that one set the date and time.)  After pushing the Start/Stop button, one can feel the cuff tighten up around their wrist.  Initially, my readings were high because I was nervous about using the Omron BP654.  Afterwards, my readings settled down.  My blood pressure, as I stated earlier, is in the normal range but it floats around the border between normal and high.  I am not too concerned.  However, I realize I need to exercise more and eat more fresh foods instead of processed ones.  One should take three consecutive measurements within a ten minute period and average them.  The machine will do this for you.  Simply turn off the machine and press and hold the memory button for more than two seconds.  Also, measurements should be taken throughout the day.  You should wait thirty minutes after waking up, eating, bathing, and exercising.  Try to remain calm and relaxed and don't speak while the Omron BP654 is taking measurements.  I always try to imagine myself lying on a tropical beach.  I can hear the waves lapping against the shore, the sun is warming my flesh and the sea gulls are crying overhead.  Downloading the Omron Wellness App to my iPhone 5S was easy.  Simply go to the App Store and search for "Omron Wellness."  The App is free and establishing an account is simple.  Your e-mail and a password are required.  No Social Security Number or home address or home telephone number.  Directions for pairing the iPhone 5s with the Omron BP654 are easy.  Make sure the Omron BP654 is off when pairing and transferring data.  Tiny bubbles will appear on my Omron BP654 when data is being transferred from the blood pressure kit to the iPhone.  You can choose which data to e-mail to yourself, a friend, a family member or a physician.  The Omron BP654 is intended to be used by only one person.  Two people could use my Omron 10 Plus Series Upper Arm Blood Pressure Monitor with ComFit Cuff Model BP791IT (Omron 10 Plus Series Upper Arm Blood Pressure Monitor with ComFit Cuff).  However, the Omron BP791IT is huge and bulky, it requires four AA batteries, it could only transfer data to a personal computer via a USB cord, and it gave me more error messages.  The cuff on the Omron BP791IT was more difficult to wrap around my biceps.  On the other hand, the Omron BP791IT could store up to two-hundred blood pressure readings.  The Omron BP654 can only store one-hundred.  The readings from both machines are approximately the same.  Both give good results.  One reason the Omron BP654 is easy to take with you when you go to work, church, and the gym and travel on vacation, etc., is because it has its own hard plastic, protective case.  The device fits securely within the case.  The case is not padded; therefore, it won't provide much protection to the Omron BP654 if it is dropped from a great height.  The device can easily be put into one's backpack, purse, luggage, etc.  I carry mine with me in my backpack.  The case has a snap latch that is easy to open and close.  There are plastic coated cards inside that illustrate the proper positioning of one's arm when recording one's blood pressure.  I wished the instruction manual or quick start guide would fit inside but they don't.  Data can be easily erased from the Omron BP654.  Unfortunately, it is either ALL or nothing.  Certain measurements cannot be deleted.  For example, when I was taking the blood pressure of coworkers, I could not delete their measurements in order to prevent them from contaminating mine.  When data is transferred to the Omron Wellness App, it can be deleted.  However, it cannot be deleted directly from the App.  One must go to one's personal computer and log onto the Omron Wellness website.  Then they must bring up their data in a table format and selectively delete blood pressure measurements.  I did this myself.  In fact, I wiped the slate clean and started over.  I also deleted all the measurements from my Omron BP654.  I am seriously thinking about buying the Omron BP654 for my dad for Christmas.  He has high blood pressure and monitors it on a daily basis.  His blood pressure kit is an old reliable Omron but I don't know the model.  It is older than my Omron BP791IT.  Dad also has an iPad.  He could transfer data to his iPad and keep track of it for his doctor.  Someone suggested that I give him mine.  I said, "No way.  I'm lazy.  This new Omron is so much easier to use than my old one."  Because the Omron BP654 is easier to use and more convenient to carry and transfer data, I am more likely to continue monitoring my blood pressure on a daily basis.  This will be good for my health because it will encourage me to exercise and eat healthier in order to lower my blood pressure.

I felt fortunate to receive a box containing five pouches of Peanut Butter Balance Bites.  Each pouch weighed only 1.482 Ounces.  Because it was delivered in stifling hot weather that was in the nineties, I immediately tossed the box into my freezer.  After removing a pouch from the freezer, I gently squeezed its contents, separating the soy puffs.  Each pouch of Balance Bites is easy to open; it has a notch at the top from where one can tear it.  The puffs are lightly flavored with peanut butter.  They are a delightfully crunchy, tasty snack.  I ate my first bag while watching a scary movie after dinner.  I washed them down with a glass of cold skim milk.  I shared the remaining four bags with my coworkers.  They enjoyed them.  As far as healthy is concerned, fresh fruit, or cans of fruit, would probably be just as healthy or even healthier.  However, these pouches are good for taking on camping trips or sneaking into theatres.  Of course, I wouldn't dream of sneaking food into a theatre, but some people might.

I am a sleep-deprived office worker who juggles two jobs.  Caffeine, like air, is essential to my survival.  I own an ancient Keurig Mini, Model B30; it is a miracle that it is still operating.  I am not a coffee connoisseur.  I usually rely on liquid creamers to make my coffee taste good.  Normally, I buy French vanilla, whichever brand is the least expensive.  The Cafejo K-cups, Signature Blend, fit perfectly into my Keurig.  I added French vanilla creamer and the coffee tasted great.  My coworker, Eric, who shares my never-ending nightmare, was given a couple of the Cafejo K-cups and he also enjoyed it.  Like me, he must add creamer to his coffee.  (Neither one of us can drink our coffee black.)  I have gladly added the Cafejo K-cups to my K-cup carousel and hope to obtain more of them in the future.

The Pilot Camo Ball Point Pen would make an awesome token of appreciation to the serviceman or servicewoman in your life.  It is a nice way of saying to them, "Thanks for risking your life to serve our country."  The Pilot Camo Pen that I received for review has Army camouflage.  I would love to buy one that has Air Force camouflage and present it to my 81-year-old dad who served in the Vietnam War.  Currently, I am a member of a Hallmark club that prepares gift bags for the local USO.  I plan to recommend we purchase these pens in bulk quantity for the bags.  The Pilot Camo Pen itself is big and thick, which will make it more difficult to lose.  It is lightweight and has a notched  rubber grip that makes it easy to hold and write for long periods of time.  The ink is black and dark and the line it creates is sharp and thin, not thick and smudgy.  The pen is refillable.  Refills can be ordered from Amazon [Pilot Dr. Grip Ballpoint Ink Refill, 2-Pack for Retractable Pens, Medium Point, Black Ink (77227)] [Pilot Dr. Grip Ballpoint Ink Refill, 2-Pack for Retractable Pens, Medium Point, Black Ink (77227)].  My only concern about the Pilot Camo Pen is its ability to withstand the test of time.  It is composed mostly of hard plastic, not metal.  Because of its expense, I will be more careful with this pen.  I keep it with some other special pens in a magnetized pen holder [Five Star Locker Storage Pocket with Dry Erase Surface, 4 X 6.5 Inches, White with Red Pockets (72616)] [Five Star Locker Storage Pocket with Dry Erase Surface, 4 x 6.5 Inches, White with Red Pocket (72616)] that remains attached to my refrigerator.  I will always cherish it because it stands for freedom.  I have attached a photo of wrestler John Cena holding the pen and a photo of the pen attributes listed on the back of its package.

The more I age, the drier my skin becomes.  In my shower, bars of soap have been replaced with bottles of body wash.  Body washes don't dry my skin like most soaps do.  Recently, I received a bottle of Curel Itch Defense Body Wash.  It is intended for those of us, like myself, who suffer from dry skin.  I must use a body lotion every day, especially during the cold winter months, or my skin becomes dry and begins to literally itch and burn.  The Curel Itch Defense Body Wash is a luxurious body wash that I can enjoy using on a daily basis.  It's scentless, white, pearlescent liquid lathers quite well.  It comes in a bottle that is easy to grip and hold.  The bottle rests on its large top.  Therefore, the liquid is always ready to come out when opened.  This product is gender friendly in that it appears suitable to be used by all genders.  It is neither masculine nor feminine in appearance.  The Curel Itch Defense Body Wash is also intended for those who suffer from allergies.  My girlfriend, Tammy, loves this body wash because it is scentless.  Body washes, body lotions, deodorants, etc., that are highly scented cause her skin to break out into a rash.  This Curel body wash kept Tammy's skin smooth and never caused her to have a skin reaction.  She has used a multitude of other Curel products because of their ability to heal dry skin.

I was excited to receive 5 small pouches of Chocolate Balance Bites in a box.  The box was shipped with bubble wrap inside a cardboard Amazon box.  It was 94 degrees Fahrenheit on the afternoon that I received them.  Immediately, I put the entire box in the freezer in case the chocolate coating had begun melting.  Later that evening, I fell asleep in my lounge chair while reading.  I woke up when my girlfriend, Tammy, called to tell me that her and some friends had arrived safely in New York City.  After hanging up the telephone, I was hungry.  I opened the box of Chocolate Balance Bites and grabbed a pouch.  I ate the Balance Bites with a huge glass of cold skim milk.  They are crunchy and airy with a light flavoring of chocolate.  Some of them were stuck together in clusters.  I suspect some of the chocolate had melted during shipping.  At least my fingers weren't messy because they were frozen.  One bag of the Balance Bites and the large glass of milk satisfied my hunger.  The Balance Bites are being advertised as a "nutrition energy snack."  However, it didn't keep me awake.  I went to bed and quickly fell asleep.  As far as being nutritious, the pouch of Balance Bites has a great deal of protein, 13 grams, but it also has a great deal of sugar, 9 grams.  It also has 0 grams of fiber.  Therefore, it wouldn't be good for those of us, like myself, who suffer from Irritable Bowel Syndrome with Constipation (IBS-C).  I think a can of fruit, a banana, a bunch of grapes, or a cup of yogurt would be just as healthy as the Chocolate Balance Bites.  However, some of us, like myself, have chocolate cravings in the morning.  The pouch of Chocolate Balance Bites makes a tasty, unique chocolate snack that is best kept in the freezer and served with cold skim milk.

Currently, the dining room table in my condominium comfortably sits six people.  However, I can add a large leaf in the middle that will allow it to sit ten.  The only time I do this is for birthday parties and holidays, mostly Thanksgiving.  (I normally leave town for Christmas.)  Unfortunately, I've never had a tablecloth that I could place over the table, until now.  The DII 100% Polyester, Machine Washable, Tonal Bordered Fabric Tablecloth is perfect for my dining room table.  It completely covers the table, with some excess.  It looks stylish and fashionable with its hemmed border that has a darker shade of brown than the remainder of the tablecloth.  It is made of 100% polyester but feels like linen.  It arrived well packaged with no flaws.  I never encountered any difficulties when I washed the tablecloth.  I washed it in cold water on hand-wash cycle.  Then I dried it on low heat.  In other words, I treated it as though it was an expensive item of delicate clothing.  I didn't need to iron it.  It came out of the drier with very few wrinkles.  I folded the table cloth and placed it in my linen closet.  I made the mistake of allowing my girlfriend, Tammy, to see the tablecloth on the dining room table.  She thought it was gorgeous.  She said we have to invite my parents and her parents over for Thanksgiving.  Unfortunately, the guest list keeps growing.  Fortunately, my roommates, Bill and Sue, will have moved to Florida by Thanksgiving and we will have more room.  Update:  Recently, I requested the white Tonal Bordered Fabric Tablecloth.  It also looks gorgeous on my dining room table.  It arrived well packaged.  I washed it in cold water on hand-wash cycle and dried in the dryer on low heat.  I didn't need to iron it.  This is a nice tablecloth that will be perfect for using all year long.  It coordinates well with most anything.  My roommates and I love it.

The Five Avery Big Tab Pocket Insertable Plastic Dividers (Model # 07708) are awesome for organizing any binder.  There are many reasons why I like these dividers.  First, each one has a "stitched," reinforced pocket in which I can store several sheets of paper, a brochure, or a pamphlet.  Second, the dividers are made of thick, durable plastic that is transparent; one can see pages behind it if there is not anything in the pocket that will block one's view.  Third, there are three holes punched into each divider that allows it to be easily inserted into a standard binder; these holes are reinforced to prevent the dividers from being torn out of the binders via the holes.  Fourth, each divider has a staggered tab.  When all five dividers are inserted into a binder, one can clearly see each tab.  They are not all behind each other.  Fifth, the tabs can be easily labeled.  A sheet of labels was provided.  From Avery's website, one can obtain templates for creating labels for this set of dividers.  Simply insert the model or serial number of the set into the website and perform a search.  Because I am visiting relatives, I don't have access to my Avery account (I can't remember my password) and I don't feel comfortable using my relatives' printer.  Also, there are helpful hints about printing the labels that are provided on the packaging.  Eventually, I decided to handwrite on the labels.  The labels are double sided; therefore, one can read the label whether looking at the divider from the front side or the back side.  The only thing I don't like about the dividers is the visual design.  The geometric shapes, e.g. dots, lines and triangular waves, are very bright.  They nearly hurt my eyes when I stare at them.  I wished the colors were more muted.  They need to be dulled down.  Natural colors would be easier on the eyeball.  Also, the design is more feminine than masculine.  Nevertheless, I like these binder dividers and think they would make a wonderful addition to anyone's office.

The Avery Tabbed Snap-In Bookmark Plastic Dividers (Model #24909) have a psychedelic attractiveness if you are a fan of the nineteen seventies, which I am.  Each of the five dividers has a unique design.  (The designs, I believe, are more feminine than masculine.  Some males, like my two nephews, would not want them for their school binders; other students might harass them)  Each divider is made of hard, transparent plastic.  You will be able to see the page behind each divider.  At the top of each divider is a tab for labeling.  The set came with twenty peel-and-apply labels.  The owner can download a template from Avery's website and print the labels.  Because I am visiting relatives, I don't have my password for my Avery account and I don't want to use my relatives' printer.  Therefore, I decided to handwrite my labels.  They were easy to peel off and apply to the dividers.  Each divider has three holes punched into it, making it easy to insert into a standard notebook.  The only aspect about the dividers that made me feel uncomfortable was the "cuts" that have been purposely made from the edge of each divider to each hole.  This is to allow easy insertion of the divider without having to open the binder clips.  The cuts, I think, will also prevent the divider from being viciously torn from the binder if excessive force is applied to it.  However, over time, the cuts will grow wider and the dividers will more likely come out by accident.  (In fact, as I turned the dividers within the notebook, they would sometimes come out.)  I would have liked it more if the cuts were not present and the owner had to always open the binder in order to add and remove them.  Overall, I appreciate having these Avery bookmark dividers for organizing one of my dividers.

I really love the Rapid Supreme Omnipress Stapler.  I'll be glad to tell you why.  First, it is heavy, like a paperweight.  I don't need to worry about easily losing it or knocking it off my office desk.  Second, it has a long, wide non-slip base which also prevents it from sliding off my desk.  Third, and extremely important, it is easy to load with staples (standard size staples will fit).  Simply grab the top, pull the top off, load staples, and shut it.  Very simple.  Very easy.  No directions necessary.  Perfect for technologically impaired people, like myself, who have difficulty reading the directions on a STOP sign.  Fourth, this sturdy, durable stapler is very ergonomic.  In other words, it is easy to hold and grip and takes very little effort to staple sheets.  I have arthritic hands and I didn't have any difficulty using this stapler.  Fifth, it can easily staple up to thirty sheets, not just a few like many of my smaller staplers.  Sixth, it staples very quietly.  Seventh, the stapler is attractive.  I received the black/gray stapler and it blends well with most of my office equipment.  I highly recommend Rapid Supreme Omnipress Stapler for any office.  It would make a thoughtful gift for anyone who owns their own personal business.

Jane Ryland is a reporter for the on-line newspaper edition of "The Boston Register." She investigates a rash of accidents and murders; women are being found dead around homes that have been foreclosed. The deaths are connected to one bank in particular, Atlantis & Anchor. Also, they are connected to a cold case involving a woman, Carley Marie Schaefer, who was found strangled to death on Lilac Sunday in 1994. The anniversary of Lilac Sunday is fast approaching. Jane Ryland may become the next victim if her and her boyfriend, Detective Jake Brogan, don't discover the identity of the Lilac Sunday Killer.Hank Phillipi Ryan's "Truth Be Told" [following "The Wrong Girl" (The Wrong Girl (Jane Ryland)) and "The Other Woman" (The Other Woman (Jane Ryland))] is the most intriguing of the three novels. It has a complex, realistic plot that involves a conspiracy among personnel in the banking industry. I never trusted banks before reading "Truth Be Told." I definitely don't trust them now. It is too easy to make money appear or disappear by pressing computer keys. In the future, I will definitely be scrutinizing my bank statements more closely. One character magically erases her clients' debts to prevent their homes from being foreclosed. Truth be told, this is not fair for those who pay their mortgages.Jane Ryland is a strong, independent single woman with moral convictions. She lives by a set of rules established for reporters. For example, never sleep with a source. She is emotionally torn about dating a police officer. If Jake and her are ever married, one of them must quit his/her job. Jake also has strong convictions. He is determined to find the true identity of the Lilac Sunday Killer; his grandfather, Police Commissioner Ewan Brogan, never could. At one point in the novel, there appears to be a love triangle. Lawyer Peter Hardesty is representing a troubled man, Gordon Thorley, who confesses to being the Lilac Sunday Killer; Peter, I believe, begins falling in love with Jane.I often think of Hank Phillipi Ryan's novels as romantic mysteries. There is a lot of sexual tension between the two leads, Jane and Jake. This is especially evident in the third novel when a competitor for Jane's affections, Peter Hardesty, is thrown into the mix. With their strong, independent heroine; intriguing, complex plots; gruesomely implied violence; and romantic touches, the Jane Ryan mysteries remind me of those written by Mary Higgins Clark. It is not surprising that Ryan has won the Mary Higgins Clark award. Furthermore, the topic of home foreclosures is a timely and sensitive one in these economically distressed times; I've had friends suffer home foreclosures.The killer's identity is kept well hidden until almost the end of "Truth Be Told." A good body count helps booster the pacing. However, the pacing could have been even faster if Hank Phillipi Ryan hadn't bogged it down with too much detail. In her attempt to make the characters more realistic, she reveals all their thoughts, emotions, etc. She describes common sounds. She also assumes we don't know the acronyms and jargon pertaining to basic police procedures. Ryan's over padded 400 page hardback novel could have been reduced to a more manageable 350 pages. Nevertheless, her latest novel is an enjoyable read. Because of Ryan, I'll think twice before entering an empty, abandoned house; I don't want to be murdered. Truth be told, I'm looking forward to the next Jane Ryland mystery.

My girlfriend, Tammy, and I often baby sit her grandniece, Claire; she has her own portable crib in our bedroom.  Upon receiving the white fitted sheet from the American Baby Company, we washed it in cold water on delicate cycle in order to cleanse it of any chemicals that might possibly harm the baby.  Last year, a neighbor bought crib sheets from a thrift store and used them before washing; her baby had a severe allergic skin reaction to the unwashed sheets.  We never learned what chemicals had permeated the sheets.  The American Baby Company fitted sheet was washed and dried without any problems.  The sheet was nearly impossible to get on the standard size mattress, but that was fine.  You want it to be a tight fit in order for it to endure numerous washings.  I have white 100% cotton Percale fitted sheets for my queen-sized bed and they started out extremely tight--so tight they were nearly impossible to get onto my mattress.  However, over the years, they loosened up with each washing.  They still fit.  I have some sheets I've had for nearly 25 years.  Friends and relatives have given me numerous sheet sets.

I have never used a wet skin moisturizer; I've always been a skeptic about them working on me.  I thought wet skin moisturizers would give my skin a greasy feel and I wouldn't be able to dry my skin off after applying it.  I was pleasantly surprised after using Jergens Wet Skin Moisturizer.  First, let me say that it has a slight coconut scent; it is not heady or obnoxious or overbearing like the coconut scents found in some tropical suntan lotions.  The coconut scent is barely noticeable, especially after it has been applied to my skin.  Also, a little bit of the white, creamy lotion goes a long way.  The lotion is much easier to apply all over your body when your body is still wet.  I never realized this.  Duh.  After applying the lotion, I patted dry my skin with a towel.  Let me emphasize the verb "patted."  I patted dry my skin versus vigorously rubbed my skin dry with a towel.  Vigorously rubbing would have probably removed the lotion.  I patted dry my skin and the lotion remained on my skin; it felt nice.  My skin was smooth and moist--not sticky or tacky.  Upon receiving the Jergens Wet Skin Moisturizer, I couldn't wait to remove it from its sealed bag and rub a dab on my hand and wrist.  It left my skin feeling tacky and sticky.  This lotion is definitely not meant to be applied to dry skin; one must apply it to wet skin.  Also, I used the lotion all over my body, including my face.  It has not caused any allergic reactions.  You can apply it, without fear, to sensitive body parts because it is not high in alcohol.  It never once stung my skin.  Also, you can still rub other lotions, if needed, on your face; I always apply some around my eyes to lessen the appearance of wrinkles.  Also, one of the first things my girlfriend, Tammy, asked me was if the Jergens Wet Skin Moisturizer is intended for men or women.  I told her it was for both.  (The plastic tube-like bottle doesn't say.)  Speaking of packaging, the bottle has a bluish-gray color that is neither male nor female.  It is what I refer to as "gender friendly."  All sexes can use it.  The bottle doesn't scream male or female.  Also, the bottle is designed to stand on its top so that the moisturizing lotion is always at the bottom, ready to come out when it is opened.  I highly recommend the Jergens Wet Skin Moisturizer for those, like me, who have dry skin below the neck.  (My face is very oily but the rest of my body is dry.)  Also, this moisturizer would make a wonderful stocking stuffer for Christmas.  (I wouldn't mind receiving a bottle of Jergens Wet Skin Moisturizer as a present.)  Anyone receiving this would be wonderfully surprised, especially if they have never used a wet skin moisturizer.

For hygiene purposes, I like to get a clean dishtowel out each time I dry cookware and/or plastic ware.  I keep a separate dishtowel for drying my hands and a separate one for wiping countertops.  Consequently, I wash a lot of towels.  The DII dishtowels are made of strong, sturdy, thick 100% cotton that is easy to wash.  Upon receiving my sealed plastic bag of four DII dishtowels from the Amazon Vine Program, I immediately washed them on gentle cycle in cold water and dried them on low heat, as stated in the washing instructions printed on the tag.  However, I always wash my towels this way.  I seldom wash anything in warm or hot water because high temperatures cause stains to set in and become permanent and for colors to fade.  The DII dishtowels are thick and absorbent.  They dry very well, without leaving lint and other residue on the cookware, plastic ware, glassware, etc.  The only thing I didn't like about them was their colors.  There are four colors grouped together and labeled "Natural."  There is beige, bone white, olive green, and chocolate brown.  The only one that won't easily reveal stains is the chocolate brown.  Overall, the colors are a little drab for my kitchen.  I think I would have preferred the "Classic" collection followed by "Warm," "Primary" and "Bright."  Nevertheless, DII Dishtowels are great for drying cookware, wiping hands and cleaning countertops.  They would make a great gift for holidays, birthdays, and housewarmings.

Recently, I received the 3M Ultra Clear Screen Protector for the Apple iPhone 6.  Normally, I let the friendly employees at the Apple Store at MacArthur Center in Norfolk, Virginia, assist me with all my iPhone issues.  However, my girlfriend's niece, Theresa, recently bought an Apple iPhone 6 and failed to buy a screen protector.  She said they were too expensive and she didn't need one right now.  I personally installed the 3M Ultra Clear Screen Protector on Theresa's iPhone.  It came with its own cleaning cloth and cardboard for rubbing out air bubbles.  The instructions were the most concise, most explicit ones I have ever seen.  I surprised myself and was able to get it on.  It was slightly off-centered the first time but I was able to peel it off and try again with better results.  The 3M Ultra Clear Screen Protector itself appears thick and durable.  Theresa is able to work all her apps without any problems.  The screen doesn't interfere with her speed typing.  She spends more time texting than talking.  (Her generation prefers to text someone rather than to call them.)  I highly recommend the 3M Ultra Clear Screen Protector for the Apple iPhone lovers in your family.

I was absolutely shocked by the versatility of these cleaning cloths from DII.  For two weeks, I have used them all over my condominium.  In the kitchen, I used them for washing and drying dishes and as pot holders for taking cookware out of my conventional oven and microwave oven.  For the conventional oven, I made sure the cloth was folded twice before gripping it in my hand.  The cloths are very absorbent.  They are also easy to wring out and are very quick to dry.  I have also used these DII cloths to dust my bedroom and car's interior.  They pick up dust very well.  (I hadn't cleaned either one in months; I'm a slob.)  I was most surprised when I used the DII cloths as washcloths in the shower.  The material feels a little scratchy.  However, after wetting and pouring liquid soap on the cloths, they felt luxuriously soft.  I believe they do a better job of scrubbing my body than my traditional washcloths and loofah sponges.  The DII cloths have a mod design of teal dots that are quite attractive and appealing.  My girlfriend, Tammy, and I babysit a neighbor's young daughter, Kelly.  One afternoon, she spied some of the cloths lying on a kitchen counter; she used two of them as blankets for her Barbie dolls.  I must say, these microfiber cleaning cloths from DII are extremely versatile.  They can be used to clean your home from top to bottom.  I highly recommend them as house warming gifts.

My condominium's guest bathroom dcor is simple:  It consists mostly of a shower curtain and wall hangings that have a beach motif of shells.  (I live near Virginia Beach's Oceanfront.)  The hand towels, bath towels, and washcloths are various shades of blue.  However, I wanted something new and different, something that would brighten up my bathroom that was beginning to appear and feel drab.  Because I am on a tight budget (my mortgage is very high), I didn't want to spend a great deal of money.  Fortunately, I received the DII Elegant Modern Lattice Lace Shower Curtain.  It is made of lightweight, easy-to-wash 100% polyester.  First, after removing the shower curtain from its plastic, zippered package, I washed it in my washing machine on hand wash cycle.  Then I dried it on low heat in my dryer.  It did not rip, tear, stain, or shrink.  I removed my old shower curtain and had the new one installed in five minutes without any problems.  The DII shower curtain is 72" X 72" and fit my standard bathtub/shower stall perfectly.  It definitely needs a shower liner, which is not included, because it is not solid.  It is very lacy.  The eggplant color and lacy design are very gorgeous and stylish, not garish or harsh on my eyes.  It is not a design that will quickly become tiring to look upon as time marches onward.  The shower curtain's design is what I call gender friendly in that both males and females can hang it in their bathroom.  It took me no longer than five minutes to remove my old shower curtain and install the new one on the shower hooks that were already there.  I saved my old shower curtain and stored it in the same plastic bag in which the DII shower curtain arrived.  Now, after a few months, I can alternate shower curtains.  The lacy, eggplant design looks good with a white liner behind it.  I may eventually try it with a shower curtain that has a solid black, navy blue or plum color.

In Preston, England, 1742, a young farmer is found lying paralyzed on the moors, the victim of a stroke; recently, he had come into possession of a silver apostles spoon that may be part of a hidden treasure.  A goldsmith, Philip Pimbo, is shot to death within his own office, which was locked from the inside.  Friends Dr. Luke Fidelis and Titus Cragg believe there is a connection between the two men and the ransacking of the goldsmith's safe, which contained the finances for Preston's fast-approaching Guild, an extremely prestigious festival.  If they can identify the man who must've been hiding inside Pimbo's office when he was shot, they can locate the stolen money and save the Guild.  "The Hidden Man" [following "Dark Waters" (Dark Waters (Cragg & Fidelis Mysteries)) and "A Dark Anatomy" (A Dark Anatomy: A Mystery (Cragg & Fidelis Mysteries))] is Robin Blake's most intriguing historical mystery in the Cragg and Fidelis series.  Hidden treasure; an ancient, sacrificial altar; insurance fraud; slave trading; cross dressing; human deformities; and bareback riding are just some of its interesting plot elements.  Life in 18th century Britain could be harsh, primitive, and cruel; but it could also be richly colorful.  Cragg and Fidelis enjoy playing amateur detectives among the villagers of Preston.  "The Hidden Man" also provides readers a view of Britain's infant judicial system, banking system and forensics in eighteenth century Britain.  Readers will be most appalled by the Guinea Trade, which involved the purchasing of African slaves for huge profits.  While crossing the ocean, slaves existed in deplorable conditions aboard the boats; many died from disease and were thrown overboard to be eaten by sharks.  One out of ten boats were lost.  There is a debate in the Preston courtroom about whether or not "negroes" are humans with souls.  Also, women, in general, weren't treated much better than slaves.  Widows were forced into a type of prostitution, always searching for a man who would support them after their funds were exhausted.  Some women were kept in financial bondage by dead employers who willed them land, allowing them to keep it provided they didn't remarry.  Dr. Luke Fidelis and Titus Cragg make a wonderful sleuthing team.  The story is narrated in the first person by Cragg.  He is still happily married to Elizabeth.  (They remain childless, which is a shame.)  Fidelis has a secret lover in Liverpool, the city of sin; he travels there for answers in regards to a slave ship, "The Fortunate Isle," which was lost at sea.  Both men are strong and brave and don't cower before pursuing a villain.  Fidelis is kind hearted, often giving free medical treatment to those who can't afford it.  Cragg, who serves as both coroner and lawyer, does an excellent job during the inquest concerning Pimbo's suspicious demise.  Modern readers shouldn't worry about the readability of "The Hidden Man."  This novel is fast-paced and well-crafted.  Words and sentences flow smoothly.  It was an easy, enjoyable read.  Fans of historical mysteries should investigate this series beginning with its macabre debut, "A Dark Anatomy," which involves witchcraft.  "Dark Waters" pertains to a heated political race that turns bloody.  "The Hidden Man" is more of a detective-like whodunit, which is packed with legal and medical procedures.  Morality and ethics also play significant plot roles.  A higher body count would have been nicer, but one can't have everything.  Still, I hope I can have at least another installment in the Cragg and Fidelis series.

A pyromaniac is terrorizing Brighton, England.  He has many aliases.  Red Westwood knows him as Bryce Laurent, a magician and escape artist who is an expert on surveillance equipment and explosives.  He is determined to slowly torture and murder his former girlfriend, Red.  Thanks to her mom's detective, Red learned that Bryce's entire past is a fabrication.  Bryce begins his campaign of terror against Red by burning alive her current boyfriend, Dr. Karl Murphy.  Detective Sergeant Roy Grace must locate Bryce before he kills Red and everyone around her.  Agonizing, fiery deaths threaten many characters in Peter James's intense thriller, "Want You Dead" [following "Dead Man's Time" (Dead Man's Time (Detective Superintendent Roy Grace)) and "Not Dead Yet"(Not Dead Yet (Roy Grace series Book 8))].  The residents of Brighton are living in terror of this insane arsonist.  Bryce Laurent's targets are not random; they all involve his deadly obsession with his ex-girlfriend, Red.  First, he burns down a restaurant, Cuba Libre; Red and he dined there on their first date.  Next, he rigs her beloved car, a vintage Volkswagen Beetle, to catch fire.  Bryce is insane and ingenious, a horrifyingly deadly combination.  If he wants you dead, then most likely you are going to die.  Roy Grace is not the tortured, wounded hero you often find in other mysteries.  He is a very successful detective who has risen up through the ranks by means of hard work and dedication.  Consequently, his first marriage to Sandy fell apart.  She mysteriously disappeared and has recently been declared dead.  Now, he will soon be marrying his live-in girlfriend, Cleo Morey, who performs autopsies at Brighton & Hove Mortuary.  Unknown to Grace, his wife is still alive.  Though Sandy and Bryce don't know each other, both are determined to upset Grace's wedding plans.  There are numerous tense moments in "Want You Dead" when the killer is pursuing Red.  She lives to regret having placed a personal ad on the internet.  I have always refused to participate in an internet dating service.  Years ago, I read Mary Higgins Clark's "Loves Music, Loves to Dance"--a suspenseful mystery in which a serial killer was targeting women who were searching for romance through the classifieds.  "Want You Dead" also reminded me of such Hollywood horror classics as "The Fan" (1981) (The Fan), "Fear" (Fear), "Play Misty for Me" (Play Misty for Me - Collector's Edition), and "Fatal Attraction" (Fatal Attraction).  "Want You Dead" has definitely made me swear off internet dating for all time.  Through the internet, it is very easy for predators to falsify their identities in order to attract certain types of victims.  Pedophiles use the internet to deceive and lure minors.  Let this novel serve as a warning for those searching for a dream love.  They may find a nightmare in the form of Bryce Laurent, one of the vilest villains I've encountered in literature.  He is a sociopathic egomaniac who has no qualms about hurting those around him; in fact, he enjoys human suffering.  Like all of the other Detective Superintendent Roy Grace novels, reading "Want You Dead" was like reading nonfiction.  It is packed with medical and police procedures.  Peter James provides enough detail about golfing, yachting, firefighting, etc., to convince readers that he has actively participated in them all.  James knows how to build suspense with numerous cliffhangers; interwoven subplots; human drama; graphic, gory violence; and a diversity of realistic characters.  My only disappointment was that the body count wasn't higher; there was a potential for many more victims.  Nevertheless, I highly recommend "Want You Dead" for anyone who wants to read an outstanding, action-packed thriller.

An arsonist is terrorizing Currituck County, North Carolina.  In Carova, a vacation paradise for tourists wishing to observe wild Mustangs, Tropical Storm Ana has swept away much dune sand.  Fire Chief Colleen McCabe and Sheriff Bill Dorman discover a badly decomposed corpse that has been hidden between an old beach walkway and the new one that was recently built above it.  Soon afterwards, a charred corpse is found in the smoldering remains of a new home under construction.  Among the numerous suspects are competitive land developers, environmental conservationists, and tour company operators.  Kathryn O'Sullivan's third entry in the Colleen McCabe series, "Neighing with Fire" [following "Murder on the Hoof" (Murder on the Hoof: A Mystery (Colleen McCabe Series)) and its debut, "Foal Play" (Foal Play: A Mystery (Colleen McCabe Series))] is the most delightful, most intriguing one yet.  This novel focuses a large portion of its plot on Colleen's pets: Sparky the playful Border Collie and Smokey the laidback Siamese.  Having once owned a Border Collie, I can attest to the fact that they are extremely intelligent and playful.  (They also love to kill squirrels, rabbits and other rodents; at least mine did.)  Also, the horses play a more significant role.  There are the tour companies that search them out and the construction workers who illegally feed them.  "Neighing with Fire" is loaded with conflict. There are some environmentalists who think their cause is more important than those of other environmentalists.  There are competing land developers who are spying on each other, trying to obtain key properties.  The obnoxious tour guides are competing with each other for business.  A lot of characters are playing with fire in order to get what they want.  From wearing silly disguises to murdering another human being, some will do anything.  It is the mystery that also makes "Neighing with Fire" an outstanding cozy.  I didn't know the killer's identity until almost the end.  I kept thinking, Colleen better find out who the killer is; we're running out of pages.  Romance is in the air.  Colleen and Bill are growing closer.  Now they are taking long walks together on the beach.  Everyone jokes them about their relationship.  They don't get married in this novel but one of Colleen's firefighting employees does.  Chip and Fawn's wedding is one of the most unique I have ever read.  I am not too fond of weddings, but I would have liked to have been invited to this one.  Sunny beaches; cute, adorable pets; wild Mustangs; feuding characters; fiery explosions; and gruesome deaths make "Neighing with Fire" an excellent installment in a unique cozy series that continues to improve with age.

Water is very good for you, especially if you suffer from allergies as I do.  It is a natural antihistamine.  Thankfully, I've been drinking more water since I obtained my blue, 22-Ounce RefresH2Go Sleek Water Filter Bottle.  I've noticed that the water I drink out of it tastes good, as though it came from my glass Contigo bottle (Contigo Purity Glass Water Bottle, 20-Ounce, Greyed Jade).  At work, I have used the Contigo bottle for nearly ten months.  Water from glass tastes better than water from plastic.  I think chemicals from the plastic itself leech into the water.  The only problem with my Contigo bottle is that it is made of glass; I'm always afraid that I'll drop and break it even though it has a beautiful teal bumper case made of hard rubber.  Water from the plastic RefresH2Go bottle tastes as though it came from a glass bottle.  This is due to the filter that is at the end of the straw.  One must remember not to wash the straw and filter with soap.  Only rinse it with clean water.  Only use soapy water on the bottle itself.  I have the OXO Good Grips Water Bottle Cleaning Set (OXO Good Grips Water Bottle Cleaning Set) that helps me clean all my bottles and thermoses.  I am a very clumsy person; I often knock things over, especially when they are sitting on my cluttered desk at work.  The RefresH2Go bottle is leak-proof.  I have turned it upside down and vigorously shaken it and water didn't come spilling out.  In the past, both my cube mate and I have knocked over our water bottles and damaged our paperwork.  I love the sleek design of the RefresH2Go Bottle, which is easy to grip.  Its Noxzema-blue color is gorgeous; it is easy on the eye.  The bottle holds twenty-two ounces, which is two more ounces than my Contigo bottle.  Twenty-two ounces is plenty of water.  According to the easy-to-read instructions that were found inside the bottle, only water should be poured into the bottle.  The cap on the RefresH2Go bottle is easy to screw on and off, even with my arthritic fingers.  The straw is simple to insert into the cap and the filter is simple to insert onto the end of the straw.  Initially, the spout was difficult to lift up.  However, there is a plastic lever that one can press against to help them lift it up.  The water itself can be difficult to sip because it has to pass through the filter.  The filters must be replaced every two to three months depending on how often you use the RefresH2Go bottle.  I will probably be using it mostly at work.  This means that there is one more extra filter I must keep track of in my life in regards to when and how to replace it.  Filter replacements can be ordered from Amazon (RefresH2Go RefresH2Go Filter Replacements, Blue, 3-Pack).  Furthermore, I don't know how sanitary it is to have a water filter submerged in the water that it is supposed to be filtering.  It would be best to filter the water before pouring it into the bottle.  Nevertheless, I highly recommend the RefresH2Go Sleek Water Filter Bottle for office and gym environments.  After two or three months, one can throw away the filter and use the straw without it.  If water continues to taste the same, then don't order new filters.  With or without the filter, this attractive, easy-to-grip, easy-to-clean water bottle is still great to drink from when working or working out.

Otterbox always offers cases that provide great protection, but until recent years, the colors of their cases were always a bit on the drab side. Not so any more, especially when it comes to this case! The soft aqua is especially lovely, and is quite a contrast to the fluorescent coral of the soft rubber portions of the case. I wanted to make a note of those colors, as what's pictured is a bit different than what you'll receive. The pink shown is not straight pink, but is definitely closer to a fluorescent orange-pink, but the blue shown is pretty close, if still just a touch on the greener side.The case is new in its one piece styling, but still provides plenty of protection while being much less bulky than the Commuter series, which is what I always used to opt for before the release of the Symmetry series. The Symmetry series offers good protection with the extra rubber padding on the inside of the case, which has an extra layer of rubber that provides shock protection to the back of your device. There are also no rubber plugs for the charging and headphone ports, which always seemed like a good idea with the Commuter cases, but inevitably ended up annoying me by being in the way whenever I wanted to connect my device to a jack or charger.Thankfully, the soft coral rubber has just enough give to work your phone into the case, but it's not  so easy to work it back out. Had this case come with the circular cutout that all the other Otterbox cases come with to display the Apple logo, it probably would be much easier to pop the device back out, but it doesn't... which, honestly, does puzzle me a little.Overall, I like this new line of Otterbox cases, and the options it offers. The protection it offers should cover the bases of the everyday user, and the colors offered should provide plenty of options. The case is easy to grip where you need it to be, and slick enough on the back to slip into a pocket. While I'm not so sure about that fifty buck price tag, I always find Otterbox products to be a bit pricier than I like, but it's not like you don't know what to expect, and if your phone is protected properly, it's worth the investment for a quality, stylish case.

The 11.6 inch Stream by HP is a lightweight, well-made system that would be great as a first system for the younger student, or anyone that needs a light duty system to get them through simple tasks.The keyboard is pretty much full-sized, and very comfortable. I compare this to the Asus Transformer Book 10.1-inch 32GB Detachable 2-in-1 Touch Laptop/Tablet T100TA With Keyboard Dock - Grey (Certified Refurbished) (64 GB Storage) that I recently bought myself, and love. Comparing the two systems, I love the wider spread keys of the HP's keyboard, and the lighter weight of the system overall, when holding it in the hand, but I like that my ASUS has a touchscreen tablet/screen that I can disconnect and use independent of the keyboard dock.The resources of the two systems are about the same, so the performance is similar, as well. Because of that, I find the HP to be a bit slow to respond when multiple tabs are open, especially considering all the bloatware that comes loaded on the system. Once the greater portion of that is removed, you're likely to find that you have more than just the 15 GB of system memory that my system currently has, pre-bloatware removal.It's easy enough to pick up a Micro SD card to add more storage to this system, but it's never going to run high-demand games or any other resource-demanding software... of course, it's not meant to run that sort of software, either.Overall, I like this system. The colors it's offered in are great and bright, thus very eye-catching. The resources are on-point for a basic, travel-friendly netbook. For the price, you really can't go wrong with the HP Stream, as long as you keep in mind what it's meant to do.

I've never before owned a curling iron/wand that had interchangeable heads, and think that that's a brilliant idea, even though this price point is going to make this set a bit prohibitive for anyone but the luxury customer or professional stylist. The wand is beautiful to look at, with the white having a pearlescent finish, and the copper accents setting it off perfectly. The cord is the smart no-tangle free-rotating type, which is a great feature to have, and is sturdy and thick, so it should last for many years to come.The unit heats up quickly and well, and has a nice range to it to adjust.
