The one real qualm I have with it is that there's no clamp to hold your hair in place, so when wrapping your hair around it, it takes quite a bit of work to lay the lock down just-so to get it to effectively style the strands. That's an oversight that really is easy enough to fix, but without that having happened, makes using this a bit of a chore until the user adapts to it...Overall, I think this is a great set to check out, if it's worth the investment to you, but the pricing on each individual piece would give me pause on a regular basis...

I picked one of these cases up (in the Purple Amethyst) at a local Verizon store just last evening, and, as is typical in my experience with OtterBox, the case fits perfectly.It is not quite the vibrant, deep purple shade that shows on my AOC monitor, but the color IS accurate on the screen of my iPhone 6s. I  thought I'd make a specific comment on that as, being an artist and very partial to shades and tones of colors when I'm shopping online, accurate color depiction has become an issue for me over recent months in ordering accessories for my devices. Since I get my heart set on a case in a certain shade, and in the last 3 out of 5 cases have received the ordered item only to find that it's NOT the shade shown, it's provided me some frustration. I'm hoping that my hyper critical nature can prove helpful for someone else out there... Just check the image on multiple devices, to be sure.The case provides great protection, and, as you can see, has the cutout to broadcast the high-end quality of the enclosed device. Since I've only just switched to iPhone from my previously beloved Samsung Galaxy (Note) devices (and was a die-hard, hyper anti-Apple customer prior to yesterday), I'd never had the extra boon of that well-known cutout on my cases, but it's a nice way to showcase the lovely original color of the device's casing, without compromising protection of the device.Keep in mind that the warranty OtterBox offers for their devices, should yours break while encased in their product, ONLY covers replacement of the CASE, NOT the enclosed device! I found that out the hard way about a year and a half ago when my Galaxy Note 3's screen shattered while enclosed in an OtterBox case... The case itself sustained no damage, and prior to the incident, I assumed that the OtterBox warranty covered my DEVICE while enclosed in their case... to my expense, and chagrin, I found out that that's not the case... Just thought you should know.As for the actual color of this case, it's a lovely shade of lilac for the hard outer casing, while the rubber inner sleeve is a deeper violet. Both colors are lovely, and show accurately on my iPhone 6s's screen, but are much more muted than my monitor shows...Overall, even though they're a bit pricier than other options, OtterBox does live up to their reputation for protecting your high-end devices. For an alternate that's just about a third cheaper, I've also had luck with Galaxy Note 5 Case, Spigen [AIR CUSHION] Slim Armor Case for Galaxy Note 5 - Champagne Gold (SGP11687), which I never took off in the year I had my Note 5, which I only just got rid of recently. It held up beautifully over the time I used it, and I always got compliments on how elegant it looked (the buttons were easily accessible with that case as well, even though they didn't protrude from the sides of the case as many protective cases do. I loved that about that case).Long story short, there are more and more beautiful yet still protective options out there to take care of your expensive device. Take your time shopping around, and choose what's best for you.

You never quite know what you'll get when you order jewelry from the Internet, but thankfully, this necklace proved to be a pleasant surprise!It's solidly made, and the winding effect of the silver makes for a very pretty piece with the addition of the gold clover. The chain it arrives on is the standard-but-sturdy box link chain, so if that's a bit boring for you, then the bail is large enough that it can easily accommodate a rope, tinsel, Singapore, or other link chain.Overall, I'm very pleased with this necklace! It arrived in a box ready to wrap and present as a gift, it's large enough to easily be seen without being oversized, and it's a well made, lovely piece overall!

I've never before thought to consider buying cloth sacks to store my root vegetables in, but now that I've got one, and see how well made this one is, it makes perfect sense to use these to store potatoes, onions, and garlic.The bag is big enough to hold a good 10 - 15 pounds of root vegetables, and considering how those vegetables don't do so well (at least for me), when I stash them in the fridge or under the sink, I'm looking forward to putting the sack I now have to good use.The sack is large, and well-crafted. The burlap is a good grade - not overly coarse, or poor quality - and the lining is well-made and nicely attached with the wooden buttons. The drawstrings are plenty long enough, and the side loop offers a nice option for hanging from a sturdy and well-mounted hook.As soon as mine arrived in the mail, I couldn't wait to add my onions to it (which, maybe, I should've replaced with fresher onions, but I'll see how these hold up first). I'm looking forward to using this to store my root vegetables for a long time to come. With the ability to remove and launder the lining, there's no reason why I shouldn't be able to get years of use from it.Worth every penny for better storage of root vegetables!

My mom, who just hit the 72 mark 6 months ago, deals with plenty of ailments and more in her advanced age, including Arthritis, Diabetes, High Blood Pressure, and Gout, just to name a few (literally). As one can imagine, she's on a whole slew of daily meds, and I swear, it's like she carts around half a pharmacy in her purse. In light of that, any new supplement or medication that gets added to her daily doses of everything-under-the-sun must be considered both for any interactions it may have, and its efficacy. Knowing how she struggles with her Arthritis, and also knowing how she's touted the use of Turmeric on anything and everything at the dinner table, I thought this would be a good supplement to send her way.She's only been taking these pills for a few days so far, but hasn't experienced any adverse side-effects. There's no unpleasant flavor getting burped up (for) hours after taking the supplement, and she hasn't seen any conflicts with her current medications, so those are all pluses in my book, and hers. As for the effectiveness in fighting joint swelling and her Arthritis, she is seeing improvement after just a short time, and plans to keep taking this in the future.Since it's early on in trying out this new supplement, I'll keep my review updated in case there are any changes, but, so far, so great! Well worth the asking price! :-)

Over the past year, I've purchased about 8 different Fintie cases for multiple devices that I own, and while they're all quite well-made and well thought out, the solid-colored devices are almost universally inaccurately photographed. The long and short of that is, the colors that you see are rarely quite the color that you get.I've bought a few Fintie products here from Ammie vendors, and quite a few more on eBay, since I can buy them there and not have to sweat the shipping costs. So far, with this line that I use for my T100TAM, I've bought the (light) Blue (which in actuality is a Robin's Egg blue, and the most accurately photographed), the Pink (which is nowhere near the soft pinky/peachy color displayed on multiple websites, and is a much darker standard bubblegum pink - which is a good 5 - 7 shades darker than what's shown everywhere), the Magenta (which is a lovely deep Rose hue - as I was hoping it'd be), and the Purple, which I was hoping would be the almost-Merlot color shown, but which proved to be more of a faded raisin color, and not as appealing as I expected it to be.Of the four that I've ordered and received, I've kept the blue (as it is a pleasant color, and, again, closest to what's pictured), and the magenta - which I love the hue of - but having viewed multiple vendor's pages for these on multiple sites, on four different devices, I can unequivocally say that you can expect the color of the case you receive to be considerably darker or a different tone than what's pictured. I'm not quite sure how many super-bright lights were used to photograph these, but whatever was used completely washed out the colors on the cases being sold, making the product images near worthless for determination of color.As for durability, I've owned and used my blue case for about a month now, and it's holding up well, with no wear visible aside from one tiny spot where the colored leather-like finish has lifted a bit. Other than that, this case fits the device perfectly. I feel that, even with the product image issues, this has been money well-spent!

My mom got me on the Garcinia Cambogia bandwagon a few years back, and, while I took the supplements, and observed no negative side-effects, I was always waiting for the shoe to drop, and the Health industry to start complaining of unexpected Phen-Phen level horrible side-effects. While I haven't heard those come to pass, I've still been suspicious, in general, of this new wonder pill... Thankfully, along comes a Jarrow Formulas Garcinia Cambogia, and finally I can put my mind at ease.While I know it'll take a bit of time for me to see the full effects of this new Garcinia Cambogia product (as you never can tell until a few weeks have elapsed), I'm now completely comfortable taking it. It's helped to reduce my feelings of hunger in the past, thus helping me to eat less, and ultimately lose weight. For the college-age young'uns out there, you don't know how good you have it, with being able to eat anything you want and never gain a pound. Hit your Forties, and all you have to do is LOOK at food to gain weight! With this happy little pill on-hand, though, I know my weight loss journey will continue, and with no side effects but reduced hunger and weight!This'll be going into my regular rotation, now that Jarrow's released their version!

I'm always surprised to find how tasty gluten-free products can be, and this scone mix is no different. It bakes up well and deliciously, and is well-suited to any number of add-ins. As others have found, the end product is really delicious!While it's a bit more costly than cheap 'ol wheat-based flour and dough mixes, for anyone trying to avoid gluten, this is a wonderful way to go! I think this just may have converted me! ;-)

Every so often, I find myself in need of a proper staple gun for mounting artwork at my school, and, in light of that, purchased a light weight staple gun about a year ago to tackle that task. While it was perfectly adequate for that one task, its features can't hold a candle to the features offered by this Tacwise stapler, and the quality of construction evident here.I'd looked at a pretty wide range of staple guns in the ten to thirty buck range, and settled on a Stanley TR45K Light Duty Staple Gun Kit (which was about 30% more when I bought it). As I said, it's been fine, but it's been nothing compared to the variety of features and overall quality evident here.This Tacwise staple gun accommodates five different sizes of staples, as well as headless upholstery pins and nails. Honestly, I had no idea a simple staple gun could cover so many bases! Add to that its solid metal construction, the adjustable pressure lever, and the margin guide, and this thing does everything I could ever ask for from a staple gun, and more!The packaging also has four strips of staples to get you started, and I was lucky enough to receive an extra box of additional staples, so I can imagine that this gun will hold me in good stead for quite some time to come. And while the girth of the handle is a bit large for my smaller women's hands, it's still manageable, and will be just fine for men's hands.Loading the staple gun is easy enough, and the open window on each side lets you see whether or not you'll need to refill the gun soon. The belt loop keeps it close at hand, and locks down easily and effectively, making it pretty worry-free. In use, there's no kickback to throw you off the task you're using it for, and it's pretty quiet while driving staples, nails, and pins into whatever you're using it on.For the price, I don't think there's anything more I could hope for here! At a twenty note, this staple gun is pretty much a no-brainer!

Talk about comfort! With this topper added to the sleep sandwich that is my bed, I've got a memory foam mattress topped with a 3" gel/foam memory foam mattress topper; this thing is just the icing on the cake!I've been a BIG fan of memory foam since I got my first mattress topper a few years back, so I love the cushy feel that they give one's bed, but if you're not a big fan of feeling like your bed is swallowing you (noooo, TOTALLY not like Johnny Depp's first big scene on film where he gets swallowed by the mattress in "A Nightmare On Elm Street""! ;)  ), memory foam toppers can sometimes be a bit more than you bargained for... Well, with THIS topper, whether you layer it over a memory foam topper or not, it'll have you feeling like you're sleeping on a cloud! And, thankfully for me, I hear no crunching or crackling from the waterproof layer of mine!The sides, as others have said, ARE made of a pretty thin material, and the elastic (which comprises the entire bottom edge of the topper) is just standard weight, not industrial or extra strength or anything, but the construction of this topper didn't look to be any less than I've seen for other similar style toppers at this price point. Long story short, Classic Brands delivered the average construction quality, IMHO - not better, not worse. Additionally, I had no problem fitting it over my mattress and memory foam topper, and have no doubt that it can fully accommodate the maximum 22 inches claimed.I am pleasantly surprised by the fact that the topper stays in place even when I'm shifting around, and it seems to keep me a bit cooler at night - important for me, as I like things on the cooler side, so I can snuggle in and get a few hours of quality hibernation. Memory foam toppers can retain body heat, and leech it back out through the night, so that's a bit of a downfall for those, but that's no problem whatsoever here. And this thing is SO DAGNABBED COMFY!!! Since I placed it on my mattress, I literally can't WAIT for bedtime to snuggle up on the plush rectangle of softness that is my mattress!I hope this thing lasts for the long haul, 'cuz I'm loving every minute that I spend on it! Worth EVERY penny!

Just like the Bounce Bursts that were my introduction to in-wash scent boosters, this baby powder-scented booster by Dreft is easy to throw in the wash, and adjust as desired for strength of fragrance. The product dissolves away easily, leaving nothing but a gentle, clean scent to make your loads of laundry smell fresher, longer.The only thing that puzzles me about the product page here is the near forty buck price tag listed  - especially when the same sized container is seven bucks at one of the pricier grocery stores in my local area - but maybe that's just an odd glitch...  Either way, this Dreft in-wash scent booster fits right in with my other three bottles of scent boosters, and I'm happy to have it on hand for when I want a soft,  gentle scent wafting from my clothes.

I'm not really sure how protective these cases are, as I bought the hot pink with a mind to change up my already awesome -  and highly reliable - sleek and streamlined gold Spigen Slim Armor case, and was disappointed enough in the Thor's cheap plastic look to initiate a return request within the hour of receipt of my case.To be fair, the case looks to be well made and of durable plastic, but again, the overall finish is cheap and unfashionable looking. Perhaps Thor himself really did design these -  after a night of hard drinking and one too many smacks to the face with Mjolnir - as that's the only way that one would find this case's appearance to be fashionable. As for me, I'm still waiting for a response to my initial return request, which Amazon requires the vendor give within two days of request submission, and I'm now at 4.Either way, I WILL get my money back, and I plan to use it on a second Spigen case, which has been reliably, and stylishly, protecting my Note 4 since I got it 6 months ago.Not a happy camper. If I wanted a case that looked like this, I would've gotten one on eBay for a quarter of the price that was made in China.

... but after two solid days of multiple dedicated attempts to set it up, with no real success, I give up.I suppose I should've known when I saw that my box of components arrived with a second clear sticker stamped "factory inspected" applied over the top of the original (and torn) sticker seal, but I still held out hope that it'd work just fine. I mean, I've gotten factory refurbished items before. Maybe that sticker was only there after agents at the factory opened the box to place my "thank you" letter inside it for reviewing it for the program. I'm not quite sure. But what I AM sure of is that, after following the very minimal instructions included on the quick start guide, then following the instructions for each individual component, then making multiple attempts to research troubleshooting online for this unit after multiple unsuccessful attempts to set everything up, I am done. Totally.The quick start guide makes it sound SO easy. Plug the hub in. Download the app. Start and follow the app. Voila'! It's all ready to add the additional components!... RIGHT. THAT'S not what I, personally, experienced.No mention is made that the handset will need to fully charge the included battery before you'll get your mobile device to register to the hub. Heck, that may not even have been the problem, but that first glitch couldn't be bypassed until the next day, when my handset's battery WAS fully charged. Then there's the fact that, even though it's all connected as each component has instructed, there's no dialtone on the phone. And yup, everything's hooked up and set properly. Nope, still no dialtone. Then there's the leaving the house for the first time after spending all of this time setting up. Now I'm no longer registered to the hub. Okay, fine, I'm out of the house; everything will reconnect fine once I get home. Uhhhhh, no. And no number of attempts to deregister and re-register my mobile device fixed that issue, even though the hub is connected to my router, which has had no problems throughout the setup, likewise my mobile device's connection to said router. It's just the security system that's had problems with setup.So, yeah, others may have had no problems setting this up and getting it operational. But for me, this system just isn't working. I've followed all the directions (which, in my opinion, HAVE to be missing some paragraphs somewhere). Tech Support closes at 9 pm EST, so they've never been open when I finally was done with my day's tasks, and had adequate time to really sit down, read everything over, and hook it up as instructed. And, I mean, I'm not a technological idiot. I've made countless PC upgrades, PC repairs, and even built my own computer from parts, for Pete's sake; I think I can handle hooking a system like this up... and I could, if the instructions were thorough, clear, and detailed enough... or it could just be that I got a defective system. It looks simple enough, but it just hasn't been.For me, as a woman living in a small apartment, this system looked as if it would be just what I needed, but what I didn't need was additional headaches by way of a system that was supposed to provide me with a sense of security in a low-maintenance, easy-to-set-up set of equipment. That's just not what I feel was delivered here.Perhaps I'll give it another go in a few days, but for right now, I'm stepping away. This just hasn't worked for me as promised.

I've owned my Spigen Slim Armor Case for about six months now, and had it installed on my beloved Galaxy Note 4 since getting it on the release day for T-Mobile stores.Prior to buying this - my first Spigen case - I'd made the rounds from cheapie-cheapie generic Made In China cases, up to the pricey (and always avoided because of it) OtterBox cases that I saw others carting their devices around in. While in the OtterBox case, I damaged my previous Note 3 (I shattered the paper-thin screen, which one never realizes just how thin they are until you see those dreaded spiderwebbing cracks make their way across the face of your device. Horrid feeling!). After calling the insurance provider for my device, I learned that that OtterBox warranty that I thought protected my device while encased in their product would actually only cover replacement of the OtterBox CASE, NOT my device when inserted into it. So, fool me once... That brought me to trying this Slim Armor Case from Spigen. I'd never heard of Spigen before, but I liked the look of their cases, as well as the price, so here I am almost six months later with my phone still encased in their product, and doing peachy-keen, even after a few minor drops.I've had no difficulty with the kickstand, although it really isn't terribly sturdy, and doesn't hold my device up very well, unless very precisely positioned. The rubber bezel has gripped my device to slicker surfaces all but once since I began using this case way back in November 2014, and the sleek surface on the overall case makes it easy for me to slip into a back pocket, likewise remove from said pocket. Even after all of this time, my case shows no real wear and tear anywhere, and I'm confident that it'll outlast the length of time I have my device before I upgrade to the next great Galaxy Note. The Champagne gold color paired with the black rubber inner casing make for a very elegant presentation of higher-end devices, but in case you're wondering about shimmer vs. non-shimmer finishes for the Slim Armor line (as I was, and really, still am, as the pictures make it hard to tell), I've asked Spigen directly. The agent that replied to my email stated that the Champagne Gold, Electric Blue, and Electric Red cases all have a shimmery finish to them, and that the mint (which I'd originally ordered with my gold, but returned when there was no shimmery finish), does not. The agent didn't mention the Shimmery White case, but I'm guessing that, by the name, that one DOES have a shimmery finish, as well (it is, however, just a guess). For some of us out there, these details may matter, and since I haven't encountered any other reviews that directly address the colors and finish of the cases, I thought I'd go ahead and write out something that made mention of them. Hopefully someone out there will find this information helpful.Long story short, regardless of color and finish, I think Spigen's products are a more than worthy competitor for OtterBox's. I owned three different OtterBox cases for my previous Note 3, and saw nothing there that surpassed what I've gotten with the sleek effects of the Spigen case I have on my new device. Add to that that the buttons on this case are flush with the sides yet still functional, and that I can access stylus, microphone, and device speaker and buttons with no difficulty, then it's safe to say that I'll be going with Spigen over OtterBox from here on out.

... at least from a carpet cleaner in the four hundred dollar range.This is the second full-fledged carpet cleaner that I've ever owned (the first being the Dirt Devil FD50105 Quick and Light Carpet Washer), and the performance of this Oreck machine is on par with the Dirt Devil that I have. Unfortunately, at four times the price, the Oreck's performance doesn't exceed the Dirt Devil, and if one is expected to pay over four times as much, IMHO, the performance should exceed what I've seen.Assembling and filling the unit is easy enough, although draining the clean/ing water was not quite so easy, considering the way the tank is made. If one is expected to use water with cleaning fluid/detergent added, then empty and reuse that same tank with nothing more than clean water in it, I would think that Oreck would've designed the tank to drain better than it does. As it stands, I had to jostle the water back and forth repeatedly in order to get it out of the greooves of the tank, and completely out of it, and some cleaning fluid was still there, even with five to six attempts to shake it all out. Added to that is the diminutive size of each tank... My apartment isn't terribly large at 750 square feet, but even still, doing all of the carpeting required 4 tank refills. Add to that the fact that this machine just doesn't seem to suck as much water back out as my Dirt Devil does, and there's one more reason to ding the unit a star.I was all kinds'a excited to get my hands on this Oreck, and while its upholstery attachments and the ease of use of them (just attach them to the receptacle for them and go to town on your furniture - an added plus, and a nice touch, there), those are still not quite enough to make me feel that the four hundred dollar price tag here is justified, in light of overall performance.Good, just not great, and a bit overpriced, to me.

It seems like every other month some manufacturer or other is coming up with a new way for the digitally-connected to listen to their devices, and it's to the distinct benefit of us, the customers. I've never heard of NYNE before, but with this Cruiser speaker, they've put a competitive and smart device on the market that's suitable for just about anyone with an active lifestyle that likes listening to their device/s on the go.The Cruiser is compact and comfortable in the hand, and the casing on it is well-designed with buttons that leave no question to the user as to what controls/does what. I really appreciate that, as not every portable audio speaker device out there makes it so easy. The pouch just fits the cables and the speaker, but it makes it that much easier to either toss it into your gym bag, hook it onto a belt loop, or toss into a tote bag for the beach so that you have it wherever you're going. The enclosed grips make it easy to attach it to your bike's handlebars, but they also will work beautifully on a stroller, whether you happen to be going for a jog with your little one, or want to play a soothing lullaby to get him or her to drift off to sleep.Each element of the music that I play through this Cruiser comes through loud and clear and, while I don't own a Beats Pill or any other uber-pricey speakers, I do have a few portable ones that float around the hundred dollar mark, and this small speaker sounds just as good as anything else I've listened to. It's also adaptable and easy to use for phone calls (although I can't quite tell where the mic is), and, even though my mom can't quite seem to hear me on this, I'm not blaming the Cruiser for that. Sorry, mom, but you're 76 in two days, and nothing that I've ever had you listen to my call on ever seems to sound that great to you, so I'm chalking it up to your well-seasoned and overused ears. It must be a result of all of those years teaching highschoolers how to sew... Those sewing machines can hum quite loudly, after all... ;)Long story short, for the features, quality of sound, customization options (including color selection, 'cuz, hey, for some of us, that's really pretty important! ;) ), and, of course, price, I can't imagine you're likely to find another speaker that offers what this one does, at a better price-for-value ratio. Happy to have this handy for the beach days ahead! :)

I was skeptical of the glowing commentary about this game when it was first released, but it's all proven to be true! The graphics here are sharp, crisp, bright and beautiful, the gameplay is fun and engaging without being so frustrating as to drive me away, and I have yet to see any ads or IAPs to provide that bad taste in my mouth that I'm so used to getting provided with from "free" games that never are.This one gets it all right, all around. I'm hooked!

I've got a Dirt Devil carpet cleaner that is the only other carpet cleaner I've ever owned, or used. While this Bissell Spot Clean "spot bot" type cleaner is meant to specifically remove set-in stains, and not fully clean carpets in the method advertised for other designated carpet cleaners, I found that my dedicated carpet cleaner cleans just as well as this Bissell SpotClean; I didn't really notice a difference.As others have said, I also was disappointed to find that this spot cleaner doesn't truly heat the water, as the product information page leads you to believe, and the residual heat produced by the motor just isn't enough to maintain any real heat for the deep cleaning that most customers are likely to purchase this cleaner specifically for.I do give kudos for the various tools that come with this cleaner, as they add versatility to it, and it's easy enough to use. It just doesn't have the real power that the product name and description led me to believe. I'll keep working with it, and if I find that it proves more thorough and successful over time, I'll update my review, but for right now, I must say, I'm just not bowled over... Bummer.

OXO has been a kitchenware company whose products I've used for years, and they've rarely let me down.This scrubber and tray are handy and effective in the kitchen for removing baked-on gunk when you don't want to resort to anything as harsh as steel wool. If the normal scrubbing surface isn't quite coarse enough, you can always dip the scrubber in some coarse or Kosher salt and go to work on more stubborn residue. The foam beneath the scrubbing surface is soft and allows some give, while the upper scrubbing layer looks durable enough to get the average kitchen through, I'd guess, a good three months or so of regular use. If you have or have seen their OXO Good Grips Soap Dispensing Dish Scrub dish wands, it's pretty much the same composition as the oblong scrubbing dish brush head.This scrubber is comfortable in the hand, easy to grip, and the addition of the sturdy plastic draining tray makes it an easy addition to any kitchen.

As most everyone else does (or, at least I'm told, should do), I change out my windshield wipers annually to ensure proper performance in all weather, but typically, I stick to the basic wipers available. I've purchased Bosch wipers once in the past, and liked them, but I rarely have found one brand to outperform another. This is a bit more of the same so far with these, at least when it comes to a brand new blade, and before a few months have gone by.The cheapie-cheapie blades that I've purchased in the past have given out and decreased performance by about the halfway point of the year from what I've seen, and I d have to say that, from what i can remember, the Bosch blades that I've installed in the past seemed to hold up better, for longer time periods. I'm not sure if that's because, here in the Virginia Tidewater region that I live in, the weather tends to be milder, but the proximity to the ocean and salt air here I"m sure takes its toll on cars in other ways. Bosch has a great reputation for quality products, and I have no doubt that the one Insight blade that I received for review will hold up better than other, cheaper blades that I've tried. Looks like, in order to make it a complete pair, though, I'm going to need to purchase a companion blade here, as they're apparently not offered in my local area yet.The Bosch insight blade has a sleek, high-performance look to it, with its fully encased rubber blade. The spring-like shaping of the blade also presses it gently against the windshield along its full length, so that ensures that it'll keep your windshield squeaky clean for the life of the blade.So far, good performance, but nothing out of the ordinary. I believe time will tell, though, and that the sleek new blade that I've installed (its partner soon to come), will prove to hold up and perform well over time.

I've had a few gaming headsets over the years, some by companies I'm familiar with (and proved to live up to the company reputation), and others by companies that I really wasn't terribly familiar with, but yet still, proved to earn a feather in the cap of the manufacturing company.In light of that, this Afterglow Nur headset by prior to this unknown-to-me PDP, proves to be on the lower end of the scale for me. While the headset is very comfortable on the head, nicely cushioned and appears to be sturdily made, the audio quality is just not there. The overall sound is just rather flat, regardless of whether I'm talking with family on my Galaxy Note 4, chatting during an online gaming session, or listening to music directly from my desktop system via one of the many included cables here. The boom mic does pick up sound well and provide clear audio to those that you talk/chat with via these headphones, but the feedback pretty much negates any value that that mic provides. I wasn't the only one hearing an echo of my own voice; the people I was speaking to complained of the same thing - hearing themselves while I used the headset. As soon as I disconnected the headset, that feedback stopped.As other reviewers have stated, the audio quality is just not there with this headset. It doesn't seem to boast any quality beyond 2.1, and in today's day and age, that's just not good enough, especially for a headset that's beyond the hundred note price point. The colors of the headset, when set to the "Auto" setting, scroll through a beautiful spectrum of colors, but again, as they're on your head, it's not like you can enjoy that directly, either, and even though this headset has the "cool factor" with regards to its appearance, that's just not enough to justify the price here for the substandard performance that this headset offers.

Being a now-avid coffee drinker, night owl, and Elementary school teacher, I need a boost of energy first thing in the morning, and the synthetic, chemical-heavy taste of such compounds as Five Hour Energy have never been my favorite thing. While I'm not so sure this Little Miracles energy drink would replace either my morning coffee, or the big burst of a Five Hour Energy product (in case I need a really intense burst of energy), it did give me a pleasant energy boost paired with a delicious, light, fruity flavor, without being too sweet or at all synthetic tasting.The ingredients listed here are high enough quality to soothe my perpetually guilty conscience, and the fact that they're all all-natural and organic makes me feel that much better about the one bottle I got to try. Since it was only the one bottle, I can't speak to how effective this product might prove over time, and whether or not it builds up in one's system to prove more effective with less frequent consumption (as is the case with my beloved Lemon Balm relaxation compound - two words: work stress). I can say, however, that I really enjoyed the one bottle I got.Flavorful, healthy, and energy-boosting. Good stuff!

I've come to find that it's hard to find a really well done mobile game, but this RPG is about as good as I've encountered, and with no real need to dish out actual money to progress through the game. It's not an easy game, but playing as a mage gives the played some real advantages, and lowers the difficulty level for us more casual gamers.Graphics are very sharp, gameplay is engaging, and real money doesn't need to be spent to keep up the momentum. Definitely a must-have for your mobile device! .

After looking for a new, innovative crochet book for quite some time now, I ended up stumbling across this one here on Amazon. I viewed the information I could, which was enough to incite me to order a copy. Upon receipt of the book, I eagerly leafed through the pages, already imagining all of the places in my home that the awesome, clever, and innovative designs within would go...Then I got to the page listing the suppliers, and was stunned and deeply dismayed to find that at least 80% of the materials used here are only to be found in Finland.I figured buying the materials online, even from a Finnish website, would be within my grasp. After all, my mom already thinks I'm addicted to online shopping, I do so much of it... Then I tried doing just that, which was just another exercise in futility, trying to figure it all out. Beautiful products are shown on the suppliers' website, but trying to figure out how to actually order from them was beyond me. There ARE alternates suggested and, I suppose, available (somewhere), but they're not going to be easily found, and you can pretty much bet that you'll be VERY lucky to find any of those alternates at your local big name crafting stores... Searching online produced no results, and I even attempted to find something at my local hardware store to approximate the fishnet twine. Nope, no luck there, either.Don't get me wrong, the book is beautiful, as are the designs within. But for me, looking through this book has been like taking a diabetic to the window of a candy shop. I am intensely disappointed that the items I was so eagerly anticipating the crafting of as I waited for my book to arrive, are going to remain beyond my reach. I mean, really, what's the point of publishing a book that solely uses products that are essentially not available to you?SO disappointed. I almost wish that they had just kept this book in Finland, since they, at least, can get the materials needed to create these items. Looks like the rest of us are just pretty much out of luck.SO disappointed!

For years, I've been a Burt's Bees addict, and I'm familiar with the Tom's of Maine brand, but, prior to this lip balm, had never tried any of their products. Well, I may have just found a worthy replacement for my Burt's Bees fix! This lip balm is pleasantly minty without being overwhelming, and makes my lips feel smooth and silky, without making them feel overly "wet" or silicone slick like some other lip balms I've tried!Definitely worth a try!

Since the nutritional stats are clearly posted for all to see, I'll comment on the flavor of the product: to be honest, I find it chalky, and not very reminiscent of a great chocolate. In light of that observation, the nutritional value here outweighs any real issues one might have with the flavor, and there's always the option of adding a little quality unsweetened cocoa, like Ghirardelli's. I also found the powder to be a bit cloyingly sweet, but this is, once again, something that can be adjusted with a few minor tweaks.Mixing the drink up isn't difficult, and using my Magic Bullet, it blends up smooth and creamy, after some dedicated hand stirring to get everything started. The protein and nutrients here also have the effect I was hoping they would: I find myself satisfied and not feeling hungry for many hours after drinking this in the recommended one cup water/one scoop powder ratio.For the regular consumer of protein drink mixes, my take on the flavor here might be one that you've already moved past. The value of a quality protein drink mix is most likely to lie in the nutritional value for you, and you've probably already accepted that the flavors are not going to be akin to high calorie creme brulees, chocolate souffles, or caramel flans; undoubtedly you gave up such diet murderers years ago. But for those of us looking to transition into healthier meal replacement options in an effort to get to the fitter place that you're already in, I'm hoping that this information will prove  at least a little helpful. If this, and other, protein drink mixes can help me cut back on my caloric intake while bumping up my consumption of protein and the nutrients my body actually needs, I'll consider this one of my new close friends.The stats here speak for themselves. While this may not be the most delicious thing I've ever put in my mouth, it's unquestionably one of the healthiest, and for that alone, it's worth adding this to a cleaner eating plan.

For years, this particular pantiliner has been my go-to brand and type when I want mass quantities on-hand. The only others that I prefer  over these are Carefree's body shape extra longs, but, again, those only come in the smaller packs (from what I've seen), and also have a whole lot more packaging to them, between the plastic packs they come in, then the plastic pouches that each individual liner is further packaged in.As far as comfort and all-day wear goes, Carefree's products are the ones I prefer. I've found that Kotex can feel a bit odd against the skin, with a strange, almost slick plasticky feel that I really don't like, and the adhesive on other pantiliners just doesn't seem to hold throughout the day. Carefree's adhesives can give out as well, should they be subjected to fresh-off-the-clothesline undies that haven't quite completely dried yet, but the adhesive of just about any liner out there is likely to give out in that situation. Carefree's liners stay comfortable throughout the day, absorb enough that they can carry you through the lighter days in your cycle, and they don't tend to stick to or feel strange against my skin, like others can.If you're a larger or plus-sized woman (like me, at a size 18), the longs may be just what you need to give you better coverage, and I feel that Carefree has the best pantiliners out there... Which is why they're the only brand you'll find in my bathroom cabinet, 10+ years running.
Graphics are very simple and Minecraft-esque, yet still charming. Easy gameplay here makes for a simple yet addictive game.

For those of us that have old (or soon-to-be new) favorite family recipes stashed around the house on random note cards, slips of paper, and even back covers of magazines (scribbled in a fit of culinary inspiration), this recipe binder by Avery is a very smart way to take an existing product, amp it up, and customize it to make your very own handcrafted cookbook with all of those beloved recipes in one easy-to-find place.The page protectors and inserts that come with the separate Avery My Recipe Binder Starter Kit, 1 Set of 8 Tab Dividers, 5 Each of 2 Pocket Recipe Card Protectors, 10 Sheet Protectors (19915) do a great job of, as the title claims, getting you started with organizing all of those paper slips and note cards, providing note card page protectors, full-size sheet page protectors, and customizable tabs. On top of that, you can go a step further by printing your own page inserts that you choose from a variety of designs for, to truly make this your own personal recipe book.I think Avery has really been smart in figuring out yet one more clever way to put their products to use here. I never would've thought of just picking up a standard binder, getting page protectors, and putting all of those recipes I've got laying around into a binder like this, but it's very clever, works, and polishes up something that, before now, has both looked haphazard, and not always been so easy to track down. If you're having a hard time figuring out what to get for that culinary master or maven that you know that you feel already has everything, this just might be the ticket right here!

I swear, adding a scale to your home during the holidays is like deciding to treat yourself to an Iron Maiden for a fun play toy, but at least I can say that this sleek black scale by Taylor puts my old scale to shame on so many levels.This scale is polished and elegant looking with its smooth black finish. It's large enough to be comfortable for anyone to stand on (although the cold glass can be a bit of a shock to the bared soles). The underpainted finish seems almost like a baked enamel, so it's not going anywhere, and the accuracy here far exceeds any scale I've had before.With my previous scale, I'd have to weigh three  times, and go with the number that came up most often, even though the scale was never repositioned. That was after having to press on it and wait for it to tare itself out each time. Here, you just step right on, and a scant three seconds later, you've got your weight, down to the ounces, and as accurate as I've seen in a LONG time!As far as scales go, this one is a lovely addition to my home. Elegant, accurate, easy to use with large numbers in the digital readout, thick, tempered glass surface, and puts my old Thinner brand scale to shame (so in the trash it went)! Worth every penny, and will look good in anyone's bathroom or home gym!

I ordered this keyboard after much debating and searching online, hoping that ALL of the reviews about defective keyboards were written by a small portion of customers, rather than their representing the greater bulk of customers. Long story short, nope. My keyboard was  defective right out of the box, too.I decided to risk it going by the lovely colors of the backlighting. And they really ARE lovely - IF you can get them to stay on!My keyboard installed with no problem (of course, since the basic pre-installed Windows drivers are all you really need). The problems made themselves evident, however, from the first time I tried scrolling through the colors to see what each looked like. The red (which is the first color on the scheme), green, and blue worked fine, but every time I tried to change to yellow, cyan, pink, or white, the keyboard would shut off for a few seconds (fully disconnecting from my system), then finally restart, right back at red (not one of my favorite colors here).Trying to figure out how to call ChallengerUSA for replacement was an exercise in frustration, so your best bet is probably to go ahead and write a review here (although after I finally gave up and just reluctantly sent an email on their bare bones site, I did get a response the very next day). They emailed me a prepaid return label, and my mail carrier picked the parcel up, which was six days ago. Since then, I've heard nothing more back from ChallengerUSA, and have yet to receive my replacement keyboard. At this point, I'm just hoping to receive my replacement keyboard some time  before the holidays are officially here, and a working one at that, but I'm just not holding my breath.The reviews declaring quality control issues are all completely accurate. A product is only as  good as its functionality, and this one needs a serious overhaul in the quality control department. Yet another "made in China" item that feels like it's just Dollar Store value. So disappointed. Just as a P.S. - I got mine when the price was a penny less than a twenty note. Even THAT ended up proving to be too much to pay... The $36 price tag they're set at right now (12/15/14) is ridiculous, considering the quality control track record here.*UPDATE*So, here I sit, second keyboard in front of me, with the EXACT SAME PROBLEMS that I experienced with the first: attempting to set any color beyond the initial 3 causes the keyboard to reboot itself, shutting off, sitting completely unlit and unpowered for about 12 seconds, then restarting on red. Trying to set any color beyond red or the "breathing" effect of scrolling through each color is an exercise in futility. And it's not my system. I did a full driver check, purge, and update about two weeks ago (which took painstaking HOURS of time), deleting every single old and possibly corrupted driver in my Device Manager for any device that I had previously installed and subsequently uninstalled, then using multiple methods to update and double-check each remaining driver on my system. Everything is up to date, so the fault here lies solely with this keyboard, and the lack of quality control for it. And this is after I asked, MULTIPLE TIMES, that agents in ChallengerUSA's Quality Control/Tech Support/Customer Service department thoroughly check my replacement for full functionality. I guess asking four times isn't enough.The colors here, again, are great, IF you can get them to stay on, but at 0 for 2 on keyboards that SHOULD work, but don't, I won't be buying anything sold by ChallengerUSA ever again. Fool me once, shame on you, fool me twice, shame on me...*FURTHER UPDATE*I feel like I'm being given the runaround from CS here, being told that they're going to check with tech support for a workaround. A Windows 7 compatible keyboard either works on a Windows 7 system, or it doesn't. My system is Windows 7 x64 SP1, with the latest Windows Update, installed just this evening right before connecting the new (still defective) keyboard, and I'm STILL having the EXACT same problems. Getting nothing but the runaround at this point has pushed me to just give up on this and ChallengerUSA, and just go ahead and order an Azio PRISM USB Keyboard with 7 Colorful Backlights (KB507). Since new egg has them for twenty five bucks right now, that's just a few dollars more than this nightmare of non-functionality has cost me (not including the expense of my sanity).Save yourself some frustration, and just say no. It's not worth the headaches.*FINAL UPDATE*The Azio PRISM USB Keyboard with 7 Colorful Backlights (KB507) is working just fine on my system since I received and installed it this evening. Drivers installed perfectly, all 7 colors and multicolor setting come up just fine. I have not experienced any of the issues I dealt with with the Redragon Karura K502.So, yeah, again - my system wasn't the problem (as I suspected all along). It's the defective keyboards sent out by Redragon that caused my system to experience problems with it.Until ChallengerUSA does an obvious and decisive overhaul of their Quality Control department, again, I won't be buying anything else from them.

This little booklight is the first that I've gotten since my first one years and years ago when those long-clip book lights first hit the market. I've often found booklights to be a bit unwieldy,  as they were frequently heavier than the paperback book I was holding, and they just never quite seemed to put out enough light for my taste. The design on this Carson booklight, though, is clearly much better thought out than that of those old, staid models.The light on mine really isn't quite as bright as I'd like, so I'm not sure if I just have a funky pair of batteries, but the light IS bright enough to be helpful. It's easy enough to turn on, as the power button is on the back of the lamp head. The plastic here is very sturdy, and has a feel that reminds me of Melamine, so I expect it to last for many a year to come. The clamp is solid, has clear rubber feet that serve as grips - placed on both sides of the clamp - so they'll hold well to even slick magazine pages. The clever design that allows for the head to nest inside of the clip both protects it during shipping, and offers another option: if you turn the lamp on before nesting the head in the hole on the underside of the clip, you can use it as a flashlight for when you've got to navigate tight spaces and may need to hang it from your wrist, or clamp it for stability, as in working behind a tall PC tower or entertainment center.The overall quality construction, cute and quirky design, and versatility of this book light will have you putting it to use for more than just reading. While mine isn't quite bright enough to turn all of the lights off and read by, I know that it's going to come in handy for many a task in my home!

This Coffee-Mate liquid creamer comes in a BIG bottle, so be sure to clear some counter space before you get your package! The pump for it is packaged separately, and in order to have the option to reuse mine, I used a large metal file to file the teeth around the neck of the bottle down (not necessarily something that's recommended, but since it's just me, and hot water should be able to clean it out, I'm not too worried).The creamer itself is very thick, so much so that when I initially received the bottle and shook it around, I was worried it might have solidified on me a bit during shipping (it's recently been pretty chilly here in Virginia). Nope, not coagulated, just super thick. In fact, the consistency is about that of sweetened, condensed milk.The enclosed pump works well to push through a stream of thick, syrupy liquid creamer, but for anyone worried that the "sweetened" here means "oversweet", don't - I like a little coffee with my cream and sugar, and it wasn't quite sweet enough for my super sweet tooth just as is (I still added my heaping four teaspoons of sugar to my standard 16 oz cup). If you're not a big fan of super sweet coffee, you're still very much in the clear here.Had I not recently taken a buttercream decorating class, I might have been skeptical of the claim that sugar makes foods shelf stable for a while, but the books and instructors that I've checked with make the same claim for icings with milk in them - apparently that bit of sugar DOES help to fight off any bacteria that might otherwise grow in and compromise food items left unrefrigerated. The taste imparted by this creamer is pleasantly creamy, not heavy on the tongue, and again, not too sweet.This creamer will serve you well whether you're putting it in an office, or a kitchen with lots of coffee drinkers around, and you get plenty of servings for your money - even the heavy creamer users should get a good 150 cups out of this! Enjoy!

You might say "a hairdryer is just a hairdryer", and that would be pretty accurate for the average customer (although I'm sure my stylist would have a BIT more to say on that topic)! ;) But, for me, it's the little things that take a reliable, quality hairdryer a bit further, putting it at the front of the pack. The features and functionality with this dryer help to move it to the top of the list for the dryers I currently have at home.I picked up this Conair 1875 Cord Keeper to replace a reliable, still functional Conair Ionic Pro dryer that I got 4 years ago (and no longer appears to be available here). That dryer is still working great for me a few years after first getting it, but I have to admit that, as with most hair appliances, that cord just bugs me every time I use it! I guess, really, if that's the only qualm I have with it, it's doing a bang-up job, but the little plastic tab that is used to keep the cord in place after wrapping is always just a pain to deal with. Thankfully, with the cord keeper feature of this dryer, that's no longer an issue.All of the functionality of my previous dryer is still here with this one. The rocker buttons on it allow you to select hot (for if you either have really thick, coarse hair - or are just a masochist, and decide to concentrate the heat via a soft bonnet curler dryer attachment, like I use  ;)  ), warm - the setting that I prefer with my mass quantities of fine hair rolled on curlers and tucked under said bonnet, or cool - which I often use to finish out my 45 minute hair drying sessions. The Cool Shot feature is also another great one for a blast of extra cool air (kind of amazing to me, considering the hot air my dryer's just been blowing out, followed by the A/C cold air that this button activates). The Cool Shot is great for locking in curls, so it's a must-have for me. The filter on the back is removable, and thus easy to clean - yet more insurance that the dryer will give you many years of great service. Add to that the fact that now you don't have to FIGHT with yet another cord after your styling session is over, and the great condition that my hair comes out when I'm done using this dryer, and there's my reasoning for moving this dryer to the top of my list!The cord rewind on mine isn't quite as strong or great as that on my typical cord rewind vacuum (my hair dryer pulls almost the entire cord up, but leaves just a little less than about a foot hanging out). It's easy enough, though, to just gently push the remainder of the cord into the channel, and push the cord rewind button again for the dryer to retract the remainder of the cord.LONG story short (sorry - I have a tendency to do that! ;)), Conair has put out yet another quality dryer here, with that last remaining convenience that I'm sure will find these in many a household to come! Pair that with the gorgeous, sparkly, ruby red nailpolish color it comes in, and it's pretty and sleek enough looking to happily hang it on display in your bathroom! Love it! 4 1/2 stars!

For years now, I've known Alienware to be a high-tech, high quality computer product brand, and, while I've always wanted to say I was lucky enough to get my hands on one of their products, I never have been. Until now. And it was SO worth the wait!I first got introduced to Alienware products a few years ago by a gamer friend of mine who works in Technology. Aric was always one to thoroughly research anything he bought, and go with the best bang-for-the-buck he could find, regardless of price (within reason). I was impressed with his Alienware system then, but I'm even more impressed with the Alienware Alpha, now that I've gotten my hands on it.Setup was no more difficult or labor intensive than setting up a standard new PC or computer system, and, just so you know, anyone that tells you that this system is NOT a full-fledged PC in and of itself either hasn't set it up themselves, or hasn't thoroughly checked it out. Aside from the lack of a DVD/CD drive (which an external option can be purchased at minimal cost, but for most, may not even be necessary any more), everything that you could need to use this system as a full-blown, dedicated PC is here. Toss in an external hard drive for extra space (as requested by the system for storage of music, pictures, and video), and you're good to go, but even that's not necessary, as a full Terabyte will be more than enough space for the typical gamer's needs.Upon connection and first-time startup, the system walks you through the typical PC selection screens, then loads up the initial Windows page, where you're asked to select the format you want to set up your Alpha in. You're given a choice of Console (which only requires the included Xbox controller), or Desktop (for which a mouse and keyboard ARE necessary), and whatever you choose is the mode that the system will startup in from that point on. Even though this is billed as a console, I decided to set mine up as a Desktop, after which it is clear how much of a full-blown, and fully loaded, PC system this lovely little box of joy is. Being that this is my first Windows 8.1 system, it was a different experience navigating the system for the first few minutes, but once I acclimated to it, it's been no big deal. As I was using both a wireless keyboard and mouse (the mouse was recognized with no problem from system startup), and the Logitech drivers for the keyboard were (obviously) not preloaded, I had to turn on the on-screen keyboard under the Ease of Use settings, but once that was done, it was super fast and easy getting everything else going. I had connected this system directly to my network via an Ethernet cable, but aside from the drivers for the equipment I connected, I had none of the issues of system updates and multiple reboots that others have complained of, so, from there, it was on to logging into my Steam and Microsoft accounts (the same Microsoft account that I had to set up for use with my Xbox Gold membership a few years back), and then getting on with the playing! I have an existing Xbox controller, but after fiddling around with it, and trying to pair it with this system to avoid having to use two different ones, I just decided to go ahead and use the new controller that came with the Alpha. I had issues with my original controller unpairing from my 360, and after I took note that my Xbox is directly below my Alpha, it just made more sense to have one for each device... It paired up just fine with the Alpha via the included USB receiver, although I do find myself defaulting to using my mouse and keyboard for certain games.In Desktop mode, Steam opens up quickly, but with a slightly minimized window, until you select the small Xbox controller icon, which takes you to Steam Big Picture mode, a fully immersive, full screen presentation of the Steam store and any games that you'll play while there. Gameplay is smooth, beautifully rendered, and super responsive with no lag, even at the highest settings. The quad core Intel i5 processor is more than enough to handle anything that you can throw at this console (and should be for many years to come, as the gaming industry - when last I checked - still had yet to modify games to fully utilize more than four processing cores), and with the ridiculously cheap sale prices on Steam right now during Thanksgiving weekend, I was able to pick up 9 new titles, some of those compilations of multiples, for less than fifty bucks. Thanks to those sales, I now own the Bioshock Triple Pack of all three titles, Skyrim, Sid Meier's Civilization V, as well as a few simulations, and Indie games. You just can't go wrong with that much fun for that little cash, and I had no problems accessing all of the games in the Steam store.Ever since setting up this system, I've been playing for hours straight, and loving every minute of it. There's nothing that I can find this console/PC system to be lacking, and the fact that all of this power and awesomeness is packed into a package this small just blows me away. This may be my first Alienware product, but it most definitely won't be my last!*UPDATE (a.k.a. NNNNOOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!!!)* And, this IS going to be lengthy - I'm writing so much here so that, should anyone else experience any problems with their unit, they might be able to check their steps against what I tried, both solo and with the assistance of Laura, the very adept, patient, and dedicated Alienware agent out of Costa Rica that helped me out so much (thank you, Laura! I hope they give you a raise! ;)  ).So, this evening, after leaving my console on and unattended for about an hour and a half, two hours at most, I go back into the living room (where I have it connected in my entertainment center) to find that my TV's screen has gone black. The same screen that my Alpha is connected to. The same screen that, when I scroll through my A/V receiver's ports, successfully display the screen of every other device. Every device, that is, but my new, coveted, this-was-my-Christmas-present-since-I-can't-afford-to-buy-myself-anything-in-this-price-range-this-year Alpha. You can imagine the heartache and heartburn that proceeded to set in.So, I try a hard reset. Three separate times. Nothing, no response on-screen. Blue system LEDs light up, but nothing displays on-screen. Maybe it's the HDMI cable? I'd used the one that came with the Alpha, so I first tried a few different A/V ports, then the extra one on the back of my TV, ensuring I switched to the correct input selection with each change. Nothing. Tried unplugging the unit from the power, counting slowly to 30, reconnecting everything & switching the power back on. Maybe the HDMI cable died? I try a different one, same multiple steps, same attempts with different ports. Nothing. *sigh*. Okay, I give in. Time to call Dell/Alienware Tech Support.... Uhhhmmm.... yeeaaahhh... Three phone calls later, and a chat window session where the agent literally took no less than two to five minutes between each response (many of which asked me questions I'd already answered when explaining the situation), I finally get Laura (this is after speaking with Rose, who accidentally disconnected my call, then another agent who transferred me through to Alienware Tech Support from the Dell number I'd dialed. The Alienware agent then, a young man, told me that, after I'd explained the situation, he was going to transfer me through to Alienware Product Exchange and Replacement... Instead, he transferred me through to an automated system that, because it was after 10 pm EST, told me that it was sorry, that department is closed, I'll have to call back again tomorrow). Well, thank God for Laura, who I got, again, on the fourth attempt to get assistance with my seemingly defective Alpha after less than 36 hours of up time. I explain to Laura exactly what's going on, the steps I've taken, and just how stressed out, frustrated, and disappointed I am at this point that my first coveted Alienware product appears to have died on me (I have friends that swear that it's one or the other of my two tom cats (because more than two, and you've crossed the threshold into Crazy Cat Lady Land), who they are certain are gremlins that screw with my technical gadgets while I'm not looking). She proceeds to attempt troubleshooting with me. She asks me, since there are no audio problem indicators with the Alpha as with other computers, whether I've noticed any sort of flashing pattern with the light that illuminates the alien head during any of my troubleshooting steps. I explain that, no, the light was always solid, no flashing patterns.We tried reconnecting the unit, for starters. This is a good half hour to 45 minutes since I've completely disconnected it - no power cable connected, HDMI, Xbox receiver, or USB mouse or keyboard dongles attached. I point this out because, after I plugged the power back in, and pushed the alien head to power it back on, it opens up right at the desktop splash screen - the last screen that would've been displayed before whatever error occurred.  Keep in mind, though, that it's been COMPLETELY disconnected from the power and everything else for at LEAST a half hour - just laying on my bed during my prior failed call attempts. Alienware, indeed... Anyway, after we see that it's back up and running and I've reconnected the USB dongles, Laura has me put it to sleep again. It goes into sleep mode, but as soon as I touch one of the keys on my attached wireless keyboard to wake it up, the power completely shuts off on it, I see the dreaded black screen again for a few seconds, then it goes to the blue "there's an HDMI device that's normally powered on and displaying on this TV input, but there's no power from it" screen. We wait a few seconds, switch to a third and previously untested HDMI cable, and try to power it on again. Nothing happens, but I can hear the fan on the back of the unit running, and it's blowing out warm air. No activity light from the hard drive is visible, even when I hold my hand directly behind the unit to catch any flashes of activity. We try disconnecting everything again, giving it a few seconds to clear anything that might be in the cache, and reconnect the HDMI cable and power cord (I've already disconnected the USB dongles again). This time, it starts up, running through the initial Alienware splash screen and the typical startup screens.At no point in time did I ever see the LEDs behind the alien head flash in any patterns, and Laura didn't seem able to completely pinpoint the problem, but she created a replacement order for me, stating that Alienware tech support agents would review her notes, and get back to me within two to three business days, and that a new unit would be shipped to me within two to three weeks. She stated that once I'd received the new unit, that I'd need to ship the existing one back (using the prepaid return label that I'd clearly requested twice - it's not even two days old, so I don't expect to pay to ship a defective unit back). At this point, it's just a waiting game paired with finger crossing in hopes that the next unit I receive won't prove to have any problems like this, or like others have experienced. It makes no sense to me, either, having these problems. I'd just run Alienware Autopsy this morning, doing a default check on the system, as the system recommended, to ensure that all of the hardware and installed software passed all the checks and tests, and all of it did - as it did AFTER whatever glitch that was, when I ran it again about an hour ago, after it DID restart. I've had to do one hard reset since, and after disconnecting the power briefly, and allowing a few seconds, again, for cache clearing, it started up again, but this time at the Windows 8.1 app screen, which was not the last screen I'd had it on. Either way, when there, I went into the system settings, and turned off the 3 hour sleep settings I'd set it to yesterday, the day I'd initially set my system up.I'm not sure what's going on here, but I swear, I feel like someone's stolen my puppy, and I want it back. :( Here's hoping the coming weeks will find me with a properly working unit again, and I'll update here once the exchange process is complete, and I have the new unit up and running.Happy holidays, until then!* FURTHER UPDATE* (a.k.a. back to joy!)Floriana, the Tech Support agent at Alienware that took over my case, contacted me three days after my initial Tech Support help calls to notify me that the request for a replacement unit had been approved, and further contact with other Tech Support agents for extended details informed me that I should expect an update on the shipment of the replacement unit - which would be built from scratch - by no later than this past Friday, six days after my initial reports of issues. Well, not only did I receive shipping status by Friday, I actually received the replacement unit itself on Friday, putting total unit build and problem resolution time at six days total. The new unit is up and running like a charm, and I am back to being fully enamored with this PC/gaming system. I gingerly went through the same steps that caused problems with the old unit, happily finding no repeats of those same issues with this new one. Setting up the new unit also proved to be faster and easier than the initial setup of the original unit I'd received. Once selecting the basic Country, Language, Time , and other initial settings, the new unit found the settings that had been backed up to the Cloud from the first one, so it was a simple matter of applying those settings to the new unit, and I was looking at what seemed to be a carbon copy of the first Alpha, but minus its glitches. No issues here with Sleep mode completely shutting down my system, and it's working like a charm. P.S. for anyone needing Tech Support, try calling eight six six, two eight seven, six seven two seven, then selecting option four for a direct connection to Alienware Tech Support. That was the number given to me by one of the agents I spoke with, and it's open 24/7. Hopefully by spelling it out the bots won't disable or remove it, just in case someone else needs it...For anyone that's looking to cut the cable cord and add PC gaming to their entertainment setup, you really couldn't ask for more than this unit. There's no need for a Chromecast, Roku, or anything else with this system, as it's easy enough to download your favorite web browser to this system (mine being Mozilla), and logging on to any number of websites to view content on your TV. Hulu Plus, Netflix, SyFy.com, IHeartRadio.com, and every other favorite entertainment site of mine come up just beautifully here, of course, since this IS a full-blown PC. Steam can prove to be a bit wonky here and there, and has caused me frustration a time or two, but that's that platform itself, and has nothing to do with the functionality of Alienware's Alpha console. As another reviewer has stated, my old reliable console that I'd been using for the bulk of my entertainment purposes (in my case, my Xbox 360) has sat neglected and forgotten since hooking this console up.I honestly couldn't be happier, so if you are searching for an all-around entertainment center, this is everything you could ever want. In Desktop Mode, it also gives me the comforting appearance and ease of use of Windows 7, my preferred version of Windows. Crunch the numbers and see what the cost of all of those consoles, PCs, and entertainment sources you've bought or are considering buying, total, and I have no doubt that, even at the full-blown Intel i7 version of the Alpha, you'll still save money for the performance that you'll get in this one tiny case.Best entertainment ANYthing I've ever gotten. E.V.E.R.

*UPDATE*Since receiving and assembling the unit, I have found that the remote is defective. It did not seem so problematic upon initial install and setup, but it has since proven to be so. While it's not a huge ordeal to get off one's keyster to turn a soundbar on, and adjust its settings, it does become an annoyance, considering that everything that arrives with this stand should be fully functional. Some of the buttons on it work, but the bulk of them don't, therefore, every adjustment to the bulk of the available audio options must be made via the front audio panel of the sound bar itself. Trying to get Customer Support for it has also been a nightmare. Corporate Living's website and phone system state that calls will be returned to customers a day after contact attempts by said customers have been made. I made my first call attempts on Monday. As of the close of business on Thursday, I had given up waiting for a call back, and attempted to call them again. EVERY call that I have made to their Customer Service department has ended with  me having no option but to leave a message, and I have left multiples. I even explained to the line operator yesterday that I've been trying to get a flesh and blood person on the line for days now. She explained that they were in a meeting. I asked her if they had been in a meeting on Monday, as well, as I got no response whatsoever from that department during my multiple call attempts that day, either.I rarely end up dealing with Customer Service departments where NO one EVER answers their phones, and I'm stuck leaving multiple unanswered messages, and when I do, it only serves to give me a more and more negative opinion of the company. Any company that wants to establish a good rapport and solicit repeat purchases from their customers tends to be far more responsive and timely than this. Being that this is a company that I have never worked with before, and it's been THIS much of a runaround with them, even though the bulk of the product seems well made, I just no longer have the confidence to be willing to deal with them again in the future. A product is only as good as its support, and for a piece of equipment in this price range, I expect better.Product quality, overall: 4 stars. Defective item: -.5 Customer service experience: -1.5 stars.~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~When I first received my CorLiving TV stand, I was dismayed by the condition of the box - it was quite banged up, even having a few tears pretty deep into the cardboard, and it just didn't look promising considering that half of the stand is composed of tempered glass shelves. I gingerly pulled it by its straps into my apartment (listening for the tinkle of broken glass - thankfully, there were no tinkles of doom to be heard), and my friend (whose assembly help I enlisted) got to assembling it.It seems like CorLiving knows how to package their products to endure rough handling by mail carriers, as everything within the boxes was intact. And, less than 20 minutes later, my friend was done putting it together, with no need of an extra hand from me. The wood sides of this stand are very solid, and heavy, from what he said (and I have subsequently felt in moving it around). I saw that there are also metal frame pieces for both top and bottom, the upper piece being smaller to accommodate the speaker bar that's included. There are three metal shelf tongues to hold the central glass shelf in place, and they do so well, using plastic bumpers to cradle the glass with no risk of shattering it. The one main complaint that my friend had in assembling it was that mine came with no stickers or labels on any of the glass shelves. Being that they're varying thicknesses, and certain shelves go on certain levels, that's not so great. I have a jeweler's gauge that I used to measure the thickness of each to ensure that they were placed correctly, but had I not had a tool meant for precise measurement of thicknesses in millimeters, I'm not so sure that would've been very easy to figure out.Now, on to the product, and its performance. Once assembled, it's a modern-looking, sleek and attractive piece of furniture. While I DO think it sits a bit low to the ground for the purposes of holding up a modern-day TV, it looks good once in place, and is quite wide, although I do find myself wishing it was deeper. If you happen to have your flatscreen mounted to the wall, you'll have no issues with the stand, but if you plan on simply standing your existing TV on this, it may sit a bit low for you, depending on your preference - the stand is only about two feet high, and there's barely half an inch of clearance below it, should that be information necessary for your setup purposes.While the stand is wide enough to offer plenty of space for low-clearance items, the middle shelf is only about six inches from bottom shelf to top, and a good chunk of that height is cut short by the depth of the speaker bar. The bottom shelf is only about five and a half inches high, so there wasn't any standing up of my Xbox 360, or even my Wii (I know, I know, but it's still fun to play sometimes. ;) ). As for getting my Onkyo receiver into one of these shelves? Forget it. Unless I pried the feet from the bottom of it, that just wasn't happening, so instead I have mine sitting on the very end of the top shelf, battling for space with my TV and a 7.1 channel sound bar (it's a long story...).As far as the sound itself goes, it's quite good, but it's not 7.1. Perhaps 5.0... The sound here is better, by far, than that produced by my TV's integrated speakers, and there are adjustments that can easily be made to the bass and treble. There are also five different equalizer-type settings, including Jazz, Pop, and News. The soundbar's connections are on the back side of the bar, and are beneath the top shelf, so they're not so easy to get to, but it's not impossible. My Galaxy Note 4 also immediately found the sound bar in Bluetooth connection mode, and connected to it right away. Being able to play music directly from my phone is a nice feature, and it's easy enough to switch inputs from the front of the speaker bar (and, theoretically, from the included remote, but mine arrived apparently defective, as only 1 in 10 key presses on the remote seem to be recognized).Overall, for anyone looking to upgrade their TV stand and include speakers that will beat those integrated into their TVs, this is a nice stand to consider, if the price is in your range. It's not perfect, but it's quite nice, sturdy, seems to be well-made, and has lots of nice features and adjustable options to round it out.

I read all of the rave reviews on this hair product, and decided to give it a shot. Being that I'm PAST due for my quarterly scalp-burning hair relaxer, I was hoping that this would prove to straighten out and defrizzify my hair just a bit, until I can relax it in a few days. Lo and behold, it actually did!For anyone else out there that has super curly/kinky hair, this might just help you out! Being that Mom's African-American and Dad's Caucasian, my hair isn't the coarsest or kinkiest around, but it DOES need a bit of chemical assistance every three months or so.
