While I have A LOT of hair (from what my stylists have always told me), my hair does happen to be fine, so I typically use a Regular strength relaxer. While it's not humid or warm, even, outside right now (it's been in the 40s for a few days now, as it's late Fall), my hair, once new growth hits a half inch, starts to show the effects in the roots, which get wooly and thick down under there, and drives me crazy. Applying just about two tablespoons of this product to my freshly-shampooed-and-conditioned, still-wet hair yesterday, I then followed my standard routine of sitting under a standard hand blow dryer with a soft bonnet similar to this Soft 'N Style Soft Bonnet Hair Dryer System (B). Once I took out the curlers, my new growth wasn't relaxer straight, but it was definitely straighter than it typically is when my hair gets to this stage. That, to me, is impressive!The smell of the product wasn't overwhelming to me, and was just a fresh, clean citrusy scent, which did fade pretty quickly. The texture of the product was a bit odd to me - not quite watery, but not quite a gel, either. Either way, it pours easily, and it's just a matter of emulsifying it in the hands, and massaging it through. The bottle is also PLENTY big enough to last any user for at least a good six months, I would guess of every-other-day washings, and, for me, with my once a week regimen, I expect to get a good year's worth of uses out of the sizable bottle.At this price, for its effectiveness, you really can't go wrong. I haven't come across a single product in my 30+ years of styling my own hair that actually DID seem to make good on its claims of minimizing frizz... Until this lovely compound! If you DO have issues with frizz, this just might be exactly what you're looking for! Can't wait to give this stuff a run for my money come the humid summer months, and I'll be sure to update my review with regards to my experiences with it.

I've seen the stone version of these in the past in my local TJ Maxx, and always thought they were cool-looking, and a clever idea. Where the pure stone ones were quite novel and just "neat", I love the elegant look that these chrome stones have.Whether in a glass of quality whiskey, or gently placed in the bottom of a glass filled with your favorite soft drink, these chrome-finish stones are cool, and they get your drink that way, too. The case that they come in is a nice way to ensure that they stay clean in the freezer, and the two stones are perfect for your average singleton to have on hand to cool a drink or two down before needing to use them again. Since they're filled with liquid (which you can hear if you shake them when thawed), they freeze up pretty quickly, and are ready to go again in no time flat.I look forward to bringing these out at my next intimate dinner, just for the cool factor, and the extra touch of class they add to my glass.

There really isn't much to say about printer paper.  It is white paper that you print words or in my daughter's case, pictures on.  I am pleased with the price of this paper, and with Prime, shipping is free making it convenient for me to order. I purchased this 3 in 1 vacuum cleaner because I have two Akitas.  Akitas are unique in that they don't just shed constantly:  they blow their coat.  There are constantly tumbleweeds of hair everywhere in my house.  Everywhere.  Simply sweeping with a broom, which must be done at least 5 times a day, does not suffice.  No matter how much you sweep, there is hair.  Period.A friend of mine owns a different 3-in-1 Vacuum, but when I came to find it and purchase it, they no longer make the exact model.  I shopped for one based on both price and reviews because I had limited funds to purchase one with.  I am just going to state this simply:  this thing is the best thing I have bought since they started making pre-sliced bread.  It is so great.  The suction is good, I can vacuum a whole room of tumbleweeds before emptying it (normal people can probably get the whole house in before emptying), and I can use it as a vacuum or as a hand vac!I have really tall ceilings in living room, and I cannot reach the tops even standing on a chair.  I use this in vacuum mode and literally roll the walls to vacuum the dust off of the top of the walls and get the dust off.  It is just amazing.  I used it to vacuum my ceiling fans, etc.  I have used this daily for 2 months, emptying it every time I use it, and thus far, I have not had to wash the filter.  All the fur and dust comes right off the filter when you tap it on the trash can, and the suction is as good as day one!The price is so great that even if I only got a year of use out of this (we do have a lot more fur than normal people which might be hard on a motor) it is a great value!  I would recommend this to anyone.  Please note that I have hardwood floors and tile. I do not have carpet anywhere in my home, so I have zero idea how it would work on carpet.  It does work great on furniture, mattresses and even dog beds to get hair, crumbs, and fur off.

1:38 Mins I cannot tell you the amount of times I have stumbled into things in the night that someone has left out. I am a bit of an odd ball.  I keep a string of lights on my foyer table all year round, but I change the lights for the Season or even by the month to fit the decor on the table. When it comes to cold and cough medicine it is hard to deny that Robitussin is a leader in the industry. My stone looks nothing like this picture, but I am wild about it.  My stone is not a muted blue like this.  Mine is a brilliant mint green with white marbling all through it. This is our go to dog food that we use here.  We have two Akitas, so we HAVE to use a grain free food. Akitas have super allergic skin that is prone to hot spots and itchiness and after years of expensive vet visits and prescriptions, we discovered that a grain free food solves Akita skin issues! Now there are cheaper brands of grain free food at your local Walmart or Target, but they are NOT the same.I have tried several cheaper brands, even name brands that are reputable.  However, every single time I use them, the dogs have hot spots after eating one dish of the food, and they eat twice as much of the food.  An immediate indication of a true high protein, grain free food is that your dog will eat at least 1/3 to 1/2 less than they do of what I call "junk food."  It's the same as if we eat a high protein, lots of fresh veggie meal compared to fast food burgers and fries! Taste of the Wild is the "real deal."My dogs eat much less of this food, have zero issues with their skin, and it is in my opinion as good as the $20-$30 more per bag dog foods you can buy.  I have used the $70 a bag food for my dogs and they did equally as well, but WHY would anyone spend more for dog food if this one is just as good?I recommend Taste of the Wild to everyone I know. My mother in law put her super overweight cat on the cat food Taste of the Wild, and she lost 10 pounds within 6 weeks!  Not only that, but the steroids the doctor prescribed for her skin were no longer needed once the old cat food was  fully out of her system which takes 4-6 full weeks.  All in all we LOVE Taste of the Wild and can't sing it's praises enough!  The price here is the same as it is at my local Tractor Supply store, and I have the convenience of 2 day delivery without having to lift and tote a huge bag of food, so I am loving ordering it!

I like this stone.  I am just getting into collecting stones after having just a clear quartz for months now, and I was really excited to try one with lithium in it because Winter is Coming! It has small streaks of purple through it, but it looks nothing like this picture.I have several friends who own Lepidolite, so I asked to see theirs, and mine looks nothing the same. Vast improvement on the unmoldable mouth guard tooth whiteners from 20 years back.These are individually wrapped tooth whitening strips for daily use.  It comes with enough for 28 days, and each package has a smaller strip for the bottom teeth and a larger strip for the top teeth.It took me a couple of uses to figure out exactly how to use these.  That is likely a user issue, but I found that taking a dry towel and wiping as much moisture off my teeth as possible before application helped a lot.  Also, as I apply the strip I rub up and down/all over each tooth to make sure it adheres before I tuck it over the teeth to secure.  Otherwise, the bleach will leak out of the strip, and while I am sure it isn't 100% toxic, I am uncomfortable swallowing it.My 20 year coffee habit means my teeth need all 28 uses, but after a week, it appears to be lightening my teeth a bit.  Can't wait to see the final result.*****Disclaimer:  I received sample in exchange for review.  All opinions stated here are 100% honest and my exclusive opinion******

This is my first time using a manual grinder for coffee, but I have been really wanting one and I am here to share my thoughts on this one after using it.What I like:1.  I like the slim size.  This makes it perfect for me to use at home, but also perfect to take on a camping trip, to the hotel room so I can make my own coffee, pretty much anywhere.  It is small enough to be convenient.2.  I like the green aspect of this product.  It is extremely convenient to always use electric, but in our house we try to be as eco friendly as is possible, and hand grinding fits the bill for us.3.  I like that it is a good emergency tool too.  Remember the last time you were without power for a storm, or whatever reason?  No hot coffee.  Well, I use a French Press which merely needs boiling water (I boil mine on the grill when we are in a power outage) and this grinder will effectively give you fresh, coffeehouse coffee even in the barest of situations!4.  I like that it has a hand crank and not just a twist and turn like a pepper grinder has.  It's nice to be able to use the handle.5.  It is very much like my pepper grinder in that you take the screw off, take off the clear plastic lid and fill will beans.  Screw back on and turn.6.  It gives my upper arms a nice little workout!  It isn't an exchange for the gym, but my arms feel it in a good way.7.  It was fun.  My kids were each bugging to get a chance to help me grind the coffee beans.  While I am sure the novelty will wear off, it is definitely a chore you can safely assign a 6 year old!What I wish were different:1. It only held two handfuls of beans in the grinder section of the canister.  In other words,  I need to refill the top part to get more than an 8 Demitasse cup (3 coffee mugs) of grounds.  This would take away from how convenient and portable it is, so there is a give and take with this idea.2.  It seems like a lot of work to grind the coffee.  This one, I am unsure there is a fix for, other than mindset.  Honestly, we live in a FAST, NOW, YESTERDAY society that wants the fastest solution to everything.  However, with a manual solution, It's as fast as your arms and hands work, so this is relative.  I just mentioned this because it does take a few more minutes than an electric grinder.The pics below include some text so that you can see how easy this is.*******Disclaimer:  I received product at a promotional rate in exchange for review.  All opinions stated here are 100% honest and my exclusive opinion!*****

I purchased this, not because I'm fluent in German, because I'm NOT, but rather it was a very inexpensive way to get backgrounds for cards and art journals. I use distress inks and/or stamp on them... it's a fun technique, but I still feel guilty for damaging a book every.single.time I tear out a page.

I use this in my Vagabond. Surprisingly, the thicker papers, like a 100lb or more, are the ones that can tear through with this folder. I'm still working on the perfect sandwich for using it with a thicker cardstock, but it's worth the effort. I'd like to get the most 3-D effect as possible without my paper looking as if it was die cut. ;)It's actually a challenge to find the perfect sandwich, and not always as easy as following someone else's suggestions. Things such as how worn your cutting plates are, slight differences in pressure between machines, the type/brand of cardstock used, whether you use an impression pad or just extra paper as a shim... yeah, it's definitely something you want to practice on your cheaper paper first. When I used it with the Neenah Classic Crest 80lb, it worked great with the standard sandwich for embossing folders, though.

I love being able to purchase the refills for my Tsukineko ink pads. The Brilliance Moonlight White is not as opaque as, let's say, the Hero Arts Unicorn... BUT it is great for doing a Bokeh effect where you can stencil it on and apply it a little more generously. Since it's a pigment ink, it does need some drying time. I also like to use a clear embossing powder over it. This not only prevents smudging, but gives it an extra bit of shine, too. If you have a stamp positioner, or something like the Misti, then you CAN easily get a richer white with a second pass.

Love these... even if the big "friend" stamp is not the same size as the big "friend" die that I bought a few months ago. There are a ton of other little sentiments that are short and sweet. I like the more modern and lighthearted vibe of these. The fonts are simple, they stamp cleanly, and stick well to my acrylic blocks.

I have a collection of glue runners, tapes, adhesives, glue dots, foam tape... basically anything you can imagine for getting two items to stick together. I was looking for a more cost efficient product than the *red* tapes I've used in the past, of which I've purchased 3 brands. All three were roughly $5 for 15-18 feet. This seemed to be an awesome deal for two rolls at $10 for 54 yards in total. I've used this Scor-Tape several times since receiving it a couple of weeks ago and I'm not impressed at all. I don't use my red tape for just anything... only for specific items that need a seriously strong hold. This tape does not give me the same results. It provides about the same tension hold as my Scotch ATG gun. Yes, it's easy to tear, but that's about all I find great about it. I wonder if I got a lemon, seeing all the excellent reviews and comparisons to the *red* tapes? If the second roll provides better results, I will update my review.Update, Oct. 9: Well, it seems I jumped the gun before giving this tape a fair chance. I've used about half of the roll and now find myself going for it a LOT. It DOES hold better than I initially thought, but I didn't find this out until I tried to reposition a few things after using it. It holds. It holds well. I like it well enough now that I went ahead and purchased the 1" size, which is great for using to apply glitter or foil to die cuts. I'm thinking about getting the 6x6" sheets, too. So, maybe I should ask for some salt to go with my crow. ;)
My daughter loves these. I ordered the small for her. She's 6.5 years, 49" tall, and 50lbs. These fit her perfectly, with a little room to grow.
I love this font. It's a nice change from what's currently on the market. These stamp cleanly and do well with embossing, too.

The Seashore brads are pretty, and perfect for when you need a small embellishment. I purchased these for under $5, so it was definitely a good deal considering they're nearly $9 locally. All the images are centered. They look just like the picture, and are good quality.
These super cute brads have come in handy when I've needed some kind of embellishment that wasn't too big. The quality is great and they look just like the ones in the picture.

These are so cool. I purchased them here for under $5, where locally they are nearly $9. They're great quality, the pictures are centered, and they go with so many other papers, other than the specific Prima Marketing "Cartographer" line. I should have bought two because I find myself hoarding them instead of using them. :p

Chalk it up to an incomplete item description (and a borderline aggressive seller that passes the buck. Hint: not prime)... but this is NOT the so-very-popular Hero Arts WHITE embossing powder that crafters love because it's considered to be one of the best white embossing powders. Yes, that picture looks like a flat white... not a shiny, or sparkly, clear. But, my fellow crafty crafter, don't be tricked and duped into buying a clear that you most likely already have a ton of, like me. When I purchased this in July of 2015, nowhere, in any of the three areas of listed information, did it say "Clear"... only Ultra Fine... and as most crafters know, ultra fine comes in many colors. So, you'll have to go to where Simon says to stamp ;)  to find the real deal in white.

One of my Memento markers had a crushed nib... but I didn't find this out until I began using it for the first time. I didn't want to throw the whole thing out, so I was quite happy to find these replacement nibs on Amazon. It was easy to pull the old nib out and place the new one in. Worked perfectly!

I gave this cardstock three stars because it's just okay. There was no cover weight listed in the description, so I was hoping that it would be at least an 80lb cover weight since it was titled "Premium." Nope. I can't say exactly what the cover weight might be, but I can say it's definitely not more than 65lb... and that's being generous. The color is odd. It appears to be a faded black, not a smooth consistent grey. It's hard to explain... but when the description reads: "12x12 inch solid-colored cardstock", then I'm thinking it's going to be smooth.... not going to have an obvious texture. I am having a hard time finding a heavier, smooth, grey cardstock! If you know of a good one, then please comment and let me know!Update: I've bumped it up a star. While I was't initially impressed, it's a pretty good paper. What I've decided that I like about it is that one side has a slight texture and the other side is pretty smooth. It IS a good paper, just not as thick as I was hoping. I would say it's a 65lb, weight, comparing it to my Neenah 65lb cover.

These are some really cute charms. They're bigger than I imagined they'd be, at roughly an inch tall on most of them. They're well made and there aren't any rough seams. On the packaging they're labeled as stickers, but they most definitely are not stickers. There's one small piece of a glue dot holding each one in it's place in the packaging, but that's the only stickiness they have. They're sturdy and the finish is even on all of them.

I didn't like this bathing suit because I followed the size chart and it was way too big. Plus, as any woman with a cup size of C or more will tell you, we need support! The straps, while looking really good on the model, did nothing to support my D cups. Nothing. I was slipping out of the bottom or squeezing out of the top, depending on how I tried to arrange it. There really should be a firm cup, if not an underwire, at this price point. Even though the straps gaped on my back and wouldn't lay flat, no matter how far I tried to pull the bottom down, they still dug into my shoulders. The waist area did not look flattering. It wasn't tight enough, but still managed to pucker in, in between my waist and hips, creating a very lumpy look. I also didn't like how tight it was around my legs. I was quite surprised the hip/leg was so tight. My reflection looked like: Convex, concave, convex with loose material, concave, pudge, roll, weird pucker, and finally, leg pudge being squeezed some more.On a positive note... it really made my tush look good. Somehow it managed to give it a good lift. I'm sure this would be a great bathing suit for others, and quite possibly another size might have remedied some of the issues I had, but I am returning it instead of hassling with an exchange. It WAS well made, with no strings hanging off and all the seams were sewn evenly. It's just not going to work for me. :(

This little bottle is roughly $4.50, and I use it to refill my Wink of Stella Clear Shimmer pens. Since the pens are anywhere from $6-$8 each, this saves me quite a bit of money. I just use a few drops of the Champagne Mist and fill the rest of the well with water and give it a good shake. It works perfectly! I have two of the clear Wink of Stella pens, so I was able to compare my mix with the brand new one, and it looks exactly the same.

I am an avid fan of the World of Wool. After reading the Wool series, I began reading all the fan fiction I could find. I came across this one, and at the time it had seven 5-star reviews. Well, it turns out that all the reviews were by readers that were previous fans of the author, and didn't seem to be originally searching for Wool fan fiction. Now, I really feel bad leaving a two star review, just because it takes talent to be able to write, which is something I've never attempted. But the purpose of a review is to give an opinion, good or bad. Let me start out with the good: She obviously can write. She created characters that were well developed, and I found myself wanting to find out what would happen between them. The love story itself was sweet.The BAD: It's as if someone told her about Wool and then she decided to write what she thought would fit into this world. If there were cliff notes on Wool, I'd believe that she had read the first line of each page. I realize this sounds so critical, but seriously... Her story does not belong in the Wooliverse. It doesn't. Not at all. It's almost insulting how she took Hugh Howey's storyline and changed it to something completely, utterly, different. There were NOT 1000 silos!!!!!!! It can't even begin to relate to his storyline, just on the basis of Silo 1's involvement. Plus, it's just simply, completely unbelievable. In her story, she claims that each silo's population had to be kept at 1,000. So, she's just taken Hugh Howey's original storyline and changed it from 50 silos, with about 10,000 (max) people in each silo, to 1,000 silos with each silo having only 1,000 people.  I also thought the idea of children being raised by their parents for the first 5 years, then being sent to a "dormitory" with other children to learn silo survival completely far-fetched. First, how the heck would there be enough children to warrant a dormitory if there were only 1,000 residents to begin with? There's no mention of how the parents would react to this either. Oh, but then several years later, those kids/strangers are sent back to their parents until they finish shadowing. So, a nurse, shadowing, would live with their parents until their mid twenties, while a farmer might live on their own by 14. Also, the author has changed the storyline to include "trips" to other silos. Complete malarkey. She writes that there are 1,000 silos, all in communication with each other, and they have to do what the other silos want in order to not be ostracized from the other NINE HUNDRED AND NINETY NINE silos. Ostracized from what? They're in self-contained silos! She writes that these 1,000 use "sanctioned trips from silo to silo, trading residents for residents, or goods for goods." No. Uh-uh. I don't even want to get started on silo 1000's neighbor. It's annoying and unbelievable.Oh, and the people who have to clean? Supposedly, they're like zombies after they get outside. Even though they're dead, their muscle memory keeps them up and walking around, doing things they did in the silo. THIS IS THE ENTERTAINMENT for the residents of the silo. This is what they watch on the viewing screens, as if it's funny or a running series on TV. Yuck. Oh, and if one of these zombies comes back inside the silo, then they crumble to ash when exposed to the silo air. Someone tried it because they wanted the zombie as a pet or something... tried to put them on a leash. **eye roll** This make NO SENSE. So... the air outside is toxic, but it's not toxic enough to eat through or break down the human body? Just a incredibly slow disintegration of the flesh which literally takes decades sometimes? Oh... and never once does she mention the nanotechnology, which is the entire basis of the original story in relation to the cleanings and what happens when people go outside. *SMH* This fact alone is one of the bigger glitches is her story. The NANOTECHNOLOGY. The good nanos, the bad nanos... it's not a WOOl story if it doesn't have the nanos! Lol... I'm feeling a little hyped up here. ;)She also writes about "condos" as living quarters. Supposedly, in her 1,000 silo world, the silos were originally built with different housing sizes (some large and lush) and who lived in these was determined by class. I just can't even believe she read WOOL! If she had, then she would have known that it went into depth about the architecture and the plans and how everything is the same between every silo. There were different sized units, due to single people vs. those with families (both still SMALL) which was planned, but no way would a "condo" fit into the storyline. I find it insulting to Hugh Howey by changing the main points; the basis; the roots; the everything of what made "silo life" silo life. While some fan fiction has included an elevator that was put in for a reason (and in a more believable manner,) this author did it in a way that just left me shaking my head. Anyone could use this elevator if it were available. People also wore clothing that showed off their "naked" legs, but would be sent out to clean for an unsanctioned kiss. Really? People were given the choice to wear whatever they wanted ("sleeveless shirt and cut-off pants") yet they'd be sent to clean for a kiss? There was also concern of "a rat gnawing at wires." Huh? If there had been a rat in the original silo, the silo would never have lasted. Those things reproduce prolifically, and would have destroyed the silo pretty quickly. Overall, there were just so many things that contradicted what Hugh Howey set up in his story, that I simply didn't like it being called fan fiction. If this book had been presented as it's own idea, and not fan fiction, I would have been able to give a higher rating. But, it doesn't belong within the well-loved idea of life in the "Wooliverse" as a "Siloan" or "Silozen" would have lived... or died... and then stayed dead.I think she should retitle this book. I wouldn't recommend this to another true fan of WOOL. While her writing, in and of itself, was fine (I'll even say very good!) she should stick with romance writing and stay out of the Wooliverse.... unless she wants to play in this playground by the *acceptable* rules. Kind of easy: There are 50 Silos. People die when they go outside... and they don't walk around while dead. A trip to another silo is not something done casually, even with some sort of "sanctioning." This is harsh, I know... but when she took the premise of Wool and made such gargantuan changes, it was almost as if she was spitting in Hugh Howey's face.

Tsukineko's Pico Embellishers are wonderful! The needle tip allows for such precise application. Inside the cap is another, smaller needle that prevents it from getting clogged. Be careful not to bend it when putting the cap back on! I love how the colors match the ink pads, also. It's a lot thinner than Stickles, and slightly thinner than Glossy Accents. It dies evenly, without cracking, and leaves a beautiful shine. I've purchased this one (Danube Blue), Cottage Ivy, Angel Pink, Clear, Rose Bud, and Shimmer. The Shimmer is the only one that isn't perfect due to the air bubbles created when it's shaken. These are addicting! Perfect for flowers, adding dimension to "water" on cards, and even lettering, just to name a few things it can be used for. It's not a tiny bottle, so it'll last a long time... unless you're trying to cover a larger area. Such a fun product!

I have six colors in the Pico Embellishers, but this is the only one I have with shimmer. While every other color is awesome, amazing, beautiful and fun, this one is a little more tedious due to the fact that it has to be shaken, repeatedly, during use. All the shimmer will settle at the bottom in between uses and it takes a LOT of shaking to get it completely incorporated. The reason I knocked off two stars is because of the air bubbles. It's not like one can wait for the bubbles to go away, because by then the shimmer is settling at the bottom again. I still like it, but it's a hassle trying to pop all those little bubbles. It helps to "prime" it on a scrap piece of paper, but there will still be bubbles.

I purchased the Neenah Classic Crest Solar White in the 110# cover weight at the same time I purchased this. This paper is advertised as 270gsm, but I have a difficult time believing it. While it's nice, it's quite the difference... and there shouldn't be a big difference between a 100# and a 110# cover. The Neenah is 279gsm, so a difference of only 9gsm is not much at all. {{{{{{{{{While this would be absolutely perfect for invitations, it just doesn't have that super-heavy cardstock feel that a lot of card makers like as a card base.}}}}}}} I've actually bumped it up to 5 stars, but I'd really give it 4.5 if I could. So, while it's a beautiful paper, and the speckles give it a unique feel, it's just shy of being a true heavy-weight cardstock. I really hate to sound like some kind of paper snob, but I was hoping for something like the Bazzill heavyweight cardstock in peanut cluster, which is a 100# cover weight also... and now that I think about it, this is definitely nowhere near as heavy.

These three *dies* are more like metal embossing sections. They leave a definitive edge line in the paper, which I don't like. They do NOT cut. With that being stated, they come in handy as a layering piece, even though they're individually small. The wood grain is the biggest at 3.75" long by 1.3" long. The other two are slightly smaller.

These are very pretty papers in muted shades. They are not the same thickness as cardstock, but about the thickness of standard copy paper. The 4.5 x 6.5 size is great for A2 sized cards when using them as a background layer. The are loose in a plastic sleeve.

First of all... this is NOT rubber, as the description states. It's acrylic. It's a great stamp set with a variety of owls. They produce crisp images and are a breeze to clean, as most acrylic stamps are.
This stamp is quite versatile. It stamps cleanly, too. I've used it for many cards... and especially masculine cards. It's just over 2.5" tall and 2.25" wide.

These shorts have a bit of spandex in them which allows for a decent amount of stretch. I love the hem because it can be rolled up with a thick or thin cuff. I could have easily taken a smaller size, but they're cut well so they fit like a boyfriend short. The rise is higher than 8"... it's more like 9", and definitely above the area where some of us have to worry about muffin top. I am enjoying these so much that I bought another pair in this color and a pair in the Airlie color.

I bought this from the Warehouse deals for about $6, so I figured it wouldn't be too much of a waste if I didn't like it. Well.... it's just "okay." One stamping did NOT give me the results that appear in the picture. Several layers, though, in different muted shades of cream to brown (I used Distress Inks) gave me a good result of a very aged-look piece of paper.I tried using this flat on it's back with laying the paper on top; I tried using it on my Fiskars big stamper with the orange foam feet; I tried using it on an acrylic block; I tried it on my art table with no cushioning; and last but not least, I tried it on a hard foam cushion. So... it wasn't for lack of trying. The result SHOULD look like a chalkboard, but I'm only finding it useful for creating the aged-paper look, which is still useful, but it requires several layers of ink.

These sequins are tiny. The colors are good, with black, silver, gold, and a light green. I'm not too fond of the packaging, though. As soon as I tried to open the back of the package, these tiny sequins acted as if they had internal motors and started flying straight out of the package. As I tried to gather them up, they developed a case of severe separation anxiety and would not leave my hands. I tried to relax them with some lavender scented powder, to no avail. Freakishly insecure little things! After ten minutes of coaxing and cussing, I finally managed to get them into the little container.
These 8mm sequins are the perfect size for card embellishments. Much larger than the tiny sequins, they can be used individually for a pop of color. All are consistently sized and colored.

I am by no means a professional... but I really enjoy all types of methods for coloring my stamped images. This was my first set of the soft core pencils and I love the smoothness of them. The colors are vibrant and easy to blend. I recently used these on an image, over some of my Prismacolor markers, to lighten up a few areas that were too dark. It turned out much better than I had hoped! I was able to save my image, rather than scrapping it.

This pleasantly plump fairy is adorable. I've had so much fun making cards with her. I've switched up the sentiment with "have a Fairy happy birthday" and the "Have a MAGICAL day!" that comes with it. She takes center stage on an A2-sized card. Stamps cleanly, too. I've added a picture of one I've been working on tonight. It's not finished, but it gives an idea of her size.
This is one of my current favorites. She's such a fun and happy pig. She stamps cleanly, too. Art Impressions' stamps are excellent quality.

These are so fun! I have several of the Plaid Delta stencils and I like how sturdy they are. This one in particular is great, not only for the balloons, but because there are two clouds and six birds. So, even if I don't need balloons, the clouds and birds come in handy often. I've recently started using rubber cement (or frisking can be used from what I understand) to mask these after I've stenciled and then do a background behind them. Once finished, gently rub away the masking and you reveal your "masterpiece." YouTube has several videos on how to achieve these effects. Super easy and fun with these stencils. I just throw mine in a bowl of water to keep them damp until I'm ready to clean them completely.

Although I returned this, it's still a wonderful die set. The description (when I ordered) made me think these would work with my card making, but when I received them the sizes were just a little too odd for me to keep them. Those who journal with the 4x6 cards would love these, though!
Great little die set of numbers and symbols. They cut well and I really like the dots in them which make them fun. Use with wax paper for super easy release.

I'm now addicted to the Silo series. If you see the compilation for sale just go ahead and buy it because once you read the first one you'll be addicted also. I was sad to see the series end, but thank goodness for some pretty good fan fiction that's out there. I honestly don't remember which phase Dust was, but the entire series is amazing... each and every book!

My daughter adores the whimsical mermaid on the top. The container fits several of my silicone baking cups, which I use as dividers for her quartered/shaped sandwiches, fruits, veggies, and a small sweet. I used four square cupcake-sized cups and one round one in the middle. It's surprisingly spacious and has more height than I expected. It fits in her square, zip up lunch box with room on the side for napkins, a fork, or a yogurt drink. One of the best things about this for me is that I am not using plastic baggies anymore. I knocked off one star due to the fact that it did not close flush when it arrived and also because the plastic "hinge" doesn't seem as if it's going to last a long time. I'll update after we've had more time to use it.

This is a big moon. It's about 3" in length, so it would take up the majority of an A2 sized card. I do like it, and it cuts just fine. I'll most likely use it as the main focus of an A2 card, or on a 5x7 card. The stars are a little whimsical and two are the same size. It would be perfect for a scrapbooking page... baby or romantic.

This is a very pretty, yet extremely tedious die to work with. I used wax paper with it, and still had trouble getting all the spaces out. There were several spots that didn't cut cleanly, which caused my paper to tear when I was trying to separate them. Trying to get my small scissors into those spots was no field day, either. I'm not giving up on it yet, but it's never going to be my favorite.

I love every single stamp I've bought by Deep Red. The quality is excellent, they're deeply etched, easy to clean, and they come on a hard plastic sheet which the stamp will cling to for storage. This set in particular has been fun because of the four "Yolanda's" to choose from. The outline is very crisp, with thin lines, so I have to take a little more time coloring in order to stay in the lines. These come on one piece of rubber (and foam) and you'll need to cut the stamps out. Once that's done, you're ready to go.

These are perfect! Because they're clear, you can repeat the pattern perfectly, creating any size background you like. I used the polka dots on the left of the package, and was able to line each stamp up almost perfectly. Once I had the entire A2 sized sheet stamped, it wasn't noticeable on the two spots that the user error ;) occurred.

These have the inner elastic band to adjust the waist, which is so handy for kids. The butterflies are adorable on the back pockets, and they're not too short. Well made shorts in a soft denim. They're not thin, though, and I expect the denim to hold up longer than the sequins on the back pockets.

I usually wear a 29 in Lucky. I purchased these in a 30 because I've gained about 10 pounds and my 29's were getting snug. These were snugger than my 29's! They'll look great once I lose the holiday weight, but they're going to be sitting in my dresser until then. It's a great denim... soft, yet sturdy.

These are precious. They cut well, too. In one run through your machine, you have two birds. With another run through on different colored paper, you have the pieces to fill in colors to create a really cute contrast for four birds. The size is perfect for A2 and A4 sized cards.

For nearly $3, all you get is four small sheets and a 1"x1" piece of sandpaper. While the description says this, it's quite underwhelming in hand. For this much, just go ahead and spend a little more for the bigger pack because four sheets at nearly $1 a piece is not worth it. Now, for the quality of this paper: It's fun. You can dry emboss on it and follow up with sanding to bring out the design even more. The core is a lighter shade of the top color. It's a nice change from their white-core papers. It does seem to be a good 80lb weight.

This thing is so handy! I absolutely love the fact that it takes the guess work out of placing a stamp. I accidentally ordered two of these, but Amazon didn't want the extra one back. So, if you want the extra one let me know. ;)

This is my second set of satin shorts and tank from Oscar De La Renta. The sizing is a little generous, but not so much that you'd need to order a size down. I ordered the medium last time, and they fit perfectly... then I gained 20 pounds over the last year (which I swear I'm going to lose, right after I eat this ice cream cone) and those are a tad snugger than I like. The large has room to spare, but they're still flattering. I have back issues, so I prefer satin pj's. Believe it or not, it makes it so much easier to roll over in bed when you wear satin. Plus, they're gorgeous!

This is the third book by Douglas Richards that I've read and it didn't disappoint. The characters are likable, except when they have their own noble agendas, which only adds to the story. I really enjoyed the science fiction of the story, and can't help but think how cool it would be to have some of the abilities he writes about.

This is advertised as a "Die Template" as of Dec. 4. But, they're not... they're simply blanks that are used as embellishments. While they are cute, they need to change the description. I'm returning them. This review is not to say the quality isn't good for a blank, but rather to warn anyone who might purchase thinking they are actually dies that cut.

For any newbies or inexperienced crafters in regards to dry ink pads. Please let me fill you in on a tip so you don't waste your money or pads like I did. I had to learn the hard way. If you are using a dye or alcohol ink, this is exactly what you need: FELT. BUT, if you are using a thicker ink such as pigment, embossing, or reflective, or any thicker specialty ink... get the FOAM pad. These are great pads, as long as you are using them with the right inks. I read a couple of reviews that stated the top didn't seem like real felt, which I agree with, but it is a sturdy type of cotton cloth... for lack of a better description. Either way, it's a great way to get your own color combination with thinner inks. Or a cheaper alternative for when refill bottles are on clearance, which is actually what I did. This pad was $3, and the refill bottle was $1, so for $4 I had the same pad as the $13 labeled pad.

I like this set. It's just what you'd expect for a stamp and die set. BUT, the only thing I don't like it how the dies are actually quite hard to line up over the stamped image. This is why I deducted one star. It's difficult to line some of them up because of the embossing portion of the metal die that blocks the image. I will definitely still use it. I just have to take those few extra moments of guesswork. Some of them looked great after stamping, cutting, and embossing... while a few made me scratch my head thinking how had I gotten it twisted? Or was it supposed to look like that? lol... I may just skip the embossing next time.

These were bigger than I anticipated, which isn't a bad thing. There are several sentiments and quotes for so many different situations where you need something about happiness or laughing. I love the different fonts, and also the quirkiness of some of the sayings. This was a really good deal at ~$10 for such big stamps.

These little greetings are small. Really small. About an inch long kinda small. But, I knew this, so I wasn't surprised. These little guys are perfect for smaller tags, pennants, banners, or just a little note. There's a great variety in such a small area, too. Some holidays, and just about every other general sentiment you could ask for.

After purchasing a couple of the Sizzix alphabet strip dies, I decided to try this. I LOVE it. It's so much easier to just cut out exactly what I need, rather than doing the entire alphabet or placing scraps over specific areas. The letters cut cleanly and the font is great for just about any sentiments.

This pack has a great variety of textures (foil, glitter, embossing), designs, and cut-outs. I'm really pleased with it, since this is my first purchase of anything by Kaisercraft. The plain sheets seem to be about a 65lb weight (or almost) and the textured pages are a little thicker. There are four pages of cut-outs, and thankfully the lines are where they're supposed to be. The fairies look a little odd to me, but that's just a personal preference. Every other page is gorgeous.

I ordered this dress for a military ball. I went by their sizing chart and it fit perfectly. The quality was excellent. All the pleats were seen evenly; not a single string was hanging off; the beads were sewn on securely, and the fabric was beautiful. I absolutely loved this dress and felt amazing in it. I wouldn't hesitate to purchase from eDressit, and I plan to again, soon.

This is a great deal on rhinestones. I usually use extra glue on rhinestones that are already adhesive because I want to be sure that they won't fall off. So adding glue isn't an extra step for me. The colors are clear and they all seem to be consistently round. (I've ordered rhinestones in the past that weren't cut correctly and some would have weird edges.)

This pad is fantastic. First, I somehow missed the fact that it was 8.26"X11.69", so I was really happy to receive more than a 6X6 pad. The pages are a great weight. It's about a 65lb stock. The quality is excellent and the colors are beautiful. I would highly recommend this pad to any card maker or anyone who uses paper in their art.

This is not my favorite paper. I thought it would be a great textured paper to add as a background or to die-cut. *SMH*First, don't even think about using it in a trimmer. That's not going to work. Second, if you plan on using it for dies, be ready to trim and trim and trim the fuzzy little loose edges... that is, if it doesn't tear in the process of the die cut or just when you're handling it. Third, if you happen to get it into some other shape than the 6 X 6 piece it comes in, you better make sure you get the placement perfectly the first time. There will be no reposistioning allowed! AT ALL. Oh wait. I guess if you used a very slow drying glue, you might have some luck. Willing to take that chance? LolWhat it is good for: Cutting with a very sharp pair of scissors and...Well, I'll update if I find something else.

These fit true to size, yet they have the ability to s-t-r-e-t-c-h a lot. He said they don't ride up or lose their shape on the second day. I'm praying he means on a particularly lazy weekend or when he's out in the field. OK, so maybe he didn't really say that, but half you guys know there's some truth to this.I've washed them twice and they seem to be holding together perfectly. I'll be buying more. I think this time I'll get the "Best Boyfriend Ever" just to impress his friends.
Loved it! It was a twisted ride from beginning to end.

This is a beautifully intricate die set that makes an A2 card go from "nice" to "WOW!" There are many combinations with these four dies. Because this is such an intricate set of dies, I've learned a few tricks to make them a lot easier to use. First, I use wax paper between the die and the cardstock. Secondly, I use the Spellbinders Craft Tool N' One to get all the little pieces out very quickly. Let me tell you... I didn't think this little tool would be all that, BUT IT IS! For dies like these, it's invaluable.Back to the dies, though.For embossing with my Vagabond, I run the die through as I would any standard die, then I flip it over while my cardstock is still in the die and sandwich it as follows: Solo platform with solo shim, acrylic plate, cardstock in die with cutting edge UP, Sizzix silicone rubber mat, and lastly, the Sizzix impressions pad. The embossing is subtle on any paper that has a print on it, but it really stands out on solid paper.

These three cloud dies have gotten more use than I ever imagined I would use them for. They cut cleanly every time. I really like the fact that they're not straight along the bottom, too. With a quick swipe of light blue, grey, or silver along the bottom, you've got yourself a beautiful puff of a cloud. They can also be used to make a tree: Simply cut out the trunk of a tree, then layer the clouds (cut from green card stock) where you'd put leaves, and viola!... You've got a tree at the height of the season.

This is such a great basic set for layering an A2 card. These nine dies can be used in so many combinations! The rounded edges give any card a subtle finished touch. The long and thin dies are perfect for sentiments. The fact that they also emboss the cardstock is such a plus. I use them in my Vagabond with no problem at all. For embossing, I run the die through as I would any standard die, then I flip it over while my cardstock is still in the die and sandwich as follows: Solo platform with solo shim, acrylic plate, cardstock in die with cutting edge UP, sizzix silicone rubber mat, and lastly, the impressions pad. Hope this helps anyone with a Big Shot or Vagabond.

I love VersaFine for embossing highly detailed stamps. It's the only embossing ink I've found that gives consistently clean and crisp results with a fine embossing powder. I use it with any images that have a LOT of fine details and also any sentiment stamps that are small or when the font is close together. It also lasts longer than other pigment inks and you don't have to worry about promptly closing it to prevent the ink from drying out. The reinker allows for many refills of the larger VersaFine ink pad and I like being able to keep the pad really moist.

This is a great Embosslit to have. It can be used for birthday cards or Christmas cards (or scrapbooking.) I love how easy it is! One quick run-through in my Vagabond and out pops a perfectly embossed and cut present. With a little Gelly-roll pen, it can be detailed even more in seconds.

These sea-themed stamps are beautiful. They're deeply etched and give very detailed impressions. I was a little surprised when I received them because they're bigger than I anticipated. I like the fact that they can be used in so many different ways individually, yet they work well together, too. The mermaid and the octopus would be a little difficult to use together since they're the biggest, unless you put them on an 5 x 7 card.

I love this set of coordinating dies and stamps. They're so much fun and make it quite easy to put together a quick card. The dies cut cleanly; the stamps give detailed images; together they work like a charm. It was a bit more than what I wanted to spend at $31, BUT, I don't regret it one bit considering I've already made about five cards from this set. It's great that Lawn Fawn puts in all the cute little stamps as extras. They come in handy all the time.

This is such a great collection of steam punk designs! Actually, It's not overwhelmingly steam punk, but all of the pages will go with any steam punk stamps or ephemera. The paper is thick and all the pages coordinate beautifully. There are three pages of each of the 12 designs. I've been able to use them in some really neat cards for friends. They also cut perfectly with the dies I've used. Since the cut-out pack only had two hot air balloons, I used my Lawn Fawn dies from the Blues Skies set and was able to make several more. This is one of my favorites!

First off, if you want to have any success at all with the smaller banners, don't even try them without wax paper. Also, don't get your hopes up that the dots will pop out without a fight. Be prepared with all your tricks and secret tools because you're going to need them. The stripes and chevron patterns work a little better, and there's no issues at all with the biggest, open banners. Hopefully, they're not all like this, and maybe my set just doesn't cut as deeply as intended.Update: One trick that I've recently found is to take a metal tip (I use a tool for pottery that looks like a metal pencil with a needle on the end) or anything hard enough that won't be damaged by the edges of the metal dies, and I rub it over the entire area, such as the dots, AFTER I've run it through my die cutter, but before I remove the paper from the die. This "cuts" through any of the areas that didn't cut cleanly in my machine. I wish I didn't have to hassle with it at all, but it's a way to get the dots and stripes out of the smaller banners, instead of them never being used at all.

I usually love Stampendous embossing powders, but this isn't my favorite. The effect itself is cool, it's just that it doesn't change color... that slight difference you see when heating it that lets you know it's done. I've actually singed some paper because of this, but I'm going to see if I can figure out any tricks with it.

I have color treated hair and I am always looking for a good solution to make it more soft and manageable. When you are always dyeing your hair because of grays and then coloring it and highlighting it can make my hair so brittle. I started using the Advanced care Shampoo and Conditioner. It makes my hair feel nice and silky and I use the conditioner. I am in much more control of my hair either letting it air dry or the blow dryer.The Argan Oil and Macadamia Oil I put in my hair after i towel dry it. When I let my hair dry naturally it gives me slight waves that do not look frizzy. It calms my hair down and makes it feel and look more healthier. Color treated hair is hard to take care of but these products from Arvazallia makes my hair feel great. I received these products complimentary in exchange for my unbiased review and opinion. All opinions and words are my own.

I love giving my dogs vitamins and my one dog is older (13) and she does have problems going up and down steps. The supplements do help with her joints. She gives me a hard time taking them she is very picky. She does take it on her own after a few minutes and chews it. I love the soft chews because it is easy for them to chew. All-natural Ingredients Glucosamine-free.Vitamins and supplements are very important to a dogs health. I received these supplements complimentary or discounted in exchange for my unbiased review and opinion. All opinions and words are my own.

Absolutely love my new Wine Bottle Opener and  Quad Blade Foil Cutter. Very well made. Corkscrew is a Lever Style Screwpull which works just perfect. I have an older type of Corkscew and this one is much easier to use. Just turn a few times till the levers on the side go up and then push down and pop that cork !! The foil cutter is easy to use and makes it much easier to then use the opener.GUARANTEED FOR LIFE: If you're not delighted with your WineTools PRO Wine Opener, simply return it at any time for a full refund of your purchase price. I did receive this product complimentary or discounted in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

A perfect set of Tweezers I received from Grooming District. The packaging was perfect. I came with 3 tweezers that can be used for tweezing eyebrows, removing splinters removing unwanted facial hair. The tweezers sit in a cute case that is great to travel with. I do not have to worry about loosing these tweezers because they have a case.Each one is different for many uses. Slant, Straight and Pointed Tip Tweezers. I received this product at a discounted price in exchange for my honest and unbiased review. All opinions and words are my own.

A double set of nail clippers two sizes. They come nicely boxed. One is a finger nail clipper and the other is for your toes. It comes in a cute pouch to store when not in use. I like that idea I do not like clippers that are just placed somewhere and not covered. It also has a convenient nail file to finish after clipping. I received this set complimentary in exchange for my unbiased review and opinion. All words and opinions are my own.

This is a fabulous set for my keyboard and my mouse. I love how soft it is.  This keyboard wrist pad is made from High Quality Foam, Lightweight, and is very comfortable. The mouse pad has a back that is higher for my wrist to sit nice comfortable. It is the perfect size. The key board wrist rest fits standard keyboards and it helps my wrists from going over the edge of my pull out drawer where my keyboard sits.I have had a similar one with gel inside that lost its shape quickly. This is foam and is so much lighter and bounces right back into shape. Perfect gift idea. I received this set from CushionCare complimentary in exchange for my unbiased review and opinion. All words and opinions and my own.

This is a super backpack for my husband and son to take upstate. When it first arrived I honestly didn't know what it was. It was a small bag that I opened and inside was the backpack. I love the idea you can put it easily back inside when not in use.My son also goes to the gym everyday and he needed a new backpack to take his towels change of clothes and water bottles. On each side you can place your drinks. In side is very roomy with an outside compartment to keep all your important items such as phone, keys etc. It is made from nylon which is nice and soft. Lightweight material so you can also take it anywhere. I received this backpack complimentary in exchange for my unbiased review and opinion. All opinions and words are my own.

Edgerton presents a very detailed and wide ranging work on British war production in WWII.  He shows us tables of goods produced and imported.  I liked that part of things.  I was less interested in the extensive coverage of inter agency battles among the various players in the British industrial and scientific community.  I still found this a useful work chock a block with data.

We look with amazement upon this volume.  How can Eric Flint still, after so many books, continue to interest and entertain us?  Well, he has a knack for creating characters that we enjoy spending time with.  Some people I think consider  these book to be a kind of action thriller.  But not so.  They are full of economics and social history-every bit as much as a heroic shoot'um up.  There are some good battle action but not as much and not as close in as in some of the other books.  Flint has a large cast to work with, all of whom are worth spending time with.  I like the inter action among them which Flint uses to explain the obscure to most Americans social and political situation in the Commonwealth of Poland and Lithuania in that era.  Flint manages to introduce the context of the culture with gentle guidance.  His over arching theme of a broken Europe, a Europe twisted and distorted by the history of Germany, is one that I find insightful.  I want to read this book and his others because they are just fun to read, to enjoy, to relax and enter another world for a little while.  But I appreciate Flint's work because of what I learn in terms of history, economics, invention and historical social realities.  I can't wait for the next volume.

Dr. Carol has created a work of deep scholarship in "From Jerusalem to the Lion of Judah and Beyond".  So deep that the last third of the book, very nearly, is taken up with foot notes, appendixes and citations.  But the body of the work is crammed full of not simply data stacked upon data but insight as well.  I knew that Idi Amin of Uganda proudly wore Israeli paratrooper wings but I didn't know that the fraud never made a jump.  Some details are utterly fascinating, like the troubles of Ethiopian fisherman in adapting to modern methods taught by Israelis.  Other facts cause a tightening of various body parts.  The long, disconnected and complicated history of helping the lost Jews of Ethiopia count here.  Dr. Carol covers East Africa from the first days of Israel's engagement to the connections with the new nation of South Sudan.  There is much here to learn, even for life long followers of the story of Israel like me.  Or for that matter for students of the post WWII history of East Africa.  This isn't always a pleasant book to read but it is vastly informative and at the core of it, it is a work of hope.  Decent people car actually make the world a better place, in spite of man's worst impulses.

Mr. Froczyk has managed to combine an astonishingly detailed, day by day telling of the first two years of WWII in the East with such compelling prose that it almost seems like a thriller.  I have read widely on matters WWII for 50 years but never have I received such a comprehensive telling of this story.  We learn just how effective the generalship of the German war machine was in the first two years, and how astonishingly incompetent the Communists were.  But at very great cost, the Soviets learned the hard lessons and threw up leaders who could stand against the Nazis.  From a human perspective, this is a tale of absolute horror.  From a distance of more than 70 years, it makes a fascinating read.

The Movie Review by Andy McKinneyThe 33 How hard is it to make a real life drama about an event that the whole world knows about?  How hard to make a film about a story familiar to every one and make it not simply interesting to watch but to make it mesmerizing to the audience?  I'd say about as hard as granite or maybe as hard as the rocks in a Chilean mine.  But Mexican born film director Patricia Riggen does just that.  "The 33" is quite simply wonderful film making. I am sure you remember the true life events depicted in the movie.  A cave-in in a deep rock mine in Chile trapped 33 miners deep underground.  They remained trapped for 69 days.  The whole world watched and waited along with the loved ones of the miners, hoping and praying for a successful rescue. While still underground the miners themselves agreed with one another to produce a single voice to the world after rescue and to share equally in any proceeds.  The men knew that they would be famous.  The book on their trials, "Deep Down Dark" became the basis of the film.  In spite of five different pens having a share in the script the power of the story comes through in the movie.  We get to know several of the miners well enough to root for their rescue.  One poor guy, the real life Carlos Mamani, was a Bolivian, a foreigner and an Indian, separated by nationality and race and on his first day on the job, friendless and utterly alone. Others among the miners included an alcoholic who could just barely function, a young new father, a Christian who served as the spiritual hub for the trapped men and their leader who became known as 'Super' Mario.  Even though we know the outcome, we sit enthralled as they struggle to survive starvation and madness deep beneath the earth. A big big tip of the hat must go to director Paticia Riggen for her management of this project.  She doesn't do anything flashy, no clever director tricks to distract us.  She lets her players tell the story, the upper story of the family members and rescuers and the lower story of the men trapped with only a few pitiful cans of tuna to sustain them. The cast members, starting with Antonio Banderas as 'Super' Mario, the natural leader of the men, do a great job of showing the strain on the trapped miners as human beings in a very tough spot.  Many of the cast members are from South America but you might have seen Rodrigo Santoro, a Brizilian actor who played the Chilean Minister of Mines.  Besides Bandaras other familier faces  include Lou Diamond Philips as a miner and Gabriel Byrne and James Brolin as rescuers.  French actress Juliette Binoche plays the sister of a miner and represents the frantic family members of the lost men.  You will recognize long time character actor Bob Gunton who plays the president of Chile. This movie satisfies on every level.  The above average four saw blade film runs a good long two hours and seven minutes.  In spite of its very serious theme it carries a mild PG-13 rating. "The 33" was filmed in Columbia and Chile.  The opening shots of the stark landscapes of the Chilean dessert show a kind of very hard beauty.  This very well done film took in only $6 million in the USA over the opening week end but world wide box office of $18.5 helps the producers make back the $26 million budget.  The producers should be rewarded for making this superior film and I think they will.

This third volume picks up the story of the time lost West Virginians and the Germany of the 30 years war.  The plot is active with lots of different story lines running simultaneously.  We have a large cast of characters, some from our time and some from the year 1634.  Eric Flint has the wonderful ability to create characters that have such authenticity that we believe in them.  They have such warmth as people that we want to be with them, to share their journey and walk for a while in their presence.  Flint is a great story teller with an imagination strong enough to take us along with him.

The Osprey Fortress boulmes are justly famed for their all around excellence.  "Norman Stone Castles 2" is outstanding in this grand company.  This is not simply a book of pretty pictures, although the drawings by artist Adam Hook are wonderful, colorful and exquisitely detailed.  Besides Mr. Hook's drawings we have the gift of many photos of castles as they exist today, ruins in other words.  In a recent to the Osprey books innovation, many of the photos are in full color.  That adds a lot to the reader's enjoyment and understanding.  Author Christopher Gravett ends the book with thumbnail descriptions of literately dozens of castles in Normandy, Sicily and Southern Italy.  In each brief entry he gives the location and current status of that particular castle.  Mr. Gravett knows his castles.  For a time in his career he served as the senior curator at the Tower of London.  Gravett covers the subject in great detail, much more detail than we have any reason to expect in a 64 page book.  He covers things that we might expect such as life in a castle and a castle at war.  Not expected are details like the cost of castles to the people who built them.  This book is well worth the small cost for any of us with an interest in the subject.

Author Eric Flint has the knack of creating such strong, vivid characters that we want to travel along with them as if they were our friends and not just made up people.  I got hooked with the first book in this series and eagerly wait for each new volume.  So, great characters, likable characters (who wants to read about characters who are believable but not likable?)  and what else?  Flint has a strong grasp of economics, which I enjoy.  He understands the relationship among the various aspects of technology, industry and invention that allows an economy to thrive.  So, the author is smart.  And the plot keeps us turning the pages.  He bumps off his characters once in a while so we never know quite how a particular event will unfold.  We hope the brash young teens will find some clever way to survive, but we have no surety that they will.  We want the brave, ambitious King of Sweden to survive his injuries, but we can't be sure he will.  We absolutely want the Prince of Germany to keep the balls in the air long enough to create a better world than the one he left.  The deep scholarship of the author also impresses his readers.  There are swirls and eddies in European history that Flint exposes and explores over and over again.  In reading The Saxon Uprising for enjoyment I find new knowledge on subjects of geography, language and history that enlighten me.  I put The Saxon Uprising right at the top rank of the books in this series.  I have re-read it a couple of time just to spend more time in that fascinating world.

The Men-at rms series of books by Osprey lean heavily to the needs of model makers and this volume is no exception.  There are long tracts covering the various uniforms, helmets and what not.  The excellent full color drawings by artist Stephen Andrew go all the way back to 1911.  These drawings also show in detail many of the extravagant variety of weapons used in China in the first half of the 20th century. Oddly enough, these drawings provided more or at least as much that is of interest to me as the text.  Author Philip Jowett includes a long and detailed chronology of the battles in China between 1911 and 1949 when the Chinese civil war ended.  This helped me to understand the flow of the fighting.  Jowett has also penned several full length books on China.  I'll be looking into them for more of the details on Chinese armies.

Bridge of Spies Ok, Seven Spielberg directs Tom Hanks for the fourth time.  We expect something extraordinary and we get something magnificent.  In every respect this film satisfies.  Hanks just keeps on getting better and better as he gets older.  The meticulous attention to detail lavished on the film by director Spielberg has not been equaled in recent memory.  The script by Ethan and Joel Coen has a solid feel illuminated at frequent intervals by brilliance.  I liked this one a lot. Some of us will remember the events in the film as part of our personal life memorabilia.  For the other, younger viewers, this film has a genuine basis in fact.  At the end of the Eisenhower administration the U2 (yes, that is where the band got its name) spy plane had just been put in operation.  Unlucky Francis Gary Powers had the misfortune of being shot down on a photo mission 70,000 feet above the Soviet Union.  Living through the experience, he suffered captivity by the Godless Communists that then ran that sorrowful nation. At more or less the same time our FBI captured a Soviet agent, a KGB officer living quietly in New York City and running an operation there.  Naturally, we wanted our pilot back safe and sound.  The communists wanted their agent back.  It seems like Kismet, no?  A simple swap, everybody gets something and we can get on with our business. Nope, nothing is as simple as it seems.  While the negotiations go on the communist government of East Germany builds the Berlin Wall and ruthlessly shoots citizens trying to escape bondage and breathe the free air of the West. Tom Hanks plays James Donovan, an insurance attorney of all things, who gets conscripted to make the arrangements.  The Soviets do not want to publicly acknowledge their agent so there can be no government to government talks.  To complicate matters further, a young American student gets snatched by the East German communists and held as a lever to force the American government into recognizing their government. This seems like a complicated, not to say tangled, story and of course it is.  But the script by the Coen brothers helps us keep up.  Also appearing is Alan Alda as the lawyers boss.  In a tiny role as an FBI agent Domenick Lombardozi (The Wire) underplays his usual bombastic self.  Amy Ryan had a very small role as Mrs. Donovan, the worried wife of the negotiator which she accomplished with grace and subtlety. This outstanding film runs for two hours and 21 minutes and will surely get a flock of Oscar nominations.  It has a mild PG-13 rating.  The budget of $40 million has returned $45 million in its first week at the box office. Watch all the way for a truly wonderful few moments of film making. Spielberg has his actors work without words for the last moments of the film.  How can an actor invoke tears while not saying a word? In real life the insurance man was not such a wild card as a negotiator.  He served in the OSS as general counsel in WWII and also as a prosecutor at the Nuremburg war crimes trials. Movie fun-watch for the Berlin theater marquee.  The theater is showing  Eins, Zwei, Dre, the German name of the American film of the time One, Two, Three, a film involving people caught up in East Berlin, West Berlin problems.  Spielberg is the man.

Slumdog MillionaireSlumdog Millionaire is not what I expected it to be and is like nothing I have ever seen before.  I expected to see brilliant tropical colors and I expected to hear exotic music in the sound track.  I got both.  I was not expecting to see the protagonist-played by handsome young Dev Patel-having the truth beat out of him by angry Indian policemen.  The torture of the young contestant on a TV game show provides the frame for the tale of the life of the young man, the Slumdog of the title. What results is a journey into the horrid underside of Indian society.  We find out about Indian gang lords and the most horrific exploitation of children.  These children are quite literally thrown onto the garbage heap of Mumbai.  Keep in mind that horror compounds horror to the beat of peppy Hindi pop music, everything filmed in the beautiful visual feast that makes up the Indian color palette. Director Danny Boyle has made his reputation with this amazing film.  He will now be joined in conversation with the very best directors in the century of film making.  Bravo.  Co-star Freida Pinto preformed her action assignments-she was tasked to be beautiful and be in danger-with room to spare.  Patel played his role with steady stoicism, as fit the character. Slumdog Millionaire is rated R-in Indian film there is no nudity or foul language, the deserved rating is for violence and theme.  It has plucked a bouquet of 10 academy award nominations from the Academy of Motion Pictures.  This gripping, horrifying, engaging and brilliant film gets a stellar four and a half saw blades. In spite of the horrid events depicted in the film, I went away from the experience feeling quite happy and uplifted.  This is a remarkable movie, go see it.

Snow White and the Huntsman We all know the story of Snow White and the Seven Dwarves.  Believe me, this is not your fathers Snow White and the sweet, goofy dwarves are nowhere in sight.  This is a fast paced action flick based closely on the traditional tale, but with a lot of extra plot stuffed in.  And it works, thanks to goodness; it already seems like forever since the Avengers started off the summer season.  Some of the other recent big budget films just didnt work well enough to justify their gy-normous production costs. Two young people that the movie audiences already appreciate star as Snow White and the Huntsman-Kristen Stewart from the Twilight series who comes to this film with hordes of fans and Chris Helmsworth recently as the Norse god Thor, a young man who has a good career ahead of him as the new hunk of Hollywood.  Helmsworth plays a troubled, even suicidal, widower who is tasked with retrieving Snow White from the deep dark woods.  He grows his character believably, he fights athletically and has the right touch of humor fed to him by the excellent writing team.  Stewart however seems to have the ability to show confused concern but little else.  Often the ingnue is not given the heavy lifting acting wise to do in a film, which works to her advantage.  She does photograph well and director Rupert Sanders does a credible job of filming around her. The big acting credits go to the enormously talented and lovely Charlize Theron as the deeply, darkly evil queen.  She scared the daylights out of me.  This is a combination of her fine talent but she was also backed up by fabulous special effects.  The combination allows us to see a being-she is hardly human when we meet her after living 20 normal lives-both irresistibly beautiful and horribly, sickeningly evil.  And there are the dwarves.  Bob Hoskins and Ray Winstone lead a band of full sized English actors as the dwarves.  Movie magic makes them just as convincing as real little people and the quality of the acting is much improved. Director Rupert Sanders is known for his videos and commercials.  This is his first time as a full length movie director.  That may explain why each frame is so packed with information.  He is used to grabbing the attention of the viewer and not letting it go.  This is not just a function of speed but also of putting so much into each scene that the viewer is fully engaged in just assimilating everything on offer.  He was expertly aided by Production Designer Dominic Watkins (The Bourne Supremacy) who builds a fully realized world for his actors to inhabit.  Big snaps also go out to three times Oscar winner Colleen Atwood (Alice in Wonderland) for Costume Design. This four saw blade winner runs seven minutes over two hours.  The PG-13 (violence, blackest of black magic) film was made with what seems to be a modest budget of $170 million.  The world-wide gross is already $96 million after only three days.  When the producers make movie goers happy, the movie goers make the producers financially happy.  Every time it happens I am reminded just how much I love the movies.

The Social Network (2010)  2010 was a kind of desert that we have to cross to find the occasional oasis of great or even above average films.  The Social Network comes along and shows us what not just a very well made film looks like but what a film of historical importance looks like.  The Social Network gives us a peek into the fast moving world of high technology and high finance.  The mostly true film tells the story of college student Mark Zuckerberg over a period of about one year when he invents and develops a new idea for application to the worldwide computer network.  Zuckerberg went from unknown college kid to mulit-millionaire in that time.  He is now 26 years old (in 2010) and worth about seven billion dollars.  He is also stupefying intelligent.  The movie shows what can happen when outright genius meets with the proper opportunity.  It is marvelous. There is so much that is good about this movie that it is hard to pick out the best people to laud.  First place should go to writer Aaron Sorkin for the script.  The development of the character of Zuckerberg (played by Jesse Eisenberg-more about him later) is very carefully controlled and deliciously spooned out.  We get a feel for the young genius in the first scene where he is in conversation with his then girlfriend.  It is as good a dialog as anything I have ever seen.  Great screen writing. And the great writing is spoken, with bewildering rapidity, by actor Jesse Eisenberg (most notably from Zombieland, The Social Network was his fourth screen appearance in 2010.)  Eisenberg plays the young genius as a fast thinking, socially inept striver who knows absolutely that he has his finger on the main chance. Justin Timberlake, of whom I have no clear opinion or even knowledge, delivers a smashingly good performance as the dude who invented Napster.  He falls in with Zuckerberg and shows the young up and comer the ins and outs of the venture capital world in California.  His personal flaws quickly force him from active participation in the new company, but not until he slices off a little, very profitable chunk for himself. There is a reason why things like Face Book are invented here rather than say, France.  In America we reward people who have successful ideas, genius ideas, and can build them into something that people will want to use.  This film shows just how quickly things can happen when the time is right.  It is very instructional.  Do French geniuses go into philosophy or do they move here to make their fortune? This mostly true drama has already brought in a satisfying $85 million on a $50 million budget.  It is rated PG-13 (some pretty raw simulated bathroom sex, some drug use) but I rate it as deserving a very high 4.5 saw blades.  This is a very good movie, a timely movie and an instructional movie.  You should enjoy it as much as I did.

Source Code Finally we have a movie where everything comes together to make an outstanding flick.  In Source Code the move guys deliver a complex, taut, compelling script combined with the best acting from Jake Gyllenhaal that we have seen, perhaps ever, and deft, unobtrusive directing from Ducan Jones in his first big league at bat.  Even the musical score by veteran song master Chris Brown adds to the overall success of the film.  Vera Farmiga plays the love interest so well, in such a warm lovely way that we have no trouble at all falling, along with Gyllenhall, in love with her-in eight minutes. Gyllenhaal comes to his senses on a train outside of Chicago, seated across from an attractive woman who he does not recognize.  His last memory is of piloting a helicopter in combat in Afghanistan.  He stumbles around in confusion for eight minutes, the train blows up and then finds himself in a sort of environmental capsule talking to a computer screen.  The screen person explains that he is on a mission to thwart a bomb plot.  He is sent repeatedly back into the situation on the train in eight minute slices of time, each time putting a few clues together to help him find the despicable bomber.
