(Although I find the All in One is better for that since it is has more "kick")Hope you have found this useful.

This is a assembled clone of Adafruit's ProtoShield (v5). This is ideal for Arduino UNO boards. This is not the first choice for Mega2560 boards (if you need lots of I/O or a larger prototyping area) as it doesn't connect to all the Mega's pins.See learn .adafruit .com / adafruit-proto-shield-arduinoSchematic at:learn .adafruit .com / system / assets / assets / 000 / 009 / 764 / original/ v5schematic.png(Remove the spaces above)THE GOOD:+ This shield is fully assembled, unlike the Adafruit one, which was offered as a "solder it yourself" kit.+ There are also 2 LEDs and a button for your use. Neither is connected to any pins, so you have the flexibility to connect these as you see fit. (Both the LEDs & button are connected to GND).+ There is a Reset button on top so you can still manually reset the Arduino if you need to (normally with older Arduinos, shields may block easy access to the reset button). If you don't need another reset button you could carefully cut the reset trace and jumper the reset button to an input pin (enabling the chip pullup resistor for that pin), giving you TWO input pushbuttons instead of one.+ This PCB has wider power traces than another clone that I bought.+ Comes with mini breadboaad and male-to-male jumpers. Nice for quickly testing your ideas, plug one end of the jumper into the Arduino and the other into the breadboard!THE BAD:- No documentation of any kind included.- This design predates the R3 pinout and does not have the extended R3 pins on Uno/Mega boards. This does not mean that this shield cannot be used with these boards, just that you wouldn't have the separate SCL/SDA, IOREF pins if you absolutely need them.- This shield is NOT "stackable" and does NOT have "pass through" headers. If you're using other shields then it must be the top one but this can cause problems if you had a LCD/keypad shield as this proto shield would block it.- To cut costs no bypass capacitors C1/C2 have been installed. You could solder your own if you need to.OVERALL it is an inexpensive proto board, and the extras (jumper wires & mini breadboard) make it very appealing. The quality is better than a previous clone that I purchased and actually has working buttons and correct LED current limiting resistors installed.As a bonus, here are other useful Arduino-related items that I have reviewed and you might be interested in:Cheap UNO clone: SainSmart UNO R3 ATmega328P Development Board + USB Cable Compatible With Arduino UNO R3 Mega 2560 Nano RobotCheap Mega2560 clone: SainSmart Mega2560 R3 ATmega2560-16AU + ATMEGA16U2 + USB Cable for Robot Arduino UNO MEGA2560 R3 Duemilanove 2013Serial 2x16 LCD using I2C (only 2 I/O pins): ZITRADES New IIC/I2C/TWI 1602 Serial LCD Module Display For Arduino BY ZITRADESCheap Ethernet Shield: RioRand (TM) Upgraded Ethernet Shield W5100 for Arduino UNO R3 & MEGA 2560 DuemilanoveI hope you have found this helpful!

This adapter works fine, but there are some things you should know:THE GOOD:+ Power adapter case has a mounting hole (useful if you need to secure it)+ AC cord allows the adapter to be plugged into an AC outlet or power strip without blocking other outletsTHE BAD:- Both the cord lengths are too short: the output cable is 34" long and the AC cord is only 16" long!- There is no power LED to indicate unit is "on"- Adapter is not UL listedOVERALL, it's OK but I prefer Kara Mobile AC/DC 9V 2A High Quality Power Adapter World Wide Voltage 100-240V Output of 9VDC 2A Light Weight Regulated UL Listed Extra Long 8' Cord instead because of the longer cord.I hope you have found this helpful!

This is a nice 9V DC 2 amp power adapter with a long 8 foot cord (measured). Note that the output connector is CENTER PIN POSITIVE (which are how most devices are wired). In other words the "inside" of the connector is connected to +9V, and the "outside" is connected to DC Ground. If you need CENTER PIN NEGATIVE you need a different adapter.THE GOOD:+ Long cord, many power adapters have a short cord but this one doesn't.+ Works fine with Arduino.+ "Universal" switching power supply, works on 100-240V. (You still may need a plug adapter to plug it in).THE BAD:- What would have made this better is a power LED so you could visually see that it is plugged in and operating.OVERALL it is a good replacement adapter, no problems so far.I hope you have found this useful!

This is a assembled clone of Adafruit's ProtoShield (v5) but mine has been assembled by someone who didn't know what they were doing.General:learn .adafruit .com / adafruit-proto-shield-arduinoshieldlist .org / adafruit / protoshieldSchematic:learn .adafruit .com / system / assets / assets / 000 / 009 / 764 / original/ v5schematic.png(Remove the spaces above)THE GOOD:+ This shield is fully assembled, unlike the Adafruit one, which was offered as a "solder it yourself" kit.+ There is a Reset button on top so you can still manually reset the Arduino if you need to (normally with older Arduinos, shields may block easy access to the reset button).+ There are also 2 LEDs and a button for your use. Neither is connected to any pins, so you have the flexibility to connect these as you see fit. (Both the LEDs & button are connected to GND).THE BAD:- No documentation included. (After searching I found the above files)- This design predates the R3 pinout and does not have the extended R3 pins on Uno/Mega boards. This does not mean that this shield cannot be used with these boards, just that you wouldn't have the separate SCL/SDA, IOREF pins if you absolutely need them.- This shield is not "stackable" and does not have "pass through" headers. If you're using other shields then it must be the top one but this can cause problems if you had a LCD/keypad shield as the proto shield would block it.- To cut costs no bypass capacitors C1/C2 have been installed. You could solder your own if you need to.- On my board, INCORRECT resistors were installed for the LED current limiting resistors R1 & R2. These were 67 ohms, you would want a higher value, like 470 - 1K ohms. Given that these were the ONLY resistors on the board how could they get this wrong?!- As if that wasn't bad enough, the 2 momentary switches were BOTH NOT WORKING! Pressing the switch would NOT complete the circuit as a "working" switch would. I had to remove both switches and replace them with working ones without further problems. You can test the RESET switch by pressing it, if the Arduino doesn't reset then the button doesn't work. The "unconnected" switch S1 can be tested with a multimeter. I suspect the board was washed with something that it should not have been after assembly and the unsealed switches were damaged!- The board has a sticky feel to it, like there is some kind of residue of it. Probably related to the above switch problems.- Packaging doesn't really protect the headers, so it is possible you might have slightly bent pins.OVERALL, it's an inexpensive prototyping shield for Arduino. But the production mistakes on this extremely simple board makes me wonder if there is any sort of quality control on these things! If you are not comfortable desoldering and soldering to fix obvious production problems you might want to skip this board (the problem is that many sell basically this same board so be warned you may have these problems if bought from another vendor). The whole point of buying this was to save me time, not make me waste time tracking down problems! Maybe the Do-It-Yourself Adafruit kit isn't so bad, I would have wasted less time assembling it instead of troubleshooting this board.UPDATE: I have found a better quality prototype PCB: Zitrades Prototyping Prototype Shield + Mini Breadboard + Free Jumper Cable for Arduino UNO Maga Nano DUE Robot. This one is very similar but has wider power traces and comes with a mini breadboard and male-to-male jumper wires.As a bonus, here are other useful Arduino-related items that I have reviewed or used and you might be interested in:Cheap UNO clone: SainSmart UNO R3 ATmega328P Development Board + USB Cable Compatible With Arduino UNO R3 Mega 2560 Nano RobotCheap Mega2560 clone: SainSmart Mega2560 R3 ATmega2560-16AU + ATMEGA16U2 + USB Cable for Robot Arduino UNO MEGA2560 R3 Duemilanove 2013Serial 2x16 LCD using I2C (only 2 I/O pins): ZITRADES New IIC/I2C/TWI 1602 Serial LCD Module Display For Arduino BY ZITRADESCheap Ethernet Shield: RioRand (TM) Upgraded Ethernet Shield W5100 for Arduino UNO R3 & MEGA 2560 DuemilanoveI hope you have found this helpful!

The RioRand W5100 is an inexpensive shield that allows Ethernet communications as well as microSD storage. The "upgraded" in the title is a bit untrue since this is based on an older Arduino Ethernet shield design and not the current "Rev6" R3-pinout design. Like most of these boards you'll have to make up your own MAC address since the board doesn't come with one, or instructions of any kind.THE GOOD:+ Inexpensive, cheaper than "official" Arduino Ethernet shield.+ Shield is compatible with Uno, Mega2560, and Leonardo.THE BAD:- As mentioned, this shield is NOT based on the most recent revision of the Arduino Ethernet shield. It does not support the "full" Uno R3 pinout (missing SCL/SDA and IOREF & the currently unused pin next to it). This does NOT mean that it does not work with Uno (it does) but if you want to "stack" a bunch of R3 pinout shields this one should be the topmost shield since it does not "pass through" the previously mentioned pins. (Actually you probably want this to be the top board in the stack for cooling requirements).- More seriously, this design does NOT include a reset IC for the W5100 chip. This was added in later versions of the official Arduino shield to eliminate problems (especially on power-up) with the W5100 not resetting and functioning properly. Since this shield doesn't have this you may need to press the RESET button to manually reset both the Arduino & the Ethernet shield. (I feel this was done to keep costs down).- Even though it is "Mega compatible" I notice that the base Mega2560 Arduino's A6 pin is somewhat blocked by the shield when in place. This may be true for the "Arduino" manufactured shield as well.- This older design does not have the vacant holes for the option POE (Power Over Ethernet) module. (Most people wouldn't use this so it wouldn't be a big deal).- Packaging is inadequate to prevent bent pins. I had to straighten a few of them.OVERALL, the price is good but at this point in time it is disappointing to see that old designs are still being sold years after the newer R3 pinout & reset issue have been addressed. There are reset modifications you can do to the board to help with the W5100 problem but you really shouldn't have to on a new board.I hope you have found this helpful!

The 1602 is the most inexpensive 2x16 LCD display (controlled by I2C, uses the PCF8574 chip) that I have found. The benefit of using an I2C display is that only 2 I/O signals are needed from/to your microcontroller, saving you precious I/O pins. Also, with I2C you can add additional displays and other I2C devices without using additional I/O pins.This is not an "Arduino-only" device and is not a "plug-in" shield. This is both good and bad. The good point is that you can use this with other microcontrollers, not just limited to Arduino. Also, because it only needs 4 wires you could mount this as part of a "front panel" interface separate from the Arduino. If using with Arduino you will need to do some easy connections to hook it up. Here's how I got mine working with Arduino.HARDWARE INTERFACING:This is a 5V powered device, so LCD-VCC goes to 5V, LCD-GND to GND. The 2 remaining LCD connections SCL & SDA depend on which Arduino model you are using.On the Uno  LCD-SCL goes to A5, LCD-SDA goes to A4 (For Uno R3 boards you could also connect LCD-SCL/SDA to the separate SCL/SDA pins on ends of the "digital" connector but be aware that this is the same as connecting to A4 & A5 as there are no "separate dedicated" SCL/SDA pins for Uno). NOTE: Remember that's A4/A5 not D4/D5.For Leonardo you use 3 (SCL) & 2 (SDA).For the Mega2560 you will need to use 21 (SCL) & 20 (SDA).Also, it is important to know that I2C pins should each have pull-up resistors to 5V (2.2K to 4.7K should work). I believe the Arduino Wire library enables the weak internal chip pullups but best practice means that you should have pull-ups on both SCL & SDA. I'll say it again: the LCD may not work reliably if you don't have a pull-up resistor on both SCL/SDA!The potentiometer on the back is to adjust the LCD's contrast. Turn it up all the way and you should see white blocks (this is a quick way to test the display to make sure there are no "dead pixels").CONFUSING THING #1If you look at the back of the I2C interface board you will see what appears to be a jumper with the labels "VCC" and "GND" next to it. You might be wondering if you will fry something because of this. You wouldn't, because the jumper is for backlight control, and the labels actually refer to the unpopulated pins for another set of I2C pins. The jumper can be removed to disable the backlight, but that will make the LCD almost impossible to read, so leave it in!SOFTWARE INTERFACING:My display came with no jumpers soldered on the Address pads, so the LCD's I2C address is 0x27.If using with Arduino there is a library that will make your life easy. Download it from bitbucket dot org /fmalpartida /new-liquidcrystal /wiki/Home(Remove the spaces and convert dot org above)You can also try searching for "LiquidCrystal_V1.2.1.zip"First (re)move your original LiquidCrystal folder in your Arduino libraries folder.You want to extract the LiquidCrystal folder in the zip to the libraries folder.In your sketch, you have the following code at the top:#define LCD1602_I2C_ADDRESS 0x27#include <Wire.h> //needed to prevent compile errors#include <LiquidCrystal_I2C.h>// next line sets up  address, en, rw, rs, d4, d5, d6, d7, backlight, blpolarityLiquidCrystal_I2C lcd(LCD1602_I2C_ADDRESS, 2,1,0,4,5,6,7,3,POSITIVE);in your setup() function:lcd.begin (16,2);  // setup for 2x16 displayin your loop() function:lcd.clear();  delay(500);  lcd.backlight();  delay(500);  lcd.print("Testing LCD");  delay(1000);  lcd.noBacklight();Note that you can control the backlight via software! (noBacklight & backlight).THE GOOD:+ Works, once you wire everything correctly and use the correct library and I2C device address. (The display outputs white text on a blue background).+ There is a power LED on the I2C interface board so you can tell if it is powered.+ Backlight can be controlled via software (you will need the backlight jumper plugged in). Note that you DON'T need a separate I/O pin to control the backlight since it is connected to the I2C interface chip and driven from it. By the way the backlight uses approx 19mA on my LCD (measured). NOTE: The backlight jumper allows very easy measurement of the backlight LED current, simply remove the jumper and measure current through both pins with the backlight turned on.+ A0/A1/A2 address jumpers are vacant so by soldering some jumpers you could have multiple displays (with different addresses) on the same I2C bus if needed.+ Price is very attractive, at less than 10 bucks for a display with backlight and an I2C interface attached. You could even buy this just for the display alone (desoldering the I2C interface board) and use it as a parallel LCD.THE BAD:- No documentation of any kind included!- Display update speed is kind of slow (I don't mean because of the I2C communication, but the display itself. Text displayed on previous blank areas sort of "fades in" and becomes white). If you are familiar with older "black on green" LCD displays that updated instantly this is a bit of a drawback. But it's one that is acceptable for the price.- There are no 0.1uF bypass or electrolytic filter caps on the I2C interface board. Since the LCD module is separate from the Arduino by (potentially long) wires I feel it should have a cap or two.I have spent a couple hours getting the LCD to work (because of no instructions) and decided to leave a detailed review so others can get started quickly. If you don't mind doing a little work with the wiring and not having a "plug-in shield" I would recommend this display over more expensive "plug-in" LCD shields.I hope you have found this helpful!

The ZyXELP660R-F1 is probably the simplest DSL modem that you can buy in terms of setup/configuration. Unlike other modems you do not have to navigate and manually setup VPI/VCI, Encapsulation mode, etc. The modem will autodetect these and all you will need is your PPPoE username and password (Ask your DSL provider if you don't have this info).Firstly, you connect the modem's phone line, Ethernet, & power adapter, switch on and wait a minute for the modem to finish booting. (If you are like most users you'd plug the Ethernet cable into the modem then the other end goes to the WAN port on your WiFi router).All you need to do is attempt to access the internet (any web site) and the modem should prompt you for the modem's login password, your PPPoE username and corresponding password. At that point the modem should login via PPPoE and the Internet should be accessible. That's pretty much it. (Note that your setup could be different depending on your ISP).I am getting slightly better speeds compared to my old modem (nothing major but that's a good sign).THE GOOD:+ Small device, with side & top vents for cooling. I have found most modern devices simply don't have very good cooling. With the side vents you could stand it on the side or at an angle for better cooling (which I recommend doing). Do NOT cover the vents or impede airflow!+ Status LEDs are easy to read at a glance. There are only 4 LEDs (Power, Ethernet, DSL, Internet).+ Powered by a standard 12VDC 1 amp power supply so easy to replace if it fails. Some old DSL modems use weird power supply adapters.+ Status screen shows modem uptime, DSL & LAN status, WAN IP address, etc.+ Supports Dynamic DNS via DynDNS+ Has on/off switch so it is easier to turn on/off than yanking the plug out.THE BAD:- First, the login screen can trip you up. When you access the modem (default 192.168.1.1) you will see a "Login" screen with a password prompt, but it appears that the password prompt is already filled on (i.e. has password dots indicating characters). You can click "Login" without entering a password and you will see the modem's "Status" screen BUT NO OTHER OPTIONS WILL APPEAR. To get the "full" menu options you will need to enter the password at the Login screen, which will bring you to the same "Status" screen but with additional options. Remember, if you need to configure the modem you need to enter the password at the Login screen!- To check DSL line parameters like Signal-to-noise margin, Attenuation etc you need to check under Maintenance/Diagnostic/DSL Line/DSL Line Status. Strangely the upstream/downstream values are not ordered logically (downstream/upstream should be grouped together but they are not). I feel these should have been shown on the status page rather than having to dig deep to find them.- Cooling is still not optimal. The placement of the "main" chip is halfway under the front of the modem's top cover (which has no ventilation!). Also, I feel the chip should have a passive heatsink on it for better heat dissipation and reliability.- Modem has "Windows Networking (NetBIOS over TCP/IP) allow between LAN & WAN" CHECKED by default(!). Recommend unchecking this for security reasons.OVERALL, it is a easy-to-setup DSL modem. It's too early to remark on long-term reliability but I will update this as time goes by.I hope you have found this helpful!

The SuperRetro pack contains 2 SNES wireless controllers (using RF not infrared so there are no issues like having to keep controllers pointed in the right direction) that fit the SNES connector ports. The receiver units (one for each port) are powered by the system so no batteries are required for those. However you will need 2 "AAA" batteries for EACH controller (not included). The antenna is internal so there are no clumsy antennas or wires hanging outside of each controller.** Syncing each controller with a receiver **1. Power on game system with receiver(s) plugged in.2. Turn on controller power switch.3. HOLD down Start & Select until LED on controller flashes. Release buttons on controller.4. On receiver HOLD down CONNECT button until LED flashes (should be done within 10 seconds of Step 3). Release button.5. When both LEDs stop flashing and stay on the controller should be working. Repeat procedure for other controller if necessary.Note: You DO NOT have to do this procedure every time you use the controllers.THE GOOD:+ Product works (I tested it on a Hyperkin RetroN 3 Video Gaming System, Charcoal which plays NES, SNES & Genesis games and has controller ports for each system).THE BAD:- Instructions don't mention that EACH controller has a tiny power switch on the inside curve (below the D-pad). I was puzzled why the red LED didn't come on after installing batteries until I found the switch. After you are finished playing you should switch off both controllers for maximum battery life.- The shape/design of the controller seems to be best for smaller hands (possibly kids). I wish they were a little larger. This is not an exact copy of the original SNES controllers (as you can tell by the different shape). However note that I do not have a set of original SNES controllers to compare with.- The D-pad could be better. I find the feel a little off (especially for diagonals but perhaps it takes some getting used to).OVERALL, it works and if you are tired of tripping over cords this might be what you need. It's difficult to give an opinion on controller "feel" since this is subjective and everyone has different tastes.Nevertheless I hope you have found this review useful!

If you simply want an easy way to play the games you remember (provided you have the cartridges) this console is a good choice but it's not without flaws. The system itself comes with 2 infrared wireless controllers, AC power adapter, composite video/audio cable and an S-VIDEO cable. Note that S-VIDEO does not carry audio so you will still need to use the audio connectors of the composite cable. Controllers each require 2 "AAA" batteries (not included).Strangely no instruction manual was included in the package. The 2 controllers look identical but above the "select" button is either a single or double dot which indicates which player that controller is used for. There is no user-selectable method to change a controller from 1P to 2P (or vice versa).THE GOOD:+ Plays NES, SNES & Genesis/MegaDrive cartridges all on one system.+ Compact design, certainly takes up less space than having 3 separate systems.+ A big plus is that the system has controller ports for the 3 systems so it can accept wired controllers which you can use instead of the included wireless controllers.+ There is a region switch (labelled "O/J", presumably for Overseas/Japan) so you can play carts for other regions.+ For SNES it appears that Super FX games are compatible. I have tried Stunt Race FX and it works.THE BAD:- The included wireless controllers are a problem, especially with 2 players. These controllers use infrared light (like your TV remote) as opposed to RF so they must be line-of-sight with the system unit. But more important the use of IR means that you will probably experience control issues with 2 players simultaneously (imagine trying to change your TV channel or volume using 2 remotes at the same time). Specifically controllers may not register input or have some lag in the response - for videogames this can cause frustration and render most games unplayable. I STRONGLY recommend than you get wired controllers to use instead of the wireless ones.- Depending on the system, the wireless controller button mapping may not match the labelled buttons. As an example the "B" button is really "A" for NES games (this is an attempt to match the physical button placement of the original controller to the wireless one). It can be a little confusing though, especially for SNES games where the wireless controller does not have the 2 "shoulder" buttons where the original SNES controller does. You will probably want to remap controls in each game but this will have to be done after power-up for each game.- I find the picture a little "noisy" regardless whether the composite video or S-VIDEO outputs were used. Also I think there is a slight difference in brightness between the two - S-VIDEO seems to output a higher brightness display. For most games you will not notice this noise in the picture.- As other reviewers have noted there may be minor differences in sound etc compared to the original systems.OVERALL, it's one of the few "new systems" to play games for the 3 old systems. (Although I have not tested it with NES games because I don't have any).If anyone from Hyperkin reads this I think this could have been a mostly perfect 3-in-1 system with some changes:* Noisy picture fixed* Use of RF controllers instead of IR ones* Have some sort of "boot menu" that you can permanently remap buttons for each system, maybe on a "per game" basis depending on the inserted cart.* What would REALLY be awesome is if it had SD card support for "homebrew" games that you could download (in addition to the cartridge slots)I hope you have found this review useful, and don't forget to clean your cartridge contacts before using them for best results!

The TL-SG1005D is a 5-port gigabit switch that is inexpensive and "just plain works". However the front panel design could have been better. Also note the case is plastic not metal, which is cheaper.THE GOOD:+ Support Jumbo frames up to 9K (according to the manual)+ Front panel LED flash rate is slow enough to easily see from across the room.+ Like most modern switches this one is "green" - uses less power for shorter Ethernet cables and powers down unused ports to save energy.+ Single-chip switch controller is heatsinked for better heat dissipation.THE BAD:- Wall mount screws are not included.- The front panel LEDs are single color (green) and do not change color to indicate "gigabit device connected" like some other switches. Thus you cannot tell if a device is gigabit or not from looking at the front panel.- There is only a single LED per port and not separate Link/Activity LEDs like on some other switches. This may have been done to keep costs down.- The Power LED is the same color as the Port LEDs. I would have preferred the Power LED be a different color (red) than the green LEDs used for the ports.OVERALL it's a good choice for a gigabit switch. However I would have really liked to see a way of determining connected device speed from looking at the front panel. Be sure to check out the 8-port version of this same switch (TP-Link TL-SG1008D 8-Port Unmanaged Gigabit Desktop Switch) as it may be only a couple of dollars more.I hope this has been helpful!

The TP-Link PA211 Kit comprises of 2 powerline adapters at an attractive price.THE GOOD:+ Cheaper than most other 200Mbps powerline adapters.+ The physical size of this powerline adapter is smaller than most of the others that I've used.+ The "pair" button placement is under the adapter (next to where the network cable plugs into) as opposed to on the size of the adapter (as found on most other devices). This is better because you are less likely to accidentally press it when plugging/unplugging.+ Utility software is better than the ZyXEL PLA407 HomePlug AV 200 Mbps Powerline Wall-Plug Adapter (Starter Kit - 2 Units) that I have previously reviewed.+ The power-off timeout (when no Ethernet device is connected to the adapter) is longer than on the Zyxel PLA-407 and is stated as 10 minutes in the manual. This is good as the Zxyel PLA-407 would go to sleep in 1 minute unless something was plugged into the Ethernet port. This made configuration difficult using the utility software. Happy to say that the TP-Link PA211 has a sensible "on" time before going to sleep.THE BAD:- Device password (required for setting Privacy/Network name for remote devices that are not directly connected via Ethernet) must be in ALL CAPS and dashes entered. I don't know why the utility software doesn't auto-capitalize password input since only caps are valid. If you enter in lower case you will get an "invalid password" error. Also the utility does not indicate that passwords should be entered in all caps.- Unlike most powerline adapters the powerline LED does NOT change color to indicate connection quality. It is always green (Most other powerline adapters that I've used from Netgear, Zyxel etc change the LED color red/amber/green to indicate line quality). You can still check the line rate & quality settings via the TP-Link powerline utility software but it is FAR easier to just plug the adapter in different outlets and watch the LED to get an idea of whether this outlet is "better/worse" than another. This in my opinion is a significant disadvantage to the TP-PA211.- There is some "bleed-through" of the Panel LEDs, so sometimes it appears that an LED is ON when it is really OFF (due to light from the adjacent LED). This affects the powerline LED the most as it is in the middle of the 3 LEDs.OVERALL, I would recommend this powerline adapter despite the few flaws. It is cheap, small, has functional utility software and works. If you can put up with the front LED shortcomings mentioned above it is a good choice for a powerline adapter. I have noticed that most TP-Link products are priced aggressively compared to traditional brands and seem to be just as good.I hope you have found this review useful!

Next Life (called Reprobates in Europe) is an adventure game with good graphics but has some flaws that affect the experience. The concept is great - the player apparently dies in the starting cutscene but wakes up on an island with 9 other characters who have seemingly also "died". Everyone always falls asleep when the bell tower rings 3 times and everybody suffers terrible nightmares while sleeping (For you these nightmares are mini-adventures that you need to solve to return to the "island"). Probably the scariest part is that some people just disappear after falling asleep - they are just "gone" the next morning. It's your job to figure out what's going on here and escape the island if possible.This is a spoiler-free review so I will not ruin any surprises for you.THE GOOD:+ 3D Graphics/2D backgrounds are good for an adventure game. The 3D models of characters are great (especially the women, who have been modeled with considerable attention-to-detail).+ The plot can hold your attention even during the weaker parts of the game. The nightmares are "scary" scenarios that are very different from the relatively leisurely "island" daytime part of the game. I would say the "nightmare" parts of the game is where it really shines.+ Game is stable, never crashed for me while playing.+ 3D graphics requirements are pretty low - I played the game with "shadows on" with a Radeon 4350 (low end graphics card) and it was fine.THE BAD:- There are 3 or 4 "timed" minigames that must be solved to proceed at different points in the game. These either rely on "do something before time runs out" or "quick reaction before time runs out". I dislike these and I absolutely hated the "spinning circle light" puzzle - I had to use a save game from the internet to pass this since I couldn't solve it in time (and I tried repeatedly).- English translation is not very good. The game has been developed by a foreign developer and some "Engrish" can be expected but when the game tells you "I knocked it in the lubber" or describing a tree as "an old bark" or your player asking another character "are you ventilating your feet?" or describing a crack in a rock as "a rent in the rock" it really distracts from the experience. Similarly the captions don't exactly match the spoken audio (when conversing with another character).- As with most adventure games you have to "pixel hunt". This game has tiny "pixel areas" so make sure you carefully move your mouse over everything!- Game is "trigger" based, so even if you figure out what you need to do next you will still have to perform the right "trigger" to get things rolling. Triggers may be talking to the right person or doing a specific task.- Your player character moves slowly especially when turning or climbing. Towards the end of the game there is a stage with lots of painful clicking as you navigate the up/down terrain - why your player couldn't just walk normally over it I have no idea, especially when it serves not much purpose except to slow the player down. Here's a tip: Pressing the "E" key shows offscreen exits for a brief time - use this often to make sure you aren't missing a place to go (this is important in the "lava" terrain stage). Also doubleclicking an offscreen exit makes your player run (faster than walking).- The load save screen defaults (on first startup every time you start the game) to the 1st save, not the last save and you have to click repeatedly to navigate to the last save. I completed the game with around 100 saves & it is a little annoying when you first start the game and want to load the most recent save.- The ending stage part of the game seems a little rushed/short and not all the engrossing compared to the rest.- The ending cutscene should have been better & shown what happened to the "other" characters.OVERALL, if you are an adventure game player (which usually means that you have considerable patience) you probably will enjoy this game (apart from the timed sequences and occasional illogical solution to a puzzle).I hope you have found this review helpful!

I have used other powerline adapters (primarily Netgear). The only advantage the PLA-407 has is the noise-filtering front outlet but this is outweighed by the awful software & difficult encryption setup.THE GOOD:+ Noise filtering front outlet allows you to plug in extension cords or other devices without affecting the PLA network speed due to noisy devices. Note that the PLA-407 is a 200Mbps powerline device (there are faster 500Mbps devices but these are typically more expensive)+ Adapter supports manually-set priority levels PER ADAPTER. You can designate an adapter to have higher priority than another one set to "Normal" for example. Note this is not "true" Quality of Service based on analysis of transmitted data etc but a simple priority scheme to allow certain adapters to have better/worse priority than others.THE BAD:The Zyxel PLA config utility v4.1.2 software is truly awful:- The configuration screen is not intuitive or friendly. The config utility seems like a prototype and not a production/end-user tool.- The utility does not show the existing network name (NMK) so you cannot tell if all adapters are setup correctly with the same name. (What Zyxel calls the network name other manufacturers refer to as the powerline password). This may be for security reasons, so you better keep track of your network name otherwise if you want to add a device later and don't remember the name you'll have to reconfig the name on all PLA devices.- Related to the above point, since you CANNOT tell what the network name is you can't tell whether the PLA is using the default (i.e. unsecure) name or a custom name. This means you will have to keep notes, especially if setting up multiple adapters.- The firmware update function is handled by a separate utility which must be downloaded. The firmware utility says "Your device is doing with new firmware" when updating (no, that's not my typo).- The default "green power-down" feature can confuse you when using the PC config utility if you don't realise that a PLA adapter that does not have an ethernet connection to a powered-up device will go to "sleep" after 60 seconds and will NOT show up or respond in the PC config utility. The default timeout should be longer than 60 seconds to accommodate setup. (As an aside there seems to be no way to extend or disable the low power mode from the PC config utility). I'm all for saving power but this makes simultaneous configuration difficult (i.e. multiple adapters at the same time) as they will all need to be connected to a POWERED-UP device with an ethernet port) to prevent them from going to sleep!- At 1st glance there appears to be no way to figure out what firmware version each PLA is using from the config utility. Hidden in the "about" icon (next to the question mark) it shows the utility version and "firmware version" but I have no idea which adapter has this firmware (i.e. it is showing a firmware version but not indicating which adapter has this version - remember the utility can show multiple adapters)- The firmware utility doesn't show the existing version before upgrading.- The encryption method using the button procedure indicated in the user guide PDF did not work for me - as another reviewer noted the LEDs don't flash as the manual indicates. I believe the manual is incorrect.OVERALL I don't recommend this PLA adapter if you care about configuring/implementing security because of the PC config software - shame on you Zyxel for having the worst software that I've ever seen on a powerline adapter (Zyxel: get the guys who did the excellent interface on the NSA320 NAS to fix your PLA software!)If you don't care about security and plug it in "out of the box" (with no security) then this may work for you. But there are cheaper PLA solutions (especially if you don't need the front noise-filtering outlet) such as the TP-Link Powerline Adapter (TL-PA211 STARTER KIT).I hope you have found this helpful!

I have 2 of these routers (version 1). This router is a "N" dual band 2.4GHz/5GHz with 4 100MBit Fast Ethernet ports (NOT Gigabit Ethernet). It also features a USB2 port which can be used to share storage if you plug in a USB hard drive. There are no positionable or external antennas.Also for some strange reason this router is model N600 as well as WNDR3400. Currently on amazon N600 brings up 2 different routers. Be sure that you're looking at the right one!THE GOOD:+ Very stable & reliable, has not required resetting despite power glitches etc.+ Router supports 300Mbps on both 2.4GHz & 5GHz bands.+ Router has auto-update firmware check on entering web interface.+ Dynamic DNS works perfectly with DynDNS service.+ Bandwidth usage stats are an interesting feature - you can get an idea of exactly how much bandwidth you really use (up/down totals for today/this week/this month/last month).+ You can enable/disable router via schedule.+ You can support "guest" networks on both 2.4GHz/5GHz bands with isolation from your "other" connected devices. This means you can give a guest internet access without worrying about privacy concerns.THE BAD:- Not easily wall mountable. There are no mounting holes underneath as in most routers.- DHCP could be better implemented:1. DHCP reservation requires router reboot to work correctly (after setting up reservation). The problem here is that if you reboot you will lose bandwidth statistics.2. There are no advanced config settings for DHCP like lease time etc as in other routers.- 5 GHz range is not very good compared to 2.4GHz, although this may not be specific to this router (I don't have another dual-band router to test against).OVERALL, I would recommend this router, especially if you are tired of others that need to be periodically reset. However you should ensure there is proper airflow around the router. I use a small box to prop up one end of the horizontally-mounted router to ensure hot air can easily rise thru the top vents. The one thing that might be a deal breaker for some is the lack of Gigabit Ethernet ports. (For the price I think it should have it).If you need Gigabit but don't need Dual band you might want to look at TRENDnet 300 Mbps Wireless N Gigabit Router TEW-639GR (Black) (which is actually cheaper at the time of writing this).I hope you have found this helpful!

Not much to say except this is the correct filter for the Bissell Cleanview Helix model 82H1 bagless vacuum. This pre-motor filter set comprises of both the foam & pleated filters as shown in the product photo.You may not recognize the 32R9 filter # but if the label on the vacuum says "Style 16 Filter" this is the one you want. According to the filter bag this same 32R9 filter can be used for the following models:Cleanview Helix 21K3/22C1/82H1 Series.Also, you might want to buy a spare belt (for the beater brush) as well. See BISSELL Style 7/9/10/12/16 Replacement Belts, 2 pk, 32074I hope this has been useful!

You know what "normal" yellow mustard tastes like. S&B hot mustard ain't that. This is a dry powder you mix with water and allow to sit a minute or two to develop the full flavor.And by flavor I mean an all out assault on your nasal passages (especially if you try too much!). It's kinda like English mustard but even more intense. (I am sure this mustard will play a lead role in "The Expendables 3").Anyway this mustard smells/tastes similar to the little packets of hot mustard you get at Chinese restaurants but with much more WAHOO!If you haven't been scared off yet I recommend trying it. If you do find it is too hot you need to either go back to the temple and retrain OR you could try diluting it with ketchup, soy sauce, or even your own tears.The little tin should last a long time since you don't need a whole lot (I would say following the instructions on the tin will make too much).I hope you find this review useful!

The Antec NP90 is a universal adapter/charger that comes with 7 different replaceable tips to fit a variety of different laptops. (See my photos for closeup of the tips)THE GOOD:+ Adapter is a 90 Watt output adapter, can power most 65 watt laptops with power to spare. 90W is the adapter's maximum rated power output, it's okay if your laptop/existing adapter has a power rating less than 90W as the laptop will use whatever power it needs from the adapter (in other words it's OK to power a less-than-90W laptop from a 90W adapter). In fact, due to the slightly larger size of the power adapter "brick" it will likely run cooler than your existing adapter.+ Power cords are long. AC adapter cord (that plugs into the wall) is 5 feet, the laptop power cord is 6 feet.+ The tips are keyed to fit only one way for proper operation so you can't fry your laptop by plugging in the tips the wrong way onto the cord and reversing polarity. (Believe it or not I have seen a cheap generic adapter that had this dangerous "feature").+ Adapter has power LED so you can tell it's plugged in/working.THE BAD:- Because it is a 90W adapter it is physically bigger than most adapters (and is likely larger than the adapter you use right now).- It is expensive compared to the cheaper "generic" adapters that are designed for a specific model.- Some laptops will not work with this charger. (e.g. newer Dells that communicate with the charger and refuse to charge unless it is a "Dell" charger).OVERALL I would recommend this especially as your "home" or "work" adapter (i.e. the one that doesn't travel with you). The replaceable tips are a good feature for the future, in case you change your laptop you can still use the adapter. I hope you have found this helpful!

This is a replacement for my Toshiba Satellite C655 laptop.THE GOOD:+ Both the AC power cord & laptop power cords are fairly long. (Some other adapters have a especially short AC cord)+ The laptop power connector is not changeable but molded on the cord (i.e. this is not a "generic" adapter with replaceable tips like some other adapters - this means there is nothing that could slacken or come out).+ Laptop power cord end has a velcro tie to help with cord management.+ Inexpensive. You could buy & keep an extra one around without much expense.So far, it's working for me and is recommended. As with any adapter you want to avoid rough handling for maximum life.Hope this has been useful!

The TopLink TK1005G is a small durable 5-port gigabit switch that's a good choice if you DON'T need to wall mount it. There are NO screw holes underneath (see images) unlike most switches.THE GOOD:+ Metal durable case, looks like it can take a few knocks without damage (watch out for falls though, the power connector could possibly be damaged). The metal case has ventilation holes on both the left/right sides for airflow.+ Metal case makes it heavier. Why is this a good thing? Well, with many plastic-cased desktop switches the switch is so light that the connected network cables tend to move/flip the switch. A heavier switch helps reduce that.+ The single chip inside the case has a heatsink on it, which should lead to lower temperatures and better reliability.+ The front panel power LED is a different color (red) from the rest of the LEDs.+ The switch indicates whether a port is 1Gbit by lighting up a separate LED from the Link/Activity LED. Thus you can tell at a glance if a device is connected at gigabit speeds. (Some 1Gbit switches do not have port speed LEDs so you can't tell the speed of devices).THE BAD:- Not wall mountable.- I wish though the LEDs on the front panel were a bit larger.- The Link/Activity LED flash rate is too fast - you need to be close to the switch to observe it (it is difficult to see from a couple feet away).OVERALL it's a good switch despite not being wall mountable.

As the owner of a somewhat mentally unstable caique parrot I had reservations that he would actually eat this. Fortunately he definitely likes it and since it contains vitamins/minerals it's better for him than seed mix (it's a bad idea to feed your bird solely seed mix anyway). Each round "berry" is made up of seeds, corn and nuts, coated to retain its shape (it smells kind of like peanut butter to me!). If your bird doesn't like pellets (mine doesn't) give this a try.The only downside is that (with all bird food) some of it goes to waste - birds aren't into food conservation and drop food frequently! If the berries were a bit larger they would not fall through the cage bars (Mr Bird's cage has fairly wide bars at the bottom and half-eaten berries fall through).UPDATE: There is a larger "berry" size available, see Lafeber's Classic Nutri-Berries for Macaw / Cockatoo 3.5 lb. Tub. It's the same thing but larger berry size (would be unsuitable for very small birds but probably OK if you have a conure-size or larger bird).

Reviewed: Zyxel NSA325. It supports 2 x 3.5" SATA drives, has 2 USB2 ports (back) and a single USB3 (front) & has Gigabit Ethernet. 1.6GHz Marvell processor is faster than older NAS devices (faster than the 800MHz CPU in the D-LINK DNS-320 or the 1.2GHz CPU in the DNS-325) and 512MB memory allows multiple functions at same time.DRIVE INSTALLATION:Drive guide rails must be attached to each drive via screws. Note that the pointy end of the rails must face INWARD (i.e. on the same side as the SATA connector). The quick install sheet doesn't mention this and it's easy to overlook from the diagram. The reason for the specific orientation is that you use a tool (located behind the drive cover) to remove an installed drive from its bay and this tool clips onto the exposed end of the drive rails. Also when installing be sure to insert the drive so that the SATA connector will mate with the drive (it will not if you insert the drive the wrong way and you could cause damage). ZyXEL needs to have better instructions. The front door is a little flimsy though, be careful when removing/installing to avoid breaking the tabs that keep it in place.Note that drives are NOT hot-swappable, do not remove/insert with the power on. Drives up to 3TB are supported with newest firmware (note if you have old firmware you will need to temporarily install a smaller drive, create a volume, then use the firmware check function in the web interface to update firmware before installing 3TB drives).RAID:RAID 0/1 are supported. RAID 0 uses the combined storage space of both drives but has no redundancy. RAID 1 mirrors contents on both drives so if one fails your data is still safe.POWER MANAGEMENT/UPS:+ You can connect a (APC brand) UPS to the NAS via one of the USB ports and it will auto-shutdown when UPS battery is low (you can adjust when the shutdown occurs based on the UPS reported capacity remaining). A nice touch and one that will help prevent data loss. I tried it with a Tripp-Lite UPS and it wasn't recognized so it looks like only an APC will work.+ You can set the UPS to always power on after a power failure, useful if acting as networked storage.+ You can spin down drives if no data transmission occurs in a specified time (adjustable in minutes)+ Supports "wake-on-lan" so device can turn on and service incoming requests even if powered off.+ NAS uses external 12V 5amp power adapter. This is better than an internal power supply as it is easily replaceable if it fails.+ Interestingly the NAS has an internal clock (powered by a CR2032 battery) and can be set to power on/off via time schedule.THE BAD:- There is no "network activity" LED at the front panel (the LED is on the Ethernet jack). I would have liked to see a front panel LED. This is important as use of one of the back USB ports will block the network LED on the jack.- I do not think there is a way to migrate to larger capacity drives without backing up/replacing drives/recreate RAID/restoring the array.- Download Manager feature (more on this below) cannot download files that require authentication from websites (i.e. files that require login). This is a shame as this would been much more useful.- This NAS takes LONG to boot. This may cause a problem if used as network storage as PCs may boot quicker than the NAS!- For some strange reason the CPU temp is reported incorrectly (12 deg Celsius) on the NSA status page after some time in operation. It still seems to work correctly so this may be a minor bug.OTHER:+ Front panel USB connector is USB3 for fast copy from/to external USB3 devices. This is just for copying data from/to an external drive, I don't think connection to a PC is supported.+ NAS has CPU temp sensor.+ The fan is a 3-wire fan (has RPM sensor so the NAS can determine fan speed). The fan label mentions that has a hypro bearing, which supposed to be a long-lasting bearing. The fan is very quiet, practically silent.+ Web-based interface is nice and clean, with attractive icons. The admin setup webpage is logically organized. You can check the CPU temp/CPU load/free memory from the admin page.+ ZPilot feature allows you to drop files/folders to an "always-on-top" icon to copy to the NAS. Optionally you can have the NAS sort files into specific folders based on the file type.+ Add-on packages really expand functionality of the NAS. For example installing the SMART package allows you to see the status (temperature, SMART status, model & serial #) of the installed drives.+ Firmware update is totally painless, one click will check for new firmware, another click downloads & installs it. You don't need to download it from a PC then upload it to the NAS. However note that you must have drive(s) installed and a volume created to use the auto-update feature as it needs to download firmware to the volume. If no drive(s) are installed it will not work.+ Has "Download Manager" built-in file download function & bittorrent client. By logging into the NAS and either entering the URL of a file to download OR uploading a .torrent file from your PC you can have the NAS download files unattended without having your PC on and running. A nice feature, especially for downloading large files such as Linux ISO images.OVERALL it's a good media server for the price and I recommend it. But also check out the ZyXEL NSA320 2-bay Network Attached Storage and Media Server as it is similar but about half the price. The NSA320 uses a slightly slower 1.2GHz CPU (but has the same 512MB memory), but doesn't have dropbox features or USB3 port. You probably DON'T want the older NSA2xx series because these use a much slower CPU/less memory and transfer performance is not as good.UPDATE: I now have multiple NSA325s and the only thing I have found problematic is the web interface. There have been times when the NSA325 is still on and working but I cannot login to its IP address (to get the web interface to display). Other times the web interface will be extremely slow to respond or even stop responding entirely. Also, the "firmware upgrade notification" message keeps appearing even though I'm on the latest firmware (which is annoying, even though I click "do not remind me"). Power resetting fixes the web interface problems but I should not have to do this. These problems have persisted even through firmware updates and I am disappointed that such basic bugs have not been dealt with.UPDATE2: One of the 2 drives in one NSA325 dropped dead. I found this odd so investigated a bit and found a flaw. The single cooling fan was failing (very slow RPMs) and the drive overheated until failure. There are 2 things wrong that could have helped prevent this: (1) Even though the system monitors the RPM of the fan there is no warning that I could find except in the log. A fan failure SHOULD send an email and/or beep the buzzer to signify that something is wrong. (2) The enclosure only has intake vents on the bottom, not the top. This means that hot air will be trapped inside the enclosure should the fan fail. As a result of this experience I recommend buying StarTech.com 60x10mm Replacement Ball Bearing Computer Case Fan with TX3 Connector FAN6X1TX3 (Black) and replacing the original fan. The fan is a standard 60mm x 10mm with a 3-pin "CPU heatsink" connector. Also, once a week login to the web interface and check the fan speed for indication of failure (so you can catch failures early). Other NAS units such as the DS413j have dual fans for redundancy.A more expensive and larger capacity NAS alternative is the Synology DiskStation 4-Bay (Diskless) Network Attached Storage DS413j. (See my DS413j review for more).I hope this is helpful!

This tank lever seems to be a good quality trip lever. The handle is attractive and the lever arm is made of brass (will not corrode) and has multiple holes for attaching the flapper chain. I would recommend hand tightening this and then applying a dab of silicone adhesive to ensure that the nut does not slacken with use. (By the way the nut on mine was plastic, not metal as stated by another reviewer)

The Hydroclean HC660 is a replacement toilet fill valve that fits most toilets. I used it on an older American Standard toilet tank installed in the 1980s. It fit fine and cured the problem with the old fill valve, namely the tank was taking FOREVER to fill (over 10 minutes!). Now it takes about 90 seconds to fill, a vast improvement.THE GOOD:+ Hydroclean tubing & nozzles agitate the tank while filling, allowing sediment to drain out with the next flush. This is the main benefit of this valve, which supposedly keeps debris/sediment from accumulating on the flapper (which can cause leaks since the flapper doesn't seal properly).+ The next benefit is that there is a mini-valve which allows adjustment of the water flow to the overflow tube i.e. the amount of water that fills the bowl after flushing (during tank filling). You can restrict the water flow so that less water fills the bowl - the theory is that many bowls are actually overfilled during tank refilling which wastes water.+ The nut that tightens and attaches the fill valve to the tank is designed to "click" as you tighten it so you don't accidentally overtighten and crack the tank. Instructions suggest tightening 1 to 3 clicks (I did 2 clicks). You don't even need a wrench or other tool to tighten this nut.+ You can adjust the height of the fill valve to fit your tank (when installing) and also easily adjust the water fill level by turning a knob.+ There is also a "float lock" so you can stop the tank from refilling without turning off the water supply to the toilet. This is useful for repairs (for example when replacing the flapper) and is more of a convenience rather than an essential feature.THE BAD:- Compared to an "old style" ballcock fill valve (i.e. the ones with the air-filled ball float) the fill valve feels a little plastic and a little flimsy. However this may just be the difference in old vs newer construction. (Hope the plastic is stronger than it looks)- The instructions mention a "cone supply washer" & "water supply nut" which were not included (for me anyway). I did not need these but am just mentioning it.OVERALL, I would recommend this fill valve. It is very similar to the cheaper Fluidmaster 400A Anti-Siphon Toilet Tank Fill Valve (which does not include the Hydroclean or mini-valve features so you might want to buy the Fluidmaster instead if you don't care about those features). I would suggest taking the opportunity to also replace the flapper in the toilet at the same time you change the fill valve since it can cause water-wasting leaks (and generally has to be replaced every couple of years anyway). REMEMBER: Do not use chemical "in-tank" cleaners as they can damage plastic parts!I hope this has been helpful!

I have 2 of the Fenix HP10 (older model LED headlamp) and had high expectations for the HP11. Sorry to say that the HP11 is WORSE in several important ways:- The on/off switch is the one on the LEFT, the mode switch is the one on the RIGHT. This is cumbersome if you are right handed. Also the HP10 had a large on/off switch mounted at the center of the headlamp which was easy to use. I feel the smaller on/off button on the HP11, combined with the bad placement makes operation more difficult than the HP10.- The battery holder is WORSE than the HP10, which had a "clam-shell" holder with protective seal that was FIRMLY secured by TWO thumbscrews. The HP11 has an annoying "slide-out" holder secured by a single screw. This screw must be tightened VERY tight to create a secure seal. On receiving this was so tight I couldn't unscrew this by hand and had to use a pair of pliers! If the screw must be tightened so tight to maintain a waterproof seal it is bad design! Also I find the slide-out holder to be annoying compared to the previous flip-open "clam-shell" holder.- The connecting cable between the battery holder & headlamp "stick out" and bend at approx 90 degree angles when the cable is inserted into the grooves on the clip-on wire guide (that clips onto the elastic headband). The problem with this is that it exposes the cable more than it should and it has a higher chance of snagging or damage due to flexing. The design should have had the cable exiting the headlamp and battery holder at 45 degree angles, which would keep the cable closer to the headband and reduce flexing.- The front half of the HP10 was metal (probably aluminum) which was good for dissipating heat from the LED. The HP11 seems to be entirely plastic construction which would be worse for heat dissipation.OVERALL the HP11 is NOT WORTH IT compared to the older model, especially at the price. I am disappointed in Fenix for producing a headlamp that is WORSE than the previous model.

The LOGISYS PS550E12BK is a ATX form factor supply that is a good choice if you need a 6-pin 12V connector to power a graphics card that requires external power. I will be comparing this supply to the similar LOGISYS PS480E12 480W 120mm Ball Bearing Switching Power Supply (which does NOT have the 6-pin connector).CONNECTORS:20+4 ATX power connector2 x 4-pin motherboard 12V power connectors1 x 6-pin graphics card power4 x molex drive connectors2 x SATA power connectorsTHE GOOD:+ Has black textured (anti-fingerprint) case+ Has one dual ball bearing 120mm cooling fan (verified by the label of the fan itself). Ball bearing fans are a must in power supplies because a bad fan will cause the power supply to cook itself to failure shortly (if you don't notice that the fan has failed). A ball bearing fan has superior lifespan over the cheaper sleeve bearing fans that are used on most power supplies. Anyway, the fan in this supply has an RPM of 1600 and is not adjustable or temperature controlled.+ This supply also has dual 12V motherboard power connectors (the 4 pin one that plugs into the motherboard). As shipped it looks like a single 8-pin connector and so you might be confused that there is no 4-pin connector at first glance. However the two connectors combine into one, so if you only have a single 4-pin connector on your motherboard (like most boards) you need to separate the two connectors. Note that the similar PS480E12 supply does not have dual 12V connectors.+ 12V power rail is higher amperage (25A) than on similar priced PS480E12 supply (16A). This is primarily because of the 6-pin 12V graphics card power connector and the dual motherboard 12V power connectors. The PS550 is rated total average power 400W (Max Power 550W), but understand that PS manufacturers intentionally rate supplies with the highest  (i.e. unrealistic) wattage figure that they can advertise. Consider this a 400W supply despite the 550W rating. By comparison the PS480E12 is rated total average power 330W (Max Power 480W)+ Has nylon mesh sleeving to keep cabling tidy which is something the PS480E12 missed.+ Internally, this PS has AC line filtering components that are not in the PS480E12.THE BAD:- Has the same generic capacitors that are in the PS480E12. Time will tell whether these are quality caps. These are 1000uF caps, would have liked to see 1500uF or even 2200uF.- The internal heatsink is different from the PS480E12 - the fins do not extend to help with heat dissipation.- Some may dislike that there is no fancy LED fan (I don't care).OVERALL I would buy this supply over the PS480E12. As I write this it is actually slightly cheaper so it's an easy decision to recommend this power supply.I hope this has been useful!

The LOGISYS PS480E12 Power Supply is a standard ATX power supply and can be used to replace the power supplies in most generic/DIY built PCs. Note that there is no 6-pin video card power connector on this supply (some power hungry graphics cards require this connector) so if you need this check out the Logisys Corp. 550W 120mm Ball Bearing Fan with PSU ATX 550 Power Supply PS550E12BK, Black instead.THE GOOD:+ Has one dual ball bearing 120mm cooling fan (verified by the label of the fan itself). Ball bearing fans are a must in power supplies because a bad fan will cause the power supply to cook itself to failure shortly (if you don't notice that the fan has failed). A ball bearing fan has superior lifespan over the cheaper sleeve bearing fans that are used on most power supplies. Anyway, the fan in this supply has an RPM of 1600 and is not adjustable or temperature controlled. Note the difference in RPM compared to the specs on the product page (claimed 2000RPM but actually 1600RPM in my supply).+ Has physical on/off switch.THE BAD:- The wires to the Molex/floppy/SATA connectors are thinner compared to previous power supplies that I've used. Wire gauge appears to be 22 AWG.- There is no nylon sleeve on cables to keep wires neat and tidy. Because of this cabling is somewhat "messy" when installed (a couple of cable ties will help).- Some people may be disappointed that there are no fancy LEDs or that the case doesn't have shiny colors. (These things don't mean much to me anyway, I prefer a reliable plain-looking power supply over a fancy looking one).- I have examined the capacitors used on this supply. As expected they are some brand that I've never heard of - time will tell whether they actually last or not. However one thing that I didn't like is the low value of the capacitors on the DC outputs. This supply has single 1000uF caps on 3.3v, 5v & 12v outputs. Generally I would like to see 1500uF or preferably 2200uF. 1000uF was probably chosen because they are lower cost. One good thing about the caps is that they are not right next to the heatsink as in other supplies so they should not be affected by high temps.- Even though the supply is labelled "480W" note that the total average power is 330W (Max Power 480W).OVERALL, I would recommend this supply at the low cost (24 bucks at the time I bought it), although I wish it had sleeving to keep cables tidy. I have installed this supply in a PC that is on 24/7 and will update this review as time passes.I hope you have found this helpful.

The ASW308 is an inexpensive 8-port 10/100Mbit Ethernet desktop/wall-mountable "green" switch.THE GOOD:+ Inexpensive.+ Compact attractive design.+ Uses Realtek RTL8309E chipset which is a highly integrated switch controller with built-in RAM etc for a more reliable & inexpensive switch.+ Documentation is better than expected for a switch. (I have noticed that AirLink's packaging and documentation seems to be better than the usual OEM). Anyway, a switch is something most people just plug in and never look at the documentation!+ Switch is a "green" switch, it saves power by powering down unused ports and dynamically adjusting power for shorter cable lengths.THE BAD:- If you need a Gigabit switch this is not for you (10/100Mbit only). It will of course work with other Gigabit devices but at reduced 100Mbit speed. I recommend the TRENDnet 8-Port Unmanaged Gigabit GREENnet Standard Switch (8 x 10/100/1000Mbps) if you need a Gigabit switch.- No screws included for wall mounting. Additionally the screw holes underneath do not have the height clearance to fit commonly available pan head #6 screws (They should have made the case screw recessed holes a bit taller).- The markings on the case do not indicate the voltage of the power adapter, in case you get it mixed up with other adapters (or are trying to find a replacement). It's 8VDC @ 0.6 amp, center pin positive. Also note that the power adapter plugs into the right side of the case so you will need some space around that side of the case.OVERALL I would recommend this switch - it is a good value for the price.

The DT-L3108HV DVR is a small 8-channel DVR (desk footprint slightly bigger than a 10" netbook). It accepts one SATA 3.5" hard drive (although the electronics look like it was designed to accommodate 2 drives since there is an unused SATA data connector on the board). Note that NO hard drive is included, this is a DIY addition. I have installed a 2TB drive and it works fine.THE GOOD:+ There is a front mounted USB port so when you want to backup to a USB drive you don't have to fumble at the back of the DVR (possibly disconnecting a cable).+ There is a single 40mm fan to cool the electronics & hard drive.+ The local DVR Interface (i.e. using the mouse) is polished, with slick menu icons. The only thing that's missing from the local DVR interface is an exit playback button (you have to right click then select stop playing, then view desktop to exit playback mode and resume live view)+ An interesting thing is that for the 9-view split (remember only 8 cams can be connected) the 9th view shows codec bitrate information for each channel which can be useful for understanding how different resolution/quality settings affect bitrate. This is something that I have not seen with other DVRs that I've used. However it would be useful if the DVR would average the last 30 seconds of video and display MByte/Hour statistic as well as the # of days of currently stored recorded video.+ The DVR interface does show the start/end dates of stored video (you have to dig in the menu options to find it)+ You can schedule periodic reboots.THE BAD:- Monitor output is only VGA, there is no HDMI output (you can also connect a "spot" monitor via BNC output connector but most people will not use this). Even though there's no HDMI support the GUI interface allows "widescreen" resolutions via VGA (up to 1440x900)- Case was a little harder to open/close than expected, you have to slightly bend the sides apart while raising/lowering the back of the case.- The printed documentation is atrocious, even by DVR OEM standards. There are no instructions on how to open the case, and the operation of the DVR isn't really covered in the sort of detail that I'd like. However by playing around you can probably figure out most things, but I would prefer to read an accurate manual to save time. There were also documentation files on the CD but my CD was defective (see further below) so I don't know if a better manual was on the CD.- Placement of video out (BNC) jack is right next to channel 1 input, if you are not careful you might plug a cam into this jack. There should have been clear visual separation of camera inputs from similar-looking connectors (or at the very least a label on the top of the DVR pointing this out).- Unlike most other DVRs the hard drive LED just remains "on" all the time, it doesn't blink to indicate activity.IMAGE QUALITY:+ Recorded playback quality is very good at D1 resolution and "best" quality. It is SUPERIOR to the Nightowl Zeus DVR that I have previously reviewed (which has a blocky mess of pixels for video playback)PC CLIENT (CMS) SOFTWARE:+ Software has good layout and options+ You can actually view live video while playing back a video file (each in different windows). This is both good & bad - both use bandwidth so if you only want to playback and don't care about live monitoring you should stop the live live (click on the cam icons to turn off) before playback. Many DVRs don't allow live monitoring while playing back.+ You can click on the video timeline to quickly jump around during playback.+ You can adjust DVR settings remotely via the client software.- Slow/Fast playback does not display an onscreen speed indicator "2x, 4x, 8x" etc like on other DVRs.- One negative thing is that Fast Forward sometimes causes playback to stop, especially at the higher fast forward playback speeds. When this happens you have to click stop then restart playback of the video file that you were watching (you don't have to close or restart the client software though). I have verified that this consistently happens even on a LAN connection, so it's nothing to do with internet bandwidth or transmission. This really should never happen for a DVR and is an unfortunate black mark against it. I have not tested the web-based (IE browser) software because I think the PC CMS software does everything needed for most remote access. The DVR also comes with mobile software for Android/Blackberry/Symbian & Windows Mobile devices (untested by me).- The miniCD that was included with the DVR was defective - I could not read the software from it and on visual inspection it had a bumpy defect on the data side. I downloaded the software from D&T's website at [...]BUILD CONSTRUCTION/INCLUDED ACCESSORIES:- Remote does not come with batteries. Some other DVRs include them.- There were a few solder splashes inside the case. I removed them but production staff is obviously not being careful enough - they could potentially cause damage to the internal electronics.- The plastic cover that covers the DVR's infrared remote sensor came out and was rolling around inside the case. I guess this was not glued down as it should be (this is a cosmetic issue, the remote will work without the cover in place)OVERALL, I would recommend this DVR, even though it's an 8 channel DVR. In terms of the last DVR I reviewed (16 channel Nightowl Zeus DVR) the DT-L3108HV has better image quality, a more usable interface, and is also smaller in size (although it only holds a single hard drive).UPDATE: There is one stupid design flaw - the clock is powered by a non-rechargeable battery that is SOLDERED-IN and not user replaceable! When it dies your clock will stop working as it is only powered by the battery (even if the DVR is on). It is unacceptable that the battery is not easily replaceable.I now recommend the following DVR model instead: 8Ch H.264 Onvif CCTV Hybrid DVR, D1 Realtime DVR, 1080P NVR with 3G, Wifi, HDMI Output CCTV Security Systems as it is an updated version that has 960H camera support, newer firmware, a user-replaceable battery and can work with either analog cameras or certain IP cameras (for better quality images). The software and user interface is virtually the same as on the DNT.I hope you have found this review useful!

I am very familiar with Security Cameras, DVRs, and have used many DVRs. The Nightowl Zeus is a standalone 16-channel DVR without any installed hard drives. I purchased the Zeus DVR model with the factory installed 500GB SATA hard drive. Apart from the hard drive difference there is no functionality difference, thus I am reviewing this DVR here.THE GOOD:+ DVR can record D1 resolution on all channels, approx 7 Frames Per Second on each channel.+ DVR can accommodate 2 drives.+ DVR has 2 fans help cool the internals, especially the drives.+ Has HDMI output in addition to VGA, so you can easily connect to a large TV or monitor. You can set the HDMI resolution in setup menu.+ Can setup to periodically reboot system.+ Can upgrade firmware remotely (via the internet) via the use of the PC Client software.THE BAD:- Front panel is "simple", probably not to confuse new users. However there is no front USB port for exporting video. The USB ports are located under the network port at the back, which is bad placement cause in trying to connect a USB drive you might accidentally unplug the network cable.RECORD COMMENTS:- The Record OSD (onscreen text) is embedded in the video file and is not at the edges of the video image, so it kind of gets in the way of the scene details.- Recorded Video Quality is BAD, even at highest D1 resolution and Best Quality. Very blocky video playback!PLAYBACK COMMENTS:- Local Playback options (i.e. you are at the DVR using the USB mouse) is very limited and cumbersome. To playback you first select a channel, then calender date, then click search, then click on a time (in half hour increments). Then you select which channels to playback (default is all 16, and if you don't want this you have to click on each channel to deselect). Finally the video starts playing but you have to go thru the whole painful process again if you want a different time. There are no controls while playing to easily jump to a specific time or a "timeline" that you could easily jump around while playing.- I just mentioned it but will do so again: You can only select time in half hour increments while doing local playback at the DVR.Local playback is retarded and cumbersome but I was hoping that the PC Client software would make up for this. It's better than the local DVR interface but has issues as well. (I used the latest DVR firmware and client software at the time of this review)PC CLIENT PLAYBACK:- For playback you cannot full screen a video file, even though you could do this if viewing "live" video.- When playing back there is no "Snapshot" feature, even though there is one for "live" view.+ One "plus" is that you can click on the timeline of a playing video file and you can jump to various times.- You can't setup the client software to autologin (i.e. without entering login details like username, password etc). Some DVR client software allows this and it can be convenient.- For some strange reason there is a "bandwidth control" that appears ONLY in the PC client software Remote Setting but not locally at the DVR itself using the local interface. So if you don't use the PC client software you'd never know it was there!- You cannot group cams to view remotely - either view all cams or manually click on each cam to start/stop playback.OVERALL, I DON'T RECOMMEND this DVR - the interface flaws and poor design really make using it a chore. It's a pity because the manuals/specs/client software/firmware is available online, which is not the case for many DVRs. It's a shame, with a little reworking of both the DVR firmware and client software this could have been a great DVR. If you do purchase this DVR be aware that there may be newer firmware available, may fix IE issues and add support for Safari browser on Mac systems.As a possible alternative you might want to look at the DNT 8ch 8 Channel H.264 Standalone Cameras Surveillance Cctv Dvr Digital Video Recorder Security Systems, D1(704x480)resolution Recording@120fps, 8ch DVR instead.I hope you have found this review useful, it sure took a lot of time to research/write!
