For those that don't know Sony's Effio chipset has adjustable on-screen (OSD) controls for adjusting picture details as well as special functions (privacy mask, lens iris adjustments, adjusting day/night trip point, turning Wide Dynamic Range on/off etc). This camera might indeed use the Effio chipset but does NOT have the controls molded into the cable as other Effio cams do. Therefore you are limited to whatever "defaults" the manufacturer programmed (and there's no way of knowing what these are).THE GOOD:+ Attractive, lightweight (due to black plastic case).+ Lots of IR LEDs for night vision.+ Comes with power supply.THE BAD:- Not fully adjustable as other Effio cams for the reason pointed out above.- This is not a varifocal cam, you cannot adjust lens to match your desired view - it's a fixed 3.6mm (wide angle) lens.- The seller has used the same amazon product ASIN for different products at different points in time. Therefore the older reviews may not match the current "Effio" product - something to be aware of!OVERALL, I would recommend Professional 1/3" Sony Exview HAD CCD II with Effio-E DSP Devices Dome Indoor Security Camera - 700 TV lines, 2.8~12mm varifocal lens, 36pcs IR LED, 98 feet IR Distance. Vandalproof. WDR (Wide Dynamic Range). OSD Menu. Great Image, Great for Entrance. instead of this camera because it has a varifocal lens plus OSD controls on the cable.Hope this has been helpful!

The N68S3+ is an inexpensive Socket AM3/DDR3 microATX motherboard that is perfect for building a low-end system. The chipset is the Nvidia MCP68S(nForce630a) which has integrated graphics (VGA output only, no DVI). This board reminds me of the older Biostar MCP6PB (which was an AM2+ socket/DDR2 motherboard) except updated for AM3/DDR3.THE GOOD:+ Has 1 serial port (on back panel), floppy connector, 1 IDE(PATA) connector and also parallel port header on motherboard (you can connect an optional parallel port connector to this header).+ Has 4 SATA connectors (note: 3Gb/S not 6Gb/S).+ Has 2 800/1066/1333 DDR3 DIMM slots for up to 8GB memory support (4GB per DIMM).+ There are 4 Back panel USB2 ports, and 2 more headers on the board to add additional ports.+ Has a single PCIe x16 slot for graphics (if you want to upgrade to something better than the onboard GeForce 7025/nForce 630a).+ Socket AM3 accepts Sempron/Phenom II/Athlon II CPUs up to 95 watt.+ Audio is provided by Realtek ALC662 codec, which supports 6-channel audio.+ I like that the ATX power connector is at the center of the board and not positioned by the DIMMs/IDE connector.+ Motherboard caps in CPU power supply section are "solid" capacitors for longer life.THE BAD:- There are 2 PCI slots in addition to the PCIe x16 slot. Some might prefer that there was a PCIe x1 connector instead of one of the PCI slots.- Network is 10/100Mbit via a Realtek RTL8201CL (no Gigabit Ethernet on this board).- There does not seem to be any updated BIOS other than what the board ships with. Biostar's website does not list newer BIOS for this board other than one uploaded on 2010-08-26.OVERALL, I would recommend this board if you need to build a cheap system for general use or for a family member doing "typical" computer use (Office, Web browsing, etc). A cheap single-core CPU that works on this board is the AMD Sempron 145 Processor (SDX145HBGMBOX)

I am experienced with microcontroller systems but new to Arduino. Here's what I think of this book:THE GOOD:+ For a beginner it's very readable and isn't "here's a bunch of theory and then we do fun stuff". The book is very much hands-on oriented, giving just enough explanation related to the task at hand (which is both good & bad, more on this below)+ Book is thin and small, will not cause "I have to read and understand all that?" anxiety for beginnersTHE BAD:- The use of timer interrupts is not discussed at all in this book. I found this disappointing as timer interrupts are a common way to handle "background" tasks (this is where you can run code at specific time intervals). One could argue that this is not a beginner topic but since pin interrupt-on-change interrupts ARE discussed I think timer interrupts should have been as well. UPDATE: The follow-up book Programming Arduino Next Steps: Going Further with Sketches (Tab) covers timer interrupts and other fun stuff.- There are many issues that could be expanded on, even a couple of sentences would be helpful. Examples include:Arduino maximum pin current sink/source & applied voltage limitations. This is briefly mentioned in Chapter 1, but the author just mentions to be careful to not exceed the 40mA current limitation. He should have also mentioned that you can damage the chip this way (also if you exceed max voltage to an I/O pin). This should have been repeated in Chapter 6 which deals with digital interfacing. One of the most common mistakes in interfacing is overlooking the max operating specifications and damaging the chip or decreasing long-term reliability.In Chapter 10 where the author discusses Ethernet shields he mentions that you need the "official" shield based on the Wiznet chipset rather than the cheaper ones based on the Microchip ENC28F60 chip. He could have stated why - the reason is because the Wiznet chip handles the gory details of TCP/IP communication for you (and is more expensive than the ENC28J60 which requires the host chip to do the TCP/IP processing, which is NOT suitable for beginners).OVERALL, it's a gentle introduction for beginners to Arduino. If you are new to Arduino I would recommend buying an extra board or chip in case you accidentally damage it. It can be helpful for troubleshooting to try the same code on a different board to see if the problem might be with the board. Also, search the internet for "10 Ways to Destroy an Arduino" to avoid expensive mistakes.As a bonus, here are other useful Arduino-related items that I have reviewed/purchased and you might be interested in:Cheap UNO clone: SainSmart UNO R3 ATmega328P Development Board + USB Cable Compatible With Arduino UNO R3 Mega 2560 Nano RobotCheap Mega2560 clone: SainSmart Mega2560 R3 ATmega2560-16AU + ATMEGA16U2 + USB Cable for Robot Arduino UNO MEGA2560 R3 Duemilanove 2013Serial 2x16 LCD using I2C (only 2 I/O pins): ZITRADES New IIC/I2C/TWI 1602 Serial LCD Module Display For Arduino BY ZITRADESCheap Ethernet Shield: RioRand (TM) Upgraded Ethernet Shield W5100 for Arduino UNO R3 & MEGA 2560 DuemilanoveI hope you found this useful!

I'm reviewing TV-IP110WN Hardware version 2. This is a 802.11n/wired Ethernet camera with no night vision capability.THE GOOD:+ Supports 802.11n+ InexpensiveTHE BAD:- Images have a lot of motion blur to them (in good light). For some reason other Trendnet cams that I've used don't exhibit this problem. I find this motion blur unacceptable. I do not know if this is something new to TV-IP110WN version 2 or if it was also present in version 1.- Frame rate is only adjustable in 5FPS intervals (5FPS, 10FPS, 15FPS, etc)- Only MJPEG compression is supported (no MPEG4 or H.264)OVERALL this camera feels like a cheap imitation of a Trendnet camera - I guess they have to cut corners and make them cheap to sell at this price? Unfortunately due to the motion blur I can't recommend this camera. Instead you might want to check out others which I have reviewed:TRENDnet TV-IP602WN ProView Wireless Pan/Tilt/Zoom Internet Surveillance CameraTRENDnet TV-IP312WN SecureView Wireless N Day/Night Internet Surveillance Camera Server with 2-Way AudioCisco-Linksys Wireless-N Internet Home Monitoring CameraLoftek Newest CXS 3200 Wireless/wired Pan:340&,<,ir Cut, Dual Audio Alarm Ip Camera,8-10 Meter Night Vision ,67 Viewing Angle,easy Installation.white(replace 2200)I hope you found this useful!

The CXS3200 is a Pan/Tilt indoor cam with nighttime infrared LEDs. Interfaces are 10/100 Mbit Ethernet & 802.11b/g WiFi (note no N!)THE GOOD:+ Inexpensive for a Pan/Tilt cam with IR capability, cheaper than "brand name" cams.+ Very quiet Pan/Tilt movement.+ Cam has IR LEDs for night vision. Also supposedly features a true IR filter for correct outdoor colors in daytime. (But remember this is an indoor camera only).+ Max resolution is 640x480, using MJPEG compression only (no MPEG4 or H.264)+ I like the bracket included with this camera, it is easy to install and adjust. You can even compensate for different bracket mounting angles which is nice. (Related to mounting is the firmware ability to flip and/or mirror the image, useful if the camera is mounted upside down)THE BAD:- Wifi is 802.11b/g NOT N. I'd recommend that you only consider this as a wired cam, especially since only MJPEG compression is available.- Firmware is missing some useful features. For example there does not seem to be a way to set preset P/T position for quick and easy position presets (where the cam moves to with a click of a button). Because of this you cannot set a certain position that the cam will "powerup" to. This is a big disadvantage in my book and is a feature in Trendnet PTZ cams that I like.- Frame rate appears to reset to default 30FPS after a power failure or reset. (Other cams retain the setting).- Also in contrast to other cams (Trendnet, Linksys etc) the setup interface feels almost like a prototype and is unpolished. At first glance you might miss additional option pages that are on the right side of the page, as opposed to the left side.- Like the Trendnet TV-IP110WN this camera has a problem with motion blur. Moderately fast motion will blur. I suspect the cam has a fixed (long) shutter speed.- At time of writing this there are no firmware updates on Loftek's website.NOT TESTED BY ME: Whatever software that comes with the camera (since I'm using BlueIris). Also I didn't test camera functions like emailing photos, FTP uploads, etc.OVERALL, it is an inexpensive camera without many bells or whistles. I doubt you will find a Day/Night Pan/Tilt camera for much cheaper. (I deducted one star for no 802.11n, one star for motion blurring, and one star for no preset positions and the ability to powerup to a preset position). You may also want to check out my review of the TRENDnet TV-IP602WN ProView Wireless Pan/Tilt/Zoom Internet Surveillance Camera for another Pan/Tilt cam.I hope you found this useful!

The Gigabyte GT440 GV-N44D3-1GI is a Nvidia GT440 powered card with 1GB of DDR3 memory.THE GOOD:+ Card doesn't require external power.+ Card has a nice large 80mm fan to cool heatsink. This fan is a 3-pin fan so the card can sense the fan RPM speed. (This is good as some cheaper graphics cards tend to use a 2-pin fan without the RPM feedback so the card has no way of knowing if the fan is working. I have fried a card or two because of this problem and I'm guessing I'm not the only one). I like the large fan on this card, in my experience larger fans are more reliable than smaller ones.+ Card has VGA, DVI, & HDMI ports. If your monitor has a VGA connector you wouldn't need a DVI>VGA adapter.+ Card delivers good performance for the price. This would be a good card to upgrade to if your graphics card is old (Note this is a PCI Express card, not AGP)THE BAD:- Because of the large heatsink/fan, the card blocks the expansion slot adjacent to this card. This is pretty much the norm for most graphics cards. Some cards have a "double wide" expansion slot bracket (which I don't like) but this one doesn't.- This particular model has 1GB of DDR3 memory. There is another model that has 512MB/GDDR5 memory which is faster. However if you're upgrading this will most likely be faster than your old card so it's not a big deal.- Card is not low-profile and cannot be used for LP systems/cases.- Unlike most new cards, the box is NOT shrinkwrapped! This made me a little uneasy but I bought 2 cards and both boxes were the same, no shrink wrap present.OVERALL, I would recommend this card, especially for upgrading. It is not a high end card, but the price isn't high end either.

This is a DELL OEM card (fits PCI Express slot, NOT AGP). Being an OEM card it does NOT include:- Drivers (download them from nvidia's website)- 6-pin power connector adapter. If your power supply does not have a 6-pin molex connector you may need to buy something like StarTech.com 6-Inch LP4 to 6 Pin PCI Express Video Card Power Cable Adapter (LP4PCIEXADAP)- DVI-to-VGA adapters (there are 2 DVI connectors on the card but no HDMI or VGA)- Fancy packagingIf you need a cheap powerful graphics card for gaming this one should work fine. Just be sure your case ventilation is good and your power supply can handle the additional load (according to wikipedia the GTS240 card consumes 120 watts).

Excellent design. Stainless internal collar. Comes with securing hardware within the scales. I thought this would be a mild upgrade, but it is an excellent evolution in the Candiru. Don't hesitate. Upgrade!

Because this uses zip ties it has no adjustment once on. Since it's almost flush, getting the GPS off of it takes some work. The spine release requires a,bit of beefing. But if snug on a stem, it's hard to wedge a finger under far enough to release it.When the GPS is snapped on (be sure it makes a firm click) it's as strong as th zip ties. In other words it will take a pretty good crash to knock free the GPS.

Better pick up the pace. Four episodes in and zombies are as scarce as normal people. Good God, is everyone in this show screwed up. We need some shoot'n an stab'n before I fall asleep.The zombies are better actors, and goodness knows if an intellectual zombie series is going to make it, there better be some action at least a few times per episode. for a 12v vacuum, this one sucks...in a good way. While it won't rip the skin off your hand, it might leave a hickey.For quick work or field/ outdoor use this is plenty good enough. Glad I got it and would do it again.

Amazing! Just took ROAM for a spin on the river and backcountry trails. Without the chip, my GPS is obsolete. What I thought was a useful collection of information about where I was and what was nearby was actually just like describing a book without actually reading it. The ROAM chip took the difference between no GPS and having a GPS and doubled it again!The level of detail is astonishing. ROAM turned backcountry trails into a street-by-street navigation. There were trails I didn't even know where there along my usual haunts and sure enough, there was a trail or overgrown logging road from decades ago just sitting there buried in underbrush.In the old trail maps I've got are mimicked on the GPS including their name. While GPS technology is already essential, the ROAM chip takes the handheld GPS to an entirely new level of use in the backcountry. I usually travel across blank space on the GPS screen, but now I have a defined trail with a clear picture of where the trail goes and what other trails are around. Plus there's the 24k topo. Plus there's the geographic features. Plus there's the general land ownership.I pulled the chip out just to see what it was like after using the chip for a couple trips. My GPS looked blank compared to all the data on this chip. Frankly, I cannot imagine using my GPS without it. It's just that good!

I have a bigger one and loved it so much I got a smaller one so as never to be without it. Everything good you read about the Silky is true. And if you want this for a camp saw, know you have the best.The shipping from Japan was lightening fast. As fast as I would expect from a US supplier.This saw is the perfect size for quick jobs and handy to have around all the time. Love the orange handle as well.

Love this blade. Well balanced. Shaving sharp. Perfect size for the space between bushcraft knife and camp axe. For all those who need more than a knife, but less than a full hatchet, this is the ticket. I'm never without it on the road or off!
95% as good as the OEM Canon batteries
Perfect for training. Well made.

Stellar Build Quality...But only 120 lumens? It's fine close quarters, but bu today's standards, 120L is wildly underpowered especially for a two 123 cell LED tactical light.The shape is wonderful for holding the light in all sorts of positions unavailable with other lights.The interface takes both practice and memory since the buttons have multiple functions when pushed in combination and with how long they are depresses.The blue-red-white strobe is a great feature since it almost perfectly mimics a flashing light bar especially when reflecting off surfaces.The finger hook is a joke. It works great until it falls off. Come on guys, make a finger hole that stays on the light without a tiny rim wedged between screwed surfaces. You can use the pinch-hold idea but over build the system!The belt hook is the best in the business and with the 90degree head, this light rocks the hands-free tactical light space.
Wow is this a performer! Wireless hub. Battery charger. Mass media sharing. This think delivers on all fronts.

For the price, you cannot beat it! While it could come with a padded sock, the form factor and operation are perfect. I gave about twelve bucks and it's worth much more. One bad bell hit and you could have bought a dozen of these. Just do it!

Interface app is a little clunky but the concept is bulletproof. If you need massive wireless storage, the Lacie is the current best choice. There is room for improvement, but that's really splitting hairs. I just wish there were several interface App options. All I need of my iPads is a media dump for backup. I don't need everything else. Maybe later, but not now so I don't want a busy App when I just need one simple tool.

My favorite iPad cover. Heavy but protective. The stand is stellar, and the grip is comfortably tacky. The screen cover is effective as long as you remove the protective film. I've use many cases and this is the single best.
This dryer rocks! So much better than my cheaper one that wasn't much cheaper. This guy will pay for itself in just a few seasons. Only possible issue is drawback it is does make noise.
Best in class. Don't even think of buying other also-ran rechargeable. eneloop is the best.
Best there are. If you need 123s then you need Surefire. For little more cost than the no-names, these will rock your lights longer and brighter, and in colder environs then everyone else.

These are amazing scissors and not for the faint of heart. They are like the machete of scissors, and need to be in harms way to fully appreciate their features. Which just happen to include:1) powerful serrated blades that will slice coins in half or anything else you can fit in their mouth.2) a ring cutter that works and doesn't grind the gold or silver into powder like twist-ring-cutters.3) foldable design for smaller storage.4) carbide glass breaker for aggressive entry.5) foldable seatbelt/cord cutter hook.6) hardcore sheath that mostly works.But on the downside, several things are apparent including:1) the sheath is not user friendly meaning inserting and deploying the Raptors is clunker than it needs to be.2) the Raptors cannot be inserted in to the sheath with the cutting hook deployed. WTF?3) the fixed carbide glass breaker causes occasional palm punctures when prying or pushing on the scissors.4) the sheath seems to hold them backwards for most of my deployment where my thumb ends up in the wrong hole.5) and finally, what's with the black? How about blaze orange plastic on the handles and black ceracoating on the stainless?No matter what, these are the best in class. I've used many other field scissors  and these are the best by magnitudes! Thanks Leatherman!

Nice light but has quite a spot component to it. I also have the 12v Milwaukee LED light and two things surface. 1) the Milwaukee is much better as a work light since a spot light is more like a flashlight. And 2) the Dewalt has a much better form factor and features that really work. The magnet on the Milwaukee barely holds it still, and it's shape prevents it from pointing easily in many directions.In a nutshell, I'd say the dewalt is more of a every-day light especially when not doing tool work, and the Milwaukee is an excellent wide spectrum work light. If I was plumbing, doing electrical or digging around in a hole or chimney, I would use the Milwaukee hands down. If I want to know whats going bump in the night or what's crawling around the back yard, then definitely the Dewalt.Really, the Milwaukee produces a beautiful wide spot-free distribution of light. I just wish it was more like the operation of the dewalt. Oh well. Can't have everything.

Oh Yea!Benchmade did it again. This is my new EDC. Sorry 530 and Volli. Catch you later Barrage and mini Griptillian. The 477 is like a fine watch. Custom feel with Benchmade performance and durability. The S30V steel is so much better than the pedestrian supersteel 154cm.The assist kicks this blade into a dimension above the regular Blue class. Buy it and fall in love.

Simple, effective, small, light. Who could ask for more. Well, I can. I wish this sharpener came in an extra fine. Most use will touch up an blade back to a razors edge.For the price it cannot be beat.

5 stars because it does exactly what it should as it should. However I also have the Rainier Arms Raptor Ambidextrous Charging Handle - .223 / 5.56mm and like it better.The Troy is an update of the traditional design, while the Raptor is a total re-engineered handle. The paddles in the Troy roughly mirror each other while the Raptor paddles are side-specific and have beefed up pins rather than the tried-and-true pins in the Troy.Both are necessary upgrades IMHO, but for roughly the same price, the RA Raptor is the better choice. When one closes in on a Benji for a simple Al charging handle, it better be golden. Also-rans don't turn me on. If you're going to make better mousetrap, then impress me.But don't dismay Troy, there's plenty of fertile ground for yet to be discovered innovation in charging handle technology. Stick with it.

Size is fine especially for the price.Given that basically ceramic is ceramic, and that it chips and shatters easily, I'd rather have one of these in every knife drawer and outdoor kit than one pricy spyderco (which I have as well).

A wonderful piece of hardware.Just tossing in my two cents. Love this camera as a happy medium between my dslrs and p&s cameras. Moved up from a similar form factor but dated nikon.Only negatives are that some of the buttons are exactly where you need to grab the camera during stress shooting like in pouring rain, snow, one handed, or panic grab shots. +\- lever spins backwards for my taste (nikon thing?) and battery seems to last forever.  Just wish there was a pro-level case for this specific model. Buy with confidence.
Overbuilt just as I wanted. Fits perfectly and is stout enough to hold a heavy timepiece in place and with the dignity it deserves.

Yup, you read it right. A $20 Fishpond brand aerospace aluminum and titanium leader gage-bottle opener-line cutter.Not the most practical, but easily the coolest. If you need a gift for a fisherman who has everything, then this might be the only thing on the planet that he/she would not buy for themselves.Enjoy life and add this trinket to your vest. Why not, it's only money...and weight...and vest real estate...and one more thing hanging off your wearable Christmas tree.

You can get all the specs, dimensions and  gory details elsewhere, but I'm here to tell you that this is a significant upgrade in the human-rifle interface.Storage is nice but the real deal is the way your cheek melts into the stock.For the price of a few boxes of ammo, you can improve your accuracy and shooting enjoyment.Forget the complaints about installing it. The included dummy round is nothing but a metaphor. As far as black rifles goes, it's a simple, painless and well-engineered fix to traditional bland buttstocks.

I have a Benchmade folder for every day of the week. This Barrage is  powerhouse for daily tasks. The Adamas is a killing machine, and the 530 is  office tool, but the Barrage cuts dangerously well and the combo edge makes short order of pretty much everything.The blade length puts this folder into the category of a serious knife that does its business with no remorse.The only minor complaint I have about this knife is there is no exposed screwhead with which you could tighten the blade pivot. I don't know if you'll ever need to, but most of my other Benchmades have this ability, and it is massively handy.Of course, Benchmade offers a cleaning, tightening and sharpening service for only $5, or free (you pay the one-way shipping) if the knife seems to require warranty service due to loosening.No matter what, this knife is a winner.

Works like Magic, and it is magic!The modern wonder of physics makes bore sighting a piece of cake, and does it like magic.because this little slice of raw physics cannot be wrong, any deviation is a problem with the scope, the mount, them alignment, or your gun.Seriously, it's that good. Just too bad it's discontinued. (:- (

I graduated from the plastic Butler Creek scope covers to these and cannot believe the quality difference.Do you need these? Probably not. But given that you raise and lower your scope covers more often than you pull the trigger, they make the whole gun thing oh so much more enjoyable.On the practical side, the caps are bombproof and deploy almost silently. The rear cap is on or not with a very effective flip lever launching the cap as needed. The front side cap can be snapped down firmly or rest lightly in the closed position only to rise silently with a slight nudge.For the cost of a couple boxes of ammo, or one box of the really good stuff, these caps of scope jewelry are worth it.

I've used many waterproof, hurricane, and stormproof matches, and these are the best. Save them for when needed, but trust your life to them when necessary.I store them in a Exotac Matchcap Waterproof Match Case, X-Large, Blaze Orange with the extra strikers.

First of all, as a Gold Ring Leupold scope, this little fellow is top shelf all the way. The optics and operation make it a joy to use all day long. Absolutely no hesitations there.But the size is what you need to be aware of. Not that there is anything wrong with the size, but instead is this the size you need?  Some other reviewers seem to have been expecting something else than the world's finest compact spotting scope.Where this scope is ideal is when you need 1. World-class optics, 2. extreme light weight in a spotting scope, 3. a 10x-20x range, 4. reasonable but not exceptional low light capability, 5. ability to easily handhold the scope, and 6. you are looking for a binocular supplement, not a binocular replacement.The Gold Ring 10x20 compact spotting scope is not for everyone. It is like the Macbook Air of laptops. Truly amazing, but with limits. However, it is those limits that allow it to be truly amazing.The major difference between this scope and its larger brethren is that you will have this scope with you. You will bother to set it up. And you will bother to bring it along no matter where you go. It doesn't matter how nice or big a scope you have. If you don't bring it with you or pull it from its case, then you might as well not have a scope.Normally compact spotting scopes are substandard designs, optics, and focus. Further, many of those junk compacts have the physics to go to 60x but have no where near the optics to pull off such a stunt. In this case, the Leupold 10-20x Compact flawlessly presents the world every time and across its entire zoom range. No corners cut here.If you need/want something in this form factor, this is the scope to get. If you need something that reaches out to 60x, look elsewhere. And also hire a sherpa to carry it. Oh, and don't say I didn't warn you.

For a reel case, this thing is overkill. It is larger than expected in shear volume, but holds a reel quite snuggly.It's possible to store a few small things under the pads.You can zip this over a reel on a rod if you like. Just line up the zipper to allow for maximum zipping since it obviously cannot be zipped all the way closed.There is an additional heavy duty hinge connecting the two clamshells (with another one at the zipper) where you could attach a lanyard, name tag, reel identifier, etc. if needed.Typical Fishpond quality.

Standup Paddle Board (SUP) fishing is the next big things, and this pack is perfect.Wearing it like a sling keeps the right hand more free to throw a line or paddle. The sling does not have an attachment point on the right side near the waist.The main pocket is larger enough for a lunch, jacket, tackle, and some other EDC odds and ends. Where this kid rocks is that, compared to a backpack, the sling allows you so slide the pack from back to belly where the zipper awaits you. If you wore it on the opposite shoulder, the zippers would be on the bottom, so this essentially a right handed pack if you want all the benefits.It will keep your stuff dry if you fall off your board and get back on reasonably soon. The zippers are the water resistant kind that are easier to zip/unzip, but not hard like those of waterproof duffles, etc.Honesty, I think it could use a few more external attachment points, but not a big deal.The waist belt is quite nice, but a little overkill given the single lightly padded shoulder strap.Another side note: this can ride higher on your back if you want allowing for a CO2 inflatable PFD to be worn around the waist. And the shoulder strap has a small release buckle on at the waist contact point allowing you to dump it quickly...if you can manage to pinch the sides of the buckle. I can barely do it with dry warm hands.

is that Fishpond went back to the drawing board with no traditions to uphold. From the standpoint of universal design and effective human/machine interaction, the Pitchfork scores big time. The large finger holes provide plenty of grip even if hands are cold or gloved.The cutting surfaces provide a snip exactly where you want it, not almost where you want it. The eye cleaner is stellar and near impossible to poke anything but what you want. I would have said impossible, but someone out there will manage to puncture their waders with it no matter where it is.And of course, there is the coolness factor. In this case its two-fold. First, it looks great. Second, it feels great to work with. Given the clipper is one of the most used fishing tools, why not add some class and tool-apprecation to your vest.So for the cost of a few lattes you can move up from your fingernail cutters to a precision instrument that would be home in a surgical theater as well as a blue ribbon stream.

For the size and price, this feature-packed weather station gives the right amount of info without a complex display requiring memorizing the instruction manual.My only complaint is that the indoor/outdoor lines list the humidity first (left) and the temp on the right. Look at the pic and you will see it is easy to mistake the humidity for the temperature.The 24 hour pressure trend is interesting.One other note, the backlighting leaves a little to be desired. The green LEDs illuminate the LCD display to the point some of the non-active LCD lines are visible making it a little difficult to see the active portions of the LCD which is the information you want to see. Hope that made sense.

Normally the charging handle blends into the background working day in and day out with no issues. So why mess with success? Because sometime even successful designs need help.Most operators are range bunnies who never push the limits of their gear. However, when things go south in an hurry, the charging handle moves front and center as the only way to move a round into battery, for working through a jam, and cycling the most important workings of the rifle.The design of the Raptor gives you the best chance for successful operation regardless of hand, palm, or stump operation. There are two critical levers that can not fail: the charging handle and the trigger. If your not pulling on one, then you're pulling on the other.Further the durability factor is important when cycling the action with whatever you have to work with. Things break. And they break faster when you are not careful. And if you need to be careful with it, then you need to leave "it" in the safe.For those choking on the price, think of it as only $50 more than a basic charging handle, and only $10 more than a BCM GUNFIGHTER Ambidextrous Charging Handle (5.56mm/.223) w/ Mod A44 (Ambi).So toss down the extra ten and move to the top of the food chain.

I have several MSR water filters and can usually get them for under $60. So that begs the question of why buy a filter for $40 when I can get an entire new filter pump and filter for $59. But when the price of the ceramic element drops to $29 which it does occasionally, then grab an extra one.Also, I highly recommend the MSR Sweetwater Siltstopper to extend the life of the ceramic element.
Other than being overbuilt, and a battery cover that required muscle, this little box rocks.If you can find these radios for $3 or less, buy several and put them anywhere you might need them.

Patriots was a mostly fun but occasionally tedious ride through one vision of the "Crunch." From what I understand, it was written as a survival field manual but in novel or storytelling form. While more entertaining than a field manual, it did require the tidbits of potential wisdom to be mined from a mildly shortsighted and narrow minded narrative. I'm sure the author would disagree, but given that the book folds over many years, few contributions are given to society at large by the main characters except some murderous assaults on evil gangs (of which the "good" shooters gloated a little too much given that they just killed a bunch of people based upon reports by others. Essentially the distopian justice dolled out by the book's heroes really provides a strong foothold for a future dictatorship in sheep's clothing.I certainly won't fault the author for trying to teach important skills while entertaining the audience, but there is actually an even better but intended message here that should be taken to heart: if there ever is a crunch event of some sort, the mindset of many will parallel that of the leaders in Patriots. Distilled, this means that there will be plenty of holier-then-thous running around dressed in camo and shooting those deemed less worthy--then grinning afterwards because they just scored more brownie points with their particular version of the afterlife.Luckily, the simplicity of the story and the writer's endless distraction with guns and acronyms has opened the window into viewing others who survived but have carved out much more noble and useful niches in the post-society. And while the major characters of the book are busy patting themselves on the back, others in the neighborhood are likely avoiding the "patriots" due to their penchant toward extreme violence, paranoia, and a deeply engrained attitude of shoot first and skip the questions.The highlighted militia followed in the book started the journey with quality preparedness, but post-event, they quickly devolved into self-anointed apostles who can kill without remorse, steal with justification (leaving useless cash is the same as stealing even if it does make the their feel better), and pretend to follow Jesus.So the take-aways of this book are really found in the vignettes and cameos we get from other non-militia survivors who run farms, show up at the barter fairs, and appear here and there along the countryside for it is within those other voices that we readers realize that the violent gun-worshiping "patriots" are actually a fungus that grows on the fringes of society and must be overcome or pacified before America can get back to business.Perhaps the characters in Patriots would be better served by reading a few history books rather than working on their CQB skills. Rawles makes it clear that there will always be plenty of room for mistrust, conspiracy theory even if there is no evidence, no facts, and no names attached to the so-called information.By the time the book fizzles out, it is clear that America can only survive if it models Germany in the 1920s. Huh? you ask. That's my point.

This is no normal backpack. Instead, it is a highly specific pack designed for the serious operator who demands a featureset that screams productivity under fire.It has surface features that would warm the hearts of any ordinary user, but also some options that might be problematic for the guy just wanting to play tacticool.The helmet pocket is a godsend for such needs; helmet, rope, coat, infant?? But unless you have a need for, or experience with such open so-called "beavertail" designs, the operation can be maddening. Some other reviewers have complained about the whole front-end of the pack flopping out upon release of the compression straps buckles, but remember two things...make that three. First, there are two strap clips designed to prevent such flop events but they do limit the helmet pocket activity. Second, the beavertail flexibility of this type of pack demands an aggressive and complete opening. So know what you are buying. And third, the only real problem is when the front pockets are unzipped and then the compression straps are released. So zip yer zipper.The water/drinking aspects are normal, and since this pack does not come with any hydration bladder, YMMV depending on your choice of water system.The strap system is first-rate and holds plenty of military clout when and where needed. The rest of the straps and adjustments and handles are effective and exactly what you would have done if you designed this pack for your needs. The compartmentalization works well for medium to lightly-heavy deployments. For an tactical laptop bag, this works wonderfully, but bring your own padded laptop sleeve. Also, The urban tech warrior will love the helmet pocket for the bicycle helmet or coat (down, suit, or other).The padded suspension yoke is perfect, and really comes alive when the pack is fully loaded and heavy. For the price, however, a waist belt, even a cheesy one, should have been included.The zippers are what really makes this a pack above others. Besides high-end hardware, One of the main access panel zippers, the one closest to your back, the zipper pulls run opposite of most other designs meaning you can dive into this pack with reckless abandon from any side. In other words, when the zipper is closed, the pulls are on opposite sides, not meeting on one end, the other, or in the middle. It's features like that that confirm that 5.11 loves us!Full bore hard core! When loaded for bear, this pack is a mobile command center, Red Cross office, or ambulance. What is not is a traditional bag you wear on your back. This is a special purpose tactical backpack with all the bells and whistles for a top-drawer BOB, GOOD bag, or disaster-based 72 hour kit. Regardless of your demographic, the AHP is not for the faint of heart, or for the uninitiated. It is as serious as a SBR or $300 survival knife. Lightweight players should steer clear since the AHP is overkill all the right directions. If you don't need or want to pay for the extra helping of tactical assistance 5.11 has pre-filled this pack with, then spend half a s much and get almost anything else.So do your homework. If you need this type of pack, then you need this pack.End of story.

I have several of these in all the sizes and love the color!This 20 is the optimum size for my needs with the 10 on the small side, and the 30 becoming a small bag.The zipper is a little rough at the start but a dozen swipes back and forth loosens things up. The belt attachment works fine. Could evolve a little by taking a nod from some military/spec ops designs. I say this because although I've never experienced a failure, I also have experience with better, stronger velcro designs.Did I mention that I love the color?

If you need a trailer like this, then this should be your only choice. While not without it's faults (cheap tire, rim, spokes hub), and should have come with a quick release rod, it still is by far the best in class.Strangely, the design limits of the clips should have evolved out of the BOB by now. It is a obsolete design that can easily cause a major failure far from a replacement. Sure you can carry spare parts, but think about it, what spare bike parts do you carry beyond a tube or two?On the ride side, this trailer tracks like it's on rails. The low center of gravity keeps loads stable and causes less lateral pull on the bike. The dry sak is meh at best. Now if it had a big waterproof zipper, then we'd be cooking with gas.

It's 1968 in this crime novel. Sam McCain is a lawyer that moonlights as a PI to pick up some extra cash. He's called out to a hippie commune outside Black River Falls, Iowa by the leader, Richard Donovan, for a matter he couldn't talk about over the phone. Sam had represented the commune a number of times in court(the sheriff was a bigot in addition to being incompetent and just plain stupid; not mention a nemesis of Sam's).He's shown a body in the barn, a young woman, the daughter of one of the richest men in town and he knows a s*** storm will hit the commune over this one. Everyone is sure who the killer is, Neil Cameron,a young man who had fallen for the young woman, a tease among the young folk of the town, and been rebuffed. A Viet Nam vet who came back a broken man over something that happened over there.Sam doesn't believe he did it, which puts him in the middle of opposing sides, as usual, as he continues to investigate the killing, and the others that come, much to the displeasure of the father, the sheriff, the folks who hate the commune(one completely nutty local radio preacher comes to mind).This was a good that is scheduled for release in October

Wonderfully written novel of a time period when I was just reaching adulthood(or at least I thought so at the time) and Mr. Gorman gets it all right, down to the smallest details. One almost feels as if there off to one side observing the action.Hippies, communes,, a murder which everyone knows the killer(or thinks they do). It's up to lawyer turned PI Sam McCain to get it all straight.Loved it.

Not the worst story I've ever read. But we have a stalker that's not really dealt with. The author seems to rely on "good Christian" feelings to resolve the situation. In light of some of the things going on in the world today, not a very realistic attitude.Disappointing.

Clay Randall was a pseudonym used by mystery writer Clifton Adams.Amos Flagg was sheriff of a small county in the Texas panhandle, based in a small town called Academy. With a permanent population of 400 that swelled when the trail herds stopped off for rest, recreation, and restocking, it was busy at those times esHeaded his way was a man he hadn't seen in twenty years, a man just released from prison. Gunner Flagg was his father, now sixty, long having abandoned Amos and his mother  a third of his life spent in prison.Amos hated him and didn't want him around, but as a lawman who to his job seriously, he couldn't force him to leave.Gunner had a plan, all that money sithing in the bank  and had convinced a couple of killers to throw in with him. One coward was already dead, goaded into a gun fight he didn't have a prayer of winning.But Amos wasn't going to allow it to happen. Father or no.Pretty good western.
A large soft towel with non skid backing that prevents slippage. Good grip 'reverse. The hand towel is perfect for drying the face and arms.

The Peregrine is back in a pair of stories, a novella where he gets involved with a range war of sorts, an old friend and his neighbor.But there's more going on as Coburn gets accused first of killing his friend, then the neighbor.The short story features Coburn and an old friend caught up in a con game.Richard writes of the early days of his native Nebraska with a sure hand.

While I make no claims at being an expert on all things Stephen King, I always thought I knew a fair amount about the author. But this volume disbursed me of that notion.A lot of fun and for the King purist.

I have a slight connection to this tale of madness in a local family. A respected physician, an aunt on North Carolina's highest courts, and a man's descent into madness.I can remember how it ended one afternoon about ten miles from home. Police following a van with Fritz driving, his woman and her children from her marriage aboard. The cops dared not fire on the van for that reason as Jenner would stop long enough to fire at the cops.Then the van exploded!Later learned the two children were shot in the backs of their heads(had to be the mother).All the more horrifying because it's true
Having a lot of fun with this one. Manning has always been a favorite and the idea of moving up levels is appealing.
The lady of the house doesn't use a lot of makeup. She thought this little box of various shades did the trick.Happy with it.

Easily assembled item, only a philips screwdriver needed. The car likes the ball hanging from the cord, not to mention the screen a matching post. One problem I see is when they get bigger. Kind of short for a full grown animal.

Somewhat unusual in that Stone and Freya have each a storyline dealing with family. Remo Williams is their father with different women.Great is back in her homeland, a chain of islands north of Scotland, participating in a ceremony that would restore her mother's honor. Stone wants to find his mother and is somewhat disappointed at what he finds.A story of family and honor.Outstanding.

This little gadget turned out to be even more useful than I'd imagined. You see, an episode with gout in my left wrist had pretty much wrecked my hand. Nerve endings gone in the fingertips, I can't even make a fist, make grasping a hard endeavor.These clippers, very slim and lock flat when not in use(a handy pouch contains them), they were easy to use in trimming the nails on my right hand.Never seen such a design before.

I got my tablet and been playing with it all day. After fully charging it, I went about segging it up. Because I am a klutz, it took me a bit to get the Wi-Fi going.But once that was out of the way, it has been smooth sailing. I run a blog a d getting that going was a priority. Still figuring stuff out and loving it.Quite pleased with my Galaxy Tab A.

Handy little pouch for the use of the handicapped. Pockets got hold various items for easy access. Got this one for my stepfather, he's ninety, and he loved it. He keeps a cell phone handy, as well as a small notepad and pencil.Great item.

Reporter Gordon Gardner thought he was getting the short end when he was assigned the hit and run death. It was because the boss was passed at him.Didn't take long before things changed. What with the dead man claiming the cars weren't real and jumping in front of one to prove it.Instinct told the reporter more was going on and, despite the newspaper's indifference, he pursues it with a vengeance.Scott Parker entertains us with another pre-WWII story set in Houston. He includes an unpublished pulp tale he came across while doing research which served as some inspiration for his own work. It was written by a fellow named Gordon Gardner.Liked both stories.
An early novel from the master, the tale of a piano player/junkie fighting to clear himself of Murfreesboro looking for that elusive fix. Pretty good crime story.

Jimmy the rabbit was the youngest of three brothers. He wanted to ride and race his bicycleg  just like his brothers.But his bike was small with training wheels. His brothers laughed at him.Dad didn't laugh though.This warm little book illustrates what a parent, dad in this case, can do to help a child learn and make his way in the world.Loved the artwork also

Tom Buchanan is out to find and kill the three man who shot his friend and business partner to pieces because he beat them in a poker game. That they had joined a larger bunch, thirty strong, didn't matter.They had to die!

I found the writing well done,  keeping the reader interested in the story.  That said, things didn't move with a lot of speed early on. Not dull by any means though. I put it down to being the author's first published work. Based on how the tale finished,  I know his work will get better as his career goes on.It's a story of identity theft and credit card scams with a dose of terrorism thrown in.Kris Storm is our heroine and works as a computer expert for her employer, tracing the various scams and terrorist activities they're hired to look into.Liked this one and will surely check out the next book.

I'm quite pleased with these night lights. Plug-ins at any outlet, they give out a nice glow, illuminating a nice size area.I got them for my parents. Mom's eighty-five, dad's ninety. They are prone to get up during the night and these lights give good illumination to, perhaps, prevent stumbling over furniture and falling.

Still trying to figure things out. Downloading music is fairly easy. The pictures I try to put in I get "doesn't support this format." That's okay. It is primarily for music anyway.Haven't tried films. Not hard, but probably not for me. The screen size is not my cup of tea.But music...

The best thing about this book was the mystery behind the murders. I've read more than one title in this genre where the vision of the piece was to obvious right at the beginning, sacrificed I believe for the romance part of the narrative. Not a problem here. I was guessing all the way. Nice couple of twists in the story. And the romance was there as well.And another good thing is it was set in my home state: North Carolina(the author's also).Recommended.

Handy little package. Each side has a zipper. One opens to a pocket obviously to hold cash. The other side has a number of sections to hold your various cards.I like that. It makes keeping up with your stuff a lot easier.

Gareth Havelock is town marshal of Vulture City, a man who walks with a limp because of a destroyed knee, the gift from the war shot by an old enemy.A hundred thousand in gold bars had been stolen by that old enemy, one Barnabas Donovan. Donovan is in jail, the gold has been hidden, and the Governor's daughter has been kidnapped to get Donovan released.Everyone wants the gold, Havelock wants Donovan, and the Marshal finds himself in a death race with Apaches wanting his life.Chuck Tyrell, pen name for Charles T. Whipped, gives us a fine novel that keeps the action rolling.

A novel of a byke race with a huge prize: Sky-Base and a life of luxury away from the drudgery of the mines. A course thousands of miles of waste lands, obstacle courses, traps,  the only weapon allowed a sling.And you'd need it. There were outlaws in the waste lands,  cannibals, wolves, and the other contestants.Adam Stone didn't plan to race originally. He had a byke, one his brother had rode until the accident had taken a leg. He wanted to stay for his brother. Then an enemy, Levi Blood, son of the Colonel and his Scorpions had attacked, leaving his brother dead!Revenge in mind. And winning the Race of course.Others in the race were Sadie Blood, sister of Levi, one Adam secretly loved, and the mysterious Kane, who'd helped Adam withers, saving his life, but was prone to disappear at times.Pretty good read with a couple of twists long the way.

Author Mark Ellis and artist Pablo Marcos give us a modern adaptation, a graphic novel, of the classic adventure tale from the nineteenth century.The story has been streamlined, omitting stuff unpalatable by today's standards, and added elements that stay true to the story.Recommended.

Ana and Miguel were partners, cops walking the best with a security drone flying overhead in one of the worst sections of Baltimore.Then one evening they find the body of a gray haired man, with bulging muscles, shot to death. Then another enhancer is found fighting a group, screaming they're coming after him.Someone is juicing the homeless, no one knows why, and Ana is determined to find out who and why.Promising beginning for the Black Market DNA series.Recommended.

Despite having been around for many years, I'd never tried Starburst candies before. Not sure then on packaging for the original, but these are small squares loose in a repeatable bag.I like the sweet taste, the texture of the candies, and the variety of flavors. The bag says unwrapped, which seems to be a trend in the candy business these days.Pretty good.

This is one terrific product. I have a love of spicy foods such that no one in my family will eat any dish I make.This Chile garlic sauce I've used in several ways. It makes a nice spread on grilled steaks. I've used it as a dip for diced and grilled boneless chicken breasts, and finally as an ingredient in my homemade chili. I have several other ideas that I'm planning to try. The large size bottle(77ozs) is not a problem. I don't see it lasting long.Then I'll just order more.

Raab Commoner and his wife Kayla are hired by Raab's old college baseball coach, now a major league manager headed to the World Series. He's being blackmailed over a stupid indiscretion and the stakes had been ramped up. It could ruin his reputation and kill his team's chances in the series. Not to mention ending his marriage.Then the young woman involved is murdered and the stakes get even higher.Author Richard David Bach knows how to keep the story moving with nice pacing and loads of action.Recommended.
A killer let out of jail to murder a man. Thing was his job had been dead two centuries. How do you kill someone like that?Why you use a time machine!
A group of tales and quotes lifted from  a larger work illustrating the benevolent side of Muslim life. Not at all what we are led to believe.

The latest Colton Banyon finds his team and him in Ecuador on the trail of the Orion Codex, a book that tells how to use the Orion weapons. German white supremacists want it as well, part of their plan to take over the country.Adventure, a bit of fantasy, hard hitting action, all hallmarks of the Colton Banyon novels.Recommended.

I'd never read any of Elisabeth Grace Foley's work before  this collection of six stories. I was quite impressed with what she's done with the tropes of the genre.There's a gunfight, threats of a range war, cattle rustling, family misunderstandings, stage build-up. Yet within those restrictions, she's given us well drawn characters doing things just slightly different from what one would suspect. I'm certainly going to check out some of her longer work.Highly recommended.

A story of love, love unrequited(at least early on), an Amish tale that could have been longer. Still a good tale of folks doing the unexpected, not moving in the right direction. Push comes to shove.Okay.

A fine little tale, a bit of post apocalypse, throw in a little spaghetti western(it's there), and a whole lot of weird western. A tale of the Professor, a bespectacled gunman that loved books in a world where they were primarily fire fuel.A world hit by plague long ago and still with flare-ups. Reverted to wild west levels.Had a good read with this one.
Wonderful combination of an old candy standard and the M and Ms company. Liked this candy a lot.Try it.
Opening.g portion of a longer story. It's incomplete, no resolution. Didn't care for that.There was promise in the storyline, just incomplete delivery in the final product.
Attractive pair of earrings, sturdy, and seemingly nice for that special woman. Would think they would enjoy them.

I'm a biologist. And I have a young daughter. I'd like to foster her interest in the natural world, and help her learn about the things around her. Including little things, like insects. This set is a good way to go about that. The bug vacuum isn't super powerful (I don't see any risk of danger), but strong enough to actually pick things up, including small to medium sized insects, without harming them. The switch that flips the door (magnifying glass) down on the chamber works well. Things won't escape until you want them to. It is a terrible magnifying glass however. Most kid toy ones are. I'd suggest a better one eventually, but this one isn't too bad to start with.The critter barn isn't bad either. It's a basic container for insects, or other small animals. It has a light, a built-in magnifier (low quality). The lid is easy to get on and off, which is good, because the little door thing might work to get things in, but out would be more difficult.An alternative to a set like this for older children might be getting actual entomology (insect study) equipment from a company like Bioquip, the same company scientists (like myself) order from directly to study small animals. For about the same amount of money, you could get a decent insect net, some vials, and equipment to start making a small insect collection.And whatever you do, don't forget a field guide. If you're going to have small critters in hand (or in a container), it's a very good idea to have a way to identify and learn about them. My favorite resource is currently the National Wildlife Federation Field Guide to Insects and Spiders & Related Species of North America. It's absolutely fantastic, and far better than the A Field Guide to Insects: America North of Mexico, Kaufman Field Guide to Insects of North America (Kaufman Field Guides), or National Audubon Society Field Guide to North American Insects and Spiders (National Audubon Society Field Guides). None of those are terrible, but the NWF guide is better, for all ages (plenty of pictures).

This is a quality wiper blade. That said, it's the standard, same-as-every-other-brand kind of wiper blade, and there's nothing all that special about it. Yes, it has the "Bosch" name on it, but it is bult quite similarly to every other wiper blade I've ever installed on my vehicle. Amazon's price on this is about nine bucks. I'd save your dough and look for something less expensive, like the ACDelco Advantage All Season Metal Wiper Blade, which I also recently installed, and which are fairly similar, for half the price. You'll be better served in the long run by replacing more often than you will by paying more for a name brand wiper blade.

This replaced an older Onkyo receiver that had a few issues, and didn't work like it should anymore. The first thing I noticed is that this one was significantly lighter in weight. That may not be a good sign, I always heard that heavy audio equipment meant quality components. I'm going to give Pioneer a pass on this and assume that maybe newer technology can be lighter without sacrificing quality. Maybe.I do wish this were a 7.1 or 7.2 unit rather than 5.2. My older receiver was a 7.2, which allowed me to bi-amp the front speakers in my 5.1 setup. Can't do that with this one. The sound quality is still fantastic though. I don't know for sure whether it's better than the Onkyo receiver I had, but it's certainly not any worse. I'm getting very good sound from this unit through my Polk speakers.Setup was as simple as these units can be. I tried out the setup app than can be used with the unit, and it walked me through the process easily enough. The only printed manual that came with the unit was a quick setup guide. It was helpful, I suppose, but limited. The receiver also came with a CD with the official user manual on it. I hate that. I would strongly have preferred a printed user manual rather than a file on out-of-date technology. Haven't bothered with the CD yet, and probably never will, unless I have a problem.The on-TV-screen menu system could use work. It looks terrible (graphics quality), but does what it needs to, I guess. Not quite as much customizability there as I would have hoped, so I may need to actually track down that user manual some day for some advanced features, but the receiver is giving me good sound when I want it to, for movies, TV shows, and listening to the (FM) radio. Which I guess is all I need it for. I may try out some of the more advanced features soon, I'll update my review if/when I do.

I like these ear muffs. They're more comfortable than some that I've tried, and work like they should. General sound gets passed through, while loud sounds (firearm fire, for instance) get blocked out. They're compact when folded up, and reduced in thickness at the bottom, which helps with rifles and shotguns (though I think the Howard Leight Impact Sport Earmuff is still a bit narrower, and also an excellent choice, for about the same price.The NRR isn't as high on these as on some of the bulkier ear muffs, so they may not be ideal for the loudest noises, but they're great for general purpose hearing protection. And you can always double up, wearing earplugs underneath if you need a bit more protection.

This is a good product, but an expensive one. It did a good job on all of the locks I've used it on, but so have other lubricants I've used that cost far less. The can is quite small, but it should last most people a long time, it doesn't take much to get your locks working smoothly. For most people though, is probably recommend a larger can of much less expensive all purpose lubricant.

I liked the idea of the game, but the implementation falls short in several areas. The dough is crumbly, and sticks to my carpet and the inside of the game box far better than the boards it is designed to be used with. It is also difficult to get out of the non-flexible fish molds, making it a frustrating experience.Game play is pretty straightforward, and easy  enough for children old enough to get it. Flip over cards. Three different fish types in a row and you get to squish a fish. When all of your opponent's fish are switched, game over.There's one problem with using fish. Now my daughter thinks all fish, including live ones, are for squishing. I wish the game were designed around a concept with a better message about how we interact with the natural world.I don't think this one will come down from the shelf too often.

I like this game. I'm a biologist, and I know a lot of animal nerds. Among this crowd, the game works. But for those with only a mild interest in the natural history of some of the greatest creatures on the planet... well, the game's weaknesses start to show. It's not fast paced, and not particularly fun. It doesn't have the playability of Settlers, and this isn't a game you're likely to come back to again and again once you've got the cards memorized. Cards Against Humanity is a different game each time, but this really isn't.Ideal audience: nature geeks, including and especially children. They don't tend to tire of it as quickly.

This is my fourth Android device, and the only one of the four that I want to use ever again. The other three (one phone, two tablets) have all become frustratingly slow. This G4 blows them all away. The screen is big enough that I don't miss using my tablets (7 and 8"). It's larger than my other phone, but still fits in my pocket just fine, and is an excellent size. The resolution is amazing, and everything displayed on the device is sharp and crisp, with plenty of detail. Colors are good. Perhaps a bit oversaturated, but vibrant and good-looking (I'm a professional photographer, so this is important to me). And there's no lag at all when using the phone. Since this is the flagship device from a major phone manufacturer, it has everything: dual cameras (and nice ones at that), flashlight, scratch-resistant glass (slightly inwardly curved, too), auto-dimming screen, excellent audio quality, advanced bluetooth features, dual band WiFi, etc.My only cons:I wish this phone came with a manual. There were no instructions in the box besides a little quickstart sheet, which wasn't very helpful. I guess that's why I have Google. Still... some features are not intuitive, like how to shoot raw images with the phone. Still need to figure that out.The charger is shaped a bit weird. Sticks out farther than I'd like from the plug. And it's white. I'd prefer black.I have the leather version, and while I like it now (looks great, and it's reasonably 'grippy'), I'm not sure I'd choose that one. The stitching isn't likely to last indefinitely with moderate use, and it's less cleanable than other options. It is nicely made, though.Anyway, this is clearly one of the very best phones available right now, if you can afford it.

While these aren't the thickest towels I've seen, they're decent, and absorbent. I like the colors, and they make a nice general purpose kitchen towel. I also like the towels I've acquired from Ikea, which were about half the price, so I guess these could be cheaper, but they're not a bad choice at all.

It's hard to review a product like this. What I can say is that I like the product packaging. The long neck on the bottle makes the additive fairly easy to get into the engine. I wish there were a better way of measuring, since I didn't have to add the whole bottle at one oil change. There are no measurement markings on the bottle at all.Did I notice a difference in the way my engine ran, or sounded? Nope. Am I 100% convinced that a stabilizer like this one is necessary (or even helpful)? Nope. There is evidence that oil additives beyond those already in the oil itself might do more harm than good, as another reviewer pointed out. I'm guessing a decent oil will be a better investment in the long run than regularly adding products like this one to oil. I like Valvoline 782256 MaxLife SAE 5W-30 High Mileage Motor Oil - 5 Quart for my older car.

Like most Perky-Pet products, this item doesn't feel like it's built all that well. Good enough, but cheap. I don't expect it to last forever. But it does what it should: sticks to my window, holds seed (black oil sunflower is the best general choice for most birds), and... well... it's clear? That's about it. There was a little bit of "assembly" required snapping in the feeding ports, but it took less than a minute, and the instructions were pretty clear. I made sure to clean my window and the included cheap-feeling suction cups well before installation, and that part went fine. The suctions cups seem to support the weight of feeder, plus seed, plus visiting birds, so they're good enough for now. It did take birds a while to find it, but that's based on placement location, and is to be expected of any feeder. I also have the Birdscapes Clear Window Feeder 348, and think I like this one better, as the main body of the feeder slides out and away from the window for easier filling. That Birdscapes one is much tougher to remove for filling, and is intended to be filled in place, which isn't as easy.Anyway, it works.

The anatomy part, I like. The drawings are fine, and yes, external anatomy is present in this anatomy toy. I would not think highly of an educational anatomy toy that did not properly display human anatomy. If you feel that children should not be exposed to facts and reality (and their own body parts), then I would suggest you re-evaluate your own beliefs, not these items.The magnetic part on each layer is thin, and not very good. Layers do not stick to each other well. And the thin tagboard used to make most of the layers isn't exactly 'wood'. I wouldn't expect this toy to be able to withstand much abuse, so I'd suggest it for older children less likely to damage things.Anyway, it's a good way to teach children about what's on their 'insides', including bones, muscles, organs, etc.

At twenty bucks a piece, this is not your cheapest cloth diapering option, but it's certainly a good one. This diaper is about as adjustable in size as they come, but that doesn't mean it'll work for your tiny newborn. For the smallest kids, I'd suggest a smaller diaper, like the Thirsties Duo Wrap Diaper Cover with Hook and Loop,Size 1, or something else small that doesn't tell you it'll fit all kids.This is my first all-in-one for my daughter. Most cloth diapering I've done has been with a separate diaper cover and a diaper insert (I love the OsoCozy Prefolds Unbleached Cloth Diapers, in both sizes). This one saves a step, but is a bit less customizable (I typically use a smaller insert during the day, and a thicker one at night, for instance). You can still add another insert with the one already attached to this diaper, but it's already fairly bulky.The velcro used is good, but I do prefer snap closures, which I think tend to last longer and attach more securely.Stitching, materials, and everything else is nice. Definitely a step up in quality (and price) from the chinese diapers I've stocked up on from that big auction site. A good choice, if you like the all-in-one design, prefer velcro over a snap closure, and have enough money to get a sufficient quantity of these.

These work fairly well, and seem well constructed. They hold quite a bit of liquid (didn't have any problems making it through the night without leaks with my two-year-old. I like the sustainable sourcing of materials and 'eco' nature of the product. The size 5 pull-up design worked well on my 28lb toddler. They're expensive though.

I've had an older-model Kitchenaid classic for a few years that gets somewhat regular use, and this has more than replaced it. Honestly, the mixer part is about the same, though I think the Kenwood has a better/stronger motor. Where this unit really shines is the all-in-one performance it gives. The mixer is great. The blender is great. The food processor is great. And the whole package takes up only the space of the mixing unit, it's not really any bigger than my Kitchenaid mixer.Build quality is solid, everything feels well made. The two small changes I might want, and where Kitchenaid still has an advantage over it, are the following: I wish the handle on the mixing bowl were more useful, and vertically-oriented like the new Kitchenaid bowls. Also, the design of the Kitchenaid splash guard thing allows it to be removed without removing the attachment in use, while with this one, that isn't possible. Could lead to a messy situation if it needs to be removed in the middle of a project.Oh, and when they say not to store mixer attachments in the bowl, they really mean it. I forgot I had them in there while testing out the food processor, and since the mixer spins at the same time, it really mangled the whisk, and scraped some metal off of the bowl itself. Oops. Not sure whether I should count that as a strike against the product or not. It was my fault, but it would be nice if the other parts of the device were disengaged when you were using a different one.Still... overall, the product is great, and a welcome addition to my kitchen.

This book meshes with much of what I know of addiction and recovery, and is helping me deal with a few of my emotional issues. I like the author's writing style. It's easy to follow> Occasionally it seems that it might be filled with just a bit too much biographical information, but the book is also filled with solid advice, from a variety of therapeutic modalities. I appreciate the solid grounding in the 12 steps combined with mindfulness meditation and a few other things that research is showing are very promising for helping people deal with addictions of all kinds.

I'm not sure what brand my prior file folders were, but they're just about the same, minus the "Mead" name printed inside the folder of these ones. They are of adequate quality, and there's nothing wrong with them, but they're also not made of magical unicorn paper, so it's just a commodity. If you find a cheaper price on a different brand, I'd say go with the lower price.

Well, I'm not sure what I was expecting, but this is the thinnest, worst magnetic sheet I've ever seen. Super thin. I guess that makes it easier for printers to handle (that part went fine), but it's barely sticking to my fridge, so I wouldn't recommend it. Besides that, every sheet in the package (yes, all three of them) is significantly warped, so that individual business card magnets will not lie flat against a surface. Unprofessional, and not worth purchasing. My preferred solution: adhesive magnet sheets I got from a popular auction site that are pre-cut in business card size. You just peel the adhesive, stick your bunsiness card squarely on there, and it's done. Good solution for small quantities, and not any more work than this option.

This is my second mattress of this type. The first, a Signature Sleep Contour 8-Inch Mattress, Queen, is the one I sleep on. This new one, a twin, is for guest bed use and for my toddler as she outgrows her smaller bed.Pluses:First, the fact that it's delivered to your home (in basically a large duffel bag, inside a huge box), and offers such a neat 'unwrapping' experience. Yeah, it's fun. The mattress quality is actually surprisingly good. The bed fluffs up without a problem, and it's not as wimpy or spongy as you might think. Actually, not at all. It's a mattress, and feels like one. This twin mattress is a significant step up from the cheap 'bunk bed' and discount store bargain mattresses. It's supportive, a decent weight, and feels great to lie down on, even for us normal-sized human beings. The wrapped coils are nice, and noticeable (in a good way... motion isolation).Minuses:Two things I can think of: one, like most mattresses (all?), it'll sag a bit over time. I don't think this style is worse than any other, but expect it to have a shallow depression after a few months to a year. Flipping and rotating the mattress will help with that. Also, due to the way these mattresses are packaged and delivered,the sides/edges cannot be reinforced like they are in some other nice mattresses. So, the edges have some 'give' to them, which you might feel when sitting on the edge. Not really a big deal, since you don't sleep on the very edge, and this particular mattress (unlike my queen mattress) has stronger, more supportive coils at the sides to deal with this issue, which is a plus for this one. This one also features respectable 13 gauge springs (my queen: 15 ga), which should help with both of these potential 'negatives'.Overall, I think it's a great mattress for the price. Yes, you could probably get something better if you were willing to shop around locally and pay FAR more, but in this price range, I'm not sure it can be beat for value.

When Barilla pasta was made in Italy, it was awesome, as all Italian pastas are (and must be, since the Italian government takes their pasta seriously). Several years back, Barilla started being made in the USA, and  quality immediately dropped, so it's basically the same stuff you get with any other brand now. That said, it's not horrible pasta, it's just not really good pasta either, and not worth a premium price.This whole grain pasta was interesting. Basic spiralled rotini. The whole grain flavor was mild, and decent. I do like the idea of making pasta from whole grains, I'd like to pretend it makes it better for me. Which it probably does, a little, thanks to the added fiber. The Amazon price is typically a bit higher (up to double) what you'd pay for the same product in your local supermarket, so there's definitely a price premium for ordering on Amazon. Still, it might be worth it if you can't get to a supermarket regularly.

I liked this book. It's a great inside look at the life of a Sea World orca trainer, including how he got there, his experiences while there (of all kinds: with the animals, with other trainers, with the public, and with Sea World corporate-types). It also offers a special insight into the minds of the whales, as told by the type of person that knows them best, having spent more time interacting with orcas than anyone else.The book is well written, easy to read, and pretty engaging. If you're at all interested in orcas, it's definitely one to add to your library.

When Barilla pasta was made in Italy, it was awesome, as all Italian pastas are (and must be, since the Italian government takes their pasta seriously). Several years back, Barilla started being made in the USA, and  quality immediately dropped, so it's basically the same stuff you get with any other brand now. That said, it's not horrible pasta, it's just not really good pasta either, and not worth a premium price.This plus pasta was interesting. The elbows were twisted, and had little stripes down the side. I liked that, as it gave them a better texture than a typical macaroni. The 'plus' flavor was mild, and decent. I do like the idea of throwing healthy stuff into the pasta itself, since sometimes I don't dress it up all that much, and like to pretend it makes it better for me. Which it probably does, a little. The Amazon price right now gives you seven pounds of pasta for about fourteen bucks, or about two dollars a pound. Which is twice as much as the same stuff in the store when on sale. Definitely a price premium for ordering on Amazon, which might be worth it if you can't get to a supermarket regularly.

When Barilla pasta was made in Italy, it was awesome, as all Italian pastas are (and must be, since the Italian government takes their pasta seriously). Several years back, Barilla started being made in the USA, and  quality immediately dropped, so it's basically the same stuff you get with any other brand now. That said, it's not horrible pasta, it's just not really good pasta either, and not worth a premium price.This veggie pasta was interesting. The rotini was made with spinach and zucchini. The vegetable flavor was mild, and decent. I do like the idea of throwing veggies into the pasta itself, since sometimes I don't dress it up all that much, and like to pretend it makes it healthier. Which it probably does, a little. The Amazon price right now gives you six pounds of pasta for about fifteen bucks, or about two-fifty a pound. Which is two and a half times as much as the same stuff in the store when on sale. Definitely a price premium for ordering on Amazon, which might be worth it if you can't get to a supermarket regularly.

I've worked in a restaurant in the past, but tested this product in a home environment. Coming in a #10 can, it's clearly intended for the foodservice industry. Chef-Mate makes about half a dozen different cheese sauces, and this isn't the one I'd pick if I were to get it again. The product is rather bland, without much flavor. While that does allow you to add your own seasonings, I didn't find it ideal. I wanted something I could use directly (to just stir it in with pasta and have mac and cheese, for instance). That didn't work out so well until I added some extras. The literature that came with the product suggested that their "Golden Cheese Sauce" might be a better fit for my needs. It doesn't seem to be listed on Amazon at the moment, though.If you're going to dress it up with other seasonings, it might work well for your needs. On its own, likely not so much.

This company is just getting off the ground, so things may get better in the future, but here's my experience:The blocks are too big for easy use on 7 and 8" tablets, which is what I used it on. On a 7" tablet, there's only one way the 5-unit toy can be placed on the screen (diagonally, across the whole thing). For younger kids, this will be thoroughly annoying, as it likely won't register correctly on the device.The toys don't always register correctly even when they are placed on the screen in an appropriate location. Multiple times, we had them come up as the wrong numbers, possibly because the entire surface of the toy didn't contact the electronic device simultaneously. Wanna teach your kids bad math?
