They see whales, observe the plants of the desert surviving brutal drought, observe birds over the entire trip, their favorite being the cheeky chickadee, have adventures along the Mexican border, then head into snow and ice storms as they drive toward the northeast, where they hunt for diamonds, discover a colony of white squirrels, explore Big Bone Lick and its cache of prehistoric bones, visit a sugarbush and a deer yard, and join a man who collects witch hazel. Along the way, they visit fellow naturalists, avid birdwatchers, and the home of "Snowflake" Bentley, who took the first microscopic photos of snowflakes.This is a wonderful book for anyone who loves exploring the natural world, whether in person or vicariously through books. I'm hoping to turn up his other three books to visit the seasonal US in an era before superhighways.

Lady Julia Grey and her husband, investigator Nicholas Brisbane, are once again home in London, with Julia trying to persuade him to make her a more active partner in his cases. She is stunned to find him working for her impeccable eldest brother Bellmont, the stolid "white sheep" of the erratic March clan. When she discovers a connection to the celebrated spiritualist Madame Seraphine, Julia's foray in investigating on her own only leaves her trapped in Madame's homeonly to find her husband hiding there as well.The story starts out a bit predictably with Julia's experiments and the expected bantering with Brisbane, whose reluctance for her to participate in investigations still persists despite promises made to her in the previous novel. This is growing a bit tiresome, but at the end of the novel it appears it may have been resolved. One can only hope. My favorite part was the sequence with the gypsy camp, and the mystery was excellent. Several old favorites appear, including Julia's headstrong father, her sister Portia still doting over her former lover's child, and her younger brother Plum, whose growing attraction to a young woman brings out another aspect of the mystery. Sometimes Julia, and Brisbane, the  stalwart moody Victorian hero, are both over the top, but they're fun to read. Remember that this is a cozy mystery with romantic interruptions and it should work fine for you.

A book about colonial Boston and its role in the Revolutionary War. How could I resist? The narrative opens in 1760, with an account of the Great Fire, and ends with the reading of the Declaration of Independence. In between there are Stamp Acts, acts of rebellion, and "the shot heard 'round the world."My favorite part of this book are the descriptions of everyday Bostonthe sights and sounds and smells of the streets, tar, ocean breeze, livestock, the hammers and squeaks of pulleys and shouting from the waterfrontand the people who lived there, from the poor apprentices at the wharfs to the solid working people to the opulent rich like John Hancock. Populated by the characters of the Revolution you know (Samuel Adams, John Adams, Paul Revere, Israel Putnam, Joseph Warren) and ones you probably don't (Samuel Prescott, William Dawes, Josiah Quincy, Robert Newman, Mercy Otis), it's a vivid narrative of the passions of the opening salvo of the Revolutionary War. A super epilogue follows up on the fates of all the people, and some of the places, mentioned, including the Tories forced out of the city after the British evacuation. At times a bit wordy, but readable and absorbing.

In this last of the Monk television adaptations by Goldberg, Adrian Monk's life seems to be going fine. While his former assistant Natalie Teeger is still in New Jersey, trying to decide if life as a police officer in the little town of Summit is for her, her daughter Julie is helping Monk with his cases, and Monk's agoraphobic brother Ambrose is marrying his ladylove Yuki (see MR. MONK ON THE ROAD). Monk even has a girlfriend now, but that's the problem. When some of his theories don't pan out, he feels like his happiness may be losing him his edge in solving crimes. Then to add tension to the perpetually tense detective, his mortal enemy "Dale the Whale" is being transferred from prison to hospital for surgery. When Dale escapes, it's Monk's good friend Captain Stottlemeyer who gets the blame.Goldberg neatly ties up all his own plot threads before leaving the book series to be taken over by Hy Conrad, including the return (no spoileryou knew it had to happen) of Natalie. I'd figured out some aspects of Dale's part of the crime about halfway through the book, but it was great to see Natalie now as a partner, and for Ambrose's happiness to be complete. No goofy jokes in this one, just a satisfying conclusion.

Lady Georgiana Rannoch, 35th in line to the British throne but nevertheless pretty much impoverished, faces a bleak Christmas at the family castle with her affable brother "Binky," her martinet sister-in-law "Fig," and Fig's equally martinet mother, who just wish Georgie to be married off and out of their hair. So Georgie hires herself out to a wellborn woman who wishes to have help throwing a Christmas house party, only to find out the guests are tourists looking for a "traditional English Christmas," and when she arrives at the home, there are police everywhere because the family's neighbor has been shot.This was an enjoyable edition of the "royal spyness" series, even though the methodology of the criminal is obvious to anyone who's listened to years of Christmas music (except, apparently, everyone involved in the mysteryso much for knowing "old English customs"!), and all the Americans are boorish. The combination of country house mystery and Christmas is irresistible, and Georgie is one of my favorite cozy characters. Georgie's self-absorbed mother reappears, working on a play with Noel Coward, and her down-to-earth, charming Cockney grandfather also becomes involved in the mystery.

Miss Gwen's (see PASSION OF THE PURPLE PLUMARIA) bestselling new book, a Gothic thriller called THE CONVENT OF ORSINO, has Society all a-twitter about vampire stories. Sally Fitzhugh, younger sister of "Turnip," is intrigued when she hears the rumor that the Duke of Belliston is a vampire and takes a dare to check out his garden, where she comes face-to-face with a less-than-vampiric duke himself, who nevertheless has returned to England under a cloud of suspicion, as it has been long since believed he murdered his own parents. At a glittering society party, Sally is with him when he discovers a woman's body with marks on her neck as if she's been attacked by a vampire.This is a lighter entry, and, alas, the next to the last entry, in Willig's Pink Carnation series. As MISCHIEF OF THE MISTLETOE was a Christmas entry, this is a Hallowe'en one, and has some funny bits between Sally and her "vampire beau" Lucien (not to mention the presence of Sally's pet, a stoat), but it's a lightweight effort before we get to the conclusion involving the Carnation herself, Miss Jane Wooliston, who has gone off on her own, and the black sheep of the Reid family, Jack. Meanwhile, on the Colin/Eloise front, some big surprises are in store. Enjoyable froth, some suspense near the end, but not the cream of the crop.

As a native Rhode Islander, a mystery set in 19th century Newport, Rhode Island, was irresistible to me. Our heroine Emma Cross is a second cousin to the Vanderbilts, alas, with none of the money. She makes ends meet by writing dull society columns for the local newspaper; the only type of reporting her editor thinks is fit for a woman to do, even though Emma would like more of a challenge. But while reporting about a party at the Vanderbilt "summer cottage" the Breakers, Emma is a witness to the murder of Cornelius Vanderbilt's financial secretary, and, even worse, her black sheep brother is blamed for the death. Emma knows feckless Brady can't be the murderer, but who is? Could it even be one of her cousins, people she grew up with, played with as children, and still sees socially as an adult?I'll probably end up buying the next book in the series just because of the setting, but I really didn't believe in Emma as a 19th century heroine. Certainly there were forward-thinking women in those days, but she sounds more like a 20th century woman playing Victorian heroine. I was also disappointed with a main subplot; why make our heroine a self-sufficient working girl and then immediately introduce a love interest? But it takes place in Newport and I...simply...can't...resist...

Yep, it's a book about math. Yep, *me* reading a book about math. Bizarre, because I despise mathematics. Not only did I read it, I enjoyed most of it, although my old bete noire algebra struck againeven with Bellos' amusing and simple explanations, I still didn't understand the algebra, and the statistics chapter was just as bad. Yet I was enthralled by the chapter about plane and solid geometry and Pythagorean proofs. I was so delighted by one of the latter that I had to interrupt my husband in the midst of his own reading and show him the drawing. There are chapters, predictably, on pi, the Golden Ratio, magic squares and other math puzzles, gambling odds, and bell curves. Other chapters discuss different societies' ways of numeration, math tricks including Vedic mathematics, number sequences, data collection, and infinite numbers, and we learn about people who play with these numbers, some just for fun, others for a living.I hate math, but I loved this book. I can hardly wait for to read the sequel. Now there's an improbability, even if not mathematical!

The Doctor negates Clara's wish to see King Arthur and instead takes them to 19th century London where a unique power spike impossible in Victorian times has just occurred. Despite the Doctor not wanting to bother the Paternoster Gang, they meet Jenny Flint almost immediately; she is searching for a man who was about to seek Madame Vastra's help and then died by mysterious means. Strax is also on a search, for whomever killed his sparring partner, a pugilist named Bellamy. Very soon, the five of them realize the mystery revolves around the Carnival of Curiosities performing at the Frost Fair, and particularly with a shadow play performer named Silhouette.I'll assume Richards was given copies of the early 12th Doctor scripts and perhaps an outline of where the character was going; he hasn't quite captured the eccentricities of Capaldi's Doctor, but it's getting there. The villain of the piece is pretty typical of what's been on the series before (going back to the classic series as well), but the suspense is well done and Clara's newfound spunk is in full bloom. The story has a "Weng-Chiang/Fang Rock" atmosphere about it that will please fans of the old series, and I found I enjoyed this more than I expected, and more than I have of books based on the previous incarnations in the new series. Strax in particular has some very funny lines. I'd like to see this as an episode of the series!

In this second of the Celebration Bay cozy mysteries, town events' manager Liv Montgomery is overseeing what plans to be the most beautiful Christmas the town has known. The square will be nostalgically dressed for the holiday season and all sorts of events are planned, but there's one fly in the ointment: the tacky new Christmas shop that has opened right on the square, spoiling its cozy nostalgia with windows festooned with drunken reindeer, beer-belly Santas under palm trees, and other tacky and inappropriate decorations, with the proprietor a grumpy Scrooge of a woman. Just when the town inhabitants think things can't get any worse, the man the owner of the Christmas shop hired to play Santa Claus has his throat cut in the store during the town Christmas parade.Freydont populates her town with people you'd love to know: the friendly bakery owner who cooks delicious treats (even for Liv's West Highland White terrier), the gregarious coffee shop owner, the nurturing quilt shop owner, the ex-hippie natural gift shop proprietor, a friendly good ol' boys club of a town council, two darling elderly ex-schoolteachers, Liv's 60-ish assistant Ted who has daily "singing" bouts with Whiskey the terrier, the bewhiskered older man who always plays Santa Claus so well, one bitchy ex-events' manager (well, there had to be one unfriendly person in town), and even a sexy but usually diffident newspaper editor. The mystery is reasonably convoluted (although you know the nice people who are accused can't possibly be guilty of the crime), the Yuletide atmosphere so Christmassy it will make you hear jingle bells and shiver against the chill, and personal attractions begun are continued.Readers of police procedurals and Nordic noir, take note: this isn't your bag, but if you're the type of person who likes cozies and Christmas, this book will be perfect for your holiday reading. It even ends up with a meal so luscious it will make you hungry, and some mistletoe. Enjoy!

Sadly, Patterson passed away just weeks before this second part of his biography of Heinlein was published.Like the first volume, Patterson has filled the book with so many miniscule details of Robert Heinlein's later life (after his marriage to Virginia Gerstenfeld) that you wonder if he was a fly in the corner during the entire period of time. We follow the development of the Future History stories, go to Hollywood for the filming of DESTINATION MOON (whose fate was tied up with another movie about, believe it or not, a squirrel), build a home in Colorado and cope with fallout from Heinlein's ex-wife Leslyn, travel along with the Heinleins to Russia, Australia, and even Antarctica, observe the long development of STRANGER IN A STRANGE LAND, understand Heinlein's support for blood drives after a transfusion saves his life, and finally follow his long slow slide into ill health as he aged. Patterson's approach seemed warmer in this volume and I didn't feel as if I was being held at arm's length as I was in the first half. Heinlein fans will definitely enjoy this concluding volume. God bless, Mr. Patterson.

This is one of four books in which naturalist Teale and his wife Nellie travel across the United States during one of the seasons and observe wildlife and ecosystems. While most fall volumes concentrate on leaf coloration and homely pursuits that include pumpkins, winter vegetables, and animals preparing for hibernation, the Teales' track starts in New England and then takes a meandering way westward through Michigan, the upper Plains states, dip down to the Great Salt Lake, go north to Oregon and end up in Northern California, both at the shore and inland, all done in the days before the interstate. They discover unique bird species, find the places where the butterflies stop over on their migrations, tour the redwood forests, view the autumn sky from a homemade sky-watching station, investigate the roamer of the plains (the tumbleweed), see migrating salmon, discover pikas and fern farmers, and even tell the story of a man's arduous multi-month search for his beloved dog lost in the wilderness. These books are a must for anyone who enjoys reading about wildlife and natural habitats, and there are great views of road travel before the superhighways. Like a virtual nature hike. Enjoy!

I bought this for events like outdoor craft shows and festivals so I could stop and sit down when my husband took a break with his walker. I admit I hate carrying it around, but I hate carrying anything around. This is a nice, sturdy seat; I've used it to sit on when we stopped to eat and, while it will never rival a regular chair, it's a good seat when they are in short supply. Very light to carry.

This is my second Bracketron purchase, the first having been from Radio Shack. I'm sorry to give poor Radio Shack even less business by not buying my replacement unit there, but really--$35 at Radio Shack, only $12 on Amazon? I'm saving for retirement here, guys, give me a break.Anyway, I like this unit because it works on my air vent rather than having it dangling from or standing on a suction cup. I know through bitter experience how quickly these suction cups lose their suction; I'm not risking breaking a $200 smartphone. I plug my phone into the power cord, wire it for sound, and while I'm using the GPS listen to podcasts or music. With a little finagling, it's just on the correct angle to see with a quick glance while you're driving. Using voice commands I can make a phone call without having to take my hands off the steering wheel. Waze guides me through traffic. Rick Steves keeps me entertained. I love my Bracketron.

I got this tablet to put on the stand of an exercise bike so I could watch Netflix and Amazon Prime and listen to my google music library while working out. I already have plenty of other devices for the more typical uses of a mobile device.In reality, this is probably a 4-star tablet, but I am giving it 5 stars, because it's unfair and counterproductive to hold it up against products costing three or four times as much, such as an iPad. It'd be like docking a Toyota Corolla a star for not being as nice as a BMW.I think I have a good frame of reference for judging the Lenovo, in that I am a long-time Android tablet user, with two Nexus tablets and a drawer full of Amazon devices in the house. As I type this review, I am sitting here with a Nexus next to the Lenovo. A new Nexus 10 is $450, against the Lenovo's $180. So let's keep that in mind: the Lenovo A10 is 40 % of the cost of a Nexus. With that said:- The only thing that seems hugely different and inferior to me about the Lenovo is the case. It is flimsy, flexible plastic and I would not want to test it with an accidental drop from arm height; I don't think it'd survive. It really does feel cheap. Then again, it IS cheap. If you're looking to carry it around and actually work on it (as opposed to what I'm doing, basically keeping it in one place, where it's not going to get banged around), I'd recommend a solid/hard cover or case.- The screen is very nice. Color saturation is too high for my tastes but others might like it. I don't think the screen is quite as sharp as the Nexus, but it's still light years ahead of the SD screens on other budget tablets. It's 1920x1080, not the 1200x800 ish resolution of most of the competition. BIG difference.- I see some complaints in the reviews about WiFi connection, but I have had no issues with this. WiFi has been very reliable, and there is no lag or stuttering while streaming movies.- I also see some complaints about the sound, but I don't share that view. I think the sound is quite good -- in fact, as good as the Nexus, and louder. I saw some reviews complaining about the volume being too low. Maybe they fixed that in between those reviews and my buying it, because mine seems plenty loud. It was kinda dumb of them to put the speakers on the rear of the unit, but actually, somehow those speakers manage to project enough clear sound to be enjoyable, even when the unit is resting flat against something that blocks them.- I haven't tested it hard, with multiple demanding apps running. For the basic stuff that 99 % of people would do with a tablet - watch some movies, do email, chat, surf - it seems adequate. Apps open pretty fast, things are smooth on screen, no real complaints. It certainly isn't as zippy and snappy as a Nexus, or iPad, or other high-end tablet. It's a bit slower. You can see it in the load times when opening an app or getting a new movie to start up, and so on. But it's a minor lag, not an annoyingly huge one.In all, I think Lenovo has put together a compelling little package: a tablet with mediocre (but not terrible) horsepower and low-end exterior casing, but with a very nice, large, true HD screen and good sound, for a truly rock-bottom price. I am giving it the full 5 stars because when you compare it to other tablets in its price range, it is truly a 5 star product. But I want to add the important caveat that in no way can it be compared to a $450 Nexus or an iPad or other high-end tablet. It is what it is, a budget tablet with a really nice, clear HD screen.Based on the research I did, the only serious competitor was Amazon's own Fire HD. I compared them side by side in a retail store, and frankly, the Fire HD felt nicer - better build quality, much nicer casing. For me, it came down to wanting a clean, true Android experience, instead of the Amazon OS. I'm just used to pure, undiluted Android, from using Nexus tablets -- for example, all of my purchased apps are in the Google Play store, which the Amazon OS can't access. If I was more of an Amazon content consumer / Kindle guy, I'd have probably gone with the Fire. I think the Fire is nicer to hold and look at. That said, there is a lot of criticism of the Fire as far as wifi, reliability, software crashing, slow, etc, whereas the Lenovo is providing a stock Android experience, which is pretty reliable and proven at this point.

Got this desktop about 3 weeks ago. It's extremely quiet - I can barely hear it at all. It's very intuitive and easy to set up. Works perfectly with my new HP 27" monitor. I trust HP. I know that's kinda stupid, since all the tech companies are sourcing their gear from the same suppliers and pretty much the same near-slave laborers, but I've always had good luck with HP equipment. I've got the same smartphone, laptop, tablet, blah blah, as everyone else, but there is still something to be said for a big, beefy desktop tower with a gazillion USB 2.0 and 3.0 and other ports, plenty of expansion space for future needs, a wicked fast i7 processor, a decent graphics card, and all the rest of the goodies. I am a big fan of Win 7 and will be the last person to give up the ghost and switch over to an inferior new Microsoft product, and there aren't that many boxes out there still being sold with Win 7. I did a ton of research before settling on this Envy box. For folks new to HP as a possible solution to their gear needs, keep in mind that ENVY is their higher end box; Pavillion and just "HP" are the lower end. You want to spend the extra $150 or whatever to get the Envy.

Great little speaker for the money. I compared them side by side with a couple other cheapo PC speakers we have, and the sound was generally better. Tight, crisp highs, clear midrange, and considering the diminutive size, pretty good sounding bass. One thing I especially like about them is that they do not artificially color the sound too much to make up for the size; some small PC speakers have a kind of odd hollowed-out area in the mid range from either base enhancement or the engineers' effort to create too much wide stereo effect. These sound pretty flat, like the source audio is supposed to sound. Of COURSE you are not going to get the kind of bass or fullness of sound that you'd get out of a 2:1 setup or a larger speaker, so don't expect that. For casual Youtube, web surfing, and occasional music listening while you work, these are really, really good. Would they be satisfactory as your main music listening speakers? Come on, that is not what these are for. For that, you have to spend a lot more money, at least 3x the price. For this price, these are solid 5 stars. I do think these are most effective at low or medium listening levels, and their limitations show up as the volume is increased, as is going to be the case in any speaker of this size. So just to reiterate the point, these are for casual listening while you're working or surfing, not for hi-fidelity music appreciation or shaking the walls of the house. For their intended purpose, they are excellent.

I truly wasn't happy about spending so much money on cat litter, especially after all these years of spending $4 per huge bag for standard litter at the grocery store. But we've had a cat who for two years had been getting progressively less regular about urinating in the box. As the smell and mess of cat pee gradually took over our house, getting into the hardwood floors and all over our couches and bed, we lashed out in desperation with every possible thing we could think of. Nothing worked. As we contemplated taking the kitty to the vet for antidepressants or something, my wife took a last look around the web for yet-another-thing we could try. And she stumbled onto this product.Bottom line: it works. We've been using it for about a month, and during that time, there has only been one minor "incident", easily cleaned up, on about the 4th day. So maybe the feline wasn't yet fully with the program. Since then, she has been, 100 %.Do I despise spending so much money on what is probably $4/bag cat litter with a little catnip thrown in? Yes, yes I do. About as much as I regret not coming up with such brilliant business idea. Nevertheless, the stuff *does* work and it's saving a whole house worth of furniture and floors, and we no longer wake up every morning wondering what part of the house we have to go clean.Totally works.

These are magic. It's just amazing how much good they do for ankle issues, so effortlessly and quickly. It does take a little while to get used to them, especially if you're a guy like me and don't have experience with heels. Even after six months, I still don't really like the sensation of having my heel lifted up, but it's a teensy price to pay for the huge relief of stress taken off an injured Achilles tendon.

Great product, and it really does work. I use it for Achilles issues, and it makes a difference. Plus, unlike a brace or heel lifts and what not, you can wear the tape all day long and get continuous relief. The website says you can wear it in the shower, and while true (it does stay on) it tends to stay a little wet and does get uncomfortable. Also, I do get some rash from the tape, especially if it gets wet. But overall, it's a brilliant, simple and effective solution to deal with aches and pains on the joints and tendons.

Very effective product for Achilles problems, either as a stand-alone solution, or in combination with other solutions such as KT tape and heel lifts. I have moderate chronic Achilles tendonitis which can be very difficult to get under control, especially with any kind of exercise. I started with the CEP brace, and it did a lot of good - immediately, like, within 20 minutes. It isn't really intended to be used when not active; it should be used during exercise (walking, jogging, etc). I didn't find that it was 100 % solving my Achilles tendonitis and read some other reviews where people had combined it with KT tape. For me, that turned out to be a great combination, and now I always use the two together when working out. If I add heel lifts to those two items, I can usually get a pain free workout - though stacking 3 different products on the ankle/heel is not totally conducive to comfort. All in all, I think this admittedly expensive product delivers on its promise, and is well worth checking out if you have Achilles issues. It's at least as useful as any of the exorbitantly expensive products peddled by podiatrists and physical therapists.

This awesome cleaning brush is the Final Word Ever on grill cleaning brushes. I grill 4-5 times per week and am psychotically picky about my grill tools. I don't even let other people use them. Normally, I buy and use whatever the highest-end Weber tool is for the purpose (tongs, spatula, etc). Weber does make a good grill brush, by the way. But of course, no grill brush gets in between the grill slats, right? Wrong. The Kona 360 Clean Grill Brush lets you get right in there, into those little spaces between the iron grates. It's such a clever design I wish I had thought of it myself. Kind of like if they came out with a shower sponge that surrounds your entire body and scrubs you clean, all at once, except applied to grills. And so, the first-ever non-Weber tool joins its Weber brethren on my grill hooks. The search is over. Best-in-class product, by a wide margin. No reason to buy any other grill brush again.

I switched over from an iPhone to the Android world 2 1/2 years ago with the Samsung Galaxy 3, and happily used and enjoyed it until it died a week ago. I was stunned when I visited the AT&T store to see how much they had improved things since then, and purchased a new Galaxy 6. However, I did spend some time fondling the Note 4 while in the store, and a few days later returned the Galaxy 6 for a Note 4. (I did look at the iPhone 6 and 6+, but for some reason iPhones just don't do it for me - I much prefer Android, even though I'm not a tekkie).The main difference and issue between the Galaxy 6 and Note 4, of course, is size: 5.1 " screen vs 5.7". While the Galaxy 6 is truly a one-handed phone, the Note 4 is only marginally capable of being operated in traditional one-hand smartphone style. Really, it is more of a tablet, in terms of how you handle it. On the other hand, after about 3-4 days of usage, I've gotten used to it. I also haven't used my Nexus 7 tablet since taking the Note 4 home; in fact I'm not even sure where it is right now. For me, being able to reduce from 2 to 1 devices for everyday carry, Starbucks hanging out, etc., is a huge benefit, and more than makes up for the fact that the Note 4 is a bit large to carry around all the time.The screen is AMAZING. So is the camera. The picture quality, displayed on this best-in-class screen, is nothing short of breathtaking. This phone truly takes everything to the next level (except audio - the small rear speaker is oddly cheesy and downmarket for this extremely expensive and premium phone).I could go over the details, but many others have done a fine job of describing the various points in other reviews here. I think my point is just that this is a fantastic phablet. News reading, book reading and such are all fairly easy on this device; Netflix watching is superb; gaming is not bad. Call quality is outstanding. It just upgraded to Android 5.0.1, which has some really nice new features (such as centralized notifications management for all applications in one place).If you want a really large phone that doubles as a small tablet, look no further. If you're intrigued by the concept but want something that fits more easily in a pocket and hand, a Galaxy 6 might be the better choice. I can see the merit in both arguments. That said, having owned both I'm very happy with the Note 4 and plan on keeping it for a full 2 years. I think once you get used to this kind of screen real estate and power in your pocket, it's hard to go back.

I bought this case for the kickstand feature. It is poorly implemented. If the phone is sitting horizontally, then it works OK. If the phone is sitting vertically, then the slightest breeze or touch will send it toppling over. It's obvious that the kickstand is too short and/or low to support the height of the phone, and should've been obvious in the design phase. I will use it until I find something with a better kickstand.

I found these to be a perfectly acceptable pair of casual slip on shoes, but I think I was expecting more for the relatively high price: better workmanship, higher-quality leather, etc. They are basically equivalent to the slip-ons I've gotten from Merrill or a dozen other manufacturers for 20-40 % less, or more when on sale. I don't think these are worth the premium price, although there is nothing wrong with them.

A great product which I recommend with no reservations. I don't use the Dunham Cloud boots for hard-core backpacking/hiking but just to tool around town, walk, etc. For that purpose, they're great! They fit and feel much like my various New Balance shoes (Dunham is a New Balance brand). One thing about Dunham and New Balance is that the sizing is almost always consistent across the brands and different models, so once you're set on a certain size/width, you're set. I returned some Timberland boots because they were too narrow and just not that comfortable - a little tight. These are the opposite - massively roomy toe box and roomy, spacious interior from toes to heel. I really like that about them. My sense is that, overall quality wise, these are a cut or two above other similar boots at this approximate price point, making them a good (though not inexpensive) deal. No boots are ever as comfortable as shoes, but these come reasonably close.

These are great shoes. They are comfortable, roomy, supportive (with excellent arch support), and stable. I got them for fitness walking, but they quickly replaced pretty much all my other shoes for going outside for any purpose. No, they're not quite "high fashion", but they're reasonably attractive casual-wear for anything from a weekend to a casual office environment. The 928's are really the gold standard for higher-end walking shoes or for people who are on their feet all day; I'm not sure there's anything better out there. I like them so much I already bought a pair in both colors and a back up pair in brown. They are so much more comfortable than other shoes, especially if you're going to be standing or walking a lot, that it's hard to describe. One thing worth noting is that they're not heavily padded; the feel is more "supportive" than "springy". Kind of like sleeping on a firm or medium-firm mattress instead of a cushy soft one. These are not cheap, but you get what you pay for; the build quality is high and attention to detail is solid. I'm very satisfied and, at least as of right now, don't see myself wearing much of anything else shoe-wise in the future.

There is so much misinformation on the web from disgruntled iFit users that I feel compelled to weigh in. Speaking of weighing in, I've been losing 2.5 pounds per week consistently since getting it. Anyway ...Here is, in a nutshell, what iFit does, assuming you have an iFit enabled exercise machine (basically, those made by Icon Fitness, which includes brands such as NordicTrack, Pro-Form, etc.):- create custom maps using Google Maps on your laptop, send them to your exercise machine, and then run/walk/cycle along to Google Street Views - anyplace in the world. Today I took a tour of Stonehenge, and yesterday I walked along a river in Australia. On my treadmill. How cool is that? The incline/decline on your machine adjusts automatically to track to the topography of the Google Map - so as you walk up a hill on the map, your machine adjusts accordingly. There are hundreds of maps provided by iFit if you don't feel like making your own. And there are THOUSANDS created by other users that you can tap into; the sharing between members is extensive. One member has created a massive database of 1,200 maps, fully searchable for location (by country), type (beaches, trails, cities, etc), hilliness, distance, etc. The Google Maps thing is absolutely the coolest fitness concept I've ever seen, and it may be the flagship feature of iFit, but it's not the only feature. There is much more:- download iFit Outside to your phone, go for a run/walk, and it'll use GPS to create a Google Map of your run/walk. It'll immediately upload the data to your iFit account, including the map, time, elevations, speed, pace, calories, etc. You can log into your account at the iFit site and review the map and every detail of your workout. As it does with a treadmill (or other equipment) workout, iFit logs all the data from your outdoor workout and adds it to your accumulating totals.- every workout you do on your exercise equipment is automatically uploaded to iFit after you complete it - all the data: time, distance, elevation, heart rate (if you're using a chest strap), etc. It's all reviewable on graphs and charts, and iFit totals it by day/week/month and forever, so you can monitor progress and see your accumulating totals. I have used the graphs showing heart rate overlayed with incline level and speed to great effect, learning how and where I can push harder to get improved cardiovascular fitness, and I have been able to see my results improve by the week on the charts.- you can log your weight, food/calories, etc. I'm not personally a fan of calorie or weight logging, but weight logging does serve an important purpose in iFit. If you log your weight, iFit will automatically use it to calculate the calories for your workouts on your machine - or even your outdoor walks/runs. This will provide you an infinitely more accurate picture of calories burned than any kind of generic formula.- any workout you do on your machine is stored forever in iFit so you can repeat it anytime- iFit displays pretty much every piece of data you can think of on your machine as you work out. It is the most comprehensive data-display I've ever seen on a fitness machine. There's nothing you'll want to know about your workout that isn't displayed on the iFit panel. Speed, pace, incline %, heart rate, calories/hour rate, distance, distance remaining to complete workout, and on and on and on.- you can set goals on the iFit site and it'll track your progress against those goals, alerting you to where you're falling short and prodding you to improve where needed.- it has social features (forum, blog, etc) for people who are into that kind of thing.So basically, it's a total system which integrates your exercise equipment, the iFit web site, and your outdoor exercise activities.But still, the Google Street View thingy is the most amazing feature and is itself worth the ticket to the dance.Now, about the complaints. Sadly, iFit is a bit buggy. One weekend it was basically not working at all for me, and I've noticed a wide assortment of minor annoyances, from workouts that aren't logged 100 % accurately, to the fact that it knocks 2-3 calories and 2-3 seconds off my workout totals (sounds minor, sure, but I do one-hour workouts only to see it logged as 59:57, which is annoying, so now I do 60:03 workouts). Occasionally iFit workouts don't log at all, and though you can always enter them manually (by typing in the time, distance, calories, etc., as they appeared on your machine after the workout), it's just not the same as having the machine take care of all of it for you. In short, iFit is more than a Beta product but something less than a fully debugged, rock-solid application. iFit needs better system testing. probably more programmers, and somewhat more of a customer-focused commitment to proactive bug and problem fixes. Having gotten to know quite a few iFit users, some of them have had great experiences like me, but others have encountered more substantial and/or persistent problems and been frustrated by the buggy nature of the system. Everything has worked about 95 % for me, but even as a satisfied and impressed end-user I can see that iFit has work to do to elevate this from "cool idea that kinda works most of the time" to a truly reliable, stable service.Some of the complaints about iFit are flat-out wrong. For instance, the complaint that once you join, you then have to pay to download specific map packages. That is wrong. I have downloaded hundreds of iFit maps and workout collections, and have never been charged one cent. It's all free, once you're a premium member, at least for anything that I've downloaded.There's really nothing else like iFit, or even close to it, on the market. Put simply, it is the ONLY fitness system that lets you walk, run or cycle anywhere on Planet Earth from the comfort of your own house, getting in shape while seeing the world - from their or your own custom Google Street View maps. That is just brilliant. And as noted earlier, there's a lot to iFit besides the Google Street View feature. Integration of an exercise machine with outdoor exercise and the web into one overall tracking system for fitness is really, really helpful, and probably more important than the Google maps for getting and staying on track.I can understand why some people are frustrated with iFit, but I encourage people looking into iFit to consider the forest for the trees. It is a brilliant fitness system. Like a lot of iFit users, I am waiting for them to put the resources on this to make it 100 % stable and polished, but in the meantime, even with its quirks and annoyances it's a truly unique and excellent platform for getting in shape.

Worked right out of the box and seems to do everything it's supposed to do. Replaced a malfunctioning Roku with it after the replacement Roku was malfunctioning too. The Fire TV stick just worked, right away, no fuss. Good product.

I only buy Hamilton Beach coffee makers. Despite being sort of a "value" / low cost brand, their coffee machines have proven to be very durable and have all the needed features. This one has a removable water resevoir, which is quite convenient and saves some cleaning time. I'd spend more on another brand if someone had a better machine to offer, but this one really does it all for me. 5 stars.

Solid laptop for the price. Core i3 chip and 500 meg drive is more than sufficient for basic work/entertainment computing; it isn't a gaming machine, of course. The 17" monitor is crisp and bright. Keyboard feels a little un-springy but is otherwise fine. The mouse button isn't great: instead of two buttons, you get one long bar, and have to push at the very ends of the bar to get a left or right click. Also, the touchpad is far to the left side of the laptop, instead of in the middle, where it should be. A big upside is that it ships with Windows 7 home premium, instead of the odious Windows 8. Overall, it's a solid value-laptop for people who don't want to spend a lot of money but want all the basics: large screen, an Intel Core processor, and Windows 7. I looked around and couldn't find anything better for the buck.

I use this shoe (and *only* this shoe) on the treadmill. I had previously been using the 860v4 but then got the 860v5 and it's even better. The new version has a strong plastic mid-sole arch support that really provides a lot of support, which was absent on the v4.  It's well worth the higher cost to get the arch support, but the shoe is lighter, too. This shoe provides the perfect amount of padding and support and fits fantastically well on my feet. It provides ample space for the foot and is a bit on the roomier side, compared to some other running shoes. This is as comfortable a shoe as I've ever worn. I have no intention of using anything but the 860v5 for fitness activities in the future.

This is a tremendous product, as fit for purpose as a product could possibly be. There are some better headphones out there in terms of audio quality, but for noise cancellation, nothing even comes close to the Bose 25s. I had the Sony equivalent, which were about 2/3 of the cost (hence my purchase of the Sonys), and they were NOTHING compared to the Bose for noise cancellation. In addition, the QC25s are extremely comfortable for my large head and ears, and I can wear them as long as needed with no fatigue. I use the QC25s to work out on a treadmill and watch a small TV while my wife uses a rowing machine and watches the main room TV at full volume. With any other headphones, or even with the QC25s and noise cancellation turned off, it's a cacophonous madhouse - a giant TV blasting, exercise equipment and fans running, etc. - I can barely hear my own TV at all no matter how loud I turn it up. But when I turn on the noise cancellation, almost all of the noise in the room just ... disappears, and I can comfortably listen to my own TV show at a low volume. It doesn't eliminate "all" background noise; for example, you can still hear voices and some higher-pitched sounds. But it almost entirely eliminates low frequency noise, background hum, buzz, fans, and other constant/ambient sounds. These headphones are nothing short of phenomenal. The price seems ridiculous, but they are worth every penny if you can afford them. In case it's ambiguous, just to be clear I ***love*** this product.I wouldn't even consider getting on a plane without these.

A useful, informative and often insightful book about the lead up to the Battle of Hastings, the major players involved, and the battle itself. Tetlow fills in a lot of blank spots in the history, with interesting and informative speculation, making the story into more of an overall narrative than the raw history would provide.That said, the book has some historical inaccuracies. Simple example: Tostig Godwinson is said to have been Earl of Northumbria for a year, whereas no one questions that he had been Earl for 10 years prior to his exile.Except for some errors of that nature and questionable accounting of force sizes at the various battles, Tetlow does a good job of distinguishing fact from speculation from probable falsehood.Given the enormity of the 1066 story in western history, there aren't really a lot of books that focus on that one year. Most Conquest books spend the first third on the earlier background (Edward the Confessor's reign), a third on 1066, and a third on the post-Conquest situation of William ruling England. Those are useful too, and the more one understands the previous King Edward's reign, the better one can follow and appreciate what happened in 1066. Indeed, in a lot of ways 1066 was the final outcome of political and historical developments that had occurred years earlier. That said, it is good that there's a book that, although it does cover the previous years briefly, really drills down on 1066 itself, devoting time and patience to dissecting the specific events of the year. Good balance of political vs. battlefield coverage.Every 1066 book has a bias one way or the other, and this one is slightly (but not overly) biased toward the English (versus the Normans). Tetlow takes a properly skeptical opinion toward the Bayeux Tapestry, the propaganda of William of Poitiers (which fed most of what we think we know about 1066), etc.The book does fall a little flat in its coverage of Harold's brother Tostig Godwinson. His cruelty and maladministration is covered in depth, but his motivations are not, leaving him a cardboard monster instead of the complex person that he probably was. There are other books that provide a more nuanced view of Tostig.I've read pretty much every book on 1066, and this is one of the better ones.
This is really a great fireplace tool. In fact, it's the only fireplace tool we have, and it really gets the job done. Can also be used to cook 2 marshmallows at a time!  Totally worthwhile product.

Very happy with this rack. I was looking for a smaller log rack to fit a small space next to our fireplace, and this fits perfectly. Holds enough logs for 2-3 nights. Very sturdy, strong and attractive, and the price was right.

Outstanding carafe in every way. I got the 34 oz one and liked it so much I got the 51 oz one too. Coffee was as hot 4 hours after putting it in the carafe as it was when it was poured in. Well made. Reasonable price. Between the two sizes, I'd probably recommend the 51 oz one. They have the same footprint on a table; the 51 oz version is just taller. So it holds 50 % more coffee while taking up no more space on a table or desk. The 34 oz one is small and is smaller than it looks in the picture - really not much larger than an 18 ounce cup of coffee. The 51 oz version is more like the traditional carafe size that you're familiar with. Both are great. A+ products.

Very enjoyable adventure novel with some fun twists and turns, a super-interesting premise, and a good cast of characters. Dog lovers will really love this book, as will most people who enjoy horror-tinged adventure stories. The writing is faster paced and tighter than in some other Koontz novels. Some insightful observations about life, meaning and purpose are embedded within the story but never preachy. A great summer read.

If 1/3 of the words were removed, I think this'd have been an excellent book. It has an interesting, intriguing premise and a fun story. But it is exceptionally wordy. Once I figured out that you could skim or skip entire chunks of text (4-5 pages at some points) and lose not a shred of the plot/story, it got better, but it was still a struggle to make it to the end. The wordiness problem occurs on two levels: (a) just generally taking 200 words to say something that could've been said in 10, and (b) a really onerous attempt to make the reader feel the fear, through incredibly repetitive long, drawn-out descriptions of the main character's fearful emotional responses to things. For those who are either very patient or proficient at skimming, buried in this book is a solid, fun story. The beginning is better than the end; the early characterizations make for worthwhile reading, while the characters in the last half of the book turn to cardboard.

There is something silly and depressing, and yet useful, about a book like this. It does exactly what you'd expect it to do: convert history's most masterful prose into garbage modern idiomatic English. Some of that is so comical that you'll find yourself sending snippets to your friends by email for days, and they will write back, "LOLOLOLOLOLOLOLOLOLOL". You'll feel guilty for reading it, and you may end up wondering whether you have just aided a wee bit in the general collapse of western civilization.All that said, I'm really glad I purchased it. Shakespeare is hard to read. Some of the archaic language can be sussed out with patience, but some of it is impenetrable. The real prose appears on the left side, and the ... for lack of a better word ... "translation" appear on the right (facing) pages. Nobody's stopping you from reading the real prose on the left pages and ignoring the modernized version. But when you hit those words and phrases that can't be sussed out, a quick glance at the right-hand page leaves you with an "ah, I get it now".It's a very useful tool that I wish wasn't necessary but found very beneficial. And when all is said and done, it got me re-exploring Shakespeare, and I'll probably buy others in the series, too.

Stephen Pollington is one of the world's best-known experts on Anglo-Saxon history, language and culture. He has written many books on the topic, and pretty much anyone who's into that topic knows that he is The Man. This book is extremely helpful, providing what is probably the most comprehensive all-around lexicon from Old English to New English.  This book is a "must own" for the self-taught student of Anglo-Saxon England and the Old English language.

Absolutely love this throne. We have two of them. Liked the first one so much that we ordered another, for another bathroom. It's small and really fits perfectly in small bathrooms, e.g. guest bathrooms or middle-level toilet/sink rooms. The dual flush system, which I've since read they've been using in Europe for many years, is far superior to the single flush system on most American toilets. It saves tons of water! I've had two jams in about 10 months of use; most of the time it provides a very decisive flush. We replaced 20 year old old-school 3 gallon toilets with these, and these flush MUCH better and stronger. All in all, it does what it's supposed to do perfectly. High recommended.

Mine is rectangular, like it's supposed to be. The other reviewer said his was square, and in fact it does look kind of square, but when I took out a tape measure it turned out to have the correct dimensions.This is an average quality product. The pole is a bit flimsy and the canopy material is acceptable but not high-end. The truth is that this is a deep-discount deck umbrella; the good ones cost three to four times as much. If what you want is what I wanted - an inexpensive way to get some shade on the deck - you'll be satisfied. If you're looking to grace your beautiful deck with a high-end umbrella, you'll probably need to look elsewhere...and spend a lot more money.

About two years ago I decided to teach myself Old English. It has been quite a difficult journey, because while there are some shared words and similarities between old and new (modern) English, the truth is that Old English is, to us, a foreign language. The grammar is way, way different than modern English, and once you get done learning the few hundred words that are similar or identical (gold, God, etc.) and congratulating yourself for being able to say "Hello! My name is Bob and I am hungry and I live in England" in Old English, you end up here: "willath hy hine athecgan gif he on preat cymeth." And at that point you realize that the complex Old English training/learning materials out there are far too overwhelming for the average adult learner to deal with.This book is the antidote. It is VERY easy to understand and digest in manageable chunks, and literally from Page 1 you get a sense that you're making progress and learning how to read Old English sentences. The language study is combined with useful cultural tidbits, and the book covers things that, in retrospect, seem blindingly obvious but that other books fail to cover -- such as the fact that the written letters of Old English don't all look like our letters; no matter how hard and how much you memorize verb tables, you will not be able to read the simplest "real" Old English text until you learn to recognize how they wrote their s, r, and g's. And especially the w's, which were called wynns and looked like thin, squashed p's. I learned that on about page 10 of this book, and it quickly informed me as to why, after managing to get the basic gist of the language in my head, I had still been unable to read a SINGLE word in an actual handwritten Old English document. Well, now I can. It isn't that difficult.The book will not fully prepare you for reading Old English texts; it is more like a primer that will get you launched in the right direction. To read the Seafarer or Beowulf in original Old English, you'll need to take it further than this book. There are plenty of other books that can help you do that, once you've got the basics down.Although superficially aimed at children, in point of fact it is a brilliant exercise in adult learning. I would go as far as to say that this book is the most ingenious piece of adult learning material I have ever encountered on any topic. It is simply flawless at getting a newbie engaged with its topic.Very sadly, I heard that the author Matt Love has passed away, so I guess we will not be seeing the additional volumes which were planned for this series. My understanding is that many more volumes were planned, and one can only imagine how they would have propelled the adult learner to mastery of this difficult subject matter. A true loss.

Ohhhh what I wouldn't have been willing to pay for this book in a larger font size ...That said, wow!  This is the real deal. The unabridged, complete translation of the Domesday Book, one of the most important documents ever put together in the English language. It's fascinating and compelling, and if you spend some quality time with it - more than an hour to flip through it; I'm talking about drill-down, whole-evening study of the thing - you will discover lifetimes' worth of fascinating facts and information.The font is tiny. Bring a magnifying glass, or be under 30 years old when you buy it.

This is quite a good book for income-oriented investors, that is, people who are primarily seeking high yields to deal with the extreme low-interest-rate environment we've been in for a half decade now. The main thrust of the book is that:- it is possible to earn a reasonable rate of return of 3x (but in many cases much more, even though the author doesn't really say that) times the rate offered by bank CDs.- however, you must be SMART about how you pick these investments, because many of them suck- you can apply a methodology to find the good ones, which is really what the book focuses on.Without going further than reading the book (the author offers a stock picking/identifying service online) I was able to choose a number of investments that have been performing well. They are averaging an 8.5 % yield, which is much, much more than 3x CD rates. They don't all fully meet the author's guidelines, but I wanted more yield. If nothing else, the book forces you to examine what risks you're willing to take and how far off the path to low-risk success you're willing to go to jack up that yield just a little more.I notice that a few reviewers criticize the book for being basically a brochure for his online service. It's possibly a fair critique but I didn't really feel that way. He's packed a lot of thoughtful ideas and good ways to look at income investing into an inexpensive paperback. If you want more in-depth guidance, you have to pay for it, just like with anything else. The book itself is a great value.I liked the book and would recommend checking it out if you're seeking high-yield income investing ideas.

This is my 3rd Safariland glock holster. I really like this product line. The Glock 21 is large and not that easy to find a good holster for. In this particular holster, the G21 is held very securely (but not too tight for me, as some other reviewers have complained about). I have not had an issue with the holster rubbing against the front sight, also a complaint of some reviewers. The two big advantages of this holster (for any Glock model) are that the kydex is very tough and thick and completely covers the trigger guard - a huge plus for any gun without a safety, such as a Glock - and the "unlock" mechanism to get the gun out of the holster is very intuitive and easy. You can get the gun out fast, but no one can easily grab the gun off your holster. For these reasons, I rate the product 5 stars.  Of course, it goes without saying that a G21 is not an easy gun to conceal and I would therefore not even think about this holster as a "concealment holster". To me, it's an open carry / range holster only. I suppose if you had a large sweater, loose pants, and a jacket, you could do it, but realistically, there are much more suitable firearms for that task.

For those who are into historical source documents and English history, it'd be very, very hard to beat this one. Henry of Huntingdon was not an eyewitness to the Norman conquest and surrounding decades (he was born 22 years after the battle of Hastings) but he was close enough in time to the action to give you a more visceral, detailed, up-close-and-personal account of the action than is available pretty much anywhere else.There are some (including the introduction in this book) who point out that this isn't "historical analysis" in the way we understand it these days. In the 11th century, history was more of a rhetorical art, with fake (made-up) speeches intending to communicate how the author imagined the main characters' thought processes, and so forth. However, I found that it was actually a pretty straightforward historical work, minus the tedious "and the English lost because they had failed God" type of stuff, which is endemic to any period writing. They just had a very different view of the role of God in the everyday happenings of man, than we do. It's easy to find historical errors in his work, but he did not have Google, Wikipedia and a modern, large body of historical books on the subject available to him. Constructing his history from hearsay, scant source documents, and passed-down oral history, it's remarkable how well his history squares with the known facts and other contemporary-ish sources. As he himself points out, once the book gets to his era, that is, roughly 1100 and later, the history-telling is much more based on his own observations, and it shows; it becomes more personal, fact-based and confident in its assertions.The only criticism I am going to level at this book is that the footnoting is terrible. Why, oh why, oh WHY, did they not put the footnotes, which often contain the most important and interesting information, directly on the pages where they are referenced? And, OK, if one has to put them at the back of the book, fine. But why use asterisks instead of numbers to reference the footnotes? Try to imagine counting how many asterisks have already been used in the section of the book you're reading, so that you can find the matching footnote. Yurgh. Hands down this is the most awkward footnoting system I've seen in a book. I'm docking it a star for that.Well, there's a subset of people out there who are going to be interested and fascinated in this book, and you know who you are, so I don't feel it necessary to say "highly recommended," although it certainly is, if you're looking to take your Norman conquest reading to another level of depth.

I really like what they've done with this mag pouch. Very handy at the range and, though I don't really expect to ever have to "deploy" it except in a range/practice setting, it's nice to know I can put a mag in the 21 and have three on my belt if I ever needed to. That's 52 rounds of .45 on tap and I can't imagine any scenario where I'd need more than that. I quite like being able to empty a whole box of ACP into the mags and head to the range. Nice product, and by the way, I'm a fan of Safariland in general, and use their paddle holsters for my G17, 19, and 21.

I haven't used it yet, and hope never to have to do so. But I did examine the unit and it appears to be of excellent quality. I especially like that it holds 100 gallons, versus some competitive products that are more in the 60 to 85 gallon range. If you need a large stash of emergency water, those extra 15 to 40 gallons could make a material difference. Don't forget to buy some kind of water purifier tablets or liquid to go with it.

This is the gold standard of manual can openers, as good as a can opener can ever be. I love OXO products for their design and functionality, and this one is consistent with their overall quality level.

When I got this thing, I almost laughed out loud at how much stuff they packed into it. Solar panel and hand crank for power generation. AM/FM radio. Flashlight. Emergency beacon. Alarm. USB port for charging a cell phone. I wish I had been on the design team - that would've been a lot of fun. The only thing missing is a soda dispenser.Well, if you're looking for one small, cheap, lightweight device that will give you light, radio, emergency beacon, and in a pinch an ability to get a few % of cell phone charging, then ... here it is. Period.I do have a higher end version of this type of device, which was more than twice as expensive. It's more rugged than this one, and has a few feature this doesn't (but no beacon). So, if you want one of these for general emergency preparedness, this is not the only option you have. But for basic low-budget multi-functional capability, this thing is GREAT.PS Don't be naive, though, you can't crank it a few times to charge a cell phone. Be prepared to put in some elbow grease for that

If you're going to buy Paracord, there is no excuse for not getting the Real Thing - true Military Specification paracord. And that's what this is. Everyone should have a few lengths of this stuff in the toolbox. It is infinitely useful. Rated to 500+ pounds. It isn't cheap but, again, this is the REAL STUFF, not some fake / imitation product. People bet their lives on paracord, in survival, hard-core outdoors/camping/hiking/hunting, and construction/homebuilding sorts of things. If you ever need to use it, you'll be very happy that you spent the extra few $ on REAL paracord. Buy it.

Not to be unoriginal, but I completely agree with an earlier reviewer who said this is as rare and magical as unicorn blood. Couldn't have said it better myself. More prosaically, I'll add that this is the best hot sauce I have ever used - out of hundreds. Not too vinegary, not too sweet, not too salty*, and it has the perfect heat level (maybe a smidge too hot for non-chili-heads, but for hot sauce lovers it hits that perfect, perfect, perfect "medium heat" -- some burn, no pain but not bland either).* Actually, there is one hot sauce that tastes even better than this one, Belizean Heat. That one is absolutely the best tasting hot sauce in the history of the universe. (And they are both from Belize ... hmm, must have good habaneros there).  However, Belizean Heat has 410 mg of salt PER TEASPOON, making it pretty much bottled salt. Sontava is less than half of that. So, on pure consideration of flavor alone, I'd probably give the nod to Belizean Heat, but considering everything overall, inclusive of health implications, Sontava is the top choice.I buy this stuff in 12 packs.

I really like this small keyboard. I got it so I could futz around and make some music on my laptop, when I wasn't in my office/music studio. And it's perfect for that application. It is truly plug-and-play: I plugged the USB cable into my laptop, and seconds later, it was recognized and available to my DAW (Digital Performer 8) as a midi input device. They keys feel like every other synth-action keybed I've used; as a piano player I don't love that weightless, plastic feel, but that is what is out there for this kind of price point. I do REALLY like the overall dimensions of this unit. By eliminating unnecessary knobs at the top and sticking to just the basics on the left side (mod wheel, one midi CC controller), it's very easy to toss this thing around, put it in front of a laptop, etc. I specifically wanted a midi keyboard that didn't have all those sliders and complicated mappings and so forth, and this one delivers. A good deal at its price point.

It is painful to give this item a 2-star review, but ... so be it. This $500 and change chandelier is absolutely magnificent and you are sure to get nods and whispers of approval and jealousy from your neighbors and friends. It is perfect for a 6 - 7 foot long table. BUT ... ours arrived misaligned. It was impossible to fix. We had to rig it with spacers picked up from Home Depot to make it level and straight. My feeling is that for $100 or $150, you expect to maybe get a lighting fixture with a small problem, but for $500 it should be PERFECT. It was not. And I'm not talking about a little bend; I'm talking about a fundamentally misshapen piece of metal that created a massive nightmare installation project. That upside-down-U shaped bracket which holds the 6 lights? Ours was lower on one side, so that the six lights tilted about 10 degrees down on one side (and up on the other). That is a totally unacceptable failure of quality control in an item of this price. So, I'm giving it 2 stars, even though it would've been a solid 5 star A+++ product if it had been in good working order.

Does exactly what it needs to do, at a very fair price. I have only used MOTU midi interfaces over the past 15 years, for good reason: they WORK. Not sometimes, not with just some keyboards, with ALL midi devices, ALL the time. If you need a simple, cheap, reliable midi interface for a couple of devices, this is it. Take note, though, that for not that much more money, you could get the MOTU MicroExpress (which I also own), which'll give you and your studio some room to grow - 5 inputs and outputs. For backpack/Starbucks type usage, though, the Fast Lane cannot be beat.

Personally, it seems ridiculous to me that heart rate monitoring is not included in the stock Water Rower, but so be it ... this add-on is an absolute MUST. My only gripe is that it seems expensive for what it is (and should be free -- that is, included with the Water Rower). That said, it does work, and work well: heart rate readings are consistent, accurate and easy to see. It's a good product, just wish it cost less.
Very nice brandy glasses. Thick, solid, hefty, just the right size. We use them often. Great deal for the price.

A fully-functional control surface to control eight tracks, for $47, weighs a few ounces, small enough to sit on top of a keyboard or toss in a small backpack ... what is not to like about this product? Seriously, it's just great.

This is a great general stretching / warming up video. My wife and I have been doing it nearly every day for about a year. We're older, with all the usual achy joints and so forth, and this video works perfectly for us. It is truly a "Beginners" video, as the title implies. We have tried MANY other exercise vids but we keep coming back to this one. And let's face it, not only is Tamilee exceptionally easy on the eyes; there's also a "buns of steel" nostalgia factor here (she was the Buns of Steel lady!!). Big thumbs up for this vid, especially if you're a little older or out of shape or otherwise in that fragile "beginners" category.

This isn't the midi controller a major studio would choose, but for those of us recording in homes or small project studios, it is a very nice piece of gear and a great value.It's plug and play, for the most part. I attached the USB cable and was getting sounds out of my apps of choice (Kontakt 5 / Digital Performer 8 on a Windows 7 machine) in about 10 seconds, but it took longer to get the non-keyboard controls (sliders and knobs) set up properly. It's worth noting that the sliders and knobs feel EXCELLENT and punch way above their weight for the price.The keyboard keys are standard cheapo synth keys; I don't love 'em but I don't hate 'em either. It would be nice if this unit was offered in a slightly more expensive version with semi-weighted keys, but there is nothing wrong with this keybed. The velocity curve out of the box is kinda weird; you have to hit the notes HARD to get volume out of them, or even to get them to sound at all. No biggie for the white keys, but it is difficult to engage the black keys hard enough, and you tend to fire a lot of blanks in fast passages. Adjusting the velocity curve to a higher setting definitely helps with the problem -- but takes some digging around in the manual, and leaves you with less dynamic range to work with.The LX61 is light and easy to toss around from desk to wherever; it only weighs about 9 pounds.I could nitpick about this-and-that, but for $200 it's a steal and I'm not complaining. It feels good, with high quality sliders and knobs. It looks good, too. It took a little futzing with the manual and knobs to get it set up right, but pretty much all midi controllers are like that.I struggled with whether to get the 49 or 61; I think either'd be fine. I chose the 61 because it doesn't take up a lot more space and offers a bit more usefulness. The 61 is only 38 " long, which fits easily on almost any desk. But if I didn't plan to play two-handed piano pieces on it, I probably would've bought the 49.Recommended product - but be prepared to spend a little while with the manual to get the most out of it.

I've been using Native Instruments products piecemeal since around 2006, and recently decided to take the plunge and upgrade to Komplete 9.Native Instruments might be best understood as the Google of music plug ins: an ambitious, creative company with a sprawling product line which includes a market-proven, best-in-class flagship product (Google Search; Native Instruments Kontakt); some off-the-wall experimental stuff that's cutting edge but maybe not of much use to most people yet(Google's driverless cars; NI's Reaktor), and, in the middle, a whole slew of product lines that range in success from "OK" to, occasionally, "superb" (Google Drive, Google Maps, etc. ; Native Instruments' dozens of synthesizers, virtual instruments, effects, etc).Komplete 9 is sort of like the experience you get when you go "full Google" - logging into Gmail and then using  Youtube, Gmail, Google calendar, Google contacts, Google+, etc. Some people love the integration even if some of the individual products aren't best-in-class, some don't value that, and some resent becoming part of a vendor's collective hive. I think this accurately sums up how people express themselves about Native Instruments on discussion boards. I for one like being part of the Google hive and I also like having the comprehensive Komplete platform to make music. Like any "Total Solution", not every single component of Komplete is a market-leader, but enough parts of it are to make it worthwhile as the main platform in your computer-based studio.I paid $400 for Kontakt in 2007, $200 for Battery, and $200 for Massive ... and I thought those were fair prices for the quality and depth of the apps. Komplete 9 includes those three apps, plus the two highly regarded soft-synths Absynth and FM8, plus Reaktor (more on these, later). Komplete also includes some two dozen instruments and effects sets that work within those apps. All of that for $500. It's an absolute steal, an incredible, mind-boggling amount of apps, content, and sound libraries for the buck. It would cost THOUSANDS to replicate all of the functionality and content in Komplete by purchasing it piecemeal from other vendors. The Kontakt library has over 1,000 usable, good to excellent musical instruments and sound samples you can drop right into your tracks, and that is just one piece of Komplete 9. I cannot overstate how much solid, basic value is packed into Komplete.As noted, all of the content is at least good, though not all of it is best in class. Let's take a look, from best to worst:- Kontakt is the best sampler/sample player/library on the market, period. With Kontakt, you can be lazy and just use it as a solid B or B+ instrument library, or you can go deep and spend the next three months learning how it works and then do very serious sound design work -- your choice; Kontakt is agnostic about what you do with it and will comply with whatever you want from it. The stock library is good enough to start making music, but the magic of Kontakt is that you can keep adding sound libraries to it until it is exactly what you need it to be, although that does cost money. A lot of people just pull up the presets in Kontakt and there's nothing wrong with that; in fact it's great fun, and pretty much destroys any need for outboard sound modules. But the thing to understand is that if you're willing to get under the hood, you'll find goodies like a high quality convolution reverb, dozens of other effects, and ... well, it'd take days to describe what you can do with Kontakt once you get beyond hitting the presets. Of special note is the New York Piano, which seems to be a sampled Steinway concert grand. It's phenomenal. Fits into any mix and is a blast to play solo. It gives you most of what you'd get from a top piano instrument such as Synthology's Ivory. But Ivory is 3/4 of the cost not of this piano but of the entire Kontakt 9 package !!!! So that's a really, really good example of the incredible value packed into Komplete 9.- Absynth, Massive, and FM8 are some of the best soft-synths on the market; just the presets on these tools are enough to cover 99 % of what you'd need from a synthesizer, especially the brilliant FM8 presets.  Over the years people have been very happy to pony up the money to buy those apps individually, and now they're tossed in the box for, basically, free. Massive is extremely easy and entertaining to program, and can be learned in a few hours. Absynth and FM8 are harder to learn, and I tend to just punch in presets on those two. Again: the FM8 presets are just stunning.- Monark is a new MiniMoog synth which is fully competitive with the best MiniMoog emulation synths out there -- I know, because I own all of them. It's not better, but it is as good, and, again, it's basically free.- Battery, NI's drum sampler/library, is a very solid program that, though not quite on the level of the best VI drums out there, is a program I've always liked and enjoyed using. Battery is not an A product but is perfectly acceptable. It has taken a turn in this new version toward hip hop and electronic sounds, as opposed to clean drums, which was a bit disappointing to me, but the Kontakt core library now includes a few outstanding acoustic drum kits to make up the difference.- Komplete now comes with a lot of effect plug ins. They're not thrilling but they get the job done. I would say their quality falls somewhere in the middle between the stock plug ins that come with a DAW, and high-end plugins from companies that really specialize in, say, reverb or compressors. If you have the budget for serious effects plug ins you can do better than what's bundled with Komplete, but if you're relying on your DAW's effects, Komplete provides a nice step up.- Guitar Rig 5 is an amp simulation program that I don't think is as good as the competition but is serviceable and will mostly get the job done when you're trying to get realistic guitar sounds into your tracks. I'm not in love with most of the sounds but I do love the user interface and overall useability. 1K Multimedia makes a better guitar amp simulator (Amplitube), but it's much more complex, costs tons compared to the bundled Guitar Rig, chews through CPU like a chew-toy, and it is very difficult to deal with that company for support if there's ever a problem. My advice would be to start with GR5, see how far it gets you, and then maybe take a look around for alternatives ... or find a way to love it.- Reaktor: this is a special case that defies "good or bad" analysis. Reaktor is a very complex program which is difficult to understand. Basically, it contains modules that you use to create your own synthesizers. It's sort of like a lego set for music creation programs - a high-level programming language for building soft-synths. The learning curve is very steep, and I can't imagine most musicians would try to get beyond the presets with Reaktor; I know I didn't. Nevertheless, it's a powerful tool for those with programming chops. NI itself and many other folks have created impressive instruments in Reaktor: the excellent synthesizer Monark is one of them. Reaktor is a nice-to-have, not something I'd have bought on its own, but good to have in the arsenal, especially for when NI or others release cool new presets like Monark.To take an extreme view of what Komplete can do for you, consider that with Komplete, the DAW program REAPER for $100 to record your tracks, and a $200 midi controller, you can make professional-grade music in your house for $800. Or, you can up the ante a tad and pick up iZotope's Ozone for $200 and then you will be able to do your own mastering and produce truly finished pro-level music, for $1,000. Of course you will still need a mic and an audio interface, and maybe you'll want a few pro-grade plugins for EQ, reverb, and compression, but you get the idea. For about $1,500 you can have it ALL. That is what Native Instruments has made possible, a world where pretty much anyone can have all of the functionality of a recording studio for $1,500 or thereabouts. Of course, Komplete does not include the talent to make great music; that, the user must provide.Big thumbs up for Native Instruments, and my highest possible endorsement for Komplete 9, a truly deep product with layers and layers of stuff to explore, learn and use, at an incredibly reasonable price.

We got a WaterRower about a month ago, to replace an old elliptical machine we'd had for 12 years. The elliptical was a good machine, but was taking a toll on my back. We looked at different rowing machines, but settled on the WaterRower, mainly due to the reduced noise and the pleasant swoosh of water while rowing. It's also a great looking machine, probably the nicest looking piece of exercise equipment I've ever seen.
