Perhaps to an Olympian or serious competitive athlete that would be an unimportant or even silly purchasing criteria, but for normal, everyday people looking to get in shape without turning a large room in their house into a "gym", the WaterRower really is an aesthetically pleasing piece of kit.Rowing is quite challenging, in fact more challenging than any other aerobic machine or workout I've tried. For the first week, I could only go about 4 minutes in total each day, with breaks every 40 - 45 seconds (although I could still do 20-30 minutes on the elliptical!). I had gotten very out of shape, and rowing is unforgiving on out-of-shape muscles. It was brutal. It took about two full weeks for me to get broken in on the machine and to be able to do a full kilometer of rowing (roughly 8 minutes), still with a break every minute or two. Now I am able to do 2 kilometers (in about 14 minutes) with just one break in the middle, and I have to say I have really started to like it. Rowing works a lot more muscles and muscle groups than other machines; when you finish a vigorous rowing workout you can feel it from your shoulders to your toes. With each passing day I feel more flexible and stronger, and I am losing weight. It is getting very easy to see how this machine can really deliver the fitness and weight loss results that I seek.The only real criticism I have of the WaterRower is the computer readout gadget. It isn't backlit, and it doesn't have color. It provides the basic information -- strokes per minute, heart rate ($100 extra for that option, ugh), time, distance, and 500 meter pace, the latter being the data point that rowers care most about -- but lacks the kinds of motivational tools, cool graphics, or competitive games that my wife and I are accustomed to seeing on exercise equipment. Supposedly there are third-party apps that you can use with a laptop to make things more interesting, such as rowing against a pace boat, or down scenic rivers and so forth, but NONE of them, as of this date, are for sale and operational. It looks to me like a small third-party market started to take off for WaterRower ten years ago and then kind of folded. The only app I could find which is working just provides basic performance info (pace, time, etc) on a computer or TV screen. Yawn. All that said, I knew when I bought it that the computer aspect is seriously lacking. WaterRower's top competitor, Concept2, has dramatically better computer functionality, apps, Internet community, and all that stuff. We thought about all that when making the purchase, but my wife and I decided that the relative quiet and pleasant, motivating water-swoosh sound was the core of what we wanted, and that we could live without an advanced tech side. Do take note that if you want the heart rate monitor -- and if you are out of shape, older or overweight, this is barely an option; you MUST have one -- it is a $100 added option. So add $100 to your cost projection for this machine.I would sum up the upsides of the WaterRower like this:- Genuinely attractive unit which fits perfectly in a well-furnished, upscale house. It does not turn a room of your house into an "exercise room".- As quiet an aerobic machine as anything we've ever used, with an incredibly pleasant swooshy water sound while you're rowing. Honestly the best-sounding piece of exercise equipment I've ever used- Comfortable seat on a supportive dual-rail system- Well-made machine which I think will last many years; the quality is apparent throughout- Well thought-out design enables you to stand it up flush against a wall in less than a minute, to get it out of the way- Compared to other rowing machines, it seems to have a smoother, more linear motion, which may be unrealistic in terms of actually rowing a boat but makes for a much better aerobic workout- Phenomenal workout - this is true of any rower, but it's still worth saying. This thing is a calorie destroyer. A month of rowing has made me much more fit, both cardio wise and in terms of muscle strengthening.- Not a bad price. It's less than half the cost of a good elliptical or treadmill. People complain about the price on the discussion forums, but in truth a k is not a lot of money for a high quality exercise machine. A WaterRower is not competing with some $399 piece of crap from Target. It's competing with $2,500 ellipticals.Overall, I have to say this was an outstanding purchase, and has my wife and me truly motivated to exercise in a way we weren't feeling in the last few years with other machines. I highly recommend checking one of these out if you're looking at rowing machines. This and the Concept2 are recognized by most people on most rowing forums as the two top-of-the-line offerings. The Concept2 wins big on computer readout and functionality, is incredibly well-made and durable, and is kind of the standard choice among serious athletes, Olympian types, commercial gyms, etc. However, it is noisy and has a huge footprint and makes whatever room it's in into the "gym room". The WaterRower has a subpar computer, and isn't as popular with serious hard-core athletes, but is probably just as reliable and durable. It has a huge advantage in terms of being quiet, aesthetically pleasing and non-gym-y, and ... well, you just have to hear the water swoosh to understand how pleasant and relaxing it is to row to that sound.PS We thought about spending the extra $500 to get the walnut, but decided to go with the ash and save some money. The ash is very attractive looking. There's really no reason to upgrade the wood from there, unless you've got money to burn and nothing better to do with it. I have also seen a walnut one and it's very nice looking, but just didn't seem $500 better.

This is quite an interesting hot sauce. I'm a huge fan of Blair's hot sauces, of which there are many types - at least a dozen. They are rank-ordered by Blairs in terms of heat level and this is the 2nd mildest sauce in their lineup.The taste is great: a very strong Jalapeno taste with hints of garlic and some other spice(s). Unlike some (many?) hot sauces, which are all heat and little or no flavor, this one is all about the strong flavor. You can really, really taste those Jalapenos, and it goes fantastically well on things that benefit from an intense Jalapeno taste - eggs, chips, etc.  This sauce is *extremely* mild, and by mild, I mean it has almost no heat. It has turned out to be the perfect sauce to offer family and friends who don't like hot foods. The heat is so mild in this sauce that it's really more of a flavoring sauce than a hot sauce. But that's OK - the flavor is superb; it stands on its own even without heat. It's just that if you want some heat, you'll have to add a real hot sauce to whatever food you're putting this on.

A great "value" mattress -- one of the best mattresses you can buy at this price point, which we are using for a guest room. But ... it is *very* firm. I've noticed that all of the cheaper memory foam mattresses have complaints about being too firm. It might be that a softer, plushier feel requires a more expensive production process for the memory foam. I'm not sure there is any mattress in this price range that'd be much softer. In our main bedroom we sleep on a latex mattress which is incomparably softer and more comfortable and plush than this one, but was $1,600 -- five times the cost. I think it's one of those "you get what you pay for" things. I'd say this mattress is a "buy" and maybe the best product available at its price, but if you're not into firm mattresses you may want to look around a bit first.

It seems kinda ridiculous to review an ice scoop, except ... this is a great ice scoop, worthy of a review!  It is plastic, not metal, so you can leave it in an ice bin/bucket in the freezer and not freeze your fingers when you pick it up. The scoop has been expertly designed to scoop just enough ice to fill a normal-sized soda glass to the top. It's tough and durable and ours has lasted a long time. An ice scoop seems like such a trivial thing, but good quality is good quality no matter what the item. Worth the cost premium over cheaper scoops, by a mile. 5 stars, recommended.

I have been using the SterlingPro French coffee press for about a week, and I have to say I am really pleased with it. I've used it four times now.First things first: this press makes a *great* cup of coffee. The flavor is smooth and robust and could not be better. The operation of this (or any other coffee press) is pretty simple, albeit somewhat unfamiliar to most Americans (like me). You just add hot water to coffee grounds (use a "course" grind, not fine), and then press the grounds to the bottom, and voila! coffee. The coffee that comes out of a press is generally much better than that from a conventional coffee maker. It's stronger and more flavorful. The usual problem with coffee presses is that there's a lot of coffee grounds left in the coffee, which is irritating. However, the SterlingPro solves that problem, and I had practically no grounds whatsoever in my coffee in the four pots I made with it.The glass canister is removable from the base and can be put in a dishwasher, which is a big plus. Still, there's some hand-cleaning required of the other components, but that was no big deal.The pot and frame have an appealing upscale appearance, which looks great in my kitchen. I'm really pleased with the appearance of this unit.I think coffee presses haven't taken off here because there's a little extra work involved in them. However, they do make better coffee. Anyone interested in or willing to try a coffee press should find the SterlingPro a worthy addition to the kitchen. I have no problem giving this very nice piece of gear a 5 star review.Disclaimer: I received this for free in exchange for an honest, unbiased review.

I've had this unit for about 3 weeks. I don't really see how you can get more bang for the buck than the LE650.The picture was good out of the box, and became "great" after a few hours of tweaking. My tweaks were pretty simple.  I turned down the red levels and color saturation (waaaaay too red and full of color out of the box for my taste); lowered the contrast a bit; increased the back lighting, etc. Go google "LE650 picture settings" and pick from among the five or six sites that offer comprehensive setting guidance. Any of them will do.The sound is, of course, mediocre, as one would expect. I got a Sony sound bar, which solved that problem. I think that in this day and age of inexpensive sound bars, TV companies are not even bothering anymore with the sound quality. Does anyone really buy a 60" TV with the intent of listening to it through the TV's speakers? LOLI have had a few problems hooking up to wireless Internet, which I'm still working through (but with a Roku and a Chromecast, I'm not highly motivated to bother with the smart TV features, to be honest).With all those small annoyances, you might ask: why 5 stars? Well, futzing with the colors, getting a sound bar, and so on are minor things. The major thing with this set is that it brings 60 full inches of glorious HDTV into my living room for under a grand. And here's something else - no minor accomplishment, this:WITH THE LE650 YOU CAN COMPLETELY AND TOTALLY TURN OFF THE SOAP OPERA EFFECT.  100 % GONE, FOREVER.Try doing that with a Samsung. Any Samsung. You will fail, because it cannot be done on a Samsung. Or for that matter, virtually any other TV. But on this TV, the soap opera effect can be completely and totally and forever taken out of your life and destroyed. Please read the top-rated review for this TV here in this Amazon listing, for the adjustments to eliminate the soap opera effect.  It takes about 30 seconds and utterly works.  Some people don't mind the soap opera effect, many detest it. It is a bitter irony of our tech age that the newest technology in TV watching involves a completely unrealistic, irritating "soap opera" style of video display on the screen, which is much worse than watching a big fat tube TV from the 1980s. I would rather not watch TV at all than suffer through the soap opera effect. I bought this TV because I knew I could get rid of the hideous soap opera effect, and voila, I could.  For that, 5 solid stars.There are more expensive HDTVs that probably have a better picture, but unless you're comparing them side by side in a store, I really doubt most people could tell the difference. The picture on the LE650 is gigantic and amazing. For the pittance that this set costs relative to some others out there, it has to be highly recommended.

The flavor is excellent, probably in my Top 10 of hot sauces. Don't be fooled by the "Death Sauce" moniker. It's pretty mild. Even people unaccustomed to hot peppers will find this sauce "medium hot". True chili heads will find it very mild and more of a flavoring sauce than a hot sauce. Overall , it's a superb mild hot sauce with unparalleled flavor and I recommend it highly, unless you're seeking a truly hot hot sauce.

Belizean Heat is probably the best-tasting hot sauce ever made. I've been eating, testing, and making my own hot sauces for many years, and trust me, there is NOTHING on the market that tastes as good as Belizean Heat. Unless of course you're not really into hot sauce and just want something mild and easy to put on nachos, burgers, etc., like Tabasco sauce. If you're into Habaneros and medium to high heat level hot sauces, there is simply nothing better on the market than Belizean Heat. Pepper enthusiasts know that Belize, for some reason, produces the best hot sauces in the world, and this one is the best that Belize has to offer.But ...Belizean Heat has 410 mg of salt per TEASPOON. That is basically 1/5 of the recommended salt intake for an entire day of food, for ONE TEASPOON of hot sauce. That is utterly ridiculous. By way of comparison, most other hot sauces are around 100 mg - still a lot of salt, but much more reasonable. Maybe if you're 20 and healthy you can afford to treat yourself to this fantastic sauce once in a while. For those over 30 or 35 it would really be irresponsible to consume more than the tiniest amounts of this sauce.So I am giving it 5 stars for being the best-tasting hot sauce ever, and 1 star for having over 4 times the salt of a normal hot sauce. Average = 3 stars.I was despondent when I learned about the salt content, because I used to go through a bottle of this stuff per week.Fortunately, all is not lost. I started trying every Belizean Habanero sauce I could get my hands on, to see if there was something else that could take its place. And guess what, there is. It's called Sontava, and it comes in X, XX, and XXX heat levels (the XXX has about the same heat level as Belizean Heat; the other two are much milder). Sontava has 95 % of the flavor and goodness of Belizean Heat with 100 mg per teaspoon of salt. Only the suicidal wouldn't find that a worthwhile tradeoff. So I recommend admiring Belizean Heat from afar and picking up a few bottles of Sontava. You won't be disappointed. While I like to have different sauces around, push comes to shove I could easily be happy with Sontava as my only hot sauce for all occasions.

These do exactly what you hope they'll do, and - having tried a lot of other similar products - they do it much better than the competition. I think I'll leave it at that, since, if you're checking out this product, you already know what it's for and why you'd want it. Suffice to say that it is very, very good at what it does. The only question is, what will you do with all that free time that you used to spend in the bathroom??

This scale has attractive, contemporary styling which will fit in almost any kitchen environment. The digital readout is large and clear. I tested it to about 10 pounds (the highest weight I'd normally be measuring in a kitchen, i.e. a big pot of soup) and it was completely accurate from 5 grams to 10 lbs. All the usual functions are present - Tare, ounce/kg/lb/reset; it also has a timer. The best feature is probably that it has a hole in the middle (covered up in the marketing pic by the bowl of strawberries), making it easy to pick up and/or hang on a wall. The only downside is that the LED light goes out after a short period of about 10 seconds, forcing you to hit any of the front buttons to get it lit again (the #'s are impossible to read when the backlighting is turned off). Just about anything you'd be doing in a kitchen while preparing food takes more than 10 seconds, creating an annoying situation where you're hitting buttons again and again to keep the display readable. This should definitely be redesigned to provide 60 seconds before lights-out. However, aside from that, the scale seems to be very well designed, aesthetically and functionally.This is a good scale which in my mind is 4.5 stars - 5 stars for a well-designed, useful product, but docked a 1/2 star for the auto-turn-off of the light after 10 seconds. They should really change that. Regardless, still a very good kitchen scale.Disclaimer: I was sent one of these for an unbiased evaluation/review, at no cost.

This is a gun laser practice tool for target shooting practice, not just defensive shooting practice. In other words, you can use it to hone your precision aiming and marksmanship skills, not just the less precise draw-and-fire self defense drills which most products of this type are aimed at. The target overlays let you take the laser reception area down to a precise 1/2 inch, which is the correct scale for simulating 50 foot slow fire target shooting within the confines of a house, where your range might be 25-ish feet. Other overlays let you make the reception area an inch, or into an IDPA target shape, or you can just skip the overlays and get about a 1.5" square to work with. It offers you a few different operating modes - counting your hits, or timed response where it beeps and counts 1/100ths of a second until you score a hit, and there's some third mode I haven't tried yet. It comes on a stand or mounts on a wall, is compact, light, and well made.It would be nice if the laser reception area was backlit. In lower or moderate indoor room lighting, the target area does not look a lot different than the overlays. Out past 20 feet or so, you can't really tell the two apart. The promo picture of the unit in this Amazon listing shows a bright red reception area, but in fact it's black and kinda hard to see. Nevertheless, the unit is great, best product in its category, and I wholeheartedly recommend it.

This book provides a good overview of chili (pepper) growing. Lots of info on cultivation, canning, etc. The large section on varieties of peppers seemed incomplete, though. Of the 30-ish varieties I've grown in my garden, only half or so were included. Of course, the basic varieties, like jalapenos and so on, are all in there. DeWitt is a recognized leading expert in the field of chili cultivation and that itself justifies picking up this book, but it's more of a "starter guide" than a book for the experienced chili gardener. Nice coffee table book with nice pictures and presentation.

Interesting video, and certain to inform and entertain those seeking some background knowledge on 1066. Pretty well done, too, in terms of the acting and scenery. That said, it's filled with historical inaccuracies and inattention to detail. Another reviewer commented on how weapons are left on the battlefield after the fight, and that is a good observation, because a good weapon was worth years of earnings and these were typically scooped up by the victors and scavengers before the dead bodies were cold. There are plenty of examples of similar oversight by the writers, throughout the video. There is also some general silliness in the writing. For instance, some Viking dude gives a pre-batte prep talk to his men, along the lines of: cattle die, kinsmen die, but the great deed lives on forever. That poetic phrase is from the Havamal, supposedly the words of the pagan god Odin. Good to see the writers studying the sources and documents, but it'd be a bit like a modern military commander reading a passage from Genesis to his troops to get them pumped for battle - it just doesn't fit the situation. So overall, it's a good video, but perhaps better taken as edutainment than fact.

The sound is very good -- about the best you can get at this price point -- but the clips are not durable at all. I've bought and used lots of these, and inevitably one of the clips simply breaks within a few months. So these are best thought of as disposable headphones, not something you're going to use for years. That said, they are very inexpensive and provide excellent sound, so it's probably worth it to just get these and replace them as needed.

These are great!  And fun. And durable! We have three cats and they LOVE sitting on our three perches (two of them are combined into a long perch for two cats on one big window sill). These can convert any window ledge (even a 3-4" wide windowsill) into a hangout pad for up to two cats. And let me say this, it is really, really cute to find two cats chillaxin' together on these window perches. We've had our perches for about a year, and they are functioning perfectly. We might add a fourth, simply because they can turn almost any window into a cat lounge area, and the cats just love that. If you have multiple cats, these units really encourage cat bonding, by giving them a place to hang out together by themselves, watching the outdoors while being out of the way of the hustle and bustle of people in the house. It only takes them about 10 seconds to figure out how cool this product is, after you install it.

This is a very good toaster. It looks good and is quite stylish on a counter top. Toasting is EXTREMELY fast - considerably faster than any other toaster I've had, which is a plus in the morning. The bagel function is great on this model, giving you a nicely browned bagel, wicked-fast. The only drawback is that it toasts somewhat unevenly, meaning that a piece of toast (or bagel) won't be browned/cooked exactly the same on all sides, so it can require a bit of mid-toasting rotation to get an evenly toasted piece of bread. I notice that some reviewers really slam this unit due to the uneven toasting. I don't think it's that big a deal, personally, but it can't really be a 5-star toaster with uneven cooking. So I'll give it four stars. You could do far worse than this toaster.

Absolutely love this tool and would not be without one in the future. So useful, in so many ways, for its intended use (gun cleaning) as well as a gazillion other things. It's really pretty amazing how often I find myself reaching for this simple, high quality tool.

These are not good light bulbs. Don't be fooled by the GE label. They are made in Eastern Europe and are junk. I bought a couple of cases in a panic -- the whole "we'll never be able to get these again!" thing at the end of 2013. What a mistake. These burn out in a matter of days; many did not work at all. Total rip off. The only thing that can be said in their favor is that if you absolutely must have 60 w incandescent bulbs and can't find them anywhere else, there'll be at least a few in the case of 48 that will work.

I'm surprised at the mediocre reviews on this product on Amazon. I have a few of these, and use them all the time. I find them very convenient and useful. They produce a moderate amount of heat, though not enough to really heat a room. These are most useful as warmers for feet or situated right next to you while you work at a computer. They're light, last a long time, and won't burn the fur off a cat who gets too close or snuggles up to it. And cheap. I find this little heater more useful than some of the competitive products out there.

A good product, though not perfect. On the upside, it achieves about 80 % of what an old-school smelly, toxic solvent can achieve when cleaning a gun, without any odor or mess and without feeling like you just took a year or two off your life span by inhaling it. On the downside, 80 % is not 100 %. This product does not clean a bore as well as a traditional solvent. Something was given up in the formula in order to get rid of the toxic smell, and whatever it was, it is needed to get a bore totally clean. Still, I use this one most of the time because I can't stand the strong, toxic smell of gun solvent. If you're cleaning guns indoors or with poor ventilation, I recommend checking it out.

I already had their version of this holster for the G17, and recently added this one for my G19. I love the design. Anyone who's into Glocks knows that, due to the lack of an external safety, it is IMPERATIVE that the holster securely hold the gun in place and completely cover the trigger. This holster does that extremely well, with tough, thick kydex that absolutely will not allow for an accidental discharge. The release mechanism is superb and will prevent anyone from grabbing the gun out of your holster, while being easy to operate for a quick draw. The paddle is probably the best one on the market, securing very well to a belt or even just the top of jeans -- it is nearly impossible to pull the holster out while drawing the gun. Whether it's a "conceal" holster is in the eyes of the beholder; I would argue that it is not, unless you're wearing a long, loose sweater or a coat. I like everything about this holster, including the price, and recommend it without reservation.

This book, simply put, is one of the most important resources ever put together for the study of 1066, Hastings and the Norman conquest. It is the resource that no one attempting to study that period can afford to be without. It provides every word written about the conflict in the original contemporary and near-contemporary sources, translated into modern English, of course. Most of the documents it includes are available out there in one form or another, but are prohibitively expensive to acquire one at a time, and require a lot of work to find. This book was, and remains, an incredible and unique resource to the 1066 enthusiast, and is a "Must Buy".There are so many fascinating things to learn from this book that it'd take way, way more than an Amazon review to describe it all. At the highest level, I could summarize what I got out of it thusly:  there really was very little written and documented at the time about 1066 (or at least, that made it down to our time). Couple of sentences here, a few pages there. Most of it was written well after Hastings, and by people who weren't eye-witnesses to it. Almost all of the books, movies, and academic analysis done in the following thousand years is based on these sources, and there's just not a lot of source material. Much of it is contradictory, obviously very subjective, and just ... sparse. It makes you realize that we know very, very little about 1066 and have been making gigantic assumptions and guesses about it ever since.Again: this book is an incredible resource, and should be the first thing that anyone interested in getting beyond pop-history and into serious learning about 1066 should purchase.

I bought two of these. One works perfectly, but the other is defective and I've sent it back. I would've given the product four stars if not for the defective one, but I do get a feeling that these have an inconsistent build quality, and three stars is the max for that kind of situation.It's a good and useful lock-box. It's large enough to hold a compact or subcompact handgun (for instance, a Glock 26 or 19, but not a 17), plus a spare clip. It could also be used to store some cash, a passport, etc. Yet it is compact enough to toss in a small drawer or store under a car seat. In addition, it comes with a cable to secure it to anything you can wrap a cable around, such as a car seat mechanism. It is not a "high security" safe; honestly, anyone with a screwdriver or a hammer could probably get inside this thing in a couple of minutes. But it will generally keep out prying eyes, and would be enough of a pain in the ass to open such that some punk stealing loose change and CDs out of cars at a mall probably wouldn't bother with it. Understand, though, that any determined thief would be able to make short shrift of it.The combination lock is not the easiest thing to use, which makes it useless as a quick-access gun safe. If you think you might need immediate access to a firearm, this is not the safe for you. This one is more about very basic security of a weapon for transport purposes, or perhaps for short-term bedroom storage. In the home, it absolutely does not replace a real gun safe. If it sounds like I'm being negative about the safe, actually, I'm not. It just depends on what the application is. For temporary securing of a firearm in the car when going into a location where concealed carry is not permitted: great. For keeping a gun secured from curious kids: dangerous, and there are better options. So it all depends. It certainly seems like a lot of product for the extremely low cost.

For years, I've been encountering academic gibberish-speak and wondering what the hell it meant.  You know, the whole "heteronormative society's hegemonic structures establish a paradigm of rationalistic male imperialistic spheres of racist Othering that transformates the cognitive self as selfness into a  ... blah blah blah"  Well, it turns out that it doesn't mean anything; it is, in fact, gibberish.In this informative, entertaining, and eye-opening book, Bawer describes what has happened in universities' Humanities departments, and particularly English Lit. It turns out our kids are not studying quite what we thought they were studying. Apparently, Shakespeare (which some English Lit departments don't teach at all, now) has been replaced by Womens Studies, Black Studies, Chicano Studies, and a slew of other "Studies". When identity politics came to the universities in the 1960s and 1970s, it resulted in new courses and new departments for aggrieved individuals and groups to have organized whine-athons focused on their own victimhood. These courses and departments have attracted a slew of mediocre talent as well as outright frauds, who've strained to achieve academic respectability. To do so, they've developed a pseudo-scientific lingo and body of "theory", which they call critical theory, from whence comes all the vaguely-subversive but basically meaningless gibberish about heternormative hegemonistic imperialism and so forth. Much, if not all, of the so-called "theory" boils down to "We deserve more power and resources and money; give them to us." It's just that such a simple formulation would neither win the argument nor give them the veneer of academic respectability they crave, so an entirely new psuedo-language of post-modernism has been invented. This is not a development to take too lightly, because at hundreds of universities degrees as high as Ph.D.'s are offered in these faux disciplines, sending kids with absolutely no skills, education, or ability to think out into the harsh world of employment and competition.Descriptions of academic conferences that Bower attended while researching this book are hilarious, and must be read and savored. I gave the book to my wife and we were  literally laughing out loud at the pretentious clown-shows going on all over the country, where black lesbian women outrank white lesbian women and both rank under black lesbian Chicano women, who rank less still than a lesbian Chicano handicapped trans-woman. The politically-correct, Marxist-leaning postmodern "theory" movement has driven itself into ideological chaos and mayhem, with a strict pecking order of victimness that ironically contradicts its now-quaint and quite obsolete egalitarian goals, and you will enjoy every page of it. At the same time, the humor is balanced by knowing that this is really happening. Thousands and thousands of students -- young people, who don't know any better -- are being exposed to this nonsense in insular classes and conferences walled off from the real world, creating yet another generation of Marxist parrots who will, like their parents and grandparents, need to learn how to think for themselves. The postmodern theory movement, in which students engage in group therapy sessions and compete to see who is more of a victim for their parents' $50,000 tuition payment per year, is so entrenched in American universities at this point that it will take many, many years to uproot it and replace it with actual educational content. And that is sad. But it's still funny.I highly recommend this book. I got a lot out of it, both in terms of reading entertaining and in terms of learning about something that matters.

My favorite target for target shooting in the 25 to 75 ft. range. They are just a god-send for the 40+ year old eyeball. At distances greater than, say, 40 feet, it's really difficult to monitor accuracy and progress using a traditional paper target, especially with a smaller caliber weapon such as a .22. The colorful splatter when a round hits this target is very easy to see at 50 feet and still possible to make out at 75. I use tons of these and only wish they came in a discounted mega-pack for those of us who blow through a pack or more per month. The 8" width is not really necessary for an experienced shooter at 50-ish feet, and 6" would probably suffice. But it is a good size target for newbies or those trying to extend their range, e.g. from 50 to 75 feet. What you lose in precise measurement for scoring (due to the imprecise splatter at the hole) you make up for in immediate, visible feedback after every shot. Personally, I am happy to give up a small amount of precise scoring in return for the ongoing visible feedback.

Blood of Ironside is the third book in the series "The Lost King" by Martin Lake. I enjoyed the first two books, which told a fictionalized account of the historical figure Edgar the Aetheling.This book, I loved.All three books in the series have Mr Lake's knack for rich characterization and good storytelling. I think if someone put an apple on a table and said to him, "tell me a story about this apple," he could fill a chapter or maybe a whole novel with an imaginative, gripping scenario, filled with colorful characters, that leads, in the end, in a clever way, to the lone apple sitting in front of him. That kind of talent you either have or you don't. Nevertheless, the first two books were loosely-written, without decisive chapter-ending hooks and other traditional devices that propel the reader from page to page. In this book, Mr Lake demonstrates more command and ease with fiction-writing. This book has all of the same elements that make the other books good - richly developed characters and vividly told stories - while bringing a much more polished narrative flow. I simply could not put it down. It is a great yarn.What makes the historical Edgar Aetheling interesting was the momentous, history-changing times in which he lived, and the larger-than-life people he intersected with -- in particular William the Conqueror. Mr Lake's challenge, as I see it, was two-fold: to make Edgar and his band of kin and supporters, of which relatively little is known, into fully developed, compelling characters, but also to bring the huge historical currents alive in a visceral, realistic way for the reader. On both counts, this book is a success. Edgar and his band of merry, grouchy, troubled, desperate, hopeful, despairing men and women are truly good characters, fun to read about, and engaging enough to enjoy quite apart from the larger historical themes. And the book does an exceptional job of bringing you into the times, to see, hear, smell and feel what it was all about, from the very personal level to the geo-strategic and military level. I am already pretty familiar with the times and people with which this book is concerned, and yet feel that I learned quite a bit.Here's one thing I thought was fascinating about the book. William the Conqueror was (obviously) a major historical figure and an interesting, scary person. But I've always thought that the really interesting thing about William was the impact he had on the world and people around him. In one battle, he brought a decisive end to a six-hundred-year old culture and changed the history of Europe. In so doing, he radically impacted whole generations of people, from the lords to the peasants. His reach into the lives of others was massive. Lake does an exceptional job of articulating how this reach played itself out in so many ways, forcing difficult moral choices on people and forcing them to choose loyalties, pick sides, and even fight against each other. A battle scene toward the end of the book, where Edgar realizes he must fight and kill his own Englishmen, brilliantly brings forth the kind of conflicted, tortured-soul conflict that a game-changing person like William forces onto others. That, I believe, is the true accomplishment of this book.It's a very fun, well-written book and totally worth buying and reading. I highly recommend it.

The writer provided me with a copy of this work for review, and I was pleased to read it. It provides a concise overview of the Battle of Agincourt in 1415. It's quite short and therefore is not going to go into the kind of detail some might like. However, taken on its own merits, it was interesting and informative. I give credit to the writer for bringing a visceral, ground-level view of the battle alive for the reader in an unusually small number of pages. Actually, I can't think of a better way to get up to speed on a complex event like Agincourt in 15 or 20 minutes. Kudos to the author for having kind of an interesting idea about a new way to present information. It could've used a few more numbers to round out the visceral battle narrative, though. What'd be really interesting would be a collection of about thirty of these short one-day-in-history narratives, pulled together into a big, thick book on the seminal days of history. I think he'd have a real winner there.

There is a lot of hype surrounding this relatively new-to-market cleaning product, which happens to cost four times as much as some perfectly acceptable alternatives, but I can report that the hype is legit. I did the same test some others have done: I took a Glock 19 apart, and cleaned it thoroughly with my other cleaning products: Break Free CLP, Slip, Hoppes 9, etc. When it appeared there was no further carbon remaining on the pieces, I then cleaned the gun again with FireClean.  That resulted in a filthy towel full of carbon, meaning that FireClean had scrubbed crap off the gun that nothing else could reach. This test confirmed to me that Fireclean does what the hype claims. I think it is one of the best cleaning products on the market, and maybe the best.It leaves a nice smooth sheen on surfaces after you've applied it. My local gun smith says he applies CLP *after* FireClean, for another layer of lube and protection, but to my eyes FireClean seems to provide the appropriate amount of lubrication on its own, and the company's directions say not to use other products with it.I believe two products are still needed when using FireClean: a copper solvent, and perhaps a strong bore cleaner like Hoppes 9, for the barrel. For everything else, I think FireClean can get the job done on its own. I still have an open question about whether FireClean provides enough lubrication for a bolt carrier group. It doesn't give you that "wet" look that some folks are used to giving their bolts, but it does give all the parts a clean, smooth, slippery surface, which might actually be better. Time will tell. For a long time I have simply put all the parts of a bolt carrier group into a bowl, soaked them in strong solvent, then soaked them in Remington gun oil. I am not sure I'm going to change that formula, despite Fireclean probably being sufficient. Bolts are not really the place for experimentation.A really nice feature of FireClean is that it has no smell and is non-toxic. I cleaned the G19 at my kitchen table with the windows closed. My wife didn't complain. It's great to clean a gun without those toxic smells and that nagging question in the back of your mind of whether you've just knocked a few months off your life span. Even if FireClean were mediocre at cleaning, the lack of toxicity and odor would still be a strong argument for its use. But it is far from a mediocre product.Even at its absurdly high price, this product is worth it, but I do hope that after the inventors have made enough coin to be satisfied, they will bring the cost down.

I was sent one of these for review, and I have to say, it's a pretty impressive little tool. I tested it on a variety of offending small and medium branches in my garden, and it made short work of them. Just hold the handles and pull back and forth, and voila!, branches gone. I was surprised at how thick a branch this thing could work its way through. Of course, it cannot compete with a real chainsaw, but that isn't its purpose. It is a very nice little addition to the gardening tool bag, and can do double-duty in the survival duffle bag too. It comes in a tidy, compact little case that goes right on a belt, making it extra-convenient. I like it a lot and would've been happy to buy one if I had known about it and hadn't been sent one for review. Five stars.Disclosure: Occasionally, I am sent a book or product for review. I do not accept any form of compensation for writing a review, and I make it clear in advance that my review will be based on my honest opinion, which may be positive or negative.

This is a pretty nice range bag, although I wouldn't call it "deluxe". It's actually fairly small, relative to most range bags. It can fit 2 guns, a few boxes of ammo, ear and eye protection, and some small (8 or 10 ") targets; that's about it. Aside from its diminutive dimensions, the only thing I don't like about it is that the side pockets (there are four total) don't have much in the way of interior pockets or straps; there is a net inside one of them, which will hold a few magazines, but other than that, they're just empty pockets. Those critiques aside, I have several range bags and this tends to be one I use frequently when I'm just hitting the range for an hour with a gun or two for practice. For a more extensive or complex outing, I use something larger. This bag is well made with a good adjustable shoulder strap.

This book and two-CD set is probably the best thing out there for self-taught people to pick up enough Old English to muddle through that ancient language.I decided to try to learn Old English on my own, with no classes, and no previous coursework. I ended up buying about ten different books. Honestly, I found most of them really terrible -- pedantic, too difficult, overwhelming, and demoralizing. In some cases I had no idea why the person even bothered putting together the book, other than to have a book to sell, since it was plainly obvious that no one could accomplish the objective of learning Old English from it.But this one is different. It takes an organic, versus grammatical approach, which -- your mileage may vary -- I just find a lot better suited to the independent adult learner. I did one chapter a day for a while. None of them were overwhelming, and I gradually got a sense of what the language was about. Lots of cultural and historical stuff is included in the chapters to keep it interesting, which is a big, big, big deal for language study: it gets very tiring, very fast, to memorize verb tables and so forth, no matter how motivated you are. This book seemed to be going at the pace I could deal with: fast enough to learn stuff, without making me put it down to clear my head. I learned a lot about Anglo Saxon culture, in addition to the language.I sadly am dinging it a star for the rather bizarre audio recordings.  There are two speakers, female and male.  The female's voice is crystal clear, loud, and very easy to understand.  The male's voice, though, is muffled, lower in volume, and extremely hard to hear and understand. He's a mumbler, and even his words in modern English are barely comprehensible - sometimes they cannot be heard or understood at all. It seems to me that if the whole purpose of a disk is for people to hear words distinctly, then someone should've listened in the product development phase and said, "Speak up!." I am only dinging one star, because the audio recordings are not essential to the package, and you can get a flavor of the language from the woman's voice parts. If the audio was much more essential to the total learning experience of this package, I'd have dinged it a lot more than one star.That one complaint aside, I do think this is by far the easiest and most accessible thing out there for learning some Old English independently. And it does give you a jump-start if you then want to tackle some of the more complex books and learning tools out there.

Yeah, yeah, I know, made in China. And it took four weeks for them to arrive. But they fit perfectly, they're comfortable (even though the description says "oval" they are elongated egg-shaped, which is actually what you want so they are wider at the bottom where the most weight is concentrated on your nose), and for cryin' out loud they're less than three bucks for a zillion of them including postage. Assuming your glasses do in fact take the push-in pads (look at the opposite side of the pad and see if the pad passes through a metal or plastic rectangle about 2mm x 7mm), they're an incredible value.

Purchased as a replacement for an Exerpeutic recumbent bike, which I had a terrible "in-warranty" experience with (in-warranty in theory perhaps, but requiring me to send the entire bike back at my expense without even offering to troubleshoot or fix locally was a non-starter). Ironically I kept the Exerpeutic - the seat half, anyway - and parked the MagneTrainer in front of it.I had previously purchased the MagneTrainer's little sister, the much smaller DeskCycle, and this is mostly the source of my one star off. That's because the manufacturer makes great play out of how the two units use the same mechanism. Except, that's not entirely true: while the basic magnetic resistance machinery may indeed be identical (I haven't disassembled them to find out), in practice the DeskCycle functions differently - and better. On the DeskCycle, the resistance adjustment knob cycles through a series of positive detents, with a readout (under a clear panel on the top of the unit) showing you exactly what level you are on. With the MagneTrainer, there's just a spinning knob with no indication of where it is set to. This makes it rather frustrating to try to repeat an exercise cycle or to cool down consistently (the latter exacerbated by the knob being too low to easily reach and change "on the fly," a problem shared with the DeskCycle). It just spins.And spins, and spins. Because while on the DeskCycle the entire workout range is within eight clicks and one revolution of the resistance adjustment knob, it takes nearly five full rotations of the knob on the MagneTrainer to go from minimum to maximum resistance. I suspect this is the root cause of some of the one- and two-star reviews of customers claiming they don't see any change in resistance; it is not at all obvious that the user is expected to keep spinning the knob round and round to change resistance.The pedals are awfully small, but they double as hand cranks so I won't hold that against them. It accepts standard 9/16" pedals so you can always put a regular bike pedal on them. By the way, after a few workouts my left pedal started to clunk every time it passed the 5 o'clock position. An email to the manufacturer returned an almost immediate reply with a suggestion and an offer to have a local shop fix it for free if need be. The suggestion worked - skip the cheap wrench included with the MagneTrainer and put a big regular crescent wrench on the pedal and really crank it down = now totally silent - but the offer to have somebody local fix it WITHOUT ME EVEN ASKING (what a concept!) was a major confidence booster after my prior bad experience with their competitor.The other problem is the slipping around on the floor issue that every reviewer complains about...but I found a 100% fix. Nearly all of my rooms, including my gym, have carpets and none of them are shag; my upstairs are flat carpet tiles and the gym has industrial outdoor-type mats. On a hunch, I verified that the "hook" side of a piece of Velcro sticks quite nicely to the carpet. I bought a two-pack of 1"x 2" Velcro (available on Amazon but cheaper at Home Depot), cut the two pieces in half, and stuck just the four hook sides to the bottom of the MagneTrainer feet. Perfect fit and the unit now does not budge a millimeter under the highest resistance, even without being careful to "pedal downwards" as they recommend in the instructions.EDIT: the glue on the Velcro gave way, but I had a fix for that too: a staple at the front and rear edges, going into the rubber pad.As for the rest...one slightly disconcerting thing is that when pedaling at high resistance I can see the resistance adjustment knob drifting from left to right to left as I pedal, but I have not noticed anything bad as a result and at least at first glance, the entire unit seems extremely solid (a property shared with the DeskCycle) compared to other mini exercise bikes. The unit has outstanding resistance and is virtually silent (its plastic body creaked a bit when I finished re-installing the left pedal, but that was because I had shoved it to one side by pushing against it while tightening down the pedal; once I straightened it back out, no further noise). EDIT: the "creak" keeps coming back, so I removed the body. That was a pain, so down another half a star. Now that the body is off, I see why the knob drifts left and right: the pedals and pulleys are located between two vertical pieces of sheet metal and they flex a bit as the pedals rotate.It has almost, but not quite, as wide a traveling diameter as the Exerpeutic (i.e. as a regular road bicycle) and provides very good range of motion, much more than the DeskCycle.  Be aware that the readout is useless for accurate calorie count (it does not account for resistance level, which while theoretically possible for the DeskCycle is obviously impossible for the MagneTrainer for the reasons described above). I confirmed this by pedaling one mile at both the minimum and maximum (whoof!) resistances and both read 25 calories. Distance and/or time are what you'll be using in practice. At least with the DeskCycle you'd be able to guesstimate but with no indication of the resistance on the MagneTrainer you can forget calculating calories.So a very well made unit and a responsive company. What's not to like? Oh right, the lack of discrete resistance levels, the resistance knob not being mounted high so you can reach it without stopping, and inability to count calories. Well, there's always the hope of a version 2. Meanwhile, the MagneTrainer is a great bike and a great bargain.

Well, at least this Nebo has the tip on the end that allows it to reach into the recess of a car lighter jack (which so far seems to be the standard on every U.S. car and most foreign cars as well, probably to keep kids with lawsuit-happy parents from jamming their fingers into the jack and frying something). I mention that because the first Nebo I bought (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00UL9XY7Q?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00) didn't have that tip and therefore cannot charge at all. That one got two stars from me as a nice light that is impossible to recharge = useless. This one does recharge but the spring on the side is far too weak and unless for some reason you have a jack that is angled upwards (against gravity) the flashlight works itself loose over every little bump and stops charging. I have to constantly keep pushing it back into the socket. So three stars for a nice light that is difficult to recharge = annoying.

Does not work with the lighter outlet in any of several Fords, and I'm just about willing to bet any other U.S.-manufactured automobile. Foreign cars? Don't know but would not recommend taking the chance. Every lighter jack I've examined has the positive contact recessed inside a well, probably to keep children from jamming their fingers and other things into it, and this flashlight lacks the tip (that's present on EVERY SINGLE lighter plug) to fit into it. Since the big disc on the end of this will only work with some (non-recessed) jacks and a plug with a tip will work with 100% of all jacks, it does make one wonder what they were thinking when they designed this.By they way I wound up buying the Nebo that DOES have the tip (also on Amazon) and not too thrilled with it either - nice (albeit non-adjustable) light but constantly creeps out of the jack and disconnects so it stops charging. But at least it can be charged, unlike this one.

Fairly simple setup, and works. Situation: recently "cut the cord" by canceling Cablevision and turning in the CableCard to my Ceton 4-tuner USB box. The thing is, I discovered entirely by accident that even though I no longer paid for cable TV, I actually still received the local channels - they must be included with the internet service, but Cablevision doesn't exactly go out of their way to advertise that (they would have gladly had me pay $12.95 a month for channels I already get). But even though technically I could get them, the Ceton was just terrible at receiving them; it would get confused (especially when trying to record two things at once) and required a laborious reset and rescan process. Don't get me wrong, the Ceton is a fabulous five-star device when running off CableCard, I suspect they never thought anybody would ever use it for ClearQAM cable signals and so while it technically lists QAM as one of its capabilities, it doesn't look like they put much effort into it (and yes I have all the latest drivers and firmware). I found a Microsoft Windows 7 patch whose description indicated it was what I needed, but I kept getting the helpful message "This update is not applicable."So I replaced it with the HDHomeRun, but not without some trepidation: according to the product description, I had no reason to think it would work at all! For starters, according to the product comparison table it is SD not HD: yes, but only when you are using it wirelessly; a PC or laptop that is hardwired to the network receives glorious HD just fine. And more importantly, according to the Amazon product description it MUST be connected to an antenna. It's even repeated right on the box: Antenna >required<. Except that it's not: "antenna or television cable carrying QAM signal required" would be more accurate.The instructions tell you to log onto SiliconDust's web site to download the drivers and set things up, so hopefully they will stay in business (I filed away the driver for a rainy day). And getting ClearQAM to work was a bit of an [undocumented] hassle: first set up the channels ON THE WEB SITE (EDIT: or, as I accidentally discovered, the Home Run program that the setup will install on your desktop), and then and only then go into Media Center and run TV signal setup, otherwise you get a Tuner Not Found error. All in all it took about an hour to set up, although most of that time consisted of the Web Site and then Media Center scanning for channels and I didn't have to be in front of the PC during that time. And worth the effort: unlike the Ceton, the HomeRun instantly switches from channel to channel and it has thus far faithfully recorded my local shows. (EDIT: once in a great while it pops up a "cannot record" or "tuner busy" message even though only one other thing was being recorded or watched. I have Media Center set to start recording several minutes in advance and while the message is a bit disconcerting, so far I don't think it has actually failed to record a show, I think it just keeps trying until whatever the error is clears itself.) And unlike the Ceton, it's on my home network so it can be used by any of my computers.Speaking of which, one of the selling points is that it will also transmit wirelessly to any device, including phones and tablets (SD only for this particular version, it appears they have another model that does wireless HD as well). I have not tried that, because not mentioned in the instructions or product description is that you must first download the SiliconDust app to your tablet - and it is >not< free!Five stars for functionality, a star off for being a bit confusing and misleading. If my main use was going to be to watch TV on my tablet I would have knocked another star off for price gouging: everything needed for the gizmo to do what it is advertised to do should be included in the price or at least make it absolutely clear up front that you are going to be required to spend more money to get the functionality they're advertising.

Dry, so that should be taken into account in recipes. I would not for example make tacos with it, but mixed in with a base that contains fat (say sour cream or butter), just fine. I use it to supplement the excellent Hormel refrigerated pork, which is delicious but whose drippings are overwhelming on their own. Fried tomatillos and onions in garlic and olive oil, tomatoes and black olives, a can white chili beans and a little can of chopped chilies, cumin, lots of oregano and cilantro, Hormel fresh pork and part of the drippings as the main meat (hint: pour the rest into the rice and you won't need to salt the rice), and a can of Keystone mushed up (you can do it by hand, no chopping necessary - that consistency might be a turnoff for some and makes it inappropriate for some recipes), as the base.Top with sour cream and serve on yellow rice. Just Heaven.Ridiculously expensive to ship, but as of this writing it's part of the Amazon add-on program with free shipping as part of another order, and that makes it competitive with supermarket prices. I suspect that if I could find it in a supermarket that would be a bit cheaper, but since no supermarket in my area carries it, I'm glad that Amazon does!

As noted by other, cheap construction but hey, sixty bucks. But also, mine was sloppily assembled - the three internal braces hold the motor so that the blades don't contact anything, and the motor was at an angle so ironically the blades whacked right into one of the very braces holding it. I realize that for $60 they're not going to do a "burn in" on each unit, but all it took was just to spin the blade with a finger and they'd have known it wasn't assembled correctly. Do what the assembler failed to do - SPIN THE FAN BY HAND before you install it! Loosened the three screws squeezing the motor, gave the blades the aforementioned spin, and tightened the screws back down with no additional drama.One odd thing is that it does not come with the little screw-on pass-through clamp that holds your feed wire securely in the hole entering the thermostat box, so if you are buying to replace an old unit make sure to confiscate that clamp assembly from your old fan first. Instead of building something fancy out of plywood, I bought a $5 18"x24" sheet of corrugated plastic at Home Depot, used a carpet knife to cut a circle out of it, slide it over the housing, and once the fan brackets were screwed in I just used a staple gun to tack the edges of the plastic sheet against the attic frame. It was close to 100 degrees outside today and I would guess about 140 degrees in the peak of the attic where I was working, so I was eager to finish the installation as quickly as possible and very happy when I was able to energize the fan and get some air moving.Because the housing is way way cheaper than my old fan (which had an honest-to-goodness formed shroud. not just a piece of bent sheet metal), it easily comes "out of round" so before you put in that last bracket screw, give the fan a last spin by hand to make sure it still has clearance.Noisy, but honestly no more so than the one it replaced (um, I mean before its bearings gave out, of course - screeeetch!) which was a surprise because my old fan had "real" fan blades while this had, again, just pieces of sheet metal for blades. I bypassed the thermostat (the thermostat is not actually wired up out of the box) so cannot speak to its function, I'm fine with just the on/off switch in my bathroom.Not expecting it to last forever but if it lasts ten years I'll be both pleased and surprised. Looks like a good value for the money, just don't expect a Cadillac.

As of this date, Amazon product description says 7-1/2 inches but in fact is is 11 inches - in other words, the same as any regular (not Mini or Large) spatula. Well-made and works well for larger pans, but since I needed a small spatula for a couple of mini skillets, a star off for incorrect size statement. See comment for note about the vendor.

Was extremely nervous about this for two reasons.1. Excessively, incredibly large number of pixels equals excessively, incredibly high likelihood of dead or stuck pixels. I hate 'em. It's...lessee...width times height...carry the one...just shy of FIVE MILLION pixels. Well, your mileage may vary, but mine had no pixel problems whatsoever. I have to stress that: not a single bad pixel out of five million. Wow.2. Excessively, incredibly large number of pixels equals excessively, incredibly high burden on graphics adapter. Now I will admit that I had not bought a computer in a long time but my brand-new Ultrabox (formerly known as Hush PC) is a completely silent model, meaning no fans; so while it is the "newest generation" it is also not running at nearly whatever speed the latest and greatest are capable of. Didn't matter; hooked up through DisplayPort and alongside (I realize how disgusting this must sound) a partner 1920x1080P touchscreen on HDMI (yes I really do use both, more on that in a moment), I'm still able to pump full out 3440x1440x60Hz and play full-screen 1080 videos without a hitch.Having said that, there are some issues. The first is with the DisplayPort itself: I have sound piped through the Envy by default, but about one out of six times the sound instead directs through the sister monitor. Control Panel insists that the Envy is disconnected. Not disabled; disconnected. Unplugging the DisplayPort cable and plugging back in instantly solves the problem. I don't think there is going to be a retroactive fix for that, hopefully they will at least find and fix the bug causing this going forward. By the way, you could simply use HDMI but at this resolution and this version of HDMI (1.2 I believe) it will only manage 30Hz at full resolution. For some that may be okay but kind of defeats the purpose of such a high resolution monitor. Before you ask, yes I tried running just the Envy by itself, but still about one in six times it had no audio connection. EDIT: I've now tried two different DisplayPort cables with the same issue, so it does look like this is a bug inside the Envy; it could be the video card or its drivers, but then that wouldn't explain why the sound then works on HDMI.My video adapter cannot put out 4K so I can't speak to how the Envy deals with such ultrahigh resolutions, but 3440x1440 is just a tad shy of 4K anyway.Color is generally excellent, but you get a LOT of light bleed along the bottom. Only noticeable when the entire screen is very dark. Oddly, I get a bad gamma problem when Windows is booting up (screen picture way too bright and way too little contrast) but a few seconds after displaying the desktop it fixes itself - usually. This is of course a Windows thing but it no doubt comes from Windows and the Envy handshaking and once in a great while it never does fix itself. Again, unplugging and re-plugging the DisplayPort cable does the trick.The curve is actually really good. I thought I wanted a seriously curved monitor to get a wraparound effect. I now realize that the monitor does not appear curved at all - it looks like it is perfectly flat and straight, which of course means the curve is doing exactly what it should.Sound is excellent, but the volume control is really annoying. It's a physical rotating wheel under the left bezel, and you have to turn it to raise the volume. And turn. And turn some more. It should be literally ten times more sensitive than it is. I just keep it cranked (no buzzing or hissing) and use Windows to control the volume.Okay, I know you're wondering why on Earth I need a second monitor with something as huge as the Envy, so I'll explain: I play Flight Simulator, turn virtual cockpit off, and drag the instrument panel over to the other monitor and resize it to fit. Now I have an completely uninterrupted (and HUGE) view of my surroundings in front of me, and my instrument panel is on the smaller monitor - which is a touchscreen, so I can actually click buttons and spin wheels with my fingers. I use Megascenary's photorealistic (actual photographs) scenery and get good refresh rates; I am told that if I was using the autogenerated scenery (the fake scenery that comes with Flight Simulator) then I would need a much more powerful computer with a screen as big as the Envy.Like pretty much every modern monitor, you can plug this into a USB port and use it as a USB hub/extender. But the extension USB ports are in a terrible location, about dead center of the back, requiring you to crawl around to get to them. Why not near or even along the side like other monitors?It can be set to kill the power if the screen goes blank, so you can use your power-off screensaver or a third-party program (I use the excellent little "Wizmo" and tie it to a hotkey) and the monitor will power itself off after a few seconds. You might think all monitors do this, but it's hit and miss with some brands so I thought I'd mention it.Running Windows 7 or 8 you can really take advantage of the "drag windows to the side and watch Windows resize window to exactly fill half the screen" feature. Looks great running two applications side-by-side and the Windows 7/8 snap-to-side feature makes it, well, a snap. One unusual use of this is if you have older programs that simply will not run in Win7 and have to run in the "Virtual XP" mode. You can drag your Windows XP Mode window over to the right side of the Envy and Windows will resize it to fill the right side of the screen - and because the Envy has so much real estate, it's like you have a complete Windows XP system sitting side-by-side with Windows 7.Finally, I get some horizontal tearing playing large or full-screen videos. I have not yet determined if that's the Envy or a video adapter or driver issue. It's not a showstopper in any event, only noticeable on occasion.At this price, unless you have an older computer coupled to an older graphics adapter, you really don't have an excuse not to buy one.

Awesome crunchiness, a lot of air but feels satisfyingly filling. Just great. Oh, and they don't snap in half while dipping them like regular flat Doritos. Not too sure about spending $10 a bag or whatever ridiculous amount Amazon vendors are charging right now, but at three bucks, go for it. Tip: great (and even worse for you ;-) ) dipped in sour cream!

Purchased for an office chair, pressed into emergency service for a portable dishwasher whose wheels were too high to allow it to fit under a counter. MUCH better made than the plastic set I had previously purchased, which disintegrated when I tried to remove them with a crowbar.

First, make sure you shop around. I got mine from the website of that big chain that starts with W and ends in Mart, $100 less than the best price I could find on Amazon and free shipping to the store. Wow.1. Absolutely true that it is very quiet. The review that you have to be standing right next to it in order to hear it is, in my opinion, a bit of hyperbole, but subjectively about a third the noise created by my old Kenmore (Whirlpool in disguise).2. Also true that it does not completely dry dishes. Once the unit beeps (more on that in a moment) to tell you it's done, crack the door open so the steam can escape.3. And yes, it's true that it takes forever to complete a cycle. But here's the thing: it uses very little water (again, about a third as much as the Kenmore) and incidentally, about a third as much detergent; obviously, they have traded water volume for cycle time. Does it really matter that a dishwasher takes longer? I guess if you really needed a full-size dishwasher but couldn't make room for it so you need to turn around several cycles back-to-back in order to wash all of your dishes, that could be a consideration. But if all you really needed in the first place was an 18", who cares if it takes two hours instead of one hour, especially if it is using less water, less detergent, and (according to the Energy Star rating) less electricity?4. Eight place settings? Of what, dollhouse dishes? Now that one *IS* hyperbole. The owner's manual shows a picture of the rack filled to the gills, plates and bowls facing down. Yes, it is possible to fill the rack from one side to the other with plates and bowls...and quite impossible to then slide the rack into the dishwasher and close the door. If you go by the owner's manual, then the tines by the left side of the rack are there only for show: you cannot actually put anything there or they will overhang the side of the rack. Oddly, one of the pictures in one of the several Amazon product pages for this unit shows the rack filled with bowls and plates facing UP, in which case you can in fact fill the rack...but that contradicts the owner's manual! (I tried washing dishes with the plates facing up and it does in fact work, so is the manual wrong?)The upshot is that this is a four-place setting washer and a bit tight even for that.  This unit is fine for two people washing dishes every several days, or a family of four washing daily, but that's it. They have compensated to some extent by very carefully engineering the small interior - the smallest interior of a standing dishwasher I have ever seen, probably to make room for the extra insulation that makes it so quiet and energy efficient - to maximize what you can get in, but the special bowl holders and flip-down mug rack aren't going to help when you have a giant salad bowl or anything else unusual in size to wash. The good news is that because the top rack has its own independent spray arm - a standard feature in 24" washers but fairly uncommon in a compact portable (neither of my Kenmores had one) - you can get away with piling one or two large items on top of other dishes in the top rack; presuming they're flat enough to still slide the rack back in, they'll come out clean.Speaking of the owner's manual, it fails to provide some useful bits of information. I had the devil of a time trying to figure out how to wash wine glasses; I use the excellent Quirky Tethers (do a search) and was frustrated by the fact that the bottom rack has large areas with no supporting wire running underneath (so on one side of the tines a wine glass has something to sit on, but on the other side they'd just fall through). It turns out that there is a dedicated place for wine glasses: the left side of the top rack (the aforementioned mug rack) also doubles as a wine glass stem holder, with special inserts to fit the stems into, holding the glass at a downwards angle (doing so means you can't fit any mugs underneath, but you can put mugs on the right side of the top rack). You can fit four regular wine glasses or three jumbo Riedels. That's great, but there is zero mention of this in the owner's manual; I figured it out by accident while Googling "dishwasher wine rack" and saw a photo of this exact same solution...on the website of one of Danby's competitors!5. It does a GREAT job of washing dishes. I tried a "regular" wash cycle with maximum detergent (hint: don't fill the entire detergent dispenser, you fill either the left side for small loads or the right side for big loads, not both) and dishes and utensils with caked-on food and everything came out sparkling. I haven't tried non-soaked, baked-on food yet but there is a pots-n-pans cycle for that. The very long soak pre-wash may be to credit for this. I was highly skeptical of the unusual silverware basket, in which forks and spoons go in handle-down: with most of the water pressure wasted on the handle and the plastic holder itself, how can it do a good job of cleaning the business end of the silverware? But it does.Here's another helpful tip not covered in the manual: if silverware has to go in the special basket that holds each fork and spoon facing up, then where on Earth do you put utensils? In turns out that the special silverware basket is actually two trays side-by-side, the tops of which can be unclipped and removed to reveal a conventional dishwasher silverware basket underneath. I removed one top, put my utensils on that side, and continued to put ordinary silverware on the side with the special holder top. Big utensils like spatulas you'll have to lay down in the top rack, but that's true of all but the biggest of dishwashers anyway.6. I use my portables as a sort-of built-in: I slide it under a counter and hook it up to the hot water and drain under the sink. This is one big star off as I discovered to my horror that the water feed hose is connected directly to the solenoid valve at the bottom of the unit (held on by a oetiker clamp, non-removable). This is unlike any dishwasher I have ever seen and means that you cannot simply remove the portable hose and screw on a replacement or an extension (and the portable hose is short, about 1 meter). It also means that if that hose ever leaks, you're screwed. In exchanges with other posters here on Amazon it appears that earlier versions *DID* have a screw-off hose and that is a huge move down in flexibility and long-term reliability. How much does a washing machine hose fitting cost, wholesale? Fifty cents? Shame on you, Danby. Anyway, I sliced the permanently-attached hoses in half with a carpet knife (voiding the warranty, no doubt, while a screw-on hose would mean I could just put the old hose back on if needed) and, with great trepidation, connected it to the push-on compression line I had coming off my hot water line with an adapter and barb fitting from Home Depot, secured by a radiator hose clamp. Not a drop of leakage, which leads me to...7. ...Superior solenoid design. My old dishwasher, and its predecessor, and every washing machine I have ever owned, had plunger-type solenoid valves: one moment it's on, the next moment it's off. You know what I'm talking about: the dishwasher or washing machine makes a huge CLUNK sound as the water comes on or off. That creates a momentary spike in the pressure inside the hose and can cause anything short of a perfect seal to leak and eventually fail. The Danby valve opens and closes more slowly, preventing that sudden thump. Hence, no leaks at my jury-rigged hose connection.4. Eight place settings? Of what, dollhouse dishes? Now that one *IS* hyperbole. The owner's manual shows a picture of the rack filled to the gills, plates and bowls facing down. Yes it is possible to fill the rack from one side to the other with plates and bowls...and quite impossible to then slide the rack into the dishwasher and close the door. If you go by the owner's manual, then the tines by the left side of the rack are there only for show: you cannot actually put anything there or they will overhang the side of the rack. Oddly, one of the pictures in one of the several Amazon product pages for this unit shows the rack filled with bowls and plates facing UP, in which case you can in fact fill the rack...but that contradicts the owner's manual! (I tried washing dishes with the plates facing up and it does in fact work, so is the manual wrong?).The upshot is that this is a four-place setting washer and a bit tight even for that.  This unit is fine for two people washing dishes every several days, or a family of four washing daily, but that's it.They have compensated to some extent by very carefully engineering the small interior - the smallest interior of a standing dishwasher I have ever seen, probably to make room for the extra insulation that makes it so quiet and energy efficient - to maximize what you can get in, but the special bowl holders and flip-down mug rack aren't going to help when you have a giant salad bowl or anything else unusual in size to wash. The good news is that because the top rack has its own independent spray arm - a standard feature in 24" washers but fairly uncommon in a compact portable (neither of my Kenmores had one) - you can get away with piling one or two large items on top of other dishes in the top rack; presuming they're flat enough to still slide the rack back in, they'll come out clean.Speaking of the owner's manual, it fails to provide some useful bits of information. I had the devil of a time trying to figure out how to wash wine glasses; I use the excellent Quirky Tethers (do a search) and was frustrated by the fact that the bottom rack has large areas with no supporting wire running underneath (so on one side of the tines a wine glass has something to sit on, but on the other side they'd just fall through). It turns out that there is a dedicated place for wine glasses: the left side of the top rack (the aforementioned mug rack) also doubles as a wine glass stem holder, with special inserts to fit the stems into, holding the glass at a downwards angle (doing so means you can't fit any mugs underneath, but you can put mugs on the right side of the top rack). You can fit four regular wine glasses or three jumbo Riedels. That's great, but there is zero mention of this in the owner's manual; I figured it out by accident while Googling "dishwasher wine rack" and saw a photo of this exact same solution...on the website of one of Danby's competitors!8. It would not fit under the counter on its wheels. It is not obvious how to remove the wheels; what you do is push a large flat screwdriver in perpendicularly at the top and push off the slip rings that hold them in place. Removing the wheels creates a new problem: the Danby cannot sit on the floor without wheels, because it has an irregular bottom. But inboard of the wheels there is another set of holes, I'm guessing put there for the undercabinet version so both models can share the same chassis. It turns out that a set of flat office chair feet fit perfectly; I used these:  <http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00CF06M1O/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1>. They'll wobble a bit when the dishwasher is flipped over, but once you set the dishwasher down they're rock solid. They'll need a nudge to get them to go into the holes, one tap of a mallet or a hammer will do.9. Water is not heated during pre-rinse; but it is heated during main wash cycle. I verified this by running it off just cold water and checking the temperature at various points during the wash. The pre-rinse stayed ice cold but the wash water warmed up over time until it was steaming hot. Not hot right at the start so it does not pre-heat like some dishwashers, but with such long cycles that shouldn't make a difference.10. It beeps.
