It beeps when you start it, it beeps every minute when the door is open to remind you to close it and start the cycle, and it beeps a bunch of times when it's finished. And no, you can't turn the beep off. Grr. At least it's not a particularly loud beep.In conclusion, some compromises (and some extra-frustratingly the result of rather short-sighted decisions by Danby that are really unnecessary), but does a very good job of washing dishes, is very quiet, and - if you shop around - is an outstanding bargain.

First, make sure you shop around. I got mine from the website of that big chain that starts with W and ends in Mart, $100 less than the best price I could find on Amazon and free shipping to the store. Wow. EDIT: as of this moment I see prices for this on Amazon range from $550 (gulp!) to >>$85<< - but that $85 doesn't include the additional $350 shipping. And this item has several different listings on Amazon. So like I said: shop around!1. Absolutely true that it is very quiet. The review that you have to be standing right next to it in order to hear it is, in my opinion, a bit of hyperbole, but subjectively about a third the noise created by my old Kenmore (Whirlpool in disguise).2. Also true that it does not completely dry dishes. Once the unit beeps (more on that in a moment) to tell you it's done, crack the door open so the steam can escape.3. And yes, it's true that it takes forever to complete a cycle. But here's the thing: it uses very little water (again, about a third as much as the Kenmore) and incidentally, about a third as much detergent; obviously, they have traded water volume for cycle time. Does it really matter that a dishwasher takes longer? I guess if you really needed a full-size dishwasher but couldn't make room for it so you need to turn around several cycles back-to-back in order to wash all of your dishes, that could be a consideration. But if all you really needed in the first place was an 18", who cares if it takes two hours instead of one hour, especially if it is using less water, less detergent, and (according to the Energy Star rating) less electricity?4. Eight place settings? Of what, dollhouse dishes? Now that one *IS* hyperbole. The owner's manual shows a picture of the rack filled to the gills, plates and bowls facing down. Yes, it is possible to fill the rack from one side to the other with plates and bowls...and quite impossible to then slide the rack into the dishwasher and close the door. If you go by the owner's manual, then the tines by the left side of the rack are there only for show: you cannot actually put anything there or they will overhang the side of the rack. Oddly, one of the pictures in one of the several Amazon product pages for this unit shows the rack filled with bowls and plates facing UP, in which case you can in fact fill the rack...but that contradicts the owner's manual! (I tried washing dishes with the plates facing up and it does in fact work, so is the manual wrong?)The upshot is that this is a four-place setting washer and a bit tight even for that.  This unit is fine for two people washing dishes every several days, or a family of four washing daily, but that's it. They have compensated to some extent by very carefully engineering the small interior - the smallest interior of a standing dishwasher I have ever seen, probably to make room for the extra insulation that makes it so quiet and energy efficient - to maximize what you can get in, but the special bowl holders and flip-down mug rack aren't going to help when you have a giant salad bowl or anything else unusual in size to wash. The good news is that because the top rack has its own independent spray arm - a standard feature in 24" washers but fairly uncommon in a compact portable (neither of my Kenmores had one) - you can get away with piling one or two large items on top of other dishes in the top rack; presuming they're flat enough to still slide the rack back in, they'll come out clean.Speaking of the owner's manual, it fails to provide some useful bits of information. I had the devil of a time trying to figure out how to wash wine glasses; I use the excellent Quirky Tethers (do a search) and was frustrated by the fact that the bottom rack has large areas with no supporting wire running underneath (so on one side of the tines a wine glass has something to sit on, but on the other side they'd just fall through). It turns out that there is a dedicated place for wine glasses: the left side of the top rack (the aforementioned mug rack) also doubles as a wine glass stem holder, with special inserts to fit the stems into, holding the glass at a downwards angle (doing so means you can't fit any mugs underneath, but you can put mugs on the right side of the top rack). You can fit four regular wine glasses or three jumbo Riedels. That's great, but there is zero mention of this in the owner's manual; I figured it out by accident while Googling "dishwasher wine rack" and saw a photo of this exact same solution...on the website of one of Danby's competitors!5. It does a GREAT job of washing dishes. I tried a "regular" wash cycle with maximum detergent (hint: don't fill the entire detergent dispenser, you fill either the left side for small loads or the right side for big loads, not both) and dishes and utensils with caked-on food and everything came out sparkling. I haven't tried non-soaked, baked-on food yet but there is a pots-n-pans cycle for that. The very long soak pre-wash may be to credit for this. I was highly skeptical of the unusual silverware basket, in which forks and spoons go in handle-down: with most of the water pressure wasted on the handle and the plastic holder itself, how can it do a good job of cleaning the business end of the silverware? But it does.Here's another helpful tip not covered in the manual: if silverware has to go in the special basket that holds each fork and spoon facing up, then where on Earth do you put utensils? In turns out that the special silverware basket is actually two trays side-by-side, the tops of which can be unclipped and removed to reveal a conventional dishwasher silverware basket underneath. I removed one top, put my utensils on that side, and continued to put ordinary silverware on the side with the special holder top. Big utensils like spatulas you'll have to lay down in the top rack, but that's true of all but the biggest of dishwashers anyway.6. I use my portables as a sort-of built-in: I slide it under a counter and hook it up to the hot water and drain under the sink. This is one big star off as I discovered to my horror that the water feed hose is connected directly to the solenoid valve at the bottom of the unit (held on by a oetiker clamp, non-removable). This is unlike any dishwasher I have ever seen and means that you cannot simply remove the portable hose and screw on a replacement or an extension (and the portable hose is short, about 1 meter). It also means that if that hose ever leaks, you're screwed. In exchanges with other posters here on Amazon it appears that earlier versions *DID* have a screw-off hose and that is a huge move down in flexibility and long-term reliability. How much does a washing machine hose fitting cost, wholesale? Fifty cents? Shame on you, Danby. Anyway, I sliced the permanently-attached hoses in half with a carpet knife (voiding the warranty, no doubt, while a screw-on hose would mean I could just put the old hose back on if needed) and, with great trepidation, connected it to the push-on compression line I had coming off my hot water line with an adapter and barb fitting from Home Depot, secured by a radiator hose clamp. Not a drop of leakage, which leads me to...7. ...Superior solenoid design. My old dishwasher, and its predecessor, and every washing machine I have ever owned, had plunger-type solenoid valves: one moment it's on, the next moment it's off. You know what I'm talking about: the dishwasher or washing machine makes a huge CLUNK sound as the water comes on or off. That creates a momentary spike in the pressure inside the hose and can cause anything short of a perfect seal to leak and eventually fail. The Danby valve opens and closes more slowly, preventing that sudden thump. Hence, no leaks at my jury-rigged hose connection.8. It would not fit under the counter on its wheels. It is not obvious how to remove the wheels; what you do is push a large flat screwdriver in perpendicularly at the top and push off the slip rings that hold them in place. Removing the wheels creates a new problem: the Danby cannot sit on the floor without wheels, because it has an irregular bottom. But inboard of the wheels there is another set of holes, I'm guessing put there for the undercabinet version so both models can share the same chassis. It turns out that a set of flat office chair feet fit perfectly; I used these:  <http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00CF06M1O/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1>. They'll wobble a bit when the dishwasher is flipped over, but once you set the dishwasher down they're rock solid. They'll need a nudge to get them to go into the holes, one tap of a mallet or a hammer will do.9. Water is not heated during pre-rinse; but it is heated during main wash cycle. I verified this by running it off just cold water and checking the temperature at various points during the wash. The pre-rinse stayed ice cold but the wash water warmed up over time until it was steaming hot. Not hot right at the start so it does not pre-heat like some dishwashers, but with such long cycles that shouldn't make a difference.10. It beeps. It beeps when you start it, it beeps every minute when the door is open to remind you to close it and start the cycle, and it beeps a bunch of times when it's finished. And no, you can't turn the beep off. Grr. At least it's not a particularly loud beep.In conclusion, some compromises (and some extra-frustratingly the result of rather short-sighted decisions by Danby that are really unnecessary), but does a very good job of washing dishes, is very quiet, and - if you shop around - is an outstanding bargain.

The kit itself comes with a variety of sliders and accessories, so good functionality. The mediocre rating is for the instructions - truly worse than useless, and that's a stretch in this age of "Chinenglish" translations. These instructions are in perfect English, clearly written by a native speaker. Too bad the author could not find the time to focus on INSTRUCTIONS. I did not buy this kit to learn about the history of the zipper...but I would genuinely liked to have known how to deduce which of the many styles of Stops to use, and how to install them. I would have liked to have known how to insert the slider (I tried pushing it onto both sides of the zipper at once, tried hand-assembling (!!!) the first inch of the zipper before sliding it on, upon finding that impossible tried against my better judgement inserting both sides into the slide upside down - which worked, but now the zipper unzipped going up instead of going down - turns out that you insert only one side, and that being the side that has the free bottom end), etc. I spent a good 90 minutes figuring all of this out when one picture (of a modern zipper being repaired along with its stop instead of antique zippers I do not and never will need to repair) and one sentence would have had it fixed in 90 seconds. By the way, I did eventually figure out that I could use one type of Stop to simply crimp-on, but the numerous other Stops that have little slotted tabs hanging off...never did figure those out.Here's another hint: Stops are in short supply in this kit, only two of each kind but numerous sliders and pulls so you will run out of Stops right away. Well, at least for a jacket zipper, I discovered (too late) that you don't actually need a stop on the side that doesn't have the slider when unzipped; while the original zipper comes with a Stop on both sides, the second one is just for show. For a jacket (whose zipper comes completely apart, as opposed to say a pair of pants where the two halves of the zipper remain attached to one another at the bottom) it actually wasn't even necessary to remove the original Stop on the non-zipper side; had I known that, I would have left one of the two Stops on in the first place. I could have saved a Stop for later use, and now I don't have another one of that type.
Bit pricey but a pleasant direct replacement for a C7 = not cold-blue like some LEDs. Needed in a tough-to-reach bathroom nightlight fixture and tired of always climbing ladders to replace it.

The current buzzword in home automation is "Z-Wave" technology, in which every single device is a miniature router that can command, receive commands from, and forward commands onto any other device. It follows an industry standard, so every device works with every other device no matter who manufactured it.Or, so they say in the ads. But here's the terrible dark secret: while the HARDWARE may be inter-compatible, the PROGRAMMERS are not - and you have to have a special separate programmer to make them work. And to get two devices made by different manufacturers to work, you need a universal programmer, costing hundreds of dollars, connected to a laptop running a special application, and have been specially trained in the Z-Wave programming language.How did I find out all of this? Take a guess!In the end, I came back to the old (practically ancient, in fact - mid 1980s!), reliable, analog standby, X10. No, I can't push a single button to turn on one thing while it dims another and turns off two other things on the other side of the house...but I didn't really need to. I needed to turn on a ceiling light in my bedroom that I couldn't get to, and this works. They were on different circuits and did not communicate at first, so I had to switch a circuit breaker from one side of the electrical panel to the other. But at least you don't have to be Z-Wave factory-certified to know how to do that. So I got another one to turn the drop lights I just installed in my gym on and off and at the same time turn my flatscreen TV on and off, using the excellent (although oddly shaped) X10 wall-mount keypanel controller, which you can change keypads to and have it control or dim one, two, or four different things without having to replace the whole unit.The inline receiver module is big and clunky, you'll need a big deep box to mount it in (it completely crams a standard one-gang plastic rectangular box to the brim),  and like all X10 devices it makes a startling loud click when the relay activates. But it's simple, and it's inexpensive, and it works.

Be aware that according to the popup displayed by Windows 7 when I first plugged it in ("you will not be able to daisy-chain additional monitors"), this is an earlier version DisplayPort, but nonetheless worked fine at an incredible 3440x1440x60Hz with stereo sound.

Worked exactly as advertised. I lost the universal cable that came with my Dell projector and Dell wanted $89 to replace it so I could connect my laptop's VGA output to the projector's digital input. Note the order of that, analog output to digital input; if you want to go the other way, this is not the right cable. Worked with no drivers, no setting adjustments. Saved 80% with this adapter, and it can potentially be used for other things as well.

Used just one screw instead of two and did not tighten all the way down so it could pivot. One on the left, one on the right, and my big wooden chessboard is now hanging on the wall in a giant diamond, a nice piece of art and it got my chessboard off my table.
Great glue, thick enough to stay where you put it, thin enough to fill in cracks. And amazing price. Star off for ridiculously difficult package to open.

Perfect size and shape, convenient hanging hook, works with a Mazulla or Ulu much better than a flat cutting board, and plastic is dishwasher safe unlike the wooden board that came with my Mazulla. Not really usable with a straight knife but okay with a curved knife - about the same as a flat board. I got a new one for under $50 and frankly that's still outrageous (hence one star off for value), some of the prices being asked for this here are ludicrous.

Product page description is dead wrong: this is a BluRay reader ONLY, not a writer. Don't believe me? Google it under its actual manufacturer, Matshita. For that matter, look at the other product page for this same unit (sold under the Matshita name) here: http://www.amazon.com/Replacement-MATSHITA-TSSTcorp-SN-506BB-SN-406AB/dp/B00N0KJPX0.Not giving it one star because it does read double-layer BRDs fine, so it's not a total loss. But it's not what I needed, and not what I was promised, and back it goes. If you read the five-star reviews here, you'll notice nobody says they tried burning an actual bluray image to an actual bluray disc (and in spite of the product descriptions that say it only burns DVDs). I tried burning both images and individual files to both single and double layer BRD discs, both in Windows and in ImageBurn, all with an "Incompatible media format" error. A different BRD drive worked fine, but wouldn't wedge into the laptop (which requires the less-common 9.5mm drive size).

Not quite pocket sized but almost. Claims IPX7 waterproof but haven't challenged that yet. Extremely well made, excellent feel.To change from one setting to another (low, medium, bright, strobe, blinking SOS) you have to repeatedly tap the power button, over and over again. It is incredibly annoying, so annoying I'd almost not carry it because of the difficulty in using it. Except......Except that it actually remembers the last setting you used! If you usually use it on medium, then the next time you turn it on, it will come on already set to medium. That is a brilliant (pun intended) solution.It is not without its nitpicks. The charging cable doesn't plug directly in, but through a snap-on adapter over the power button. I suspect this is to maintain waterproofness, but it unfortunately means that you cannot stand the flashlight on its end when the adapter is snapped on (and if you unsnap the quite small adapter, that's one more thing to lose). The instructions did not explain how to attach the provided lanyard, but thirty seconds of studying the situation solved that one (two small slots on either side of the power button, either one will do). And the focusing mechanism is just a slide in-and-out tube, not a twist-and-focus like higher end lamps. That's not enough to deduct a star when compared to its extremely competitive price.It is quite dim at lowest setting - more like a nightlight - and at highest setting is is nowhere near the intensity of one of the more powerful modern multi-LED units; about as bright as a four- or five-D cell incandescent police torch (which was considered really bright just a few years ago) but a quarter the size, a tenth the weight, and rechargeable. Charger and cable are included, but if you own a Kindle or a non-Apple cell phone, you already have those.Check to see if the vendor is including a battery. Mine did not come with a battery but I had a deal that I could order the battery at the same time and get it for free - and it did, arriving in a separate box.

Contrary to the picture shown on the product page as of this date, this is actually a ultra-low profile stick (outside edge is just past the second side notch) so worked in my mini-ITX case...but even if you have a larger case that could accommodate a larger board, why not go with this anyway so as to improve clearance and airflow? Great price for 8GB. Remember, you must have a 64 bit operating system or you won't see more than 4gigs.

One of the only truly miniature mini-PCIE boards (most are quite a bit rectangular, this one is shaped like a postage stamp and not a whole lot bigger) and the only one I could find whose connectors stick up vertically - a mini-PCI board with horizontal connectors in all likelihood defeats the purpose for most users (it certainly would not have worked for my situation, an UltraBox silent PC with a mini-ITX motherboard and every square millimeter of horizontal occupied - but plenty of room vertically). Unplugged the onboard mini-PCIE wireless card, plugged this card in its place. Recognized instantly both by the BIOS and by Windows 7, no drivers, no configuration, no nonsense. For those who actually need one of the rectangular boards, this comes with a little add-on plate to give it the bigger dimensions to fit but I see other boards here on Amazon that are already that "bigger" size, and for less money.

HDMI turned into VGA out exactly as stated and at 1920x1200x60. Some one-star reviewers claim that this is only a dumb passthrough, that's definitely incorrect. I had previously tried an HDMI to VGA cable whose product page clarified was only a passthrough (not intended for computer use) and wound up with a blank screen. This on the other hand worked perfectly. A bit thick, was able to move another cable from DVI next door to a VGA connector and free up some neighboring space, otherwise it would have been a tight squueze.

Added some switches and a wall jack before a 30 foot run to the gym, and that was enough to ruin the picture and make audio a sometimes proposition. Changing the splitter (before the wall jack) to a powered amplifier version helped but not much. What finally fixed everything was this device, which conveniently runs off the power already in the line, with a 15 foot cable on either side in place of the single 30 foot cable.

Wish it also amplified the signal to make up for the small loss incurred with multiple connections, but only noticeable over a long run. Worked exactly as advertised.TIP: Windows control panel declared that only a stereo signal was possible thru HDMI. Boo hiss. But in Windows Media Center speaker setup, 5.1 surround sound was an available option under HDMI and sure enough, it worked!

Yes, it is a bit tight but with some thought about what goes where I got everything to fit. I had RJ45s mixed in with USB, coax, HDMI and speakers so I cannot confirm or deny the one star reviews stating that it cannot be filled up with 100% RJ45s, but I think a single star is an unfair review even if true because one star means the product could not possibly be any worse and I have not seen anyone say that it actually did not work at all.One star off for the dual side by side design, which unless you get the spacing between the separate 6 port plates just right the faceplate will have to be removed while you loosen the underlying screws and try to jigger everything into proper position. It took me three tries before the outer faceplate finally was able to snap into place.

This cable works perfectly for what it is designed for, which is simply to extend out a female connector to a male connector. For example, I have a wall plate with a USB female keystone jack that goes down into my gym. I can connect a remote control dongle or a joystick in the gym. But if the wall plate has a female jack and the back of my computer has a female jack, guess how I connect them? That's right, with this male to male cable. If you want the cable to actually perform some kind of logic like getting two computers to talk to each other then this isn't it, and since the description says nothing that even implies that this is what this cable does, shame on the fools who have the gall to give this product one star for not doing something that nobody ever said it could.

37" now securely fastened to a tiny 10cm mount (the other end of the swing arm is screwed directly into a massive wooden beam, otherwise the mounting end of my original mount would not have supported the weight). Like everybody else, had to figure the screws out on my own, so one star off. Helpful note: if the arms don't seem to be fitting, you've probably got one or more upside-down.

Quieter than the Artic Cooling F9 I also bought, but almost double the price. Whether at full speed or throttled back, it is consistently quieter than the Artic while subjectively appearing to move about the same amount of air. As a replacement for a Wine Cooler (yes, these fans do appear in things other than PC cases), when the unit hits its temperature setpoint and dials back the fan speed, the SilenX is so quiet you have to put your ear to the unit to hear it. Not so the Artic - and the Artic was already far quieter than the original fan being replaced.One star off for claiming "silent" when it is definitely not, especially at speed.12/13/14 edit - down one more star.Now that winter is here, ambient conditions in my house don't require the wine cooler, or its fans, to work so hard. Very often, the fans come to a complete halt. And that's fine by me, I understand that at some voltage the fan cannot overcome its own resistance.But here's the problem: the SilenX, and >only< the SilenX, emits a whiny buzzing noise when it is stopped! The Artic stops at about the same time - very often I notice (walking down the stairs behind the unit so you can see the fans through the grille) both fans at a standstill, but only the SilenX is making any noise.End of story: after only two months, the SilenX went into the trash and I installed a second Artic. Both red and white wine zone fans now stop at the same time, and both silently. If you need a fan running all the time, the SilenX is a tad quieter at a good deal more cost. If your fan may be slowing down sometimes enough to possibly stop, get the Artic and save some money.

Compared to the stock external fans that came with my wine cooler (yes, they use these things for stuff other than tower PCs), it was indeed a little quieter. But when the wine cooler is first cooling down and the fan is kicked into high gear, it was many times louder than the other fan I purchased (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005ZF65E0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1) for the other zone. My internal fans I used 80mm units from here on Amazon that had their own mini-speed controller, but I couldn't find a completely adjustable 92mm. In any event, even when doing the initial cooldown the other fan was quieter, and upon reaching temperature setpoint the other fan really was silent while the Artic F9 was audible, although certainly quiet.12/13/14 update: sigh, there is no perfect solution. Now that's it's colder, the fans in my wine cooler work a lot less hard and often come to a complete stop. The "other" fan emits a whiny buzz when stopped while the Artic is dead silent. So pick your poison, one is quieter when turning, and the Artic is quieter when not turning. If your fan may be going so slowly as to stop completely, get the Artic and save some money.That does not earn the Artic any additional stars, but it did cost its competitor a star. It did, however, earn the Artic an extra sale: I bought another one to replace the buzzy red "silent" fan, which went into the trash. Sigh...

Got at Home Depot for a decent price, not quite as low as the best price on Amazon but close.It was, I suppose, quiet, but not nearly silent. But I also have another brand, much larger (36 bottles) and it is far louder especially when first chilling down so I suppose this is one of the quieter units. Nonetheless, I did not understand why it should make any noise at all and I replaced all four fans (two internal, two external, or two top zone and two bottom zone) with ultra-quiet fans purchased here on Amazon. The internal 80mm fans I replaced with fans that have their own speed control, so I dialed them down to the fastest speed that is inaudible. The external fans I replaced with the quietest-rated 92mm fans sold on Amazon and wired them in series, which cut their speed in half. The result: absolute, complete silence for an additional $36 and some elbow grease; and still quickly cools down to 55 degrees. So it is definitely possible to make a truly silent cooler: one star off for cheap fans.And as mentioned by other reviewers, the unit does forget what temperature you set it to when the power does out (I was unplugging and reconnecting mine a lot while I was improving the fans). Not worth a whole star off so I'd rate it overall 3- 1/2 stars if I could.EDIT: while replacing the internal fans with adjustable-speed units was a total success, I learned something about the external fans. I noticed that the temperature of one of the zones was suddenly above room temperature (!) and the top of the unit was noticeably warm. It turns out that when the inside temperature reaches the preset, the unit automatically decreases voltage to the external fans - enough that one of them no longer had enough juice to keep turning while wired in series. I reconnected them back to their independent connectors like they were intended to be, and while they were definitely audible during cool-down (still much quieter than the original fans), once the unit reached the preset temperature they became essentially silent; I have to put my head right up to the unit to hear anything. Overall I would say the new fans (wired correctly a.k.a each fan to its respective power jack) while cooling down are about as loud as the original fans were when at setpoint, and once at setpoint the new fans are essentially silent. All of these situations are of course vastly quieter than the original fans were during cooldown, which was quite noticeable even in a fairly noisy room.

This must be the ultimate "fully objective" review, because I am giving the J&J tape four stars even though it did not work for me at all. It did indeed go on easily, sticks well to itself but hardly at all to my skin (a pretty important characteristic), and when applied as per the instructions held my foot in position quite solidly. But a) it does contain latex and I and so many others are allergic, so when removed my skin was red (quickly went away) and b) my foot hurt like hell when walking, but that's probably because this isn't the right cure - my doctor later recommended heel lifts for my Achilles's tendonitis and those are helping, the tape is of course for injuries where preventing flexion is the cure and that turned out not to be my problem. But for someone who has an injury that requires a joint to be immobilized (and preferably is not allergic to latex) this would be the solution. Cheap, shipped quickly, well packaged.

Received as a present the smaller pan. I was really psyched because it is a genuinely well-made, sturdy little guy. However, it burns everything (I have an electric range - perhaps people with gas would fare better) and everything sticks. Things that I would not have imagined. For example: the main use for this is when I am alone on weekends I make myself breakfast: heat up a can of corned beef hash, and then use the same pan to fry an egg. Hash is quite oily, you cannot say that the pan is not well-greased when it is done. But not only does the egg stick like glue to the "well-oiled" pan, but even the potatoes in the hash does. Yes, I know, the Internet shows ways to prepare a stainless pot to reduce sticking, but they overlook a basic fact: I'm lazy. And unlike cast iron pots, which you season once and then as long as you keep them away from a dishwashing machine they're basically set for life, the articles I have read (and remember, I'm lazy, so I'm already exhausted just from having to do research on a $^&%$^%$!! pan) say that stainless has to be continuously seasoned.And what's more, they say something else: avoid high heat like the plague, because stainless will warp when exposed to high temperature differentials. Apparently, putting a hot stainless pot under running water can permanently ruin it.None of this diatribe, by the way, is directly at Begique: I wound up getting the hard-enameled version of this set (on-sale at Macy's for about what this set costs here on Amazon), slightly thinner bottom. Have not had them long enough to comment on longevity but has the same massive handle and appear to be very well made (I'd include a link but frustratingly, Amazon doesn't seem to carry them). Worked perfectly and very happy. Keeping the steel pan because for certain things such as sauteing onions, the heat control  offered by that thick aluminum bottom really is superior. If it weren't for that I'd have given just two stars, but if you want a general-purpose pan and not cookware that fills a very niche product, you may want to steer clear of this and perhaps all stainless steel skillets.

Well made, replaced my godawful Panasonic thermal carafe. I particularly like that it has graduations in both "cups" and "mugs" (and let's face it, isn't that more meaningful anyway?).Boo hiss to the people here giving this one star because it did not fit their particular coffee maker. How is that an objective review? The vendor says it fits "most" coffee makers, not "all" - do people expect a magic carafe that you push a button and it grows or shrinks to fit your particular unit? These complainers should try finding a match for a thermal carafe (which start around $40 and go up rapidly from there) - then they'd really have something to complain about!One star off for a slightly misleading statement: "built to North American electrical standards." No it's not, that doesn't even make any sense. I happen to deal in electrical certifications and the actual standards like NEC, UL60601, IEC60601-1, E/S-1 etc. There's no such think as an electrical standard for a glass coffee pot!
I purchased one of these on August 24, 2014. When it arrived, it was not new as claimed but used, as evidenced by an entire Windows installation already being present on the drive.

The drive itself is fine. Well, a bit slow, about the speed you'd expect for a relatively fast (but hardly record-setting) magnetic drive, but less than a quarter of the speed typical for an SSD - but that's okay, I knew that when I bought it. I am replacing a swap drive on an older XP machine and so long as it runs at least as fast as the old magnetic drive it's replacing, no worries. The point is that this drive claims  to be an SLC-type drive, which would be far more reliable than the typical (and, byte for byte, much less expensive) MLC drives - an important consideration when you are using it for a swap drive and data is getting written over and over again to the same location on the drive.But the product page says it is new, and it is in fact used. The price charged was already expensive for a 4GB drive but I had a very niche need and considered it worth it. For somebody else's used drive, not at all.

You can find my highly detailed review of the GW77 posted separately under the now-discontinued U.S. model posting. I gave it two stars for a number of defects, including an annoying tendency to turn itself off in the middle of use - apparently a common problem. My two stars was also based on the price of nearly $800, and I wound up returning it. I did state that I would reconsider my rating if Sony were to update its software to fix some of the glaring problems - which they never did, they just dropped it.Or so it seemed, but the GW77 lived on in Japan. Yes, it's still a 5MP camera masquerading as 20MP, and although I have not tried its low-lux setting I bet it still stinks taking stills in low light with no flash (but it has an excellent, adjustable flash). And it is still touchscreen-only, making shooting underwater a bit of a hassle because the touchscreen is disabled underwater. But the Japanese version is far cheaper - no import duty, for some reason - and most definitely has a new firmware, because it has features like "take a picture when two people smile" that weren't in its U.S. incarnation.And more to the point, they work! As I admitted in my original review, and in comparisons in my Amazon review of the vastly inferior Panasonic WA03/WA30 (the closest thing the GW77 has to an underwater competitor), this thing takes movies, in good light and poor, that you would think came from a $10,000 camera. Underwater (when set correctly, although that's a lot of menu items that of course cannot be done underwater) it is not going to appear in the next episode of "Planet Earth" but still amazingly good for such a small package. It still comes with that useless GPS feature that made the U.S. version so expensive, and it is, of course, entirely in Japanese. I have the Japanese manual and the U.S. manual (both available as free PDFs if you Google them) and can, for the most part, match up the icons to figure out what is what...but the menus are not identical (for one thing, the Japanese-only unit has no "select language" setting) so that doesn't always work, and there are some settings with no icons that lead to screens that I have not, as yet, figured out. But for several hundred dollars less that I originally paid, I can live with that I just wish they could have fixed the U.S. version - and lowered the price!But do check out my original review (<http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00863R36W/ref=wms_ohs_product?ie=UTF8&psc=1#cm_cr_dpwidget>, two star review titled "Going back to Amazon") so you know the pros and cons of this particular camera, it is not for everybody and if you don't need underwater capability, there may be better choices.

Best price on Amazon for this, free shipping, worked perfectly. I saw the reviews that the pin was not long enough to activate some cylinders but works perfectly with mine (Worthington) and the pin looks very long, perhaps they improved the design? The item pictured as of this date is exactly what I received.One star off for the lack of documentation, as this thing could easily injure or kill you and yours - like anything that is connected to gas. You must always connect it to the grille FIRST, then to the cylinder. That's easy so long as you remember it! Disconnecting is a bit trickier: you must always disconnect it from the cylinder FIRST, but now it is secured to both the cylinder and the grille so if you simply start unscrewing it, whichever one is the loosest is the one that is going to come off; so you have to make sure you hold the adapter (or put a wrench on it) to ensure you disconnect the cylinder, not the grille. Otherwise, gas will come blowing out and possibly ignite.Oh, and make sure you keep the cylinder upright at all times - while connecting and disconnecting it; and while using it, put the cylinder into a stand or otherwise make sure it stays upright, otherwise it's not gas that will be coming out but concentrated liquid. Boom!Note that these warnings apply to ANY adapter you use with propane, the one star off is simply because this one doesn't tell you about them. Now that you know, go buy one!

I had given five stars for the powerful, but big (as most are) Zap Master <http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008G4AFDY/ref=oh_details_o00_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1>, but I will be downgrading that because two of them started having the same problem within weeks of one another, one of which was thus far fatal, after only 10 months. Wanted something smaller to carry while walking - a full-size tennis racquet is simply not convenient - and gave the OneShot a try.Well, it is smaller, but just. Think "super extra large borderline cheating racquetball racquet." And the handle is very big, not so much long as wide. Which is surprising, considering it takes the same two AA batteries as other units. It does have the definite advantage of having the batteries load from the end, rather than the side, so the battery door release isn't constantly sticking you in the palm while carrying it.MUCH lower voltage/power than my prior unit (whose advertising makes a point of its power); the OneShot gives a modest pop and a dead or dying insect falls to the ground; while an insect contacting the Zap Master explodes into a brilliant blue flash and anything less than a horsefly left nothing but a puff of smoke.Finally, safety. I have already gotten zapped twice by having my fingers pressing into the mesh. Okay, that was stupid of me, right? But here's the thing: this was AFTER I had released the zap button. The Zap Master drains the charge when you release the button, rendering the mesh harmless, while the OneShot apparently retains the charge for some time afterward. Dangerous? I don't know, but I'd be careful about setting it down into say a pile of dry leaves if I'd pressed the button recently.Meanwhile, my fruitless search for a genuinely smaller (ping-pong paddle sized) zapper continues...

Lots of gizmos that allow different sources to be connected to a single monitor, a capability that is rapidly becoming moot as more and more monitors are shipping with multiple HDMI inputs. Not so many gizmos that do the opposite, allowing a single source to switch between different monitors. This particular gizmo does both, and does it well.To be extremely, exceedingly, absolutely clear: you will not be able to watch video on two monitors at the same time with this. While it is theoretically possible, most of the video in the world that is flowing through an HDMI cable happens to be copyrighted and therefore copy protected (HDCP). There are schemes to allow HDCP video on two monitors at the same time (my Kindle Fire in combination with my Netgear Push2TV does it) but a) only under certain circumstances and b) only in the way the copyright owner wants it, not the way you want it. (For example, I can see video on my Kindle and on one and only one monitor - the Push2TV still doesn't allow the signal to go to more than one monitor.) So if you want to display an HDMI signal on two monitors at once, this device won't do it, and you may have to lower your expectations because of the technological limitations mandated by copyright laws.For me, I usually have my HTPC connected to both my living room TV and a monitor down in the gym. No, I still can't watch both at once, but Windows 7 makes it easy to instantly switch between them. But I sometimes play Flight Simulator and use a little touchscreen monitor to display the instruments. It's a hassle to have to dig behind the HTPC to switch cables, so the Portta with a little 1-foot cable is just the ticket.  I use the Windows-P key combination to toggle to "extend desktop," push the button on the front of the Portta, and now I have a live HDMI jack I can plug into. When I'm finished playing, I just reverse the procedure and I can still watch Mad Men in the living room or P90X in the gym.Using the Portta to do the opposite - to allow one monitor to switch between two different HDMI sources, say a cable box and a BluRay player - is just as easy. Be aware, however, that the Portta does not "automatically" switch between sources (so for example if you turn the power on to the BluRay player, the Portta does not recognize that you want to watch BluRay and switch over to that source). There are other switches that do that, some sold here on Amazon. As I said, this particular functionality is rapidly becoming moot: even my little 20" touchscreen came with two HDMI inputs.One minus, but not enough to deduct a whole star: Portta has unfortunately followed the fashionable trend of having a really, really bright blue LED shining into your eyes. As in, bright enough to read by. I will probably get around to putting a piece of electrical tape over it.

Works great with a D3100 battery at a fraction of the OEM price. Not sure when I would ever use the car plug cord but a nice bonus. I read the review here stating that it won't stay plugged in; no such issue for me - I do note that it could be plugged in in two possible orientations, it needs to be plugged in with the plug at the top or it will indeed fall back out of the outlet, but that's by design.

First of all, this is MISLABELED as of this date - the product information says it is for 3/8, 1/2, and 1/4" fittings; it should state "and 3/4" (if you click on the image that shows the reverse of the package and zoom in you'll see that this is exactly what it says on the package, it's the Amazon description that is wrong). Also be aware that when they say 1/2" they mean a pipe that is not at all 1/2", it's another one of those crazy "National Pipe" dimensions, so measure your pipe and Google "National Pipe OD" to make sure you really have a 3/8 or a 1/2 or a 3/4 pipe. Yeah, it drives me crazy, too.Anyway, my situation was that I had a pipe fitted into a union that had never been soldered, and it had rusted internally so much that I couldn't get a good solder joint. Unfortunately that left me with a pipe with a bit of solder adhered to the bottom, ruining its perfectly circular profile; and the LeakMate needs a perfect circle. To be specific, the clamp comes with several rubber sleeve inserts to adopt it to different pipe sizes, and these sleeves have a small step-down to match the corresponding pipe union. This step-down has to fit over the place where the pipe enters the union EXACTLY (at least on the 3/4", which being the largest has the least amount of rubber; the sleeves for the smaller pipe sizes have a lot more rubber so they might be more forgiving). So all I accomplished was to slow, but not stop, the leak, which I finally fixed using the excellent Rectorseal pipe repair kit (also from Amazon - do a search).Nonetheless, I am keeping the LeakMate because I can see that it might be a lifesaver some day. You should not consider the LeakMate as in any way a permanent fix but rather something to "mostly" fix a problem pending a permanent solution. I have to subtract a star because it is, as of this date, mislabeled; and another star because it did not work for me (and my situation is surely not unique). But as something to have in your toolbox for a rainy day - or at least a leaky day - it seems like a good thing to have.

Tried the rubber patch with the radiator hose clamps; tried the U-clamp with the liners; tried soldering. They all slowed the leak but did not stop it. I have a baseboard forced-hot water radiator installed by, well, let's just say a less-than-attentive contractor who was never heard from again; and one of the pipes was never soldered into its union, resulting in a rapid drip whenever the heat comes on. This was in the dead of winter so I wasn't too eager to shut my heating down in order to drain the system and properly solder. Big mistake; the aforementioned rubber tube patch only slowed it down, and by the time the summer came along, the inner surfaces of the copper union had rusted, making a good solder seal impossible. I guess if I was a plumber I'd have access to a strong acid that could have stripped the corrosion inside the union joint clean, but a blow torch and flux couldn't get in where it was needed, and I don't have the skill to disassemble and re-solder the whole thing. The LeakMate U-clamp/lining gizmo might have worked if I had not already tried unsuccessfully to solder the pipe, but now I had solder adhering to the copper and making its profile not perfectly circular, which seems to be a requirement for the LeakMate (the shape of the clamp needs to align exactly with the profile of the pipe) so again, it slowed but not completely stopped the leak.The Rectorseal stopped the leak dead, both static and with the heat and recirculation pump running. You do need to rough up the pipe surface (coarse sandpaper) and you need to have everything ready - included gloves on, a bowl of water by your side, lots of paper towels - because once you start you are committed and you need to work quickly, splashing water on your gloves and the joint occasionally, winding the tape back and fourth and giving it a good, gradual pull after every wrap. It supposedly sets in 30 minutes but I gave it several hours to be on the safe side before re-pressurizing the line, but not a drop since then.The reason for four stars instead of five is because the outermost eight inches of the tape spool had already dried out and set, and had to be cut off and thrown away. Fortunately the remainder was more than enough for my situation.

Banged my plantar fascia during P90X (jumping) and felt something pop loose inside my heel. I've done it before but this time it didn't get better after a few days, with blinding Achilles pain first thing in the morning, limping up and down stairs, even pain in the opposite leg caused by compensating for my limp. Tried a set of strap-on in-shoe orthodics during the day - helped but didn't cure...and gave me a sore calf, and gives no support going uphill, and way too much support (like bouncing on a ball) going downhill. Tried a big fuzzy splint from Amazon during the night - helped but too hot, if the pain wasn't keeping me awake then a sweating foot was, and obviously did not keep me from re-aggravating the tendon while walking. But the Footminder really has made a difference, after two months I'm 90% better (I even went for a short jog today with them today, unimaginable a month ago) and I am seriously considering continuing to use them even after I'm cured. I liked them so much, I bought a second pair so I don't have to keep switching them between shoes.My only complaint, and I honestly don't know how they could have designed them to account for this (so no star subtracted), is they do slip down inside the shoe when I am putting the shoe on so I have to hold the shoe at an awkward angle to keep the Footminder near the heel while I get my foot inside. Once my foot is in, however, the arch of my foot forces the arch of the Footminder to naturally drift into and stay in the correct position.

The good: extremely light, good picture. Touch works very well. Love the fold-out stand, which worked perfectly for me - I wanted this to serve as a temporary second monitor when I play Flight Simulator (so I can display my virtual aircraft's control panel next to me and actually change my instruments and switches by physically touching them - works terrific, and although I have to set my monitors up so that Windows thinks my secondary monitor is the primary each time, that's a Microsoft thing and not in any way this monitor's fault) but when I'm not playing, I fold in the stand and return the monitor to my VESA-compatible wall mount that I use to broadcast Netflix to through my Netgear Push2TV. One of the smallest monitors out there that's true 1080P.The bad: A touch small for the wall application, but that's a matter of taste. You've also read other reviews about how tinny the speakers are (true) and at least one reviewer recommending that you plug an external set of speakers into the monitor. That reviewer should have actually tried that before making that recommendation, because unfortunately it is quite impossible: the 1/8" audio jack on the back of the monitor is a stereo INPUT not an OUTPUT. There is no way to hook a set of speakers up to this monitor, and it needs it pretty badly. Audio in is far less important since it already receives audio through the HDMI connection (which also carries audio) and fewer and fewer users are going to need a separate audio in, but the poor speakers demand an audio out for any serious multimedia application. Lacks scaling options, which are a standard feature on just about every other HDMI monitor, but which is becoming less important as "underscanning/overscaling" becomes a forgotten technology so probably not a concern.The neutral: glossy screen sure to show fingerprints, but that's true of all touchscreens. Powered by a small power brick instead of a cord directly in; I prefer the simplicity of a single cord but I took a couple of sticky tabs and just glued the little brick to the back of the monitor, so for all practical purposes it's the same as having a cord plugging directly in.

Caught about one bug per minute until I a) cleared some brush so it could be seen in all directions, b) lifted it up to head-level (eye hooks into two trees, ran a ratchet rope between them, and hoisted it up), and c) wedged a block of octanol (from Home Depot) between the bars. I found a Black Flag octanol unit here on Amazon that clips to a zapper and I'll use that when the current one runs out. The first night it rained and still almost no hits, and I started to lose hope. But the next night, and every night since, it has been a non-stop fireworks show. The fun dies down around midnight so I put it on the excellent Woods timer <http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00002NB2X/ref=oh_details_o05_s00_i01?ie=UTF8&psc=1> that lets me set it to turn off four hours after sundown. I still get daytime mosquitoes biting me and perhaps I'll try alternating octanol with Lurex (I understand that they don't work well together, but so far I only see Lurex in cartridges intended to be used with units with fans) but fortunately the vast majority of mosquitoes in my area seem to be drawn straight to the combination of octanol and 120 watts of bug inferno. Sometimes it almost sounds like rain, the bugs are being zapped so incessantly.It comes with hardware to hang it horizontally, but for the life of me I have no idea why anyone would ever want to do that. Doing so would block the light in two directions (and so reduce its effectiveness in drawing pests) and you can accomplish the exact same thing by simply removing the bottom cover and leaving it off - while the sides are covered in heavy wire, the top and bottom (under the plastic covers) are covered in strips of heavy flat steel. Dead bugs just fall right through (well, those whose bodies survive in some form, mosquitoes are mostly just turned into smoke).Comments on other reviews:First, ignore the idiot who said this is flimsy and held together by a tiny screw. He never actually removed that screw (and the top), otherwise he'd have known that the top mount screws into not the plastic cover but the massive steel frame hidden under the cover.Second, I've read the post that the starter and bulbs need to be replaced and are difficult to replace. I have not had this long enough to have an opinion on that so I'll assume that his review is accurate. Nonetheless, I still stick with my five stars: for me, if I have to throw this entire thing away every year and buy a new one, it would still be worth every penny to me for its incredible effectiveness. I've tried the others and $250 spent on something that works is better than $40 wasted on something that doesn't.I'm not saying I want to replace it every year, and I'm hoping I don't have to; but it would definitely be worth it. Zap!EDIT: see comment for my bulb-changing experience, definitely something worth knowing before you buy one of these.

Didn't write a review right away as I saw some had complained about consistent operation and I wanted to check it out first. I note that the number one reason given by people writing one-star reviews is something to the effect of "didn't work," but I suspect most of them did not actually give the product a fair try. I say that because if you simply plug it in and cover the optical sensor expecting it to immediately turn on, it won't and you might think the unit is defective. But in reality, it could not turn on immediately because unlike a regular photocell such as a entrance light, this thing also has to start counting down a timer. If you think about it, before it can start the timer it has to know that it is actually dark, and not just seeming to be dark because perhaps a tree blocked the setting sun for a moment. So it pauses for a moment (actually about 20 seconds) before the unit switches on and starts the timer, which is exactly how it should be. On the other hand I also see some poor reviews for units that stopped working weeks or months later and it's more difficult to mark those up to poor understanding of operation; if mine dies I'll update this review. Meanwhile, activates my 120-watt (!) bug light at sundown and turns it off four hours later. Cheap, delivered quickly, and works: five stars.

With an incandescent bulb this will indeed let you cycle through three levels of brightness by "touching" the lamp - but note the quote marks. With a solid brass lamp plugged into it, I had to grab hold of the lamp with my whole hand to get a response...and sometimes, grab and release several times. Simply touching with a finger was never recognized. I have other touch switches (admittedly on/off, not dimming) that work exactly as expected.On the other hand, they are certainly inexpensive, and they do technically work, so it wouldn't be fair to give only a single star - much as I'd like to.

I bought this to connect a Netgear Push2TV <http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00904JILO/ref=oh_details_o02_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1> directly to my HD TV set. The Netgear puts out a signal through an HDMI port, but also requires a USB cable to provide power. I noticed that the distance between the HDMI and USB ports on the Push2TV was about the same as the distance between a USB and HDMI port on my TV, so on a lark I ordered this along with a similar (but rotating in addition to swiveling) USB connector <http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00B5K1G0C/ref=oh_details_o07_s01_i01?ie=UTF8&psc=1>.The upshot is that my Kindle Fire is broadcasting HD video and audio directly to my TV set, with the Push2TV plugged right into the TV with no cables sticking out the side. I only rate this as 4 stars because the USB and HDMI connectors point in opposite directions between the TV and the Push2TV, and the Hoye adapter would have had to point in the wrong direction (i.e., the Push2TV hanging in front of the TV instead of behind it). However, because the USB adapter both rotates as well as swivels, I was able to rotate the USB adapter around so that it changed orientation 180 degrees, and then both the HDMI and USB adapters line up with connectors on both the TV and the Push2TV. The USB adapter therefore got five stars for its extra flexibility that saved the day, while the Hoye gets four stars for being a very good, but not quite as spectacular, accessory.

On a lark - I realized the probability of this crazy idea actually working was slim to none - I ordered this along with a similar (folding, but not twisting) HDMI connector <http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00C2WEKZK/ref=oh_details_o08_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1>. The idea was that I could bend this and the HDMI connector at a 90 degree angle, plug them into my Netgear Push2TV wireless adapter <http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00904JILO/ref=oh_details_o02_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1>, and then plug both the bent HDMI and bent USB straight into the connectors on the side of my TV, which just happened to have an HDMI post and a USB port next to each other.And astonishingly, it worked! The connectors on the TV are almost the same distance apart as they are on the Push TV, so they all align. Unfortunately, the USB connectors and the HDMI connectors face in opposite directions; so it was a godsend that the YCS adapter happens to also be able to rotate, so the USB connector on the other end now faces the same direction as the HDMI.Now I can broadcast my Kindle Fire wirelessly to my TV in high definition video and sound, without having any cables dangling off the side of my TV. It was specifically the rotating characteristic of the YCS adapter that made it work. I therefore gave the HDMI adapter four stars for its good, but not spectacular, flexibility and five stars to the YCS for saving the day with its multi-axis capabilities.I cannot yet speak to longevity, but at least in my case the total combined weight of the Netgear, the YCS, and the HDMI adapter is less that a few ounces so I don't expect any difficulties.

Work, that is. I suspect that the reviewers giving this item high marks did not actually try it out with all connectors. I will try to upload a photo showing the problem (edit: uploaded, depending on your browser you may have to scroll down on the main product page to see the thumbnail), but: the big connector that plugs into your available power connector is ever-so-slightly too wide to then plug into a SATA drive and leave enough room for a data cable to plug in alongside it. Looking at the picture, you'll see that the data cable is pushed all the way up against the main connector body but still cannot quite reach the data terminal on the hard drive. I am baffled why they would have designed it so, just 2mm off the side (the side opposite the four colored wires) would have been enough. You might be able to make it work with a very low-profile right-angle data connector, but a standard straight cable just doesn't fit. In all probability, you'll need to hook your third drive up to this with a male-to-female extension cable, kind of defeating the "all in one" concept.On the other hand, it makes for a fine two-way power splitter, and as I said could possibly be used as a three-way splitter with some degree of finagling.

The basic part itself is excellent. But:1. I was expecting it to have some sort of rubber lining to protect the mirror surface, but it does not. The way this works is you install the actual clip first, and then the round cover screws down around that. That cover is brushed nickel, which will easily (let me rephrase that, "inevitably") scratch or even break the mirror. There is an easy solution, not described in the scanty instructions: first of all, obviously don't torque down the cover hard; it is, after all, just a cover. Secondly, as the cover closes in on the mirror surface, use your other hand to push the mirror back against the wall and DO NOT let the cover actually touch the mirror while you are still twisting the cover on. When you release the mirror, it will spring back slightly and press lightly against the cover. (Which means that the mirror and the cover are simply pressing against each other, which is okay, and not that you actually ground the cover into the mirror while you were screwing it on.)2. As others have mentioned, this thing won't hold a mirror of any size whatsoever; not because of the clamps, but because of the little short screws and terrible anchors. Get longer screws and if possible run the bottom clamps straight into a stud (because you'll want to make the clips symmetrical, that might not be possible depending on where you want the mirror to hang - in my case, I was able to run one into a stud but not the other). Otherwise, get a "real" anchor, I used a toggle bolt for the non-stud one. Don't go cheap on this one, because even if the anchor is structurally sound the clip will "droop" under the mirror's weight and you will see a gap between the mirror and the cover - which will of course look twice as big as it really is, because you'll see the gap and its reflection! (Experience talking here.)  The anchors on the top don't really matter, it's the bottom two that take the weight and tend to droop or worse. Whatever anchor you use on the bottom, make sure that it is METAL and big enough so that the clamp physically presses up against the metal of the anchor. Why? Because if it is plastic, and/or the anchor is so small that the clamp touches the drywall, then when you start to tighten the screw in the clamp you'll start to pry the anchor back out. No, the anchor will not and cannot actually come all the way back out of the wall (the anchor and your screw both tighten in the same direction), but possibly enough to result in the dreaded "droop." If you have a good, sturdy anchor but the contact area is too small or non-existent (for example, when you screw straight into a stud then the only thing the clamp will contact is, by definition, drywall) then put a flat washer between the wall and the clamp.Why on Earth did I give this four stars with all the apparent hassles? Because none of this is the clip's fault, and they certainly can't be expected to include every kind of anchor to address every possible situation. If you follow my instructions to avoid scratching the mirror and to provide a rock-solid anchor with metal-on-metal contact for the bottom two, you will be very happy.

Technically, this accomplished my goal. My car's cigarette lighter is always on, but its AC outlet in the center console turns on and off with the ignition; so I bought this so my Nuvi would turn itself off when I turn off the car. To that extent, it works; but lately the GPS has been giving me "low battery" warnings just before shutting down. It seems that this "charger" fails to produce enough juice to both power the GPS and charge it at the same time.Nonetheless, I do not happen to own one of the three Garmin GPS units that the product's description lists (Nuvi 550, which has a large capacity battery), so I do not know for fact that it would exhibit the same deficiency when used with one of those models; I therefore am giving it three stars by default.

Hard to put on but that was because the old handlegrips had disintegrated and hung on like a pitbull. Good looking, very comfortable. I have a thumbshift gear changer on the right handlebar and needed grips that were asymmetrical, and these fit perfectly.

Full disclosure: despite what it may say above this review, I do not own an island purchased from Amazon; my horror story of what Amazon's customer service put me through is explained in a separate "vendor feedback" review and I ultimately purchased this, for less money and zero hassle, through Wayfair. This review is only about the product itself.Really nice design, except bottoms of drawers could be sturdier. I do wish the side attachments were designed to be put on or left off at your discretion (cannot be left off without leaving large holes in the side). I bought some white screw-in hooks and converted the left attachment to a mug rack, four mugs above and four hanging beneath. This is not a center island, doors are only on the front - I mention this because I wanted something to go against a wall and it was actually difficult for me to figure out from the descriptions which islands did, and did not, have doors on both sides. Both wheels and feet are included. The feet, by the way, do not actually touch the floor but terminate in a small rubbery circle, so I am not sure which would be better at distributing the weight (with the granite top this is very heavy) if you have a floor that can be easily damaged - probably a felt pad would be a good idea in either case.VERY well packed (including the top coming in a massive wood frame for protection) - and that excellent packaging is, in a way, the reason for my unimpressive review. You see, there were lots of nicks and dings, and one panel completely crushed. Now, that panel is on the left, inside, and cannot be seen without getting down on your knees and had no functional impact - which is very suspicious. I work in quality assurance and I know that companies will have criteria about what can and cannot pass, and it is common that even a major defect, if not visible and non-functional, will be allowed through. And some of the dings were on the edges of doors, and on top of the shelf that the aforementioned mugs are sitting (which could not be flipped over to hide the ding as there are big holes in the bottom of that shelf to hold the towel accessory). That last one is missing paint so it occurred after the shelf was already painted. Most, if not all, of these dings and the big crack could not have occurred during shipment because the whole thing is extremely well packed and protected - a forklift tine driven trough the box might shatter a panel but not cause paint gouge off a shelf.Yes, I know that this is an assemble-by-numbers and not an heirloom piece of furniture. But it is also not $59.95 from Ikea, either

Top and sides are very nicely made and assembled, but bottom is a cheap plywood, glued and nicked. One star off.Two stars off for misleading description: on the inside, which after all is what actually matters when it comes to a box that is intended to hold things, the dimensions are 1.3" x 3.54" x 9". The dimensions stated by the manufacturer are just bizarre: for example, the description states "4-Inch" but there is no dimension, internal nor external, that is even approximately four inches. Since the manufacturer states that this is 1-1/4 by 4 by 10-1/2 (52.5 cubic inches) and it is actually 41.4 cubic inches, you are not getting nearly what they claim you are paying for.

Arrived quickly, seems well-made; but while the Amazon picture of the product (including the picture of the product that is on the packaging of the product) clearly shows three outlets in a row, the actual cord I received has two outlets on one side and one outlet on the opposite side (like a typical extension cord, only with the two outlets slightly more spaced out). The number on the package is 03507, same as in the Amazon description, so it does not appear that the wrong item was sent.Since for me, and for others I am sure, the big advantage of this cord was going to be that I could lay it on top of a surface (kitchen counter) and plug things into it like a mini-power strip, that greatly reduced its usefulness (one star off), and two stars off on principle for misleading description. If by the time you read this Amazon has corrected the image and correctly shows and states that the outlets are on opposite sides, this disregard this and consider this a four star product.

The product itself deserves five stars. Yes, I can certainly see why people would be disappointed if their particular glasses use an oddball screw size that this doesn't accomodate...but that's really a critique of the eyeglasses, isn't it? Shouldn't they instead go back and give their eyeglasses a one-star review for using non-standard screw sizes?And ignore the people who say it doesn't (or worse, "cannot") work on spring hinges: of course it can, they just didn't bother reading the helpful hints posted by other reviewers. In fact, the design makes it far far FAR easier to use on spring hinges than a regular screw would, if you spend a minute reading the reviews to understand how to do it. I'll even repeat it here: insert the long screw shaft at an angle so it bridges both halves of the hinge mount. As you push the screw in with the screwdriver, the screw shaft becomes a lever that naturally pivots the two halves together. Damned clever (just go slow and gentle, because that shaft is, after all, designed to break off under force). Obviously if you have a spring hinge that also happens to use a size screw not included with this kit you're still out of luck.But one star off because once you use up the handful of screws (and if they indeed come in different sizes - I'd need a microscope to confirm that! - then make that "one or two screws") that come with the kit, then you have to buy the whole kit again. No "refills," as it were.

Just installed so I cannot really rate it for the claimed dependability (kind of hard to objectively classify how well it withstands punctures without doing controlled experiments anyway). But I did want to post about how difficult it is to get these to mount - and a quick trick around that. 1.50" is at the extreme low end of this tube's stated size, and there was simply too much tube to cram inside the tire. Try as I might, I wound up with several inches of extra tube with no place to put it. the first one I eventually got on with innumerable air filling and deflation cycles, but even then I had to keep breaking the tire bead and re-adjusting to get the valve stem square.On my second one, I tried an idea. I left the tire UNMOUNTED (one side on the wheel, the other hanging off) and inflated it to 40 PSI. I then deflated the tube, pushed it under the tire, pushed the second tire bead onto the wheel, and inflated to 60. Perfect fit that time.EDIT: My initial experience was rather negative as I found it was much more difficult to pedal with these installed. To be honest, I also had bought new tires so I could not at first definitively blame the tube or the tire. I also found that these tubes lose pressure rather quickly, initially dropping 10psi in a day - and since that happened on four tubes on two bikes, not a fluke. (After a while the pressure drop decreased considerably, so I suspect the valves were seating.) The solution to the hard rolling was to overinflate the tires, they're rated to 65psi max and I am inflating them to 80psi (a quick check on the Internet found that bike tires are deliberately rated far below their actual maximum inflation values). Which fixed the difficult rolling problem - but I wonder if by having to overinflate I haven't negated the puncture-resistance I was after in the first place.What it boils down to is this: these might be fine for a balloon tire around the tube's nominal size (I note others here had problems on the other end of the spectrum with tires around the tube's maximum stated size), but cramming them into a 1.50 is just too problematic.7/13/15 UPDATE: Been using them for two years now, and although I've only put about four or five hundred miles on my bike, they're coming off. In that time I have not gotten a single flat, so they do seem to work; but even maxed out at 80+ psi in a 40-65psi tire, they're tough rolling. When I tried to remove the tube, it had to be dragged out of the tire and when it fell on the floor, it still looked like it was fully inflated (usually an uninflated bike inner tube looks like a wet piece of spaghetti). Perhaps with a tire size more matched to the tube's nominal might give a happier result, but while it works as promised - no flats - it just wasn't worth the effort (literally). I replaced the rears with the Sunlite 1.50-1.75 regular tubes and inflated to 65psi already saw a big relief in pedaling effort, and ordered another set to replace the fronts as well.So, which is more important to you:- Ease of pedaling your bike? Two stars.- Not getting flats? Four stars.- Both equally important? Three stars.

I used to have a 2.5" IDE drive with an IDE-to-USB adapter, and currently have a 2.5" SATA SSD with a SATA-to-USB adapter. I use them for portable backups, and have often wondered why somebody doesn't simply squeeze the whole thing into a single package. I thought that what I had found when I ordered the Kingspec 32GB USB "SSD" - but I was wrong.I don't claim to be an expert on hard drive protocols, but I do know what a real SSD does and how it appears in various software system when connected to a USB port, and this ain't it. For example, when I connect an SSD to USB under Windows, I can create and delete partitions on it, and under Windows 7 I can resize them. Not so with this device; I was eventually able to figure out how to do so by using the tools in my backup software (Acronis) but not within Windows - and even then, only one partition was possible. And formatting it as anything other than FAT prevents it from booting, even though a "real" SSD boots fine when formatted as NTFS - which by the way is required if you want to have files bigger than 4GB (kind of important if the purpose is to store backups).And the list goes on. Despite the Amazon description, despite the box and graphics, this is in no way an SSD; it is a bootable flash drive (which, if I understand it, means that an identification bit is set that flags itself as non-removable; while it still shows up in Windows as "removable," I can confirm that it shows up in my BIOS as a "hard drive"). Now that may not be a bad thing (and the box claims dynamic wear leveling and mean time between failure rates that would be indicative of a genuine SSD - but since they are not completely honest about the first part...) and for some applications, e.g. under Linux, it might work very well indeed. But it is not a solid state drive in the sense that I think most people would expect, and 32GB bootable flash drives can be had for a lot less money.I'd send it back, but it came all the way from China (about a month for shipping) and it's not a bad bootable flash drive...but I wanted an SSD!

Milk crate forced into service as a cargo bin in the back of Ford Escape slides all over the place on the slippery carpet. Tried velcro, tried sticking carpet non-slip to bottom of crate, nothing works. Go around a sharp corner and Bang! as the crate slides across the rear deck and slams into the other side of the SUV.Drilled a hole through the bottom of the milk crate, drilled a hole through the carpet, ran a short, fat screw up through the carpet and into the bottom of the crate. Works, but big ugly hole in carpet that will only get bigger and uglier with wear.Hmm, here's a large diameter metal grommet...but surely it won't fit and secure itself across the thickness of a carpet?Wrong - worked perfectly, easy to install, looks great. Only needed two and lots of leftovers for a future product.Crate now secure as if it was a part of the car.Happy.

Okay, let's get this straight right away: I ordered this without fully reading the description. My fault. I have no need of a cache drive, since every computer I own already has a small SSD as its main O/S drive, with data (for computers that handle a lot of data) pointed to a larger magnetic drive. I ordered the wrong thing.But so long as I had it, on a lark (and because another poster here said it would work) I tried plugging it in and seeing if I could mount, format, and use it as a primary drive on a friend's Dell laptop. And sure enough, it worked under Windows 7.But it was too little capacity, since she has just the one drive; so I swapped it out for a 64GB Kingston I had on another PC, one with a 2TB Samsung for all my data and therefore largely going to waste. And the SanDisk worked perfectly there, too, under XP.So: zero experience with using this drive for what it is marketed for, and I did not play with the included software. But I can confirm that it is a very light, even smaller (thinner) than usual 3.5" (it does come with an adapter plate if you need one), and lightning fast SSD that works plug-n-play in a variety of circumstances; and the price was cheaper than an equivalent sized "proper" SSD.One of my best mistakes ever!

Read my update, and then downgrade of this three-star review at the bottom.Saw these, of all places, at the pool restaurant at the Marriott in Kauai and had to talk my girlfriend out of stealing them, she liked them so much. For salt they are terrific for the table; but for pepper, they are a lot of work to get just a little out and there is no adjustment. I wondered if maybe one is specifically for salt and the other dedicated to pepper, but that's not the case: when one ran empty, I switched their contents and the other grinder still takes ten pumps to get even a little pepper out. DEFINITELY NOT for cooking (except as arm calisthenics!) but very attractive and unobtrusive at the serving table.At least, that is, for salt.-------------6/23/13 update: out of the blue, I was contacted by the manufacturer offering to send me another unit. I was frankly not interested, since as I describe above two out of two grinders exhibited poor grinding of pepper. But lo and behold, they sent me a new unit anyway; and it actually works perfectly.Which leads to an interesting ethical problem for me. Yes, it is fantastic that I now have a working pepper grinder, and even more fantastic that the company has such high regard for its customers (or its reputation, which boils down to the same thing). They didn't even ask for the old one back and I'll use that for salt by my BBQ grill.BUT, I nonetheless received two "defectives." What does that say about their quality control? I am a pharmaceutical quality engineer and I face these questions every day. It's hard to give this five stars when I have circumstantial evidence of a systemic quality issue.
