It's terribly unlikely (but nonetheless possible) that I received two bad units just by coincidence.But ultimately, coincidences do happen and I also have insufficient data to say that there IS an underlying quality issue, so I am going to give Epare the benefit of the doubt and credit them both for an excellent and attractive little grinder and outstanding customer service.----------------5/25/14 update: like many other reviewers have experienced, the little metal sleeve above the (plastic, not glass) window that lets you see how much salt or pepper remains came loose - on both units, almost simultaneously. It was an easy fix (drop of superglue) and I see several reviewers state that Epare has fixed the design flaw, but the fact is mine both came off - one star back off again down to four stars.----------------11/23/14 update: now the threads inside the top have stripped out so that the entire mechanism no longer works. Put it together, go to use it, and the plunger springs out like a Jack-in-the-Box. This is after about a year of very light use. How can that be, if it is stainless steel? Sloppy tolerances? Or the internal parts are not steel? In the trash it goes - along with the midget grinder I bought a few months ago, and already the plunger on that gets routinely stuck halfway depressed, I suspect a weak spring. Epare, you design a great product but your manufacturing sucks.

If this could be disassembled I would have given it five stars - and kept it. I wound up returning this and buying a unit that was not polished stainless and whose finish I did not like nearly as much - but the addition of a simple removable pin means it can be disassembled, and when you are trying to fit one of these into a dishwasher that is a must. These are WAY bigger than you probably think, both this unit and the one that replaced it can literally hold a meal for two into their bowl.

Shame on the dozen or so people here who gave this product a single star - the absolute worst rating possible, meaning that nothing could possibly make the product any worse - because they failed to read the quite clearly stated pre- and post-cooking rice volume.However, the one-star reviews about this cooker dying shortly after purchase cannot be so easily ignored and are quite worrying. If that happens I will return and downgrade my review.For one or two (or three, if you don't eat a lot of rice) people, the size is downright perfect. The complaints about splattering can be instantly fixed (and B&D should add this to the instructions) by simply rinsing the rice beforehand: dump the rice into a strainer, run under water, dump rice into cooker, flip strainer over, rinse strainer, shake strainer dry and hang up. Twenty seconds and no more boilovers. I have read that pre-rinsed rice is healthier but I don't have an opinion on that; I just know that it keeps this cooker from splattering.Another point that other reviewers are sort-of right about is the confusing measurement - it is baffling! You mix in an ACTUAL amount of water with a deliberately WRONG amount of rice. This is the manual's fault, here's all you need to know: fill the rice measuring cup to the bottom of the lip and dump the rice into the cooker (er, after rinsing :-)  then fill the cooker with water up to the marked line. You don't need to know that the one-cup rice cup isn't actually one cup, that's irrelevant to using it - but the manual describes it as though it's something critically important.And yes, it is true that the rice on the bottom comes out brown. Thing is, it still tastes perfect and doesn't have anything odd or different with the texture; it's just slightly brown. My experience has been that if your rice is coming out solid on the bottom, you took the lid off while cooking - BIG no-no, once you hit the Cook button, don't remove the lid so you should have added and stirred everything before you press "Cook."Black and Decker claims it will keep rice warm basically forever. Don't you believe it - I can tell you that you should eat that rice within a half hour or so of completion (and for white rice, it cooks in about 20 minutes) because the steam vent will dry the rice out pretty quickly. But if served within fifteen minutes of completion it really is very good. Maybe not as good as the $100 steaming units (this is more of a parboiler than a true steamer) but for the price, amazingly good.Somebody mentioned that it should have a handle on the rice bowl. That may seem like a silly detail; but because the rice bowl is so small (very shallow) when you go to scoop the rice out the bowl will jump all over the place and there is no way to get a good, well, "handle" on it. That really is my only complaint, provided that it doesn't die on me like so many other people seem to indicate.12/29/13 update: still working perfectly. I have loaded it up to the maximum once or twice and it will indeed make enough rice for three or possibly four people, so it's not really as small as everyone says (however the rice cup only measures out for a two-person amount so there's a bit of guesswork involved). Here's a new tip: if you are adding anything that floats - herbs (mmm, cilantro...) or sesame oil - remove the lid and give it a quick stir just before it starts boiling. As I mentioned above, if you remove the lid while cooking you will definitely wind up with dry rice, but that seems to be an issue only once the rice has started boiling. Put that lid back on, though!

Returned a competing German-made spatzle maker, very similar size, quality, and price, because it did not disassemble. Why is that important? Try fitting one of these in a dishwasher and you'll see why.Makes amazingly good spatzle, very little effort, and an entire meal fits inside one scoopful.You will find it quite impossible to force the pin out in order to disassemble. The trick? Don't force it. The device should be in the fully closed position, but with no force applied to to the arms. The pin will pop right out!One very minor quibble, not worth a star but Amazon won't let me rate something as 4-1/2 stars: no hole or loop to hang it (and trust me, you will have trouble finding a drawer this will fit into). I am planning on drilling a hole through the notched end so it can hang from my pot rack.

Incredible price compared to brick-and-mortar, especially the brand-name drug. Not time-released...and you're probably already aware that any guaifenesin is supposed to be taken with plenty of water, right? Well that goes quite literally double for these. Whether on an empty stomach or after a big meal, this large-dose, instant-release pill gives me a stomachache within 30 seconds of swallowing unless I down it with not just a glass but at least a full half-liter bottle of water, and even then it results in a slightly uneasy feeling. Your mileage may vary and surely some will not be affected as much (if at all), but for me the effectiveness of the medicine outweighs the inconvenience; after all, it is both cheap and effective.
Excellent! The clarity is superb, totally worth it for the price! You cannot go wrong with this brand, and 1080p 3D is an excellent upgrade to old school VGA projectors!
Excellent! They were better quality than I expected and definitely worth the cost. Nice color variation and packaged in a nice locking pouch, overall very pleased!

Works great, no mess. Caught 2 mice in the first day! They are re-usable, but will break down eventually. I got about 3 or so catches with each before it began to break apart. But not bad for the price!

Exactly what I needed! Works great and as described. I haven't had any problems with it at all and it's convenient being able to connect multiple SD cards at once. Also the MicroSD card port is convenient so I don't need to carry an adapter with me anymore!
Works great, just as expected!
Excellent quality and worth the price!

Great quality at a good value! Don't get caught up by the negative reviews. All cough liquid gels (including Robitussin), include red dye. I have no idea where the allegations of LSD and Heroine came from but really these are fine generic cough pills!
Great quality and worth the price. Batteries fit in snugly and the exterior is rubberized and feels like GoPro quality! No problems so far and charges the batteries quickly!

AMAZING improvement over the older BacPac. Holds true to claims of an increased 15% battery life over previous generation BacPac (1260 vs 1060 mAH). I got a 35% increase in battery life!I tested it on a GoPro Hero 4 Silver shooting with LCD off (of course because of the BacPac) at 2.7k 30 FPS. Without a BacPac I have tested it 3 times, the average being 1 hour and 33 minutes. With the new BacPac I was able to get 2 hours and 57 minutes before the camera shut off. This is almost doubling the original battery. GoPro claims I should get 3 hours so I am well within what is expected.I tried this test again with the older BacPac (the AB-PAK301) and got 2 hours and 27 minutes which is about 35% less. Definitely a great improvement!

I just purchased the Hero 3+ Black Edition one month ago. When the Hero 4 came out I had to try it and I ended up returning my Hero 3+. Why did I get the Hero 4 Silver over the Hero 4 Black and the Hero 3+ Black?Three Reasons:1. The Hero 4 Black is $499 and does not come with an LCD (because of heat issues from 4k they could not put on an LCD).So really if you bought an LCD BacPac for the Black edition, it would cost you a total of $579 compared to the $399 of the Silver. This is a $180 difference!2. The two models BOTH have improved sharpness compared to the Hero3+ Black.This video compares the sharpness of the Hero3+ Black, to the Hero4 Silver, and the Hero4 Black:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=07Y2iTSNy8g&list=UUTs-d2DgyuJVRICivxe2KtgWatch this video to compare the Hero4 Black to the Hero3+ Black:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BacBT268-pQ&list=UUTs-d2DgyuJVRICivxe2KtgThen watch this video to compare the Hero4 Black to the Hero4 Silver:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aNazYkq4omY&list=UUTs-d2DgyuJVRICivxe2KtgAs you can see the sharpness between the Hero 4 Black and the Silver is the SAME. They both have the same upgraded sensor/lens and it's definitely improved over the 3+ Black. Yes, the 4 Black can do 4k at 30 FPS, 2.7k48, and 1080p120 while the 4 Silver can only do 2.7k at 30 FPS, 1080p60 (it can do 4k 15 FPS but that is not really usable for most purposes). But to be honest, that is the only improvement and it is a $180 difference! At this moment I cannot justify 4k for that much of an additional increase. I am happy with what the 4 Silver offers AND I get an LCD which is extremely convenient.3. Compare the battery life of the Hero 4 Black vs the Hero 4 Silver here:http://gopro.com/support/articles/hero4-camera-battery-lifeAt 2.7k 30 FPS, the Black only lasts 1 hour and 10 minutes while the Silver lasts 1 hour and 50 minutes!! This is the SAME resolution. Why? Because the Black has a more powerful processor to handle the 4k, and this causes it to eat up more battery regardless of the frame rate.Given these three reasons, I do not believe the Hero 4 Black is worth the cost. But the Hero 4 Silver is definitely a bargain and worthy of an upgrade from the 3+ Black edition. Don't forget in addition to the cost, the Hero 4 Silver has identical specs as the Hero 4 Black (except for 4k 30 FPS). This means you will also get (compared to the 3+ Black):- Upgraded sensor with better ability to resolve detail- 2x the WiFi Speed (less lag and faster transfer speeds)- 2x the Dynamic Range for Audio Quality - watch this video comparing! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZqXVPyTCr-E&list=UUTs-d2DgyuJVRICivxe2Ktg- Bluetooth Capability- Night Photo Mode (and ability to control shutter speed)- Night Time Lapse Mode (and ability to control shutter speed)- Protune for Photos- Auto white balance in Protune (enables higher bitrate while allowing for zero editing in post)- LCD TouchScreen (Silver only)All of these are the same upgrades on the Hero 4, so really you're trading $180 and the LCD screen on the Silver for 4k 30 FPS  and decreased battery life on the Black edition. Each person may have their own opinion but I think this is a big problem for most users because the cost does not justify the upgrade.I haven't had too much of a chance to test it out, but quick photos and videos showed it truly is sharper than the Hero 3+ Black edition. And given the video links I posted above, it is the same sharpness as the Hero 4 Black (unless you shoot in 4k of course). The touch screen is a GREAT addition and very responsive. It works like I would want it to so I am happy with that.Battery Life with LCDI also recently tested out the battery life with the LCD screen always on. The Hero 4 Silver comes with an auto-off of 1 minute and can be set at either 1 minute, 2 minutes, 3 minutes, or always on. The LCD brightness can also be set at high, medium, and low. My first test was with the LCD always on, brightness set to high, recording 2.7k 30 FPS. I was able to get 1 hour and 40 minutes out of the battery! That is pretty amazing as I did not expect that with the high brightness setting. I then did a test with the LCD off with the same frame rate and got 1 hour and 45 minutes (I did this 3 times with the same result).This means the LCD draws very little power (which is really really great)! For scuba diving, you will need the screen always on as you cannot activate it again once it turns off under water (unless you stop recording and record again but that can be annoying) and knowing it doesn't affect the battery significantly is a great plus. I also tested the Hero 3+ Black in 2.7k 30 and got 1 hour and 38 minutes so the battery life between the two cameras really is the same; even though the Hero4 is 20 mAH less it seems to give more battery life (1180 mAH in the Hero 3+ while 1160 in the Hero 4).Battery BacPacFor those curious I also tested the new Battery BacPac (claims 15% increased battery life) and compared it to the older Hero 3+ Battery BacPac. I used the Hero 4 Silver and recorded at 2.7k 30 FPS with LCD off. I got 2 hours and 57 minutes with new Battery BacPac compared with 2 hours and 27 minutes with the older Battery BacPac! So improvement of about 30 minutes is not bad at all! This is more than 15% (it was 35% with my test)! GoPro claims the Hero 4 Silver should get 3 hours with the Battery BacPac with 2.7k 30 FPS so I definitely would consider that result accurate.ConclusionOverall a great improvement and the recent firmware update released on the 14th of October has fixed all the minor bugs that were out there. I would highly recommend getting this especially if you are upgrading from an older model like the Hero 2 and Hero 3. If you have the money it is worth the upgrade from the Hero 3+ especially for the LCD, the improved sharpness, night time lapse modes, and audio improvements. I think the double wifi speed and bluetooth connectivity are bonuses but I wouldn't upgrade just for those reasons alone but if you combine all the other benefits it's definitely worth the upgrade!

Easy to set! The bar just clicks itself into place. So far the target has been evasive, but that may be my fault regarding positioning or not using gloves to bait it, as the bait hasn't been touched.Seems well made (plastic and metal) and sturdy, should last for years.

I was expecting this to be a book of traditional math puzzles with some historical context. Instead, this is a book of puzzles, conundrums, mind games, and more, with some basis in math for sure, and some math history, but also plenty of psychology and mind-bending challenges, and even visual and illusion-type puzzles.The layout is more magazine than math book, with very active pages (unfortunately, as of now you can't peek inside on amazon). The author gives insights into his thinking process and why he puts in various challenges. It seems his goal is more to teach us how we think (and can improve) than teaching math itself. Yes, there are indeed historical math challenges included, but so much more so be prepared for plenty of diversions.I haven't gotten through even most of the book yet (it will take some time), but so far, as something of a math geek, I haven't found the math problems very challenging. To give you an idea, one puzzle that is marked as more challenging, goes something like this: Take a long telephone wire with a bunch of birds on it. Each bird is either looking to its right or left. How many birds are being watched by 0, 1 or both of its neighbors?The book can be very wordy (again, think magazine vs. math puzzle book), and even a bit strange at times. An early puzzle puts forth a scenario in which you are set up on a blind date with Julia Roberts, and you are supposed to figure out what is wrong. Unfortunately, the answer isn't "because she is already married to Daniel Moder." Maybe the author didn't realize that, or doesn't care, but either way that disturbed me - I mean, she's even got 3 children!There were also some puzzles that were missing key parts or were simply misleading. One puzzle says there are 2 daughters - one is married, one isn't (you don't know which), and one is always truthful and one always lies (you DO know which). You are supposed to figure out a 3-word question to ask either daughter that will tell you which is married (presumably because you want to marry the other one - never mind that she might be a compulsive liar). Obviously, you could simply ask the truthful daughter a question, but that is too simple - after reading the answer it seems you don't really know which is the truthful daughter after all.Some pictures were incorrect too, such as a cube dangling by a string that looked like Picasso drew it. The point is, the book needs more proofreading and polishing - but for a first edition, it could have been worse.In conclusion, this can be a fun book for junior high through college level readers, with a lot of variety, just be aware this isn't just math problems, and the math problems tend to require more problem solving skills than math knowledge. But it _will_ make you think, and provide new insights into how your mind solves a variety of problems.

Strong enough to hold up to most jobs, yet thin enough that I can feel what I'm doing (I'm writing this review with one on). Mine was true to size (XL), with a snug fit that stays in place, though the wrist band is a bit loose.The glove just covers my wrist, unlike the picture that seems to show it going a couple inches past the wrist. Mine is more like 1/2" past the wrist.They are waterproof, and yes the hand gets sweaty, but that's to be expected with this type of glove.  Just what I need for those dirty jobs!

This small, portable heater works great and heats up small rooms quickly. It cycles on and off to maintain the desired temperature. The included remote can be placed anywhere in the room and the heater will use the temperature at that location to cycle on and off. This is great - put the remote at the bedside and stay just the right temperature in bed. Using the remote is optional and the heater will function normally without it.The heater throws out a lot of heat without being uncomfortable nearby or even hot to the touch. The heat goes through plastic fins, so I was concerned about outgasing. There is a slight odor emitted, but it doesn't seem too bad and the plastic never really gets very hot.The cord stowage on the bottom is very convenient, and can store excess cord when in use. The cord length is a generous 6 feet in length with a grounded 3-prong plug.There is also a tip-over sensor on the bottom that shuts the unit off automatically if it is knocked over. So this unit seems really safe around children - not too hot and it won't set the rug on fire. As a side effect, the sensor can keep the unit from coming on when placed on a deeper pile carpet. But it is small and light and works fine on our table too.The unit does produce a slight click when cycling on or off, about as loud as a lamp switch, which can be annoying esp. since this heater seems to cycle a lot. Often it will turn on for only a few seconds at a time. It also has a timer that can turn the unit off after a few hours - perfect for warming up a room in the morning or as you are going to bed.The control buttons on the top of the unit are easy to use but don't light up for use in a dark room. The display and status LEDs can put out a lot of light though, esp. the green light when the remote is in use. We put a small cloth over it so we can sleep.Overall, this is a safe and convenient portable heater perfect for use in a nursery or child's room, or anywhere you need a little extra heat.PROSQuiet fanRemote temperature sensorTimer featureLight and portableTip-over sensorCord stowageCONSClicks when heat turns on and offCycles too oftenSlight odor when heat is onLights can be bright in bedroom

This Celtic-style silver cross with garnet stone looks pretty much like the amazon picture, although the finish is highly reflective so its actual appearance depends on lighting. The grooves appear black oxidized which helps highlight the patterns. Overall it looks very nice and has a decent heft to it.The garnet is very red but can also show a brownish-pink hue when backlit. My chain measures 17.5" and is also sterling silver - both the cross and chain are stamped 925. The chain is very lightweight and mine arrived tangled with one link broken, despite being messily taped to the back of the display card. It is nice that it is real sterling silver also, but treat it delicately.I would say the overall quality including detail of finish and stone cut is average, nothing extraordinary but fine for basic jewelry. The cross dimensions are 1 1/4" tall by 13/16" wide and seems durable (except for the delicate chain). It is made in China and comes in a nice blue and black amazon-style jewelry gift box.

I really wanted a self-winding watch, and love this style showing all the cool inner workings. The inner motion is constantly visible and you can see everything going on inside from the front and back. You can even see the winding mechanism working as you move it around.  It also just looks great being worn.  It is a large size and has some heft to it; my arms are not that wide at the wrists and this is about the biggest size watch that would work for me. The arms don't glow so there is no night visibility.It is entirely mechanical. I'm not sure how long it can go without winding, but I don't need to wind it when I wear it every day. The included manual is generic to all their watches and doesn't say anything about the self-winding mechanism.Unfortunately, there are a couple of serious drawbacks with this watch - the watch hands and band. The hour and minute hands are thin and reflective metallic blue. In most lighting conditions, they are very hard to see.  I can't simply glance at my watch to see the time; I usually have to tilt it around or move to get the lighting right to actually see the time.  With all the gears right behind the arms, they are basically camouflaged.The second hand (in a separate little dial in the bottom middle) has a white dot near the tip that helps, but the hour and minute hand just have a hole there. If the hands were larger or white (or at least had the white dots) they would show up much better. The blue is a cool color, but actually looks almost black much of the time and simply isn't functional.The band is an interesting design, with a metal clasp similar to all-metal bands, but mostly leather. Part of the clasp attaches to one of the holes in the band to adjust size. I thought this would be more convenient than a regular all-leather band, but it isn't working for me. First, the clasps pop open too easily, and even sometimes out of the hole when removing, defeating the purpose. There are two band retaining loops; one is fixed in place and whenever closing the clasp, one end of the watch band needs to be slipped into it but there isn't enough room so you have to really bend it. It's a pain and the band will probably wear out pretty soon from the bending. Finally, the large metal clasp also feels uncomfortable under the leather band. It's probably not worse than metal bands, but contrasts with the comfort of the leather.The watch band could be replaced, but the watch hand visibility issue is a huge caveat. Otherwise, the watch is attractive, fun, and well made. It comes in a very nice gift box too.

I was really shocked that these roughly cut pieces of fabric, unhemmed, are sold as "scarves." The fabric has a silky, filmy, polyester feel, and is very light-weight, textured and  somewhat shiny. They began to catch and fray on the ends right away. The colors are vibrant. I use them as a headcovering for church, and they are not too hot in summer. 70"x10" Why not just buy your own cut fabric pieces of your choice at the fabric store?

This is one of the more impressive toy lightsabers, but still has some shortcomings. This is the one made (and used) by Kylo Ren, a follower of the dark (evil) side in the new Star Wars movie "The Force Awakens."  Batteries are pre-installed so it works right out of the box (or even in the box in demo mode).  The main light saber and two side guards light up, but not the dagger, which can attach to the bottom of the handle for a cool 4-sided weapon.  (In promo pictures Kylo's version is 3-sided.)The saber can be swung to fully extend it, and it can be manually pressed back in to about 1/2 its full height.  Unfortunately it doesn't fully retract, but neither do most toy lightsabers.  The side guard blades and dagger stay their regular length.  The sound comes out of the bottom of the handle, where the non-lighting dagger can attach.  It is fairly easy and quick to twist the dagger on and off the saber, so it can be done as part of a play fight sequence.You can purchase other compatible sabers also and combine them to make all sorts of shaped weapons.The rumbling sound varies, making it seem like the saber is in motion, although the only feature triggered by motion is a short flashing and sound sequence when it strikes something in regular mode. The main problem I have with the sound is when holding the saber still, it continues to make the various sounds as if it is in motion; I'd prefer it to be relatively constant until it strikes something. Most users will probably like the varying sounds though.There are 2 switches, the on/off switch on one side and a button on the other. There switch has 3 positions: off, I/demo mode, and II/regular mode. In demo mode, the button starts a short 10 second sequence with a bunch of sounds and flashing and then it turns off until the button is pressed again.  In regular mode, the button turns the saber on and off and it reacts to striking things. However, the button doesn't turn it off if it is in a strike sequence, so you can't, for example, do a kill strike and then immediately turn it off.This would certainly be enjoyed by any young Jedis - wait, no, actually, make that dark side villians-in-training.  If you are looking for a cool light (good) side of the force weapon that's also in the Bladebuilders series check out the Star Wars Ezra Bridger Lightsaber Blaster. There are cheaper options too such as the Star Wars Revenge of the Sith Obi-Wan Kenobi Electronic Lightsaber.

This is a super-strong trash can. The rubber is thick, flexible, and heavy, the sort that lasts and lasts. It is extra wide and only about 3" taller than my typical 32 gallon trash cans.  (And several times heavier.) I use the 45 gallon Kirkland Signature "Smart Tie" Outdoor bags and they fit perfectly, and the flaps tuck into the retainers by the handles to help prevent slipping (not perfect but it helps).Lids are sold separately: Rubbermaid Commercial FG264560GRAY Brute Round Plastic Lid, Gray Why? These are commercial grade trash cans so often no lid is needed, such as when used inside a bear-proof metal container. Or with a Dome Top. Or in a prep kitchen. You get the idea.There are grips on the bottom for 2-handed dumping. The bottom also has anti-slip traction grooves. The bottom scuffs up pretty quickly but it doesn't affect functionality.Be warned that this trash container is HEAVY. Compared to typical residential-grade trash cans, this requires considerably more effort to lift even when empty. When full, it can weigh much more. If you don't need the superb durability, consider a residential trash can or one with wheels such as the Rubbermaid Commercial Brute Rollout Container, Square, Plastic, 50 Gallons, Gray (9W27GY).There are even deep, wide "venting channels" to prevent suction holding the bag in the can when you try to pull it out. And I like that it holds way more than a typical 32 gallon trash can.This is a great commercial trash can that can handle tons of abuse!

Fit is great in my 1998 Honda CRV LX AWD.  Took a little effort to wiggle on, I'd say perfect sizing.  Seems well enough made if not quite up to OEM quality.Got this as my radiator had a slow leak and figured I'd replace the hoses as they were original and almost 20 years old. Looking at them closer I could have kept them - used a heat gun and they slid off nicely so no damage.If you are replacing both hoses you might want to do the thermostat too as it's at the back end of the upper hose and you have to pull that hose to get the housing open (2 bolts on top right and lower left). I used this thermostat this thermostat as it was a good value and included the gasket - at 180F it's 10F higher than OEM 170F which is fine by me.BTW if you are needing the radiator for a 1st gen CRV too the Denso 221-3209 Radiator fit my 98 CRV perfectly and works great.

This was a perfect fit in my 98 CRV LX AWD.  Quality seems excellent and it is working great so far.I do most of my own work on my Hondas and this took me about 4 hours including the thermostat and transmission fluid change.  Would probably take me 3 hours if I did it again.  I also replaced the upper and lower radiator hoses but not the transmission fluid hoses which are just regular smaller diameter hoses that connect to the bottom of the radiator.The radiator came with no extra hardware other than the nuts for mounting the 2 fans but all the old parts worked fine despite being 18 years old and a little rusty.  It does have the plastic drain plug in it too.Other parts I used (all worked fine):Beck Arnley  143-0698  ThermostatGates 22322 Upper Radiator HoseGates 21871 Lower Radiator HosePT Auto Warehouse R126 - Radiator Cap, 16 PSIA few installation tips that might help if you haven't done this before:A heat gun loosens up the hoses so they slip off without damage. (I replaced mine anyway.)Take off the under-radiator plastic guard (one of them) first to get to the lower hose connections easier.Have something ready to catch the transmission fluid from the 2 smaller hoses.Be sure to disconnect all the fan wire clips (I think there were 3 of them).A second person helps to guide things when actually pulling out the radiator.There were 2 round rubber bumpers on the bottom - be sure to put them on the new radiator.Double check you've moved everything between the radiators before installing.You might need to remove the left fan before pulling the radiator. I was able to barely squeeze it in front of the A/C line above the radiator (with help).If replacing the thermostat also, take off the lower radiator hose, then take the 2 bolts off the housing the hose connected to. One is on the top right, the other on bottom left. I needed a small 1/4" drive to get to them.

Put this in my 98 CRV LX AWD when I was replacing the radiator.  Had been noticing weird fluctuations in the dash temp gauge such as sudden drops and then climbing back up for a couple minutes followed by another drop during normal driving.  This one is 82C which is stamped right on it (about 180F) vs the OEM which is 78C (about 172F).  I know some people like to go to 195F but that's too high for my tastes.  I also liked that this one included the gasket at a reasonable price.It was fairly easy to replace once the upper radiator hose came off the housing. I had to use my heat gun for a minute to get the hose to slip off as it had been there almost 20 years. Just a couple bolts on the top right and lower left of the thermostat housing the hose disconnected from.  The bottom left bold is kind of hard to see and get to. I found my Craftsman 1/4" drive with a regular socket just worked and I didn't need to use my universal joint extender. It's a tight spot so be careful not to drop the bolts.The included gasket fit fine, was maybe a little bigger than the original and I had to kind of work it into place to get it to stay in the right spot when re-bolting the housing.  At first I thought it was too big but it worked great.  Pin side goes up and slightly to the left.  Be sure the gasket is installed correctly on the thermostat before installing.So far it is working great. No leaks and no more gauge weirdness.  The Denso 221-3209 Radiator is working great too and was a perfect fit.

Fit is okay. No major issues, but slightly different shape from OEM making it lean left almost touching air filter housing, and not quite straight through one green clip just left of the engine. But fit is acceptable and it works just fine. Fit nice and snug on the radiator end and thermostat housing on the other end. Took a little effort to wiggle on, I'd say perfect sizing.Seems well enough made if not quite up to OEM quality.Got this as my radiator had a slow leak and figured I'd replace the hoses as they were original and almost 20 years old. Looking at them closer I could have kept them a while longer - used a heat gun and they slid off nicely with no damage.If you replace this hose you might want to do the thermostat too as it's at one end of this hose and you have to pull this hose to get the housing open (2 bolts on top right and lower left). I used this thermostat this thermostat as it was a good value and included the gasket - at 180F it's 10F higher than OEM 170F which is fine by me. Glad I did mine; the original thermostat had rubber falling apart on it.BTW if you are needing the radiator for a 1st gen CRV too the Denso 221-3209 Radiator fit my 98 CRV perfectly and works great.

This is a really nice watch! It looks bright and attractive, and feels comfortable to wear. With adjusting, the band will fit a large range of wrist sizes, and doesn't catch hairs like some watches do. The watch is marked for water resistance to 100 meters, which means that you can swim or snorkel (but not dive) while wearing the watch.There are three small dials on this watch. They are, from left to right, the stopwatch minute hand, the stopwatch second hand, and a 24-hour clock. The stopwatch is accurate and easy to use, although it can be difficult to see the dials when the hour or minute hand crosses over. The same goes for the 24-hour hand.I love the glow-in-the-dark feature of the watch. The hands glow a pleasing blue color in the dark, while during the day they look a normal white color. Sometimes, though, the glow is bright enough to see even in lit areas; during these times, the glow reminds me of Elvish swords. It looks pretty cool. All of the hands on the watch have this glow effect, except for the two second hands (stopwatch and regular).To remove the links and adjust the band, we used a link pin tool set, sold on Amazon. The task is pretty straight-forward: just hammer out the pins in the direction the arrows are pointing. They look a little like screws, but they aren't. When you hammer them back in, make sure it's the same side they came out.Overall, this is a high-quality, well-made timepiece. You won't be disappointed.

This watch looks much more impressive in person than in the amazon image. The watch body and hardware are a rich golden brass. It is also larger than I expected.  Not gigantic, but definitely very large. My wrists aren't very big for a guy, but it still fits. The watch body is almost as wide as my wrist. This watch would look impressive on any guy. I love it.The windows on the front and back (yes there is a crystal on the back too!) allow a great view of the constant motion of the intricate parts inside. You can actually look right through it, and with a lit background it's even more amazing. At first you might think it's just decoration but these gears are for real. You can actually see the winding and ticking inside.The band is a nice padded leather with a pattern imprinted on it. It has a large metal hybrid clasp that is a little tricky. Two sides (arms) of the clasp pop out and then you feed in the other side of the watch band. Once you've got the size right, it goes on and off much like a metal band clasp. It is stiff to open at first but breaks in quickly.I've been really wanting a wind-up watch; I guess I miss the ones I had when I was younger, and like that this is "off the grid" with no batteries! And it has a beautiful ticking sound against my ear. The second hand races around at about 4 ticks per second. The hands glow a light green for viewing in the dark, including a dot at the tip of the second hand.The only negative is the included manual is general and geared more towards their battery watches. So far winding lasts at least a day - I haven't let it go longer than that yet. I'll update this review as I learn more. The warranty is for 5 years with a $15 fee for a covered repair or exchange.I would love to get a watch like this as a gift. It is an impressive and quality watch, evident as soon as you open the box. Even the case is really nice and helps make this a special gift, whether from someone else or just for yourself.

This is a fun puzzle for kids around 8 and up. The pieces are made of a hard colored plastic material, so they won't develop frayed edges the way 2-dimensional puzzles do. The pieces are numbered, so that the solver can easily figure out where they go; without the numbers, it is quite challenging to find the correct arrangement, because of the repeating striped pattern.At the top of the puzzle, there's a larger piece with a picture on it. The picture is actually a printed sticker, which the solver must stick onto a plastic unit. It's best to have an adult do this; when my kids assembled the puzzle, they stuck the sticker on wrong, and it had to be removed and restuck.When completed, it makes a nice decoration. We put it on our mantel.

This watch was designed to be massive. Its size makes it rather special. I don't have very large wrists, so when it arrived, my first thought was that it seemed unusable because of its size. However, after looking at it for a while, I realized that it would be perfect for a man with a high muscle mass and large arms.Actually, it would also be good for a man who desires a higher muscle mass, because the watch weighs more than half a pound and will probably strengthen the arm you wear it on. It isn't heavy enough to weigh me down, though - I can comfortably play a piano while wearing the watch, and it doesn't have any noticeable effects.At first, the band was way to big for me, so I had to adjust it. Six of the links on the band are removable (you need a very small screwdriver, like the ones used for most eyeglasses); with these links removed, the watch can fit a wide range of wrist sizes. I only needed to remove five of the links to make the band the right size for me. The clasp also has a spring bar adjustment for fine-tuning the band size (you may need a spring bar remover for that). This does not void the warranty, as far as I can tell.The watch is marked for water resistance to 100 meters. This doesn't actually mean it can go 100 meters below the surface; it just means it can withstand water for swimming or snorkeling. According to the instruction manual, if you don't need a helium-oxygen mixture, you're good.The watch also has a rotating bezel that can be aligned with the minute hand for measuring elapsed time. Oddly, the bezel only rotates in the counter-clockwise direction. This seems backwards to me. Also, if I rotate a little too far, I have to rotate the bezel all the way around again.I'm finding two problems with the watch. First, it's really thick, and sticks out so far that it tends to bump into things. I already have a small gouge on the bezel which is too soft to stand up to small impacts - I don't even remember it hitting anything. The rubber guard around the edge doesn't help for this, because most impacts are going to come from the top... not the sides, because that is where your arm will be. Second, the minute hand is slightly loose - it wobbles back and forth by about 1/3 of a minute. It doesn't affect me too much, but for a watch of this type, I would expect higher quality.But if you want a huge watch that will get noticed, this is it.

PROSSnug, flexible fit with 6 different types of ear tipsExceptional clarityLong lasting batteryIntuitiveBlock external noiseCONSExpensiveCan be uncomfortable when fully insertedI was impressed by the clarity of these ear buds compared to other decent mid-level ear buds. These must be properly inserted for great sound.  If the bass seems weak, they aren't all the way in, so try again. Max volume is decent but not ear breaking as with many wired ear buds, which is fine by me. My teens reported a very slight added buzz on some songs such as Brave by Sara Bareilles, but I am not sure if that's the headphones or the phone.The medium silicone ear tips fit snugly in my ears and block out most external noise. It's really easy to swap out the ear tips and you can choose between S/M/L flexible silicone or molding foam. These do NOT have noise cancelling as some seem to think, but you don't really need that with these as they fit so tight you really can't hear much (could be dangerous actually). The ear fins didn't do it for me with my ear shape, but these stay in great with just the ear tips. They do get a little uncomfortable over time because they are so tight, but the smaller ear tips won't stay in for me.The cord is tacky/grabby and can stick to my neck, which is fine most of the time but occasionally will pull out one ear tip when I turn my head if the cord is resting on my neck. Also the cord is pretty thick and can transmit sound if it rubs on your shirt. Use the included cable clips to help prevent these issues (see manual).Easy to sync with a Bluetooth device (V 2.1 which is perfectly fine for headphones). The 3-button controls make sense but it helps to look at the online manual; e.g. hold the volume up or down for forward/back. Works great with my android phone and handles calls like it should. I liked the case; it seals well (might even be waterproof) and holds everything. It's a little big but is well made and is easy to open/close once you know how.The battery does last for many hours (they say 8) and charges only take up to two hours.  Overall decent little high-quality wireless earbuds.

PROS: Bright, sturdy, sleek; USB charging ports and built-in wrench.CONS: Cant twist to adjust the light direction; imposing power supply and cord.This lamp is very sturdy and produces an even, bright white light, which is shaded on the sides so it doesn't shine in your eyes. The black finish is glossy black, and I can even see my face reflected in it (you can't tell from the picture). The button (next to the handle at the tip) requires only a light touch. In fact, I don't even need to touch the button - if I move my finger close enough to it, the light turns on. I think there's some sort of electric field involved. There are three brightness settings which can be picked by holding the power button.The double-hinge allows for 360-degree positioning. The other hinge has a range of about 110 degrees. No matter where you position the light, the base is stable, and will not fall over. It can be quickly adjusted by hand, and the tension of the hinges can be adjusted at any time using an included Allen wrench, stored in the underside of the base.The base also has 4 large rubber pads to hold it firmly in place on the desk.  The USB charge ports in the base are nice and are used for changing devices, not the lamp; the lamp must always be plugged in.  The base measures 8 x 6 x 1.The lamp comes completely ready to use, no installation/assembly required.  It is not actually a Black& Decker design, but is made in Taiwan by Amax Incorporated under license from Black & Decker.If this lamp were $50 cheaper, I would recommend it. However, for the price, I would expect more. For example, the lamp does not swivel or rotate in any of the joints, so you can't swivel the light back towards the wall, for example. The wall adapter sticks out about 2" from the wall, causing problems if the outlet is behind a dresser. A built-in rechargeable battery would solve this problem, but this unit does not have that. Finally, the cord plugs into the back of the lower arm; I'd rather it plugged into the base where it would be less conspicuous.Overall, this is a decent, sturdy and bright but pricey lamp.

This sturdy, well-made set is easy to assemble and provides interactive play. It is ideal for 4 to 6 year olds, and older siblings will want to help too!  Besides assembly and re-building, the fire arch and turnstile require constant attention as the train races around the track. The plastic is high quality and has some flexibility to it so the pieces should hold up well.My 12 year old assembled the whole set by herself in about 10 minutes with only one minor difficulty she quickly figured out - the fire arch required a little push on the railing of the track to get everything in place, which is nothing a small child couldn't do once shown. The engine requires 2 AAA batteries (not included); just unscrew with a small Phillips screwdriver and the door slides right off. It is easy to close also - insert the little tab in place and just screw it back on. Other than that, no tools are needed. There is a little lever on top of the engine to turn it on and make it go. You have to pick up the engine to do this as the lever is rather small.This is a FAST little engine, and even I had trouble keeping up with it. It is 4-wheel drive with rubber-coated wheels so it has excellent traction and can handle steep inclines. However, it still has trouble trying to get up the steep yellow ramp and often needs a little push - it has plenty of power, just not quite enough traction for such a steep ramp. The children don't mind; in fact they like to help keep the train on track and zooming around.The other minor issue is the engine often arrives at the turnstile before it has been oriented in the correct direction, hitting the rail and usually waiting there, pushing until it is turned to allow the engine through. But the engine has so much power, it sometimes ends up turning itself off the track and heading off across the room, requiring someone to chase it down.But these are minor issues and having such a peppy little engine is worth the effort.  Additional sets such as the Chuggington StackTrack Drop and Load Dash Set add to the creative ways to assemble and use the tracks.

The author has a very simple 6-part (not really step) approach to investing "safely". If I were to summarize his approach, it is this: play it safe, pay off your house first, don't do anything stupid, and don't take any chances.This means no stocks or bonds. Instead, he advocates buying a home and paying it off first, then put any more cash into government guaranteed assets in an RRSP (for Canadians). This supposedly ensures guaranteed interest and no loss of funds.While I appreciate his simple, no-nonsense approach and that he is willing to take on conventional wisdom regarding investments, I have some concerns about his approach.One issue is that stocks tend to do really well long-term. Taking the slow, steady approach with a small but sure interest has done far worse in the long term. The author seems extremely risk-adverse, which may or may not match your risk tolerance.On the other hand, if you share his fear of the market, note that his approach also won't preserve the real value of your money during periods of high inflation when interest rates don't keep up. I believe there are safer approaches to preserving wealth than his.Third, if you are of moderate means and follow his advice, you will have almost no investments other than your home. I'm not totally opposed to that approach, but it's basically putting all your hopes on the real estate market. In a downturn, you could fare very poorly. To me, that's risky.Further, the value of a mortgage can rise dramatically when interest rates go up, and one may be able to get a better return in other investments. Again, it boils down to your view of the world economy and tolerance to risk.I was disappointed in the lack of in-depth analysis in this book and very little presentation of other viewpoints, although that does match his ideology of keeping things simple. Many of the charts appear to be from the previous edition; I would have liked some more recent data. He does expose some of the downsides of conventional investing, but doesn't really consider other options or give any advice to those willing to take on some investment risk.For other views that are also contrary to the conventional stocks & bonds advice, read The Aftershock Investor: A Crash Course in Staying Afloat in a Sinking Economy and The Real Crash: America's Coming Bankruptcy - How to Save Yourself and Your Country.For a Canadian who wants to play it extremely safe, and isn't worried about inflation, his is a simple and reasonable approach. But I don't have confidence in the value of our fiat currencies long-term, and am willing to take on some risk in the hopes of greater returns on my investments. I suggest reading other books for a much more thorough analysis of investment options and then decide what is right for you.

Very readable analysis of why our economy is in big trouble and what could happen in the near future.  The authors give advice on how to prepare if their predictions come true.I found this book informative and intriguing if a bit simplistic.  There are so many factors and possibilities of ways things could unravel that weren't individually considered, that I am left wondering about alternate possibilities to the authors' prediction.They also don't go into the phases yet to come in the detail I would have liked to see.  In the end, the message just seems to be: retreat to gold before it's too late!Still, the overall message of being prepared for the inevitable collapse of our economy under the weight of our tremendous debt is an important one, and the authors provide important insights into the state of our economy and the magnitude of the necessary correction.

This is a decent accordion folder for a moderate numbers of papers (up to about 180 sheets) that should hold up well enough for a year or so of student use.  I was planning to use it in my office, but my high school daughter claimed it for herself as soon as it arrived.It is nicer than typical cheap plastic folders with extra protection on the top sides including a strip of fabric folded over the top of the accordian sides, and plastic rivets on each end (4 total).  Sometimes ours rip on the bottom and there's nothing extra to help with that, but overall the quality and durability seem very good.Each section is tabbed with paper inserts included.While the sides and top can expand, the base is fixed width at 1" so it won't expand as much as others with an accordion base.  The bottoms aren't attached along the length, so it can adjust to allow most of your papers to go in one section, but no more than 1" of papers total due to the fixed size base.

This TV is very light and extremely easy to set up. The foot design is surprisingly stable, so there's very little danger that this thing will get knocked over. Overall, it seems like a very high-quality product. I only had one issue: when I slid the TV across my dresser, one of the rubber pads came off and disappeared. I contacted Samsung, and they sent me a new set of feet at no cost.When placed on a flat surface (like a dresser), the feet lift the TV by about 1.5", which is plenty of room for most blu-ray players to fit underneath. You can also mount it on your wall, but you'll need to buy a wall mounting kit (not included).The sound quality is pretty good for a TV, and at 50% volume it's loud enough for my needs.The TV comes with Amazon Instant Video pre-installed, and the TV also has built-in WiFi which is fast enough to stream HD video without any lag. It also comes with YouTube, Hulu, and Netflix, so you can watch stuff from those sites as well. The TV can also download new apps from the internet, if there's something you need that isn't already preinstalled on the TV. This is all easily accessible using the remote.The TV only takes a couple of seconds to turn on, so I can start watching movies from my blu-ray player right away. However, there's one slight annoyance: it takes a full minute before SmartHub is ready and the contained apps are ready to use. So if you want to watch something from Amazon Instant Video, you have to wait for another minute after powering on.On the back, the TV has the following ports:* Component audio/video in (several ports)* two HDMI in ports* ANT (TV) in* USB 3.0* LAN (Local Area Network)* Digital optical audio outI've only needed to use the HDMI port, but the audio out will be useful if I ever want to upgrade to a high quality speaker system.

I've had great luck with the SanDisk microSD cards in everything from my android phone to GoPro HERO3 Black.  The adapter lets it work in most any device taking SD or microSD cards.According to SanDisk, this version has a faster max reading speed than the old version at 80MB/sec vs 48MB/sec, with the minimum writing speed unchanged at 10MB/sec.

This is a great cleaner for paints, inks, and anything that requires a non-water solvent-based cleaner.  I've used it to get pen and marker out of couch fabric, to clean streaks of paint out of carpet, and even to get stubborn stains off my hands.  Use with care on painted surfaces!For fabrics, try putting this on a terry cloth and blotting out the stain.For ink or other stains on smooth surfaces, I strongly suggest trying something safer first such as Mr. Clean Magic Eraser sponges.  Those are amazing and much safer than Goof Off.

It is rare that I find a new childrens book of this caliber! My teens loved it, girls and boys both, and I could barely put it down myself.This inspirational story featured a truly virtuous protagonist, a knight-to-be on a critical but mysterious mission in a Middle Ages setting full of knights, barons, monks, robbers and peasants - many varied, and interesting characters of all sorts brought to life in a masterful way. The kingdoms portrayed in the book are fascinating and realistic, brought to life in richly described settings.The story is suspenseful and engaging, even reminiscent of The Hobbit, one of my favorite books, but no dragons or wizards, but rather a more realistic and fascinating world full of perils and surprises.I am surprised that a work of this quality and magnitude has taken so long to translate into English. And the translation is quite good, reading smoothly and naturally. The language is fine English, very appropriate for the story and a great pleasure to read.This is surely destined to be a classic work in English as it was in the original Dutch. It is long at about 500 pages but not too hard to read (though I had to look up crenellated). Excellent for ages 12 to adult, including teens, young adults, and anyone who loves to read a suspenseful and action-filled adventure!

Great quality and smooth rich balm that feels great and lasts. Doesn't dry out my lips later. The scents are pleasant, and there are no added colors. All of the lip balms in this set contain beeswax, as well as other moisturizers including lanolin and sunflower seed oil. Definitely worth the price.Note that the two "original" lip balms aren't fruit-flavored, but have a strong peppermint flavor instead. They also cause a cold sensation (probably from naturally-occurring menthol in the peppermint) which feels really good. Some reviewers didn't like the feeling, but it seems fine to me, and anyway it stops after a few minutes. The original lip balm is also firmer than the other fruit flavors, making it less likely to wear off.The other natural lip balm we all love is eos - a little pricier but we like it even better.

This humidifier uses ultrasound to vaporize the water into a cool mist. The main advantage to a "cool mist" humidifier is that it begins producing mist as soon as it's turned on. Some people prefer to use steam humidifiers, however, because they boil and sterilize the water, and don't eject live mold or bacteria into the air. This humidifier does not boil the water at all; if you use the warm mist setting instead of the cool mist setting, all it does is warm the water to about 80 degrees before it vaporizes it (which actually makes it easier for bacteria to thrive). If the humidifier is maintained well and cleaned periodically, this shouldn't be a problem, but I wouldn't recommend sticking your face into the mist and inhaling deeply.Regarding the warm-mist setting, it speeds up the humidification of the room. Because it heats the water to only 80 degrees before it vaporizes it, I can't imagine it would be very effective if the water starts out warm (especially during the summer), but in cold temperatures I could understand how it might help. (The mist itself feels almost the same whether you're using warm or cold mist.)I like the other features. One is variable mist output - I can adjust the amount of mist that comes out. On the fastest mist setting, running constantly, a full 2-gallon water tank lasts a little under 2 days (~43 hours, actually). You can make it even faster by removing the attachments. I haven't tried the lowest mist setting for extended periods of time, but based on the level of mist coming out, I bet it would last the full 120 hours as advertised.Probably the most useful feature is the desired humidity level; you can set the humidity anywhere from 40% to 75% (in 5% increments), or you can tell the humidifier to run constantly. There's also an optional timer, so I can tell the humidifier to turn off automatically after a period of time. The room's current humidity is displayed on the screen.When "auto" is enabled, the humidifier automatically uses warm mist, keeps the nightlight on, and sets the desired humidity to 50%. Kind of pointless, because those are all features that I can easily set myself.I really like the vertical extension. It's basically a pipe which takes the mist about 4 feet above the ground before releasing it into the air. This allows for more even humidification, because the mist is heavier than air and sinks downward. There's also another attachment which goes on the end of the tube, and can be used to direct the mist. I prefer not to use it, because it restricts the airflow, so a lot of the mist collects on the inside and runs back down into the humidifier. This slows down the humidification process.The thing I find most annoying about the humidifier is that it has a bright blue display that won't turn off. If I'm running it in my bedroom at night, I have to cover the display with some cardboard so it won't keep me up. The display is bright enough to illuminate objects in my room. It wouldn't be so bad if they used green or red light, but blue is the specific color that prevents sleep. I hate to think how bright the nightlight would be, but thankfully that can be turned off.Another problem I noticed is that the water in the vaporization area gets a slight off-odor if it sits for a couple days without running it. The obvious solution here is to pour out the water when it isn't being used, but now I wonder whether the inside of the tank is the only part of the unit with antibacterial properties.So to summarize, it's a pretty cool humidifier (pun intended), and has a lot of useful features, but it does have minor issues.Pros:+ Very quiet (regardless of the settings).+ Adjustable mist output. Nozzles can be removed if necessary, so the mist will come out faster.+ Large 2-gallon tank lasts almost 2 days when running at highest setting, 5 days at lowest setting.+ The humidifier maintains a specific humidity, or can be told to run continuously.+ Comes with a vertical extension, which brings the mist 4 feet up into the air.+ Cool mist will slightly cool the room in Summer.+ Unit without water is very light, making storage easy.+ Has an optional built-in nightlight.Cons:- The bright blue display cannot be turned off at night.- Only the tank seems to have antibacterial properties; the other parts of the humidifier are unprotected.- Uses ultrasound, so water is not sterilized. If tap water is used, minerals are released into the air.- The buttons respond to a very light touch, and can be activated when accidentally brushed against.

This well-made pack is best suited for overnight or weekend backpacking trips, or possibly longer.  It is fine for all-day hikes as well, especially for those who tend to carry more.  The color is sort of muted teal, not quite as bright as the amazon pictures.  We have had good experiences with Kelty backpacks as far as utility, durability and comfort and this one is no exception.This backpack will fit the vast majority of women as it has a generous torso range of 14.5" to 18.5".  The shoulder straps slide up or down to ensure a correct position with the pack resting on the hips.  There are 2 coated aluminum strips running the height of the pack behind the shoulder and waist pads for enough rigidity to keep the pack from slouching.  For shorter women, the top of the pack will rise nicely above the shoulders.  It has just the right amount of padding for the back and hips.The main pack has a cinch closure on top with a rain flap.  It also has a side zipper midway up for secondary access into the main pack.  There are a few smaller pouches on the back and top (on the rain flap) as well as 2 small pockets on the waist belt.  There are 2 side mesh pockets that can we used for water bottles, though I didn't see anywhere special for a water system or corded MP3 player as you might find in a day pack.The pack is fully adjustable with straps everywhere.  It can expand or contract to fit a variety of load sizes using straps to keep the weight center closer to the body.  There are 2 loops on the lower back and some sewn straps on the bottom for external attachments, as well as a large hanging loop.  The fabric is durable nylon and there is mesh inside the waist belt and midback for breathability.This should (roughly) fit most women from about 5'4" to about 5'11" with an average torso to height ratio.  If you are in the middle of that you will be fine with this pack.  Otherwise, to ensure a good fit, measure your torso from the bony protrusion on the back of the neck (tilt your head forward) to the top of the hips.

This book is an enjoyable read touching on many aspects of evaluating character and abilities in others, with plenty of anecdotes and a measure of humor thrown in.  The book covers how to evaluate, choose, attract and retain great leaders and team members for any type of organization.  It also talks about how to be a great leader and improve one's skills and effectiveness, building a positive culture, choosing values, and handling legal issues.  It even provides guidance on how to pick a new leader for an organization.Rather than provide a step-by-step guide to making leadership decisions, the author aims to change your thinking and processes for making decisions and handling a variety of milestones in running an organization or team.  Some of my favorite parts of the book challenge conventional thinking about topics such as compensation, what makes effective workers, or even how to analytically choose a spouse!One chapter that particularly impressed me included one on working with team members and the importance of alternate, even opposing, viewpoints in an effective team.  I tend to gravitate towards like-minded individuals, and have to make a conscious effort to include and value others with different mindsets.He does make one claim I remain skeptical about: `You don't need to go out looking for geniuses since, for most jobs, there is a "threshold level" IQ needed, and anything above it has almost no impact on performance.' (p.87)  However, I do appreciate his insights into seeing the many facets of individuals, and the great importance of potential, "our ability to grow and adapt to fundamentally different and increasingly complex responsibilities.... [including] keen insight that allows them to see connections where others don't."  These, I think, are part of IQ.Overall, I believe his wealth of experience and well-founded guidance will prove valuable to anyone involved in management or hiring decisions.

This is a really cool toy for boys ages 7 to 10, although other ages and many girls will most likely find it interesting as well. Various lion growls and roars are automatically activated when certain features on the Lion's Den castle are used; according to my 10-year-old son, this makes the toy seem like a lot more fun. But if the sound becomes too annoying, it can be disabled with the flick of a switch.Included are a toy king, a soldier, two suits of armor, two shields, two double-sided axes, a king outfit, a throne, a toy lion, and a green villain.  The Lion's Den castle itself is large - about 2 feet across and 16" high.The castle also comes with a disk launcher, which is actually strong enough to activate special features on the castle. It surprised me how well it worked, as similar features in other products tend to be cheap gimmicks.  Not so with Imaginext - I've found several of their products we own to be consistently well made and durable.Features that can be activated by the shooting disks include: a tower that will collapse when hit; a secret exit from the dungeon that opens; and a flag that will terminate "defense mode" when hit by the disk launcher.The other features of the castle include "defense mode," which means that the doors and openings are secured; a trap door which drops the enemy into a dungeon; a door that opens to release a toy lion; and a moving paw which grabs enemy pieces and pulls them into a dungeon. My kids particularly enjoyed the moving paw; the mechanism works nicely, and it's fun to see the bad guys being snatched by a castle.The Lion's Den has proven substantial enough to provide many hours of playtime for my boys, and can be added to with other Imaginext products in the same "Castle" line, such as the Castle Serpent Vehicle.

I need licorice for an adrenal boost. I get this because it is cost-efficient as pure licorice root extract without added sweeteners or artificial additives - the only other ingredient is organic mint flavor. It is an aquired taste: naturally, mildly sweet with a strong bitter flavor similar to something like coffee.  Awesome little box to stick in my purse!I suck on two little pellets after breakfast and again after lunch to get my required dose. If I take it before bed I feel slightly wired, so I don't recommend that. :-)Don't get this if you are looking for sweet candies; it is a powerful, pure concentrated licorice with bold flavor.

If I take this right as I start to feel sickness coming on, I can avoid coming down with it. I take one every 8-12 hours for a total of 3 packages. It has really worked for me this way, though not as well when I'm already sick. TPA is specifically for people who have poor immune function due to a poorly functioning thymus gland, which seems to be most Americans.

Update 5/5/2015:Even after the latest updates, this unit is still the worst Garmin I've ever owned.  They seem to have slightly corrected the time to destination calculation, but it still overestimates.  But the horrendous traffic reporting still has the major flaws: re-routing you onto overcrowded back streets without telling you what the delay on the main route is, and still no "traffic search" feature to show traffic delays on nearby roads.When you hit serious traffic, you're on your own.Update 11/26/2014  Traffic reporting is totally worthless when you need it most!During some recent pre-Thanksgiving traffic, I came to realize more than ever how horrendous the traffic feature is on this GPS unit.  Coming home from work on the Friday before Thanksgiving week in heavy traffic, the GPS wanted me to get off the freeway and onto a main road with traffic lights.  I knew that the alternate road was often jammed also.  So I wanted to know how long the delay on the freeway was to make an educated decision.But this GPS won't tell you!  There is no way to see nearby traffic.  It only shows the traffic on the route it has chosen (and sometimes on one alternate route if you know how to check that).  And since the alternate road wasn't a freeway, the GPS thought it had NO traffic.  I took the exit anyway (I'll explain later), and sure enough, the road was DEADLOCKED.  Fortunately, it was the same exit as a friends house - in the other direction, and as the Garmin was giving me NO indication of how long the backup on the freeway was, I went there for the next few hours and watched the traffic online (since the Garmin was pretty much useless).On my older Garmins, I can simply hit the traffic icon on the main screen, select "Traffic Search" and see ALL the nearby traffic sorted by distance away.  Then I can select any of the roads listed and see all the delays on that road.  But no more!  This 2597LMT will only show the delays on its chosen route.  There is a hard to find menu option to show "Incidents" which has only ever shown construction.So when it really counts, this GPS is a total let down in terms of traffic reporting.  Garmin, please FIX this major issue!  If anyone knows a work-around, PLEASE reply to this review and I'll update it.  I called Garmin and they said the traffic search feature had been removed from newer Garmins.Original Review:I have several Garmins and have had this one for about 7 months now and am very disappointed.It is missing a lot of features my older Garmins have, such as viewing local traffic by radius - now it only shows traffic on the current route so it is impossible to know other traffic in the area, except looking at the hard-to-see colors on the overhead map, which DON'T show the delay times.  I would use this often, so if traffic to one store is terrible, I might want to see what the total traffic picture is in the area to decide whether to choose my own route or simply go to a different store, etc.  Can't do this anymore.There are some improvements to routing, so it will SOMETIMES find better routes automatically, but often still won't find the best route, esp. if traffic is involved and despite the fact that it KNOWS the delay times.  Again, since this model won't show me the traffic on nearby roads, I can't decide whether to take an alternate route that I know about.  There's no way to force it to show all the multiple routes to a destination so I can pick one myself based on my knowledge of those roads.The automatic rerouting sometimes inexplicably doesn't do anything, even if an alternate route is 15+ minutes faster.  When I suspect this is the case, I will cancel the current route entirely and start over, and then finally it shows the better route.  There seems to be an overall very poor traffic handling with this unit, as if traffic were an afterthought and isn't very well integrated or even fully functional.Also the voice commands is cool but very limited in what you can do; for many common things you have to go back to the touch screen. For example, there are no traffic voice commands.It also totally overestimates time to destination.  The older Garmins assume there are no such things as red lights, and you always go the speed limit no matter what (around turns, etc).  They overcorrected on this model by arbitrarily adding about 40% to the commute time.  For example, it might say 44 minutes for a 28 minute trip for no apparent reason, whereas the older Garmins might have said 24 minutes.  If I didn't know better, I might just give up and go home instead of making it to my movie with time to spare.Finally, the cord isn't durable.  My first one lasted about 6 months with careful use before shorting out.  (Garmin did send a new one with little hassle.)  Every trip I carefully put it in my glove compartment to avoid being stolen (no yanking of the cord).  And the cord is very stiff in colder weather, which can be annoying depending on where you mount it.  And after a couple of months the suction cup keeps falling off the windshield - I've been meaning to try putting Armor All on it but haven't gotten around to it yet.Many newer navigation systems will learn your routes.  Despite the fact that I take the same route out of my community every day, it still keeps trying to take me on slower roads through the neighborhood where I'd also have to take a left at a stop sign onto a busy road instead of the main route out that everyone takes.  It doesn't seem to realize which the main roads in the community are, which wouldn't be so bad if it could eventually learn that I always go a different way and use that route instead.So while the older Garmins were good for their time (except for underestimating travel times), this unit really needs a major redesign to make full and proper use of the features.On the plus side, there's enough memory in it now to upgrade the included North America maps including USA and Canada without having to add a memory card.While this unit is certainly useable and probably really deserves 3 stars, but because it is so poorly programmed and so inferior to older models, I am only giving it 1 star.  If they fix the firmware I will update my review.

I love this mattress.  I usually spend several days finding just the right mattress and this is one of the best I've slept on.  Softer mattresses, and especially older ones that sag in the middle, really bother my lower back.This Dreamax DM-230Q provides great support plus a soft, comfortable feel.  I actually fall asleep faster on this mattress than our higher-end Simmons!  I usually go to sleep on my side or stomach and wake up on my back.  On this mattress, I can sleep on my back, side or stomach and feel very comfortable.  This is a sturdy, heavy mattress; I'd rate it mid-level overall; not light like cheaper bunk-bed mattresses and not super-sized like some of the $1000 ones.The mattress arrives in a surprisingly small but heavy box.  The mattress is compressed to about a 3" thickness and rolled top-to-bottom into a long box.  It took two of us to carry the queen size and put it on our platform bed.  No boxspring is needed with this mattress!  Keep in mind also that it is heavy, and there are no handles or straps built into the mattress to help move it in the future.No need to worry about the mattress being compressed in shipping - most spring sets are shipped to the manufacturers compressed anyway, and the springs can handle that just fine.Once decompressed, our mattress measures about 10" thick; 7.5" for the spring box and 2.5" for the pillowtop.  The fabric is very nice and sturdy quality, and the top feels soft and luxurious.  There was only a little "new mattress" smell, and after a few days is almost gone.  I am sensitive to chemical smells (and had to return a mattress once due to the odor causing sinus problems) but the slight lingering odor in this mattress is very mild and actually pleasant.The mattress has 13.5 gauge coils with a 312 count innerspring, which is on the firmer side by the numbers.  To me it feels like a medium-soft mattress; medium firmness underneath that feels softer due to the pillowtop.I've tried memory foam but found that as those mold to my body I'd sink in and my back would hurt; plus, when I moved they would take too long to re-form to my body.  I also prefer the feel of an innerspring mattress.  I get both great comfort and the support I need with this mattress.The only issue I am having is that it sags too much when I sit on the edge of the bed.  This most bothersome in the morning when I drowsily swing myself into a sitting position and it feels like I am sliding onto the floor.  This may bother anyone over my weight of 170lbs or so.  Most higher-end mattresses have extra support (usually foam) all around the sides to prevent this, but perhaps that would make it harder to ship compressed.  The corners do have extra support.The mattress can be flipped top-to-bottom (but not upside down) for more even wear over the years.

What sets this headset apart is the very long battery life combined with the amazing sound.  I know of no other headset that will give you such great sound and 15 hours of use between charges.  I listened to everything from classical to rock and watched videos with dialog.  They all sounded wonderful, although I did want a little more bass.  I would describe the sound as crisp, clear, and natural.  One can install the Samsung Level app (if you have Android 4.2.2 or later) or a bass boosting app to help personalize the sound.Yes, there are headphones with better sound.  What Samsung did with these is give maximum sound quality balanced with long-lasting battery life.  And they did that amazingly well.Included in the box are the headphones, a nice semi-flexible card case, an audio cable with multi-function buttons and MIC, airplane adaptor, data link cable (USB to micro-USB), and manual.  The headphones have a small on/off switch, a button for Bluetooth sync and turning on/off noise cancelling, mic for talking, and 2 front mics for noise cancelling.  There's an extra mic on the back of the right ear cup and Samsung says there is a fourth hidden inside an ear cup to help with noise cancellation also.The noise cancellation works remarkably well, and the ear pads alone provide privacy so people right next to me can't hear what I'm listening to.  Though I haven't tried these on a plane yet, when planes are going over my house, I can hear a low-pitched rumble until I press the ANC button to turn on the cancellation - then the annoying rumble disappears completely and I only hear a much less annoying light white noise.  There are mics on the front of the headphones for cancellation; if you touch them you get noise through the noise cancellation system.  This is a quick way to verify it is turned on.  It works best on humming/rumbling noises, targeting the sounds that most interfere with your listening experience.  Note that it only works on external sound, so it won't cancel noises in your head; you'll have to look elsewhere for help with that.It is easy to register the headphones with a Bluetooth device such as a smartphone or tablet using the ANC button or NFC.  I am using it mostly with my Samsung Galaxy S Blaze Android phone.  Unlike my Logitech Z600 speakers, I wasn't able to connect these headphones to multiple devices simultaneously (probably a good thing considering the intended use).  You can also use the included audio cable, which has volume controls and a multi-function button for answering calls and the like, and the included airplane adapter allows these to be used with the L/R jacks on older planes.I found the fit and comfort great for headphones of this size.
