They weigh 350g, or about the weight of 2 cell phones.  The cushioned adjustable headband rests comfortably on the top of my head holding the ear cups nicely in place.  While the ear cups don't swivel, they are also cushioned for better fit.  I wear wire-rimmed glasses and they fit over them fine.  They are a bit cumbersome in bed due to their size - I have to tilt the top forward a little lying back on my pillow.  These Samsung Level In ear buds would be much better for use in bed, or possibly the Samsung Level On, the other headphones in their lineup.  Samsung also offers a Samsung Level Box bluetooth speaker.The right ear cup is a touchpad that allows volume adjustments and track fwd/rev, as well as multi-function tapping to answer calls or turn on S Voice for voice commands to the connected device.  The volume increases gradually but will reduce quickly, which is useful when someone starts talking to you or music starts up too loudly.I found that with my phone at least, using Bluetooth I needed to adjust volume on both the phone and the headset - they are separate but both affect the actual volume.  At first I didn't realize this and wondered why the sound wasn't very loud.  With the cable, however, the volume is only adjusted through the device or buttons on the cable - the touchpad does nothing.  In fact, the headphones work with the audio cable whether the they are switched on or off.The Samsung Level app only works with Anrdroid 4.2.2 or later (newer Jelly Bean, KitKat); if you can't find it in Google Play, just google search for it on the device.  While useful and cool, it isn't necessary to use the headphones.  As of today the manual isn't available online, so don't lose it!

Update 5/11/2015Got another shipment and the chemical smell is back. This is obviously a sporadic but ongoing problem.Update 2/2015:I decided to give these another try (actually my amazon subscribe & save shipped them automatically), and the new shipment didn't have the smell problem.  There is still a very faint odor, but it isn't the same as before and is so slight as to not bother me at all.  It would seem the smell issue I and a few other reviewers reported has been resolved.Original review:Every one of these tissues that I tried (from several boxes) had a strange disgusting chemical pesticide-like smell.  I called Kleenex and was told the tissues shouldn't have a smell and they would send coupons to replace the product.  But they only sent me two $1 coupons to replace 8 boxes of tissues!Now I see several other reviewers complaining of a weird odor, including someone who purchased them elsewhere.I did not notice any tissue fibers coming off these tissues like some reviewers reported.  Maybe they fixed that?  They do seem slightly less absorbent than regular tissues, but that wasn't an issue for us.  However, we aren't using them anymore because of the headache-inducing smell.Regular Kleenex are fine, no smell at all.  I also like the cheaper Angel Soft Facial Tissue, 12 Count or 18 Count, which have no bad odors, but aren't quite as strong as Kleenex.

This is a nice phone, my wife is very happy with it. She loves the mid-sized screen at 4.5" and the fact that it is so responsive. Gorilla glass is great too.If you are thinking about this phone look at the newer LG Optimus L90. Twice the memory (8GB) so much better capacity for apps etc. Also the L90 is 1.2GHz quad vs. 1.0GHz dual on the L9. And it has a 4.7" screen, and the newer 4.4 KitKat Android OS. The T-Mobile Prepaid L90 can be found for much less than the $150 we paid for the L9 last year.

This is a nice phone; my wife is very happy with it.  She loves the mid-sized screen at 4.5" and the fact that it is so responsive.  Gorilla glass is great too.If you are thinking about this phone look at the newer LG Optimus L90.  Twice the memory (8GB) so much better capacity for apps etc.  Also the L90 is 1.2GHz quad vs. 1.0GHz dual on the L9.  And it has a 4.7" screen, and the newer 4.4 KitKat Android OS.  The T-Mobile Prepaid L90 can be found for under the $150 we paid for the L9 last year.

This is better than a Cadbury bar, and yes, that is damning with faint praise. To their credit, Cailler is very generous, cramming this bar full of cranberries and nuts. On the other hand, this leaves little room for chocolate, or a chocolaty taste. The substrate is creamy and mildly sweet, but there is no chocolate punch.I would rate higher but for the mid-premium price.

A shelf and drawer liner that is removable? -Not rubbery so it can be removed easily? Washable? It all sounded good, but I found the imagined utility was not there. For cupboards, it turns out I like contact paper better because I can wipe a sponge and clean, instead of removing and washing cloth. While I appreciate the fact that I can slide objects across the surface without impediment, again, regular contact paper does the job. And yes, certainly these liners are more attractive than almost any contact paper, but for many shelves and drawers the liner is out of sight.For refrigerators, I immediately noticed that these liners were opaque (duh) and rendered the interior a shadowed cavern. They are certainly not going to line the veggie drawers at the bottom because, again, simply sponging out an unlined drawer is easier than removing odor-absorbing cloth liners that have to be washed.This is hypothetical, but I can actually see this liner being of use as a table runner; they look good and are cheaper than many runners of the same coverage. The second use would be on display shelves where the bare surface is unattractive. Choose the right color and the liner makes a very nice backdrop.The textile itself seems to be of quality construction.

John Sanford impresses more and more. Correct science in the "science" fiction: yes.  orbital mechanics, check. Brilliantly delineated cynical politicians, nailed it. Character development: people you learn to care about in peril. The Big Idea--unique! Pacing and suspense, yes yes yes.Humor, of course.Sanford brought Ctein aboard for the science, and in hundreds of pages, only once did my nerd radar twitch. There is a delightful postscript too, describing the science.Dialog is a Sanford forte and he carries it over to "Saturn Run". These are Joss Whedon, Aaron Sorkin level interchanges.And WHAT is out there orbiting Saturn? What a great concept he comes up with! I have read thousands of pages of SciFi and it is hard to come up with anything that has not been thought of before. I will of course be argued with, but for me, this exact concept is new, and that is amazing. I just can't talk about it because spoilers.I will say that keeping the crew of the "Richard M. Nixon" in the dark about the mysterious Chinese space vehicle gave an ominous tension to the book, and subsequent revelations inform us re human nature. Great way to handle that part of the story.I do have a complaint: it ended. Yes, it ended when it needed to end: not chopped short and not dragged out. It was just right, of course. needs an Ah, but how I wished for another hundred pages.Two comments:-If humanity gets hold of a way to produce abundant antimatter before we colonize the asteroid belt we will kill our own species; all our eggs in one basket, as Hawkings says.-Sandord views humanity with that American blend of cynical ill-regard of humanity en masse and those who come to control societies, counter balanced with optimistic ebullient affection for individuals of the species.
There may be better tape made by someone else, but every other brand seems to be an inferior knockoff. I have no brand loyalty; somebody direct me to a better brand and I'll jump ship.

I quite like the look and feel of this lightweight, minimalist case. If you must sacrifice the svelte 8 ounce thinness of the iPad 2 for the sake of protection (while traveling, for instance) and do not need water resistence, this is the case.I am not a fan of the screen protector- any screen protector, really. But the case itself feels good in the grip and is half the weight of the typical Otterbox. I am not about to test its claimed 6 foot drop protection, but it feels up to the task. The sharp 90 degree corners are surprisingly appealing to the eye and the touch. These corners deform under pressure for shock absorbtion, so it is claimed. One hopes.There are no button extensions to feel with your fingers, just faint embossments marking where you must press. Best to memorize to location of your power and volume controls. Pressing the proper spot does press the iPad's buttons properly but one star off because the embossments need to be thicker.A star off because the back shows fingerprints as badly as any screen. It should be patterned.

I can still feel the weight on my tongue and taste of a couple of little pieces half an hour later. Put the rest of the bar is some semi-inaccessible nook at the other end of the house. No, really. Don't sit there with the rest of the bar within reach. Fifteen minutes later the whole thing will be gone; eaten up.Make it last two, three days. Be strong.Just a few simple ingredients well blended. No soy lecithin or emulsifier.

Dean Koontz is to Steven King as Robert Crais is to... every other crime/thriller writer I guess. By this I mean that he is more optimistic and affectionate toward humanity. There is a strong and overt moral compass in his outlook. Donald Westlake created the great anti hero Parker, and also his sometimes partner Grofield, who was the other side of the coin: wisecracking and light-hearted. Elvis Cole is Crais' Grofield, and Pike is his Parker. However, Of course, Crais being Crais, Pike is no thief and murderer.Here are some impressions about "The Promise".-Who knows how dogs think? But Crais writes GREAT dog. Maggie the ex-war dog is a wonderful creation, full of love and fierceness. You really really don't like to see her in peril, which of course, she is.-Bob Scott, a K9 patrolman, is a new character and a co-protagonist in the story beside Elvis Cole. He is a fleshed out character: young, ernest, and  emotional, loves his dog. We like him and of course, HE is in peril. More to worry about.-The story is complex and keeps us puzzling until it shakes out into a satisfying clarity well along in the story.-The rythme of action scene/exposition/detective work/more action is skilled.-The character Jon is introduced. I have a feeling we may see more of him, perhaps in a spinoff novel entirely devoted to his character, This is what happened with Elvis' sidekick Joe Pike, to my great pleasure ("The Watchman", "The First Rule", etc.)-The sympathy and love shown toward Amy, the woman who lost her son, is moving.On the minus side:-"The Promise" was not a compulsive page-turner. Somehow I found it easy to put down and not get back to for days.-What happens with Scott's girlfriend? She drops off the map.-Near the end of the book (no spoilers) the character "Charles" indicates big big internal conflict, and takes a radical action the motivation for which needs to be explored.

This is the first in a series of books set in New York City about several wealthy siblings who have seen their parents and own relationships crash and burn so badly that none of them are interested in a relationship. This book is about the middle brother, Dane, and his experience meeting the lounge singer Julia for his new luxury hotel. While this author is new to me, it appears that this book is similar to others she has written, so if youre a Jennifer Gracen fan, you should be pleased with this new release.Gracen seems to lean toward writing steamier romance novels. Our two main protagonists are irresistibly, physically drawn to each other, which is fine since neither is looking for an emotional attachment. The book explores each characters discovery that there may be more to life than just sex, and that past wounds may be overcome if they are brave enough to extend themselves one more time.Why didnt I give this book 5 stars? While I enjoy steam, I find I prefer it in lighter doses. The author interweaves so many references to the physical attraction so often -- especially at the beginning of the book -- that for me, after so many small sips of seduction I just wanted to say yeah, yeah, yeah, can we just get back to the plot? by the time a full-on seduction scene actually commenced. It seemed like the efforts to promote chemistry actually reduced the effect for me.The first half of the book was a bit slower than the second half, but the last quarter of the book was great. Finally we dig into the emotional content that makes a book interesting to me. The characters finally become real and we finally have reasons to care about them. The author introduces that old  last-minute break-up/reunion trope. This is a pet peeve of mine which usually makes me roll my eyes. I was very happy to see that for once,the cause was actually realistic and believable.If you are looking for a steamy romance novel with wounded characters who ultimately find that missing something in each other, there is a good chance you'll enjoy this book.(Mrs. Js)

I would not expect to give 5 stars to such a moderately priced tee, but this is a quality product.The stitching is well done and the threads at the collar are soft.The black tee is surprisingly color fast and black color has not faded in 2 Washings.The 40% poly added to the cotton gives a slight stretch for a nice fit.Drip dries wrinkle-free overnight if you hang it up right out of the washer.My medium fit well, even with my long torso.I like the trend of printing the brand/laundry instructions on the cloth itself.  Oxford NY uses labels but they are not irritating.
Lots of filament tape is too thin and tends to separate lengthwise. This stuff is thicker and high quality.

Very well sewn by ladies and gentlemen in Bangladesh. Faultless and thoroughly-stitched medium denim on the outside and polyester felt material from top to bottom inside. There is a tool loop and two extra narrow pockets, one 9 deep, one 5. The inseam claims 32 and is slightly shorter. The Waist is supposed to be 36 and is closer to 33".I will update this winter for how this feels in the wind, but I can estimate that working down to 20 degrees in calm weather, or standing idle at around freezing should be fine. Looks to be too warm for all but the most brisk autumn nights, unless you have circulation problems. If so, then these should be very comfy.Obviously not for cold and wet environments. That is the purview of wool or synthetics, not cotton. A good value for the price.

The cable is the same thickness as Apple OEM, and the Barrel is slightly longer and thicker so that it might not fit some cases. Apparently authorized after-market manufacturers have learned how to make reliable lightning cables now.The Amazon cable is somewhat less flexible, but this is apparently worth the trade-off. Why? because my iPad2 charged substantially faster (2.1 Amp) than the Apple cable, and slightly faster than a Belkin.As for the length, I have cables of all lengths from 4 inches to ten feet. They all have their uses. The shorties pack well for travel attached to portable chargers. The longer ones are great for charging while in use.

Perhaps Not.Four Stars, but really 5 star writing and 2 stars for making me unhappy in the particular way the story ends that sent me into a sulk.This is the book for those who want to share in the delicious  love-fest mass experience of Lord of the Rings  or Game of Thrones readers-- except for the ordeal of reading the stuff.How can you not honor a writer who pens:As usual a small number of Flemworthys more superfluous inhabitants had gathered in the Square to enjoy the spectacle of people parking their cars....she had abandoned work and gone off to be a pole-dancer in Lapland. Or was it a lap-dancer in Poland?Back in his dusky parlor, he fumbled at the experience like an ape looking for the edible parts of a digital camera.We cuddon see nothun cos the glass was covered in condescension.The author with the unlikely name of Mal Peet (I checked for wicked anagrams but no luck) produces rich prose indeed in the Murdstone trilogy, The Murstone Trilogy is much much more about the writer (or is he?) than the trilogy itself. We do indeed get some pages of fantastical description full of Morl and Swelts and Cadrel and the Greme and The Amulet of Power and whatnot. Not so much as to induce nausea or narcolepsy, but to give you the idea, before we return to poor Phillip Murdstone, much beset author and a man less than the sum of his parts who gets past a huge period of writers block to strike gold and tap into the most high voltage of all Muses to produce Dark Entropy, the biggest thing since LOTR and Harry Potter. This is due to the fantastical visit of Pocket. Pocket is a Greme, a kind of malign and more virulent version of Dobby the Elf in  Harry Potter. Beware Gremes bearing gifts, but wheres the story in that? Of course Phllip Murdstone makes his Faustian deal, and hilarity and horror ensue. Phillip's success is delicious, and the consequence as well.  *  *  *  *  *  *SPOILER:Do read this book, and skip perhaps the few chapters, when you sense things turning all wiggly, insert the Xtrapol8 computer program, slipped to Murdstones agent, the lovely Minerva by her publisher, into your own computer, and have it write the last few chapters, as it does 40% of all British soap operas, with Fecundity and narrative grasp (that are) extraordinary, and as it will the madness-deleted third and final part of the Murdstone Trilogy.And if it was ALL in his head, what of the Giant Fly?Finally, sadly, I learn that Mr. Peet died in March of 2015. I will never know if his ending was somewhat forced by his illness or deliberate. Sorry that I will be reading no more of his adult novels. I will find and read his much praised children's book "Keeper".

I don't use laurel sulfate on what is left of my hair. Usually warm water and a scratchy-scrub keep my hair in looking good, in good health, and with body. Remember: "squeaky clean" means the natural oil in your hair has been removed. But occasionally my hair gets enough dust or debris in it that I use this product. I think coconut milk tastes like sweat squeezed out of socks, but this stuff is just fine on on top of my head, removing dirt but leaving natural oils.It has no thickening agents so it can spill right out of your hands. I remove it from its original container and put it in a pump bottle; less waste.

Contemplating the deliberate ingestion of whey slurry, even if infused with cocoa powder, will make any sensible person quail. Nonetheless, Zig somehow manages to make this product palatable. In fact, mildly pleasant.When I ski, I am not so fat of wallet that I can comfortably contemplate $12 hamburgers and $4 cups of chocolate. I stuff my pockets with "ensure" type products, or power bars ("Zone Perfectly Simple" brand is my favorite) to hydrate me and keep me going. These 180 calorie bags of refueling material take up much less weight and somewhat less space than protein shakes. As long as you can find a source of water, especially cold water, This the way to go. Fill  with 6 ounces of water, shake, for 30 seconds, and you have thin chocolate "milk". Afterwards, just crumple and toss.Note: the packet does not lie perfectly flat in the pocket, having a sort of mixing cage inside.

Prepared to cut a lot of slack to an iPad cover that is much more affordable than the absurdly expensive Apple folding iPad cover, I found not enough of that slackness to accept this as more than a 3-star effort from the usually solid  Bellkin.To be fair, Belkin makes a slightly different cover for the Air 2, which I have. Go ahead and give this a try for the Air 1.Pros:-Fits the iPad Air  snugly and will provide real scratch protection and some impact protection.-Magnets provide proper shut-down signal to iPad.Cons:-Case is too pliable at its "hinges" to provide precise positioning. Better on the Air 1?-Button manipulation is difficult even through the generous openings.-Notches provide less than firm seating for the various tilt angles.

These tiny altricial humans can barely roll over. Their environment blasts them with uncontrollable inputs of supreme intensity. Tiny fingers reach out, curl, and sweep in uncontrolled spasms. They touch microfiber. They touch slightly rough linen. They touch satin. They feel fluffiness, then smoothness. They push at floppy folds. They clutch and hear crinkles.Who can see into the minds of these miniature proto-humans? I think this is making little William happy.

I have gotten to the point where if I buy a tool it is going to last a lifetime because 1) My lifetime isn't all that much any more,  and 2) I finally see the false economy of less costly tools that are serviceable but not a pleasure to use.That being said,I don't turn up my nose at Black and Decker.  I couldn't always afford Knipex, Snap-On, or what have you. When you're on a budget, good enough will do. So no, this Black and Decker isn't buttery smooth and quiet like saws costing 3 and 4 times as much, but B&D has stepped up its game here.  It is a noisy little beast, but seems very well put together. They have designed a lot of value into an economical package. On the plus side:-Inserting/removing the blade is dead easy and intuitive and the blade is held securely.-The control for increasing orbital action is big, well marked, and easy to use.-You can attach a vacuum hose in the back, although you will probably need a step adapter for most American vacs.-The shoe adjusts from flat to about 25 degrees and then 45 degrees.Some of the compromises that had to be made to keep the price so affordable:-Again, noisy.-I find the light weight means you have to keep more downward pressure on the saw if the material is difficult; you can't completely let the saw do the work for you.-The vacuum suction intake is too far back to do much good.-The saw speed is variable by trigger pull, but you can't lock in a certain speed.-The trigger lock, unlike the orbital dial, is small and pressing it is finicky. It only locks at top speed.-The shoe has to be adjusted to only two positions: 25 or 45 degrees by means of a screw rather than a lever, but that is easy enough and a cost-saving compromise.-The power cord is only 7'. A 10' length or more would be nicer, buy hey, just leave an extension cord attached.-Finally, and most importantly, every time you pick it up you will hit the trigger and start the saw. The trigger is large and your grip naturally falls on the trigger. This could be dangerous.So with all those compromises, why 4 stars? Because  B&D made it inexpensive, but not cheap.

In my experience Eneloop lasts the longest, and I hate changing batteries. They always take 6 to 8 hours to charge, so have extras. I use them for my garden drip emitter, flashlights, remotes, clock backups, wireless headphones, and bike light. Ongoing battery costs have dropped to zero.

This has been my watch forever. Usually I don't factor in price, but this slim and comfortable wrist watch is the greatest timekeeping bargain on earth when you factor in reliability, comfort, and yes, that low price.The band will wear out but is easy to replace.The alarm sound is weak and won't work for old ears.Mine drifts a minute off every three months or so. Phenomenal at the price. The battery may die. I'm not counting on outliving it.It will fail to impress the LaCroix owner in your social circle. You will have to live with that shame.

This lightweight light duty blower is perfect to fight back the daily encroachment of nature's windblown detritus invading my garage. The knurled speed setting nob need be no more than a "2" setting to send leaves scuttling down the path toward my neighbor's property. No earplugs required and it goes weeks for me before needing recharging. In wet weather, which lately in Northern Cal means a few hours every year, a more robust machine is needed, but for 95% of the time, using this is so easy.

I regard this watch as horological jewelry more than timepiece.  Recommended for vigorous young men with napoleon complexes attending  keggers. This monster watch weighs a third of a pound, is half an inch thick, and makes a statement without calling to mind the phallic compensation associated with sports cars. A swift backhand while wearing this Invicta will knock someone across the room.Encased in a big yellow box and  enthusiastically wrapped in plastic, paper, and cord against the rigors of international shipping, it takes time and dexterity to unwrap. Arrived ticking-- or humming, anyway.The battery is nonstandard but this just means send it to Invicta for a  $10 battery change plus shipping, or void the warranty by having the watch shop at the mall do the work, or even do it yourself once you open up the back and see what kind of battery it takes.Average wrist size of an American male is about 7.3 inches, with great variation. My left wrist is just that, about seven and a quarter inches. The Invicta comes sized for a 9 circumference wrist; too big for most, It is standard for metal bracelet watches to arrive sized large: It is easier to remove links to downsize than order extra links from Invicta. I had to remove 4 links, two to a side. This simple procedure will take a professional 4 minutes. It took me over an hour, but I am the un-handiest of handymen. Visit YouTube for instructions. After the resizing it fit perfectly. Further micro-adjustment can be made by moving the adjustment pin in the fold-over clasp.The watch felt absurdly heavy at first, but after 20 minutes I was completely used to it. The thickness means that the cuff of a long sleeve or dress shirt will hang up on the Invicta unless you use the widest button adjustment.I dont need to mention to actual divers that the Invicta Pro Diver watch is NOT an actual divers watch as per ISO 6425. It does not have a 2-way bezel, for one thing. and I find the silver numerals against the black background grayed out in dim light. White numerals would be better in the briny murk. The Roman numerals are raised, which is good, and the hands are white tipped- also good. The Crystal sits proud of the case but is slightly beveled which is a nice touch. The crown is protected by side projections and in any case feels solid when pulled out for adjustment. The crown pulls out easily and returns to seated position with a positive feeling. Adjustment is slightly loose-feeling but very smooth. I think that from a technical standpoint, this watch is a good value for the money.The Divers Watch description is not a problem. Scuba divers know what they need, and divers watch is acceptable shorthand for very water resistant and tough in the retail watch world. No need to be embarrassed if the guy next to you is wearing a G-Shock as long as you do not pretend youre a diver.A note on battery life: This watch ought to hold a fairly big battery; there is certainly the room for it. The batteries, even on analog watches, last a long time: a year, even several years. Mine last "forever" because I pull the stem out to stop the movement when they are going in a drawer for awhile. This reduces battery drain to almost nothing. This strategy requires a more elaborate reset every time if your watch has day/date, but for me that is easier than battery replacement.

Pros: Nice color, matched a comparison leg very realistically Application is more even with the included soft mittCons: Irregular staining due to rougher skin areas or insufficient feathering, even with the nice mitt Visual enhancement of roughened skin (see inset in photo) was dramatic  rough skin went from invisible-at-a-distance to a dark, ugly splotch A slight odor, which isnt horrible If applied everywhere it results in a sticky feeling in crooks of arms and legs for most of the first day Can stain clothing, although the stain was very light and only seen on white fabricI dont use self-tanners often for two reasons:1. There is not usually much of me to see, as my legs are encased in jeans 99.9% of the time, and I favor 3/4 length sleeves, even in summer.2. Splotchy application in the past made my legs look even worse than their usual pale selves.I am planning a tropical vacation soon, however, and decided it was time to try them again to try to lessen the blinding whiteness of my legs.The mousse came with an application mitt, which has a short nap on one side. I really like the mitt. It keeps the mousse off your hands, and I made  it much easier to smooth out and feather blend any edges. (The mitt, by the way, is almost too small for my husbands medium-sized hand, but fit my small hand, well, handily.)For the first application I applied the mousse to my entire body directly after a shower. I first applied a small amount of regular body lotion to areas that tend to darken too much, such as my knees, tops of feet, and elbows.My photo shows a comparison of my leg with my husbands slightly tanned leg for comparison. I was pretty pleased with the After, as it gave me just a bit of color and removed that pasty white look. The downsides, however, were a slightly sticky feeling for quite a few hours, and the dreaded non-uniform absorption of the color, especially on my legs. One knee soaked in a lot more, and my ankles, as carefully as I tried to blend in the mousse, still had irregular dark and light areas. I also have one small patch of rough skin that soaked up a LOT of color, and went from invisible to really noticeable.Since my main interest was my legs, I decided to apply a bit more mousse to my lower legs after just a few days, since shaving seems to lighten them. I tried applying it without the mitt and decided that I much prefer using the mitt, it just feels like Im not leaving steaks. But doing just one section of a leg (the lower part) is really hard, and so I ended up with even more splotchy marks around my ankles and knees, since feathering out the mousse is still pretty hard.I was pretty happy with the appearance of the rest of my body, especially my arms and upper legs. I think the mitt helps spread the mousse out more evenly. It might be helpful to know how many squirts to use for a given area  I am small and tended to use four squirts for each whole leg, and maybe 2-3 squirts for each whole arm.Overall, I think this product is pretty average compared to the other self-tanners Ive tried in the past as far as application and irregular absorption, but has a better, more natural color. The application issues are inherent in all self-tanners, and the biggest advantage of this product appeared to be the mitt.(Mrs. Js)--and Mr. Js' leg TMI

This is a feature, not a bug. I think maybe XEN-TAN has put a mix of skin dye and surface color into this lotion. The former gently and gradually darkens your skin with repeated applications and the latter can be wiped away if it is too much or blotched.I tried this to help balance the paleness of my neck to the more weathered appearance of my face. While I have a Xen-Tan mitt, I quickly decided that the fingers are the best applicator for the face. I liked how the instructions said to use a dime-sized amount, that was helpful.The material is fairly thick  definitely thicker than most lotions I apply. I wasnt sure whether it should be applied to my eyelids or not, but I went ahead and smoothed it over everything, trying to feather it carefully into my hairline and the front of my ears. Didnt want to end up with an abrupt line in such a visible location.The good news: I have very sensitive skin, and this product did not bother me. I never noticed an uneven appearance The color is very naturalThe weird surprise:I wash my face with a washcloth. I happened to wash my face 3 times in 24 hours after the first application, and was surprised to see a brownish residue on the washcloth, even after the third washing. Hence my thought that this lotion is not like the usual self-tanning lotions. However it works, it will definitely leave a residue on washcloths.

Not being a fan of peering at my garbage through transparent 9 mil plastic, I can yet  see the utility. I have in the past and frequently, wondered where my wallet went and have rooted around amidst coffee grounds and banana peels for absently-minded tossed items of value. Transparent garbage bags help in that regard.Otherwise, these are perfectly standard and sufficiently sturdy. They will easily fit in a bin as high as 22". The drawstring clinches tight and knots easily. Obviously sharp objects may tear the bag more easily than the thicker bags used for garden debris. That's OK; not designed for that.Recommended.

These are the version with no inline device controls.Get these for exercise, not the sound. They'll give you perceptible sound from 80Hz up to the limits of my hearing. Mid range is OK but smeary and somewhat harsh.Try all 3 earphone sizes. The proprietary tips fit securely and change easily.  I usually take a small in my left ear and medium in my right, but for some reason, the large size gave the best fit. I am a fan of tight seal earbuds but those make many people uncomfortable. The SoundSports stayed securely in my ears and are light and comfortable. They are well constructed.The Bose earpieces rest against and not inside the ear canal opening. The advantage is that if you want to hear your environment, like that car coming up behind you when you are running, these will allow that. The disadvantage is less volume and less bass, not that these have much. Efficiency is medium. There should be no problem producing enough volume in all but the noisiest of environments; for those, switch to earbuds that make a tight seal.Music is important to me, and many other in-ears sound more pleasant.
No comment on healthiness, just that I find it slightly different from Hellmans/Best Foods but just as good.
My hands are medium and the gloves took 4 minutes to put on. Perhaps order one size larger? They did not do me much good as far as forward thrust is concerned. They seemed sturdy.

12" is a very handy size for a charging/sync cable. So often I deal with extraneous cable length; more than I need, and enough to get in the way.The title says it: a well built cable that also happens to be kind of pretty. I know that isn't a practical feature, but esthetics were in play here; almost a piece of jewelry.

I have that kind of curly hair that isnt beautifully curly, its annoyingly curly. And frizzy and dry looking, even when its not dry. When I see reduce frizz Im mostly looking for something to turn my hair into model-worthy locks of which I can be proud. Yeah, well, maybe thats not quite possible.I found this product to help in making my hair look shiny. Compared to my current favorite, Dove  Hair Therapy, it creates more separation of individual curly strands, as well as more volume. It seems to be  about as effective at de-frizzing as most products Ive tried.I tend to use more of it and it does not detangle hair as much as the Dove Hair Therapy. Tres Semme has more of a squeaky feel than smoothing, which Im not sure if I like more or less. Its just different, I think.It has a pleasant scent, and I would probably buy more.(Mrs. Js)

This Belkin flat cable from a 2.1A charger to my iPad2 from  from 10% to full charge in 193 minutes. An OEM cable took 213 minutes. 9% slower.This Belkin cable is cheaper.This Belkin cable tangles less.This Belkin cable is more sturdily built.This Belkin cable is less expensive and slightly longer.Syncs fine (so far).Apple products are more expensive and better built? Not their cables.

Four signs this bing cherry and almond bar is a winner.1- I wanted another right away.2- Mrs. Js says it's too good to be healthy.3- Bing cherries and dry/roasted almonds are the second and third ingredient in order of amount. I presume "soy protein isolate" is edible glue to hold the good stuff.4- I had a yen for coffee as I ate this Perfectly Simple bar, which is a sign that my tummy thinks the Perfectly Simple Bar is a pastry.Some reviewers mention a chocolate taste. I could not taste chocolate, even though there is cocoa butter listed as the 10th ingredient  on the list. I regard nutrition bars as fuel utilitarian, doesn't matter what they taste like. Not these! Hope they stay in business 'cause I'm buying more.A bit high in fat and sugars, but also high in carbs, at 17 grams, which is good. Also low in salt and gluten free, if you care.Not just for day hikes; this could be dessert. Despite the reservations of a leading consumer magazine, this is the bar for me.This crunchy, sweet bar looks like a bunch of whole almonds and dried cherries held together by brown gunk and it tastes good, especially if slightly warmed.

Put tissue in pouches, put pouches under rocks in a big bucket of water. 6 hours later, dry as a bone. The real test will be wearing ta pouch with the attached waist strap and moving around in the Pacific. Will update in late September after returning from Kauai.If one press-and-seal barrier is good, 3 is even better. Each ridge snaps into the "lips" with an audible and positive snap. a final fold of velcro presumably reduces any lateral flexing. The material is very thick.So: see you in September, with an update about protecting items more valuable than tissue.Update: iPhone, wallet totally dry after 90 minutes in roiling Poipu surf.

Put tissue paper inside and sunk it under 1 foot of water for six hours. Came out dry as a bone.You can  work the phone through the plastic. I am a very clumsy texter but it was just as easy to hit the little letters through the plastic. Calls were easy to make, selecting from contacts or through Siri. The sound was perfectly clear if I held it up to my ear or on speaker. Facetime worked just fine with a clear image sent to the other party.No problem holding an iPhone 5 or 6. Outer colored edges glow in the dark for quite some time. So useful during eclipses.The little  barrels with their tabs  provide a positive lock and are  easy to manipulate. This product is amazing in its simplicity and effectiveness.

Compared to my 20 year-old Nippon Sanso thermos, this Stanley "classic"  quart thermos is one big bruiser. Maybe this translates to ruggedness? Let us hope so. It is not going to go in any backpacker's kit anyway, so who cares if it's big.Hot: Stanley thermos In a 75F room, 9-1/2 hours boiling water went from 212F to 168F. The Nippon (same volume) was at 172F. So Stanley is not bad at keeping things hot.Cold:  75F,  8 hrs. ice water went up from 33.5F to 43F. The Nippon temp. increased to 42F. Again, a virtual tie. Well done Stanley.Best for throwing in the the trunk next to the fishing gear on a cold day. On a hot day, I'd throw a few ice cubes in, or better yet, fill it with ice cubes and then pour in your drink a few minutes before drinking.

All in all, this is a light romantic read, and if you love Fools Gold, even after 18 books, youll love this one too. If, like me, you have read them all and are starting to feel as if most of the characters speak in the same voice  albeit a snarky, sassy, witty voice  you might find, as I do, that the series is getting a little stale.I like Susan Mallerys writing style. She keeps it upbeat and light, and is good about adding humor. If this were the first or fifth book of hers Id read, Id give it 4 or 5 stars. Shes always been an automatic buy for me.And  are there really so many people out there with trust issues, or who are afraid of love (or the possible pain that a broken relationship can cause)? Because they sure all ended up here. The romance in the Fools Gold series has become formulaic. I now prefer the authors womens fiction series, Blackberry Island and the new Mischief Bay, which are glimpses into the lives of several friends, and the emphasis is on the interrelationships, rather than the romance. Ive also enjoyed a few other authors who paint more believable, realistic characters, such as Penny Reid, Liza Palmer, Emily Giffin or JoJo Moyes.Personally, I love romances where the two main characters are attracted to and love each other from the outset, but circumstances (not fear) provides obstacles for them. If Susan Mallery were to put her excellent writing skills into a book where both protagonists were fighting *for* each other, that would be an amazing book.If youve never read one of the Fools Gold books before, no worries, each book is a standalone. But the background characters do repeat and its more fun to read in order. If you love Fools Gold and are looking forward to a new chapter, this book should be a satisfying return to a beloved, idealized small town.(Mrs. Js)

I have, when visiting, literally sneered at acquaintances who dared offer me their pathetic version of coffee. This was in my young and arrogant days when I thought that their tolerance was a measure of friendship. These days lifes lessons have humbled me; I value kindness more than coffee and admit that a hit of caffeine is what I need well before taste nirvana.That said, lets not poison ourselves. Drink as soon as you Grind as soon as you Roast. Practical considerations limit the number of times I  hit the mark and I count myself lucky if one cup in 5 is  perfect. I can think of a few situations where I would take this nifty little grinder on the road, but its real use for me is that one first cup in the morning.So enough with the barely relevant, here's my short take:Fill the little bin half full of beans and about 50 turns of the crank will give you 2 scoops of very fine grind. Back off on the knurled set-screw just a little and about 50 turns of the crank will give you 2 scoops of medium grind. Back off a little more and you get coarse grind. A small adjustment on the screw makes a big difference in the grind. Halfway up the view window will give you enough for one cup of coffee. If you fill up the whole grinding barrel you will get 3/4 cups. YMMVPros:-Your electric grinder will wake up the whole house in the morning. This grinder is stealthy quiet.-Light but well-built.-Intuitive operation (which is good because there are almost no instructions).-Compact and fairly easy to take apart.-No markings for gradation because they trust you to learn by an easy period of trial and error.-sturdy cleaning brush included.Cons:-Immersive cleaning will get water between the outer metal barrel and inner plastic window.-Practice your grinding technique so the nice big handle does not come off mid-grind.-Kind of messy.

We were excited to try out the Exolens for iPhone 6. We love the photos our iPhone takes, but sometimes it would be nice to get a closer or wider angle. We took it to San Francisco for a field test. Please see the test photos.Pros: It slides on and off the phone very nicely. It has a firm grip, but not too firm, and it feels very smooth and does not harm the phone. Workmanship is first rate. Tolerances are perfect. Threads work smoothly and the little lens caps fit perfectly. If you have an image where the lens barrel distortion doesnt matter, it does bring in the subject quite nicely. See the photos of the workmen sandblasting the bridge and the last picture of the flag. The wide angle is really, really wide-Includes a nice lens shade.Cons: It would be preferable if the lenses screwed onto a case, instead of a frame. Take your case off and leave it off for the duration of your photo shoot with the Exolens. We found it difficult to swap out lenses quickly. It was very helpful to have two people, one to hold, one to affix the different lens and juggle the caps. The curvature introduced in the 3x was surprising  see images of the Golden Gate Bridge when its not centered  it is not subtle! Most of the time, the images were fuzzier than those taken without the device. They look OK on a phone screen but anything bigger reveals the fuzziness and distortion. Cropping down unmodified images resulted in better quality than the one taken with the 3x. White circle artifact in the flag photo shows the lens shade is often really necessary, sometimes even if the sun is way off to the sideOverall, the inconvenience of having to carry a separate set of lenses, trying to affix them quickly, resulting in distorted, fuzzy, low quality images, means we would not use these except in very rare instances. If we have to carry something else, a compact camera with a range of zoom settings (these were often either too zoomed in or too far out) would make a lot more sense and take up no more room in pocket or purse.So:-Here is an unmodified photo of some bridge or other with the iPhone 6 lens.-Next photo is an Exolens telephoto of bridge workers. Since the interest is at the center of the picture, the distortion of the girders is noticeable but OK. There is fuzziness.-Wide angle was  distorted and fuzzy.-Lastly a couple of telephoto shots. Ouch! (By the way, fairly good center sharpness on the telephoto flag shot).Carry a point-and-shoot, use panorama, or just crop your image. "good enough considering" is not good enough.

Describing the elusive flavor of this sweet, strong syrup is difficult. I simply do not have the vocabulary. I find myself resorting to the "tastes like chicken" trope. In this case, I have to go with "tastes like butterscotch".  And it does until you taste it next to butterscotch and realize it is not quite that. And bear in mind this is syrup from the coconut palm, and ONLY that. No guar gum, no "artificial" flavor, no sodium hexametaphosphate, just coconut palm syrup.First use was the classic syrup employment of waffle sauce: go easy because the flavor is more intense than artificially flavored maple syrup; almost as strong as real class B maple syrup... I like maple syrup better but it would be an OK substitute if, for some weird reason, you were allergic to maple. Anything is possible; I'm allergic to beets.Next application was vanilla ice cream. Chameleon-like, this coconut palm syrup tastes really close to butterscotch, and you can drizzle a LOT less on top because of its strong flavor. A definite success.Next: spaghetti sauce. I could not detect any difference from using brown sugar. I think my next try will be as a glaze on sweet potatoes and grilled meats. I will update.Conclusion: I think chefs should experiment with this very interesting new ammo in their culinary arsenal.

I just love the ending of this story and I know all the explanations will never match our imaginations.As well written as always, this Baxter novel is a Big Story gulping up big swaths of time and space. There are AI's who may not be our friends. There are big political/military power blocs. There's space travel and murder and betrayal. Our hero, Yuri, has a Big Secret (which is... meh) and a nice rhythm to the pacing that never leaves you bored.Future society calls the 21st century  "The Heroic Years" is a fully ironic sense. Big projects, big waste, big harm to the planet. The development of new artificial intelligence is now banned. Big projects that waste energy are not tolerated. The only reason we contemplate colonizing  of Proxima Centauri  IV is that mysterious energy "Kernals" have been discovered on Mercury. We don't understand them, but we can use them to power a few great big colony vessels to Proxima as a kind of last-gasp  high-water mark of the Heroic Years.I am giving this book 5 stars even though the whole Colony Ship idea is such baloney. You don't stock such a vessel with criminals and misfits whose only positive quality need be "genetic diversity". One of them doesn't even know he IS on a ship!You also keep them in suspended animation, not wake them up years before arrival to consume supplies and cause trouble. So silly.  Let's make this amazing effort to reach another planet and them toss them out onto this planet with some power bars and basic tools.  Nonetheless, the characters are so entertaining and the story so good that I have forgiveness for a some nonsense.The hinting of a possible alternate reality is tasty and restrained. How Proxima IV REALLY gets colonized is great fun. The natives are imagination's flower. The rolling robot that follows some of our characters around the planet is our new Robby the Robot, a wonderful character.Occasionally some vast and hidden string-pulling intelligence whispers to life with suggestive, italicized thoughts about what really might be going on with the Kernals and the Hatch (no spoilers re the hatch).The Penultimate chapter... wow. No spoilers.The ending disappointed a lot of people. I think it's great if that were the end. The fact that so much is unexplained is, I think, a virtue, not a failing, and will be undone in the sequel with something I fear will be banal and derivative.

But an exciting series of chases. From the first sentence of the book we are catapulted (now there's a just jacket blurb verb) into the action. Our teenage heroine ends up blasted and shot at, soaked and punched and on the run with almost no resources, and those are just the first few pages. A typical American teenager of current fiction, Jenna is quick to begin resenting her father despite some extremely positive actions on his part to keep her little hind end intact. This theme continues throughout the book and becomes a bit tedious, as do the chases. Just the same, the action flows naturally and does not have the robotic clockwork formula feeling of a Dan Brown thriller. In fact, repeatedly Jenna's father grumps about the lack of realism in action movies and television shows. The author and I share the same pet peeves.Jenna's origins are the big mystery, and we get our answers doled out in small breaks from the action in the form of flashbacks and exposition. Can anybody be trusted? Why are various Federal agencies tripping over each other like Keystone Kops? In fact, not just tripping over each other but shooting up big and expensive installations in a hail of gunfire. There seems to be an amazing willingness to kill civilians and cops as well. Although young adult in form, this novel has plenty of gruesome death.On the plus side, the writing is clear, syntax lucid, and vocabulary and grammar all get a pass. This is no small thing these days when it seems anything can get published and good editors are scarce. The action shows a good grasp of physics. Nobody is surviving bomb blasts without a good reason nor flying cars off parking garage roofs into adjacent office buildings. On the other hand, people seem to heal up pretty darn fast from bullet wounds to little areas like, say, the thigh; up and about on crutches in hours.In the end, it all turns out to have Big Answers that lead to more Big Questions with "to be continued" stamped all over them. I believe the authors have this all planned out and when we get to the answers it may not have been worth it. I think I will wait on the reviews when the sequel comes out, because I am not waiting with bated breath.

Do not try to figure out the instructions before you check out this official Dyson video for a similar product on Youtube. the video exudes condescension, but  mutely shows you what you need to know.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Spo8itk_chYI wanted it, then I hated it, then I loved it, now I know its just OKI learned 3 lessons from trying out the Dyson Big Ball:1)  New and different isnt always better.2)  I vacuum too fast. Make slow passes.3) Cost correlates only loosely with quality.Nothing works like actual real-world testing to knock down you biases.I compared the Dyson to my trusty and well-rated Eureka Boss Upright.-The Dyson would be superior because it is so expensive.-The Dyson would be bad because the pictographic instructions were so really, really poor.-It would vacuum really well because marketing says so.Then came the test. I poured out 3 Tbsp's sand/ 2 Tbsp's salt onto a deep pile rug.The Dyson pulled up 95% with its first 6 passes, then a little more with 6 more slow passes.The Eureka pulled up 98% with  the same first passes, then a little more with 6 more passes. Photos below.I ran both vacs sideways along an outside wall edge littered with tiny birch seeds. The Eureka sucked in most of the seeds right up to the edge of the building; the Dyson got 40%The Dyson steers better once you learn to lean the machine as well as twist your wrist.Both machines take 3 moves to ready the wand for its attachments, The Dyson is much harder to re-seat.The crevice tool on the Eureka is better: slim and tapered. The Dysons is wider with a ridged snout: poor design.Far more tools on the Dyson. Some of them are unique and let your imagination be your guide as to how to use some of them. My imagination came up with zero ways. A very silly collection of tools that come with a separate poorly designed bag with a shoulder strap. The side pockets are too shallow and/or narrow to hold the tools. The central storage can easily hold all the tools in a jumble.Some good Dyson things:-though not as quiet as a Miele, it is 2 dB quieter than the Eureka. Not quiet, but quieter.Dyson has a nifty little turbo counter-rotating brush that resists tangling to use on pet hair. It worked wonderfully with a bunch of thread.  This brush is a great attachment; Kudos Dyson.Dyson has a transparent dust bin that shows you when to empty it. Emptying is really easy although a bit of a dusty job if you are not careful. There are NO filters to periodically replace. Good good good.The Eureka uses a dust bag that is easy to change-out and keep all the dust inside, but if you let it get too full you lose suction. Not good.The Dyson looks like some cool alien dropped it out of a UFO.Notes:-Unlike some reviewers, I had no trouble getting this vacuum to stand up straight.-The cord is of good quality: nice and long.-Vacuum slowly. Time and again I noted that fast passes leave lots of dirt. 2 slow passes beat  4 fast back-and-forths every time.-On the crevice tool push the button and pull back to expose the tip.-On the flex wand push the button and push forward.Conclusion: For a lot more money you get a cool-looking vacuum with no filters or bags to bother with that is almost as good as the Eureka Boss.

Tom Kratman is a better writer than the author of Mein Kampf (Godwin's law strikes again!) and with a whole lot more military acumen.  This is the guy we should have had in charge of our desert adventures over the last few years as long as we keep him away from the whole "intelligently applied"  torture thing, which he describes in hand-rubbing detail. A somewhat enthusiastic dude as far as detailed description of the deplorable  sexual practices of the "progressive" (liberal) enemy-- but hey, I'm calling the kettle black.Seriously, I want this man heading the DOD. If we are going to do war, do war right.

Updated and uprated. We are through much of the summer now and no more poor birdies getting conked.From the photo (bottom right) of this particular window you can see why the poor birds  experience startling stops midair a couple of times a month in the Spring and Summer when the lighting is just wrong, We jump in our chairs to hear the hearty THUMP. Another bird has seen open space where there was none and we look down to see if this one will pick itself up, brush off its feathers and fly away-- or twitch a time or two and die. Anthropomorphization aside, we dont like the alarming noise nor bonked birds bamboozled by our clean windows.Will these work? An arbitrary 4 stars for now to be upgraded if we get through the season without more birdy head-banging and a big down-grade if they fail....and success.The Birds Eye View window film looks good. Im not a fan of faux stained glass film nor little stick-on flowers. These are more subtle and elegant. Thumbs up on the aesthetics.3 methods alert the birds:-UV light reflection, which most birds see better than us.-Dichroic glass effects which shift the color on the surface. I don't think this will work for us because this is a north-facing window-Textured pattern simply shows the bird that something solid is there.It was very easy to apply. Peel the film from its backing and stick it on a wet window. Slide it just where you want it. Press out any bubbles, of which we had none. You're done with all 4 pieces in minutes unless you are OCD about alignment.We live in hope.

A grudging 4 stars. SO many factors to consider. Too bad you can't take a vacuum cleaner for a long test-clean.I compared the well-reviewed Eureka Boss against the Hoover Commercial Windtunnel.  Short take: Eureka is somewhat better for me. But it is more complicated than that. Here are some of the factors to consider:Performance on a deep pile rug: Eureka wins. without telling my wife, I poured 1 Tbsp sand, 1 Tbsp salt, 1 Tbsp flour on our rug (see photo below) and made three slow back and forth passes with each machine. Then I ruthlessly cut open the bags and measured the take. The Eureka sucked up 2 ozs. and the Hoover was 1.9 oz. (see cup o' dirt photo below). That is pretty much a tie.Cord length: Hoover wins by 10 feet BUT the cord is somewhat fat and awkward.Noise: A tie.  84 dB on my sound meter BUT the Eureka is a hushed roar while the Hoover Windtunnel is a banshee shriek. It is very wearing.Stairs: Hoover is the clear winner. It is 2 lbs. lighter and has a smaller width that is easier to maneuver. BUT a narrower track means more passes.Attachments: A tie. Hoover tools snap in tighter than Eureka's BUT remember to point the upholstery brush down in its clip so you can wind the cord.Bags: A tie. Both are easy to change although i find the Hoover Windtunnel bag door finicky to open and close.Floor illumination: Hoover wins. It is not that bright but a lot better than the pathetic Eureka light.Getting under furniture: A tie. They can both get in 12" if the furniture has an eight inch lip. Neither will equal a canister with power brush.Power switch: Eureka wins. It has a bigger, easier to reach switch that is not recessed. Both would be better if the switch were on the handle.Floor maneuverability: Hoover wins. This is a big one if you have a lot of floor to do. The Hoover Commercial Windtunnel is a bit easier to push around and turn... and a "bit easier" starts to mean a lot if you really are doing commercial-sized work, like a floor of offices. It was not a factor for me with just one floor of rug to vacuum.So personally I like the Eureka because it is subjectively quieter, is slightly more powerful, and has a slightly wider track which works for me because I don't need to get it into narrow spaces. I can describe the differences but can't call a winner for you.

Tough little tool for chopping at and levering out roots.  Also good for breaking up dry soil to help  dig an irrigation trench. If you can't pre-moisten hard soil this is almost as good. Save your back and don't raise the Mattock too high.

I use for repair of cracks and pinholes on schedule 40 and 80 pvc irrigation pipe. We have very high water pressure where we live, and these have never failed me. Make sure the pipe is straight, then prime, use plenty of glue, and use a quarter twist once it snaps into place. Sometimes I have to use a pliers to get the two pieces to snap together. As long as you "work fast slowly" you have plenty of time before the solvent sets.I have also used these to join two pieces of pipe in tight spaces where I can't use a coupler. After I wait an hour (to be conservative) I turn on the water and things are dry and tight. Just as easy and often cheaper than a slip coupling.

WellA couple of quick thoughts. First: raised a Catholic, I realize for complexity, tradition, guilt-- we are amateurs compared to the Hassidic Jews. Wow.  Second: I took this not as a story about a branch of Judaism so much as a story of religion in general, of Humanity, spirituality, of what we seek, what we need or think we need; a universal story.I set this book down feeling as if I had walked blinking out of some intense movie that engulfed and distracted me from everyday life.. So yes, good story. I did not realize it was a memoire at first. I thought it was fiction, not because of any lack of credibility but because it seemed so fantastic. Don R. suggested that if I wanted to read a real time-travel story, I might try this one. It seems more like another world, parallel to the one I know.I loved the look at a branch of Judaism so insulated and protected that indeed, English is truly a second language. Vending machines are an attractive and dangerous novelty, and radios are regarded as a dangerous window into a world of temptation (as indeed they are). As well as the radio, television and the internet are the apple in this Eden. Ah, the internet: blogs, community, social networks-- people who have the same crazy thoughts you do.Deen knows how to write, and how to structure. The story starts with his expulsion. He is being kicked out of the Skeverers. How did it come to this? How did it all start? So begins his story, moving back and forth between diligent Talmudic scholar, disinterested youth, ecstatically transported True Believer, and the big mess he got into by asking questions, questions that were not the allowed questions, the claustrophobically naval gazing minutiae just as well as the profound philosophical stuff, but the dangerous questions.Do I come away from this viewing the Skeverers negatively. Why yes, yes I do. Religion in general, I believe, starts out with good stories to make children and then adults behave. Dont steal, dont murder, dont hate. Be part of a social and cooperative entity for your good and the good of all. But in no time at all, if being a part of your religion is very good, then NOT being a part of it must be bad for you then bad for everyone, then a sin and then a crime. Fortunately for Shulem Deen, his sect is something of a hot house flower, without great secular power and poor indeed-- in fact surviving somewhat on the the welfare and the good wishes and tolerance of others.  They could onlySPOILER--only punish him by denying him his children. But to do that shows what might be done if there were more power in their hands, say the power of the Catholic church when it burned heretics, Islam with its murtad fitri punishments for the fallen away.And yet, Shulem Deen does not sugar coat his lack of belief. He is not happy with the loss, with the hollowness in place of the early ecstasy, with the empty feeling he has. I think this is a very brave story.Give this book time to unfold. It is not a happy story; not a sad story. It is a life story and it ends with more questions.

Top thing I love about this case is that it offers real protection but still leaves the retina screen uncovered. My peeve is that fingerprint password function is somewhat compromised, sometimes taking three tries and the volume buttons are hard to use.Quick conclusion: I will use this case with confidence on the road, and pry it off to enjoy the  naked iPad at home.I tried a case for my original iPad 2 and gave it up. It was very good but just too bulky and clumsy. This case is much better. My old iPad, while perfectly functional, and with a flawless screen, looks scratched and beat up from the backside. That is why I want this iPad Air2 to live in a case. This is somewhat paradoxical, like covering your furniture with plastic so someone else can enjoy it after you put up with the vinyl. OTOH, this thing cost a bundle and I do NOT want to break it.Push down HARD with both thumbs all along the edges to snap the case closed. I was irritated until I realized the very tight fit and exacting tolerance of manufacture are what  keeps water out and still allows this case to be relatively slim.Included with the Lifeproof Nuud is a  stand-in for your iPad: a blue plastic blank in the shape of the iPad. Use it to see if  the case is good and to practice the closure procedure, try  first with this plastic stand-in. I put some tissue paper inside as well, and immersed it in about 8 inches of water. An hour later, that tissue was dry. While the specs say you're safe to 6', which my iPad will never see if I am careful, mere rain will certainly not be a worry. Lifeproof claims good drop protection too. If I am unlucky that test will be performed unintentionally sometime in the future  and I will update... But I am pretty careful.-It is surprising how good the sound quality is with the speakers blocked by thin plastic diaphragms. High frequencies and volume are somewhat compromised.-Enter your fingerprints BEFORE closing the case. The sensor area is reduced once the case is on. My fat thumb still worked but I added my litle finger because it fits better in the newly circumscribed sensor area and should lead to quicker recognition.-The weight of the iPad Air2 with this case feels about the same as my original iPad2 with no case but with the folding cover.-If you have a folding cover, put it back in the box. It won't work.-Despite its slimness you have lost the amazingly svelte original form factor.No one will know that you have a cool new iPad Air 2 once this black, anonymous case is on. What do you want, to impress people, or protect your costly purchase?I love that while this case is highly water resistant, it still leaves the screen exposed. There is no compromise of your retina screen resolution or touch sensitivity.A negative that will reduce star rating for you if photography with your iPad is important: I believe the extra layer of plastic over the lens reduces clarity and slows focus. Incidentally, there seem to be a bunch of people in the media who think using your iPad for photography is bad. I find their reasons weak or irrationally concerned with what others may think of you. Do what you want.There is a flap that covers the ear bud port. I often use ear buds when surfing the internet sitting on the sofa next to my wife so she won't have to listen to cats meowing. There is a adapter you can use that retains waterproofing. I am not going to use it because I think I will lose it and I only use the ear buds indoors, where it does not often rain.A little orange tool is provided to help you remove the case. I gave up and used a quarter coin held with a pliers. THAT is how tough this case holds together and how hard it is to get off. Forget doing it by hand.
A tiny flimsy thing good enough for touch-ups. Easy to clean.

Since we went with a 3 star rating, lets mention the positives first:Set up was smooth.Great operation interface.The double-sided printing worked really well.The auto document feeder worked well.Its been pretty easy to use so far.Ink cartridge installation is so easy.Speedy printing when set at low quality for in-house use.All very good However:The printing quality in general is not what we consider acceptable to hand out to customers or clients. Skip down to PRINT QUALITY for that assessment.We wanted to like this printer. Its got all sorts of features that we could use  printing on 11x17, double-sided printing, fax, scanning, and more. But this printer is presented as a high-volume alternative for small businesses. They also say spend less for more pages. Maybe they achieve that by using a tiny amount of ink compared to other printers. While the printer itself is pleasing to use so far, with an excellent on-screen interface and speedy delivery of regular print jobs of low quality, everything Ive printed is dull and lifeless in comparison to our HP Photosmart 7525 or our old Brother MFX laser fax/scanner/printer.SETUP AND INSTALLATIONAlthough set up went pretty smoothly, although there were several things that were a bit tricky to figure out:-Loading the paper: to adjust the paper guides, press the little tab on the right green vertical slider.manual feed sheets need to be set printing side up (which matters with photo paper).-Pulling out the paper support after loading the paper: the illustration makes it look like you pull from the sides, but you actually just pull out the 2 wide section in the middle.-Closing the lid for the phone cord access  turns out you just press it down, gently. It resists at first, and we kept looking for a latch to press to release, but no, just press.-I really liked the inkjet cartridge installation  the green lever one must swivel to remove the orange seal on the cartridge is so much easier than our HP printer cartridge. And we liked how easy it was to tell when they were fully seated  the tab just pops up. Not much of a clicking sound, but it was still very easy.The driver installed easily on our Mac computer, and setting it up as a wireless printer went very smoothly, despite our not having a USB cable long enough to reach from the computer to the printer.When the printer initializes the first time, it takes about 5 minutes, then another few minutes where you have to follow the onscreen instructions. One of the steps is to set up the paper trays. Note that you need to designate the TYPE of paper (inkjet, regular, photo) as well as the size, because if you choose inkjet paper on the printer and the paper tray is designated regular, the printer wont print. But it walks you through correcting the problem very quickly.PRINT QUALITYSee our photos for several tests we did, comparing this printer to our HP Photosmart 7525. Obviously the HP is going to do well with the photos, but it was sad to see how much better it does. And when both printers were set to best photo quality, with the appropriate glossy paper settings, the HP printed a beautiful, color correct copy in 2 min 30 sec, while this printer took 6 min 10 sec to print a faded copy.Even a standard sheet of black and white text looks faded next to our HP printer, and even more so compared to a laser printer.On the plus side, there was some yelling at the HP printer over its refusal to print because the paper size is not set correctly, and while the Brother experience was not perfect, the machines really great interface on the front panel pointed out what we were doing wrong and allowed us to change settings, resulting in far less frustration. For photos, the easiest thing is to take them down to the one-hour photo at Costco!When the printer initializes the first time, it takes about 5 minutes, then another few minutes where you have to follow the onscreen instructions. One of the steps is to set up the paper trays. Note that you need to designate the TYPE of paper (inkjet, regular, photo) as well as the size, because if you choose inkjet paper on the printer and the paper tray is designated regular, the printer wont print. But it walks you through correcting the problem very quickly.We have not yet had a chance to try out other bells and whistles, of which there are many: fax machine (we do need this so we hope it works well), scanner, printing from mobile devices, printing on an 11x17 sheet, etc. Well update as we learn more.Update July 2015: It's stunningly slow sometimes. The fax works fine.

Weird Christmas gift accepted with graceful skepticism makes me shiver with delight when wife s-l-o-w-l-y lowers it straight onto my cranium for about 5 reciprocating osculations.Cat does not like it.

First off, the Thera Breath Plus matte silver bottle with its orange safety seal looks like some kind of scary bio-war canister: serious, like it means business. Thats good marketing! I like it.3 stars because the formulators of this mouthwash try so hard to make it natural and non-alcoholic. I imagine that it might do a mighty job of suppressing or banishing odors of oral origin.  Mouthwash works in the mouth and throat, and cant touch what is going on in the stomach. Vapors emitted from deeper in the alimentary tract issue forth through the throat and mouth, but only as a miasma decorated with a minty bow, noxious nonetheless.French Onion Soup:It is my bane. I am possessed  with fairly neutral breath, even in the morning, but delicious french onion soup or similar onion-based soups  transform me into an oral toxic broadcaster  for hours. The scary thing is I dont even know it! My wife certainly does. She has requested that I mosey on down the hall and use the guest room for the night.So it was easy to test Thera Breath Maximumand here is how it went:Had the DELICIOUS but usually forbidden french onion soup. An hour later:  breath horrible. After brushing with toothpaste and Sonicare: breath minty and horrible.After rinsing with warm water and baking soda: breath less minty and horrible.  *  *  *  *Thera Breath Plus:A little more minty and slightly less horrible but still horrible.Instructions call for a minute of swishing around the mouth. Thats a long time and I usually cheat but Im being good here and trying to get the full benefit. Then 30 seconds of gargling with a fresh dose. Again, a long time, took about 5 breaths, but I did it.It stings. Not as bad as Listerine or some of the other alcohol-based nostrums, Still, I was tempted to rinse lightly with water a minute afterwards to get the sting out. I refrained and it was OK in another minute.  Even after that I could still feel the potion doing something... good or bad. Again, may be good for mouth-origin bad breath.

Update after 2 months of daily use. Still perfect unlike my Monoprice cable.The Apple-provided 36" cable is too short to let me do what this one does: perch my iPad on my belly in bed and read while still providing good the tablet's nightly dose of electricity. And Apple hasn't figured out a way to reject this cable with some "unauthorized equipment" nonsense... yet.

These would actually look sleek when paired with a metallic-finish rod and a shower curtain with large blocks of the same color... maybe best with a dark color.I am using them with my patterned curtain. They clash, but I don't care because they don't snag. My pretty decorative hangers were the hook type, and always catching on the little bump at the midpoint where the two pieces of this spring-loaded rod intermesh. These roller hangers slip right over with nary a bump nor snag.A point off because the skinny bottom of the hanger in time will wear through any curtain that does not have grommeted holes.. There should be a flange.

Update: It is bee season now. It seems because the flowers angle outward instead of facing up allows more of the nectar to remain accessible to the bees. They are now making regular visits. Admittedly, this is not stopping the bummers, but I have to be careful not to bring bees in the house when I refill the feeder. So I'm downrating.Yow! When I pulled this Perky-Pet double decker from its plastic cocoon, though e flowers were so big! They looked kitschy. But fear not: once out in the backyard 'midst the real blooms they compete with, they fit right in. The HBirds won't miss these babies.Not that the Hbirds appreciate the extra feeding stations. As usual, they spend half their energy in a "mine, not yours'" territorial dogfighting aerial gavotte. Well, I suppose Nature knows best and this is a winning strategy. Sticking up a post-it note reading "chill out" is completely ineffective.However, the double-decker easily separates. Hang one around the corner and the beta birds have their chance, while that big (Relatively speaking) redheaded bully of an alpha bird exhausts himself trying to cover two bases; serves him right.Pros:-prettier than you would think.-does not leak for once, YMMV.-easy to separate parts for cleaning.-the upper and lower units detach and reattach easily and securely.-plastic construction is light and unlikely to break.Cons:-plastic construction is also a con for some; glass feeders are more elegant.-the smaller top unit is a little fiddley to close and seal securely.-the plastic tanks are slightly cloudy instead of clear as glass. But this did not bother me.

Early update on June 10th just a month later: better than soapy water; brought one of our succulents back from the dead, killing off some black nastiness fast. Arbitrarily rating this product at 4 stars, I will update once a month, as I see how it copes with a ground cover plant regularly attacked  by a stubborn infestation. A sprayed solution of mild soap has been fairly successful and now this neem oil solution will take over the duty.A note on toxicity: Ortho faithfull fulfills all regulations reporting on the possible problems with this stuff. Like TV drug ads, the list of problems and cautions is considerable but in researching neem oil and Pyrethrins found them to be on the namby-pamby end of the Spectrum of Scary. But be careful on a windy day not to kill bees.

Firstly, how can Command Wall Hanging Systems Market these kits? You cant really understand how cool they are until you get them in your hands. I recommend J-J-J-Jinx video review posted on 4/27/15, and also some of the reviews with photos. This system can really class up the joint with very little work. These 3-dimensional display boxes really pop, and project a pro-decorator aura at a really low price. So: mucho aesthetic bang for the buck.The kit we were provided with to review came with 3 tiles, one riser and 4 strips packaged together. The corners of each art tile were protected by thick cardboard. There is one extra strip in case you make a mistake. There are individual levels on each base", so you can easily make sure its straight before pressing down to affix the strip to the wall. All in all a well-thought-out system to make it super easy to spiff up a wall.My only nits are these: - It says to wipe the wall with rubbing alcohol. Theyve done such a great job of making it so easy, but there were no alcohol pads. That seems like an easy add to really ensure these successfully adhere to the wall. - The plastic transparency over the photo is anti-glare so the photo is not seen quite as clearly as it would be through glass. Also, if you stand close, the slightest raggedness at the outboard edges of the box tend to look white against the black background, which looks a bit cheap.Here are a few tips:1. Read the instructions and look at the individual pieces and understand how the system works before you install. Although the system is pretty forgiving, so even if you dont, you wont get in too much trouble.2. When cleaning the wall with rubbing alcohol, mark where youve cleaned it, so you dont lose track once its dry.3. When they say to affix the base to the wall, dont affix the riser if you have one. The base has a level, the risers dont.I love the risers, I really like overlapped look. The magnets are way cool, I love how easy it is to pop the artwork off to change it out, and . alignment is automatically perfect  If youre creative, once you have the base system installed it seems like it would be easy to customize these.-Mrs. Js... mostly

I read Thrillers and SciFi. I like spies and murders and aliens. This is literature. While I say "literature", what I usually mean is "painful". But "Lifted by the Great Nothing" was not a slog. Although the story is as serious as life can be serious, it is not mired in dour pessimism and understands that life is always not so serious, sometimes even when it is.Young Max is being raised by his single parent, his strange father whom Max wants to make happy. In a rapid arc, Max is a child, a boy, a young man who would have been better served by honesty than the bodyguard of lies cosseting him. By the end of his 17th year he finds out all. It is a mad story but a very human one. I found his life fantastic yet utterly believable.Karim Dimechkie is a fine writer with a good ear. There are no blunders that take you out of the narrative. The story flows organically and is an easy read, even when things get painful for our characters.
